HEADLINE: The Baron Of the Bronx -- Second of two articles.;
In an Antipoverty Empire, A Clinic Is an Opportunity

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB with DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Despite its fresh coat of paint, the large forest-green medical clinic at Westchester and Metcalf Avenues in the Soundview section of the Bronx echoes the blandness of its surroundings -- a row of private homes, some elevated train tracks, an empty supermarket.
 On Monday mornings, when it is busiest, the clinic seems unremarkable, its large sitting area half-filled with dozens of people willing to wait hours rather than deal with Medicaid mills or hospital emergency rooms. 
But behind this scene is a tempestuous and complicated story. In part, it is a story of how, for years, a neighborhood was deprived of access to decent medical care. But it is also a story of the ubiquitous influence of a man who, for a quarter-century, has been the antipoverty lord of the South Bronx, Ramon S. Velez.
 
An Ambitious Project
 The building at 1675 Westchester Avenue once housed a Federally financed model clinic, the Massive East Bronx Comprehensive Health Center. The ambitiously named project was born of the dire need for medical care in one of the most underserved areas of New York City.
 In the mid-80's, though, the clinic was taken over by a faction friendly to Mr. Velez. And over the next several years, according to audits and Government reports, management and medical care deteriorated to the point of bankruptcy.
 A board meeting was disrupted by threats of violence; money was mishandled, and the clinic's original staff of idealistic young doctors were replaced by a largely part-time crew that included one physician who no longer had a license. The Federal Government canceled hundreds of thousands of dollars in support, and the state followed suit. By the time Massive closed in 1991, its consulting accountant reported, it was borrowing money from a "street banker" in a doomed effort to pay its bills.
 
Expanding an EmpireA
 It was another setback for the South Bronx, but not for Mr. Velez, who saw an opportunity to expand his empire. Last year, his largest nonprofit organization bought Massive's building and started the new private clinic that subsists largely on Medicaid reimbursements.
 Mr. Velez and his allies say Massive's troubles can be traced to dissident board members and earlier financial problems. "I had no control over Massive," Mr. Velez said in an interview. "If so, it would be an institution today."
In fact, Mr. Velez served as a consultant and interim director, and for long periods his associates were in charge. Their role in Massive's sad history tells a lot about the way they have built their larger empire, which for many is the quintessential political machine fashioned with antipoverty money.
 At Massive and elsewhere, free of many of the contracting and hiring rules that apply to government agencies, Mr. Velez and his allies have long worked the interplay of antipoverty programs and politics to their advantage. They have taken control of turf and government dollars and used them at least as much to sustain their political organization and private enterprises as to help the South Bronx. In the process, Mr. Velez has become a millionaire.
 
Programs Help Thousands
 With an annual budget of more than $30 million, including operations run by relatives and associates, the Velez empire sprawls from the health clinics, substance-abuse programs and other social services dispensed through Mr. Velez's flagship Hunts Point Multi-Service Center, to the 56 government-subsidized apartment buildings developed or managed by the South Bronx Community Management Corporation headed by his son, Ramon Velez Jr.
 Many of these programs provide thousands of people with needed social services. Some have been highly rated. But many have been investigated and, at one time or another, denied funds because of poor management, questionable finances and poor service.
 Mr. Velez, who is 60 years old, boasts not only of helping some of New York's poorest residents but also of building "institutions" throughout the South Bronx. He dismisses the criticisms as old or politically motivated, and points out that none of the investigations have led to indictments.
 "I've been able to advance not because anyone in particular gave it to me," he said, "but I fought hard to get something with the people and for the people."
 
A Clinic Is Born
A New Building, A Committed Staff
 The initial $1 million in grants for Massive were arranged during the last days of the Carter Administration, recalled Mr. Velez, who said he traveled to Washington to help secure the funds. The idea was that poor neighborhoods suffered not only from a shortage of doctors -- at the time, only eight practiced within several miles of the proposed clinic -- but also from a lack of preventive care. By providing that care, residents would be less dependent on emergency-room treatment when they got sick.
 The clinic was to be staffed largely by members of the National Health Service Corps, who serve in exchange for Government medical scholarships. The half-dozen doctors assigned to the center would provide preventive care for a projected 35,000 patient visits a year.
 By most accounts, the first years, 1981 and 1982, were successful in reaching a growing number of people. Visiting on a job interview in late 1982, Dr. Nicholas Fiebach, an internist about to enter the health service corps, recalled a spanking new building with a committed staff. "It seemed like a wonderful little neighborhood center," he recalled.
 
The Battles Begin
 But fault lines emerged. In early audits, the center's accountants warned of discrepancies between what patients paid and the amounts deposited in the bank, of inadequate inventory controls and of vendors paid without authorization or documentation.
 Ethnic and political battles on the center's board of directors, on which Velez-related forces were a minority, began to percolate. At the same time, the potential value of controlling the center was becoming evident: under the terms of its lease, Massive's building -- fertile ground for a neighborhood power base -- could be bought for $300,000, or $1 million less than its appraised value. Also, there was hope that the center would attract millions in government funds for other health services, like home care.
 In May of 1983, according to five people involved with the center, as many as 15 men barged into a board meeting where a new executive director was about to be named. According to these accounts, they harassed the interim director and the prospective new director with taunts and threats until the meeting ended in disarray.
"That was a real nightmare," recalled Bertrand Simmons, a longtime board member who still recalls the fear that night. "There were threats, intimidation," he said of the intruders, who were "coming in to force themselves on the board."
 The acting executive director and 10 board members resigned, and the prospective director never returned. The health service corps doctors walked out, forcing the center to close for three weeks.
 
A New Administration
 Mr. Velez denies involvement with the meeting, though four people associated with the center say the intruders were his allies. His presence, though, along with that of his associates, was soon in evidence. According to notes taken by a health service corps worker, the Federal Public Health Service held a meeting at the center on June 7, instructing the staff to return the following Monday. Present, along with the new acting administrators and a handful of board members, was Mr. Velez.
 Within a year, he was listed on documents and letters as a consultant to the board. Within a few years, one of his daughters was working at the center as an $18,000-a-year health educator. One of his allies, Gumersindo Martinez, now the supervisor of a methadone clinic run by the Hunts Point Multi-Service Center, became co-chairman. And Antonio Nin, a man from Mr. Velez's hometown, Hormigueros, P.R., who Mr. Velez said was like a brother to him, became executive director, even though the Public Health Service first rejected his appointment, citing a lack of appropriate credentials.
 Mr. Nin, who said he got the job by answering a newspaper advertisement, said the dispute arose because he had a master's degree in clinical psychology, rather than in health administration. He said he had years of experience as administrator of a health clinic -- the one operated by Mr. Velez's Hunts Point Multi-Service Center.
 The Public Health Service remained dubious, but it acceeded to Mr. Nin's hiring at the behest of Massive's new board. However, the health service became concerned that Mr. Velez might be exerting undue influence over the board. Bernard Passer, who headed the service's Division of Health Service Delivery, made a point of speaking with Mr. Velez.
 "He knew Nin, and what we did was put two and two together," Mr. Passer said. "He admitted that he was interested in the project and overseeing that everything went right." Mr. Passer said he emphasized to Mr. Velez that the board had to remain independent.
 
Ambitious Initiatives
 Massive's new administration attempted ambitious initiatives. Within a year, it won a lucrative city home care contract and had begun to contemplate buying the building.
 Neither enterprise worked out. In late 1985, the city canceled the $2.4 million home care contract, which provided roughly 250 jobs. In a review of Massive's operation, the city found significant deficiencies in five of eight areas. And thoughts of buying the building -- even though it would have to the economic advantage of the center -- went nowhere as its deficit ballooned to nearly $250,000 from $3,968 a year earlier.
 "I never met anyone in my life that was so disorganized at managing property and the business," said the center's landlord, Myron Exelbert, after years of fruitless talks about a possible sale. "These people lived in dreams."
 He added that people involved with the center were trying to buy the building for themselves at the same time. "It was clear there were people there more interested in making money than serving the community," Mr. Exelbert said.
 Meanwhile, Massive stopped using an established medical data-processing company and replaced it with Bronx Computing Systems and Service. The company is owned by a profit-making subsidiary of South Bronx Community Management, which is run by Ramon Velez Jr. Bronx Computing collected more than $70,000 for its work for Massive.
 
A Company That 'Ramon Wanted'
 Massive's consulting accountant, Sunil Mukhopadhyay, said he had begun to solicit bids on the data-processing contract, but that Mr. Nin told him, "Ramon wanted a company to come in." As for the quality of Bronx Computing's services, the accountant said: "They didn't give any service. They just processed. I could do that on my P.C."
 Mr. Velez says he doesn't remember if he recommended Bronx Computing.
 "And if I recommended," he said, "there is nothing wrong with it. All the computer companies were from the outside and they were overcharging us."
 A State Health Department report found that it was Bronx Computing that was doing the overcharging -- billing at two-and-a-half times the going rate. As for service, the Health Department reported thousands of dollars in late billing had severely hurt the center's cash flow.
 Mr. Simmons, the longtime board member, said that despite repeated requests, the board was never shown financial documents involving Bronx Computing. Mr. Velez's relationship with the company is the subject of inquiries by the State Health Department and the City Comptroller. Both are trying to determine if Mr. Velez has a financial interest in the company that he should have revealed. Mr. Velez denies having such an interest.
 
The Breakdown Begins
'An Unacceptable Level of Service'
 For many on Massive's board, the failure of the home care operation and the hiring of Bronx Computing were simply too much.
 Dissident board members sued, alleging that Mr. Velez and his allies on the board were manipulating Massive for their own ends. The suit sputtered and eventually died. Many of the health service corps doctors began to look for other postings. They were replaced by whatever help the center could find, much of it part-time, and so less able to provide the ongoing preventive care that had been the center's reason for being.
 In an interview, Mr. Nin maintained that he brought financial stability to the center and increased patient visits from 18,000 a year to 45,000. He also accused the young doctors of not working hard -- a charge several called insulting and laughable.
 Government records also contradict Mr. Nin. The State Health Department reported that while Mr. Nin had made bookkeeping improvements, Massive still suffered from a lack of internal financial controls and, in 1986, had a deficit of more than $150,000. The department also said that the number of patient visits never surpassed 30,800 in 1986, then dropped to 23,000 in 1987, 13,000 in 1988 and as few as 11,000 thereafter.
 
Federal Grants Withdrawn
 In 1986, the Public Health Service chose not to renew its last grant to Massive, citing "an unacceptable level of service," "significant deficiencies" in clinical programs and the "misrepresentation to patients of the status of medical assistants as 'Dr.' "
 Mr. Nin disputed the findings and said many of these assistants had degrees from their home countries in Latin America but were not certified as doctors here.
 For four years, the state stepped in with $650,000 in funds. But Massive continued to deteriorate.
Among those hired as physicians was Elie Abraham Horn, who before joining Massive, according to State Health Department records, had surrendered his license amid professional charges of writing unwarranted prescriptions for Qualuudes. Mr. Nin and Mr. Velez said they were unaware of this and that Mr. Horn had been hired through a personnel service. Dr. Horn could not be reached for comment. Another doctor was later found by Connecticut authorities to have billed Medicaid for patients she hadn't examined.
 
A New Executive Director
 By 1988, according to a state review, the handful of remaining doctors showed up only a few mornings a week and the clinic had no registered nurse. The review also determined that laboratory tests were not being done for some children and pregnant women and that some patients were not receiving follow-up care despite abnormal test results.
 Citing high blood pressure, Mr. Nin stepped aside, and in 1988 an acting executive director came in for $1 a year: Mr. Velez.
 Mr. Velez credits himself with putting Massive on sound footing and training the center's board on its responsibilities. "I paid all the debts and accounts," he said. "I paid everybody."
 Mr. Mukhopadhyay commented: "He maybe thought that's what he did. He never asked for any financial report or anything."
 As for board training, Mr. Simmons, the longtime board member, said, "That's news to me."
 
Borrowing From a 'Street Banker'
 Soon, the center was being run by a dental student named Waldemar Rivera, the brother of a friend of Mr. Velez. The chairman of the board was Luis deRosa, who worked for another Velez-related organization. According to State Health Department analyses, the center had $4,600 in assets, which were frozen by the Internal Revenue Service for unpaid taxes, and more than $400,000 in liabilities. In a memo, Martin Kivell, a department official, likened the center to "a patient gasping for air and deteriorating physically on a daily basis."
 In Mr. Mukhopadhyay's final audit, he reported that cash was disappearing from Massive's front desk, that the phones had been cut off, and that it had resorted to taking "highly improper" and "usurious loans" from a man he identified in an interview as a "street banker" named "Dom." He said Dom lent the center as much as $40,000 in cash at roughly 23 percent annual interest.
 In 1991, the State Health Department chose to discontinue its support.
 A last Medicaid payment was divided between two of Massive's many creditors: the I.R.S. and Paul Bleifer, Mr. Velez's personal attorney and the lawyer for Massive's board, who had filed a lien. Doctors who had worked in Massive's waning days have yet to be paid a total of $90,000 in fees.
 
Joining the Empire
A New Clinic, And a New Name
 In 1991, only one "serious" bidder applied to reopen the center building, according to Peter Slocum, a State Health Department spokesman: Mr. Velez's Hunts Point Multi-Service Center.
 A year earlier, the Public Health Service had withdrawn a $1.1 million grant from Hunts Point's own health clinic after finding serious problems with the oversight of its finances and management. But Mr. Slocum said the state still held the Hunts Point clinic to be "in good standing."
 Today, after a dozen turbulent years when it was known as Massive, the health center has been rechristened the "Governor Juan Ponce de Leon Health Center" and Mr. Velez's name hangs high on the wall.
 The center operates largely on the strength of Medicaid billings, processed by Bronx Computing. The State Health Department is evaluating its performance. On three of four visits by reporters in recent weeks, the waiting room was largely empty.
 Massive, meanwhile, remains a troubling memory to some who held out great hope for it.
 "If you think that was the only health center in the area, that was a tremendous loss," said Mr. Simmons. "Those were poor people and they needed the place."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Ending the Subsidies For Timber Barons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Forest Service's plan to phase out taxpayer-subsidized timber sales in our national forests (front page, April 30) is long overdue. The timber companies contend the Government loses money by complying with environmental standards. Would critics argue that we should revert to the days when we played erosion roulette with watersheds for half the West's drinking water supply? Or not worry about the impact on fish and wildlife?
Moreover, the highest cost for taxpayers stems from bulldozing roads to remote forest areas, often up steep hillsides, a road system eight times the interstate highway system. 
 The industry, trying to create a backlash, claims that phasing out subsidized sales will send lumber prices into a spiral. National forests provide 12 percent of the nation's timber, and timber from private lands can pick up any slack. The industry also claims that protecting majestic ancient forests in the Northwest is driving up lumber prices. Those prices, adjusted for inflation, are lower than they were in 1979.
Studies show that in the regions most affected, tourism, recreation and "footloose" businesses (communications-based, for example) are passing logging and other extractive industries as job sources. A tree left in the ground has more value to the local economy than riding out on a logging truck.
 
GAYLORD NELSON
Counselor, The Wilderness Society
Washington, May 4, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Stuff Misty for Me And Other Tales of Growing Up

BYLINE: By Felicity Barringer; Felicity Barringer, who reported from Moscow between 1986 and 1988 for The New York Times, now writes from Washington.

 BODY:
AT the desk across from me sits a fine, curmudgeonly fellow who can -- and does -- recite the entire text of Margaret Wise Brown's "Goodnight Moon" at unlikely intervals. "In the great green room," he begins, "There was a telephone / And a red balloon." Two decades after he lulled his toddlers to sleep with the book, he can call it all back.
As he recites, the words that dug deep ruts in his memory gain traction in my own. I drive backward in time, not very far, to moments when small boys, bundled in diapers or towels, warmly filled my lap after their baths. Fingers, still small then, point and bang at the pages of the same book. 
 The singsong good nights are fixed in childhood time. That period is populated with people who lived and others who were imagined. But what if the bunny in striped pajamas in that great green room grew up? Got a life? Took S.A.T.'s and went out on dates? Dropped out? Went into the Army? Got a job?
The very idea is dissonant, a kind of betrayal. Yet the decades since the 1930's have given us a small regiment of real children who, like the bunny, are icons of childhood but who, like the rest of us, are harnessed to clocks and calendars now. They are the children who served as models for some of the most-loved children's books. Like actors, they are themselves, yet a part of them belongs to the culture.
Unlike actors, they have not chosen this dual existence. Really Rosie didn't know, until she was in her 40's, that Maurice Sendak had been inspired by her antics and had immortalized her dramatic turns on her Brooklyn stoop. She is in her 50's now. The children of Robert McCloskey's "Blueberries for Sal" and "One Morning in Maine" are in their 40's. They still live on the New England coast in close proximity to sea gulls and clam chowder. The voice on Sal's answering machine is cheery, but recent calls about the books were not returned.
For some of these eternal children, it is a surprising pleasure to be linked with a character alive in the popular imagination. They have a sort of fame without the attendant problems of celebrity. For others, the character that once adopted their name and identity now has a separate life.
Barbara Bemelmans, whose father, Ludwig, created the self-possessed, winsome Parisian gamin Madeline, speaks of that fictional character with affectionate kinship. That child is not so much a mirror of what she once was as a companion. She, like her mother, was christened Madeleine; an aunt later suggested Barbara. Her name was changed before the birth of her fictional namesake in 1939, thus depriving her of her most obvious link to the Parisian girl of infinite aplomb. ("To the tiger in the zoo, Madeline just said, 'Pooh-pooh.' ")
"I would have got much more mileage" out of the more famous name, she said, though Bemelmans rearranged the vowels in the character's name because "Made-line" was easier to rhyme.
"My father said she was a little bit of his mother, a little bit of my mother and a little bit of me," said Ms. Bemelmans, her parents' only child, who was 3 when her father wrote the first of the "Madeline" books. "I would certainly like to be like Madeline," added Ms. Bemelmans. "She has so much spirit and spunk. I think maybe she's -- I don't want to say better than I am, but . . . yeah, better than I am."
The soon-to-be-married, 26-year-old Alexander Viorst recounted a pell-mell succession of feelings -- pride, resentment, bemusement and pride again -- when he thought about himself in his mother Judith's book "Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day" (1972).
"Generally, if I'm meeting someone for the first time and if they have kids, or are my generation and have read the book, they say, 'You must be Alexander,' " said Mr. Viorst, a businessman in Chicago.
"At the same time, people have the impression that I'm going to be some wild, unhappy, ratty-haired-looking child. They are quite shocked when they see me for the first time. When I meet younger kids, they don't believe I am who I am. I'm supposed to have red hair and gum stuck in it. When I try and impress 7- or 8-year-olds with who I am, they walk away. They think I'm some impostor."
But overall, he said, the book's life has made his life easier more often than not.
"I was looking for a job at a firm in Chicago once. I was introducing myself, telling everyone who I was. One of them had a 5-year-old they had recently read the book to. There were three other executives -- they all ended up talking among themselves, swapping stories about how their kids liked my mom's books. I was just the audience. Twenty minutes later I had a job."
If Alexander had a horrible day, he has had some wonderful ones since. Paul and Maureen Beebe are known for their wonderful days, taming the wild horse called Phantom and her foal, Misty. In the late 1940's, Paul rode Phantom to victory in the race that became the climactic moment in Marguerite Henry's "Misty of Chincoteague" (1947).
A decade later the boy from the Virginia shore came out of the Coast Guard, bought a new Chevrolet and drove it into a tree. "He was killed right after my son's birthday," said Paul's aunt, Jeanette Beebe. "It was pretty bad on the island right then, because right after Paul, then Grandpa Beebe passed." Maureen Beebe, Paul's sister, still lives on Chincoteague in a house without a telephone; she sometimes runs a gift shop in the summer. Wild horses are still rounded up on the island every July, though a conservationist group is trying to end the practice. There are no more races, though. Jobs are disappearing; the area's economy suffers.
Against that backdrop, memories of Paul and Maureen and the Phantom and Misty have become more important on Chincoteague. For Jeanette Beebe, the old, idyllic scene of family love and two children's devotion to their horses was worth preserving. When Misty died in the early 1970's, Jeanette and her husband had her stuffed -- "preserved" is the word she uses. "She's in Pennsylvania now," she said. "She'll be down here for Memorial Day. She'll be here all summer."
It is a different esthetic, perhaps, but is Jeanette Beebe's desire to preserve Misty in the flesh really all that different from the desire of Barbara Bemelmans to preserve, in this new day of Madeline-mania, the spirit of the child her father created? Is our own preservation, in rhyme or image or joy, of these remembered common childhoods a way of fixing part of our own childhood in our memory?
Really Rosie was born in 1957, when Maurice Sendak wrote "The Sign on Rosie's Door," drawn from the street theater put on years earlier by a 9-year-old Sicilian-American girl with a yen for drama. Mr. Sendak, then a 16-year-old boy, watched unnoticed from a second-floor window. In the book, Rosie becomes "Me, Alinda, the lovely lady singer," who gathers her friends Pudgy and Dolly and Lenny to watch her perform, or disguises herself and convinces them that Magic Man will turn them all into firecrackers for the Fourth of July.
A quarter of a century later, Mr. Sendak found out where his muse had gone. A television cameraman, working on a story about the author, knew the girl he was describing. She had no memory of him or of those days. He sent her his books. The stories made her cry, Mr. Sendak told an audience shortly afterward. Why? "I don't know," she told him when they finally spoke on the telephone. "I suppose it's because I wanted to do what I imagined when I grew up, and I never did. I got married when I was 18, just out of school, and now I've got five children, and we work very hard, and I'd forgotten all about Alinda and all about Pudgy and Dolly and the rest."
Mr. Sendak and Rosie Stacompiano made plans to meet. "Finally, obviously, we both wanted to and couldn't," he told his audience. "Then her husband, George, called and said that it was best we didn't; that it was so upsetting to her, and so exciting to her, and so unreal, that we should leave it alone."
Maybe I didn't want little Sal to call back, fearing she would tell me she was a harried mother, or a harried single person, or a lawyer or a doctor or a radical feminist for whom "Blueberries for Sal" had about as much relevance as reruns of "Rin Tin Tin." If actors and politicians always seem disappointingly shorter in person, the children of our imaginations should not be disappointingly older than we expect. Perhaps not even real.
But, like the rest of us, they have to live outside the childhood time. Only the bunnies and the badgers and the Cat in the improbable Hat stay put where we want them to be. Still, at the cost of living in two worlds, Rosie and Alexander and the other real children have achieved a kind of immortality. By lending us a piece of their childhood, they help us reclaim our own. When we are all gone, they'll still be there. I want them to stay in that childhood time. And I am ashamed that I want to make real people prisoners of my imagination.
In the great green room, the bunny in striped pajamas crawls under the covers. And sleeps. "Goodnight stars / Goodnight air / Goodnight noises everywhere."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2661 words

HEADLINE: In the Cockpit of the Free World

BYLINE: By Elaine Sciolino; Elaine Sciolino is chief diplomatic correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:

TURMOIL AND TRIUMPH
My Years as Secretary of State.
By George P. Shultz.
Illustrated. 1,184 pp. New York:
A Robert Stewart Book/
Charles Scribner's Sons. $30. 
 THE popular perception of George Pratt Shultz is of a stolid, dependable, often stubborn statesman who made no waves and avoided the limelight in his six and a half years as Ronald Reagan's Secretary of State. His languid manner of speaking confounded world leaders, who at first failed to appreciate the power of his intellect, while his impassive style frustrated journalists, who longed for more flair and drama. Mr. Shultz could talk more passionately about the yen-dollar relationship and the information revolution than about peace in the Middle East or arms control agreements with Moscow.
For months after he took the job at the State Department, following Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s abrupt resignation in mid-1982, Mr. Shultz was an unknown in diplomatic circles. On his first official trip to Germany, the embassy press kit read on its cover, The Official Visit of Charles P. Shultz. When he set off with Mr. Reagan in November 1982 on a swing through Latin America, the motorcade left him behind in Brasilia. "Then and thereafter," he recalls, "I was fully aware that on a Presidential trip, the Secretary of State is nobody."
His sprawling memoirs are a kind of coming out, a firsthand description of what he calls "life . . . in the cockpit of the free world." The book captures some, but not all, of the real complexity of the man and of the Presidency he served. Stripped of the inevitable speeches, Congressional testimony and after-dinner toasts, "Turmoil and Triumph" is the most balanced of all the Reagan-era confessions, falling somewhere between Caspar W. Weinberger's panegyric to Mr. Reagan and David A. Stockman's scathing attack. At nearly 1,200 pages, it is also the most comprehensive.
Drawing on the skills he developed as a labor negotiator, Secretary of Labor and of the Treasury in the Nixon era and a president of a major corporation (Bechtel), Mr. Shultz approached foreign policy as a bricklayer rather than an architect. Those skills served him well in dealing with Moscow. His greatest achievement as Secretary of State was helping to move Mr. Reagan along an ideological journey from verbal warfare -- and the belief that the Soviets wanted to take over the world -- to sober diplomacy and pragmatic moderation. In part because of his efforts, the Reagan Administration will be remembered less for its virulent strain of anti-Communism than for taking bold steps towards establishing normal relations with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
In other areas, Mr. Shultz was less successful. He may not have shared the President's passion for anti-Communist guerrilla wars, which drew the United States into unsavory alliances for the sake of democratic principles in places as disparate as Angola and Nicaragua. But he faithfully executed the policies. By the time he was able to start negotiations in Central America, for example, it was too late in the Administration to accomplish very much.
Similarly, when Mr. Shultz stepped out of character in 1983 and tried to strike a Kissingerian kind of deal between Israel and Lebanon as a first step toward bringing peace to the Middle East, he made the mistake of ignoring Syria, and the ill-conceived initiative predictably failed. Despite the energy he expended at the end of the second Reagan Administration, the Middle East was no closer to peace than when Mr. Reagan took office.
Mr. Shultz presents himself in this book first and foremost as a chain-of-command company man who yearned to head a well-organized, collegial foreign policy team, but who found himself instead a lone voice of common sense battling ideologues like William Casey and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, who were pressing Mr. Reagan never to negotiate with the enemy. Writing in a style that is like Mr. Shultz himself -- unadorned and deliberate -- he describes himself as the consummate loyalist to a President with "visionary ideas." Even when Mr. Shultz was at odds with Mr. Reagan, he believed it was generally the advisers, not the President himself, who were at fault. When Mr. Reagan made mistakes, he was the victim of their bad advice. The major flaw in the book is that Mr. Shultz is incapable, even now, of laying bare the shortcomings of his former boss, who floats ghostlike through the narrative.
By contrast, Mr. Shultz uses his memoirs to complain about his place in the system -- that he was out of the loop, that Mr. Reagan's other advisers were constantly overturning his decisions, that he could never talk to the President alone. The former president of Bechtel just couldn't get used to the fact that in Washington "nothing ever seemed to get settled."
Despite his reputation for patience and forbearance, he also reveals himself as a swashbuckling interventionist, eager to use force -- to combat terrorism, to install a democratic government in Grenada, to curb Muslim militias in Lebanon. And for months now he has called for punitive air strikes against what he has called Serbian genocide, likening Secretary of State Warren Christopher's four rules for American military intervention to "a counsel of inaction." If Mr. Shultz were Secretary of State today, he would be arguing forcefully that it is the moral responsibility of the United States to take charge and act, with or without allies.
In "Turmoil and Triumph," Mr. Shultz attacks Secretary of Defense Weinberger mercilessly for his reluctance to use the American military to combat terrorism, for calling for a delay in the invasion of Grenada, for resisting the deployment of American troops to Lebanon after the massacres in the Palestinian refugee camps in Sabra and Shatila. "To Weinberger, as I heard him, our forces were to be constantly built up but not used," Mr. Shultz says. "Everything in our defense structure seemed geared exclusively to deter World War III against the Soviets."
William P. Clark, Mr. Reagan's first national security adviser, is pictured as indecisive, duplicitous and "deeply uncomfortable and insecure in his role in foreign affairs and national security." William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, is trapped by simplistic anti-Communist ideology that colors the Central Intelligence Agency's assessments and renders them worthless. "Bill Casey and the C.I.A. acted independently and provided information on which I could not necessarily rely," Mr. Shultz writes. The relationship between the two officials deteriorated even more during the Iran-contra affair when, he says, "Casey had grossly distorted the proper conduct of government, and I was going to make it my crusade to stop him from continuing these renegade operations." The bureaucratic wars were so bloody that one has to wonder how anyone ever got any work done.
MR. SHULTZ came up with his own two-layered strategy in fighting back. First, he would struggle to convince the President privately of certain proposals in the hopes that Mr. Reagan would parrot back the arguments in announcing his decisions. "The task before me," he says during one battle with the National Security Council staff, "was to make them irrelevant." Second, he would threaten to resign, a dramatic offer he made several times. More than once along the way, James A. Baker 3d, then the chief of staff, later George Bush's Secretary of State, advised Mr. Shultz to stop whining. "You're winning," he said, "so what's your complaint?"
The most dramatic part of the book is Mr. Shultz's version of the Iran-contra affair, the sale of weapons to Iran in exchange for American hostages held in Lebanon and the disbursement of the profits to Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. Shultz argues here, as he has elsewhere, that he was outmaneuvered by the National Security Council, who kept the details of the program secret from him. In staying on, he says, he saw himself as Mr. Reagan's rescuer, the only one at the White House who was determined to prevent the President from getting caught in a web of lies and from continuing the arms-for-hostages swap after it was exposed. "I was convinced that my success in this fight was essential to save the Reagan Presidency," he declares.
But he refuses to accuse Mr. Reagan of lying when the President denied knowing that he was trading arms for hostages. "Ronald Reagan still truly did not believe that what had happened had, in fact, happened," he writes in perhaps his most damning criticism of his former boss. "I had seen him like this before on other issues. He would go over the 'script' of an event, past or present, in his mind, and once that script was mastered, that was the truth."
Mr. Shultz's assertions that Mr. Bush tried to obscure his role as Vice President in the Iran-contra scandal challenge Mr. Bush's account that his knowledge was minimal. They also raise serious questions about Mr. Shultz's own motives. During last year's election campaign, he refused to discuss Mr. Bush's activities in the affair, and the delay in his revelations makes one wonder whether Mr. Shultz was trying to help get Mr. Bush re-elected.
Although Mr. Shultz is revelatory in dealing with Mr. Bush, he is less than candid in discussing Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams, his trusted aide, who pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors in the Iran-contra affair, including concealing from Congress his solicitation of a $10 million donation from the Sultan of Brunei for the Nicaraguan rebels. (Mr. Abrams was pardoned last Christmas by Mr. Bush.) Mr. Shultz had intended to make the solicitation himself during a visit to the Sultanate, according to other accounts by Reagan Administration officials, but in the end gave Mr. Abrams the task. In "Turmoil and Triumph," Mr. Shultz's only mention of the matter is in a footnote in which he says that during his trip to Brunei, he "did not raise the question of support by Brunei for the contras." But then, memoirs are an exercise not only in setting the record straight, but also in enhancing the place of the author in history.
Take the policy toward Iraq, for example. Mr. Shultz was responsible for the "tilt" toward Iraq's President Saddam Hussein in the early 1980's, when Washington feared that Iran was poised to win the border war between the two countries and spread revolution throughout the Islamic world. During the Reagan years, the United States shared intelligence with Iraq, secretly urged its allies to sell weapons to Mr. Hussein, removed Iraq from the State Department's list of countries sponsoring terrorism and kept it off, and extended billions of dollars in American-backed loan guarantees to Baghdad.
In August 1988, after a cease-fire was declared in the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, Zalmay Khalilzad, then an official on the State Department's policy planning staff, drafted a memorandum to Mr. Shultz calling for a more balanced approach to the two countries. The paper recommended that the United States should take steps to curb Iraq's growing influence by lifting the war-related sanctions against Iran. When Mr. Shultz learned about the draft proposal in a news report, he called an urgent meeting and angrily vetoed it, officials familiar with the incident told me at the time.
So it is curious that Mr. Shultz writes that once the war was over, "it was clear to me that no further reason existed for the United States to give Iraq the benefit of the doubt for balance-of-power purposes against Iran." To that end, he says, the State Department recommended in one of its transition books to the incoming Bush Administration that "a new and tougher policy toward Saddam Hussein's Iraq was now appropriate." What Mr. Shultz omits is that the transition book's recommendation -- also written by Mr. Khalilzad -- mirrored the one he had rejected.
This book does capture some of the high-spirited George Shultz that eluded public view. One cannot imagine Henry Kissinger or James Baker 3d or Warren Christopher presenting Japan's Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe with a Washington Redskins pennant and singing "Hail to the Redskins." But even when Mr. Shultz is dealing with his lighter side, he has his secrets. His wife Helena once told reporters not only that he had a tiger tattooed on his backside, but that he used it to play with the grandchildren: they got to press the tattoo, and he got to growl for them. In his memoirs Mr. Shultz notes the intense news media interest in his posterior, but maintains what he calls a " 'neither confirm nor deny' policy." The only official comment on the matter came from the State Department spokeswoman, Phyllis Oakley, who told reporters, "I'm not in a position to comment."
Despite the omissions, the book clearly illustrates Mr. Shultz's microhistorical approach to foreign policy, one devoid of sweeping generalizations and grand gestures. He left behind no "Shultz doctrine," but rather a mixed legacy built on what he calls "incremental steps." He no doubt agrees with Dean Acheson, who said that "statesmen are not architects but gardeners, dealing with such materials as only nature can provide." Indeed, Mr. Shultz calls one section of his book "Gardening," an indication that he tried to do what he could with what he had. And maybe that's the best that can be expected.
 
 
 
THE TOOLS OF REMEMBRANCE
 By the time he came to write his memoirs of his more than six years as Secretary of State, George P. Shultz said he had read all the earlier versions of the genre -- the efforts of American statesmen making their bid to mold history. He said in a recent interview in Washington that he found the autobiographies of Henry A. Kissinger and Dean Acheson the best of the lot, providing the kind of historical sweep to which he aspired in writing "Turmoil and Triumph."
But he also wanted to provide a sense of immediacy, of the day-to-day tug and pull on the office of the Secretary of State and how the occupant lurches from one seemingly unrelated issue to another.
Toward this goal he was helped by the notes taken during most of his tenure by his executive assistant, Charles Hill, a veteran Foreign Service officer. The skill of taking good notes is highly prized in the diplomatic corps, and Mr. Shultz soon discovered that Mr. Hill was a master at keeping meticulous contemporaneous notes of everything that happened. "When I returned from the White House, I briefed him as to everything that I saw happen," Mr. Shultz said.
In the end, Mr. Shultz found he had nearly 200 standard steno pads filled with Mr. Hill's neat and highly readable handwriting. The Hill diaries and their completeness became well known during the prolonged investigation of the Iran-contra affair, because they helped investigators expose many details of the scandal. The most noteworthy example was Mr. Hill's notes of a conversation between Mr. Shultz and Caspar W. Weinberger, then the Secretary of Defense, which cast grave doubt on George Bush's assertions that he had only limited knowledge of Iran-contra matters.
With Mr. Hill's notebooks as one of his prime tools of remembrance, Mr. Shultz ensconced himself at Stanford University, where he is an emeritus professor of international economics and where he has long had a cozy home on the campus. In addition to "Charlie's notes," as he calls them, Mr. Shultz had his own papers: "Everything that came into the Secretary of State's office that had G.P.S. on it," he said, referring to his initials and to a standard procedure for identifying the flow of documents in the Government.
The State Department allowed him to copy all those papers at his own expense and to ship them to a Federal documents center in San Bruno, Calif., near his base in Palo Alto. A Stanford archivist with a high security clearance set to work cataloguing the Shultz papers because, as Mr. Shultz said, "It's all useless until it's catalogued." NEIL A. LEWIS

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 16, 1993,

SECTION: Section 7; Page 40; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 920 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
BARN BLIND, by Jane Smiley. (Fawcett Columbine, $10.) Jane Smiley's first novel, published in 1980 and never before in paperback, deals with an ambitious woman determined to have her farm-bound children become prize-winning equestrians. The author "handles with skill and understanding the mercurial molasses of adolescence, and the inchoate, cumbersome love that family members feel for one another," Michael Malone said here.
THE CULTURE OF CONTENTMENT, by John Kenneth Galbraith. (Houghton Mifflin, $9.95.) The contented -- the top 20 percent in income in our society -- are a minority in number but a majority in power, asserts John Kenneth Galbraith. Opposed to economic reform, these are the voters who brought us the lower taxes and laissez-faire approaches of the Administrations of the last two Republican Presidents. Last year our reviewer, Robert N. Bellah, said: "I know of no book -- and I have read a number of excellent discussions of the subject lately -- that treats more incisively or more convincingly the profoundly injurious consequences of these policies to our economy." Houghton Mifflin has also reissued Mr. Galbraith's strangely prescient 1968 novel THE TRIUMPH ($9.95), in which the American Government intervenes in Latin America on behalf of a corrupt but anti-Communist dictator. Donald Barthelme found the book stuffy but, he said here, "The story is dandy." 
 THE DARK SISTER, by Rebecca Goldstein. (Penguin, $11.) A feminist writer named Hedda, obsessed with the literary art of Henry James, writes a very Jamesian tale that blends fiction, history and her own relationship with her sister. In 1991 our reviewer, Angeline Goreau, said that Ms. Goldstein's third novel "represents an impressively ambitious advance."
THE DISUNITING OF AMERICA: Reflections on a Multicultural Society, by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. (Norton, $7.95.) The author cautions against educational curriculums that celebrate ethnicity at the expense of the unified, democratic culture that has always been the American ideal. Last year our reviewer, Frank Kermode, called this a "sane and temperate book." More on the subject can be found in LOOSE CANONS: Notes on the Culture Wars, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. (Oxford University, $9.95), which argues for an open approach to the humanities based not on political correctness but on the need to understand our own diverse origins. The book "should prove especially illuminating and reassuring to nonacademics," James D. Bloom said here last year.
EVER AFTER, by Graham Swift. (Vintage International, $11.) A professor becomes embroiled in existential questions when he comes upon the notebooks of Matthew Pearce, a 19th-century man whose discovery of a fossil led him to abandon God and embrace Darwin. Last year our reviewer, MacDonald Harris, said: "The prose is rich, lush and unhurried; this is a modern British novel for the reader who is getting bored with the contemporary American mode of fiction."
IN THE REALM OF A DYING EMPEROR: Japan at Century's End, by Norma Field. (Vintage, $12.) Norma Field, the daughter of a Japanese mother and an American father, explores the state of civil rights in Japan through the cases of three citizens who questioned the culture's conformist ethic. The book is notable for its "well-researched, well-observed and completely absorbing reporting," John David Morley said here in 1991. Also available in paperback is THE OUTNATION: A Search for the Soul of Japan, by Jonathan Rauch (Little, Brown, $10.95), in which a young journalist who spent six months in the country reached the surprising conclusion that the Japanese may not be so different from us after all. Last year one critic called his book "one of the very best accounts of modern Japanalia."
LITTLE WOMAN, by Ellen Akins. (Harper Perennial, $10.) The heroine is anything but little: large and ungainly, Beauty Skinner leaves her husband and twins to set up a shelter for battered women and pursue her own ulterior motives. In 1990 our reviewer, Susan Dundon, called this novel "exquisitely written."
WOODROW WILSON, by August Heckscher. (Collier, $18.) This biography relates the achievements of Wilson's political life to the evolution of his character, also illuminating the President's relationships with both his wives. The author's "description of Wilson's personality is by far the most persuasive I am familiar with," John A. Garraty said here in 1991.
NELLIE WITHOUT HUGO, by Janet Hobhouse. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.) In this 1982 novel, Nellie, a 30-year-old New Yorker, takes advantage of her husband's absence to have an affair with a brutal ex-lover. Although our reviewer, Katha Pollitt, found the female characters' attitudes and choices regressive, she described the author as a "lively, intelligent writer."
THE MIND'S SKY: Human Intelligence in a Cosmic Context, by Timothy Ferris. (Bantam, $13.95.) Timothy Ferris, a science journalist, explores the connection between the universe of mind and the universe of matter. His is an "informed, inspired investigation of the intellect and the infinite . . . anchored in hard science and good sense," Dava Sobel said here last year.
KISSING THE GUNNER'S DAUGHTER, by Ruth Rendell. (Mysterious Press/Warner, $5.50.) In Ruth Rendell's latest Inspector Wexford mystery, her hero investigates a gruesome triple murder in an elegant English country house. Last year our reviewer, Winfred Stout, called it an "intricate story that hinges on vanity and self-deception."

HEADLINE: FILM VIEW;
Of Hems and Haws: The Insiders' Guide to 'Dave'

BYLINE: By Maureen Dowd

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the new political comedy "Dave," the film makers have clearly gone to a lot of trouble to ape the look and tribal customs of the capital.
But the true measure of their success is found in Sigourney Weaver's wardrobe as First Lady. Proving that even great beauties can be dimmed by Washington style, Ms. Weaver is trapped by verisimilitude into wearing outfits of transcendent blandness. Her skirts hover between knee and midcalf at that peculiar length favored by professional Washington women that has never been fashionable anywhere, anytime in history. 
 Fashion here echoes politics; skirts and hairstyles usually end up at compromise lengths designed not to offend anyone or make a statement of any kind. Like Presidents, skirts try to please all of the people all of the time -- and often end up pleasing none.
The skirt lengths may be impeccable, but there are a few things in "Dave" that the cognoscenti-critics in Washington can quibble with -- the color of the rug in the Oval Office, the egress of the tunnel leading out of the White House, that tone of selfless idealism that exists in Washington only in the movies. But setting aside such cavils for a moment, there are lots of things that ring true about the Ivan Reitman comedy about a Presidential look-alike, played by Kevin Kline, who takes over for an ailing President.
1. Helen Thomas, that crusty doyenne of the Washington press corps who plays herself in the movie, rolls her eyes in disgust after the President takes to the podium in the White House press room to announce that Every American Who Wants a Job Can Have One, and then refuses to take press questions.
"That's accurate," confirms Dee Dee Myers, the real-life White House press secretary who jousts with reporters about job programs from behind that podium. "Helen rolls her eyes at me every single day."
2. The ruthless, lying, power-hungry White House chief of staff, played by the wonderfully oily Frank Langella, has plenty of historical precedent. Bill Clinton's chief of staff and childhood friend from Arkansas, Thomas McClarty, is uncommonly polite and low-key, but it wasn't so long ago that John Sununu, George Bush's chief of staff, was threatening to use a chain saw on the tender body parts of a Chamber of Commerce official who did not go along with a White House position.
Chiefs of staff do sometimes secretly believe that they are smarter than the Presidents they work for. And it's not so hard to imagine one blurting, as Mr. Langella does about the pauper-turned-President Mr. Kline: "Was he on the Trilateral Commission? Was he a Senator? Was he in 'Who's Who' seven years in a row?"
Frank Mankiewicz, the Washington public relations executive and former Democratic pol who has a bit part as a Wise Man in the movie, says: "We have had some terrible chiefs of staff. But I don't suppose any of them are that ugly or brutal -- except maybe Bob Haldeman."
3. Senator Alan Simpson, the Republican from Wyoming whose tart tongue has occasionally earned him the sobriquet "The Meanest Man in Washington," plays himself with perfect astringency, carping about Mr. Kline's do-gooding President: "This guy's out to lunch. The lights are on, but nobody's home."
And Senator Paul Simon, the Democrat from Illinois, does a funny turn on politicians' insatiable desire to claim credit, commenting about the President's jobs bill: "It's a little bit like the program I presented four years ago."
4. Proving that Washington is beyond parody, its talking heads fit into Hollywood farce without even having to ham it up, because the members of "The McLaughlin Group" and CNN's Michael Kinsley and Robert Novak are already, to some extent, conscious caricatures of themselves.
Indeed, Mr. Kinsley recalls how easy it was for Mr. Novak, playing his partner on "Crossfire" in the movie, to work himself into a conservative froth over the celluloid President.
"They told us the basic situation, that a President was trying to cut the budget to fund a homeless program, and let us improvise from there," Mr. Kinsley says. "Novak starts screaming and yelling, 'This man is refusing to cut the capital gains tax!' He worked himself up into what seemed to be a genuine rage. It was phenomenal." Unfortunately, that particular scene was cut, but Mr. Novak is splendidly sneering in the scenes that remain.
5. One nice artistic touch, echoing the Yale sweatshirt Kevin Kline wears in homage to George Bush, is a shot of an oil painting of Millie, the Bushes' English springer spaniel, based on a real painting that was given to the Bushes by the Secret Service and displayed in the White House residence during their tenure.
Not that anyone cares, since "Dave" is a Capra-esque fantasy, but the movie is based on a false premise: that the Secret Services sometimes uses Presidential look-alikes as decoys to walk through crowds at the end of speeches.
The Secret Service might use limousines as decoys. And it is true that the last two Presidents have had a lead Secret Service agent who closely resembled them in face and build, presumably to confuse would-be assassins. Mr. Clinton has a tall agent with a Brillo pad of salt-and-pepper hair who could be his brother, and Mr. Bush had one who was his height, with chiseled, WASPy features and slicked-back brown hair.
Although he's proud that "Dave" got better reviews than the other spring movie about capital politics, the remake of "Born Yesterday," Michael Kinsley lodges an objection to the film's Perot-style message, in which the Kevin Kline character sneaks his old friend Murray, an accountant (played by Charles Grodin), into the White House to help pare $650 million out of the bloated Federal budget. Murray does it nearly painlessly with a few financial shell games.
"This plays to the sense that anyone with any common sense who's not a Washington insider or Beltway type could balance the budget in a second without causing anybody any pain," Mr. Kinsley says. "To me, that is the basic fallacy that is destroying this country." The columnist and "Crossfire" host also drolly notes that if all it took was an accountant named Murray, the Federal Government would not be in such disastrous straits.
"All the trouble started with a guy named Murray, Murray Weidenbaum, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers under Reagan," he says.
It is a fun trivia game for Washingtonians to check out the slight disparities in the movie. Dee Dee Myers notes with amusement that when Kevin Kline asks the pack of White House reporters and photographers to give him some privacy as he talks to a small boy at a homeless shelter, they leave quite amenably.
"The reporters all just walk away," she says. "If only my life could be so easy." Ms. Myers is a friend of Gary Ross, the politically active screenwriter of "Dave," who learned just how farcical politics can be when he worked as a speechwriter for Michael Dukakis in 1988.
Proving that vanity is more important than verity in Hollywood, the color of the rug in the Oval Office has been changed from light blue to golden brown because it is more flattering to the actors' skin tones. There is a tunnel under the White House, like the one Kevin Kline and Sigourney Weaver use to run off for a bit of "Roman Holiday" slumming, but it comes out at the Treasury Department, not Lafayette Park.
And the door in the movie's press room is on the left side of the room, across from the podium, whereas the real door is a sliding door in the wall behind the podium. (O.K., we're getting a little picayune here.)
At least "Dave" does not take the sort of egregious geographic liberties that past Washington movies have. The 1987 thriller "No Way Out," for instance, had Kevin Costner riding the subway to Georgetown, where it does not go, and had Gene Hackman eating breakfast at a rooftop restaurant that, judging by the angle of the Lincoln Memorial in the view from the restaurant, could only have been in the middle of the Potomac River.
And the new "Born Yesterday" was based on the fallacious assumption that the Washington elite usually talk about such highfalutin topics as Alexis de Tocqueville and Europe qua Europe, when they are often jabbering about the latest with Charles and Di and the Redskins' prospects for next season.
And, of course, the Washington of "Dave" is a much more sentimental place than the real capital, which is, like Hollywood, often compared to a snake pit.
Already, one jaded Washingtonian, complaining that "Dave" is simply a rehash of movies like "Prisoner of Zenda" and "Moon Over Parador," has concocted a plot for a better film: When a powerful movie studio chief falls ill, the board of directors -- nervous about the health of the company's stock -- plays for time by replacing him with a talented but unknown screenwriter who is his double.
The screenwriter-turned-mogul immediately cancels plans to make "Born Yesterday" and "Dave."

HEADLINE: Second-Home Market Begins to Stir

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
FEW sectors of the residential market have suffered as much in the last five years as second homes. Prices for beach and country houses in most parts of the Northeast have fallen by as much as 30 percent, pushed down by the 1987 stock market crash, the subsequent recession and changes in the Federal tax code.
But in the last year the second-home market has shown faint signs of life, particularly in more affordable areas, like the Jersey Shore and the Poconos, but also in costlier locales, like the Hamptons, Vermont and Cape Cod. 
 Increasingly, New Yorkers are also buying second homes outside the Northeast, like South Miami Beach, Fla., and the fast-growing resorts along the South Carolina coast, like Kiawah Island and Hilton Head.
"We're getting a ton of people from the Northeast," said Brad Munday, a sales manager with Kiawah Island Real Estate on Kiawah Island, S.C., a barrier-beach resort island about 20 miles south of Charleston. "We're even getting people who are moving here from the Hamptons, Martha's Vineyard, Nantucket."
In many of the traditional vacation areas in the Northeast, second home sales seem to have risen in the last year while prices have remained flat or fallen. Brokers, however, are optimistic that this pattern, combined with a lack of current construction, will start to reduce the glut of homes on the market. And, they say, a shrinking inventory of second homes eventually means rising prices.
"Our office did 50 percent more volume last year than the year before, but at reduced prices," said Paul Spera, a real estate agent in Stowe, Vt., and a former regional vice president of the National Association of Realtors.
Brokers attribute the current blip of increased sales primarily to mortgage interest rates, now at 20-year lows, and to the fact that many sellers are "highly motivated," industry lingo for willing to accept less, sometimes substantially less, than their offering price.
Second-home buyers, brokers note, are also usually more affluent and confident about their financial future. Thus, they do not have the job insecurity that has paralyzed many potential buyers of primary residences in many places.
"I don't think you'll ever see a better market for people who have money," said Ann M. Crotty, sales manager of Westledge Real Estate in Mystic, Conn., who noted that homes that had sold for $300,000 in nearby Stonington Borough, a popular weekend and summering place for New Yorkers, were now selling for as low as $180,000.
Many areas, like the Poconos, also have large numbers of foreclosed properties, which has attracted so-called bottom feeders. "Investors are coming up regularly just to check the inventory," said Denise Fey, a sales agent with Davis R. Chant, a real estate broker in Milford, Pa., in the Poconos, where homes on several acres can be found for as little as $70,000.
FORECLOSURES also pull down the sale prices of other homes in the immediate area, as has been the case in parts of the Hamptons, where many homes, especially those under $400,000, are being offered at fire-sale prices.
"There are bargains out here," said Timothy G. Davis, managing partner with Allan M. Schneider Associates in Southhampton, L.I.
In the Hamptons, it is the top end of the market, homes selling for $800,000 or more, that has held its value better than lesser-priced properties, those generally selling for $200,000 to $400,000.
"We have had more activity out here than we have had in a couple years," Mr. Davis said.
"A market that has come back is south of the highway, Water Mill, Bridgehampton, $500,000 to $800,000," he added, referring to the Montauk Highway. "A good percentage of that inventory has been sold this year."
Though much of the sales in second homes of late has been spurred by reduced prices, some brokers also believe, wishfully perhaps, that vacation home prices will soon start rising as the acquisitive baby-boom generation, especially the large number of two-career couples, enters its prime earning years over the next 10 to 15 years.
Jean Luedtke, a manager with HCH Properties in Harvey Cedars, N.J., an affluent oceanfront community on Long Beach Island on the central Jersey Shore, said that her company had sold 57 homes in the first four months of 1992 and 61 in the first four months of this year.
She also said that the average sale price for that time period was $309,000 last year and $375,000 this year.
"The market is coming back, and across the board," she said. "We're seeing properties go for $2 million and for $150,000."
Ms. Luedtke said that many of today's buyers came from the same socioeconomic background of previous generations of second-home buyers; many are professionals, lawyers or doctors or work in senior management for large corporations.
There is a difference, Ms. Luedtke added. Today's second-home buyers are often younger, sometimes in their mid-30's to mid-40's, rather than the late 40's and 50's, which is when previous generations bought beach or country houses for weekend and summer use. These buyers, in many cases, also often have few or no children and aren't burdened by the specter of college costs.
"Their accountants are telling them that they are the making too much money and they should buy something," Ms. Luedtke said. "They don't want any more exposure in the stock market, and real estate is now looking like a good investment again. It is also something they can use and enjoy."
The ranks of second-home buyers also include more single professional women and married couples trading up from their first second home.
STANLEY AND SUSAN FISHMAN of Livingston, N.J., for example, recently bought their second second home in North Beach on Long Beach Island. They sold their first one for $310,000 in January and used the money to buy a larger home on the ocean side of Long Beach Boulevard, the island's main thoroughfare, for $440,000. The home, being built "on spec" by a local developer, is 90 percent complete and the Fishmans expect it to be finished and to move in within a few weeks.
"One time the market seemed strong and then it died, and now it seems that it is coming back," said Mrs. Fishman, who is 45 years old and a nurse. Her husband, 48, is a lawyer. They have three children 19 to 23 years old.
Any full-throttle revival of the second-home market, however, depends on the economy's recovery. And the recovery may become very regional, with some areas steeply up and others down sharply. Currently, the Northwest and the Middle West have strong economies and second-home markets; the Northeast, which has more second homes than any other region, is lagging behind in both.
"Prices are, well, they are not going up," said Charles F. Lockhart, executive vice president of the Cape Cod and Islands Board of Realtors in South Yarmouth, Mass. "But the banks are a little more willing to lend, and the outlook on the economy is a little brighter."
Specifically, he said, average sale prices have dropped 27 percent, from $169,313 in 1988 to $133,197 last year. "Sales volume, though, was up at the end of 1992 -- we were over 30 percent ahead of 1991," Mr. Lockhart added. "I would hope that we have leveled off and I have a hunch maybe we have."
Precise statistics on second-home sales do not exist because second homes are defined by use rather than construction. Moreover, the best studies, by the Bureau of the Census and the National Association of Realtors, have not been updated in several years. (In 1990, according to a report by the National Association of Home Builders in Washington, about 4 percent of the nation's households owned about 5.2 million second homes. The organization believes that new construction of second homes will increase, from about 75,000 units a year to 100,000 to 125,000 by 1995.)
HOMES in vacation-oriented areas used primarily for second residences in the past are also increasingly being sold to those who own no other homes. These buyers are often retirees, telecommuters, people willing to make long daily commutes in exchange for a cheaper house in a more desirable location or those who would rather rent near where they work and take out a mortgage for weekend or summer property.
The second-home market has been depressed in large part because of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which took away the deductibility for passive losses, which had allowed investors to deduct losses from other forms of income. This effectively removed investors from the market. Owners of a second home can still deduct their mortgage interest and taxes, provided the mortgages don't add up to more than $1 million.
Moreover, if the home is rented out for only 14 days or less, the income is tax free. And if the house is rented for more than 14 days it can be classified as a rental property, which allows deductions -- up to the amount of rental income generated -- for a variety of expenses, including insurance, maintenance, utilities and improvements, during the period when the house is considered rental property.
Taxes aside, in some areas, particularly those like the Hamptons where second homes are in demand during the summer season, three or four months of rental income can cover a year's worth of mortgage payments.
If there is any area teeming with New Yorkers in search of a second home, it is South Miami Beach. "The rehabilitation market in SoBe is primarily made up of New Yorkers who find great bargains in these old buildings and turn them into condos for other New Yorkers," said Jeff Cohen, president of the Miami Beach Association of Realtors.
Both Mr. Cohen and Mr. Munday of Kiawah Island said that New Yorkers were being lured out of the Northeast for the second homes by the better weather, cheaper prices, less traffic and congestion and an overall higher quality of life.
"A lot of our buyers are people who are buying a second home and hope at some point to phase it into their primary home, either in retirement, or they hope they're company will transfer them, or they'll start their own business and work from home," Mr. Munday said.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Housing the Homeless;
Utilizing Private Vacancies for Families

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
"IT'S a marvelous program," says Baxter Lanius. Then he identifies it by the uneuphonious acronym that has been its misfortune from inception -- EARP.
Mr. Lanius owns 10 small rental buildings in Harlem and West Harlem, bought in the 80's at a time of rising property values. "A child of the Harlem bubble," he calls himself. 
 Now he finds himself with 10 vacancies in his 300 apartments and trouble finding tenants. The pool of low- to moderate-income people who can afford the basic rent that privately owned apartments need for decent operations is limited. Many tenants in Harlem are on public assistance and the state's rent limits are well below the level needed for sound operation.
Figures from one major management group, Ralph Langsam Associates, show that its vacancy rate has reached 4.2 percent in the 7,000 apartments it runs in the Bronx, from 149th Street to Gunhill Road. They are in 170 buildings, more than 100 of them upgraded by moderate rehabilitations in the last 10 years.
The Emergency Assistance to Relocation Program -- EARP -- is one of the mechanisms city government has devised to induce owners to take very-low-income tenants. The program helps provide permanent housing units for the families who enter transitional housing, usually from doubled-up situations, as homeless people.
The program's specifications have been revised over the years. In its present form, the owner gets a one-time payment of $2,300 per family member when the tenant moves in on a two-year lease with the right to an eight-month extension. The tenant comes as well with a Federal Section 8 rent subsidy, which pays the difference between the economic, or fair-market, rent to which the owner is entitled, and the share of that rent paid by the tenant, pegged to 30 percent of income. Current fair-market rent is $630 a month for a two-bedroom, without utilities.
The effectiveness with which government bridges the gap between the economic rent and the tenants' ability to pay will be a fundamental test in the 90's of its ability to help low-income families find permanent housing. Many of the families that come through the transitional-housing system -- usually young women with one or more children -- have had no experience with independent living and need social or educational services as well as housing.
Using the existing private housing stock with governmental rent assistance may also be a way of warding off a new wave of housing abandonment. Already tax arrears show signs of increase in low-income housing. Payments received by owners under the emergency assistance program will help pay off these arrears.
The significance of the Emergency Assistance to Relocation Program is coming into focus just as the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins is moving to establish a separate agency called the Department of Homeless Services to coordinate the delivery of housing and social services to homeless families and singles. Legislation is pending before the City Council's General Welfare Committee.
Managing the transition to the new agency is Charles V. Raymond, director of the Mayor's Office for Homeless Facilities and Service Development, its commissioner-designate. Mr. Raymond said there has been an upward trend in the use of the private stock for permanent rehousing of the homeless. The extent of the use of the program depends on the level of availability of rent subsidies.
Roughly half the families in transitional facilities eventually find permanent housing on their own, officials say. The rest have been rehoused with government help. About 22,000 families over the last five years have gone from transitional housing into public housing or newly renovated city-owned tax-foreclosed property.
But in fiscal 1993 (ending June 30) privately owned housing will get more formerly homeless families than public-sector housing for the first time in five years. The projected figure is 2,700 apartments, up from 1,420 last year and 350 when the program began in fiscal 1989.
Mark Engel, president of Ralph Langsam Associates, has been a user of the emergency assistance program.
"OUR vacancy rate has been the highest since I've been in the business -- 18 years," he said. "It used to be 2 percent over-all. Now it's 4 1/2 percent."
His well-maintained apartments rent for $440 a month for one-bedrooms and $550 for two-bedrooms. A shortage of two-bedroom apartments generally is one of the limiting factors in the use of the private stock as permanent rentals for homeless families.
"I don't want to overload any one building with EARP families," Mr. Engel said. "I've taken 50. You can screen them just like any other tenants." He said he favored limiting the number of families per building taken through this tenanting method, a principle some City Council members want to enact into law.
New York City is in the position, practically and perhaps legally as well, of having to provide emergency housing for any individual or family (defined as two or more persons, often a young mother with children) that presents itself as in need of it. To the extent that families see this as a path to improved living conditions, "homelessness" is a new route to independent living and a private apartment.
The inflow of families arriving as homeless into transitional housing is running at about 11,000 a year. Kenneth Murphy, deputy commissioner in charge of crisis intervention services, estimates that about 7,000 of these families have never before entered the transitional housing system. The others have used it at least once, but been out for at least 30 days. The reasons for return range from unsafe living conditions to untenable domestic conditions, Mr. Murphy said.
About 70 percent were doubled up and more than 50 percent had never lived independently, he said.
A bone of legal contention is whether the city is free to exercise discretion on the admission of night-arrivals at an emergency assistance office into the transitional-housing system. The city's belief is that a certain number of these families ought instead to go to the welfare office in day hours for housing assistance.
ONCE a family is in transitional housing, the city is effectively obliged to find permanent housing for those who don't or can't find it on their own. In practice such families are put in a favorable position on the waiting line for permanent subsidized housing, for which other doubled-up families, though not technically homeless, are also waiting.
Hoping to ease the pressure on transitional housing, the Department of Social Services began a "diversion" program last year, trying through interviews by specially trained teams to see how many families might be helped to find housing without entering the city system. In 28 percent of the cases families who were seeking emergency shelter found it elsewhere.
There were 1,562 interviews by diversion teams between Jan. 14 and April 30. A total of 441 families avoided emergency housing, 167 going into vacant private apartments (where they might later receive a Section 8 rent certificate) and 274 going to doubled-up situations with friends or relatives.
To Steven Banks, coordinating attorney of the Homeless Family Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society, the city's standards for admission to emergency housing are too stringent. He argues that desperate families seeking shelter overnight should not be told to come back during the day for evaluation.
THOUGH disagreeing with Dinkins administration officials on that issue, he agreed that the Emergency Assistance for Relocation Program had already shown that use could be made of the growing number of private vacancies to meet the permanent housing needs of homeless families.
Twenty years ago there was a glut of low-cost housing; owners could hold back taxes for long periods and give low-quality shelter to very poor people without subsidies.
Today, shallow-subsidy programs, complementing the remarkable quantity of low-rent, high-subsidy new units that have been built as gut rehabilitations in older neighborhoods, are essential to meet the housing needs of the city's poor.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Italianate Town House;
Banco di Napoli Buys Landmark

 BODY:
When bank executives look at mansions, they usually think "mortgage." Rarely do they look and think "headquarters."
But that was the reaction that Lucio Passarello, first vice president of Banco Di Napoli, had to 4 East 54th Street, the five-story, double-width town house that the industrialist William H. Moore had built as his primary residence almost a century ago. The 454-year-old Italian bank just agreed to buy the landmarked building as its permanent New York headquarters for $12.8 million. 
 "This building, with its Italianate architecture and history, would look right at home in Naples," Mr. Passarello said.
The price is higher, on a per-square-foot basis, than most town houses have commanded in the neighborhood. But Norman Livingston, the broker at James Felt Realty Investment Services who represented the bank, says such comparisons are specious.
"Those were vanilla boxes," he said. "This is a piece of art."
The mansion, designed by McKim, Mead & White, boasts 20-foot ceilings on the parlor floor and copious amounts of marble, woodwork and stained glass windows. The 36-foot-wide, 22,000-square-foot building, which was most recently used by the Government of Indonesia as an economic development center, has practical appeal as well: Its floorplate allows for a trading floor. And it comes with air rights that will allow the bank to build two more floors. Since they will be set far back from the street, the bank expects the Landmarks Preservation Commission will approve.
