HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Parking Space in a Co-op
 
Question: I am a tenant in a Yonkers co-op. What are my rights regarding parking spots? The co-op owner in charge of parking spaces appears to be ignoring my request for a parking space. Do co-op owners have priorities when a parking spot becomes available? . . . Seymour Daks, Yonkers
 
Answer: Maybe. According to Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives, a renter who has a parking spot when a building is converted has the right to maintain the spot. But, he added, if a spot becomes available after the conversion it is up to the board of directors to decide how it will allocate the spaces, and it can do it any way it wants as long as it is done in a prudent, businesslike manner. 
 "They don't have to increase an amenity, but they can't decrease amenities," Mr. Saft said.
 
Modifying a Mortgage
 
uestion: I have a one-year adjustable mortgage with the Dime Savings Bank and have read in numerous financial magazines that banks can do a rate modification on an existing loan, and the cost of a rate modification is much less than for a refinancing. When I inquired about this with the Dime, I was told that the Dime will only refinance. This, however, is of no help to me since my property has declined in value.
How can I get a rate modification? If the Dime will not provide it, can I use another bank or mortgage broker? . . . John J. Malardi, Brooklyn
 
Answer: Probably not. According to Stan Greenstein, executive vice president with the Mortgage Clearing House in New Hyde Park, L.I., you can modify only with the bank that holds the mortgage or loan. With refinancing you can take your mortgage to a new bank or mortgage broker.
There are technical differences between a modification and a refinancing. With a modification, you are only changing the interest rate charged on the remaining balance of your loan. With a refinancing, you are essentially taking out a new loan to pay off your old one. Generally, you wouldn't seek a refinancing if a modification is available unless you have paid off a significant part of your mortgage and want to take cash out of the transaction.
Modifications are given by the banks to keep customers from taking their mortgages and loans to another bank for refinancing. Essentially, with a modification you pay only legal expenses, a new appraisal and possibly a new credit report, which probably won't cost more than $1,000.
Costs for a refinancing, on the other hand, can run as much as 3 to 4 percent of the mortgage. With refinancing, you will obtain a slightly lower interest rate than you will with modification, but in many cases the costs involved will negate any savings.
All this, though, may not apply to your situation, since your property has declined in value. In many cases where property has declined in value, your home may now be worth less than the value of the mortgage. In such cases, it is unlikely that any lender will modify or refinance your loan.
 
Who's in Charge?
 
Question: Could you please tell me which politicians and committees are involved with reforming the rent-regulation laws in New York City. . . . Robert R. Ginsky, Manhattan
 
Answer: The legislative committees in Albany that deal with the city's controversial rent-control and stabilization system are the Senate's Housing Committee, Cities Committee and Judiciary Committee.
In the Assembly, it's the Housing Committee, the Cities Committee, the Judiciary Committee and the Real Property Taxation Committee.
In the City Council, it's the Housing and Buildings Committee.
Of course, the Governor and the Mayor would also have a say in any changes, as would the state Department of Housing and Community Renewal in Albany, which administers the system.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Blauvelt

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
"I'VE been here for 22 years and I still feel like a newcomer," said Eileen Larkin, a Councilwoman who represents the hamlet of Blauvelt in Rockland County. "There are so many people who have been here for generations. Unless you're a member of one of the founding families, you feel like you just arrived."
And Kimball Parker, whose family moved to Blauvelt in 1954, just before the construction boom of the 50's and 60's, shares that view. 
 As a child, he remembers, he played in cornfields, cabbage patches and sand pits.
""When the subdivisions started to go up around us," he said, "I felt like they were taking away my playground."
To most casual observers, today's Blauvelt, while a typical suburban community in many ways, retains much of its rural quality. That is a result, in large part, of strict zoning; a minimum size lot is one-third of an acre and many houses sit on one acre or more.
The community takes in part of the 600-acre Blauvelt State Park, which stretches over the top of Clausland Mountain with commanding views of Tappan Zee Bay, the Hudson Valley and Hackensack Valley.
"Of all the villages and hamlets in the Town of Orangetown, Blauvelt probably has the least turnover," said Frank A. Fornario, a part-time realtor and a county legislator for Orangetown. "The people who move to Blauvelt are often moving up from some other Rockland communities. They want the quality of life, and once they come in they tend to stay."
Many of the residents originally came from New York City, a migration that is still going on.
Barbara Melfi, her husband, Thomas, and their 11-year-old daughter moved in November from Brooklyn. "We really moved for our daughter's sake," said Ms. Melfi. "We heard the schools were good and we knew it was a beautiful area."
Mr. Melfi, a route salesman for an ice cream company who had worked in Rockland County, was familiar with Blauvelt.
One of the attractions of Rockland County is its low-cost housing, relative to Westchester County or Long Island. "We were looking in the $200,000 to $250,000 range," Ms. Melfi said. "A lot of the houses at that price weren't in great shape." It took a while, but they finally found a Cape Cod they liked.
Most of Blauvelt's homes are ranches, Cape Cods and colonials built in the 50's and 60's and priced in the mid-$200,000's, according to Mr. Fornario.
"You can still get a house for under $200,000, but it will probably need a lot of work," he said.
There is also a smattering of older homes, including the highest concentration of Colonial-era Dutch sandstone homes in Rockland County, which is what brought Shirley Pederson to Blauvelt from nearby Pearl River in 1957.
"I WAS brought up in New England and always lived in older houses," Ms. Pederson said.
She and her husband, Emil, bought a dilapidated sandstone house on South Western Highway that once belonged to Johannes J. Blauvelt, a descendant of one of the area's founding families. The house was built in 1755, with several wings added over the next 100 years. The Pedersons had to rebuild the interior, fitting in walls around the original beam work.
Up the road from the Pedersons is the Blauvelt Free Library, in a 1752 Dutch sandstone. It has 40,000 books and serves as a community center.
In the early 19th century, the center of village life was the Greenbush Presbyterian Church, founded in 1812. The present Gothic church, completed in 1883, is on Western Highway. Opposite it is Blauvelt's first one-room schoolhouse, built in 1809 and now headquarters of the Greenbush Little League.
According to the area's oldest history, a Dutchman named David De Vries bought 500 acres -- taking in parts of what are now Blauvelt, Tappan, Orangeburg, Piermont and part of northern New Jersey -- from the Tappan Indians around 1640. When the Dutch Governor tried to collect tribute from the Indians, a war broke out and De Vries fled to Holland.
In 1686, after the English took over, 16 families were granted land patents for De Vries's 500 acres by King James II. Founding families' names -- Van Houten, Haring, Conklin, Blauvelt and Tallman -- can still be found in local phone books.
The area was originally known as Greenbush but was changed to Blauveltville to honor Judge Cornelius I. Blauvelt, who helped finance the building of the New York and Lake Erie Railroad, which was completed in 1841, running from Piermont to Goshen through Blauvelt. It was said that when railroad workers first saw the beauty of the Blauvelt area they quit their jobs and settled there and turned to farming. Many of their descendants live in Blauvelt.
During World War II more than a million troops moved through Camp Shanks, just outside Blauvelt, in Orangeburg, before going overseas. After the war, the camp was turned into a veterans' housing project and later was subdivided for homes. Many of the former G.I.'s eventually settled in Blauvelt, which by then was well on its way to being a bedroom community for New York City.
This process was accelerated by the building of the Tappan Zee Bridge in 1955. Rockland County's population went from 81,276 in 1950 to 260,000 in 1975.
Blauvelt, which has 1,455 housing units, is still growing, although slowly.
That's by design, according to Town Supervisor Roger Pellegrini. "I feel we're at a crossroads now," he said. "Due to economics, development has slowed down, giving us time to think about how to hold on to our green space, which is really the charm of this area."
The town is spending $9 million to upgrade its sewer system. "Any more development would just tax the system further," Mr. Pellegrini said.
The only current developments are small-scale one-family projects like the Knolls, a subdivision of 16 houses averaging about 3,200 square feet with at least five bedrooms and three baths. They are priced in the $400,000's, according to Claire Merkley, sales manager for Merkley Brothers, a local builder. "Only two of the lots are unsold," she said.
The developer is planning a nearly identical eight-house subdivision.
BLAUVELT'S commercial development is concentrated along Route 303 and includes Bradley Corporate Park and several strip shopping centers with small shops and restaurants, including the Mongolian Garden and the Blauvelt Diner. Most other pursuits can be found a few miles away, such as movies in Pearl River and supermarkets in Orangeburg or Northvale, N.J. There is more extensive shopping at the Nanuet Mall, 15 miles away.
The South Orangetown Central School District has five schools, encompassing kindergarten through high school. Only the Cottage Lane School (grades 4 and 5) and the South Orangetown Middle School (6, 7, 8) are in Blauvelt.
At the Middle School is an Indian village, celebrating the lives and customs of the Tappan Indians, that was conceived and built by students, who also act as guides. The Middle School also offers foreign language study, including Spanish, French, Italian, German and Chinese.
The Tappan Zee High School in Orangeburg has a legal laboratory at which students assume all roles from attorney to court reporters in mock trials. Ninety-one percent of last June's graduating class went on to higher education.
Children may also attend the Roman Catholic, k-8, St. Catherine's School. The Middle School has the hamlet's only public swimming pool. Blauvelt also has a variety of ballfields and picnic areas.
Blauvelt residents can use the three lighted tennis courts and playing fields at the 43-acre Veterans Memorial Park in Orangeburg and the 18-hole Blue Hills Golf Course in Pearl River.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Greenbush Presbyterian Church, top left, was built in 1883. The Knolls, right, is a new 16-house development. Jacob L. Blauvelt once owned the house, left, on Western Highway. (Photographs by Eddie Hausner for The New York Times)

Except for ceiling beams and a few other identifying characteristics, the Army gutted and rebuilt the interior. When the Pedersons found it in 1957 it had been vacant 11 years and "was just a big empty space," Shirley Pederson said. The couple put up adobe walls, exposing, when possible, original beams. In 1983 the house was designated a historic site by the Historical Society of Rockland County. It is one of eight stops on its annual historical house tour.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Philadelphia Trying to Channel Parking

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
City planners have turned the spotlight on the downtown parking situation with new regulations aimed at encouraging lots and garages in some areas and discouraging them elsewhere.
They have made it harder for developers to utilize a favorite method of drawing income from land being held for future development. This, in turn, may discourage the demolition of uneconomic old buildings specifically to create parking. 
 But they have also made it easier to establish parking facilities along the northern fringe of the business district, close to Interstate 95 and the Vine Street Expressway, in the hope that drivers will park there before plunging onward to narrow and congested streets in the heart of the business district.
Philadelphia had been relatively lenient on parking regulations. Developers have encountered no difficulty in utilizing land they have been unable to reuse for parking to get temporary income.
For example, Acme Markets spent six years looking for a buyer for its headquarters building, but chose to demolish the 11-story structure at 15th and Race Streets last year, leasing the site to the Philadelphia Parking Authority for a 125-space lot.
Simultaneously, the city's inventory of covered parking facilities has grown substantially with the building surge of the 80's. The city went from 43,800 covered spaces in 1980 to 60,500 spaces in 1990, a 40 percent increase. Since then, even with the decline of private office construction, at least 2,000 more spaces have been added. The increase gave added impetus to the planners' desire to cut down on open-land parking.
Under the new set of land planning regulations, lots and garages are "acceptable as an interim use" in the areas north of Market Street, the city's north-south dividing line, as far as Vine Street four blocks away. Interim use of a site must be approved by the planning commission before existing buildings can be demolished. No street-level lot may remain for more than five years and basement-level parking in new projects is not counted as developed floor space.
But no street-level lots are allowed at all south of Chestnut Street -- one block south of Market Street -- for three blocks to Spruce Street, the boundary of the city's busiest and most historic and congested business and residential area. Nor is any new garage, except with special approval, which is considered unlikely in the district.
Part of the goal is to deter developers from razing the two- and three- story brick buildings common in the area, said Richard Lombardo, chief of project planning in the Planning Department.
In the Vine-Callowhill Streets area, north of downtown but close to Interstate 95, parking lots and garages are encouraged by excluding parking space from the bulk restrictions of the zoning envelope.
"The goal of the regulations," Mr. Lombardo said, "was to protect the smaller-scale commercial development south of Chestnut Street that was built in the 1920's and 30's, before every building needed parking."
"Most of the city's business core is in an area where parking lots are permitted," he said.
The Philadelphia actions call attention to the problem of drawing revenue from land intended for redevelopment during sometimes extremely long periods of market weakness.
As air-pollution regulations and traffic problems have curbed parking lots, developers have often tried to lease land for flea markets or low-cost tennis bubbles as interim uses. Even local gardens have sprouted on land held for development.
"A lot of downtowns have a tremendous amount of space devoted to suface parking, and it may be a transitionary phase," said Bob Dunphy, senior research director of the Urban Land Institute, a nonprofit land development research organization. "Parking is the Rodney Dangerfield of transportation -- it gets no respect, but it's critical to development."
That transition may take years or decades. One of Philadelphia's prime development spots, at Broad and Locust Streets across from the Academy of Music, was vacant for more than 20 years until a hotel opened on the site in 1983. When it was vacant it was used as surface parking.
The parking industry tried last year to get the Philadelphia Planning Commission to accept the principle that all new buildings should have on-site parking. That was rejected because of the size of the existing supply.
But in projects already planned but not built, still more on-site parking is to be produced. Hahnemann University Hospital will build an 800-space garage with room for its data center on the now vacant former site of the Philadelphia Athletic Club at Vine and Broad Streets near the downtown business core.
On Market at 19th Street, the Philadelphia office of the Linpro Corporation plans to build a second office tower to complement one completed four years ago, and a new parking garage to go with it. So far the, 45-story, 761,000-square-foot project has no garage.
Linpro has a hole in the ground at 20th and Market that was to have become an underground parking garage. It has asked for and been given a variance to fill it in as interim street-level parking lot.
The decision by Philadelphia's largest private parking company, Parkway Corporation, to expand its surface lot at 15th and Spruce Streets last year shows that site development, and new interim parking space, has proceeded even when office development has slackened.
Joseph S. Zuritsky, Parkway's president, said it spent more than $925,000 to acquire and demolish two buildings adjacent to the lot, in an area of office and theater uses and heavy residential traffic. By expanding its holdings from Spruce to Latimer Street, Parkway has made the site more attractive for future commercial construction, Mr. Zuritsky said.
The company also sees itself as a developer. In 1986, it announced plans for 300,000 square feet of residential apartments atop a garage and retail building on Walnut Street between Eighth and Ninth Streets. The garage and shops were completed but no schedule has been disclosed for the towers.
Mr. Zuritsky would give no occupancy data about the 500 spaces that Parkway owned or operated downtown. He said the industry overall had suffered during the recession because of job and shopping cutbacks, home-based telecommuters and people shifting to mass transit.
But Andrew Lenton of the planning commission said that a survey in 1990 showed that parking occupancy rates averaged 79 percent and that the rate probably had dropped since then.
According to Mr. Lenton's survey, downtown parking occupancy rates rose from 68 percent in 1980 to 79 percent in 1990. More striking was the increase in the all-day price -- from an average of $4.69 in 1980 to $8.70 in 1990.
Mr. Lombardo said the changes were a result of a comprehensive plan to revise restrictions created eight or nine years ago by a previous City Council that were inconsistent and required variances for most commercial projects outside the business district.
One element of the current plan, he said, requires landscaped screening on parking-loot frontage along major streets.

HEADLINE: Campaigning With Jim Wallwork

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
IT was 8 o'clock on a recent Wednesday morning, and a tall, gray-haired, round-shouldered man was shaking hands with men and women in the ballroom of the Sheraton Hotel in Hasbrouck Heights.
"Hi, I'm Jim Wallwork, running for governor," he said as he greeted members of the Commerce and Industry Association of New Jersey who had gathered to meet three Republicans vying for the party's nomination for governor in the June 8 primary. 
 Mr. Wallwork, a former State Senator from Essex County, started his 12-hour campaign day by arriving at the breakfast meeting a half-hour ahead of his rivals, Cary Edwards and Christine Todd Whitman, and was chatting with everyone who would stand still long enough to listen.
When the speechmaking started at about 8:35, Mr. Wallwork was the first to take the podium, wasting no time telling the 150 business executives why he was there. "I'm running for governor because I want to get government off people's backs and out of their wallets," Mr. Wallwork said. "I, like you, believe in less taxes, less spending and less government."
The essence of the speeches made by all three candidates that morning would be repeated at other events throughout the day. Mr. Edwards would talk of his experience in government as Attorney General and counsel to Gov. Thomas H. Kean as making him the most qualified person to run against Gov. Jim Florio in November.
Mrs. Whitman would talk about her "economic blueprint" as being the best bet for re-energizing the state's economy.
And Mr. Wallwork would talk about his years in the Legislature, his career in the military and his acumen in the world of business as making him the person most capable of leading the state toward the 21st century.
"I'm a conservative businessman," Mr. Wallwork said in a refrain that he would repeat many times in the day. "I know what it is to roll up my sleeves and go to work every day. I understand how important it is to provide good jobs for the working men and women of New Jersey."
During his speech, Mr. Wallwork described the centerpiece of his political platform: a vow to "roll back every dime of Governor Florio's tax increase" by trimming $2.2 billion from the state budget over the next four years.
In the question-and-answer period after the candidates' introductory remarks, Mr. Wallwork explained that he would accomplish his goal by cutting the state budget by 4 percent a year in each of the next four years. He will do that, he said, by streamlining state government.
 
'You Need a Businessman'
 "You need a businessman who has operated a business and who will run the state government like a business," he said.
By 10 o'clock the meeting was over, and Mr. Edwards and Mrs. Whitman had headed off to other campaign stops. Mr. Wallwork retreated to the hotel restaurant to be interviewed for a cable television show.
While the camera operator prepared for the taping, Mr. Wallwork chatted with Julie Bidello, a television reporter for Vision Cable in Palisades Park. In what appeared to be a subtle shift in roles, however, Mr. Wallwork asked a steady stream of questions of his interviewer.
 
A Campaigner's Greetings
 Though he appeared uncomfortable sitting well forward in his chair, Mr. Wallwork seemed genuinely engaged in his conversation with Mrs. Bidello. He touched on many of the same points he had addressed at the breakfast meeting.
After the interview, Mr. Wallwork headed out of the hotel, stopping to shake hands with employees and patrons he passed on the way.
"Hi," he would say to each in their turn. "I'm Jim Wallwork, running for governor."
James L. Wallwork, 62 years old, was born in Belleville, where he lived until he was 8 and his family moved to Montclair. He attended the Montclair public schools and graduated from Montclair High School in June 1948.
"Seven days later I was up in West Point as a cadet," he said, sitting in his shirtsleeves in the back of the 1993 station wagon he uses for his campaign. He was heading toward his next campaign stop, in Aberdeen.
After graduating from West Point in 1952, he was stationed in Germany as company commander of a combat engineering group. After completing his tour of duty, he served in the National Guard with the rank of major.
Courteous and slightly formal in manner, Mr. Wallwork wears his military experience like a badge, attributing his success in business to his West Point training.
"It teaches you discipline," he said. "It teaches you to concentrate on your mission."
 
Start in the Legislature
 Stopping for coffee at a service area on the Garden State Parkway in Essex County, Mr. Wallwork talked of his successful election to the State Assembly in 1963. It was at the same time that he met Lark Lataner, who was writing an article about him for a magazine. They have been married for 28 years and have a daughter, Lyric Wallwork Winik, who lives in Maryland.
In 1967 Mr. Wallwork was elected to the State Senate, where he served until 1981.
He said that during his 16 years in the Legislature, he was guided in large part by the military code of honor drilled into him as a cadet at West Point.
"You don't lie; you don't cheat; you don't steal," he said. "You are what you are 24 hours a day."
 
Recognized by Residents
 During the brief stop at the parkway service station, two residents of the area recognized Mr. Wallwork and stopped to say hello. The first, Daniel Ward, knew the candidate from his days as the owner of Wallwork Brothers Inc., a West Caldwell-based company that he sold in 1990.
"How do I make a contribution to the campaign?" Mr. Ward said, shaking Mr. Wallwork's hand. The candidate was quick to hand him a brochure containing the address and telephone number of his campaign headquarters in Short Hills.
A few minutes later, Nicholas Caputo of Rochelle Park approached Mr. Wallwork and said, "I campaigned for you way, way back."
Mr. Wallwork shook his hand and gave him a brochure. "Did you know I'm running for governor?" he asked.
Mr. Caputo replied: "I know. And I'm voting for you."
 
Another Early Arrival
 At 11:30 Mr. Wallwork arrived at the Garden Manor in Aberdeen for a "candidates' forum" sponsored by the Matawan Rotary Club. Again, he was a half-hour ahead of his opponents and spent the time shaking hands with waiters, waitresses and Rotarians.
After a brief interview with a reporter for a local newspaper, Mr. Wallwork joined Mr. Edwards and Mrs. Whitman on the dais. When it was his turn to speak, he returned to the theme of using his legislative experience and business savvy to streamline government.
"I know the nuts and bolts of state government," he said. "And I would bring business techniques to the office of governor."
Mr. Wallwork also described other changes he would make, including establishing a "free market" for automobile insurance in which competition would encourage lower premiums, and requiring a 60 percent "supermajority" of legislators to pass any tax increases.
In addition, he said, he would push for legislation that would establish 12-year term limitations on all state, county and municipal offices, and would favor a prohibition against "double-dippers" -- people who hold two public offices at the same time.
 
'Golden Political Trough'
 "The politicians have been feeding at the golden political trough for far too long," he said. "I don't think it's fair and I don't think it's proper."
Later, Mr. Wallwork was approached by a man who neatly illustrated the capricious nature of primary election politics.
"If you're successful, we're behind you," said Carmen Stoppiello, the Mayor of Union Beach and a Monmouth County Freeholder, explaining that if Mr. Wallwork won the primary, he would support him against Mr. Florio. Mr. Stoppiello's preference in the primary, however, was displayed on his chest in the form of a Whitman badge.
At 1:55 Mr. Wallwork was back in his station wagon, heading to Cedar Knolls for an interview with ABC News and with radio station WMTR. Walking in the front door of the WMTR studio, Mr. Wallwork introduced himself to the receptionist and then, continuing down a corridor, introduced himself to a man who was painting the hallway.
"Hi, I'm Jim Wallwork, running for governor," he said, shaking the man's paint-stained hand.
"Everyone's important," Mr. Wallwork said later.
 
TV and Radio Interviews
 Before the radio interview began, Mr. Wallwork was interviewed by Pat Dawson for "The ABC Evening News." Mr. Dawson asked him what prompted him to enter the race for governor.
Mr. Wallwork said he first thought about running when he heard that both Mr. Edwards and Mrs. Whitman had voluntarily disclosed that they had employed illegal aliens. He talked to his wife about it, he said, "slept on it" for a night, and then the next morning decided to run.
"I said to my wife, 'Look, I want to be a player; I'm not going to sit on the sidelines and complain,' " Mr. Wallwork said.
After the television interview, Mr. Wallwork went into a recording studio to tape an interview for the WMTR radio program "Insight." Bob Neil, the program host, asked Mr. Wallwork what distinguished him from the other candidates.
"Frankly, Mrs. Whitman doesn't know business," he said. And of Mr. Edwards he said: "Cary is really a lawyer. He never ran a business. I think there's no substitute for 25 years of business experience."
During the interview Mr. Wallwork also explained that he supports initiative and referendum, whereby voters can initiate legislation through the voting booth, and privatization of state services like the Division of Motor Vehicles and the Department of Transportation.
Mr. Wallwork ended the interview on a confident note.
"It's going to be a close race between Florio and me," he said. "We're going to give the citizens of New Jersey a clear choice."
 
A Dinner Before a Dinner
 At 4:15 Mr. Wallwork, who had been on the go since 5:30 in the morning, returned to his home in Far Hills to have a quiet dinner with his wife.
Later that evening, Mr. and Mrs. Wallwork drove to the Morris County Golf Club to for a dinner meeting with the New Jersey Society of Surgeons.
Mr. Wallwork drew applause from the group when he told them he would appoint a practicing or teaching New Jersey physician as health commissioner. He also pledged that he would appoint an insurance commissioner who would focus on limiting medical malpractice premiums and who would curb reviews of physicians' health-care decisions by insurance companies.
"You all know of the wasted hundreds of hours doctors spend explaining to an unqualified reviewer why a patient stayed in a hospital eight days instead of seven or why one medication was selected rather than another," he said.
 
The 'Pizazz' Factor
 Dr. Adolph Wichman of Boonton, one of those in attendance, told a colleague: "I'll vote for the guy. As far as I'm concerned, he hit all the issues on the nose."
Dr. Wichman had one criticism of Mr. Wallwork, however. "His style as a politician is a bit lacking," he said. "I'd like to see him have a little more pizazz."
In fact, throughout the day Mr. Wallwork was the only one of the candidates who relied extensively on written notes for his speeches. Except when answering questions extemporaneously, he looked out at the audience only occasionally. He delivered his prepared speeches in a tone bereft of variation.
"I'm not a showman; I'm a businessman," he said when told of Dr. Wichman's observation about his lack of "pizazz."
"I think that as I move down the campaign trail, I'll probably improve my style," Mr. Wallwork said at the end of a grueling 12-hour day of campaigning. "But right now I'm concentrating on the issues."

HEADLINE: The Big Bang That Never Was

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
NEARLY a decade ago, when Japanese manufacturers were looking invincible and huge trade surpluses were starting to pile up here, the Government sought to place Japan at the forefront of a new realm: international finance. Tokyo declared that its financial markets would be thrown open, making this the third leg of the global order, along with London and New York.
The Government promised a step-by-step freeing of Japan's minutely regulated markets. The final blow to the old system -- the rough equivalent of London's "Big Bang" in 1986 -- was to have come last month, when the barriers preventing the many kinds of banks and securities houses here from competing with each other were to be lifted. 
 But if Tokyo had its own version of the Big Bang, hardly anyone heard it. Numerous impediments were left in place, and in some cases the Government even appears to be backpedaling on its commitment to eliminate its interference in the country's coddled financial system.
Many Japanese as well as foreign bankers, brokers and other experts are shaking their heads in disappointment, wondering how the country with the largest pool of investment capital, the largest banks and securities houses and the second-largest stock market has remained so defiantly out of step with international trends toward financial liberalization. How, they ask, can a country that boasts the most technologically advanced manufacturers retain a cumbersome financial system that is a throwback?
The heart of the problem, experts say, is that the Government cannot let go. It started down the road to deregulation, then seized on the stock market crash and a series of scandals to reassert itself. The Finance Ministry admits, without apology, that the philosophical winds have shifted.
"In my personal opinion, the age of laissez-faire policy is over," said Eisuke Sakakibara, a senior official in the International Finance Bureau. "In the mid-1980's, this Reagan-Thatcher deregulatory movement was in full swing and this affected the mentality of the authorities here as well. We did not want the Tokyo markets to lag behind other markets."
He added that Tokyo would eliminate unnecessary regulations when appropriate -- but only on its own terms.
 
Finding a New Base
 The reversal has irritated foreign banks and securities houses trying to make headway in Japan. No one is talking about leaving Tokyo, but many companies -- from CS First Boston to Merrill Lynch and the Bank of America -- have already moved their Asian headquarters to Hong Kong, which is a smaller but significantly freer market.
But experts say the shift has a deeper significance as well. Financial liberalization touches on the more fundamental issues of the openness and fairness of Japan's economy. The debate over protectionism has tended to focus on computer chips, construction contracts, rice and the like. But some Japanese and foreign experts say the reluctance to open Japan's financial system and turn it into "the London of Asia," as had been promised, raises questions about whether foreigners, be they financial institutions or manufacturers, will ever be able to compete on equal terms with the Japanese.
This is one reason Lawrence E. Summers, the Undersecretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said in his confirmation hearing in March that the Clinton Administration was targeting the removal of financial barriers in Japan as a major policy goal. Mr. Summers commented, as other experts have, that these regulations could provide Japanese manufacturers with an unfair advantage by giving them access to capital at cheaper rates than their foreign rivals could get.
To be sure, the Government has taken some important steps toward opening the financial markets. It has permitted foreign brokers to join the Tokyo Stock Exchange, opened the Government bond market to foreign securities houses, created a stock index and bond futures market and freed banks to set interest rates on deposits.
But that has made the signs of heavier regulation even more glaring, many here say. Under the changes that took place on April 1, for instance, only a few Japanese banks were permitted to underwrite bonds, but no banks may trade bonds or deal in equities.
The Finance Ministry has permitted tough new restrictions on stock-index futures. These restrictions, and proposals for more, loom as a possible trade issue with the United States, since dealing in stock index futures is a major source of profits for American brokerage houses here.
The corporate bond market remains underdeveloped because of regulations that make it expensive to issue such bonds and almost impossible to trade them. Managing pension-fund money is still mostly closed to newcomers, domestic or foreign.
 
Calling the Shots
 With the stock market in the midst of a long slump, the ministry decreed nearly two years ago a virtual halt to new public issues of stock, rather than allowing investors to decide whether they wanted to buy. There were three new offerings of shares last year, which raised the equivalent of $36 million, compared with 227 offerings that raised $52 billion in 1989. And the Government intervened in the shaky stock market last fall. Institutions were pressured not to sell shares and Government-controlled pension funds have bought more than $25 billion of stocks to prop up prices.
"They had a glimpse of an open market, and then they flinched," said John S. Wadsworth Jr., formerly the president of Morgan Stanley's Japan operations who has moved his base to Hong Kong, as head of the newly formed Morgan Stanley (Asia). "They didn't like what they saw."
Added Maynard Toll, who runs CS First Boston in Japan, "In our business we're used to making decisions based on the economic facts placed in front of you. Then you come to this place and all that is thrown into question. One wave of the Government wand can change anything. It's very frustrating."
Major banks and securities houses are reassessing Tokyo's role as a financial hub for another reason: Japanese institutions have lost their taste for international investments.
Japanese investors sent abroad hundreds of billions of dollars during the 1980's, buying everything from huge sums of Treasury bonds to Rockefeller Center and Pebble Beach Country Club -- and giving lots of business to foreign banks and brokers in the process. But they have grown surprisingly stingy in recent years. Japan made $28 billion in long-term investments abroad last year, compared with $136 billion in 1987.
That shift, along with the outrageous level of costs here, has made business even tougher.
"A lot of companies should consider whether to open up in Hong Kong rather than in Tokyo," said Jackson Tai, head of Asia operations for J. P. Morgan & Company. "The growth rates are far more compelling in the rest of Asia."
 
Investor Indifference
 But more than just financial institutions are losing their enthusiasm for Japan. Foreign companies seeking to float bonds or find Japanese buyers for their shares are giving up because of the complex regulatory rules, the expense and the indifference of investors.
Ten foreign companies have withdrawn their listings on the Tokyo Stock Exchange because of the lack of interest by Japanese investors. Among them: General Motors, Philips, Kmart and Avon.
"In terms of supplying funds to the world, this is a very important market; in fact, it is increasing in importance," said Shoichi Royama, dean of the economics department at Osaka University. "The problem is that Tokyo is not as liquid or as advanced as New York or London. Tokyo is definitely behind, farther behind than we expected it would be by this time."
Such concern amounts to a basic reassessment of the role Japan will play in the international markets and of whether the Finance Ministry can ever really loosen its grip.
"The Ministry of Finance believes the financial business is different from any other industry," said Yoshihiko Miyauchi, president of the Orix Corporation, Japan's largest leasing and financial company. "They spoke of liberalization, but the philosophy behind that was always different from what you mean by a free-market system. They believe that the critical part of financial management should not be left to the market. It was just a matter of degree, of loosening control a small amount."
The mixed success of financial liberalization has set off a lively debate about what Japan gains, or loses, from protecting its financial markets. Classical economists say Japan is the loser, arguing that its markets are less efficient at providing capital to the most able companies.
 
A Big Advantage
 But other economists contend that the system gives Japanese industries a big advantage over their foreign competitors, not only providing them with capital at lower rates but with fewer demands for quick returns, effectively subsidizing their expansion into global markets.
"The strong competitiveness of Japanese companies in world markets can be largely attributed to their low cost of capital -- which was significantly lower than the cost of capital for American companies," wrote Masasuke Ide of the Nomura Research Institute in a report last year.
The pressure for change came from the United States, which fought with Japan until an agreement was reached in early 1984 for the Finance Ministry to open Japan's markets. Soon after, the authorities made a virtue of a necessity, embracing financial liberalization.
"The issue of deregulation and internationalization of the Tokyo market can now be considered to have entered a new stage, moving from a time of catching up with the leading markets to unification with these markets," Tomomitsu Oba, a former vice minister of finance, wrote in an upbeat essay six years ago.
But the stock market crash, starting in 1990, and then the financial scandals here made regulators reconsider and cast a new light on the basic nature of the Japanese system.
"The basic point is simple," said Takaaki Wakasugi, a professor of finance at Tokyo University. "In the late 1980's the Tokyo market grew so big, but it was just a matter of size, not quality. We were still second or third class in terms of real financial capability. People here said we were world class based on this mistaken look just at our size."
But that size was hit hard. From the stock market's peak at the end of 1989, to its bottom, last August, it lost 60 percent of its value, wiping out more than $3 trillion from portfolios. And a sharp decline in land prices left banks holding tens of billions of dollars in overdue loans, creating a sense of crisis.
"The collapse of the bubble economy has had some impact on the Ministry of Finance, there's no question about that," Mr. Sakakibara conceded. "But it's true in New York and London, too. There has been some rethinking of deregulation, some appreciation of the fact that proper supervision must accompany deregulation. I want to stress that this is not only a Japanese phenomenon."
Whether it is or not, most financial experts here agree that Japan has not come close to living up to some of its promises. The Quick Research Institute here reported in a study that of 25 financial products routinely available in New York and London, only 12 are available in Japan. There are still no individual stock options, junk bonds, floating-rate notes or medium-term notes, for instance.
"An individual Japanese has fewer tools to manage his money here than in any other developed country," said James M. Walsh, head of Prudential Securities here.
The Big Four securities houses -- Nomura, Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi -- underwrite more than 70 percent of the securities issued in Japan, making them a sort of cartel, foreign firms complain. Meanwhile, the amount of loans here by foreign banks has dropped to 9 trillion yen as of March 31, compared with 12 trillion yen two years earlier, another indication of the sour atmosphere.
 
Longer Timetable
 Discontent is clear in a recent survey of foreign banks and securities houses by the Japan Center for International Finance. In a survey four years ago, the foreign institutions predicted that Tokyo would overtake London as a center for international financial dealings within five years. But this time the foreign institutions said Tokyo had no hope of catching up within the next five years.
"You have an ironic situation," said Takuma Takahashi, an economist at the Nomura Research Institute and author of a book on the rise and fall of international financial centers. "Eastern Europe is moving finally toward a market economy, but in Japan it's been the opposite. There's more Government control."
And it is not just the Government that is shifting gears. Other Japanese institutions have been reassessing what they got out of the rush to internationalize and whether an open financial system is worth the risks.
"We're very fond of that word, internationalization, but we're wondering what it really means," said Hisao Kobayashi, managing director at the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, the world's largest commercial bank. "It actually helped the growth of the Japanese economy, and we should not neglect that fact. But the environment has changed and so the system has changed."
 
 
 
THE OSAKA AFFAIR: TOKYO GETS TOUGH
 OSAKA
This city in western Japan was once the heart of the country's commercial life, but it has slipped deeper and deeper into Tokyo's shadow in recent decades. It was thus regarded here as a coup when the sleepy Osaka Stock Exchange recaptured some of its lost glory by becoming the center for trading stock index futures contracts.
The popularity of the Nikkei index future took the Tokyo establishment by surprise after its introduction in 1988, and became particularly nettlesome when it turned into a moneymaker for foreign securities houses. Firms like Morgan Stanley, Salomon Brothers and Goldman Sachs used the index futures to conduct program trading and other strategies that Japanese firms had not learned.
So Tokyo flexed its muscles, citing complaints from the Tokyo Stock Exchange that the Nikkei futures hastened the stock decline after 1990. A stock index future permits an investor to bet on the movement of the broad market, based on a basket of many stocks, rather than on individual stocks.
Since the decline, the authorities have imposed measures to quash futures trading, including increasing the margin, or downpayment, an investor must make when purchasing a futures contract to 30 percent of the value, from 9 percent in 1988. The pace of change in futures prices has been slowed so much that when the stock market grows volatile, the futures market effectively shuts down.
"The problem is quite political," said Shoichi Royama, dean of the economics department at Osaka University. "They're jealous of the success of the Osaka market."
Meanwhile, one beneficiary of the clampdown has been the Singapore International Monetary Exchange, or Simex, which also trades a Nikkei stock index future.
While average daily trading volume on the Osaka exchange hit a peak in 1991, and then tailed off when the restrictions were put in place, volume has picked up in Singapore, where 16,071 contracts were traded on average each day in the first three months of this year, compared with 3,045 contracts a day in 1991.
The Japanese authorities failed to persuade Simex to adopt similar restrictions. "They expected us to adopt the same standards, which were intended mainly to depress interest in futures," said Ang Swee Tian, president of Simex. "I think we would find it very hard to agree to that."
The irony, said Mr. Royama, is that the stock index futures have been leading the Tokyo market's rebound.

 
 
THE FOREIGNERS CUT BACK
 WITH the financial atmosphere getting tougher in Japan, many foreign banks and brokers have responded with their first cuts here and have even moved some operations out of Japan.
Salomon Brothers Asia, for instance, had a staff of 600 at its peak a couple of years ago, but now is trying to whittle that to 510. Prudential Securities has reduced its staff to 90 from 275 three years ago, and has closed one of its two branches. Merrill Lynch Japan has said it remains committed to Japan, but it is closing three of its six retail branches in the country and the head of its Asian operations has moved to Hong Kong from Tokyo.
County Natwest Securities, an arm of Britain's National Westminster Bank, sold its Tokyo Stock Exchange membership recently, the first foreign firm here to do so. Foreign brokers, permitted to join the exchange only since 1986, were clamoring for seats a few years ago.
Disappointment over the pace at which the financial markets are opening here is not the only problem cited. The enormous costs of doing business in Japan -- commercial rents are astronomical despite a recent property market slump, and senior foreign executives routinely live in homes that rent for $15,000 to $60,000 a month -- were ignored when the markets were perceived to be opening. But now those costs are regarded as a burden.
"The expense level in Tokyo is just too high, and being in Hong Kong puts us closer to our big thrust into China," said Larry Greenberg, formerly the head of the Japanese operations of the Bank of America and now the Hong Kong-based head of Asian commercial banking. "When you're in Hong Kong you're a part of everything that's happening in this part of the world."

HEADLINE: At Work;
Busting the American Dream

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
That giant sucking sound you hear is the audio portion of Bill Clinton's popularity going south. Maybe the Balkans are in flames, the recovery is guttering out and Mr. Clinton's chief of staff needs to start carding his new hires. But those are not the only reasons Mr. Clinton's ratings are going phttt! He is taking the hit for business-as-usual, filibustering Washington, which seems not to have noticed that many Americans feel the country is adrift and that they think their feelings, like the Velveteen Rabbit, are really real.
As Mr. Clinton looks for ways to regain his Administration's composure, he could start by sending several cartons of Katherine S. Newman's new book, "Declining Fortunes: The Withering of the American Dream" (Basic Books), over to the Hill and down to the lobbyists on K Street. Ms. Newman, an anthropologist, spent many months talking with 60 or so intergenerational families in a suburban New Jersey town she calls "Pleasanton," both to disguise its identity and to indicate that it stands in for communities across the country. She learned that high anxiety about the future has become the permanent existential state of young and youngish suburban middle-class Americans. 
 Ms. Newman's central finding is no longer unfamiliar: That bulging demographic cohort born from 1946 to 1964, the baby boom, is likely to be the first American generation that will not live as well as its parents. What Ms. Newman does, sympathetically and in clear nonacademic prose, is to put texture to what could be viewed as petty fears and frustrations. She fulfills one of the prime anthropological directives: to explore the cultural terrain between belief and behavior, image and reality, what people say they believe and what they actually do.
At the root of the baby boomers' malaise, Ms. Newman argues, is the mythology surrounding their parents' generation: children of the Great Depression whose lives were touched directly or indirectly by World War II. They came home from war, bunked with their parents until Mr. Levitt built what would become the suburbs, put on their gray flannel suits or maternity dresses and went to work or stayed home, taking Miltown and having the next generation. They were, in their own view, hard workers who endured hard times, sacrificed and, because of that, ultimately prospered.
There is truth to that version of events, but through nothing more profound than being born at the propitious time. The World War II generation also was the primary beneficiary of the public works projects of the Depression, the huge postwar economic expansion and a mad explosion of real estate values. In recounting their stories, Ms. Newman said during a recent interview at Columbia University, her academic home, "people subtract large factors."
As Ms. Newman points out, two of the critical elements of the American dream, an education and a home, were made possible for people who would have had neither without Government subsidies, in the form of the G.I. Bill and low-interest mortgages. The rise in real estate values turned many relatively modest homes into equity worth hundreds of thousands of dollars. Houses bought with low-interest mortgages were the basis of social mobility and affluence -- and, now, the postwar generation's extremely comfortable retirement, thank you very much. "On virtually all counts," Ms. Newman writes, "it was better to have reached adulthood by the early 1950's than at almost anytime afterward."
The boomers, by contrast, don't quite know what hit them. "They want to know why the gravy train stopped before it reached them," Ms. Newman said.
The older generation is sympathetic enough to recognize that their grown children's struggles are real and that the necessities of life like housing and transportation are more expensive than they used to be. But they don't quite get why hard work doesn't do for the children what it did for them, and many of them think their kids are spoiled. "Our children go on vacation several times a year," one parent tells Ms. Newman. "We didn't go on any vacation for about 10 years after we were married. . . . We were never poor or hungry, but we didn't have all the things that our children take for granted." Defer a vacation, forgo a night out. Prosperity will come.
Boomers may have a collective attitude problem -- though they are by no means a monolithic generation -- but that's hardly the real trouble. The generation is simply too big for the opportunities available to it: too many boomers chasing too few jobs, schools and livable neighborhoods and watching the country's infrastructure decay.
Somewhat incredibly, given the activism of at least the older boomers there has been little anger or political reaction against the parental generation, which by all accounts is the single most powerful interest group in the country. Boomers may be relatively quiet because they know the United States is a rich country and that in many basic ways they are fortunate.
Knowing they are better off than the starving masses of the childhood dinner table does not necessarily lessen their sense of betrayal and unease. "They know something is deeply wrong," Ms. Newman said. "They would like to think Clinton can fix it." But, she added, "They don't believe in the halcyon days."
 
 
 
'SPEAK TO THE ISSUES THAT MATTER'
 Katherine S. Newman violates anthropological norms. She does her research not abroad but in the suburbs, where half the American population lives. In a field notorious for celebrating the ethereal, she thinks it's important to "speak to issues that matter in our society."
The middle class matters hugely in this country, and Ms. Newman is well on her way to becoming its pre-eminent chronicler. "I look through anthropological eyes at the impact broad economic trends have on the lives of ordinary people," she said. Her earlier book, "Falling From Grace: The Experience of Downward Mobility in the American Middle Class," detailed the lives and tough times of unemployed high-wage blue- and white-collar workers. Like much of "Declining Fortunes," "Falling From Grace" is about individuals coping with forces beyond their control. Despite their best efforts, the workers are unable to retain what they have achieved.
Ms. Newman is a sympathetic observer, but, based on the intractability of the current downturn, not an optimistic one: "I'm without much confidence that this is temporary."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Katherine S. Newman, the author of a new book on middle-class malaise. (Eddie Hausner/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: T.W.A.'s Bumpy Flight Back

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Whatever the fate of Trans World Airlines, this much is certain: There is no lack of can-do enthusiasm among its employees for reviving the bankrupt carrier, once ranked among the world's best.
Pilots dipped into their wallets to buy billboard advertisements, and are chatting up the airline to travel agents long disenchanted with it. Workers bought sweatshirts proclaiming, "We're Comin' Back." In Kansas City, Mo., they posted a sign outside an overhaul base that reads, 
 "It's ours now, let's work smarter."
Add a slew of strategy shifts, and the airline's top managers are talking about a rebound for their hobbled airline, particularly after its revenue per passenger jumped 15 percent in the first quarter, while the industry overall stood roughly flat.
"We have a classic turnaround under way," said Glenn R. Zander. He and Robin Wilson were appointed by T.W.A.'s creditors and workers to manage the airline after Carl C. Icahn ceded control in January.
Early signs of their performance will come clearer in the next few days, when the airline is expected to announce its first-quarter results.
But thus far, talk of a turnaround has met with skepticism; many analysts doubt that T.W.A. will survive another year. "They have an impossible task ahead of them," said Kevin C. Murphy, airlines analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Indeed, if and when the carrier emerges from bankruptcy this summer, it will have a thin cash cushion -- roughly $200 million -- leaving it in a fragile position should the industry wage a grueling fare war or should fuel prices spike. Neither is expected, but neither can be ruled out. And T.W.A. remains weighed down by $1 billion in debt, although it has shed an equal amount and cut its debt service payments by more than a third.
Furthermore, many analysts consider T.W.A.'s projections through 1997, which assume a 5 percent annual growth rate, optimistic. The company, for example, assumes the price of jet fuel will rise just 2.5 cents a gallon over five years.
"T.W.A. has given itself the benefit of every assumption, but life is often not as charitable as that," said Phillip Brannon, a high-yield bond analyst at Mabon Securities. The value of T.W.A. bonds has fluctuated in recent months, but in general reflects "a limited measure of confidence" in the carrier, he added. For example, $265.1 million worth of 17.25 percent senior subordinated notes issued in 1988 have traded between $22 and $26 since January, and were trading at $26 late Friday.
Other challenges include T.W.A.'s route structure, focused on its hubs in St. Louis, New York's Kennedy Airport and Atlanta, which pit it against tough competitors. Its list of international destinations is considered fair, but sorely lacking after Mr. Icahn sold off such key routes as the highly prized J.F.K.-to-Heathrow route.
A poor public image, fueled in part by the oldest fleet of the major domestic carriers, is also difficult to change. The image is darkened by the cloud of bankruptcy that has hung over the carrier since January 1992. Many travel agents and travelers shun bankrupt carriers.
Questions were raised about T.W.A.'s survival in recent weeks, after some boilerplate language in legal documents warned of possible liquidation, leading to overblown newspaper and trade press headlines.
"It's very frustrating," Mr. Zander said, adding, particularly because T.W.A. has lined up the pieces for a solid recovery.
And some analysts share his view. Michael W. Derchin, airlines analyst of Natwest Securities, calls T.W.A. a "born again" carrier, a label he also applies to Continental, which emerged last month from bankruptcy for the second time. Both carriers, he said, have low operating costs and are attempting to rebuild themselves while their larger competitors are trying to shrink themselves to profitable core operations.
T.W.A.'s Comfort Class program is working precisely as planned, Mr. Zander said, even though it cost the carrier some seats. The passengers T.W.A. is attracting with the program, in which it added about two inches of leg room per seat in coach class, are more than making up for those turned away on full flights.
"WE have a higher proportion of business travelers paying higher fares," Mr. Zander said. The airline's new strategy contrasts with Mr. Icahn's discount-store approach of trying to fill planes by cutting fares, a miscalculation in that he failed to anticipate his competitors would follow his cuts.
T.W.A. has also lowered its expenses, winning $660 million in employee concessions over three years, for example, and is no doubt enjoying the bidding war to attract its headquarters, currently in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., near Mr. Icahn's home.
In Missouri, for example, Governor Mel Carnahan signed legislation on Monday to save the airline $28 million through 1996 on state sales tax. The airline is considering St. Louis, where its domestic hub is located; Kansas City, Mo., site of an overhaul base and an administrative center, and Queens, N.Y., near Kennedy Airport.
The carrier is also weeding out its older aircraft and leasing newer models that are less expensive to operate and maintain. The strategy has proved timely, because the industry's excess capacity has depressed aircraft leasing rates.
EMPLOYEE morale and service have improved, reflected to some degree in Government statistics tracking airline performance. Although T.W.A. had the highest consumer complaint rate of the nine major airlines in March, it is improving; in January the rate was even higher. On-time and baggage handling performance were much improved in the first quarter.
Julius Maldutis, airline analyst at Salomon Brothers, said he believes T.W.A.'s service is getting much more friendly and efficient, and that service is often underestimated as a reason fliers choose a carrier. "Quality of service gets you the premium traveler, and no airline can survive without the premium traveler," he said.
Nor can an airline survive without capable managers, words often used by analysts to describe Mr. Wilson and Mr. Zander. The co-chiefs appear to have set aside any difficulties in sharing the chief executive's responsibilities. "Neither of us are possessed of a particularly large ego," Mr. Zander said. "We have an interest in seeing T.W.A. prosper, and we have no real hidden agendas."
Unlike Mr. Icahn, who had no previous airline experience, both men have long ties to T.W.A. Mr. Wilson, 56 years old, was chosen by employees. An operations man with 17 years experience at T.W.A., since 1988 he had been chief executive of GPA Technologies, a unit of the aircraft leasing company. Mr. Zander, who is 46, is the former head of finance appointed by the creditors. They have hired back several key T.W.A. executives who had left, and more are considering returning if the carrier finds a profitable niche.
But that is a big if. The airline has said it is seeking alliances with foreign carriers, although it declined to name any. Separately, some analysts have speculated that USAir and its partner, British Airways, might be tempted to acquire T.W.A.'s assets. The management team may also be changed -- perhaps making one of the two executives the boss, or perhaps bringing in an outsider -- upon the airline's departure from bankruptcy.
The uncertainty over the airline's future does not appear to weigh too heavily on Mr. Zander or Mr. Wilson. After all, Mr. Zander said, many of the people who predicted in 1992 that T.W.A. would be gone this year have moved the guessing game into 1994.
"Now they are saying, 'Will they make it through the winter?' " Mr. Zander said. "We've done better than anybody thought we would do."

 
 
IT'S ALL IN THE LEGROOM
 The survival of T.W.A. has been questionable for some time, but in its bid to leave bankruptcy this summer the carrier has given all those people who have made cramped legroom the No. 1 complaint on passenger surveys reason to cheer it on.
T.W.A. is trying a strategy that few others are eager to copy, namely adding about two inches of legroom to each seat in coach class, where the industry standard is 30 to 32 inches from the back of a seat to the back of the one in front of it. Many other carriers have added legroom in business class, but T.W.A. is the only major airline to offer it at competitive prices in coach class.
T.W.A.'s so-called Comfort Class, in which it is also striving to improve service -- a departure from Carl C. Icahn's ill-fated effort to gain market share with lowball fares -- is lauded by passengers and consumer advocates alike. "I just hope they are around long enough to make it," said Ed Perkins, editor of Consumer Reports Travel Letter.
But some analysts join competitors in wisecracking that the carrier is moving the deck chairs on the Titanic. Competitors, not wanting to match T.W.A. in removing seats, contend that the move is economically foolish because with fewer seats they would have to raise fares to levels passengers are unwilling to pay.
T.W.A. executives dismiss the wisecracks. They project that the new business the airline attracts will more than offset those passengers it might turn away on those occasions when it could fill an entire plane. The carrier, which is filling, on average, 63 percent of its seats, removed about 8 percent systemwide, an average of nine seats from its narrow-body aircraft and 25 from its wide-body planes.

HEADLINE: It's Pay-for-Play -- Health Clubs for the Toddling Set

BYLINE: By DANIEL M. GOLD

 BODY:
CHILD'S play is becoming big business.
Gambling that parents of the growing baby boomlet are willing to pay for safe and creative places for their children to play, more commercial operators are rushing in to fill the perceived need with kiddie equivalents of health centers and fitness programs. 
 As they do so, what had previously been the province of localized or regional entrepreneurs is becoming the turf of such astute family marketers as Blockbuster Entertainment and McDonald's.
Discovery Zone, a Chicago-based chain founded in 1988, is the largest franchiser of indoor playgrounds, called Fun Centers, and is poised for a major growth spurt. At the end of March, the company was in 24 states with 64 centers -- brightly colored havens of plastic tubing, mazes, ladders, slides, netting, water mats, climbing ropes and assorted padded delights. The company says 16 more are being built while sites for another 36 are in some stage of negotiation.
Last month, Blockbuster bought a 20 percent stake in Discovery Zone and a two-year option to acquire a controlling interest after June 1994. Early next month, Discovery Zone plans an initial stock offering of 2.3 million shares, to be priced at $16 to $18 a share.
On its face, that might seem a bit much. It would raise more than $41 million for a company which, had it been a corporation instead of a partnership, would have had a net loss of $5.7 million in 1992 and an accumulated deficit of $8 million. Moreover, after the offering there will be 16.8 million shares outstanding, giving the company a valuation of $285 million, if shares average $17.
But the company plans an aggressive expansion by the end of the year, hoping to grow to 90 company-owned and 120 franchised centers in 31 states, Puerto Rico and Britain.
Going after the same market of 1-to-12-year-olds as Discovery Zone is that savviest of kid marketers, the McDonald's Corporation, which expects to have about 30 of its Leaps & Bounds play centers open by year end. Though known for its glacier-like testing methodology, McDonald's has moved uncharacteristically fast in expanding Leaps & Bounds. Its first center opened just two years ago.
"It seemed sort of natural for us," said Katherine Hartman, director of marketing at Leaps & Bounds. Still, she characterized the new openings as a test. Based at McDonald's headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill., Leaps & Bounds has operated mostly in the Midwest but plans to expand to both coasts by year end.
The older siblings of the indoor playground concept are the spate of developmental play programs, of which the leading marketer is Gymboree, of Burlingame, Calif. The company, now primarily a supplier of children's apparel, started in the mid-1970's franchising programs consisting of supervised play for children 6 months to 5 years old. With 360 licensed programs in nine countries, Gymboree's play programs bring in less than 10 percent of company revenues, said Linda Rasmussen, Gymboree's franchise president. "But it's very large in terms of good will," she added.
A score of local and regional operations with names like Playorena and Gym Dandy offer similar programs.
But it is not at all clear just how big the national appetite is for what these ventures are offering. Linda Killian, for one, an analyst with Renaissance Capital, a Greenwich, Conn., firm that tracks initial public offerings, is not convinced that pay-for-play is a necessarily sound concept.
"Retailing in general is becoming more and more kid oriented," she noted, with stores of all stripes providing more entertainment for the youngsters. "How many parents are going to want to fork over $8 for play and assorted knick-knacks for their children when a lot of entertainment is offered free in other stores while they shop?"
OTHER drawbacks are as obvious as the weather. Discovery Zone franchisees say the business ebbs and flows with the seasons, as well as the days of the week. And while all the operations stress they are not replacements for day care -- each requires that children be accompanied by an adult -- analysts say that liability coverage is onerous for those actually encouraging roughhousing among their young patrons.
Still, the commercial appeal is as easy as arithmetic. The 1990 Census found 47.4 million children 12 or younger in the United States. By the year 2000, there might be more than 51 million, more than one of every six Americans. That's a lot of quality time to fill.
"People are trying to figure out what to do with the kids," said Leo Shapiro, who heads his own market research firm in Chicago. "What these places offer is a structured environment in which the adult can feel comfortable. You're having a parent-child experience take place in a kind of amusement park. It's an extraordinarily positive experience."
On the other hand, Mr. Shapiro acknowledged, it can turn out to be "kind of negative. It's like having a kid who always wants to go to the neighbor's house. It's more interesting than at home."
AT Gymboree, franchisees hold weekly sessions, usually in neighborhood churches or community centers, with toddlers scrambling over slides and mats, see-saws and stairs for sessions up to an hour long. Sessions cost about $7 to $14 each, payable as a flat fee for a "semester" of 12 to 14 weeks.
Ms. Rasmussen contends that Gymboree doesn't really compete with indoor playgrounds. "What makes us unique is that it's a program, not just a place," she said. "You come every week, you see the same people, the same leaders, the same kids, the same parents."
Discovery Zone's Fun Centers and McDonald's Leaps & Bounds each have distinct play areas geared for toddlers, but children 4 to 9 clearly get the most fun out of the equipment. Staff members roam the area to enforce safety rules and to nip any antisocial behavior in the bud. There are arcade games for older children.
At Fun Centers, food courts and television monitors allow parents to do something else while keeping one eye on the play area. Admission is $4.95 to $6.95 per child, depending on location, for two hours of play. Parents are admitted free.
Leaps & Bounds centers operate similarly, except they charge $5.95 for each visit, with no time limit. And so far, all outlets are company owned and operated.
The Discovery Zone prospectus says a franchise costs $800,000, much of which is eaten up by the lease for sites that are generally 10,000 to 15,000 square feet.
Analysts see one likely target for expansion as shopping malls, many of which were hurt badly during the recession by tenants shuttering their doors. As a result, they have good sites available at relatively low lease rates.
Ms. Killian believes the race is to the swift -- and that favors fast-growing Discovery Zone. "If Discovery Zone is able to position itself as the child's entertainment outlet in a mall, there may be no need for other entrants," she said.
One such Discovery Zone outlet is in the Cross County Square Mall in Yonkers. With three sons 7 to 13 years old, Alice Scarborough, of Pelham, N.Y., has visited the Fun Center there a half-dozen times in 18 months. "It's a wonderful concept, especially in the doldrums of winter," she says. "The boys have a great time, there are lots of smiles and lots of sweat."
Still, between the food and tokens for the skill games, fun is not cheap. "The costs can get up there," she says.
Brochures promoting the centers emphasize that children will gain in coordination, agility and endurance from repeated visits. Whether all the activity actually makes for healthier children with improved motor skills is debatable. The most informed opinions on the subject seem to be, well, it couldn't hurt.
"It's important for kids of all ages to exercise," says Steve Guback, director of information for the President's Council on Physical Fitness. "It's just not necessary to go to these centers to get it."
 
 
 
A TINKER TOY HERITAGE
 DISCOVERY ZONE and Leaps & Bounds each developed from the idea it was time to get serious about playgrounds.
The leading chain of indoor play centers, Discovery Zone traces its roots to 1988, when Ron Matsch, a Kansas City, Mo., gymnastics coach, used 50 Tinker Toy sets to design the model for the first Fun Center.
Mr. Matsch is still with the company, in charge of research and development. But last year, Donald Flynn, a board member and major franchiser of Blockbuster Entertainment video stores, gained a controlling interest in Discovery Zone. He became chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Flynn's involvement helped attract Blockbuster, which took a 20 percent stake and made a commitment to help finance an expansion into Britain. Blockbuster chairman Wayne Huizenga and several other top Blockbuster executives are now on Discovery Zone's board.
While not nearly as aggressive as Discovery Zone, McDonald's Leaps & Bounds is staking out its own corner of the sandbox.
The company says the idea for Leaps & Bounds came to Ed Rensi, president of McDonald's USA, while he was bemoaning the lack of a playground for his grandchild.
Started in 1991 with a single operation in Naperville, Ill., Leaps & Bounds plans to expand almost weekly through the summer.
Katherine Hartman, marketing director at Leaps & Bounds, said it was purposely made a separate entity to avoid confusing children. "If they start thinking that they're going to find something in Leaps & Bounds that's at McDonald's, or vice versa, it's going to be a disappointment," she said.
But the company has used coupons at McDonald's stores to help promote the play centers.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
New Tax Policy: Losing Investors Must Pay More

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Let's hope stock prices never go down. If they do, Dan Rostenkowski and Bill Clinton have decided that the losers should pay more taxes.
A provision buried in the tax act approved by the Ways and Means Committee may make it impossible for investors unlucky enough to have capital losses ever to take tax deductions for those losses. 
 Would such a tax provision affect investor behavior? It might. To be sure, no one buys a stock expecting to take a capital loss. But this tax bill also has some unwelcome news for those who get the capital gains they wanted. Some of them would end up paying higher taxes, too.
None of that sounds like the incentives for long-term investment that candidate Clinton used to talk about, even though the bill increases the tax advantage for long-term capital gains. The top tax rate on such gains would stay at 28 percent, while the marginal tax rate on ordinary income would rise to 39.6 percent for high-income taxpayers. Relatively speaking, that makes it more attractive to own a stock on which returns will come as capital gains, than a bond or high-dividend stock that will pay ordinary income.
But a catch comes if you borrow money to buy that stock. An investor who has investment income can take tax deductions on the interest paid to finance those investments. But the new bill effectively reduces the value of that deduction for those whose investment income is capital gains. As a result, leveraged winners will pay more taxes.
As for losers, the tax law has never treated them with love. The current law says that capital losses -- what you got if you bought Philip Morris last year -- can offset capital gains but that only $3,000 a year of such losses can be deducted from ordinary income.
Wall Street has come up with ways to get around that, by locking in short-term capital gains in essentially riskless transactions. Alas, the tax bill has provisions that recharacterize the gains from those transactions as ordinary income. So the loser will bear his losses alone, while the winner shares his profits with Uncle Sam. "This is targeted at the poor guy who has losses," said Bob Gordon, the president of 21st Securities. Mr. Gordon is not objective -- he has made good money from designing such strategies -- but he has a point.
This tax bill by itself probably is not enough to make investors bail out of stocks, but it comes at a time when inflation-adjusted stock prices are at the high end of historic valuations and potentially more vulnerable even to minor disturbances. By contrast, gold is cheap from a historical perspective.
It was bad inflation news, not the tax bill, that shook up investors late last week, pushing gold up and stocks down. But even after the inflation scare passes, the tax bill might dampen investor enthusiasm for stocks. By changing the rules to make wins less valuable and losses more painful, the Government might make losses more likely.
