HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Stars That Got Lost in the Crowd

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
With oceans of money flooding mutual funds, and more and more of the most popular ones slamming the door on new investors, it hardly seems possible that a good fund could escape notice.
But in their fourth annual list of "forgotten funds," analysts at Morningstar Inc., the Chicago mutual fund researchers, have found five overlooked funds they call real winners. The funds, which each manage less than $100 million, have at least five years of track records, mostly built by the current managers. They offer what Morningstar calls "two splendid attributes -- proven managements and agile asset bases." 
 The sole bond fund in the group, Harbor Bond, has outperformed its peers by more than 2 percentage points a year, on average, for the last five years. Managers of the four stock funds, while varying markedly in stock-picking style, are all leery of today's stock market, describing it as overvalued.
* Edward Trumpbour has managed Delaware Value, which he calls a "traditional small- and mid-cap value fund," since its 1987 inception. While he looks for such usual measures as low price-to-earnings ratios, he says, "I try to buy mundane growth, in the 12 to 15 percent range, while most small-company funds look for 25 to 40 percent growth."
By focusing on what he calls "discounted growth situations," he reduces the fund's volatility and buys strong but overlooked companies. His real competition, he says, consists of corporations seeking acquisitions.
The fund's 110 or so stocks have market capitalizations ranging from a tiny $15 million to as high as $1 billion. Money has been flowing in recently, pushing assets to $93 million, more than double the level when Morningstar began compiling this list two months ago. But much of that new money remains uninvested "because it's a tough market on a valuation basis," Mr. Trumpbour said; the fund's cash level has risen to nearly 30 percent.
A trip to Hong Kong in February has led to investments there that now comprise 5 percent of the fund, including Top Form, an apparel and lingerie company, and Hong Kong Aircraft and Engineering.
* William H. Gross is manager of, among other things, a primarily institutional bond fund, Pimco Total Return, which holds more than $3 billion, and Harbor Bond, with under $100 million -- a difference Morningstar analysts attribute to a wrongheaded lack of enthusiasm on the part of investors for researching fixed-income investments.
The "forgotten" Harbor Bond owns a mix of government, corporate and mortgage issues, with an unusually high 15 percent now stashed in overseas bonds because Mr. Gross sees more opportunity in Canada and Europe than in the United States.
While he is not particularly worried about inflation picking up, Mr. Gross is sour on the stock market. Profit growth, he said, "will be decent, but we've gone too far in terms of valuations relative to foreign markets, and we're soon due for a setback."
* The Meridian Fund, in Larkspur, Calif., invests in small and mid-size growth stocks: 90 percent of its companies have $750 million or less in annual revenues and anticipated revenue growth rates of 15 percent or better, says Richard Aster, who has managed Meridian since its mid-1984 inception. Its portfolio is concentrated, holding between 20 and 40 stocks (32 at the moment), mainly in the health care, retail and technology sectors.
Mr. Aster's favorite sector today is cellular operations and paging. He likes Cellular Communications Inc. and Vanguard Cellular, two independent operators, as well as Mobile Telecommunications Inc.
One-third of the portfolio right now is in cash. "We're not market timers, but I'm having trouble buying the companies I want to buy at proper valuations," he said.
* The Phoenix Total Return Fund, in Enfield, Conn., juggles its portfolio among stocks, bonds and cash. Today's equity allocation is a low 40 percent because "there's a great deal of difficulty finding companies with good earnings at a decent price," said Phoenix's manager, Robert Milnamow, who took over the fund in late 1989. The fund owns a combination of small- and large-capitalization issues, and Mr. Milnamow's favorite area now is telecommunications, where he owns Motorola and QVC Network, a home-shopping channel.
Bonds, which can range as high as 35 percent of the fund, account for only 3 percent today because "the absolute return on bonds isn't worth the risk," he said. Given that bonds pay a premium of only 3 percentage points over cash, it's not surprising the fund's cash position is at about 60 percent today.
* The Weitz Value Fund, in Omaha, is a stock fund, "but I'm interested in absolute as well as relative return," said Wally Weitz, the fund's manager since its 1986 inception.Given that, cash holdings range as high as 35 percent, leading Morningstar analysts to call it "an unannounced balanced fund -- and a fine one at that."
Cash represents nearly one-third of the fund today because Mr. Weitz says stocks are overpriced, partly a function of investors fleeing low-yielding certificates of deposit, creating "an inflation of equity prices."
The fund has a minimum investment of $25,000. Its biggest sector now is cable television, which Mr. Weitz says is "mispriced because of the legal uncertainties." Among his holdings: Time Warner, Telecommunications Inc. and the Comcast Corporation.

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
H-P's New Laser: Smaller, Cheaper but Not Faster

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company's new Laserjet 4L personal laser printer, for DOS and Windows computers, is better and cheaper than its popular predecessor, the Laserjet IIP. At a suggested list price of $849, and a probable discounted price of $650, the 4L might be the laser that blasts dot-matrix printers into oblivion.
Hewlett-Packard plans to deliver another version of the printer, called the Laserjet 4ML (list price $1,279, with a likely street price of about $999), for Macintosh computers and those PC users who use the powerful Adobe Postscript Level 2 software. The 4ML will come with more than 50 extra type fonts (80 fonts in all, compared with 26 in the 4L). 
 For many executives the 4L and 4ML may be inexpensive enough to justify, finally, having a personal laser printer.
"These are convenience printers for people who want to attach a printer directly to their PC and be able to bring a page out whenever they need it," said Jack E. Gold, senior analyst with the Meta Group, a research company in Westport, Conn. "It really goes after the dot-matrix printers, where people aren't getting the quality they expect, especially now that they have Windows and other graphical user interfaces."
For those who think of laser printers as bulky behemoths, the 4L will open some eyes. It is about half the size of previous Laserjet models, and at 15.5 pounds, less than half the weight of the IIP. Hewlett-Packard achieved the reduction with a new printer engine and by compressing many electronics onto a small internal card.
But it is probably the slimmer price that will attract the attention of executives and people who work in small offices or at home. The difference in the price of a typical dot-matrix printer and that of a laser printer is now only a few hundred dollars, and the difference in print quality is dramatic.
The printers will be among the easiest laser printers to operate, with the exception of the Apple Laser writers.
"The most startling feature of the 4L is the presence of only a single button on the front control panel," said Marco Boer, a printer analyst with the International Data Corporation in Framingham, Mass. "H-P has shifted all status feedback to the users through software."
If the 4L models have a shortcoming it is printing speed, which is rated at four pages per minute, the same as the IIP. Still, the print quality of the 4L is noticeably better. The new printer has a standard resolution of 300 dots per inch (300 d.p.i.), but it uses the Hewlett-Packard resolution enhancement technology to produce especially crisp graphics and text. The resolution enhancement technology was first used in Hewlett-Packard's more advanced Laserjet models, which offer 600 d.p.i.
The 4L also reflects a new level of environmental awareness. A small touch is that the manual is printed on recycled paper; of more significance is Economode, the equivalent of draft mode on dot-matrix printers. In Economode, the 4L lays down half the toner used in regular mode, thus extending the life of the print cartridge.
C. J. Meiser 3d, who analyzes printers for BIS Strategic Decisions of Norwell, Mass., said, "Type and images are still readable when printed in Economode, but the page looks dull and flat." But for rough drafts that may be all right, and on the environmental side, there would be fewer of the hard-to-dispose toner cartridges.
One radical change is that neither the 4L nor the 4ML has an on-off switch. Instead, the printers slip into "sleep" mode when they do not detect any printing requests. While sleeping, the printer draws just 5 watts of power, compared with the 40 watts to 90 watts that earlier Laserjets drew even in an inactive mode.
People tend to leave laser printers turned on for long periods of time because it takes so long for the printers to warm up. In contrast, the 4L arises instantly from sleep, and is immediately ready to print.
Hewlett-Packard also has replaced the conventional corona wire, which deposits the toner particles in the right place on a printer document -- and which produces ozone -- with a nonpolluting transfer roller. The environmental advances presumably will soon find their way into other Hewlett-Packard products.
Macintosh users and PC users who embellish text documents with graphic images or fancy type fonts, will be attracted to the 4ML when it becomes available in the summer. The 4ML is a Postscript printer, which refers to the page description language software that determines how the printer and the computer software work together to lay an image on paper. The 4ML also has the Enhanced PCL 5 language that is standard on the 4L, and it automatically switches between the two depending on the type of file it is asked to print.
Postscript, a powerful language, is a favorite of graphics professionals. When a Postscript file is created, or when a Postscript font is used, a Postscript printer can take over many of the computational chores from the main computer processor. It was not long ago that the Postscript option added $2,000 to the cost of a laser printer.
While Panasonic, Epson and others also offer laser printers in the $999 range, the 4ML seems to have far more features.
The 4ML, for example, uses a RISC (reduced instruction set computing) microprocessor, the Intel Corporation's 80960. Until now, the powerful RISC chips have been used mainly in high-end lasers to speed the printing of complex graphics. The 4ML also comes with a Localtalk connector for attachment to a Macintosh, as well as a Bitronics parallel connector for a Windows computer. The 4l has the Bitronics connector.
The Bitronics port will be especially useful, because it will allow two-way communication between the printer and the computer. Macintosh users have had similar abilities for years, but Windows users will find the bidirectional communication features of the 4ML refreshing. Hewlett-Packard has not finished the Windows software needed to take advantage of the two-way communication but has promised that it would be ready later this year.
The two-way messaging addresses the annoyance of sending a file to the printer and discovering that the printer is jammed or out of paper. When the software is available, both the 4L and 4ML users would get messages from the printer alerting them to any printing problem.
Another new feature on the 4L is called memory enhancement technology. Laser printers, like computers, must have system memory to store documents waiting to be printed. If a laser has limited memory, it may not be able to print all of a complex image. As more users switch to Windows and take advantage of its graphics abilities, the chance of overwhelming the memory of a printer increases.
Hewlett-Packard has developed a way to squeeze more out of the printer's memory. Its memory enhancement technology compresses data and font information, much like Stacker or other programs do on hard disks. While it does not work with Postscript files, in many cases the 4L can print more with less memory.
So what is the future of the dot-matrix printer? Probably it would continue to enjoy a life in offices that use multipart forms, which laser printers in any variety cannot handle.

PUB-DATE: May 16, 1993,

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1557 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 9-14

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Clinton Counter-Revolution on Taxes 

It'll be a tough job to undo the Reagan tax revolution, but somebody's got to do it -- and Bill Clinton has volunteered. He passed the first hurdle last week when the House Ways and Means Committee approved the basic outline of his plan to raise most people's taxes to hack away at the deficit. Voting strictly on party lines, the panel voted one of the biggest tax increases ever -- nearly $250 billion over five years. The Republicans weren't even invited for the tinkering -- not surprising, since they're standing so fiercely against Mr. Clinton that, if they could, they'd probably veto his morning jog. The tax bill should clear the full House, but the Senate -- with Bob Dole ready to pounce -- is definitely another matter. So it's anybody's guess what tax bill, if any, will emerge.
Could This Be Inflation?
 
You were greedy. You didn't want to refinance your mortgage quite yet. Rates might drop another half-point. Well, maybe you blew it. Inflation -- the beast supposedly in long hibernation -- poked its nose out last week and growled. First, April producer prices jumped 0.6 percent -- the biggest rise in two and a half years. Next came word that consumer prices rose twice as fast as expected, 0.4 percent -- for a 4.3 percent rate so far this year. And there were no comforting footnotes: The price rises were broad, affecting most goods and services Americans use daily. President Clinton, counting on low long-term rates to offset the effects of higher taxes, didn't want to hear it. "It could be just a blip," he said. But it looks like more than that.
 
Forgiving Air Traffic Controllers
 
Ronald Reagan was one sheriff you didn't cross. Air traffic controllers tried it in a 1981 strike, and were soon sent packing, barred from ever getting their jobs back. Mr. Reagan rode on, a bit taller in the saddle. But for better or worse, politics has ceased being a cowboy movie, and congressional pressure mounted to end this harsh exile. President Clinton agreed, and will invite the dismissed controllers to reapply. But symbolism could outweigh reality here, for there are precious few air traffic jobs available.
 
Cezanne, at 1980's Prices
 
Amid all this 90's austerity, the spirit of 80's-style spending clearly lurks -- just lying dormant between eruptions. It bubbled forth at Sotheby's last week, the tone captured in an auctioneer's comment in the heat of the bidding: "What's $100,000 between friends?" The 80's, with art prices at giddy highs, were followed by a couple of morning-after years when prices turned decidedly sober. But when the hammer fell at this sale, Cezanne's "Still Life With Apples" had fetched $28.6 million. It was, by more than $10 million, a record for a Cezanne, and the first painting to sell for more than $20 million in three years.
 
Untangling Those Nanny Rules
 
It's about as much consolation to Zoe Baird as pardoning someone who's just been executed. But in a tacit admission of the complexity of paying taxes for domestic help -- the issue that derailed Ms. Baird -- a House panel voted to simplify the rules. It also voted a sharp rise, to $1,750 a year, in what an employer can pay a worker before becoming liable for Social Security taxes. This rule had clearly fallen by the wayside, for the $50-a-quarter threshold had not been adjusted for inflation since 1950. The rusty lining, though, is that domestic workers -- the forgotten part of this equation -- could find it harder to gain eligibility for Social Security benefits.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Japan Exports Some Tough Talk
 
Though America can never seem to export many of its products to Japan, its exports of criticism are never in short supply. In Bill Clinton's Washington, bashing Japan's trade practices is an increasingly popular parlor game. But Japan has had it with this abuse gap, and last week it lashed out, trying to turn the tables by accusing the United States and other nations of unfair trade practices. It assailed America's policies as being based on the assumption that the mere fact of a trade deficit proved unfair trading. Among the things it singled out for criticism were the "Buy American" provisions in various laws and the classifying of mini-vans as trucks, not cars, for tariff purposes.
 
Italy's Corruption: New Heights
 
Italy's corruption scandal reached the top of the nation's largest public corporation last week, two weeks after a new Government came in amid a tide or reformist fervor. Franco Nobili, head of Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, set up by Mussolini and now Italy's biggest employer, was arrested in Rome and charged with corruption. He has a lot of company: in just over a year, 1,500 executives and politicians have been arrested or interrogated in connection with bribes made in return for public-works contracts.
 
Meanwhile, Italy's biggest private company, Fiat, sought to leave the scandal far behind, becoming the first company in the nation to issue a code of ethical conduct for employees. Fiat, which at first had indignantly denied involvement, forbade its 300,000 employees to offer bribes of any kind.
 
A Blow to European Unity
 
It looked good on paper: Europe would move steadily, by decade's end, toward a single currency and a central monetary policy. But reality proved messier. A deepening recession made it harder for nations with weaker currencies to keep up with the likes of Germany and France, and fault lines started slicing through Europe. Another big crack appeared last week, when Spain and Portugal -- two of the weaker links in the hoped-for chain -- devalued their currencies, by 8 percent in Spain and 6.5 percent in Portugal. Spain had for months tried to prop up the peseta, but in the end, the dream of a unified Europe had to give way to more immediate needs back home.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Pension Alert at General Motors
 
In spite of recent rises, today's interest rates are still awfully low -- and, as often said, that's good for many people but bad for those depending on interest income. And when it's a giant like General Motors, that bad news can have some big numbers attached to it. As if G.M. didn't have troubles enough, it said last week that if rates stay low through October, its unfunded pension liability could rise as high as $20 billion, from $14 billion, because of low yields on bonds held in its pension portfolio. This could force G.M. to chip in more for pensions, meaning it would have less to offer the U.A.W. in contract talks this summer.
 
'Defective,' Every Single One
 
When tobacco companies are sued, they trot out their "experts": Yes, they say, the earth is flat, and cigarettes are safe. In the next breath, the companies say smokers assume the risk themselves. (Or, as a 9-year-old boy might say, standing by his sobbing little sister, "Nothing happened, and I didn't do it.") But it's worked, as they have fended off all suits. But last week a Mississippi judge came up with a new twist, ruling that cigarettes are defective products because, "when used as intended, they cause cancer" and other diseases. The ruling, in which the judge called cigarettes "the most lethal product which may be legally sold," could clear the path for more suits.
 
You Could Look Out the Window
 
Here's what the world has come to: people so busy -- or feeling some bizarre peer pressure to appear so busy -- that at every spare moment they must tether themselves to some electronic device. The hiker, once alone with nature, might stroll wooded paths, phone at ear, talking to a stockbroker. The air traveler who once gazed at the Grand Canyon now stares at a laptop computer. Well, the airlines are enforcing just a slight return to simpler times: Last week, American Airlines became the latest to ban laptops and other devices during takeoff and landing, saying they may disrupt navigation instruments.
 
Equitable, Alive and Kicking
 
Two years ago, Equitable seemed on the brink of insolvency, brought low by those familiar sirens of the 80's -- junk bonds and real estate. But a lot has changed since Richard Jenrette took over in 1990. The new chairman slashed away at costs and assets, and the giant insurer got a $1 billion shot in the arm from Groupe Axa, the French insurer, plus more than $1 billion by issuing stock. Last week it capped its turnaround by reporting its first profitable quarter since 1989. Its stock, which went as low as $7.125 in the fall, now sells for $21.
 
Boeing Jets for Continental
 
Continental Airlines is wasting no time showing the world that it's back. Upgrading its fleet is important for the reborn carrier if it's going to fly in the big leagues, since its planes, on average, are four years older than those of its main rivals. So just two weeks after fleeing bankruptcy -- the first airline ever to do so twice -- it ordered 92 Boeing jetliners, worth $4.5 billion. Continental was mainly reviving an order wiped out by the bankruptcy, but Boeing still saw a "strong endorsement of our products," since a pre-bankruptcy order to Airbus was not revived. And Continental could also be saying thanks, because Boeing gave it some help while it was in bankruptcy.

HEADLINE: Latin America's Dark Side

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A New Rush to Latin America" (April 11) addressed the economic situation and prospects for the southern hemisphere from an exclusively northern perspective. The effects of the free market were discussed only in the context of the increasing strategic importance of Latin America in the United States business agenda. 
 In fact, there is a dark side to the economic reforms imposed by the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the International Development Bank as conditions for economic aid. Impressive macroeconomic growth has come hand-in-hand with rises in poverty and hunger.
The "economic miracle" in Latin America has received a great deal of hype in recent years, with Chile, Mexico and Costa Rica given as models that demonstrate the successes of unregulated free-market economics. For example, Chile boasts a decade of the highest growth rates in South America (5 percent a year), low inflation rates (20 percent a year) and unemployment rates lower than those of the United States (under 5 percent this year).
What these figures don't say is that macroeconomic growth has been accompanied by declining wages, unambiguous growth in poverty, loss of social benefits and a growing income gap between the rich and the poor.
Debt has grown faster than gross domestic product, wealth has become more concentrated, and the percentage of the population living below the poverty line has climbed. For example:
* In 1987, 18.6 percent of the Costa Rican population was living in poverty; in 1991, the percentage had risen to 24.4 percent.
* In Chile, 42 percent now live below the poverty line, and the income share for the top and bottom fifths of the population went from 44.5 percent and 7.6 percent, respectively, in 1969 to 54.6 percent and 4.4 percent in 1989.
* In Mexico, more than half the population lives below the poverty line, and labor's share of the national income dropped from 43 percent to 35 percent between 1980 and 1987.
Social spending and government programs have been severely cut as a condition for the United States and World Bank loans, so the poor have no social safety net.
The rise in employment is in part a rise in those self-employed, or working in the informal economy: i.e., people often living on the cusp of poverty, with no benefits or security. For example, in Costa Rica, the percentage of self-employed (including informal-sector) workers leaped from 3.6 percent in 1987 to 24.8 percent in 1991.
In sum, debt is at record levels, many macroeconomic targets are unfulfilled, people have diminished access to social services, poverty is rising and growth is slackening. The article left the impression that United States investment prospects are promising because Latin America's economy is picking up. In truth, it is the other way around: the growth is a result of foreign investment -- attracted by low wages, devalued currencies and less regulation.
 
CATHERINE ORENSTEIN
New York, April 12
 
The author is promotion manager at the North American Congress on Latin America.

HEADLINE: ENGAGEMENTS;
Ms. Kelley and Mr. Southworth

 BODY:
Rosemary and Kevin Kelley of West Point, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Mary Kathryn Kelley, to Hamilton Southworth 3d, the son of Eleanor and Hamilton Southworth of New York.
Ms. Kelley, 27, is a law student at the University of Virginia, as is her fiance. She graduated from Mills College. Her father, an Army colonel, oversees field recruiters for the department of admissions at the United States Military Academy at West Point and teaches economics there. Her mother teaches job-search skills, primarily in Newburgh, N.Y., for the New York State Division of Adult Education. 
 Mr. Southworth graduated from Yale University. His mother is the coordinator of alumnae affairs at the Chapin School in New York. His father is a systems consultant at Paine Webber in Weehawken, N.J.

PUB-DATE: May 16, 1993,

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1380 words

HEADLINE: What People Want When Taxes Rise: Their Money's Worth

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN his quest to persuade Congress and the country to swallow a nearly $250 billion tax increase over the next five years, President Clinton could do worse than to listen to Darry Sragow. He's walked the walk.
Now California's deputy insurance commissioner, Mr. Sragow was recently chief aide to the chairman of the state's Board of Equalization, which oversees the most politically volatile property tax system in America. More to the point, he is a Democratic campaign strategist of some skill, a man who recently placed his stethoscope to the heart of public opinion in focus groups. 
 Taxes? "Nothing's changed," Mr. Sragow said. "People don't want higher taxes and they don't think they need higher taxes.
"But," he added, "the underlying dynamic isn't financial, and it isn't economic. It's the complete lack of faith in governmental institutions. They just don't believe that throwing more money at social problems and government agencies is going to work."
Dislike of taxes is a constant. No lessons for Mr. Clinton there. But if Mr. Sragow and his peers in other states are to be believed, overcoming a deep distrust of government's ability to perform is the key to whether those who raise taxes will survive politically.
This distrust rises menacingly, the state politicians say, each time a tax is advertised as a cure-all for fiscal or social maladies only to be revealed later as simply a vial of especially nasty snake oil. It is a phenomenon that governors, legislators and even Presidents ignore at their peril.
New Jersey's Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, illustrates the challenge. Three years ago, the Governor rammed a $2.8 billion tax increase through the state Legislature largely on the premise that the money was essential to shore up the government and overhaul the schools.
 
Florio's Vulnerability
 After that widely unpopular step, he has rebounded in the polls for a variety of reasons, but in November he faces voters with his tax vulnerability still showing: Four large school systems, ones supposed to have been helped by the new revenue, are under state oversight because of incompetence or corruption, including Newark's, whose finances were taken over last week.
Stephen A. Salmore, a Republican political consultant and professor at Rutgers University, said "education frames the issues exactly" in the coming gubernatorial campaign.
"The Government's broke," he said. "We wasted the money. We tried spending lots of money on the schools and it didn't work. Now it's time to try something different."
Montana may set a different sort of example next month. There, the newly elected Republican Governor, Marc Racicot, persuaded the Democratic Legislature this spring to schedule a referendum on the first sales tax in state history. Mr. Racicot has tied up the scope of the proposed tax tighter than a roped calf. Proceeds will be used to equalize spending in schools statewide and for relief from a painfully high property tax. The poor will get a rebate to offset its regressive nature. Future increases will be hamstrung by a constitutional cap.
One other thing: Before proposing the tax, Mr. Racicot wrung $100 million from the budget. "It's an uphill fight, no question about it," Andrew H. Malcolm, an aide to the Governor, said of the June 8 referendum. "But I think we've got a fighting chance."
Summed up, the morals of the Florio and Racicot stories are: Don't raise taxes until you've exhausted every other alternative, or at least have persuaded voters that you have done so. If you still must do the deed, explain why convincingly, and say precisely how you will spend the money, preferably on a popular cause. Then lash yourself down with restraints on your use of the take.
Finally, once the money is in hand, deliver on your promises. Voters sometimes forget, but nowadays they almost never forgive.
After months of stumbling, Mr. Clinton now seems wise to those rules.
Last week, with his energy- and income-tax plans under attack, he delved into his gubernatorial files for a tactic he used in Arkansas just two years ago: He vowed to place new tax revenues in a "trust fund" dedicated solely to reducing the deficit.
That the pledge was wholly an accounting device, lacking either teeth or fiscal impact, was secondary. The idea was to recouple his tax proposal to the argument that helped get Mr. Clinton elected: that the Government is bobbing down a raging river of red ink and his plan is the only way to rescue it.
Nevertheless, by the yardstick of campaigns for state tax increases, the President's sales job has not gotten off to a good start. His case for public sacrifice suffered a deep and self-inflicted wound in March, when he requested and Congress rejected $19 billion in new deficit spending -- for roads, Government jobs and research projects -- before cutting even one Federal program. Since then, Republicans have skillfully savaged the White House over backtracking on spending cuts.
Out in the states, experts say passage of Mr. Clinton's tax measure in anything like its present form is by no means certain. For one thing, they point out, Congress reacts to public pressure. Without a voter mandate for the tax plan, lawmakers are prone to adjust it to the liking of special interests or reject it altogether. Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois said as much last week as he steered the tax plan through his Ways and Means Committee. "The Administration, never having written a tax bill, doesn't understand that you have to get supporters out there -- not exclusively in the House and Senate," he said.
Another factor is that Mr. Clinton, much like Mr. Florio, has lashed his political fortunes to a pledge to change Government for the better, even at the cost of some pain. If voters are not brought aboard the tax juggernaut now, the pain -- and the exponential force of mistrust -- will be all that matters when the President seeks re-election in 1996.
"People want action on the economy, and if he can convince them they can't get the economy going until the deficit comes down, then they'll support him," said Jim Ruvolo of the Democratic National Committee. "But if they don't see any results, they're going to punish those they think are responsible."
Still, recent history suggests that luring the public onto the juggernaut is not impossible. Tax increases seemed to have little impact on the electoral fates of state politicians in 1993, according to the Center for the Study of the States in Albany, N.Y. Since 1991, said Steven Gold, the center's director, more than 15 states have raised taxes by at least 5 percent of their entire state budgets. Connecticut's Democratic legislature enacted its first income tax ever in 1991, at the urging of a political independent, Governor Lowell P. Weicker Jr. So far, lawmakers seem to have suffered little at the polls.
But that masks the real difficulty of persuading voters to open their wallets. To cite just two cases, Californians rejected requests last year to raise taxes on the rich and property taxes on business; South Dakotans turned down the chance to trade lower property taxes for a new income tax.
Tax increases that generate money for unrestricted spending, similar to the income- and energy-tax increases Mr. Clinton proposes, are rare as spotted owls at the state level. "Dedicated" taxes are the rave, like the cigarette-tax increase approved by Massachusetts voters in November to finance health programs, to name just one.
Mr. Sragow, the California strategist, says the President has a signal advantage in his tax campaign -- his image as a man who can change the status quo. "If I were advising Bill Clinton on what he has to do to sell a tax increase," he said, "I'd tell him he has to show that the cause is an important one. And maybe more important, I'd tell him he's going to have to show that elected officials aren't going to mess with the money."
But just how much ground the President has to make up from his earlier miscues was underscored the very night after his trust-fund pledge, when the comedian Jay Leno took aim at it on NBC's "Tonight Show."
"Clinton and trust -- I don't know," Mr. Leno cracked. "It's sort of like Senator Bob Dole starting a charm school."

HEADLINE: The Nightmare's Roots: The Dream World Called Serbia

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
OVER the last year, as Americans and people in other Western countries have been forced to focus their attention on Serbia, this land and its inhabitants seem to have become more and more puzzling. In their efforts to justify the brutal war and "ethnic cleansing" being waged in the name of a Greater Serbia, Serbs often appear gripped by emotions that take them beyond the reach of rational argument.
In explaining this, many analysts have pointed out that Serbia operates in near-isolation from the outside world's information media, and from opposition viewpoints. Some, like the late novelist Ivo Andric, have suggested that the explanation lies deeper, in the land's historic culture. Serbs, Mr. Andric wrote, are a people "who easily make up fables and spread them quickly, wherein reality is strangely and inextricably mixed and interwoven with legend." 
 The central belief that has sustained Serbs during the current war is that they are in the right and that their critics (meaning virtually everyone else in the world) are either blind or malicious. This belief, put forward by their leaders and built partly on remembrance of grievous wrongs done to previous generations, has led them into a war in pursuit of an ethnically pure nation-state, a concept that repels most of the rest of the world.
But in the context of daily life in modern Serbia, it is not so surprising that so many Serbs could believe there is a global plot to suppress them. Life here often seems enveloped in a strangeness that sets the intellectual climate apart from that in most other European capitals.
State-run television, which is the main source of information for most people here, often features guests who proclaim odd and wondrous theories. One writer who often appears on talk shows asserts that Serbs are "the second Biblical people," chosen by God like the Jews but destined forever to be misunderstood and persecuted. Another regular guest assures viewers that at the moment when final destruction threatens the Serbian nation, a fleet of vampires will arise from the cemeteries to overwhelm its enemies. Serbs, he warns, should stockpile garlic to be sure the vampires do not mistakenly attack them.
One evening recently, the nightly television newscast carried a graphic report that Croatian forces in Bosnia had attacked a Serbian village and systematically killed every man, woman and child there, using not firearms but implements of torture. Inquiries revealed that the report was substantially true, but that the reporter had omitted one detail. The massacre took place more than 50 years ago, during World War II.
It is not just television that treats Serbs to such spectacles. Serbia's leading institutions include people who, in other lands, might be behind bars or in padded cells. One leading member of Parliament heads a terror squad that specializes in blowing up mosques. Another, a convicted bank robber, is one of Interpol's most wanted criminals. Others are small-time thieves and triggermen. Many democratically oriented deputies have quit the Parliament in disgust.
What does such a Parliament debate? In one recent session, the principal agenda item was a proposal to ban use of the letter U. This is the initial of Ustashe, the fascist movement that ruled Croatia under Nazi occupation in the 1940's, and Croatian fighters in Bosnia sometimes paint it on the ruins of Serbian houses they have destroyed. Use of this letter by Serbs, members of Parliament argued, constitutes virtual treason and publishers should be required to substitute the letter V.
Then there's this: Serbia's two most successful bankers, who made fortunes last year by promising gullible depositors interest rates of up to 200 percent a month on hard currency deposits. When these confidence games collapsed, one of the bankers, who ran for president last December, fled the country and announced from abroad that he would use his fortune to sponsor the assassination of the country's leaders. The other, a woman who drives a shiny Mercedes and wears fabulously expensive clothes and jewelry, surveyed a crowd of ruined depositors clamoring for their money outside one of her banks and asked, "Who are these scum?"
 
Worthless Money
 Hyper-inflation has rendered the currency all but worthless. In December a dollar bought about 600 dinars. The rate is now over 100,000 to 1.
Serbia's political leaders also reflect an other-worldly quality. The shadowy President, Slobodan Milosevic, rarely appears in public, and citizens are left to divine his views from cryptic statements. Radovan Karadzic, the psychiatrist who is the Bosnian Serbs' leader, insists in the midst of Serbian offensives that Serbs never launch offensives. His hobby is gambling, and he has spent many post-midnight hours running up debts at Belgrade's fanciest casino.
Until last week, Mr. Milosevic used his control of local television to portray Mr. Karadzic as a noble hero, and his after-hours habits were a taboo topic. Almost overnight, following a political dispute between the two, newscasters launched a campaign of merciless vilification of Mr. Karadzic and even his relatives. Viewers who formerly knew nothing about his gambling now even know the amount he is said to have lost at the tables: $200,000. Mr. Milosevic clearly had him in mind when he warned Bosnian Serbs recently not to throw away their futures "like a drunken poker player."
"Gangsterism and criminality are so rampant here that we are now like some Latin American country, Paraguay perhaps," mused one Serbian official. "But it isn't just the criminal aspect that is overwhelming our society. There is a drifting away from reality into a bizarre kind of fantasy world, like the world in Garcia Marquez novels."
 
Like Argentina?
 Predrag Simic, who directs a foreign affairs research institute in Belgrade, also sought to compare life in Serbia to the Latin American tradition of magic realism. "People here are willing to believe absolutely anything, the wilder the better," Mr. Simic said. "We drift along in a dream world that is like something you expect from a place like Argentina."
By quirk of history, Serbia is falling into this unreal world just as many Latin American lands are emerging from it. Paraguay, for example, appears to be making a genuine transition from thuggish dictatorship to democracy. And even Argentina seems to be shedding its half-century-old infatuations and emerging as a modern state ruled by rationalism.
"Almost everyone here has accepted the national illusion that this is a small heroic country which is being horribly and unfairly victimized," said a European diplomat posted in Belgrade. "It is a phenomenon that can be better understood by psychoanalysts than by politicians."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan Asks: Who Dispatched Us to This Hell, Anyway?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
CAPTAIN SHIKAUCHI of the Japanese Self-Defense Forces knew what to do back in February when the United Nations convoy he was leading was attacked by a vicious band of Khmer Rouge rebels along Cambodia's border with Thailand. As the dubious hero of a popular adult comic book called "P.K.O." (for "Peace Keeping Operation"), he dutifully radioed to Phnom Penh for instructions. Then, waving aside objections from a pesky Japanese television reporter who reminded him that Japan's Constitution renounces war, he ordered his troops to return the fire, killing hundreds of his attackers.
"We are simply obeying the orders of the people, and of the United Nations," the muscular cartoon captain declared to the cameras after the firefight was over. Anyway, he demanded to know as he stood in the Cambodian jungle, "Who dispatched us to this hell?" 
 For the last two weeks, as Japanese television viewers have watched in shock, the real-life equivalents of Captain Shikauchi have been asking the same question of their national leaders. Only three months after the P.K.O. comic book hit the newsstands, two of the more than 700 Japanese now working in Cambodia have been killed -- one as the Khmer Rouge attacked a convoy near the Thai border.
But this time there was no shooting back. The Japanese civilian police working in the region, all volunteers, carried no guns at all. In plaintive calls on satellite phones back to Tokyo, they complained that local bandits were stealing all their food and water, and that the United Nations had no reliable way of resupplying them. When the Japanese Government tried to get them recalled to Phnom Penh, the United Nations commanders in Cambodia angrily told them to stay at their posts.
In short, Japan's first quasi-military foray abroad since the end of World War II is hardly an adventure-writer's dream. The deaths and other Japanese casualties, while small by the standards of other nations, have prompted calls for the Government to pull out before bigger disaster strikes -- which seems inevitable. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, his Government clearly viewing Cambodia as a Bosnia-sized crisis, declared last week that Japan would stick it out at least through elections to be held May 23 to 28. "That is the kind of international contribution that is expected of us," he said.
Cambodia is serving as an elaborate shadow play for Japan and its neighbors as they stumble toward a new set of power relationships as messy as the arguments over whether America or Europe will take the lead in the Balkans. In Tokyo, Cambodia is being viewed as a taste of things to come if Japan gets serious about amending its Constitution's famous Article IX, the "peace clause" that Japan interprets, at least for now, as requiring it to remain a bit player in U.N. peacekeeping -- staying far from the line of fire and, in theory at least, returning home when cease-fires break down. (Japanese leaders say the cease-fire holds in Cambodia, despite almost daily incidents of violence.)
 
A Traditional Reluctance
 Government officials say they are dragging along a reluctant and instinctively isolationist public, getting it accustomed to the human sacrifices that are deliberately never discussed when Japanese politicians give earnest speeches about Japan taking a political role in the world "commensurate with our economic power."
"You may think that we are overreacting to these two deaths," a senior Foreign Ministry official said. "But I hope you understand that this is the first case since 1945 of Japanese troops being sent abroad. And we have to move very cautiously. If we fail, it will take years to dispatch them elsewhere."
Perhaps most striking as Japan wavers over what to do is the almost amused reaction of its Asian neighbors, who hint that Japan is proving itself unready for the leader-of-Asia mantle it covets. Last year many of those countries denounced Japan's authorization of the deployment to Cambodia as a dangerous first taste of forbidden fruit. Lee Kuan Yew, the former Prime Minister of Singapore, likened the idea of sending the Japanese military abroad again to giving liquor candies to an alcoholic; his biggest worry, he said, was that one morning while shaving he would look out his window and again see Japanese warships flying the Hinomaru flag in Singapore's harbor.
But last week Mr. Lee's successor, Goh Chok Tong, was among the first to suggest that a withdrawal would mean "Japan will have decided not to play an international role." Mr. Goh added that "Japan's ambiguity reflects the profound insecurity with which it regards the post-cold war world," and he prescribed the couch. "It would be helpful if Tokyo discusses even its own uncertainties with its neighbors and other countries in the region, and works with them to define its role."
In fact, talking openly still seems to be one of the last things the Government feels it can afford to do. For 50 years Japanese leaders have been trained never to talk about "strategic interests" or even national ideals; no wonder they grew fond of checkbook diplomacy. As a result, it would be "suicidal," one of Mr. Miyazawa's aides suggested last week, to explain Japan's peacekeeping presence in the idealistic terms that an American or European leader might use: "We all benefit from peace and prosperity in Asia, so as the richest and most stable nation in the region we have a responsibility to take the lead in bringing democracy and prosperity to Cambodia, even at the cost of many Japanese lives."
That simply doesn't work in Japan, where it is always smart politics to portray the country as being forced into a policy by outside powers. To win passage of the peacekeeping bill last year, the Government wove an elaborate fiction that its troops would somehow be walled off from the danger. Unfortunately, that can't be done in the four-way factional struggle in Cambodia. As one Foreign Ministry official noted dryly last week: "We neglected to send a copy of our Constitution to the Khmer Rouge."
The bigger problem the Government faces is what to do after the election. There is no national consensus for a continued role in Cambodia, and Mr. Miyazawa has never even defined Japan's national interests in the region. Instead, his Government has justified it primarily on the basis of fulfilling foreign expectations. Not surprisingly, there is already an undercurrent of resentment against foreign pressure (read American pressure), that is once again perceived as pushing the Japanese faster than they want to go.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
What Does Europe Want?

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
WHAT does Europe want? The question hung in the air from Washington to Sarajevo last week. The answer, paradoxically, is stronger American leadership.
How could this be, in a week when European Community foreign ministers rejected Clinton Administration proposals for bombing Serbian military targets in Bosnia and Herzegovina and arming the Muslims there, at the same time as military and civilian officials of the NATO alliance were saying they urgently needed United States leadership to find a way to halt the cruel slaughter of Bosnian civilians? 
 Conflicting signals from Washington have left everybody confused. The American military establishment in Europe does not know what the President will finally ask it to do. American commanders have worked out contingency plans for bombing Serbian military targets and for taking part in peacekeeping missions, they say, but not because anyone in Washington has ordered them to.
It is arguably not Europe's irresolution on Bosnia, but Washington's that has led to the latest trans-Atlantic crisis.
 
No Continental Cohesion

 
 Europe has an excuse for division. As one European Community official facetiously put it, the United States exists, but "Europe" does not. Geographically undefined in the 1957 Treaty of Rome that established it, the European Community is a trading bloc without internal tariff barriers. Its members have only aspirations to act as one, military and politically. The United States has been a Federal state for two centuries.
As such, it can make clear decisions on foreign policy and bring its full weight to bear on its European allies to support them, if it chooses to. Up to now, in Bosnia, it has not done so convincingly. Secretary of State Warren Christopher came to the allies with a plan to threaten limited air strikes against Bosnian Serb military targets that would allow the Muslims to rearm themselves. Even some of his own senior military officials in Europe regarded the plan as ill considered and impractical, although the President said Friday it was still on the table.
Several European military and civilian authorities said privately last week that American advice on strategy in the Balkans would be better grounded in reality, and therefore taken more seriously, if the United States had a sizable ground force commitment to United Nations humanitarian or peacekeeping missions already in the Balkans, as both Britain and France do.
For most of the past 80 years, Americans have believed that American security and European stability were inextricably bound, re-learning the lesson painfully after the isolationism of the 1920's and 30's.
Woodrow Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt before Bill Clinton were also not elected to save the world, and they also often had to sort through a babble of European voices. Like them, Mr. Clinton must decide what the Europeans are really trying to tell him -- in his case, whether "no" really means "yes" on Bosnia. His decision will have to depend mainly on his assessment of what the American interest is.
The NATO alliance -- the expression of American strategic interest in Europe and of the European need for American commitment -- explicitly recognized the link between European stability and global security in the post-cold war strategy that it adopted in 1991. "Risks to allied security are less likely to result from calculated aggression against the territory of the allies," it said, than from "the adverse consequences of instabilities that may arise from the serious economic, social and political difficulties, including ethnic rivalries and territorial disputes, which are faced by many countries in central and eastern Europe."
Ethnic cleansing and the other horrors of the war in the Balkans, which formally lies outside NATO's geographical boundaries, proved this assessment only too accurate. In late 1991, Europeans thought they could handle the problem themselves, and the Bush Administration mistakenly left it to them rather than to the alliance.
 
Containing the Conflict

 
 Both European and American civilian and military officials share a common interest: stopping the slaughter of civilians in Bosnia and preventing similar tragedies from spreading elsewhere in the Balkans. But to many Europeans, the Bosnian Muslims, while the war's main victims, are as guilty of past atrocities as Serbs or Croats, and they also fear that if the West appears to support them by lifting the arms embargo, the Russians will want to send supplies to the Serbs, escalating the conflict.
The problem is that NATO has failed up to now to be relevant to the conflict, a failure acknowledged by American and European officials alike. Many of them say it might not have occurred if the United States had become involved earlier and taken a stronger leadership role before the conflict intensified. Unless the United States gives NATO clear leadership now, many alliance officers say, the alliance will lose credibility at a time when mounting instability all over the former Communist world seems to make it more needed than ever.
Some are beginning to suggest that the best alliance strategy would be to send in troops to protect civilians in safe areas, and help the United Nations insure that no more arms get into Bosnia from Serbia, accepting President Slobodan Milosevic's invitation to send in a monitoring force along the border, quarantining a conflict that only the combatants can end.
Whatever decisions are made, the American President's will be the crucial one, and he will have been brought to it by American moral and ethical sensibilities. More strongly than most Europeans, Americans feel that it is unacceptable to stand by and just watch the slaughter.
The ideal of European unity, a vivid dream when European Community leaders agreed on a treaty on a common currency and a unified foreign and security policy in Maastricht at the end of 1991, has also been seriously corroded by the consequences of failure in Bosnia.
The Maastricht treaty's ambitious design also faces a crucial test this week in Denmark, whose voters rejected it narrowly in a referendum last June and will have another one on Tuesday. If they reject it again, the treaty will die. The British House of Commons would then almost surely refuse to ratify it, and the treaty must be ratified by all 12 community member states to go into effect. And even if the Danes approve, many people doubt whether monetary union will ever happen. Public sentiment in Germany, racked by a recession that is a direct consequence of miscalibrated economic and monetary policies after unification in 1990, is heavily against giving up the Deutschmark.
Europe is not united, except at times in opposition to American attempts to galvanize it into common action. But this is only another demonstration of how much Europe depends on the United States for strong leadership. It fails usually when that leadership is not strong enough.
Whatever they seem to be saying in public, Europeans -- including the French -- admit in private that they need the United States and the alliance it leads now more than ever.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 868 words

HEADLINE: Lawbreakers We Have Known and Loved

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
THEY walk where they're not supposed to walk. They climb where climbing is not allowed. They jump where they shouldn't jump, and, yes, they drive trains they have no business driving.
They are the daring and endearing fools who rush in where angels fear to tread, and when they do, it is generally the angels who lead the applause. 
 For their feats, as illegal as they are daring, almost invariably capture the collective imagination of a generally law-abiding population, which cheers their defiance of the laws of gravity and established authority even as the authorities are clearing their throats and filing criminal charges.
The details aren't important. It hardly matters whether they're leading the New York police on a 10-mile chase in a hot air balloon, parachuting into Shea Stadium -- or taking the A train out for a spin.
That was more or less the case last week when word got around that one Keron Thomas, a 16-year-old Trinidad-born train buff from Brooklyn, had walked into a Transit Authority terminal in upper Manhattan the previous Saturday, nodded to dispatchers and blithely driven off with a New York City subway train.
By the time the police arrested him several days later, Mr. Thomas seemed well on his way to becoming as much a local hero as George Willig and Philippe Petit were before him, and Adie Walford was before them.
It was Mr. Walford who took a stroll across the Williamsburgh Bridge on June 1, 1901, when the bridge was no more than a few thin cables stretched across the East River. He had been long forgotten by the time Philippe Petit, a French high-wire artist, stretched a tight rope between the towers of the World Trade Center on Aug. 7, 1974, and walked from one to the other, turning the Trade Center into an icon of derring-do.
On July 22, 1975, Owen J. Quinn, an unemployed construction worker, parachuted off the North Tower, and on May 26, 1977, George Willig, a mountain climber, scaled the South Tower, assisted in his preparations by Ronald DeGiovanni, who had delighted New Yorkers six months earlier by riding a hot air balloon from Staten Island to Queens by way of Lower Manhattan.
Why are the Walfords and the Willigs of the world so lionized? Dr. Joyce Brothers, the psychologist whose public practice gives her special insights into public emotions, didn't have to consult her files. "We are tickled to death," she said. "They are fulfilling our own Walter Mitty dreams. Everybody has fantasies. They actually go out and do them."
 
The Lure of the Illicit
 A key appeal of such feats, Dr. Brothers said, is that they are illicit as well as daring. Skydivers, for example, have been employed for years to help promote sporting events, and nobody paid much attention when parachutists were engaged to help celebrate the 1986 Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pa. But two months later, when Michael Sergio made a distinctly unscheduled parachute landing in the Shea Stadium infield during the first inning of Game 6 of the World Series, it was an immediate sensation.
Dr. Brothers sees a little vicarious fantasy larceny in us all. "We root for them," she said, "because our lives are filled with rules, and petty bureaucrats are always finding ways to make things more difficult for us."
After an initial bluster, the bureaucrats generally back down. When Mr. Willig completed his climb, he was arrested and sued for $250,000 to cover the city's cost and trouble. Two days later he was given a hero's welcome at City Hall by Mayor Abraham D. Beame, who made clear that he had not authorized the suit, which was settled for $1.10, a penny for each of the tower's 110 stories.
Whether Mr. Thomas is treated so gently remains to be seen. If convicted of all charges that have been lodged against him, including reckless endangerment, he could spend more than seven years in prison.
While such a sentence seems unlikely, not everyone sees him as a hero, even though his adventure seems certain to be memorialized in a television movie. Parachuting off a skyscraper to a deserted street is one thing. Risking the lives of thousands of subway passengers is something else again, even though the evidence would suggest that the passengers on Mr. Thomas's A train were in capable hands. Until he took a curve faster than the 20-mile speed limit and tripped the automatic brakes, Mr. Thomas, who was just two stops from the end of line, had driven 45 miles without incident and made 85 smooth stops, picking up and dropping off 2,000 passengers during the three-and-a-half hour run. Indeed, there were those who expressed admiration for him precisely because he was so dedicated in his obsession with subway trains that he had pored over the official operator's manual and assembled his own set of operating tools.
And while there are those who believe he belongs in jail, a common reaction to his adventure was that he should be hired by the Transit Authority and given full motorman's training. Given that, Dr. Brothers said that she would not hesitate to ride a train driven by the young man, who, she suggested, has given evidence of another rare and admired quality shared by popular heroes.
"He cares," she said.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Health Care's Fever: Not So High to Some

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
WITH medical bills hogging one dollar in eight of Americans' income, just about everybody knows there is a cost crisis in health care. But could just about everybody, including the first President to focus like a laser beam on health care reform, be wrong? Could rapidly rising outlays be a sign of the rational will of a rich society to take advantage of spectacular, if very expensive, advances in medical technology?
That remains a minority view in the ripening debate over health care reform. But a striking number of economists do think that the severity of the medical-cost illness has been exaggerated. "There's a problem with health care costs, not a crisis," says Burton Weisbrod of Northwestern University. While he and others acknowledge that spending cannot continue to rise indefinitely two or three times as fast as incomes, they worry that cost containment will retard technology that promises enormous dividends in the quality of life. 
 Everybody agrees that the market for health care can't be relied on to generate the most value for the least cost. Sellers need not compete on quality because the consumers rarely understand what they are buying. Nor do they compete on price: "With insurance covering 90 percent of the bill," says Martin Feldstein of Harvard University, "it's not surprising that people treat health care as if it were free."
There is, in fact, solid evidence that overuse of health care is the rule, not the exception. In the late 1970's, the Rand Corporation randomly assigned volunteers to alternative insurance plans. Families required to absorb the first $1,000 a year of their medical costs spent 40 percent less on medical care than those with no insurance deductible, and with "negligible" effects on health.
This failure of the market to link cost to value may well account for the fact that America spends at least one-third more on health care than Canada or Germany. And it seems to be fueling the Administration's optimism that universal insurance coverage can eventually be underwritten from money now spent on services that few would willingly pay for directly from their own pockets.
 
Inflated Figures
 American spending, both per person and as a percentage of national income, is exceptionally high by any standard. But Joseph Newhouse, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, draws an important distinction between the level of health care spending and its rate of growth. The American rate of growth shows no particular trend over the last half century, suggesting that if there is a crisis in costs it is a very old one indeed. What's more, the rate of growth of spending is only a bit above average for advanced economies.
The common explanation for soaring medical outlays, seemingly validated by Government statistics, is what President Clinton occasionally calls "price-gouging." From 1980 to 1990, for example, the medical-care component of the Consumer Price Index rose almost twice as fast as the overall index.
But few knowledgeable economists take this calculation seriously. The statistics gatherers compile the medical index from list prices that are little more than the benchmark for bargaining between insurers and providers. One study found that California hospitals raised their official prices by 70 percent from 1983 to 1988, but after accounting for discounts, the actual increase was closer to 40 percent.
More confounding still, the measurers ignore key productivity improvements: a day in the hospital is still counted as a day in the hospital, though it now takes, say, half as many days to complete treatment for appendicitis as it did in the 1950's.
Even if these statistical glitches were fixed, measurement would be dogged by the difficulty of accounting for quality. This is a general issue when everything from car radios to microwave dinners is getting better. But the problem is particularly acute with health care, where the change is rapid and the benefits are conceptually difficult to quantify.
"If you had $10,000 to spend on medical care, which would you rather buy," asks Mr. Weisbrod, "1960's care at 1960's prices, or 1990's care at 1990's prices?" The fact that most people would hesitate to answer makes the overall inflation figure problematic at best.
If inflation is not the culprit, what is? Mr. Newhouse acknowledges that a wide variety of factors, everything from the aging of the population to the spread of insurance to the scourge of malpractice, have played a role. But at least half the increase in outlays, he reckons, has gone into new technology.
 
Someone Else's Money
 Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution, finds this a distinction without much difference. As with other medical decisions, consumers rarely have to plunk down their own money to choose new technology, he says. And since insurers have been inclined to pay for every new drug and procedure that generates any benefit whatsoever, reform is needed to control technology creep as well as to clean up embedded waste. At the very least, he argues, broad caps on spending would "promote a debate over technology and a demand for information."
Uwe Reinhardt, a Princeton economist, dismisses the practical consequences of such a debate. He notes that other affluent economies, which have already socialized decisions about who is entitled to kidney transplants and who gets first crack at the M.R.I. scanner, are coping with roughly the same rates of cost increases as America. "I don't believe for a minute," he says, that Americans would choose to deprive themselves.
But Mr. Weisbrod is less sanguine. He worries that health care reforms that are sold as a means of containing costs will create a bias against new technology that is no less damaging than the current bias in its favor. And certainly there are grounds for believing that cost containment will become the central focus of reform.
While most economists agree that the employer-financed health insurance actually comes out of net pay, business does not see it that way. Sky-high health-care premiums figure prominently in conventional wisdom about why America can't compete in world markets. Corporate America is thus pressing for caps on total spending.
No less important, cost containment is seen as the key to success in the war on the budget deficit. "We are kidding each other," President-elect Clinton said at the economic summit meeting last December, "if we think ... we can get control of this budget if you don't do something about health care."
But the cure may not prove much better than the disease. Mr. Aaron concedes that the pressure to contain costs is likely to create a two-tier medical system, if only because it is not the American way to deny individuals the right to buy what they are willing to pay for.
It is possible that everyone will get treatment as good as that now received by the well-insured. A small minority who could afford exotic technology and chose to buy it would pay their own way. But it is also possible that skeptics like Representative Pete Stark of California are right -- that while decent care would be universally available under managed competition, the only way to save big bucks would be to dribble it out on terms unacceptable to the middle class. The majority would thus opt for supplemental private insurance that gave buyers access to the physicians and treatments they expected, and in timely fashion.
This second scenario would mean acceptable care for more people at lower cost than the hodgepodge of public and private efforts today. But it is hardly the vision of an egalitarian health care system that is driving Bill Clinton to bet his Presidency on reform.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Making His Way Out of the Muddle He Made

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS President Clinton strolled onto the White House South Lawn Friday morning for an education awards ceremony, he was greeted by the ruffles and flourishes of the Marine Band. The day was sunny, the House Ways and Means committee had just passed his tax package and all seemed well at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.
"The Marine Band has been in especially fine form this morning," the President remarked cheerily. "I woke up to them. I went jogging to them. I almost felt like a President this morning, for sure." 
 It was a long time coming, this sense of comfort. The President has seemed more battered than confident recently. His economic package had suffered from what Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen delicately called a "diffusion of the objective," and the President is now determined to regain his footing.
Recognizing that their pitch has lacked an organized theme, the members of Bill Clinton's political brain trust have sketched out a new approach for the President that they hope will restore his standing as a leader with a clear sense of what he was elected to do.
"Out in the real world, people know that things are related, that things are integrated," said Paul Begala, a political consultant who advises the President. "In Washington, one of the problems is that things are broken down into their component parts. Things are considered in a vacuum, not in context."
Mr. Clinton plans to knit the strands back together, undertaking three tasks that he all but ignored during the first weeks of his Administration: traveling outside of Washington, hammering away at a single theme and -- reporters beware -- wooing the press.
When Mr. Clinton and his Vice President Al Gore decided to package their campaign promises last year and publish "Putting People First," a modest little paperback, everything seemed so simple.
The two Southern baby-boomers had hit on a simple approach, a simple package and an attractive message. Little did they know how messy it would all become.
The famously focused Clinton campaign quickly evolved into the famously scattered Clinton Administration. All of the ideas detailed so neatly in the campaign came across to Americans as an unwieldy bunch of ambitious ideas laden with suspicious new taxes.
Mr. Bentsen, in a meeting with reporters, acknowledged as much late last week.
"For the past few weeks, you might not have known that we had a four-year $500 billion deficit reduction up at Ways and Means," he said. "You'd think all we were going through was a stack of unrelated bills. But the fact is we were building, one item at a time, a deficit reduction package to change the course of our economy."
Mr. Clinton scored an unalloyed victory when the House committee passed his tax package virtually intact. The party-line vote smoothed the way for a measure that would increase taxes for higher income Social Security recipients and wealthier individuals and energy users and increase tax breaks for the working poor.
Administration officials were happy to bask in the glow of their success and even admit to the mistakes they made along the way. They have confessed to fuzziness of purpose, an extended bout of hubris and a fundamental misunderstanding of the balance of power between the opposite ends of Pennsylvania Avenue.
Mr. Clinton and his advisers always saw the common thread that ran through the President's proposals. To them, campaign finance and welfare and health care and urban development grants and college tuition aid and immunization and energy taxes all seemed naturally linked.
But to many outside the White House, the list of Administration goals looked like the worries of the world crammed into a barrel.
When the President announced last week that he would support a measure to create a deficit trust fund to receive all new tax revenues, he showed that he was catching on. It was a symbolic statement, but in the attention it paid to public perception, it was a telling one.
"Until we can prove that we have the discipline to control our budget, I don't think we'll have the elbow room necessary to have the kind of targeted investments we need," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference on Friday.
 
Road Warrior
 Even the measure's sponsors were unprepared for the Presidential endorsement, which was immediately denounced by Republicans as a gimmick. But White House officials were sanguine about the criticism. They wanted a weapon to take on the road when the President travels to California this week, and they got one.
By the end of the week, the White House had produced three senior officials -- Mr. Bentsen, budget director Leon Panetta and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the Council of Economic Advisers -- to emphasize the good news.
In the Rose Garden on Friday, Mr. Clinton followed through on the strategy he has devised with his advisers to drive his point home.
On his swing through Illinois, Ohio, New Mexico and California, he will try to build support for his economic policies. At home, he will send muted warnings to Congress.
"We have to win inside by playing outside," one of his advisers said.
But even as the President struggles for discipline, he has had trouble concealing his exasperation when things do not go his way.
"On one day people say, 'He's trying to do too much, he's pushing too hard, he wants too much change,' and then on the other day says, 'Well, he's really not pushing very hard,' " he told reporters, with more than a hint of pique. "I think we're getting good results."
"I love the way all our victories are discounted," his spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, said later.
Yet Mr. Clinton was pleased with the results of the news conference and with his week, his aides said later. The White House had intended to take advantage of a lull in activities in Bosnia to make news only about the economy, no matter what else he was asked.
But the President remains puzzled about some basic vagaries of Washington political life. Admitting error does not come easily to him, and he has learned the hard way that striking out at those who oppose him is often ill-advised.
"There is a permanent government here, but there's also a permanent political culture," he told The Washington Post in an interview published Friday. "And I have to learn -- it is my job as President to make the most of that instead of let it make the most of me."
