HEADLINE: In Zaire, Starvation Is Growing in a Wealthy Land

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
In a fly-infested feeding center on the outskirts of Kinshasa, nearly 200 children gathered listlessly around a huge steaming bowl of milky gruel. This was the only meal of the day for some, and others were eating for the first time in days.
There was no laughter or play. Some of the children, no more than tiny skeletons with the faces of emaciated old men, were too weak to move. Relief officials predicted that at least 10 percent of the children would soon die of hunger. 
 Until recent months, severe malnutrition and starvation on this scale were virtually unheard of in Kinshasa, the capital of this central African country and a densely packed river port city of nearly five million people.
 
Unparalleled Since the 1960's
 "We haven't seen this amount of hunger in West Africa since the Biafran war in Nigeria during the 1960's," said Wayne King, the chief officer for the United States Agency for International Development here, who has worked in Africa for 20 years.
A State Department cable in March, in what it called a conservative estimate, said at least 5.2 percent of Zairians, or nearly 1.8 million people, were suffering from "acute malnutrition." The cable recommended that the United States provide emergency short-term food assistance, warning that a delay could make any aid "too little too late."
In truth, the acute food problems facing Zaire appear self-inflicted, the result of nearly 30 years of Government corruption and economic ineptitude. Now they have become so severe that they are bending society with their pressure.
"It's always been a struggle to live here, but things have never been this bad," said Zanga Yumbi, a local Red Cross official.
In many families, she said, food is so scarce that girls are fed one day and boys the next.
Some children have been abandoned to die, an extremely rare practice in a society where the extended family system, an informal network of blood ties, often embraces hundreds of people. There were always aunts, uncles or cousins willing to provide housing and food for children whose parents, for whatever reason, could no longer take care of them.
But for the first time, diplomats, relief officials and missionaries said, the level of deprivation is so severe and pervasive that even close relatives are reluctant to take in ailing or needy children, and a growing number of parents have been forced to seek help beyond the traditional family connections.
 
Parents Give Up Hope
 Musongi-Mpwono Munol, the director of the Kizito-Kingabwa Health Center, said nearly 60 percent of the children there had been abandoned -- left to the care of relief organizations and missionaries -- because their parents could no longer afford to feed them.
"Many people simply don't have the ability to support all their children anymore, so they are making very difficult choices," said Sister Tacita Laranang, a Roman Catholic nun who works at St. Kizito's feeding center.
St. Kizito is one of nearly 30 centers that Doctors Without Borders, a European relief organization, has opened in the last year. Relief organizations that have stepped in receive virtually no assistance from Zaire's troubled Government.
And it is not only the children who are suffering. Mrs. Yumbi of the Red Cross said that early in May, an old and sickly woman dressed in rags had been abandoned at the doorstep of a local church. "This would have never happened even five years ago," Mrs. Yumbi said.
Kinshasa's deprivation is a poverty that somehow seems a terrible mistake.
The food shortages stem not from drought, which devastated food production in Ethiopia in the mid-1980's and more recently in Zimbabwe, Mozambique and other countries in southern Africa for much of the last two years. Nor do the shortages result from violent ethnic and territorial disputes, as in Somalia or the Sudan.
 
Food and Resources Plentiful
 Indeed, food is relatively plentiful in Kinshasa's central market, and north of Kinshasa stretches an area with more than enough arable land to feed the country's 40 million people.
Moreover, Zaire is a leading copper and cobalt producer, the world's largest supplier of industrial diamonds, rich in coffee, timber, palm oil and other agricultural exports, and it also has vast reserves of hydroelectric power.
At the top of this country blessed with abundant natural resources and cursed by starvation is one of the world's richest men. Mobutu Sese Seko, the country's autocratic leader for 28 years, has a personal fortune estimated at $4 billion, say African and Western diplomats as well as numerous scholars on Zaire.
"In our view, Zaire is not faced with a food shortage per se, but rather an acute food access problem," concluded a recent study by Catholic Relief Services, a group based in the United States.
To be sure, chronic malnutrition has long existed in Kinshasa, but the problem has steadily worsened in recent years. The problem became a crisis with rioting in September 1991, when disgruntled soldiers seeking back pay went on a rampage, looting homes and shops and setting off a wave of violence that left dozens dead. Belgium, the former colonial ruler of Zaire, and France deployed troops to help evacuate 30,000 foreigners, mostly Europeans, and to maintain order.
 
Rioting by Soldiers Repeated
 Rioting erupted again in February when soldiers discovered that the new five-million-zaire bank notes used to pay them were impossible to spend. Heavily armed soldiers seized control of the Parliament building and held several hundred lawmakers hostage, demanding that they order local merchants to accept the new bank notes. Hundreds, including the French Ambassador, were killed.
Since then, the economic collapse has been staggering. Many of the foreigners held vital technical and managerial positions -- jobs that most African and Western diplomats believe that Zairians, for now, are incapable of filling. More broadly, Zairian businesses dependent on imported materials, spare parts or machines have faced sharp reductions in production and earnings and laid off tens of thousands of workers.
As a result, according to figures provided by the United States Embassy here, before the 1991 riots, unemployment stood at nearly 40 percent, a figure almost unheard of even among Africa's poorest cities.
The unemployment rate has continued to rise and is now estimated at 80 percent. Zaire's continuing power struggle between Mr. Mobutu and leaders of the opposition has virtually paralyzed most governmental institutions. Compounding the misery, the annual inflation rate is now about 4,400 percent, partly because of a huge budget deficit that developed after the Government abandoned a broad range of belt-tightening measures devised by the International Monetary Fund in early 1990, and instead increased spending.
Since then, Zaire has been declared "non-cooperating" by the monetary fund, and a decision to expel it from the world's leading governmental lending organization is believed to be imminent.
 
Migration to City Slows
 An enigma that strikes many Western analysts visiting or living in Zaire is why the people appear to tolerate conditions that clearly should produce deep discontent. Despite the economic deprivation of recent years -- hyperinflation and the lack of jobs and housing -- there has been a steady migration of people into the city.
But even that may be changing, said Martine Dedeur Warder, a nutritionist with Doctors Without Borders. For one thing, prices for basic food items have become so high here that even the relatively well-to-do are struggling. Mid-level civil service workers, for example, earn about $25 a month, yet a 110-pound sack of corn flour -- enough to feed a family of four for about a week -- costs about $50. To make matters worse, she said, most Government employees have not been paid for at least four months.
As a result, Miss Dedeur Warder said, for the first time in recent memory, migration from the villages to the city appears to be slowing, and perhaps even reversing.
"People are leaving the city and returning to the bush because they understand there's no food, there are no jobs and there's no money here," she said. "Leaving Kinshasa is a drastic step for many Zairians, but it's one of the few solutions for stopping the misery here."

HEADLINE: On Air in Los Angeles, A (Rare) Serious Voice

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 15

 BODY:
In the wasteland that is broadcast journalism in Southern California -- in which reality is nightly distorted through a prism of high-speed car chases, rapes and drive-by shootings -- Warren Olney stands out like a lush oasis.
With a deep steady baritone that exudes both authority and impartiality, the veteran television reporter has turned a small cramped public-radio studio in a basement at Santa Monica College into the main broadcast forum for serious issues in the troubled Los Angeles area. 
 At a time when Southern California is struggling through its worst economic slump since the Depression, when Los Angeles is troubled by social and racial ills and is electing a mayor, these issues are virtually ignored by the commercial television news outlets -- particularly the three stations owned by major networks. The vacuum has been filled by Mr. Olney's hourlong program, "Which Way, L.A.?," broadcast weekday evenings on KCRW-FM and closely monitored in government, business and sometimes even among street gang members, whom he finds "astonishingly articulate, passionate, very sympathetic, oddly."
Each day at 1 P.M., five to eight guests talk live by telephone. Sitting in shirt sleeves at an octagonal table, the tall, trim 55-year-old Mr. Olney deftly leads them through discussions of matters like criminal justice, immigration, mayoral politics, military conversion, racism, education and gangs. Listeners are invited to join by phone. The program is rebroadcast at 7 P.M.
 
Longtime Television Reporter
 It is a long way from the days when Mr. Olney, a fourth-generation Californian whose great-grandfather was Mayor of Oakland, worked as reporter for all three of the network-owned stations in Los Angeles -- KCBS, KNBC and KABC -- as well as anchor for the independent KCOP. After 22 years in television, he quit the medium a year and a half ago.
"Television news was a serious enterprise once," he said recently, looking up through wire-rim glasses from a cluttered desk before air time. "The traditions observed were journalistic traditions. But now the shows are format-driven with calls for very brief stories.
"There is a minimum of production investment in trying to make complex issues important to a mass audience -- at a time when the need is greatest. Management has allowed a deterioration of standards of journalism to below minimal. Producers think politics is dull, so instead of trying to make interesting what they know is important, they abdicate responsibility for detailed coverage of politics and government."
Fairly typical of the Olney program was the April 27 installment, which discussed that night's "Frontline," a harsh documentary on Los Angeles and race relations.
 
Debating Racial Problems
 The guests were Kevin Starr, professor of urban and regional planning at the University of Southern California; Tim Rutten, an editorial writer at The Los Angeles Times; Sue Horton, assistant professor of journalism at U.S.C.; Susan Anderson, a black leader in the city; Donna Foote, an urban reporter for Newsweek here, and Ruben Martinez, a senior editor at the L.A. Weekly.
They debated Los Angeles's racial cauldron, and whether a national media dominated by "Frontline" and other Eastern-based organizations tended to give a distorted, simplistic view of this complex city.
"Olney offers far and away the most intelligent broadcast discourse in all of L.A. on matters of great public interest," said Joel Bellman, press deputy to Ed Edelman, chairman of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors.
"Which Way, L.A.?" began modestly a year ago just after the riots that tore the city apart after the verdicts in the first trial of police officers in the beating of Rodney G. King. Before that, Ruth Hirschman, general manager at KCRW since 1978, had steered away from local news, catering to an elite, mostly white audience that was more interested in the Soviet Union, Latin America and the Middle East than in Sacramento and South-Central Los Angeles.
 
A New Awareness
 Suddenly, Ms. Hirschman said, "the whole world understood something phenomenal was happening here which never happened before; there was an awareness that we were all in a caldron, something that sophisticated people did not think about before."
She turned to Mr. Olney, an acquaintance, because he had the "background, temperament, connections and a great Rolodex in his head." What was intended to be a monthlong temporary forum has now evolved into a permanent program that, according to Arbitron, has about 136,000 daily listeners, 10 percent to 15 percent above average for KCRW. Surveys show that about one-third of listeners are black and Hispanic, unusual for public radio. "We really set out to bring people from those communities on the air, to give them a hearing," Mr. Olney said.
The television critic for The Los Angeles Times, Howard Rosenberg, recently measured the news output of local commercial television on a typical Monday night. He found that crime and other "negative news" took up the bulk of time not devoted to happy talk, sports and weather. KCBS (Channel 2), for example, devoted 11 of 11 1/2 minutes of a recent report to crime, mainly to an attempted carjacking in Beverly Hills, and, as usual, nothing about the mayor's race.
 
30 Seconds of Thanks
 Meanwhile, KNBC (Channel 4) used 24 of its 27 minutes of news for negative news, not including an endless half minute in which the announcer, Colleen Williams, thanked her station colleagues for a baby shower.
Mr. Olney has theories to explain this avoidance of significant news. Partly, he says, it has to do with the sprawl of the Los Angeles region, in which the City of Los Angeles is only one of scores of communities in the television market. "That becomes a handy excuse for not doing anything," he said.
Asked for comment, the news directors of KCBS, KNBC and KABC did not return telephone calls.
There are other forums for serious issues here, including the Michael Jackson program on KABC-AM radio; "Life & Times," weekday evenings on KCET-TV, and a weekly political discussion run by Bill Rosendahl on Century Cable Television, seen in some parts of the region. But none have quite the regular impact and following that Mr. Olney's does.

HEADLINE: The 'Forgotten Borough' Makes Its Voice Heard

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Queens, the self-described "forgotten borough" that nearly broke John V. Lindsay, cemented Edward I. Koch's neoconservative coalition, and gave Rudolph W. Giuliani more votes than David N. Dinkins received from any single borough four years ago, is flexing its political muscles again.
Last week alone, Carol A. Gresser, the New York City Board of Education member appointed by Borough President Claire Shulman, was elected president of the board after earlier providing the pivotal vote to oust Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez. And Representative Thomas J. Manton, who doubles as the Queens Democratic leader, endorsed Mr. Dinkins for re-election and urged the Mayor's chief remaining threat to renomination, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, to quit the race. 
 Mr. Manton and Ms. Shulman were motivated by separate -- arguably, even conflicting -- agendas. But both moves reflect the growing influence of a borough that was never quite comfortable with joining Greater New York (indeed, Flushing voted against the 1898 consolidation), is again considering secession and has always been more politically and emotionally akin to the suburbs and the rest of America than to Manhattan.
While the Governor, the Assembly Speaker in Albany and the City Council Speaker are all from Queens, since 1898 no candidate born in Queens has been elected Mayor.
 
Ignore at Your Risk
 Still, said Edward Sadowsky, a former City Councilman and Board ofEducation member from Queens, "the borough does represent a sentiment that has to be taken into account and a point of view that you ignore at your own peril."
Fairly or unfairly Queens has for years served as a metaphor for the Archie Bunker brand of middle-class values that have also been associated with the city's least populous borough, Staten Island. Yet instead of being notable for its differences, Queens does embody an ideology that crosses the geographic and arbitrary political boundaries that separate the boroughs.
Writing in the latest edition of "City Journal," published by the Manhattan Institute, Frank J. Macchiarola, the former schools chancellor and now a law school dean, recalled that "outer borough New Yorkers can be found in Manhattan and Manhattan types can be found in the outer boroughs" -- though another barrier begins today, when Manhattan exclusively claims 212 as its own area code.
"Outer borough" values also cross racial lines in Queens. If Archie Bunker had been a real Queens resident rather than a television character, he probably would have retired to Florida by now after selling his one-family home to a middle-class black or Hispanic couple. In Queens, perhaps to a greater degree than any other major county in the country, blacks and whites have achieved statistical equity in median household income.
 
'Different Complexion'
 Last week Dennis Walcott, the newest member of the Board of Education, who happens to be from Queens and who also happens to be black, said he generally opposed policies of making condoms available in high schools without parental consent and of teaching children about gay and lesbian life styles before the sixth grade -- the very policies that persuaded Mrs. Gresser to vote against renewing Mr. Fernandez's contract. Mr. Walcott also happens to be Mr. Dinkins's appointee.
"People talk about Staten Island as being on some other universe," Mr. Sadowsky said, "but Queens does have a different complexion from the rest of the city. Even its black politicians are likely to be more conservative than those in Manhattan."
Queens, said Mr. Koch, "is the borough of moderation."
Until provoked, that is. Queens voters rebelled against Mr. Lindsay in 1969 over the city's failure to deliver services adequately -- most egregiously, its insufficent snow removal -- and its placement of a low-income housing project in middle-class Forest Hills. Mr. Lindsay lost the Republican primary and was outpolled in the general election by his Democratic and Republican rivals by almost 2-to-1 in Queens.
After defeating Mario M. Cuomo of Queens in the 1977 mayoral race, Mr. Koch, a Manhattan Congressman, consolidated his political appeal in the borough where he had first gained a footing by opposing the very same Forest Hills low-income housing project that was built only after Mr. Cuomo fashioned a compromise.
 
Returning the Favor
 In 1981, 1985 and even 1989, Queens returned the favor, providing Mr. Koch with margins he needed to counter liberal inroads elsewhere. Mr. Koch, in turn, forged an alliance with the Queens Democratic organization -- which, after it was implicated as the centerpiece of the municipal corruption scandals, tainted his administration.
But in the 1989 primary, according to an analysis by John H. Mollenkopf and his associates at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, as many as 17 percent of the voters in a white Catholic district in Richmond Hill strategically voted for Mr. Dinkins against Mr. Koch in the Democratic primary, mainly in order to remove him as an obstacle to Mr. Giuliani's election that November.
Mr. Giuliani received more than 284,000 votes in Queens to 190,000 for Mr. Dinkins, whose biggest total from any borough was the 277,000 he got in Brooklyn.
Those figures must have been gnawing at Mr. Manton, who had endorsed two other candidates before settling on Mr. Dinkins four years ago and who nearly lost to a Republican when he sought re-election to Congress last year.
Only two mayors since 1933 have hailed from outside Manhattan, and the others -- Mr. Lindsay, perhaps, excepted -- sought to contain the political quakes that occasionally erupted in Queens and reverberated all over the city.
Fiorello H. La Guardia actually spent his summers in College Point. Robert F. Wagner, recalled Edward N. Costikyan, a prominent lawyer and the former Manhattan Democratic leader, "never allowed Manhattan liberalism to override his sense of what was palatable in the other boroughs."
 
Low Poverty, High Income
 Walter L. McCaffrey, a Councilman who is loyal both to Mr. Manton and to Mr. Stein, said yesterday, "If the question is whether this is a resurgence by Queens, the answer is that it is a continuation."
By almost every measure, Queens is different. Poverty in Queens is below the national average. And while it is described as the most ethnically and racially diverse county in the country -- about one-third of the population is foreign-born -- it boasts the highest median household income among the four largest boroughs, the lowest unemployment rate and the fewest reported AIDS cases.
If any public official embodies the borough's middle-class homeowner mentality, it is Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, although he maintains that the borough, while very important, is not unique.
"The majority of people in every borough feel that in some way Queens is reflecting what many people feel -- just that we in Queens never forgot it. The notion that every kid has sex and doesn't listen to their parents -- we don't know who they're talking about."
"An evolution has taken place," he added. "New York is catching up to the rest of the country. It is really mainstream and middle class."

HEADLINE: India Bombings: Gangs Involved, But Who Else?

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOMBAY, India, May 11

 BODY:
For nearly two hours on March 12, explosions thundered through this city, sending pillars of black smoke skyward.
First the stock exchange was jarred by a blast that collapsed walls and ceilings. Then the central office of Air India shuddered under the force of a blast. And then, through the city, more bombs, more columns of thick, sooty smoke. By the time the explosions ended, more than 250 people had died. 
 Now, after two months of investigation, the police say that it is clear that the bombings were committed by members of the city's organized crime networks, and they have arrested nearly 100 suspects, all of them Muslims.
Perhaps more signifcantly, they believe that the bombings were in retaliation for the killings of hundreds of Muslims in this city in December and January and that some foreign government or organization was behind the blasts. But there is little evidence that points to any particular government or organization or substantiates their theory of retaliation.
 
Hundreds Are Questioned
 The police have questioned hundreds of witnesses, summoned specialists from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and sought information on terrorism from Western intelligence agencies. But as in the bombing of the World Trade Center in New York, while the authorities believe they have arrested the people who carried out the attack, they do not know who was behind it.
Overshadowing the investigation are the raw tensions between Pakistan and India: even before investigators began assembling evidence a wide range of Indian politicians, both senior Government officials and opposition leaders, accused the Pakistani Government of masterminding the blasts.
Despite these accusations, Bombay's top police officials say there is scant evidence that points to Pakistan.
What they do know, they say, is that Bombay's criminal underworld was deeply involved in the bombings. But the police, who have no organized crime task force and have never jailed senior gang members for any crime, say they are uncertain why the underworld took part.
"This is fairly well thought out," said Amarjeet Singh Samra, the Bombay Police Commissioner. "There is lots of money involved, explosives, landing operations, transport, procuring vehicles. The thinking has gone on for a couple of months, it could have been October or November.
"You can't do this job unless you take a very professional approach. Whichever country organized it has done it in a very professional way. They won't have links with anybody. I am not saying it is Pakistan. I am not saying it is Iran. I am just saying it is a foreign power."
Last December, and again in January, Bombay was torn by violence, the first wave pitting the police against Muslims enraged over the destruction of a mosque in northern India by Hindu militants, and the second a pogrom against Muslims by Hindu gangs.
The violence left the city's Muslim minority frightened and angry, and left unsettled as well the confidence that had been a hallmark of Bombay, the economic heart of India.
Then came the bombings in March.
 
A Vehicle's Number Is Found in Debris
 Almost immediately, the Home Minister, Shankarrao Bhaorao Chavan, who heads the country's internal security forces, labeled the attack "an international conspiracy." The leader of the Hindu chauvinist Bharatiya Janata Party lashed out at Pakistan, and, by inference, at India's Muslims.
"The needle of suspicion is pointing very strongly at Pakistan," Lal Krishna Advani, the Hindu party leader, said the day after the explosions. "Maybe the brain is in Islamabad, but the hand is certainly here and it is the hand of traitors." He offered no evidence to support his charges.
Bombay's police, who had no experience in investigations of this sort or size, quickly made considerable progress. As in the investigation of the bombing of the World Trade Center, a vehicle identification number was recovered from the debris at the stock exchange.
Two agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrived within days to examine the blast sites, but apparently found them so disturbed that they were unable to uncover much significant evidence.
"The Bombay authorities were so intent on getting things back to normal, like the stock exchange, that they destroyed a lot of evidence," a diplomat said. "The bomb sites were never closed off."
But in the days after the explosions, the police did find unexploded bombs in the storage compartments of several motor scooters. They also found a small maroon van containing seven AK-56 assault rifles and four hand grenades. Almost immediately, the police traced the owner of the van and found that it belonged to one of Bombay's underworld families, the Memons.
 
Family's Trail Followed to Dubai
 Like all of Bombay's crime families, the Memons operated with virtual impunity. Ibrahim Memon, nicknamed Tiger, began his career by smuggling with his five brothers.
"He was a small-time operator dealing in smuggled goods, gold, watches, that sort of thing," said Vasant Keshaorao Saraf, who retired as the director general of police eight months ago. "Then he got involved in protection."
When the police, after tracing the owner of the maroon van, hurried to the Memons' apartment the evening of the bombings, they found the entire Memon family gone. After checking with the airlines, investigators learned that all 12 members of the family had left Bombay for Dubai over a nine-day period before the explosions.
With the Memons' flight, Bombay's police believe they lost the key link in the chain of evidence that would have provided insight into who, or which country, was behind the bombings.
But they arrested more and more suspects, moving from one arrest to the next as interrogations revealed the names of others who took part in the bombings. At the same time, the questioning of those arrested led to caches of weapons and explosives, material the police believe was part of a larger terrorist plot.
"This cannot be the work of ordinary criminals," said M. N. Singh, the police official directly supervising the investigation. "They don't go in for mass destruction. This was done to destabilize the country. Obviously only someone with an organization and resources could do this."
But, he added, "those who know everything are out of our net."
 
Suspects Recount Training in Pakistan
 Throughout April, Indian officials issued a series of often contradictory statements on the explosions, some accusing Pakistan, others maintaining there was no evidence pointing to Islamabad.
Ten of those arrested told the police that they had been flown to Islamabad in February, along with 20 other people, where they had been shown how to fire Kalishnikov assault rifles and how to throw hand grenades.
Most incriminating, Mr. Samra said, was that the passports of the suspects did not show Pakistan entry stamps, evidence, he said, that there was complicity by Pakistan to admit the suspects.
According to Western diplomats, militant Islamic fundamentalists have long used Pakistan as a training base, particularly during the 14-year war in Afghanistan. None of these diplomats said they were surprised that the suspects could have been in Pakistan, but they said that this itself did not prove the complicity of the Pakistani Government. "A lot goes on here," said one diplomat in Islamabad, "and the Government doesn't necessarily know about it."
Another diplomat said the insistence by officials in New Delhi that Pakistan was involved was hurting the investigation. He also said that the Bombay police knew little about organized crime in the city.
 
 
The Rise to Power Of Organized Crime
 Bombay's underworld -- a flourishing assortment of smuggling operations, protection and extortion rackets, illegal foreign exchange dealers and unlawful construction outfits -- began much the way organized crime started in the United States.
"Bombay is known for decades for street dadas, street toughs, the bully," said Mr. Saraf, the former police official. "They carried flick knives. They weren't everywhere, but they were there. Then prohibition came in '49 and '50. And with that came the first rudimentary organized crime. Illicit distillation became an industry. A cartel-like thing came together."
As socialism, currency controls and bans on imports became part of India's economic strategy, organized crime prospered. "Gold smuggling began in 1962," Mr. Samra said. So-called black money -- income that is earned illicitly and that is untaxed -- "grew because of government controls and restrictions."
"So much money was put into gold," Mr. Samra said. "And where did the gold come from? Dubai."
A man named Dawood Ibrahim, a former street hoodlum, became the city's leading gangster after moving into smuggling and protection rackets in the late 1970's, officials say.
"Twice cases were taken against him for killings, in '83 and '84," Mr. Saraf said. "In both cases he got bail from the court. He thought things were getting too hot and one fine morning he landed in Dubai."
Since then, officials say, Mr. Ibrahim has used Dubai as a base for running his criminal enterprises in Bombay and his legitimate trading businesses in the Persian Gulf and Europe. The Bombay police suspect he was involved in the bombings; he denies any role.
 
The Search Is On For a 'Third Force'
 By the end of April, the Bombay police, and Mr. Samra in particular, had changed their view of the origins of the conspiracy, saying that more than criminal activities were involved.
"Obviously the Memons and Dawood don't gain from this," Mr. Samra said. "There is some third force behind it. Someone wanted to hit India. The Memons and Dawood were told to take revenge. After the riots in December and January, people felt aggrieved. The Memons provided a ready-made infrastructure."
Many of the people who made up that infrastructure, low-level street criminals, have been arrested by the police, who now say that nearly 100 are in custody. All of those arrested, from those who actually planted bombs, to those who helped store explosives, to those who said they were trained in Pakistan, are Muslims. But none were in on the planning of the bombings, the police commissioner said.
"They didn't have an idea of why they were doing it," Mr. Samra said. "Some of them were told it was to take revenge for the riots. These boys just did what they were told to do."
In Bombay, there is an acute awareness that all those arrested are Muslims. And within the Muslim community there is a mixture of concern that Muslims will be singled out for reprisals by Hindus. But there is a quiet satisfaction about the bombings as well, a feeling that Muslim confidence had been restored after the violence of December and January.
Abbabhai Kamruddin sat on a shelf in his small shop in the Nagpada area of Bombay, a mostly Muslim neighborhood. Around him were long rolls of canvas, muslin and plastic, fabrics used to make carry bags.
"In January, they were entering the houses of Muslims and slaughtering them," he said in an unmistakable reference to Hindus. "But after the bomb blasts they are a little afraid. In the past, if a man with a beard was on the bus, they used to tease him. Now there is no taunting. The insults have stopped."

A victim lay in front of a car after a blast at a gas station. (Reuters) (pg. 10)

HEADLINE: Appeals Court Upholds Shifting of Hospital Costs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 15

 BODY:
A divided Federal appeals court ruled Friday that states may legally shift the hospital costs of caring for people without insurance onto those who have it.
The 2-to-1 decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, reversed a May 1992 ruling by Judge Alfred M. Wolin of Federal Court in Newark, who struck down New Jersey's hospital rate-setting system. 
 Albert G. Kroll, a lawyer for some of the 14 labor union benefit plans that sued, said his clients were considering further appeals.
Judge Wolin's ruling led to a sweeping overhaul of New Jersey's health regulations in November, including the imposition of a payroll tax to cover uncompensated hospital costs. Unemployment taxes were reduced at the same time, so workers and employers would not notice.
Since the laws were changed, the appellate ruling's impact on New Jersey is limited to bolstering efforts by hospitals to collect an estimated $130 million in payment withheld by union and other self-insured benefit plans before the new law took effect.
A spokesman for the New Jersey Hospital Association, Ronald Czajkowski, said the ruling was being closely watched in other states, like New York, where cost-shifting regulations were being challenged.
Hospitals commonly build into their basic rates the costs of charity care and unpaid bills. In New Jersey a system of surcharges was developed in 1978 to equalize costs between wealthy suburban hospitals where most patients are insured, and urban centers where most are uninsured or underinsured.
The uncompensated care surcharge had grown to 19.1 percent in 1992 when Judge Wolin ruled in favor of labor unions that the charges violated the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, which prohibits unions or other self-insured benefit programs from providing coverage to non-participants.
Judge Walter K. Stapleton, writing for the Circuit Court panel's majority, disagreed.
"This effect is no different in kind, however, from any state regulation that increases the cost of goods and services that hospitals consume and pass on," he wrote.

HEADLINE: Kentuckians Try to Rein In Suburbia

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky.

 BODY:
The way Bob Clay sees it, Kentucky's Bluegrass Country is a national treasure, much like the Grand Canyon or the Great Lakes or the Florida Keys.
"It's one of those special places that Americans like to celebrate and visit," said Mr. Clay, a horse breeder. "Mention the word 'thoroughbred,' and people see in the mind's eye neatly fenced pastures with frisky foals rolling around in lush bluegrass. Maybe there's a picturesque barn standing on a hill beyond." 
 But these days the vista does not always end there. In a growing number of places, especially around Lexington, housing subdivisions are creeping toward the barns and pastures and frisky foals. The turf where the likes of Man o' War and Whirlaway and Secretariat once grazed contentedly is beginning to disappear.
 
More and More Pavement
 In fact, some horse farms have already been chewed up and transformed into suburbs, complete with cul-de-sacs studded with enough of those little front-yard jockey statues to run a full card of races. Fast-food restaurants abut paddocks where champion studs court skittish mares. There is even a plan to bulldoze part of one breeding farm, pave it and put up a shopping mall.
"I'm afraid that the celebration of the Bluegrass Country occurs more outside of Kentucky than inside," Mr. Clay lamented. "People just assume that there are stewards who will take care of this national treasure. But if you look around, you'll see that you can't take that for granted. We've got to take action."
To that end, Mr. Clay and a group of business leaders and planners in the Lexington area have formed Bluegrass Tomorrow, an organization whose goal is to come up with a plan that will encourage growth in the region while keeping that growth from destroying the uniqueness of the Bluegrass Country.
No final decision has been made. But in general the group hopes to persuade local governments to adopt zoning and easement policies that will lead to clustering of houses and shopping areas, with farms left in between.
 
Still Much to Save
 None of this is to say that the last horse farm will be gone in a matter of a few years.
Despite the encroachment of houses and shopping centers, and despite some bankruptcies among horse breeders who overextended themselves while trying to take advantage of tax write-offs, the fact is there is still a lot of open Bluegrass Country left.
But the danger of further encroachment is real because the Lexington area is steadily gaining population, growing to 348,000 residents in 1990 from 267,000 in 1970, an increase of just over 30 percent.
The region is coming out of the recession in fairly good shape, with unemployment now down to 4 percent, and local planners are confident that manufacturers and other businesses will be drawn to the region's readily available labor force, its easy assess by interstate highways from Eastern and Midwestern centers and, of course, its natural beauty and enviable quality of life.
 
Tobacco Loses Ground
 From Lexington, its heart and soul, Bluegrass Country extends for 25 miles or so in all directions, encompassing a half-dozen smaller towns and villages. In some places, tobacco farms are mixed in among the horse farms, but their number has dwindled with growing health concerns about smoking.
Whether the grass is actually blue is in the eye of the beholder. Those who perceive a bit of tint say it derives from the plate of limestone that lies beneath the rich, dark soil of the region. They also insist that the grass, because it contains minerals taken up from the limestone, gives Kentucky thoroughbreds a soundness not found in thoroughbreds raised anywhere else.
"You can argue endlessly about the color and mineral content of bluegrass," said Horst Schach, the chairman of the landscape architecture department at the University of Kentucky and a member of Bluegrass Tomorrow. "But what you can't argue about is the record of Kentucky horses. They've got to be getting that extra push and strength from somewhere. People keep coming to this part of Kentucky to buy and breed, more than anywhere else. That's reason enough to come up with a plan to save the bluegrass."
 
Challenges on Horizon
 Other communities around the country, including some of the suburban towns and cities on the outskirts of Washington, have experimented with plans to maintain open space through special zoning and easement provisions. It is too early to assess success, but in almost every case the zoning aspects were politically difficult to sell to developers, while buying easements from farmers to maintain a rural atmosphere proved costly.
Bluegrass Tomorrow is likely to face a similar challenge once it decides on the final details of its plan.
"They have a laudable goal in trying to save the bluegrass," said Bill Justice, a Lexington real estate agent who specializes in horse farms. "But it's a tricky balance trying to maintain growth and life style. The politics can be especially difficult because so many interests are at stake."
Leaders of Bluegrass Tomorrow say they do not underestimate the challenge.
"We've got a real tough selling job ahead of us," said Joe Graves, a Lexington banker who helped found the group. "But we can't afford to fail. Already we've begun destroying the main engine of our economy, the very thing that most sets the tone for our lives. If we don't move, and move now, we're going to wake up one day and find there's no bluegrass left, and it's too late to replant."

HEADLINE: Average Traffic Speed: 2.7 Miles Per Hour

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
After a day slogging through the Garment District in a rickety truck loaded with dress suits, Jerome Miller was nearing the end of his delivery route. One more stop, he muttered as he lurched down Seventh Avenue. But then he turned west onto 37th Street, and suddenly it seemed as if he had driven into a bog.
Trucks and vans appeared to be glued to the street. There was only one escape, a cramped passage to Eighth Avenue, but even that was jammed with workers unloading clothing. Men pushing racks of dresses lunged on and off the sidewalks. Pedestrians danced around the stranded vehicles.
 
'It's Crazy Out There'
 Time had been defeated. There was no progress. Mr. Miller and his truck had been swallowed up by perhaps the most congested block in New York City. 
 "It's crazy out here, trust me," Mr. Miller, 28, yelled when he reached the middle of the block 15 minutes later. He double-parked to make his delivery, adding another obstruction to a street that symbolizes how difficult it is to unclog traffic in the city's commercial areas.
Sometimes it seems that every roadway in New York is maddeningly congested, but even by the city's abysmal standards, a few stand out. When traffic engineers survey vehicle speeds in midtown Manhattan twice a year during business hours, 37th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues almost always tops the list of the slowest blocks.
Vehicles average 2.7 miles an hour, meaning that human beings can often walk faster than their mechanical rivals can drive -- that is, if the human beings can navigate the clothing-rack-and-shipping-carton obstacles on the sidewalks.
"If you have a heart attack on this block and an ambulance wants to get here, consider yourself dead," said Dennis Martinez, 25, a freight elevator operator at 241 West 37th Street who spends much of his day watching (and musing upon) the kaleidoscope of activity in front of his building.
Thirty-seventh Street and other notoriously crowded midtown blocks -- like 53d Street between Park and Madison Avenues or 46th Street between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue -- are more than just annoyances that provoke temper tantrums from normally composed adults. The congestion contributes to air pollution and traffic delays that drain $7 billion a year from the city's economy, studies show.
So untangling these roadways through technology, stepped-up enforcement or other measures will not only make life easier for Garment District workers like Mr. Miller and Mr. Martinez, but also provide benefits to the city as a whole.
The challenge, though, is immense.
On 37th Street, there are daily truck accidents amid processions of well-coiffed industry buyers, gangs of thieves who take advantage of the frenzy to snatch clothes off moving racks and fistfights over parking spots that are more coveted than the latest Donna Karan dress.
Parking signs are mounted against the buildings because so many vehicles used to knock them over while pulling into spots (and some deliverers then stole them so they would not receive tickets). Some United Parcel Service trucks receive up to four parking tickets a day.
What is more, many vehicles not connected to the Garment District use the block to reach the nearby Lincoln Tunnel -- a foolish choice, it usually turns out.
 
Frustrated Firefighters
 All this unfolds to an unending soundtrack of car horns, yelps of frustration and roaring engines.
The block "is the closest thing that we have to the photographs of the Lower East Side during the turn of the century," said Joseph DePlasco, the chief spokesman for the Department of Transportation. "There is an extraordinary amount of diverse activity."
Not to mention the firehouse.
Most firefighters worry about deadly blazes. The members of Engine Company 26 worry just as much about getting to them. They work out of a firehouse that was built in the middle of the block, at 220 West 37th Street, during the Civil War, well before the Garment District rose around it.
Several times a week, a call comes in and they must maneuver their truck to a fire in their section (from 34th to 42d Street between Sixth and Eighth Avenues). The deliverers, freight elevator operators and other regulars on the block long ago stopped reacting to horns and sirens, so the firefighters use other strategies.
 
Help From the Homeless
 They jump off their rig and try to direct traffic. Or they turn the truck around and drive east -- the wrong direction -- on 37th Street. Sometimes, homeless men who loiter near the avenues run into the street to halt delivery trucks at the intersections.
"People just don't get out of the way," said Joe Petrich, 48, a firefighter who has worked at Engine Company 26 for 21 years. He often stands guard in front of the firehouse to shoo away truckers who salivate when they see the empty space in front of the building's driveway.
Not everyone curses the chaos. To many executives at the factories and wholesale showrooms in the area, the din indicates that the Garment District remains vibrant despite the recurring predictions of its demise. In fact, Iranian, Syrian and other immigrants have opened numerous retail and wholesale clothing stores on 37th Street in recent years, helping to revitalize an area that was starting to lose factories and other tenants to New Jersey.
"Thank God it's congested, or we'd be out of business," said Gary Welikson, 40, a partner at Royal Craft Trimming Corporation, a wholesaler. "Business people who see activity feel things are happening. It feeds on itself. Business people feel more confident."
 
Speed vs. Business
 For transportation officials, that is the problem: How can they speed up traffic in commercial areas without damaging businesses? Currently, for example, trucks can park on many Garment District streets for up to three hours to make deliveries. Officials could easily liberate some roadways if they sharply reduced that time limit.
But that move would wreck many companies, turning the area into the ghost town that it seems at night, when workers have gone home and the streets are deserted.
Officials are hoping that a new system of sensors to monitor congestion along with "smart" traffic lights -- part of a $100 million traffic-tracking network -- will help reduce crowding. Some traffic agents now complain that the light changes at many intersections in the Garment District are too quick, so trucks do not have time to pull through the mobs of people crossing streets before the lights turn red.
With "smart" traffic lights, engineers could instantly change the length of red signals from a control center to move traffic more smoothly. Another option is to ban some vehicles from certain areas -- particularly cars, which tend to be the most flagrant violators of parking rules.
 
Can't Have Everything
 "There is this sense that anyone should be allowed to be on any street they want to," Mr. DePlasco said. "But we can't have that all the time. Theoretically, somewhere down the line, you may see restrictions on vehicles moving on some places around Manhattan."
That change would appeal to workers like Anthony Arias, 28, who spends his days delivering cardboard boxes to showrooms on 37th Street. Mr. Arias was recently released from a boot-camp-style prison for an assault conviction. He said he had learned some powerful lessons there for dealing with his job.
As he pulls his heavy hand cart along the streets and sidewalks, dodging racks and pedestrians and trucks and bicylists, he repeats a mantra to himself that he learned from the prison guards: "You have to accept things you cannot change and change the things that you can."
"Emotionally, it breaks you down," he said of the block. "Mentally, it wears you out. It's hectic and it's tiring, but it's the only job around, and for $4.25 an hour."
Others workers on 37th Street are just as fatalistic.
"What can they do to make things better?" asked Mr. Martinez, the freight elevator operator. "I don't think a man in this world has the answer. That answer has to come from heaven."

HEADLINE: After a Wedding, a Death in the Family

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YONKERS, May 12

 BODY:
When Iona College agreed to consolidate with Elizabeth Seton College four years ago, both institutions were pleased with the prospects of an academic marriage in the Roman Catholic tradition.
For Iona, a four-year college in New Rochelle founded by the Congregation of Christian Brothers, it meant an expansion of its programs in Westchester County. For Elizabeth Seton, a financially troubled two-year college established by the Sisters of Charity, it promised survival into the next century. 
 But now for many at Elizabeth Seton -- or more accurately, the Yonkers campus of Iona College -- that friendly merger is feeling more like a hostile takeover. At the end of this month, Iona will close the doors of the 21-acre campus overlooking the Hudson River here.
 
Drop in Enrollment
 Officials at Iona say the decision to shut down the campus was painful but necessary because of a drop in enrollment over the past two years. That, and the cost of catching up on maintenance that had been deferred until the consolidation will leave the Yonkers campus $1 million in the red this year.
"There are some people who haven't left the funeral parlor yet," said Brother John G. Driscoll, president of Iona College. "I had to leave it, but I took the living with me."
It is not merely grief that many faculty, administrators and students are grappling with, however; it is a sense of betrayal.
"Iona College took us over with all sorts of assurances and promises and task forces saying we would remain autonomous," said Myra Russel, an associate professor of English at the Seton School of Associate Degree Studies. "All the promises that were made are now null and void."
Some of the most bitter critics of the decision argue that Iona could have taken less drastic measures, such as selling off a piece of the valuable riverside campus, in order to preserve the legacy of Elizabeth Seton College, named for the first American-born saint. They say that Iona, which acquired $1.7 million in debt during the consolidation, now stands to make millions of dollars by selling the entire property.
 
Seeing Dollar Signs?
 Some speculate that Iona had dollar signs in its eyes when the consolidation agreement was signed. They say Iona could have prevented the downturn in enrollment by doing more to promote the associate degree programs. Iona counters that the Seton students -- many of them from poor families -- were hurt by the recession and government cuts in financial aid.
But most people at Seton say they believe Iona simply lacked the commitment to ride out a shaky period. Seton's enrollment is now 426, which is higher than it was before consolidation. Enrollment jumped after the merger to a high of 737 in 1990, but has since steadily slid. And it is a fraction of the total 5,759 students at Iona.
"It's possible it was not a deliberate plan but rather something where they said to themselves, 'We'll do this and if it doesn't work out, we always have an escape hatch -- a valuable property to sell,' " said Richard L. Nochimson, the academic dean of Seton from 1976 to 1986. "But, of course, that was really double-dealing. Seton's finances were marginal but we were not gasping for breath, and we certainly weren't within four years of having to close."
 
Not Alone in Troubles
 According to the American Association of Community Colleges in Washington, the Seton campus is not alone in its troubles: the number of private two-year colleges has fallen from 216 in 1975 to 164 in 1990. Public two-year colleges, where tuition is lower, expanded during the same period, from 1,014 to 1,273.
National trends are little solace here, however. "Personally, I don't think Iona had good intentions when they merged," said George Scudieri, 22, a lab instructor in the Radio-Television Department who just got a pink slip since he is considered part of the staff, not the faculty, which is under contract.
"Iona spent a lot of money in the 80's and now they're in debt," he said, referring to new construction at the New Rochelle campus. "Brother Driscoll dug himself into a hole and he saw the solution in Elizabeth Seton."
Iona strongly defends itself against such allegations, saying it had entered into the consolidation with genuine excitement and was looking forward to creating an arts center out of the limestone mansion designed by Carrere & Hastings, who also did the New York Public Library, that is the heart of campus. Known as the Alder manor house, it is home to 12 nuns.
"I had a lot of grieving to do myself, because I was the one who spoke most romantically about the vision at the time of consolidation," Brother Driscoll said.
As for Iona's own finances, he acknowledged that last year the college did not break even for the first time in his 22-year presidency, but he said that the budget was now in line.
Iona has promised to transfer all students from the Yonkers campus, along with their academic programs, to the New Rochelle campus. For next fall only, the Seton students will get a break on tuition, paying what they would have paid had the Yonkers campus remained open -- about $1,000 less than at Iona.
Iona plans to honor all faculty contracts through next June, bringing some three dozen professors over to New Rochelle. Beyond that, however, hiring of nontenured faculty will be based on student enrollment, while those with tenure will have guaranteed jobs for as long as their departments remain open.
The sisters, some of whom still teach, have shunned publicity since the announcement Jan. 25 that their campus would close. But they are said to be devastated; a few have lived in the manor house since the college was founded in 1960.
Iona is considering a number of proposals for the property, zoned for education use, including one from a university in Turkey. Closer to home, one scenario that would carry on theSeton spirit would be a proposal from Mercy College in nearby Dobbs Ferry -- itself an institution with Catholic roots -- and the City of Yonkers, which has expressed interest in a linkage between Mercy and the city's schools.
Residential or commercial zoning would certainly be more lucrative, but the Mayor of Yonkers, Terence M. Zaleski, a former teacher, seems intent on keeping it a campus.
"A city is very much defined by the types of institutions within its borders," he said, "and having an institution of higher learning is good for us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: When Iona College agreed to consolidate with Elizabeth Seton College four years ago, both institutions were pleased with the union. But now many at the Elizabeth Seton campus in Yonkers, above, are feeling betrayed because at the end of this month, Iona will permanently close the 21-acre campus. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Mayoral Candidates Look Past the Primary

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
For years, the maxim of New York's fractious but politically dominant Democrats as they faced make-or-break primaries was N.D.C., which really stood for the national New Democratic Coalition but came to mean "November doesn't count." In this year's mayoral election, however, most politicians are already acting as if November is the only thing that counts.
To be sure, Mayor David N. Dinkins still faces a Democratic primary challenge from his long-time nemesis, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, and from Roy Innis, the chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, though he holds a roughly 30-point lead over Mr. Stein in all the polls and Mr. Innis has only single-digit support. 
 But the maneuvering last week surrounding the withdrawal of the fourth Democratic hopeful, Herman Badillo, showed just how thoroughly the candidates have jumped beyond the September primary in their strategies. Mr. Dinkins's Republican challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani, is trying to forge an alliance with Mr. Badillo by persuading him to run instead for Comptroller with multiparty support.
Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani won the endorsement of the state's Liberal Party, as he did in 1989, which lends plausibility to his pledge to forge a broad coalition. [Page 34.]
The Mayor's supporters are making similar efforts to look ahead to November. Those range from faltering attempts to forge an alliance with a Hispanic candidate for the No. 2 office, Public Advocate, to entreaties to secure Mr. Dinkins the nomination of the New Party -- an independent group founded by some of the Mayor's most liberal allies in organized labor to prod the Democrats from the left. That could provide extra votes or a fallback for the general-election ballot in case, unlikely as it seems now, he should lose the Democratic nomination.
Even a lukewarm Dinkins ally like Representative Thomas J. Manton, the Queens Democratic leader, felt compelled to rally around the Mayor in the cause of party unity last week and to urge his old friend Mr. Stein to run for re-election instead.
All of this jockeying is testament to the fundamental facts of Mr. Dinkins's political life. On the one hand, his rock solid support among black voters gives him the biggest single electoral bloc of any candidate. In fact, at roughly one-third of the primary electorate, it is almost enough to assure the 40 percent needed under election rules to avoid a runoff.
But he cannot win a general election without expanding significantly beyond that base and surveys over the last two years have revealed an extreme polarization between black and white New Yorkers' views of him. With Mr. Stein running so far behind, many white voters who would normally be reflexive Democrats have apparently already settled on Mr. Giuliani as the only plausible alternative.
"What's unusual here is that there has not been in the past a two-party system in New York," said Maureen Connelly, a political consultant who has advised both Democratic and Republican candidates and is not involved in the current race. "And when a strong individual arises, there's the appearance of strength," she added, referring to Mr. Giuliani.
So comes the quest by both camps for the swing voters -- Hispanic New Yorkers, homosexuals, women, Jews -- that can tip the balance.
General-election battles for City Hall are hardly unheard of, of course. John V. Lindsay faced them in 1965 and 1969, first as a Republican and then as the Liberal nominee. Edward I. Koch, the Democratic nominee, barely held off Mario M. Cuomo, the Liberal nominee in 1977. And four years ago, Mr. Dinkins defeated Mr. Giuliani by just 2 percentage points, by putting together a coalition of black, Hispanic and liberal white voters, but only after each candidate had faced significant primary fights.
 
Lookin Ahead
 But at no time in the recent past has the prospect of a real general-election fight loomed over a primary season as desultory as this one has been so far -- much less a November rematch between the same two well-known candidates. That itself has advisers to both the Mayor and Mr. Giuliani on tenterhooks. Meantime, recent polls have shown Mr. Dinkins's support slipping among such key groups as Hispanic voters and Mr. Giuliani's growing.
Bill Lynch, the Mayor's campaign manager, has said over and over that his biggest worry is that complacency among Mr. Dinkins's Democratic supporters could translate into trouble in November.
The Giuliani camp -- while supremely grateful to face no Republican opposition like the $14 million fusillade in 1989 from Ronald Lauder, the conservative cosmetics executive -- is equally on guard. Last time, Mr. Giuliani conceived his campaign as a challenge to the scarred three-term incumbent, Mr. Koch, only to find himself the only thing blocking Mr. Dinkins's bid to become the city's first black Mayor and fumbling for weeks as a result.
"I think it's right to say that it's not right from a political point of view to already be so focused on November, because you never know what's going to happen in politics," said Mr. Giuliani's chief strategist, David Garth. "But the primary appears to be, in many politicians' minds, over. If Andy was within 10 or 15 points, things would be a lot different. There's also a sense that the Mayor's in some difficulty, so people are searching for alliances or something different."
Mr. Stein maintains that Mr. Badillo's withdrawal enables him to home in on the Mayor, and that may be the case, since Mr. Stein has enough money to continue his campaign. But so far even a month of costly television advertising has only seen him sink further in the polls.
As the incumbent, Mr. Dinkins holds many powerful advantages for November: ready access to news organizations and to fund-raising from the city's permanent business establishment in real estate and finance, which is wary of rocking the boat. But he is also responsible for running the show and a single calamity -- a riot, a rash of crimes, a big new hole in the budget requiring cuts in city services -- could instantly shift public perceptions of him, or freeze them irretrievably to his disadvantage.
"We're at a point where the whole focus and scrutiny and frame is on the Mayor," said Hank Morris, a Democratic consultant working for Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi's campaign for Comptroller. "The cleavage is up or down on Dinkins."
Even as he is seeking to mend fences with the middle-class white constituencies represented by Mr. Manton, Mr. Dinkins is counting on party loyalty to help him in a city where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by nearly 5 to 1. He hammers away again and again at Mr. Giuliani as a Republican, a member of the party whose national convention became a showcase for the right wing last summer and whose national economic policies the Mayor blames for 12 years of urban neglect.
 
Avoiding Ideology
 By contrast, Mr. Giuliani is taking far greater pains than he did in 1989 to portray himself as a nonideological candidate, willing to try new ideas like farming out some city services to the private sector, and preaching a credo of personal responsibility that actually echoes themes sounded by Bill Clinton in last year's Presidential campaign. He has also gone out of his way to express tolerance for homosexuals -- while also expressing qualms about the specifics of plans to teach respect for gay life styles in the schools and to make condoms available to students without parental consent.
Even Mr. Giuliani's effort to win the Conservative Party nomination -- which ultimately failed -- was billed by his advisers as an effort to show just how nonideological he was, if the Republican, Liberal and Conservative parties could all rally around him.
In fact, neither candidate can afford to be seen as appealing to extremes. "The key thing," said Ms. Connelly, the consultant, "is you can't do anything in the short term to get a leg up that'll hurt you in the long term."

HEADLINE: Stiff Test for Newark Schools Auditor

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 14

 BODY:
People who know Rebecca A. Doggett say she knows how to walk into a complex situation and untangle things. Her next assignment, auditor general of the public schools here, will test that appraisal in a politically sensitive job that could bring her into conflict with friends and former colleagues.
Ms. Doggett, an executive with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was appointed auditor general of the Newark school system on Thursday as part of a state monitoring effort that could lead to a takeover of the district. 
 In an interview she talked about why she thinks she was chosen by Education Commissioner Mary Fitzgerald for a job in a city where she once played a role in major community programs in some of the poorest neighborhoods.
"I guess the reason I got the call," she said, "is that the Commissioner was looking for someone who had extensive managerial experience in the public sector but also someone who was identified with the Newark community. I think she feels that's important, so people understand that she wants to do what's best for the people of Newark."
 
'Privileged Poor Kid'
 Ms. Doggett, 52 years old, grew up in nearby Orange, the only child of a registered nurse and her husband, who owned a garage and tire business. She attended Orange High School, graduated from Upsala College in 1962 with a bachelor's degree in French and received a master's degree in human relations from New York University in 1968.
"My family has always been socially conscious," she said, "and I think being a child of the 60's and being influenced by Dr. King and the civil rights movement, I've always felt that growing up as a privileged poor kid, one of the few that had the advantages of going to high school and college, that we had an extra obligation to help."
When she takes over the job officially on June 1, she will be returning to a city she knows well, a system from which her daughter and a step-son graduated and a school district where she has many friends and colleagues from her days with Head Start and programs supporting early childhood education.
Peter Shapiro, the former Essex County Executive who is now a Citibank official, said he first met Ms. Doggett when he was a State Assemblyman in the 1970's and she was running the Head Start program, one of the country's largest.
 
Viewed as Service Provider
 "She headed up one of the most credible agencies in Newark," Mr. Shapiro said. "Unlike other ones, which were based mostly in the more affluent parts of Newark, this was based right in the heart of the Central Ward. It wasn't able to boost its performance by taking on a demographically easier population. She showed dedication guts and smarts."
When he became County Executive in 1979, he named Ms. Doggett to head the newly created Citizen Services department, which reorganized the former welfare agency and added programs for children and the elderly. It was among the three largest agencies in the county, serving tens of thousands of residents.
"She has a great combination of competence, coupled with a desire for change," Mr. Shapiro said. "The best change agents are those who both have a justifiable anger at injustice that makes them want to make the world better and an understanding of how things work. Becky has both."
Kenneth A. Gibson, the former Mayor of Newark, first met Ms. Doggett through civil rights work in the 1960's.
"She's a good choice for anything," Mr. Gibson said. "As a person, I think she approaches almost anything with the notion of getting the job done, not as a hard-nosed person but one who provides service to the community."
 
Veto Power on Spending
 Dr. Elena Scambio, an assistant education commissioner who oversees urban districts, said Ms. Doggett's philosophy was "absolutely in sync with the Commissioner and me, in terms of looking at schools and communities as large systems."
"We see schools, particularly in urban settings, as part of a broader system," Dr. Scambio said. "We look at health services, employment and unemployment. We think you've got to pull the family, whatever the family looks like, into the process. We don't think you can go into the system and institute programs and think the kids are going to learn better. Becky comes from that school of thought. Unhooking the fragmenting that's existed."
Ms. Doggett's appointment as auditor general, with veto power of school board spending in excess of $20,000, came as the state issued a report that portrays Newark's schools as bloated by waste, chronically mismanaged and educationally bankrupt, all on a $535 million annual budget that is 85 percent state and Federal aid.
In the coming months, the Education Department will send in a team of investigators to determine why Newark suffers from the many problems identified in a state report released on Thursday. They will do the investigating, while Ms. Doggett, a deputy and three assistants will oversee the day-to-day fiscal operations.
 
On Loan From Port Authority
 But the routine spending of dollars means hiring staff, repairing buildings, buying textbooks and setting up clear procedures to do so. And as the district acts, Ms. Doggett and her staff will be watching, advising and taking steps to be sure the system spends the money wisely.
She is on loan to the district from the Port Authority, which approves such temporary assignments to public agencies. The state will pick up her $90,000 port salary for as long as she remains in the Newark post. The Education Department's investigation could last as long as a year.
At the port, Ms. Doggett has served since 1988 as director of the newly formed Office of Business and Job Opportunity. Directing a staff of 30, she helps the port's tenants, at the World Trade Center and elsewhere, find qualified support staff and designs job-training programs for them. She also heads the agency's program to recruit qualified businesses run by women or minorities for work at the port or for contractors doing business with the agency.
With a conciliatory tone that friends say is no sign of weakness, she said she hoped a takeover by the state would not be necessary.
"My hope is that Newark will cure itself," she said. "Nothing would please me more."

HEADLINE: Calling the Rich the Rich

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thank you for publishing the wail penned by Leonard Riggio, chief executive of Barnes & Noble ("Dear Democrats: Don't Trash Business," Viewpoints, April 25). It is good to know how sensitive to words Mr. Riggio is, but I think he may have missed some of the jillion books sold in and about the 1980's explaining in detail about "greed" and about being "rich" and how good these words were, not to mention the attitudes and behavior they denoted. Much nicer than the cozy "wealthy" or "well to do." 
 Mr. Riggio tells us that class war is signaled by calling rich people rich. I distinctly remember reading somewhere in the mid-1980's -- probably in The New York Times -- that rich people preferred the word "rich" to the word "wealthy." "Rich" is so clean and to the point, so hold-your-head-high proud. And for a nice rhetorical turn, we learn that those who get rich are doing it selflessly, as a form of national service. Mr. Riggio ought to read some of those books he sells, in which Republicans, conservatives even, explain how the "rich" got rich(er) at the expense of the middle class and the "poor."
"Poor" -- now that must be such a class-war fighting word that it could not be mentioned during the recent Presidential campaign, or at any moment since.
 
MARTHA ROSLER
Brooklyn, April 26

HEADLINE: Whose Government?

 BODY:
Bill Clinton got an unexpected dividend when he hit the road last week to rescue his economic plan. Whenever he segued from budget and tax proposals to the evils of influence-peddling and the need for political reform, the crowd loved it. Therein lies a reality check for lawmakers, especially those who remain in deep denial.
This week, the Senate begins battle over campaign financing reform. Some legislators profess indifference. "My constituents don't care about this stuff," one House member said the other day. 
 But they do care. Average Americans may not follow every nuance of the debate over lobbying restrictions or the technical rules for financing election campaigns. But they understand the cozy ties that exist between lawmakers and gift-bearing advocates for narrow special interests. They sense that Washington no longer belongs to them. And they urge Bill Clinton to do battle when he says, as he did in Cleveland, "The lobbyists are lining the corridors of Washington as never before."
Ordinary citizens want their government back. Sounds corny. But reclaiming democracy is what the fight's all about. Mr. Clinton's newly minted campaign finance package isn't perfect. It won't end all shady dealings between lawmakers and favor seekers.
Still, the measure contains strong disinfectant. Common Cause, the public interest group, says the Clinton bill would squeeze $130 million in special-interest contributions out of Presidential and Congressional politics. That's a big wad of checks in search of tax breaks and ambassadorships that simply won't be there anymore.
Like the version President Bush vetoed last year, the bill would establish a cleaner and more competitive system of spending limits and public financing for House and Senate campaigns. Candidates who agree to limit their spending would be entitled to vouchers they could use to communicate with voters through the media or mail.
Mr. Clinton would also shut down the soft-money loophole that has allowed millions of favor-seeking dollars to pollute publicly financed Presidential campaigns, including his own. In an intriguing twist, the bill would require lobbyists to observe a 12-month cooling-off period before showering a campaign contribution on a lawmaker from whom they've just sought help on an issue.
The Senate bill is notably stronger than the companion House measure. The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, and the bill's chief Senate sponsor, David Boren of Oklahoma, deserve much credit for making it so.
For example, the Senate bill repeals members' free mass-mailing privileges in an election year. And Senate candidates could raise no more than 20 percent of their war chests from special-interest political action committees, and in amounts no more than $2,500. That's still too high. But it makes the more lenient PAC limits favored by timid House Democrats look even greedier.
How would this new, publicly financed system be paid for? By shrewdly eliminating the tax deduction for lobbyists. That's an appealing change in any case, and one that torpedoes Senator Bob Dole's argument that public financing amounts to "welfare for politicians."
There will be chances later on to strengthen the House proposal. But this week all eyes are on the Senate -- including, one hopes, the President's. Mr. Clinton was timidly neutral when Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota fought successfully earlier this month to include a provision forcing lobbyists to disclose their gifts to lawmakers in a lobbyist registration bill.
The President now embraces that provision. But the campaign finance bill represents a sterner test. If Mr. Clinton wages a crusade for cleaner government, standing firm against defenders of the discredited status quo, both democracy and his Presidency will be winners.
