HEADLINE: FEWER JOBS FILLED AS FACTORIES RELY ON OVERTIME PAY

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
In another sign of how hard it is to create jobs, American manufacturers are paying record amounts of overtime and factory workers are putting in more extra hours than ever before. By relying on so much overtime, companies have avoided hiring and jobs in manufacturing have continued to disappear.
For decades, overtime encouraged hiring. Companies found it cheaper to hire a new worker rather than assign more hours to existing employees, who have to be paid a 50 percent premium for the extra work. 
 But particularly in the last two years, the cost of a new employee -- recruiting, training and ever-more-costly health insurance -- has made overtime the less expensive choice.
 
Heavy Demand for Product
 "You almost always hire people now only as a last choice," said Robert Cizik, chairman of Cooper Industries and also of the National Association of Manufacturers.
When Cooper had a surge in orders for the computer cables it makes, more than 2,000 workers were asked to work an additional two hours a day, on overtime pay. Only as a last resort has Cooper recently begun to hire. "People got tired of working 10-hour days," Mr. Cizik said.
Part of the corporate reluctance to hire is clearly the rising cost of benefits, which now amounts to 28 percent of a worker's wage, up from 20 percent in 1970, the Labor Department says. But that is still well below the overtime premium. An even greater obstacle to hiring is the weak economy and the uncertainty about when it might improve.
 
Employers Are 'Very Cautious'
 "Benefit costs, including health costs, are a major factor, but there is more concern about all the costs of recruiting people, training them, carrying them until they become fully productive, and then the cost of firing them if production slacks off," said James Waters, a vice president of Towers Perrin, a company hired by corporations as a consultant on personnel. "The weak economy has made employers very cautious."
The workers themselves often welcome the overtime pay, at least for a while, as a supplement to salaries that have barely kept pace with inflation in recent years. But if the overtime continues week after week, both workers and employers say, morale and efficiency can suffer.
Nearly $900 million a week is now going for overtime pay, according to Labor Department data. That would provide for about 1.3 million new employees -- each with an average manufacturing wage of more than $11 an hour plus benefits -- if the money could somehow be channeled into wages.
Suddenly, the unemployment rate might fall by as much as a full percentage point, to 6 percent from 7 percent. And the 1.3 million jobs would nearly restore all the manufacturing employment lost in the United States since the early 1980's. Even now, the smaller manufacturing work force -- about 18.4 million people -- puts in as many hours a week as the larger number of manufacturing employees worked in the early 1980's, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics says.
But instead of hiring, overtime has reached record levels. The average overtime for a factory worker rose to 4.3 hours a week in April, the highest level since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began keeping overtime records in 1948. With so many extra hours, the average work week in manufacturing rose to 41.5 hours in April, the longest since June 1966.
"Overtime for the average production worker in manufacturing has gone up one whole hour each week since the end of the recession in 1991," said Thomas Plewes, an associate commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "That is really an astounding increase."
 
The Costs of Hiring
 The overtime phenomenon is most evident in manufacturing. Factory workers, who represent 17 percent of the nation's employees, are generally skilled and well paid, and they usually work full time because factory shifts require full-timers. Each new worker, as a result, means a considerable investment not only in benefits but also in recruiting and training.
The service sector, on the other hand, particularly the huge retail and food industries, can get by with less-skilled people on more flexible schedules. Rather than overtime, employers have resorted to hiring part-time and contract workers, mostly without paying them benefits, Labor Department data show. The result has been shorter workweeks and rising employment in the service sector.
But that modest creation of jobs has fallen far short of the 200,000 a month that most economists say needs to be created, at a minimum, if the economy is to shake off the recession that officially ended in March 1991. Job creation has not even been sufficient to keep up with demand from people entering the work force.
Citing such data, labor unions and some economists are increasingly urging the Clinton Administration and Congress -- so far without success -- to enact laws that would give companies incentives to hire, rather than resort to overtime. Corporations that hire, for example, might get a tax credit for each new worker, says Ronald Ehrenberg, a Cornell University labor economist. Or minimum overtime pay might be set at double or triple straight-time pay, in an attempt to make overtime too costly an alternative to hiring.
The Federal Government, struggling to reduce huge unemployment in the Depression years, took this tack in 1938, requiring for the first time that employers pay millions of workers time and one-half for each hour worked after a 40-hour week. That same Federal legal requirement still applies today, and in many contracts, unions have negotiated overtime pay for work after 35 to 37 hours of work.
"Other nations have decreased hours of work for a variety of reasons -- external pressure, to spread employment, and the sheer value of leisure," John Zalusky, a senior economist at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said in a recent paper arguing for fewer hours and more employment. "In the 1930's, the U.S. had a policy of using shorter hours as a means of job creation, but in the last decade, public policy and private actions have addressed hours of work only as an employer cost."
The United States and Japan, in fact, have the longest workweeks of the major industrial nations. Richard Freeman, a labor economist at Harvard University, said he would recommend moving American employers to the shorter hours favored in Europe, in part by making jobless pay, under the unemployment insurance program, available to workers who agree to work, say, 30 hours a week instead of 40 hours. The pay would help to compensate the worker for the 10 hours lost. Mr. Freeman would also have the Government mandate more vacation time, perhaps a minimum of four weeks, the norm in Europe. That would also leave room for more jobs.
Labor Department officials decline to comment on most of the proposals, but Lawrence Katz, the department's chief economist, said that using unemployment insurance to subsidize workers opting for shorter hours was on the table. "In thinking about ways to encourage hiring, that is certainly an option that we are thinking about seriously," Mr. Katz said. "There does seem to be evidence that this is useful."
 
Health Care Is a Factor
 A greater impact on hiring practices would come from changes in health-care insurance, which for most factory workers is largely paid by their employers. Under the present system, the cost is a fixed amount for each employee, rather than a premium, as in the Social Security payroll tax, that rises and falls with wages earned, including overtime pay.
"A payroll tax for health care would undoubtedly make employers less reluctant to hire," said William S. Custer, research director at the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington. So would a Government-financed health insurance plan, the union preference.
But corporate executives shun such solutions. The workers themselves, they note -- accurately -- often welcome the overtime pay, at a time when raises barely keep regular hourly wages from losing ground to inflation. More important, the executives are counting on stronger economic growth to increase demand for their products and make hiring kick in.
Surveys of members conducted by the National Association of Manufacturers suggest that once economic growth rises above an annual rate of 3 percent a year and stays that high for a year or two, then factory hiring will resume, said Jerry Jasinowski, the group's president.
Economic growth, as measured by the gross domestic product, fell to an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the first quarter after having surged to 4.7 percent in last year's fourth quarter.
 
Two Companies' Solutions
 Lacking enough demand, some manufacturers are finding ways to avoid both hiring and overtime. The Quaker Oats Company of Chicago, which now employs 11,000 Americans, down slightly in recent years, has shifted many of them to 10-hour daily shifts, four days a week -- giving up overtime. The fifth day is reserved for maintenance that had been spread through the week, said Ronald Bottrell, a Quaker Oats executive. The maintenance workers, too, also now work without much overtime.
The Gillette Company of Boston has borrowed a solution from the service sector. Many of the company's 7,000 American workers had been assigned to overtime to cover weekend shifts. "But that became stressful," said Gerd Domajnko, director of corporate personnel. "You cannot do that indefinitely."
So Gillette hired part-time workers for weekends at the one or two plants that have weekend shifts. None work more than 20 hours a week, Mr. Domajnko said, and none, for that reason, qualify for Gillette's company-paid benefits.

HEADLINE: Focus: Philadelphia;
Zoning Downtown to Channel Parking

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
CITY planners have turned the spotlight on the downtown parking situation with new regulations aimed at encouraging lots and garages in some areas and discouraging them elsewhere.
 They have made it harder for developers to utilize a favorite method of drawing income from land being held for future development. This, in turn, may discourage the demolition of uneconomic old buildings specifically to create parking. 
But they have also made it easier to establish parking facilities along the northern fringe of the business district, close to Interstate 95 and the Vine Street Expressway, in the hope that drivers will park there before plunging onward to narrow and congested streets in the heart of the business district.
 Philadelphia had been relatively lenient on parking regulations. Developers have encountered no difficulty in utilizing land they have been unable to reuse for parking to get temporary income.
 For example, Acme Markets spent six years looking for a buyer for its headquarters building, but chose to demolish the 11-story structure at 15th and Race Streets last year, leasing the site to the Philadelphia Parking Authority for a 125-space lot.
 Simultaneously, the city's inventory of covered parking facilities has grown substantially with the building surge of the 80's. The city went from 43,800 covered spaces in 1980 to 60,500 spaces in 1990, a 40 percent increase. Since then, even with the decline of private office construction, at least 2,000 more spaces have been added. The increase gave added impetus to the planners' desire to cut down on open-land parking.
 Under the new set of land planning regulations, lots and garages are "acceptable as an interim use" in the areas north of Market Street, the city's north-south dividing line, as far as Vine Street four blocks away. Interim use of a site must be approved by the planning commission before existing buildings can be demolished. No street-level lot may remain for more than five years and basement-level parking in new projects is not counted as developed floor space.
 BUT no street-level lots are allowed at all south of Chestnut Street -- one block south of Market Street -- for three blocks to Spruce Street, the boundary of the city's busiest and most historic and congested business and residential area. Nor is any new garage, except with special approval, which is considered unlikely in the district.
 Part of the goal is to deter developers from razing the two- and three- story brick buildings common in the area, said Richard Lombardo, chief of project planning in the Planning Department.
 In the Vine-Callowhill Streets area, north of downtown but close to Interstate 95, parking lots and garages are encouraged by excluding parking space from the bulk restrictions of the zoning envelope.
 "The goal of the regulations," Mr. Lombardo said, "was to protect the smaller-scale commercial development south of Chestnut Street that was built in the 1920's and 30's, before every building needed parking."
 "Most of the city's business core is in an area where parking lots are permitted," he said.
 The Philadelphia actions call attention to the problem of drawing revenue from land intended for redevelopment during sometimes extremely long periods of market weakness.
 As air-pollution regulations and traffic problems have curbed parking lots, developers have often tried to lease land for flea markets or low-cost tennis bubbles as interim uses. Even local gardens have sprouted on land held for development.
 "A lot of downtowns have a tremendous amount of space devoted to suface parking, and it may be a transitionary phase," said Bob Dunphy, senior research director of the Urban Land Institute, a nonprofit land development research organization. "Parking is the Rodney Dangerfield of transportation -- it gets no respect, but it's critical to development."
 That transition may take years or decades. One of Philadelphia's prime development spots, at Broad and Locust Streets across from the Academy of Music, was vacant for more than 20 years until a hotel opened on the site in 1983. When it was vacant it was used as surface parking.
 THE parking industry tried last year to get the Philadelphia Planning Commission to accept the principle that all new buildings should have on-site parking. That was rejected because of the size of the existing supply.
 But in projects already planned but not built, still more on-site parking is to be produced. Hahnemann University Hospital will build an 800-space garage with room for its data center on the now vacant former site of the Philadelphia Athletic Club at Vine and Broad Streets near the downtown business core.
 On Market at 19th Street, the Philadelphia office of the Linpro Corporation plans to build a second office tower to complement one completed four years ago, and a new parking garage to go with it.
 So far the, 45-story, 761,000-square-foot project has no garage.
 Linpro has a hole in the ground at 20th and Market that was to have become an underground parking garage. It has asked for and been given a variance to fill it in as interim street-level parking lot.
 The decision by Philadelphia's largest private parking company, Parkway Corporation, to expand its surface lot at 15th and Spruce Streets last year shows that site development, and new interim parking space, has proceeded even when office development has slackened.
 JOSEPH S. ZURITSKY, Parkway's president, said it spent more than $925,000 to acquire and demolish two buildings adjacent to the lot, in an area of office and theater uses and heavy residential traffic. By expanding its holdings from Spruce to Latimer Street, Parkway has made the site more attractive for future commercial construction, Mr. Zuritsky said.
 The company also sees itself as a developer. In 1986, it announced plans for 300,000 square feet of residential apartments atop a garage and retail building on Walnut Street between Eighth and Ninth Streets.
 The garage and shops were completed but no schedule has been disclosed for the towers.
 Mr. Zuritsky would give no occupancy data about the 500 spaces that Parkway owned or operated downtown. He said the industry overall had suffered during the recession because of job and shopping cutbacks, home-based telecommuters and people shifting to mass transit.
 But Andrew Lenton of the planning commission said that a survey in 1990 showed that parking occupancy rates averaged 79 percent and that the rate probably had dropped since then.
 According to Mr. Lenton's survey, downtown parking occupancy rates rose from 68 percent in 1980 to 79 percent in 1990. More striking was the increase in the all-day price -- from an average of $4.69 in 1980 to $8.70 in 1990.
 Mr. Lombardo said the changes were a result of a comprehensive plan to revise restrictions created eight or nine years ago by a previous City Council that were inconsistent and required variances for most commercial projects outside the business district.
 One element of the current plan, he said, requires landscaped screening on parking-loot frontage along major streets.

HEADLINE: Where the Streets Are Paved With Depositors

BYLINE: By Ken Bode; Ken Bode is director of the Center for Contemporary Media at DePauw University and a CNN correspondent who covered the savings and loan scandals.

 BODY:

S&L HELL
The People and the Politics
Behind the $1 Trillion
Savings and Loan Scandal.
By Kathleen Day.
416 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company.
$24.95. 
JIM HIGHTOWER, the Texas-populist radio commentator, often reminds his listeners of that period in the late 1980's when personal checks were clearing but all over the country banks were bouncing.
Kathleen Day covered that story for The Washington Post, then took a leave from The Post to empty her notebooks of those behind-the-scene events and descriptions that never make it into the columns of a daily newspaper, but do so much to enrich understanding of so complex an issue as the savings and loan debacle.
In "S&L Hell," Ms. Day recounts the institutions' origins, their regulatory history and the earliest days of the most recent crisis with anecdotes and vignettes that make a dry subject come to life. There was, for example, the day in 1985 that Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio, facing the possibility of a run on his state's savings institutions, threatened to camp out on the doorstep of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington until its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, talked to him.
Ronald Reagan may have been the President who turned deregulation into a governing public philosophy, but it was Jimmy Carter who signed the bill deregulating savings and loan associations, facilitating the freebooting that led to their collapse. At the signing ceremony, President Carter assured America that the law would "strengthen our financial institutions."
Ms. Day tracks the passage of that 1980 law raising the federally insured level of deposits in commercial banks and savings institutions to $100,000, which in the thrift industry became a license for risk-free gambling with depositors' money -- or, as she puts it, "financial cocaine."
This book is at its best when Ms. Day takes the reader to a secret House-Senate meeting on that bill, for example, where the lawmakers are so fearful of being overheard that they pass one another notes.
Kathleen Day arrives at her own estimate of how much the savings and loan scandal will cost taxpayers, an estimate significantly higher than that put out by successive Administrations: more than $1 trillion over several decades, enough to add $13 billion a year in interest to the national debt forever. Threading through the labyrinth of this disaster, she provides fascinating profiles of many of the key players. Among them:
* Gaunt, balding and sanctimonious, Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, nicknamed "the screaming skull" by banking lobbyists.
* Donald T. Regan, Treasury Secretary and later the autocratic White House chief of staff, who because of his Wall Street background considered savings and loans dinosaurs hardly worth saving and once, with an offhand comment to an industry newspaper, caused a one-day $400-million run on ailing institutions.
* Representative Fernand (Freddie) J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, who included the carnal enjoyment of women among the appetites he expected to be satisfied with money from savings and loan lobbyists. As chairman of the House Banking Committee until his 1988 defeat for re-election, he was so important to banking interests that a United States League of Savings Institutions lobbyist who worked the committee was said to withdraw thousands of dollars from petty cash regularly to support what he euphemistically called the Congressman's "deep-sea fishing."
* George Bush, the apparently out-of-the-loop Vice President, who dropped by a meeting of the Cabinet Council on Economic Affairs one day to ask, "How come my friends in the S.& L. industry tell me things are so dire?"
Kathleen Day makes clear why a financial crisis so severe and so costly escaped wide notice in the press for so long. In the early 1980's, regulators were estimating privately that only 40 or 50 of the country's 4,000 savings and loan associations were actually solvent. But Government officials maintained that disclosure would be reckless because the financial markets were so sensitive. From the earliest days of the crisis, regulators had one abiding fear -- that the press, especially television, would discover the severity of the problem, causing a run on savings institutions. Then, a problem that had been buried on the business pages would be piped into millions of American living rooms at dinner time.
If there are any good guys, among them might be the General Accounting Office, which constantly vexed the Bush Administration's efforts to play down the scope and cost of the scandal. In 1989, President Bush promised "to put the S.& L. crooks in jail." Almost three years later, just before Election Day, the agency reported that two-thirds of the major cases (involving amounts over $100,000) had been dropped and that while the courts had ordered nearly $850 million in fines and restitution, less than 5 percent of that amount had been collected.
Before we get the scandals officially off the books, there will be time for Kathleen Day to write a sequel to "S&L Hell."

HEADLINE: How Garden Hobby Grew to Full-Time Job

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
SPRING may have been a little late this year, but at 80 Primrose Avenue here, a new evergreen rock garden is nearing completion.
The garden is one of many on almost an acre of plantings that serve as the showroom for the Primrose Landscape Design Company owned by the Gussoffs, Michael, age 42, and Beverly, somewhat older, a mother-and-son team who eight years ago turned their hobby into a blooming business. 
 "My interest in gardening dates back to when we moved into this house," Mr. Gussoff said. "I was 7 and helped my mother plant her first garden."
Mr. Gussoff added that although he grew up to be the largest (in height and girth) landscaper in Westchester, standing 6 feet 5 inches tall and weighing more than 200 pounds, he never thought of gardening as anything other than a hobby until recently.
"I do remember taking a career-aptitude test at college and I scored highest as a farmer," he said. "It may have been prophetic, but it gave me a laugh at the time because I was heading straight for the corporate world. I graduated from Marquette University in Milwaukee with a business degree and eventually became the national sales and marketing manager for Fisons Instruments in Saddle Brook, N.J., which is the fourth-largest scientific equipment company in the world."
 
An Expensive Hobby
 During the same period, his mother was a senior manager at the former Alexander's in White Plains. "However, I spent all my spare time in the garden or taking various courses in horticulture and design," Mrs. Gussoff said. "I became a gardener out of necessity 35 years ago when we bought our house. It had no landscaping to speak of and looked so barren and forlorn that I had to do something to it. In order to learn about plants and what to plant, I began taking courses in adult education and at the New York Botanical Garden, and I got hooked."
Mrs. Gussoff added, "I became an avid gardener and enlisted Michael, who was willing to learn, to help me carry out my ambitious schemes, such as the first rock garden we built and our woodland garden that borders the brook that runs through our back lawn."
Mrs. Gussoff eventually estimated that she was spending an average of $5,000 a year on the garden.
"I was forever upgrading and refurbishing and hunting for unusual specimens," she said. "When I realized that what I wanted wasn't available to me at any retail outlet, I managed to get myself into a trade show in Valley Forge, Pa., where I was in heaven. I saw choice grafted hemlocks and weeping Norway spruces and red pines for sale. I was ecstatic."
 
A Career Change
 The unusual gardens surrounding the Gussoff house soon won the notice of family and friends.
"We were asked to design a number of gardens and at first we were glad to oblige," Mr. Gussoff said. "It was what we wanted to do anyhow, and I remember spending hours at nurseries looking for the ideal plant for a particular spot in a friend's garden in New Jersey. But when we found ourselves spending all our free time and a considerable amount of money on gardens for friends, we realized our hobby was getting out of hand."
About the same time, Beverly recalled that she had to make an important decision. "My job had changed," she said. "And when Alexander's decided to close the White Plains store, I was asked to transfer to a store in the city, something I wasn't really keen on. And that was the catalyst that made us turn our hobby into a business."
For his part, Mr. Gussoff said: "I was fed up with having to travel 80 percent of the time in my job. The corporate environment had also changed and lost its strong attraction for me. I was interested in doing something more entrepreneurial."
At that point, Primrose Landscape Design began to take shape as a business.
"We pooled our money, $50,000, which we invested in equipment and marketing," Mr. Gussoff said. "We made our plans in the fall of 1986, and in the spring of 1987, we had had our first client, a couple in Ardsley who were landscaping their house because they could not sell it. When we finished that job -- and incidentally, the couple liked the refurbished landscaping so much they decided to stay in the house -- we got three more clients through that. One was a next-door neighbor and the other two close by."
Yet, the first year was difficult, Mrs. Gussoff recalled. "It's a very competitive business, and we were new," she said. "It wasn't until the second year that we were able to go into the black. And a lot of that was due to Michael's developing a successful direct-marketing campaign, which brought us a 5 percent return. Out of that, about 10 percent of those responding actually became customers."
Mr. Gussoff has the responsibility for the day-to-day operation of the business and the marketing, and his mother does most of the landscape design. "We specialize in four-season gardens that keep their looks all year, and we like to use dwarf varieties because they retain their shape and size, and the maintenance is low," Mrs. Gussoff said. "We choose plants for their shapes, colors and textures, and our specialty is our unusual selection of dwarf conifers. We buy plants from dozens of suppliers. Some of the best plants come from Oregon."
 
Client Questionnaires
 New customers are first asked to fill out a questionnaire in order to give the Gussoffs an idea of the type of landscaping the customer envisions.
"Our goal, of course, is to give customers what they want, provided that what they want will work," Mr. Gussoff said. "For instance, one customer who wanted a large English-style perennial border in front of her house had to be told it was not the right spot for it, and it would not look good the second season. Another customer who was determined to incorporate a pair of huge overgrown yews they had planted when they bought their house, had to be convinced in the new landscape plan that such plants were not only unattractive but potentially dangerous, as they concealed possible intruders."
In Primrose's first four years of operation, business grew about 250 percent. Last year, with the recession in full swing, the increase was smaller -- between 130 and 140 percent.
The assignments range from a 30-foot-by- 8-foot border to an entire landscaping project, costing from $5,000 to $10,000. Ninety-nine percent of Primrose's customers also contract for a maintenance program, which is priced at 10 percent of the installation cost, and that includes monthly service visits and biweekly tours of inspection.
"I think we have done about 36 gardens to date," Mr. Gussoff said. "The majority of them have been low-maintenance evergreen rock gardens. But we do stress using appropriate landscaping for each house. For instance, we are putting in an English formal garden for a client who has a large Tudor house. And we also did the backyard and play area for Hale House in Harlem, which is completely different. We also do the maintenance of Hale House pro bono."
 
Projects Continue Until Winter
 Digging time, he added, is late this year because of the long wet winter. But the Gussoffs say they plant until frost.
"This season is finally shaping up," Mr. Gussoff said. "Now we are averaging two or three jobs a week. The average job takes about 40 hours and includes the design plan, site preparation, the plant materials and a warranty for the survival of the plants for one growing season. And all the work is done by our own crews."
"As for me," Mrs. Gussoff said, "I enjoy the business so much I still feel it's a hobby."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Gussoff and his mother, Beverly, owners of Primrose Landscape Design Company, working at a home in Ardsley. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
Barter Is Best With Cash-Poor Russia

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. LESSER; Lawrence M. Lesser is an adjunct professor of business and management at the University of Maryland.

 BODY:
WINSTON CHURCHILL once described Russia as "a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma." Much has changed since Churchill's time, but not the truth of this dictum. One of the hardest riddles posed today by Russia and the other former Soviet states is: How can America foster a good economic relationship with this promising but poor region?
On the one hand, the region is a huge potential market and a storehouse of resources. Russia alone grows more wheat and produces more oil than any other country, for example. Such facts aren't lost on American business, which had $3.6 billion in exports to the former Soviet states last year. The area's attractions have also made American businesses the largest group of foreign investors in Russia today. 
 But these new nations are strapped for cash. Since December, Russia has failed to meet interest payments on $4.2 billion of United States agricultural credit guarantees. It is now $600 million in default. Russia also has failed to pay more than $200 million owed to 57 American companies.
Big market, but no money. What is to be done? The answer to this new conundrum is barter -- the exchange of goods or services for other goods or services, rather than for currency. Barter is not mere theory. Many of our major competitors barter with the former Soviet states right now. And the reason they do so is the reason the United States, both its Government and its business, should do so: Barter can provide an important region with vital goods and services while minimizing nonpayment risks for suppliers.
The people of the former Soviet states are very familiar with barter because they bartered for years with their former Eastern European allies. Barter also was widely used between the producing and consuming areas of the former Soviet Union, and among individuals.
How would barter with the region work? American companies might modernize energy production facilities -- and get paid in oil. Or the United States Government might improve safety at the area's perilous nuclear power plants -- and take plutonium and uranium in return.
These are just two examples. The former Soviet states are in great need of immediate help on many economic fronts. They need housing for the returning members of the armed forces. They must upgrade their food distribution system, convert defense facilities to commercial purposes, and modernize telecommunications and transportation. By assuring vendors of payment, barter can speed completion of these critical tasks.
But barter carries other advantages. By accepting oil as payment, for instance, the United States reduces its reliance on the volatile Persian Gulf. By taking plutonium and uranium instead of cash, the United States helps avoid the nuclear proliferation that may occur if cash-desperate states sell these strategic materials on the world market.
With its obvious advantages, barter has garnered some support in the United States. President Clinton has approved of the general idea, and Michael Espy and Ronald Brown, the Secretaries of Agriculture and Commerce, respectively, have specifically expressed interest in barter with the former Soviet states. Under a 1992 measure sponsored by Senator James Exon, an Administration task force will complete a report on this subject by month's end.
But, despite this recent interest, the Internal Revenue Service and the Customs Service have long discouraged international barter transactions, through audits and other measures. These agencies fear that American businesses will fail to pay income taxes and import duties on bartered goods. Unfamiliar with barter and worried about resale of the payment, business has been leery of international barter as well.
WITH some rare exceptions -- such as Pepsico's 21-year exchange of soft drinks for Soviet ships and vodka, and chicken-for-oil talks between Tyson Foods and Russia, announced last week -- these factors have stymied the use of international barter by America.
But some of our competitors are not so stymied. Canada has traded wheat for Russian timber and cotton, and is now negotiating a wheat-for-diamonds deal. And Australia recently traded 1.5 million metric tons of wheat for aluminum.
America must learn what its competitors already know: In this rapidly changing world, it needs creative approaches to international finance. Fears of tax evasion are real and should be accommodated, as should legitimate business concerns. But in the end barter must be expanded. It is the solution to the new Russian riddle.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Anne L. Pierce;
A Space Career Booster, Against the Odds

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THREE decades after President John F. Kennedy set in motion a space program that finally put a man on the moon, President Clinton, who likens himself to Kennedy in many other respects, is deliberating about whether the nation needs expensive programs like the space station.
That is distressing to Anne L. Pierce, the executive director of the Connecticut Space Grant College Consortium. 
 The consortium -- which was formed in 1990 and is composed of the University of Hartford, University of Connecticut, Trinity College and the University of New Haven -- was organized to stimulate research among the faculty and the students at those campuses, and to promote student interest in science courses that could lead to space-related careers.
Ms. Pierce, who did undergraduate work at Westminster College in Pennsylvania and graduate studies in botany at Arizona State University and Vanderbilt University in Nashville, is working on a degree in higher education administration at UConn. Three years ago she became the first director of the consortium.
In a recent interview at the Legislative Office Building in Hartford, Ms. Pierce answered questions about the consortium, and its goals. Here are some excerpts from the conversation.
Q. What got you interested in space?
A. I was born the day Sputnik went up. And then I was in elementary school when John Glenn went around the globe, and our teacher made us keep a scrapbook that she anticipated would be for the school year. I kept it right through high school. That motivated me to go into science, and when this job came along I jumped at it.
Q. Did you want to be an astronaut when you were younger?
A. No, I never really wanted to be an astronaut. I was more fascinated with the hardware. My parents lived in Florida, so I had been to Kennedy Space Center. You could watch launches right out of their backyard.
Q. Can a student who is interested in space courses take different courses at other schools in the consortium?
A. At some of them. Trinity and the University of Hartford, for instance, have an arrangement where you can take courses at either one. And of course you can always take a course and transfer the credit, depending on where you are in your agreement.
But we don't have any formal space grant consortium agreement yet. Some time in the future we'd like to, but we're just now beginning to address the curriculum aspects of it.
Q. Isn't this a bad time to get people interested in a career in space?
A. Some people would say "today the space industry isn't doing very well, why would you want to encourage students?" But it won't always be that way. By the time today's freshman is ready to graduate, some kind of space station will be ready to go, and the trip to Mars will be a few years further along.
Q. Why do you think Mr. Clinton is calling for scaling back spending on space programs?
A. Well, it's hard to tell if he's really backing away. Until all the legislation has gone through the process it's hard to tell. But I think the budget deficit is his biggest concern, and I don't think people realize how much it costs to do something for the very first time, when you don't know what the results are going to be. You have to amortize those costs over time, because the benefits are realized over time. You have to look at the spinoffs.
Q. Have there been a lot of valuable spinoffs from the space program?
A. Where would we be without Velcro, or some of the optical coatings that have come out of the space program? A lot of materials like Kevlar, we would not have had. A lot of optical coatings, thermal and insulating substances. A lot of laser technology, cutting tools, we would not have had if they had not been developed for the space program.
Every year NASA puts out a book called "Spinoffs," a thick book that only lists some of the applications that have come out of the space program in the previous year. I don't know that anyone has ever calculated the combined value, because it's too soon even now to say. Even the materials from the early years of the space program are still being improved upon.
Q. How much of a blow would it be to the space program if the space station is eliminated from the budget?
A. Because that's only one part of the program, I don't see that being a blow to the entire space program, or to the consortium. But it would be a blow to Connecticut. The estimates I've seen are that the space station contracts will bring about $200 million to Connecticut, through that one program. As far as the colleges are concerned, it will mean fewer research opportunities for the faculty and students. For instance, this summer the consortium is funding students to go to San Francisco and learn how to configure experiments for the space station. It's very exciting for students. If the space station is scaled back it will take a little gloss off the program. But I think there will always be students interested in doing something for the first time.
Q. How important is space to the Connecticut economy over all?
A. Contracts contribute $120 million a year to the state. Connecticut ranks number 15 over all in terms of NASA contracts for education and research.
Q. Why don't people think of the importance of the space program in the state, versus, say, defense?
A. People don't realize Pratt and Whitney is working on the national aerospace plane through the NASA budget. They don't realize that at Hughes Danbury Optical, they're doing work on the Hubble telescope as well as coatings and optical devices for other astronomical projects. Maybe it's our fault for not communicating strongly enough how important the space program is to the state.
Q. If space is so important in Connecticut, why don't we have a Goddard or Langley type research operation?
A. A lot of the NASA research centers were established historically. Langley was the first one. I don't know why Connecticut wasn't chosen in those early years, except that it's not in an area of the country where you would have had a launch, because of the weather, and because it's so densely populated.
Q. Where does the money for the consortium come from?
A. It comes from NASA, out of the education division. It was an allotment made by Congress, so it wasn't carved out of another NASA program. It was modeled after the old land grant and sea grant programs.
It was Lloyd Bentsen's dream, really, that space would become as much a motivator and public resource as the agricultural extension program or the fisheries program. Eventually it may be that way. It is that way in some of the bigger states.
Q. What are the big states for space programs?
A. Texas is the largest. They have 200 colleges and universities in their consortium. Probably California is the second largest, because that's the whole University of California system. Colorado is No. 3 -- a lot of space business goes on in Colorado, with the Air Force Academy there. Connecticut would probably never rival any of those states unless we get a research center here. You don't really need a launch site anymore, so if NASA were expanding it is possible. The University of Hartford has made an offer: if you're looking to expand, here we are.
Q. How active is Connecticut industry in the consortium?
A. Very active. There are 16 board members for the consortium, and half of them are industry folks. We have a wealth of experience here. Most of these businesses were here at the start of the space program. They also support us financially as well as with summer jobs for students.
Q. When Mr. Clinton talks about cutting the space station, do you think that reflects a national mood that we're spending too much on space?
A. I think the mood is that we don't want to see Government funds wasted. When people read that we've paid too much for a certain piece of hardware or that in someone's opinion the money would be better spent somewhere else, I think that is what bothers the general public.
I don't think anyone would argue that going to space is too expensive. I think that people would say we have to be very careful about how the money is spent.
Q. Aside from dollars, though, are people still getting excited about things like the trip to Mars?
A. I think the trip to Mars is too far off for people to get excited about it. That's still very Buck Rogers in a lot of people's minds. I think it's easier to get excited about the space station because they can envision the shuttle coming alongside and disgorging passengers. They can envision, because of Skylab, what it will be like to have a laboratory in the sky.
I think the enthusiasm of the public goes in spurts, though. The day of a launch people gather around the television and excitement is high. The next day, people are a little more blase about it. I think that's because we have so many launches now. It's become so matter of fact.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne L. Pierce, the executive director of the Connecticut Space Grant College Consortium, in her office. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 22; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 884 words

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Bountiful Platters and Moderate Prices

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY

 BODY:
IL TULIPANO of Huntington has bid farewell to its traditional ways and become Trattoria Tulipano, a family style Italian restaurant.
It is not just another Long Island restaurant that has jumped on the family dining bandwagon. Rather, it is the paradigm of the genre with a renowned chef and experienced owners. The savvy restaurateurs also operate two of the Island's top Italian restaurants, Navona in Great Neck and Stresa in Manhasset. 
 The new chef, Mario Maggi, earned his culinary stripes at Bice in Manhattan and later at Bice of Tokyo. Mr. Maggi joins three old friends, Giorgio Meriggi, Pasquale Cervera and Tony D'Arcangelo, as part owner of the Huntington restaurant.
Trattoria Tulipano combines the bountiful platters and moderate prices of family dining with the ambiance of a traditional northern Italian restaurant. There are no poster-size menus on the walls.The decor features floor-to-ceiling mirrors crisscrossed with wood lattices, pale-green walls dotted with subdued paintings, dusty-rose tablecloths and dramatic flower arrangements.
Service is another break with family dining style. Instead of plunking down platters, waiters serve portions, replace silver and plates after every course and keep the water glasses filled. Such superior service may have resulted from being recognized at this restaurant. Yet, service at other tables also seemed well above the norm.
The food is also a switch from the expected. Diners can order menu listings intended to serve two or more, or they can opt for nightly specials geared to singles.
Specials one evening included a baby chicken, red snapper, a veal chop and salmon en croute. The salmon, topped with spinach and wrapped in phyllo pastry, was one of the few disappointments. It was overcooked. The thick succulent veal chop smothered in mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes, however, was a superb pick.
A holdover from former days is the outstanding fried zucchini. This crispy wispy treat is listed with the vegetables, but the economical platter ($5) is big enough to be an appetizer for four.
Other recommended openers are the delicate rolls of eggplant wrapped around oozing goat cheese and sauced with fresh tomatoes and onions and the platters of creamy polenta with a tangy Gorgonzola or hardy Bolognese sauce. Additionally, a special grilled portobello mushroom zingy with garlic and placed atop tricolor salad earned a best-ever rating.
Speaking of salad, there are two rarely seen standouts on the menu. The insalata alla paesana is a toss of romaine, endive, radicchio, grilled eggplant, roasted peppers and fava beans. The other rarity is a Tuscan bread salad that includes thin slices of toast, chunks of cucumber and tomato, slices of red onion and assorted greens.
Although appetizers, salads and entrees all boasted obvious superstars, pastas were pleasing but none were show-stoppers.
The red-meat headliner is a dish called Robesbierre alla moda del Tulipano, which is designated a house specialty on the menu. The platter features butter-tender slices of sirloin steak sprinkled with rosemary and black peppercorns, all encircling a centerpiece of diced fresh tomatoes. The other house specialty, lamb shanks stewed in wine, was undercooked and chewy.
A gentrified chicken scarpariello, served off the bone with lots of garlic and rosemary, was fine, as was scaloppina alla paesana, tender veal scallops under a spirited topping of mushrooms, onions and fresh tomatoes.
Desserts are the same renowned homemade treats that were always served at Il Tulipano. Best are the lush tiramisu, the satiny creme brulee, the homemade ice creams and the flourless chocolate cake under its drift of freshly whipped cream.
It has always been possible to purchase a bottle of wine from Tulipano's largely Italian list of 56 selections for as little as $12. The restaurant's transformation has not changed that. Diners will not regret choosing one or more of the Ruffinos. A lively Libaio white n/v ($19) and a youthful 1991 Aziano single vintage Chianti Classico ($18) tasted as though they were made to be drunk with family style fare.
 Trattoria Tulipano
Very Good

HEADLINE: Helping Families Avoid Plight of Homelessness

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: GREENBURGH

 BODY:
THE early-morning sunlight streams into the dining room of the modest home where Naomi Washington has lived for more than 30 years. A vase with pink tulips is carefully arranged on the dining table, offering a suggestion of spring. In the living room, where large recliners flank a sectional sofa, mirrors reflect matching bookcases that contain encyclopedias.
In this white, six-bedroom house in the Fairview section of Greenburgh, children's riding toys share driveway space with the family car, evidence of Mrs. Washington's three great-grandchildren, who share her home with their grandmother, Joyce Pegram, the eldest of Mrs. Washington's five daughters. 
 Despite the efforts that the family has made to keep its home neat and tidy, it is hard not to notice the wobbly counters in the kitchen, the broken tiles in the bathrooms or the obviously new windows that just as obviously are missing proper wood frames -- reminders of the shabby renovation work that almost cost Mrs. Washington and Mrs. Pegram their home.
What prevented Mrs. Washington and Mrs. Pegram from becoming part of the county's homeless statistics was the intervention of a nonprofit program called the Bridge Fund, a program of Grace Church Community Center in White Plains.
The fund was started in January 1991 by Nan and Oscar Pollock and the Rev. Peter Larom, former rector of Grace Episcopal Church and now director of the Seaman's Church Institute of New York and New Jersey, to help people avoid homelessness by making available small, short-term loans limited to $2,000. According to the county's Department of Social Services, close to 60 percent of those families who become homeless have been evicted from their homes.
 
A Referral Is Necessary
 "If a pot of money were available when someone has a crisis, chances are they wouldn't end up in a hotel," said Stanley Schear, director of the Bridge Fund. "And once people are in a system, it's hard to get out. Because of the economic decline, lots of people lost income in the last few years and couldn't handle a crisis. Eighty percent of the people who come to us are working people who live from paycheck to paycheck. When they are in trouble, they need a little help and maybe some hand holding from us. Their biggest fear is 'I don't want to be homeless.' "
To receive help, people must be referred to the Bridge Fund by a major social services agency or a charity like the United Way, Catholic Charities, the Salvation Army or the Red Cross, or a church or synagogue or Westchester Legal Services or the county's mediation service, called Cluster, which monitors the court system. Applications from walk-ins are not accepted.
"In preventing homelessness, speed is of the essence," said Oscar Pollock, a Katonah resident and partner in the Wall Street firm of Ingalls & Snyder. "The Bridge Fund was created in response to the needs of advocates of the homeless. They all felt that many homeless situations could be prevented. The Bridge Fund works best with a family or individual whose problems are largely financial. We are financial advisers to people in trouble who are at risk of losing their homes. We help individuals get a job, do budgeting, get their expenses in line with their incomes and work out a financial plan.
"It works best with the working poor of the county -- most of our clients fall into that broad category. When somebody becomes a client of the Bridge Fund, it becomes a challenge to us. We make every effort to see our client succeed. We want to prevent them from spiraling downward. That's the key. We want to avoid having good people, who are trying, fall into the public-shelter system; it's not easy to work your way out."
 
A Typical Example
 Dorothy T., a 45-year-old White Plains resident whose last name was withheld to protect her privacy, is typical of the Bridge Fund's clients. When an accident left her unable to continue working as a bookkeeper, she was discharged and found it difficult to pay rent on her apartment. As a single mother of a disabled son, she applied to the Department of Social Services for assistance but was told that her rent was too high.
"They said they couldn't help me," Mrs. T. said. "They told me if I was evicted, I would be put up in a hotel. It's terrible not knowing if someone will throw you out of your apartment. It's hard when you work all your life and pay your taxes and try to get help and can't get it. The Bridge Fund gave me some money to help pay my rent and helped me with social services to get nursing assistance and other help. This was the bridge over rough water. Mr. Schear was our guardian angel. If it wasn't for Mr. Schear, we would have been a homeless statistic."
The Bridge Fund, which is privately financed by contributions from individuals and foundations, made loans and a few outright grants totaling $97,154 in 126 cases last year. Eighty-nine of those loans helped prevent evictions or foreclosures, and 17 assisted people who needed more affordable housing. An additional 20 loans, for security deposits and moving expenses, were offered to families that wanted to move out of the shelter system into permanent housing.
Although the Bridge Fund primarily offers assistance to those who face evictions, some of their clients, like Mrs. Pegram and Mrs. Washington, are homeowners who face the prospect of a bank foreclosure. When Mrs. Pegram became a widow a few years ago, she decided to move in with her mother, who had also been widowed. With the original home mortgage down to a negligible amount, the family decided to apply for a loan to upgrade the property. They ended up with a 15-year mortgage at a 15.5 percent annual interest rate, which substantially raised their monthly expenses -- and quickly caused them to fall behind in payments to the bank and Con Edison.
"We were looking to fix up the kitchen, our three bathrooms, roof and windows," said Mrs. Pegram, a postal employee in Elmsford and the mother of six grown children. "The contractors were with us for a year, and it didn't take that long for all the money to be gone. The contractor had left debris on the side of the house, which caused a fire, and then he added the damage to the bill. We paid them in full, but the windows still aren't framed, and now the kitchen looks worse than it did before. The tiles are all broken and there is constant leakage under the sink."
By the time Mrs. Pegram and Mrs. Washington were referred to the White Plains office of the Bridge Fund by a housing counselor in the Office for the Aging, they were a few weeks from foreclosure. Mr. Schear worked with the family to consolidate its two mortgages by applying to Chemical Bank, which provides mortgage money from its affirmative mortgage pool for at-risk families. Mr. Schear and a counselor from the Bridge Fund worked with the family on a budget that would bring expenses into line with the family's income. Mrs. Pegram said: "Every week I come and go through the bills with Mr. Schear. He is just like my father. I think of him as family. When this ends, we will miss him. But as soon as we get back on our feet, we will pay back our loan." All loans that the Bridge Fund makes to its clients are interest free -- and last year, repayments totaled close to $42,000.
Paul Feiner, Town Supervisor of Greenburgh, added: "I've worked with them very often and think it's a fabulous group. This is much more cost effective and makes more sense by enabling people to avoid homelessness. Once people are homeless, they stay in the system. It's hard to escape. You want to avoid people going into the system."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joyce Pegram, right, and her mother, Naomi Washington, of Greenburgh, who are being aided by the Bridge Fund. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Finding Washington at Home

BYLINE: By T. H. Breen; T. H. Breen is the author of "Tobacco Culture: The Mentality of the Great Tidewater Planters on the Eve of Revolution" (Princeton).

 BODY:
MOUNT VERNON, VA., draws visitors today for many of the same reasons that it attracted them during George Washington's lifetime. They come in search of a personality, looking for the man obscured by myth and the passage of time. During a visit to the most famous private home in America, I, too, found myself viewing Mount Vernon not so much as a historic building but, rather, as a key to understanding an extraordinarily elusive man.
During the final years of Washington's life, hundreds of people navigated the muddy roads of northern Virginia to reach Mount Vernon. Some were friends from the Revolution; others were foreign dignitaries curious to meet the great republican leader. A few were simply pests. Whatever motivated the trip, travelers always encountered a gracious welcome. Washington accepted the burden of entertainment as a civic responsibility, and he seemed genuinely surprised when visitors did not appear. "Unless someone pops in, unexpectedly," he wrote in 1797, "Mrs. Washington and myself will do what I believe has not been [done] within the last 20 years by us, that is to set down to dinner by ourselves." 
 However warm the initial greeting, dinner at Mount Vernon must have been an ordeal. Seated around a long table in what Washington called his "new room" -- a large dining room papered in a brilliant green that shocks modern visitors who assume that 18th-century interiors must have been drab -- his guests tried to spark light conversation. They quickly discovered that Washington had no talent for small talk. At such moments he must have seemed a painfully wooden figure. Benjamin Henry Latrobe, architect of the United States Capitol, recorded that Washington "was frequently entirely silent for many minutes during which time an awkwardness seemed to prevail in everyone present." In 1790, another traveler described Washington as a "god," a term of respect, to be sure, but also an indication of just how hard it was to relax in the presence of a national deity.
During the long pauses, Washington's guests may have concluded that Mount Vernon expressed the man's character more articulately than he did himself. After all, the plantation was the emotional center of his life. No matter how pressing the crises Washington confronted as general and President, he allowed not a single day to pass without thinking of Mount Vernon. Seeds had to be purchased, trees planted, fields plowed, overseers instructed and rooms redecorated. No detail of plantation management escaped Washington's attention. And not surprisingly, like Thomas Jefferson's Monticello and Landon Carter's Sabine Hall, also 18th-century Virginia estates, Mount Vernon acquired the stamp of its owner's personality.
Mount Vernon had once been the possession of Lawrence Washington, George's half brother. It had been Lawrence who named the modest country house after Adm. Edward Vernon, the British naval hero. Like the homes of other moderately successful Virginia planters, Mount Vernon consisted of four small rooms built around a central hall. The structure's most distinguishing feature was its marvelous location on a hill overlooking the Potomac River. In 1754, George Washington moved to Mount Vernon, and, as he prospered, Mount Vernon expanded. In 1759, Washington constructed an entire new story, and then, on the eve of the American Revolution, he began large additions on both the north and south sides of the house. These contained the General's study, his bedroom and the large dining room. All these changes occurred without disturbing the original core of Lawrence's Mount Vernon.
No one knows exactly where Washington got his ideas for the house. Like other provincial Americans, he probably drew inspiration from pattern books published in Great Britain. Whatever the source, Washington decided to make the wooden exterior look like stone. By beveling the boards and then putting sand in the paint, he tried to transform a Virginia structure into a proper English country house. He also devised a plan for a long, high-columned piazza running the full length of the house, an architectural feature so common in modern America that it is hard to appreciate Washington's originality in Colonial America. While these various projects were going forward, Washington busily imported manufactured goods, china and pewter, metal items and glassware, the sundries that revealed to those who understood such matters that the owner of Mount Vernon had good taste.
The house itself remains the high point for most modern visitors to Mount Vernon. Self-guided tours direct the public through the large dining room -- where, in 1789, Washington learned that he had been elected the first President of the United States -- out onto the piazza where they absorb the magnificent and now fiercely protected view across the Potomac. Visitors then re-enter the central passage and wind their way up the stairs to the small guest rooms on the second floor. They pass the surprisingly Spartan bedroom, with its principally bare wood floors, in which Washington died, and, finally, return to the ground floor for an inspection of his study. Only about a quarter of the objects currently to be seen were actually in the house during Washington's lifetime. Curators continuously search for missing items, possessions long since given away or taken as souvenirs in the early 19th century. One curious survivor displayed in the central hall is a key to the Bastille, a gift from Washington's devoted friend General Lafayette. "It is a tribute which I owe as a son to my adoptive father . . ," the Frenchman explained, "as a missionary of liberty to its patriarch." Whatever original artifacts may have disappeared, the interior of Mount Vernon looks very much like it would have at the time of Washington's death in 1799.
Few 18th-century visitors appreciated what a sacrifice he made to keep up appearances. Visible evidence of good taste was as expensive then as it is now, and, throughout his 45 years at Mount Vernon, Washington had trouble balancing accounts. He told contemporaries that he prided himself on being a farmer, a man of the soil, a Cincinnatus who gladly exchanged the sword for the plow. There is no reason to doubt Washington's sincerity. Indeed, he was never more revealing about his personal beliefs than when he celebrated the virtues of agriculture.
Whatever rhetoric he may have employed, Washington was no yeoman farmer. Late-18th-century travelers who inspected the entire 8,000-acre plantation -- the four outlying farms as well as the central "mansion house farm" -- would have seen a complex commercial operation. Mount Vernon was a business. In 1799, more than 300 slaves labored to turn a profit for their master, and no captain of industry ever monitored the bottom line more closely than did Washington.
Today's visitors learn a lot about Washington as well as the many slaves whom he owned. A small museum -- easy to miss, but well worth the effort to find -- includes a remarkable archeological exhibit displaying various materials salvaged from a trash pit once located near the slave quarters. The site yielded an impressive range of imported English goods, pieces of white salt-glazed stoneware and creamware, for example. Researchers also discovered brass buckles, glass bottles and clay pipes. Many of these items, especially the ceramics, probably first appeared in the house itself, but over time, chipped plates and castoff objects came into the possession of the slaves.
The point of the archeological research is not that slaves lived better than we had previously thought. They always led a precarious existence. Rather, the appearance of manufactured ceramics and metalware reminds us that 18th-century slaves as well as their masters were linked to a huge Atlantic economy in which crops produced locally were exchanged internationally for a wide range of consumer items. What I encountered at Mount Vernon was a surprisingly fluid world. Where I anticipated stasis, I found evidence of change: an evolving house, circulating goods and constant agricultural experimentation. In fact, during my visit, I met an anxious George Washington, the manager of a great agricultural enterprise trying to accommodate the everyday demands of plantation life to the pressures of an increasingly complex international economy.
In one important respect, however, he was unusual. Washington envisioned commercial farming without slave labor. When he died, he did what most of his contemporaries in Virginia failed to do: Washington freed his slaves.
Without his constant attention, Mount Vernon fell on hard times. The visible deterioration of the mansion house shocked one French official who reported in 1840, "All is as shabby as possible; the park is grown over with weeds; the house tumbling down; everything dirty and in a miserable condition." The owner, John Augustine Washington Jr., George's great-grandnephew, offered the property for $200,000, a very large sum considering the condition of Mount Vernon, to the state of Virginia and the Federal Government, but neither volunteered to provide the money.
A remarkable woman saved the day. After viewing the ruin of Mount Vernon, Ann Pamela Cunningham's mother wrote to her invalid daughter in 1853, "Why was it that the women of his country did not try to keep it in repair, if the men could not do it? It does seem such a blot on our country!" Miss Cunningham accepted the challenge, dedicating the remainder of her life to the preservation of Washington's home. It was a hard battle. The owner was none too keen to sell Mount Vernon to the group of women who had organized under Cunningham's banner. The Mount Vernon Ladies' Association of the Union managed to raise the money, however, and, in 1858, the last member of the Washington family to own the property informed the victorious Cunningham, "Heretofore I have only been willing to dispose of Mount Vernon to the United States or to Virginia, as I believed that in the hands of one or the other it would be better protected and preserved than in the possession of any individual or association . . . [But] under the circumstances, and believing that after the two highest powers in the country, the women of the land will probably be the safest, as they will certainly be the purest, guardians of a national shrine, I am willing . . . to comply with your request."
Today, almost a million people a year visit Washington's home, still owned by the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association. The mansion house, the beautifully maintained grounds, the grazing cattle, the striking view across the Potomac, even the tomb where George and Martha are buried, all provide clues to the character of the man who transformed this site. As it has done for nearly 250 years, Mount Vernon invites travelers to confront a gracious but still elusive George Washington.
 
A VIRGINIA GENTLEMAN'S ESTATE
 MOUNT VERNON (telephone: 703-780-2000), Mount Vernon, Va., is 16 miles south of Washington, on the George Washington Memorial Parkway South. It is open daily from 8 to 5 through August, with shorter hours in the fall and winter. Admission is $7.
Self-guided tours lead visitors through the mansion, museum and around the grounds. The museum contains a diorama documenting the construction of the mansion and detailing how various elements -- plaster moldings, roof shingles -- were made; there is also a collection of personal items belonging to George and Martha Washington and portraits, among them Houdon's bust of Washington, which was modeled at Mount Vernon in 1785. A 30-minute guided walking tour concentrating on Washington's landscape design for Mount Vernon and his horticultural and farming activities is given twice hourly from 9 to 4 through August; the Museum Shop specializes in gardening goods, including seeds, herbs and cuttings propagated from Washington's own gardens.
 
REFRESHMENTS
 Just outside the estate, the MOUNT VERNON INN, operated under the auspices of the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association, includes a snack shop, restaurant and gift shop. The snack shop, which offers inexpensive sandwiches, salads and ice cream, is open daily from 9:30 to 5:30; the restaurant is open daily for lunch and on Mondays through Saturdays for dinner. Reservations (call 703-780-0011) are suggested for dinner, which might include peanut and chestnut soup, Roquefort and walnut salad, game pie and chocolate pate with pistachio sauce, served by mobcapped waitresses (about $75 for two, with wine).
 
THE POTOMAC ROUTE
 From Washington, visitors can cruise down the Potomac to Mount Vernon on the POTOMAC SPIRIT, operated by Spirit Cruises, which sails from Pier 4, Sixth and Water Streets, S.W. From now through June 13, and from Aug. 31 through Oct. 1, the ship departs at 9 A.M Tuesdays through Sundays, docking at Mount Vernon at 10:15, leaving Mount Vernon at 12:15 P.M. and returning to Washington at 1:30. From June 15 through Aug. 29, a second ship leaves Washington at 2 P.M., returning at 6:30. From Oct. 2 through Oct. 17, the Potomac Spirit sails on Saturdays and Sundays only, at 9 A.M. The fare, which includes the round-trip cruise and entrance to Mount Vernon, is $20.25. Call 202-554-8000 for reservations.

HEADLINE: In Sri Lanka, Partition Can Stop the Violence

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The United Nations working group on enforced or involuntary disappearances, reporting on Sri Lanka for 1983 to 1991, characterized killings on that unhappy island nation off the south coast of India as "by far the highest number ever recorded by the working group for any single country." But the United States news media give this tragedy little coverage. "The Tragedy of Sri Lanka" (editorial, May 5) is a welcome change. 
 Political violence in Sri Lanka started in 1956, when it was still Ceylon. The political system, a legacy of British colonial rule, which coalesced two nation-groups and then granted permanent power to one, is the cause of this discord. The Sinhalese, who acquired the dominant role, embarked on making Sri Lanka a country of one religion and one language. Sinhala was legislated as the official language, Buddhism as the state religion. Discriminatory policies deprived the minority Tamils of education and employment, and the Government began a policy of state-aided colonization of Tamil areas.
Protests were quelled with violent reprisals. There were no fewer than 27 pogroms against Tamil civilians between 1956 and 1983, and 40,000 people were killed. In 1977, the Tamils voted en masse to secede from Sri Lanka. The Government retaliated with repressive steps, resulting in the treatment of Tamil areas as virtual occupied enemy territory. The Tamil response to this was a violent guerrilla war for a separate state. The Government started aerial bombing and naval shelling of these areas. The resultant economic ruin is compounded by an embargo on food and medical supplies.
The irony is that the conflict is easily resolvable. The two warring parties occupy well demarcated areas of the island, the land mass of which is almost twice that of Switzerland, with its federated states. The easiest solution is to segregate the Sinhalese and Tamils by separate self-rule for each area. The two sides, however, are unable to agree on a suitable political structure.
As a result, violence has escalated between the two groups and has spread to political parties and factions within both. This ominous development, compounded by the huge influx of arms and explosives into this once-idyllic island, is what culminated in the May Day assassinations (front page, May 2).
The problem is unlikely to be solved without intervention. The ill-fated effort by India in 1987 failed primarily because India, burdened by its own secessionist groups, used a half-hearted, sometimes partisan, approach. In the end India got embroiled in an unnecessary war with the Tamil Tigers and had to abandon its involvement.
The situation demands an honest broker. Some countries, notably Australia, Norway and Canada have expressed willingness to play this role. Their hands should be strengthened, or the United Nations should intervene.
 
RAJAN K. SRISKANDARAJAH
Poughkeepsie, N.Y., May 6, 1993
 
The writer is editor of Tamil Voice, the newsletter of the Association of Tamils in the U.S.A.

SERB DENOUNCES PEACE EFFORT 

As the count began for the referendum in Bosnia on the Vance-Owen peace plan, the Serbian nationalist leader there declared the plan dead and said outside powers should realize that Bosnia had ceased to exist as a state. A1

FIGHTING ON TWO FRONTS
