HEADLINE: CLINTON AIDES SEEK NEW REVIEW BOARD FOR DRUG PRICING

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
President Clinton's health policy advisers have suggested that the Government set guidelines for new drug prices, monitor compliance and reprimand companies whose prices are judged to be excessive.
But under heavy lobbying by the drug industry, the Administration has apparently backed away from the idea of trying to impose rigid, legally binding controls on drug prices. Prominent Democrats, including the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, have also expressed distaste for price controls in general. 
 While Administration officials still assert that drug prices are too high and have been rising too fast, they now appear willing to try Government exhortation and voluntary restraints rather than compulsion to curb such costs.
 
Price Reviews Suggested
 Confidential work papers obtained from the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform suggest that the Government should establish a drug price review board to set guidelines for drug prices. The board would collect data on drug prices and manufacturing costs and could, through "adverse publicity," put pressure on a company to reduce prices.
"Under this option," the papers say, "the board would collect information about prices, and it would establish guidelines as to a reasonable price for prescription drugs that have no therapeutic alternative. It would have the authority to publicly condemn any companies that violated the guidelines."
The board would be loosely modeled after a Canadian agency, the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, which, according to a recent study by the Congressional General Accounting Office, has helped slow the rise of drug prices in Canada. Representative Pete Stark of California, chairman of the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, has introduced a bill to create a similar board here, and the American Association of Retired Persons supports the proposal.
 
Drug Industry Fears
 Drug companies dislike the idea of a price review board, fearing it would gain access to confidential data on their research, marketing, promotion and other costs. Moreover, they worry that after creating a board with limited authority, Congress might later give it power to set prices.
President Clinton has not made a decision on such a review board, nor has he decided how to prevent drug companies, doctors, hospitals and other suppliers from raising prices during the transition to a new health-care system, which could take three to five years. The White House says the health-care proposal, originally scheduled to be issued on May 3, will not be unveiled before mid-June.
Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, said it was reasonable for the Government to restrain drug prices because manufacturers would get a windfall when millions of people gained insurance coverage for drugs under Mr. Clinton's plan.
But Kevin Colgan, a spokesman for Merck & Company, said his company saw no need for a Government agency to review drug prices. "The vast majority of new drugs are responsibly priced," he said in an interview. "When somebody sets an outrageous price, there are plenty of public interest groups and elected officials who can focus attention on it."
Last month, Merck proposed a voluntary system of price restraints, enforceable through contracts between drug manufacturers and the Federal Government. Merck suggested that companies be given the opportunity to sign such a contract "rather than be forced into mandatory legislative Government price controls."
 
Keeping Pace With Inflation
 Under the Merck proposal, the average of the price increases for all of a company's prescription drugs could not exceed the general rate of inflation, measured by the Consumer Price Index. For any one product, the increase would be limited to the rate of inflation plus one percentage point.
People working for the health panel, headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton, said they welcomed Merck's proposal as an acknowledgment that some drug prices were too high. Administration officials said they would probably ask Congress to authorize such "voluntary agreements" through legislation, perhaps with the addition of safeguards to make sure companies comply.
The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association estimates that prescription drugs account for 7.2 percent of total spending on health care in the United States, or $67 billion of the projected $940 billion total this year.
For a decade, drug prices have been rising more than twice as fast as the Consumer Price Index, and they are a ripe target for politicians because consumers often pay such costs themselves. Private insurance is much less likely to cover drugs than hospital care or doctors' services.
 
Coverage for Prescriptions
 The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association says 72 million Americans have no insurance coverage for prescription drugs. This group includes 37 million people with no health insurance at all.
The Administration says it plans to change that. Ira C. Magaziner, manager of the task force, told consumer groups last week that the Administration would recommend coverage of prescription drugs as part of the standard package of benefits guaranteed to all Americans.
In the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would "stop drug price gouging." But within the task force and its working group on drug prices, opinions vary on how to do that. Some officials favor Federal regulation of drug prices. Others, including economists on the White House staff, said such regulation could destroy incentives for drug research. There is a consensus on the task force for a drug price review board as a compromise, officials said.
Mr. Clinton's health plan is based on a strategy of managed competition, which envisions networks of doctors and hospitals competing under Government supervision. The Administration assumes that competition will hold down drug prices when there are two or more similar products on the market. In such cases, a health plan could negotiate over prices before deciding which manufacturer's drug to buy.
But, the work papers say, "There is no reason to expect that market mechanisms will control prices of single-source drugs for which there is no therapeutic equivalent."
 
The Political Factor
 The work papers also offer a political argument for Government action: "If citizens do not see some moderation in drug price increases, the Administration will probably be held accountable."
A lobbyist for a major drug company was equally blunt. "Administration officials," he said, "have made a political calculation that they need to go to war with us and with insurance companies, to have us as the opposite pole to them."
The mind-set of some Administration officials can be inferred from work papers that say the drug industry must pay for "sins of the past."
Senator Pryor is one of Mr. Clinton's closest friends in Washington and, as chairman of the Special Committee on Aging, has been investigating drug prices for more than three years. As examples of high-priced products, he cited tissue plasminogen activator, a genetically engineered drug for treating heart attacks, which costs $2,200 a dose, and Ceredase, a drug for treating a rare enzyme deficiency called Gaucher's disease, which costs an average of $140,000 a year.
The task force has also been receptive to the arguments of retail drug stores, which complain that they cannot get the deep discounts offered by manufacturers to hospitals and other big purchasers of prescription drugs.
Robert A. Waspe, senior vice president of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, said he had urged the White House to seek a ban on such "price discrimination" and to establish a board to set a standard price for each prescription drug.

HEADLINE: In Growing Piles, Dead Tires Haunt New York

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
New Yorkers have endured more than their share of latter-day urban plagues -- from graffiti and street crime to car alarms that go off in the middle of the night. Now come tires, thousands upon thousands of them, in tumbledown piles in vacant lots, scattered beneath elevated highways like steel-belted doughnuts baking to a vulcanized doneness in the warm spring air.
Largely because environmental restrictions have raised the cost of disposing of them, discarded tires have increasingly become fixtures of the city's landscape in poorer neighborhoods in the South Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn, creating a visual blight that has begun to alarm residents and community leaders. 
 "It was never like this," said Mike Colon, 51, who has lived in the Fordham section of the Bronx more than a decade. Pointing to dozens of junk tires lining the block of Park Avenue where he lives, he said, "You call Sanitation and they clean a lot today, and the next day the tires are piled up again."
Last year, the city's Sanitation Department helped to collect about 200,000 tires illegally dumped in New York City, said Anne Canty, a spokeswoman for the department. Nearly all come from commercial dealers.
Ms. Canty estimates that about four million tires are discarded -- legally and illegally -- in the city each year.
Although she could not say how many of those were dumped illegally, the Sanitation Department is now finishing a survey to determine how many junk tires are cluttering the city's streets and vacant lots.
Once the counting is done the department can turn to figuring out what to do with them. It is already buying new shredders to help with the disposal and is considering a plan to attract tire recyclers to New York.
"Hopefully, we can create a market for the tires," Ms. Canty said. "The city could reap economic development benefits by helping to foster businesses around recycling."
Until then the tires will remain an eyesore, a nuisance and a potential health hazard. City health officials say mosquitoes breed in them; firefighters complain that children set them afire, and many parents say they worry about their children playing in and around their shaky mounds.
Besides being a source of filth and irritation, the tires provide an interesting lesson in environmental consciousness, experts say. As concerns rose in the 1980's about what was being dumped and buried in the earth, it quickly became clear that traditional ways of disposing of tires, like stacking them in huge piles on vacant land, led to unacceptable environmental hazards, tire disposal experts say. Such hazards became obvious whenever the stacks were set on fire.They burned out of control for days at a time and producing thick clouds of noxious smoke.
Landfills were also a problem. For years, old tires were routinely tossed into their seemingly bottomless pits. But environmentalists discovered that tires were bulky, did not decompose and had the nasty habit of floating to the tops of landfills, even breaking through their surfaces after they were sealed and covered with a layer of soil, Ms. Canty said.
Consequently, by the late 1980's, New York City began greatly limiting the numbers of whole tires that could be dumped in landfills. Now, some landfills will accept tires, but only after they are chopped into bits.
 
Recycling Is Expensive
 But the environmentally sound alternative -- having tires hauled to processing plants where they are ground for reuse or disposal -- is very expensive, waste management officials say.
Although ground-up tires can be used to produce a variety of products, including asphalt and a coal fuel additive in making electricity and cement, the industry is relatively new. Officials say nearly three-fourths of the 200 million tires that are discarded each year are not recycled.
Ideally, when a customer buys new tires the tire dealer disposes of the old ones by paying a reputable tire processor. The processor charges the dealer $1 or more to haul each tire away, a cost that is usually passed on directly to the customer. The processor then grinds up the tires and pays a recycler to take them away or pays a fee to have them placed in a landfill.
To avoid the costs that the processors charge, some tire repair shops and garages have turned to an underground economy in which anyone with a truck and a strong back can cart away the tires at a cut rate, Ms. Canty said.
 
Anywhere No One Is Looking
 Many underground haulers then dump tires any place they think they can get away with it, experts said. In recent years, those places have increasingly been vacant lots.
Currently, illegal dumpers can be fined $1,000 to $7,500 by the city if caught, said Ms. Canty. Vehicles used in illegal dumping can also be impounded, she said. Recently, an illegal dumper was caught in the act near Shea Stadium by a special sanitation task force, she said.
Yet the penalties have not discouraged many.
Nicholas Lugo, 16, said he had seen men dump junk tires in his neighborhood, the Fordham section of the Bronx, many times, "even in plain view."
"They just look both ways, and -- WROOF! -- they're gone," the ninth-grader said as his mother and aunt nodded in agreement.
 
Issue in Bronx and Queens
 Olga Ortiz, who has lived in her Fordham neighborhood for nine years, said illegal dumpers seem to think they can act with impunity. "I think they figure that it's the Bronx," she said. "I think they think it's just more garbage and no one around here is going to make an issue of it."
But an issue is precisely what discarded tires have become in the Bronx. One of the first questions Borough President Fernando Ferrer fielded at a recent community meeting in the University Heights section of the borough was about junk tires in its streets and on the hillsides.
"It's disgraceful," said Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, about the numbers of junk tires turning up on vacant land and parkways in parts of Queens. "This is not a single tire or two, but mountains of tires. They are coming from business people, gasoline stations, tire repair shops and trash dumpers. I'd like to catch some of them."
Mrs. Shulman said discarded tires were particularly troublesome on stretches of the Grand Central Parkway, the Van Wyck Expressway and Brookville Boulevard as it runs through the wetlands near Kennedy International Airport.
 
Blight and Expense
 Besides the blight the tires carry to some of the borough's most beautiful open spaces, Mrs. Shulman said, they are also costly to remove.
Jo Soriano, who with her husband operates an auto parts and tire repair shop in the Fordham neighborhood, says she pays a commercial hauler to dispose of the tires the three-year-old business accumulates. But that does not stop the underground haulers from buzzing around her door.
"We just had some people come by here and ask if they can pick up tires and dump them," said Ms. Soriano. "They wanted 50 cents a tire. I told them no."
But the price being offered to Ms. Soriano was about half what legitimate tire processing operations charge, said Charles Piggot, president of Integrated Tire, a processing operation based in Buffalo. "They are making my life miserable," he said of the underground haulers. He complained that he had to follow all the rules and regulations of the Department of Environmental Conservation, "which are very strict in New York State, and they don't."
Ms. Canty said that the Sanitation Department had been studying the disposal problem about six months, and was buying five shredders this year, for about $250,000 each, to help.
But even with those tire shredders running full time, Mr. Piggot suggested that the city would still face the expensive task of gathering the tires to bring them to the shredders.
Mr. Ferrer, however, says he believes he has a solution. He is studying a plan that would give some Bronx residents an incentive to bring discarded tires to collection centers, much as some people collect and redeem discarded cans.
The Federal Government, he noted, will begin requiring next year that all highway projects involving Federal dollars have at least five percent of the road materials made from tires. Thus, he said, junk tires will have a salvage value.
Mr. Ferrer said he was also trying to persuade a tire recycler to open a business in the Bronx. "This is in a sense a rubber mine," he said. "We are ready to mine."
At the same time, the Sanitation Department is considering proposing a modification to New York's recycling law that would attach a surcharge to the cost of any new tires, Ms. Canty said. Part of the surcharge, she said, would be used to pay tire retailers to dispose of the junk tires properly. The rest would help underwrite the city's campaign to pick up discarded tires.
In the meantime, the piles of abandoned tires have proven to be something of a windfall for people like Anthony Benjamin, 33.
 
'Still Got Some Meat'
 "Here's a good one," Mr. Benjamin said as measured the tread of a tire discarded beneath the Cross Bronx Expressway near Webster Avenue. "The trick is that you got to find the ones that still got some meat on them."
Already, Mr. Benjamin, who estimates that he sells about 50 tires a week to passing motorists on Webster, had two tires, patched and inflated. They served as both product display and a seat from which to hawk his finds.
In less than 15 minutes, two gypsy cabs stopped to inquire about Mr. Benjamin's tires. They sold for $5 apiece, a little more than half his asking price. Nonetheless, Mr. Benjamin was elated.
"It don't cost me nothing," he said. "There're always plenty of old tires around here."

HEADLINE: Optima's Promising Rescue Effort

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
With a blue cardigan casually covering his plaid shirt, Frank L. Skillern looks a little out of place sitting at the dark wooden table in a sober private dining room high atop the American Express tower.
"Fridays are dress-down days," he said apologetically, explaining that the policy had been instituted by Harvey Golub, who was named chief executive of American Express in February. 
 Dressing down seems a fitting symbol of contrition for this once-cocky company, which grew mighty in the 1980's, combining prestige and pizazz, then stumbled as the country headed into recession.
In no area was the company more humbled than with its Optima card, an attempt to compete with bank Mastercards and Visas. Since 1990 Optima has lost nearly $2 billion from bad loans.
 
Rescue Mission
 "If it was a stand-alone company, it would have gone bankrupt," said Mr. Skillern, who a year and a half ago was assigned to rescue the Optima card and some related American Express products.
A blunt, folksy Texas lawyer, Mr. Skillern is representative of the new, more down-to-earth management style that is coming to American Express under Mr. Golub. Even in a suit at New York headquarters, he bears little resemblance to the corporate climbers who had dominated this most image-conscious of companies.
Over lunch recently, he described how, as a newcomer to American Express Travel Related Services, the card unit, he moved to flush away some of the bravado that had led to Optima's disastrous losses. He tightened credit standards, slowed marketing and established rewards for good customers.
American Express introduced Optima in 1987, after years of debate within the company about how to get into the revolving-credit business. The company did not want to issue a mass-market credit card, fearing that it would undercut its green and gold charge cards. (Charge cards make their profits not by charging interest on customer balances, but by exacting higher fees from both card holders and merchants.)
And American Express did not want to simply add revolving credit to its existing accounts, because much of their perceived prestige stemmed from the fact that card holders are required to pay their bills in full each month.
But American Express had also found that many of its card holders were among the heaviest borrowers on their bank Mastercard and Visa accounts, stretching out payments and being assessed finance charges. So to capture some of this interest being paid by its existing customers, American Express introduced Optima as a companion card, with a below-average interest rate, available for a $15 annual fee to holders of its green and gold cards.
It was a marketing success, adding a total of 3.5 million cards at its peak in 1990, one-quarter of the holders of American Express charge cards, with loans outstanding of $4 billion.
This seemingly brilliant compromise failed, however, because the product often attracted the worst credit risks, Mr. Skillern said.
"People who used Optima to a certainty made a decision they didn't want to or couldn't pay us back at the end of the month," he said. Ninety-five percent of customers who used the card borrowed on it, a much higher rate than for users of bank cards.
Optima did not attract those who bankers call "accidental revolvers," customers who can afford to pay their bills but forget to every now and then, accumulating interest charges.
Without such profitable and creditworthy customers, Optima had a much higher proportion of card holders who ran into financial problems as the recession deepened. By last year, the bad debts that American Express was writing off amounted to nearly 11 percent of its almost $7 billion in total assets, a loss rate unheard of in the bank-card industry.
Compounding the problem was American Express's growth-oriented corporate culture. As the loan losses mounted, managers in the Optima division used accounting gimmicks to hide the extent of the problem.
Mr. Skillern, however, is an outsider to this culture. Once general counsel to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, he was hired in 1984 as a lawyer for IDS Financial Services, American Express's Minneapolis-based financial-planning and mutual-fund company. Mr. Golub, then IDS's chairman, in time assigned him to run various businesses, including IDS's bank and a start-up operation in Britain.
A dog breeder, history buff and avid theatergoer, Mr. Skillern will often work Shakespearean quotations into his remarks at business meetings. On a bet during his time in London, Mr. Skillern stood on a table and recited, in his Texas drawl, all of Britain's rulers in chronological order.
 
Punctuality a Character Trait
 For all his eclectic interests, Mr. Skillern is a notably disciplined manager who concentrates his efforts on a small number of objectives. "He is the most punctual person I have ever met in my life," said Peter A. Lefferts, a senior vice president at IDS.
For Optima, Mr. Skillern intends to achieve a profit of 1.75 to 2 percent of assets within three years; that will require cutting losses to 7 percent of the unit's assets.
He imposed much tougher procedures to prevent or reduce losses from the existing card holders. Some were as simple as calling delinquent customers sooner to ask for payment.
And he spent more than $8 million to develop computer models that use information about card holders' activity to predict who is likely to get in financial trouble. American Express now cuts off credit to those it identifies as being at risk: for example, people who withdraw cash so regularly that it appears they are living on it.
And Mr. Skillern severely restricted all card holders' ability to borrow cash. Losses on these loans, which had been as much as 25 percent of Optima's receivables, ran close to 20 percent of the amounts outstanding. "People used cash for the wrong reason," he said. "We wanted to position it as emergency money."
For 1992, Mr. Skillern slashed the budget for soliciting new Optima card holders by 75 percent, but he did not eliminate such spending because creditworthy new customers would help improve the unit's earnings.
 
Prestige No Longer Enough
 Credit standards were tightened so much that only 25 percent of the supposedly elite holders of another American Express card would qualify. Since then, American Express has developed more advanced screening criteria that would approve Optima cards for about half the green and gold card holders.
The consumer lending unit is now about half way to Mr. Skillern's goals for reducing losses. It wrote off $147 million in bad loans for the first three months of the year, an annual rate of 8.8 percent of its total loans at the end of the period.
To many analysts, this is slow progress. "When a company with losses of 11 percent says they've lowered them by two percentage points, this isn't good news in the banking business," said Donald Auriemma, a credit-card consultant. Other banks with problems have been able to reduce the losses much faster, he added.
 
Variety of Interest Rates
 The decline in losses may appear slow, Mr. Skillern said, because he is trying to preserve as much of the potential revenue from the business as possible to reach his profitability goals.
To this end, he adjusted Optima interest rates last year to encourage customers to pay their bills and charge more. Customers could qualify for a lower rate if they charged $1,000 annually, but their rates would rise significantly if they did not make their minimum payments on time.
Mr. Skillern is now turning his attention to selling Optima more aggressively. To compete with bank cards that offer bonuses like airline frequent-flier miles and automobile discounts, Optima now offers bonus points, good for merchandise or travel. (Spending $3,000 gets you two dozen bagels and lox; $300,000 earns a week for two at Euro Disneyland.)
 
About Those Ads . . .
 A new challenge, Mr. Skillern said, is how to sell Optima again without looking hypocritical in light of recent ads for the American Express card that feature the comedian Jerry Seinfeld sneering at "revolving debt."
Mr. Skillern's answer is to cast the credit card as a lesser evil. "Our message is when you do borrow, we want you to borrow from us and we will offer you one of the best deals," he said.
More difficult will be deciding whether to separate Optima from the green and gold cards and offer it as a stand-alone product. Mr. Skillern has been an outspoken advocate of this. But he said that he needed two years to prove to skeptical American Express executives that he could manage the company's credit business. Still, he argued that Optima would always be subordinate. "Lending is not the reason of existence of American Express," he said. "We are the tail, and the charge card is the dog."
At the end of the lunch, Mr. Skillern stood up crisply. It was 1:25 P.M. and he was heading for a 1:30 P.M. meeting. Under the new Golub order, he explained, meetings start on time.
"When I got here, there was clock time and T.R.S. time, which was always a quarter of an hour later," he said, referring to Travel Related Services. "That is less than optimal efficiency."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Chronicling the Drama Of Japanese Business

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 16

 BODY:
The industrial image that Japan likes to present to the rest of the world is an economy in which diligent workers devote their lives to the company that employs them, management decisions are made by harmonious consensus and networks of affiliated companies work together for the common good.
But for a truer, darker view of what Japanese corporate life is really like, many Japanese turn to the nation's popular fiction, in particular what are called "economic novels." Here one finds a world of back-stabbing, board-room coups, pressure tactics, cheating and stifling working conditions -- in short, an unvarnished portrait of the nation's vaunted business system that is rarely found in newspapers and textbooks. 
 Americans also have business-related fiction, like Arthur Haley's "The Money Changers." But in Japan, a nation in which life centers on work, it is perhaps not surprising that the economic novel is a distinct genre like science fiction or mysteries.
Consider, for example, "The Keiretsu," a best seller last year about the fictional Tokyo Motors, which is said to be based on the real-life cartel led by the Nissan Motor Company. At a time when Japanese keiretsu, the networks of suppliers affiliated with an industrial giant, are viewed as a reason for Japan's competitive success, the novel paints a grim portrait of how these captive suppliers are exploited by the parent company.
To lift its own sagging profits, Tokyo Motors, a giant auto company, is pressing its suppliers to cut their prices to the bone. The chief executive of Taisei Lighting, a headlight supplier, is resisting the cuts and trying to stave off his mandatory retirement until he can position his son as his successor. If Tokyo Motors forces his retirement and installs its own man to run Taisei, it could suck dry the smaller company's remaining profits.
"In the economic novel, you find the real story that you can't find in journalism," Makoto Sakata, a nonfiction business writer, said.
Or, as the author of "The Keiretsu," Ikko Shimizu, puts it, "If you don't write about the drama in business society, you cannot describe real life in Japan."
The novels, some of which are actually more like short stories, sport titles like "The Public Relations Section Keeps Quiet" or "Ward of the Overworked" or "Novel of the Industrial Bank of Japan," a five-volume epic. They deal with topics as varied as the building of a refinery, death from overwork, corporate politics, complex stock manipulations and trade disputes.
And scandals. Japan has been rocked in recent years by a series of scandals involving illegal stock trading, bribes to politicians, business dealings with gangsters. Virtually all of these scandals seem to end up as novels, with the names changed.
 
Quiet Desperation, Described
 Many of the novels paint a bleak picture of the life of Japanese middle managers, the so-called salary men, who are also the major readers of the novels.
"Economic novels are the middle managers' enka," said Mr. Sakata, referring to the soulful ballads of loves lost and found that are popular in Japan. "Middle managers always have the feeling of one-sided love for the company, but they are always betrayed by the company."
In Mr. Shimizu's "Silver Sanctuary," for instance, the lights dim at a bank branch's year-end party as the branch deputy manager is dragged away and shoved down the stairs. It was, Mr. Shimizu writes, "a sinister rebellion by the underdogs against the institution which forced them into a uniformity in which one must not stand out, must not be praised or berated; one must not be in the news; one must strive in every way possible not to commit either virtue or vice."
There are the inspirational novels like "A Life Aflame," in which Ryo Takasugi tells the story of an engineer who works night and day to install a computerized control system at a new refinery, hiding from his colleagues the diabetes that is blinding him. When the engineer dies at the age of 45, his boss cuts short a meeting, closets himself in his office, and bursts into tears.
 
Popular Since the 1950's
 Economic novels first became popular in the late 1950's with the writings of Saburo Shiroyama, an economics professor. One of his early works, "Made in Japan," portends a theme that would concern Japan for much of the following decades -- trade fiction.
A Japanese thermometer company president tries to stop the United States from putting tariffs on Japanese thermometers, despite the pleadings of other Japanese companies to agree to voluntary export restraints. In the end, the United States requires that Japanese imports have "Made in Japan" stamped on them, which back then virtually assured the products would not sell.
Dozens of writers now churn out business novels. Some worked for companies like Japan Air Lines and Hitachi. Others are former journalists. Mr. Takasugi, one of the most prominent and prolific writers, worked for a chemical industry newsletter until 1974, when he took a year off because of an illness. That's when he wrote his first of 46 novels.
Mr. Takasugi interviews extensively for his novels, getting information from whistle-blowers and others. "I don't write anything that cannot happen," he said. "Everything is either fact or has a very high possibility of happening."
 
More Freedom Than Nonfiction
 Mr. Shimizu, who is 61, worked as a freelance journalist and at one time for a labor union. By his own count, he has written perhaps 200 novels, mainly business novels but also some mysteries.
Mr. Shimizu specializes in muckraking exposes and scandals. He employs six or seven reporters, many of whom also work for newspapers or magazines. Because his own name is now so famous, "it's almost impossible for me to interview people myself at the companies," he said.
The idea for "The Keiretsu," Mr. Shimizu said, came from news articles. The chairman of a Nissan supplier, had been kicked out of his company in a boardroom revolt and then sued the management of his old company.
Both the chairman and his son cooperated with Mr. Shimizu in the interest of leaving a record of what had occurred.
"My father could not explain this to his grandson, but if someone wrote it in a novel, it would help explain it," the son said in an interview, adding that the events described in the novel were mainly true. "The keiretsu system actually killed my father's entrepreneurial spirit." He spoke on the condition he not be named because his father has since settled with his old company and did not want any more trouble.
So far, few business novels have been translated into English and there is doubt about whether they would appeal to foreign audiences. The best collection is "Made in Japan and other Japanese Business Novels" (M.E. Sharpe Inc., 1989), a collection of seven stories translated and edited by Tamae K. Prindle, an associate professor of Japanese language and literature at Colby College in Maine.
Still, as more attention has been paid to Japanese management methods in the last few years, the business novel is being discovered as a sort of textbook with drama thrown in.
For example, The Harvard Business Review, in its May-June 1991 issue, reprinted a story called "A Longer Vacation" by Jun Asakawa, about a company's attempts to thin its management ranks by getting workers to discover there is more to life than work. The plan works well until a top nuclear engineer, privy to all the company's secrets, decides after a long vacation to quit and devote his life to the anti-nuclear cause.
John Wiley & Sons has expressed interest in publishing "The Keiretsu" in English. Mr. Shimizu said that the American publisher asked him to cut the novel's romantic subplot, in which the president's son pines for a fiance he fears he might have helped kill.
"If I cut that part so drastically," Mr. Shimizu said, "it cannot be called a novel."

HEADLINE: California's 'Reagan Country' Open Minded About Clinton

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN GROVE, Calif., May 14

 BODY:
Standing on her front lawn barely out of earshot of her husband, Betty W. lowered her voice and told a secret. "Yes, I did vote for Clinton," said the retired school secretary and longtime Reagan Democrat, giving only her first name because she feared scorn if her family found out. "I didn't tell my husband. He voted for Ross Perot."
Now, on the eve of Bill Clinton's second visit to California since becoming President, Betty is a bit uncertain but still thinks she made the right choice. "I don't know whether he's on the right track or not," she said. "I just feel he's trying to do something." 
 Many in this city in Orange County, a bedrock of conservatism in the 1980's, offered similar views in door-to-door interviews in two voting precincts, saying they had not yet warmed up to Mr. Clinton but were determined to give him the benefit of the doubt as he struggles with issues that are close to home in this working-class community. Instead, they attributed the country's ills to Congress, which they accused of trying to block many of Mr. Clinton's programs.
 
Pain Felt at Home
 Mr. Clinton's trip to California, which starts Monday with a visit to San Diego, is crucial in the short run as he tries to sell his economic program to the nation, and in the long term if he hopes to be re-elected in 1996. Last year, Mr. Clinton carried the state, the nation's largest electoral prize.
But the state's economy continues to lag behind the rest of the country because of continuing cuts in industries like aerospace and banking and the closing of large military bases. Such woes are especially hard-felt here in Orange County, home to thousands of blue-collar aerospace workers and several military bases that the Pentagon wants to shut down.
"Everybody was very excited that there was a change," said George T. Urch, chief of staff to Tom Umberg, the Democratic State Assemblyman who represents Garden Grove in Sacramento, the state capital. "They really want to believe in Clinton. They are really looking for an excuse to believe in Clinton, but he hasn't given them anything to believe in yet."
 
Democrats Return to Roots
 In the 1980's, Republicans won big in Orange County thanks to conservative Democrats who flocked in droves to the Reagan-Bush camp. But last fall George Bush got only 44 percent of vote here, thanks to the many Reagan Democrats who returned to their roots in the hope that Mr. Clinton would restore life to the area's economy (Mr. Clinton received 32 percent of the vote and Mr. Perot 24 percent).
With the economy in trouble, many who were undecided as well as some leaning toward Mr. Bush ended up voting for Mr. Clinton.
"At the last minute, I decided to vote for Clinton," Kathleen Kackley said Friday evening as her husband, Leonard, sat watching Bob Hope's 90th birthday celebration on television in their mobile home. "But I'm kind of worried, the way things are going. I'm a senior. Hearing all this flak about the medical changes -- I'm concerned about that."
Last summer, the Kackleys, both registered Democrats, said they would vote for Mr. Bush even though Mr. Kackley said he was turned off by the Republicans' stance against abortion rights. At the time, Mrs. Kackley said she liked Mr. Bush's strong stand on family values. But later she said she just felt it was time to give someone else a chance to address the nation's problems.
Mr. Kackley, 74, stood by Mr. Bush to the end. But now he supports President Clinton and scorns Congress for blocking his programs. "Give him a little more time," Mr. Kackley, a retired school custodian, said during a commercial break in the Bob Hope special. "I think he'll be all right. They keep holding him back. They ought to get rid of them. The Republicans are against the Democrats, the Democrats are against the Republicans.
"Everybody wants to be the big dog in Washington now. They don't want to give anybody else a chance. I didn't vote for Mr. Clinton, but now that he's in there, give him a chance."
 
Cigarette at Sunset
 Down the street, Robert Milhollin sat outside his house, smoking a cigarette as the sun set. A registered Republican, he voted for Mr. Bush in 1988 and Ronald Reagan in 1980 and 1984, but last fall he supported Mr. Clinton. He plans to change his registration to Democratic before the next big election.
"Give him a chance," said Mr. Milhollin, 70, a retired building contractor. "You're not going to change it overnight. I like Clinton because he seems to use a little common sense with what he's doing.
"He can't do any worse than some of the jerks we had before."

HEADLINE: Khmer Rouge Given a Warning by U.S. On Defying Election

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei, May 16

 BODY:
The United States warned the Khmer Rouge today against any attempt to carve out territories in Cambodia in opposition to the government to be formed after United Nations-sponsored elections next week.
"There is always a danger of that happening with the Khmer Rouge," Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said at the end of two-day talks with the Association of South East Asian Nations. 
 "We would of course firmly oppose that, and I would imagine Asean would also oppose it," said Mr. Lord, who is visiting the region for the first time since his appointment by President Clinton.
He said the United States was helping to fly additional military equipment to forces of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia. But there has been no discussion on the United States sending forces to join the 22,000-member unit, he said.
Mr. Lord left for Thailand after the meeting and will also visit Cambodia before going to Singapore for further security talks with Asean and other countries. Members of the group are Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.
Officials said the group and the United States exchanged views on the possibility that the Khmer Rouge would try to seize parts of the country.
"There was exchange of views but we made no decision on what to do," said Lim Jock Seng, permanent secretary of Brunei's Foreign Ministry and a spokesman for the group. "Our immediate concern is the election."
Mr. Lord said: "The stakes are very high in Cambodia. We have been very disturbed by attempts to disrupt the elections. There have been intimidations by a couple of the factions, but the most serious sabotage has been coming, of course, from the Khmer Rouge."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Focus Shifting to Municipals

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Amid the rubble of last week's disappointing inflation reports and the selloff in the bond market, tax-exempt municipal bonds look pretty good. And the Clinton tax bill, which passed its first major Congressional hurdle when it was approved on a party-line vote by the House Ways and Means Committee on Thursday, makes these bonds look even more inviting.
Traders and analysts argue, and the statistical data seem to back them up, that there is both some good yield to earn and a nice chance for some capital gains in the municipal market, a possibility that is fading in the Government securities markets. 
 One signal was the performance of municipal bonds last week. Prices barely budged lower although Treasury prices fell sharply, with the 30-year bond off 1 3/8 points while the yield jumped to 6.94 percent from 6.84 percent. In comparison, the yield in the Bond Buyer Index of 40 municipal bonds slipped 1 basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.86 percent.
 
Change Not Factored In
 The main reason behind this positive thinking on municipals is that it appears that investors have not yet factored in that if President Clinton gets his way tax rates will rise next year. And the higher tax rates will make tax-exempt municipals a better bargain.
In the Ways and Means tax bill, which is expected to be voted on in the full House later this month, the current 31 percent tax rate would jump to 36 percent. And for taxpayers with incomes over $250,000 there would be a 10 percent surcharge, lifting the effective top rate to 39.6 percent.
But in looking at the level at which tax-exempt municipals are trading relative to the yields on taxable Treasury securities, that does not seem to have been considered. Because they are tax-exempt, municipal bonds trade at lower yields than Treasuries.
But currently they are trading at higher yields or ratios compared with Treasuries than recently and than would be expected at the higher tax rates the Clinton Administration is seeking.
 
Initial Effect Eroded
 "It had an effect initially but that had eroded slowly," said Austin Tobin, president of the Delphis Hanover Corporation in Southbury, Conn., referring to the President's proposal to raise tax rates. "There is a lot of sophistication out there and I don't think anyone is jumping ahead of this on the tax bill."
At the end of last week, 10-year municipal bonds with a top triple A credit rating were trading at yields that were 81.7 percent of those on 10-year Treasuries. This is well above the 52-week low of 75 percent reached at the end of November. In fact, it is closer to the high of 86 percent reached in October. Prices and yields on bonds move in opposite directions, so when the yield -- and the ratio to Treasuries -- is lower, the price is higher.
The same is true for five-year tax-exempt municipals. The current ratio is 81 percent, while the low of the last year was 70.7 percent, also at the end of November. For 30-year bonds, however, the opportunity is not as enticing. The current ratio is 79.9 percent, not far above the 52-week low of 77.8 percent at the end of July.
But many analysts advise against buying in the 30-year sector anyway because the yield is not that much higher than those of bonds in the 10-year range but the risk of loss is greater.
 
Room for Yields to Drop
 The high ratios mean there is room for yields to move even lower against Treasuries and that means the price -- and the capital gain -- will move up. In addition, the higher tax rates, if they become law, should mean that the present ratios between municipals and Treasuries will widen, which means more opportunity for capital gains.
Mr. Tobin said the ratio of the yield on 30-year tax-exempt municipal bonds had not been able to get much below 80 percent in the past. But with higher tax rates he expects that the threshold level for the ratio could move to 75 percent or lower.
Even without the capital gains potential, the tax increases make tax-exempt bonds look great. Now at the 31 percent top tax rate, a municipal bond with a 6 percent coupon has a yield that is equivalent to 8.70 percent on a taxable government or corporate security. If the tax rate goes to 36 percent, that taxable equivalent yield jumps to 9.38 percent. And at the proposed top tax rate of 39.6 percent, the yield is 9.93 percent.
There are several explanations of why -- when it has seemed clear for some time that tax rates were going higher -- investors have not been buying tax-exempt municipals and why the ratio between tax-exempts and Treasuries has not widened already.
One is the crush of new issues in the municipal market to take advantage of lower interest rates and to refinance old higher-interest-rate debt. According to the Securities Data Company, the total of new issues this year is now $97.2 billion, well ahead of the record pace set in 1992.
"The supply has put a lot of burden on the market," said Kenneth Meiselman, a senior vice president at J.B. Hanauer & Company, a brokerage firm in Parsippany, N.J.
Another explanation is that while President Clinton has promised higher tax rates and the Ways and Means Committee has approved them, investors are not so sure that will happen or just are not paying attention.
"We are getting the word out" about higher tax rates, said Terry Tracy, national sales and marketing manager for municipals at Lehman Brothers, adding, "People think about it and understand it but they don't do anything about it until it hits home and often that doesn't happen until they do their taxes."
There is, however, at least one small negative in the tax bill that could have an impact on the municipal market. It is the tax treatment on capital gains from tax-exempts. Under the new proposal, there will be situations when the gain on a bond that was bought at cost below the price at its original issue will be counted as ordinary income, which would be taxed at the new higher rates, instead of as capital gains, which would still have a rate of 28 percent.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
With Badillo Out, What Is Effect on Mayor Race?

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
NOTHING became Herman Badillo more in this year's mayoral race than leaving it. His withdrawal informally signaled the beginning of a general-election campaign that culminates fully 25 weeks from tomorrow.
Doesn't Rudolph W. Giuliani have a lock on the election? 
 More like a latch, given his proposed alliance with Mr. Badillo. Four years ago, Mr. Giuliani, the Republican, lost to David N. Dinkins by only 2 percentage points and it is assumed that the Democratic Mayor's support among many groups has eroded since then. This year's public-opinion polls, while largely premature, are just as close. And those surveys have typically, though not always, overstated support for black candidates.
New York City voters dumped the last two Democratic incumbents, Abraham D. Beame after only four years and Edward I. Koch when he sought an unprecedented fourth term. Mr. Koch now seems poised to endorse Mr. Giuliani, lending him the same credibility among Jewish voters that Mr. Koch provided for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato last year.
So can we skip the next 25 weeks of political oratory and analysis?
Not so fast. No Republican has been elected citywide since 1965. And Mr. Giuliani's appeal four years ago was grounded largely in his reputation as a Federal prosecutor -- a reputation that may have lost some of its gloss and its relevance.
Also, Mr. Giuliani just might make a mistake. Peter J. Powers, who managed his campaign four years ago, wrote recently that "oddly enough" his fondest memory of Mr. Giuliani was Election Night in 1989, when he "had to sternly let a crowd of enthusiastic supporters know that it was over and that we had to get behind the city's new mayor." It demonstrated, Mr. Powers wrote, Mr. Giuliani's "integrity, his leadership, his strength of character and above all his caring."
Others remember the moment less fondly -- Mr. Giuliani was screaming "shut up" to supporters who booed the very mention of Mr. Dinkins -- as evidence of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's forecast that the man elected mayor that year would be the candidate who could best bring the city together.
 Has Mr. Dinkins brought the city together?
Compared to whom? Ask New Yorkers their views of the city and of Mr. Dinkins himself and the replies are often racially polarized. Race is not an issue, Mr. Giuliani has often asserted. It doesn't have to be. This time, Mr. Dinkins has a record as Mayor that Mr. Giuliani can attack. Also, how race plays in the campaign may depend on whether, in the next 25 weeks, the city becomes consumed by the murder of a Yusuf Hawkins or of a Yankel Rosenbaum.
But let's look at the record. Isn't crime down?
Statistically, yes. But convincing New Yorkers that they are safer today than four years ago may be a tough sell. Testimonials celebrating the return of beat cops will help. But reminders that the police no longer routinely arrest neighborhood drug dealers -- part of a strategy to focus on higher-level dealers -- may undermine Mr. Dinkins's vow to be the toughest mayor on crime. His best rejoinder: how much more could Mr. Giuliani or any mayor do?
Mr. Dinkins's indulgence in self-congratulation over balancing the city's budget may not be all that great a political asset, given that, even in a searing recession, he was merely fulfilling a legal mandate and surpassing low expectations by doing so. In counting so heavily on help from Albany and Washington, Mr. Dinkins has taken a calculated risk: that in a melding of public and political interest, a Democratic Governor and President will be inclined to invest enough state and Federal aid to justify Mr. Dinkins's claim that having a Democratic Mayor is an asset to New York City and also would be an asset to a Democratic Governor and President when they seek re-election.
 Still, hasn't Mr. Dinkins had a good week?
Ask Andrew J. Stein. Mr. Badillo's sudden departure set the stage for the head-to-head contest that Mr. Stein, the City Council President who is running for mayor, has claimed that he wanted in order to inherit all of the Democratic opposition to Mr. Dinkins. But Mr. Stein's previous political feats are failing him now.
He is far behind every self-imposed benchmark in the mayoral race, except perhaps in fund-raising. He faces defections from his potential supporters whose fear of a Republican mayor may be deeper than their opposition to Mr. Dinkins or their faith in Mr. Stein. But Mr. Stein may be in a bind: switching gears to run for re-election to the Council job that is being renamed Public Advocate may no longer be a viable alternative; running for mayor as an underdog -- even losing -- might seem preferable.
Also, ask Mr. Badillo about Mr. Dinkins's week. Mr. Badillo got more attention leaving the mayoral race than had he ever formally run. But, like Mr. Koch, he would bestow another imprimatur on Mr. Giuliani by joining him as an unofficial running-mate for city comptroller -- if, that is, Mr. Badillo actually decides to run, if he shuns coyness and actually embraces the Republican nominee, and if all of his new-found friends love him in September and in November as they do in May.

HEADLINE: PULSE: Teen-Agers at Risk

 BODY:
Across the nation, increasing numbers of teen-agers are neither in school nor in the labor force. Arrests of teen-agers for violent crimes have risen substantially. Violent deaths are taking an ever greater toll.
The same troubling picture applies in this region, In New York, a teen-ager's likelihood of meeting a violent death increased at nearly three times the national average from 1985 to 1990 - though it remained less likely than in the nation as a whole.
 From 1986 to 1991, the rate of teen-agers arrests for violent crimes grew slower in New York than in the nation. And while more New York teen-agers dropped out of school and work between 1985 and 1990, a greater percentage of teen-agers in the region as a whole were enrolled or employed.

HEADLINE: JERSEY CITY JOURNAL;
The Picket Line Comes To the Checkout Line

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
THE advertisements blared "Buy one, get one free," so Arthur Graham drove to the Pathmark on Route 440 one recent afternoon for his weekly shopping. But before he could fill his cart with soda and cereal and boneless chicken breasts, he found himself ensnared in a bitter labor dispute.
"Please support us!" Nicole Nesheiwat shouted at Mr. Graham as he was about to stroll through the entrance. She shoved a flier into his hand and stared into his eyes, searching for sympathy for the 250 union workers at the store who have been locked out of their jobs since the conflict at four supermarket chains flared more than a week ago. 
 "The more people who walk through those doors, the longer we're going to be out for," implored Ms. Nesheiwat, 19, who normally works as a bookkeeper at the sprawling 24-hour store but in recent days has perfected a convincing sales pitch for dissuading customers from shopping there.
After listening for a few minutes, Mr. Graham, 24, a station attendant for N.J. Transit, turned around, announcing to cheers from the union workers that he would take his business to the nearby Acme supermarket. "I think she has a strong argument," he said.
It was one small victory for the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, Local 1262, in a war that has spread in recent days to nearly 130 supermarkets in the Pathmark, Shop Rite, Foodtown and Grand Union chains in parts of New Jersey and New York.
Frank Margiotta, a spokesman for the union, said that 12,634 union workers were either on strike or locked out of their jobs. Negotiators met with a Federal mediator on Friday, but no new talks have been scheduled.
The dispute centers largely on health care and retirement packages, with the union accusing management of trying to slash away at parts of the previous contract, which expired on April 10. The four chains say they can no longer shoulder the burden of providing all of those benefits.
"We are trying to recognize the economic conditions that exist, as well as the spiraling costs of health care," said Larry Salinas, vice president for public affairs at the Supermarkets General Corporation in Woodbridge, N.J., the parent company of Pathmark.
At the Pathmark here, a greeting committee of sorts has gathered at the entrance to the parking lot every morning since the dispute began on May 7. Waving signs and shouting into bullhorns, the union workers urge motorists to turn around and suggest other stores nearby that they can visit. And because Jersey City has been flooded by immigrants in recent years, they do it in many languages: Spanish, Hindi, Tagalog, Haitian Creole.
As she stood on a traffic island trying to attract the attention of passing motorists, Albina Spicacci, 41, said she was particularly upset that Pathmark had locked out its union workers even though the workers had not decided to strike.
"I didn't think that we'd be out this long," said Mrs. Spicacci, a bookkeeper whose face has turned a bright red from all the hours spent in the sun picketing the store. "No one is winning in this situation. The store is losing money, and we're not getting paid. It's a stalemate."
Mr. Salinas insisted that Pathmark had locked out workers at 24 of its stores only after the union tried to divide the four chains, which bargain as one, by striking at eight Shop Rite supermarkets. Grand Union has also locked out employees at some locations.
But Mr. Margiotta said the chains were ganging up on the union. "Who is it that escalated this thing?" he asked. "They wanted to create a crisis and then blame it on the union."
The workers believe that their cries of "We need your help!" are taking a toll. Since the dispute began, Pathmark has sharply reduced its hours at locked-out stores -- 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. on weekdays and 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. on weekends. And Mr. Salinas acknowledged that though temporary employees were filling in, the drop in business had been "fairly dramatic."
But for every shopper like Mr. Graham or the motorist who turned his car around in the parking lot and yelled, "O.K., I'll go to Kmart!" there are many who stride right past the pickets with steely looks.
About 10 seconds after Ms. Nesheiwat finished talking to Mr. Graham, she quickly walked over to another man. When she asked him not to enter, he sneered and hurried into the store. "Why should I?" he asked. "Where am I going to eat?"
Others criticized the union for provoking the supermarket chains even as companies around the New York region are facing tough times.
"With so much unemployment, it's stupid to strike," said Dave Pymdus, 37, a construction salesman who came to the store with his two young children. "Besides, I got to buy diapers, and they have a great sale going on."

HEADLINE: Small Business Gives Tax Break Mixed Reviews

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
On Friday, a day after the House Ways and Means Committee had approved a tax break for small businesses that buy new equipment, the managers of the Marvelous Market bakery convened to decide whether to spend $19,000 for a new bread oven.
The oven was the kind of investment that sponsors of the tax provision had intended to encourage, on the premise that such spending made small companies grow, increased productivity, and created jobs. 
 The provision, inserted in a big tax bill, would increase to $25,000 from $10,000 the amount of capital spending a small company could deduct from its income in the year the money was spent, rather than requiring the company to deduct the amount over several years through gradual depreciation.
But when Mark Furstenberg, the owner of the Marvelous Market, which makes a gourmet sourdough that was introduced to the affluent suburbs of Washington in 1990, was asked whether the tax bill would encourage him to increase his capital budget, he answered without hesitation: "No."
 
Decision Driven By Demand
 "It is almost entirely irrelevant to me whether the tax code rewards me for this," Mr. Furstenberg said at his planning meeting.
Rather, he and his managers agreed, the bakery would buy the new rotating rack oven to replace an existing stone deck oven simply because demand for the company's products was booming.
"I would love to be able to expense the full cost of this oven rather than to depreciate it," he added. "It's a nice reward. But it does not have anything to do with my decision."
Lobbyists for small businesses said they were delighted with the tax provision, which would be retroactive, but has not been approved by the full House or the Senate, where the tax bill faces further changes by the Finance Committee in the next few weeks.
"The increase in the direct expensing will help millions of smaller businesses," said H. Ted Olson, the chairman of the Small Business Legislative Council, a group of trade associations that represent many industries. "While we are sorry the committee could not make the investment tax credit work for small business, this is a very positive alternative."
The Administration had proposed a tax credit that would have directly reduced the amount of tax owed, but the committee rejected the plan. It opted instead for the expensing mechanism, which would reduce the taxable income of a company.
Family farms, which might use the tax break to subsidize the purchase of a new tractor, would be important beneficiaries as well, said Representative Peter Hoagland, Democrat of Nebraska, and a member of the Ways and Means Committee.
But tax accountants warned there were many reasons the provision would be of relatively narrow benefit, especially compared with an investment tax credit, the alternative that the Clinton Administration failed to push through Congress.
"This is pretty small in terms of manufacturing businesses," said Thomas Ochsenschlager, a tax partner at KPMG Peat Marwick. "It favors mom-and-pop businesses in the service sectors."
To take full advantage of the provision, accountants said, a company would have to have profits of at least $25,000, as the provision could not be used to create a loss for tax purposes. That means small business with profits of less than $10,000 would get no additional incentive from the proposed change.
Many small businesses pay their owners a salary and keep corporate income -- and corporate taxes -- low. And if corporate taxes are just 15 percent, or even 25 percent, as they are for companies with profits of less than $75,000, an increase in expense deductions to $25,000 from $10,000 would make a difference of just a few thousand dollars in the amount of tax owed.
Many midsize companies, which might be taxed at higher levels and would have more to gain, are too big to use the technique of expensing. Under current law, the benefit is phased out for companies that make more than $200,000 in qualifying investments. A company that buys a machine tool, for example, for $210,000 cannot treat any of the investment as a direct expense. While the complete language of the new provision has not been released, a similar limit would be included.
Tax savings that would accrue from the expensing provision would occur anyway in a few years under ordinary depreciation schedules, especially on equipment like computers that can be depreciated relatively quickly.

HEADLINE: Puzzle of New York City's Growing Budget

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Only in the upside-down world of New York City budget-making could the Mayor talk of hard times and spending cuts to close a budget gap while the bottom line of his budget is growing faster than inflation.
But that is exactly what has happened. While Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Council leaders are preparing for a tough budget that will probably contain millions of dollars in spending cuts in some areas, the overall cost of the city government has actually grown by $1.1 billion in the last 12 months and will grow at least by another $800 million in the next fiscal year, budget officials said. 
 The Mayor's political opponents charge that the inexorable swelling of government spending reflects Mr. Dinkins's timid management style and his reluctance to make fundamental changes in the way the city delivers services. For their part, Mr. Dinkins's aides argue that the budget has grown largely because of forces out of the Mayor's control and that most of the new spending comes not from local tax money but from state and Federal funds earmarked for specific programs.
Independent experts on the city budget contend that the truth lies somewhere in between: While much of the increased spending was unavoidable -- either because of unforeseeable emergencies or because of state and Federal requirements -- the city could have used some of its extra tax revenue to close its budget gap or pay off debt.
Between the time the city adopted its budget for the current fiscal year in June 1992 and the time the year ends next month, the city's total revenue and spending will have grown by 3.7 percent -- to $30.6 billion from $29.5 billion -- fueled mostly by unanticipated costs for labor settlements, overtime, Medicaid and welfare.
That means that before the last ledger is balanced on June 30, the city will have taken in and spent nearly $450 million more in municipal tax revenues and about $700 million more in state and Federal money than it originally planned.
And Mr. Dinkins has proposed a $31.4 billion plan for the fiscal year that begins on July 1, meaning that next year's budget will grow at least 6 percent over what was adopted last year, twice the rate of inflation.
At the same time, the city is in such dire financial straits that Mr. Dinkins has said he cannot balance next year's budget without about $530 million in new aid from Albany and Washington.
Critics of City Hall have placed the blame squarely on the Mayor. "Had the Mayor managed the budget and kept spending roughly within the budget that had been agreed upon last year, the Mayor would not be sitting there with a budget deficit now," said Rudolph W. Giuliani, the likely Republican challenger. "That creeping up of the budget is really a failure of management at the highest level. The city spends whatever it can confiscate."
But Mr. Dinkins's aides say the spending increases were largely unavoidable.
Droves of new welfare recipients have gone on the rolls, lifting their numbers above 1 million, officials said. Health costs are soaring, pushed up by epidemics of AIDS and tuberculosis. Classrooms are teeming with new students. Disasters like the World Trade Center bombing and two devastating winter storms have sopped up enormous amounts of money for overtime to the police and other city workers.
And City Hall officials also note that much of the additional spending comes not from local taxes, but from state and Federal money that is given to the city for specific purposes. "It's not discretionary spending," Philip Michael, the budget director, asserted. "It's not managerial decisions. It's all case-load driven. We're like a stake holder in a way. The Federal and state money comes through our budget, but we can't do anything with it but pass it through."
 
Mandated Spending Cited
 Charles Brecher, the director of research for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private budget monitoring group, agreed that much of the fresh revenues could not have been used to close the city's budget gap because they were earmarked by the state and Federal governments for specific purposes.
But he said the portion of the new spending that came from higher-than-expected city tax receipts, about $450 million, might have been better used paying down some of the city's debt.
"Their approach is that you reduce the government if you have to and when the resources appear, you say you don't have to anymore," he said. "If you're trying to shrink the government and cut taxes, then this would not be the way to spend new resources."
Compared with the other years of the Dinkins administration, the current year's budget has grown slightly faster, said Dean M. Mead, an analyst with the commission. In 1990 and 1991, the budget rose 2 percent between adoption and year's end. In 1992, that rate grew to 3 percent. This year it is nearly 4 percent.
"Part of the answer to the puzzle is they had more money to spend, and they spent it," Mr. Mead said.
But where did all the money go?
Bernard Rosen, the first deputy budget director, said the city raised about $450 million more in municipal taxes than it had planned. Of that, $321 million went to pay for a labor settlement with city workers, spread out over all agencies.
The rest went to help offset a bevy of other unforeseen costs that totaled about $461 million. Chief among those were overtime costs of about $70 million, driven up by two blizzards, the Democratic National Convention and the World Trade Center disaster. The list of new costs also included $81.5 million for unanticipated Medicaid payments, $13.2 million for new school counselors and other staff, $85 million in additional subsidies for city-owned hospitals and nearly $50 million for teachers' wage increases.
 
Federal and State Aid
 The city also spent $700 million in additional aid from Washington and Albany that was not in the adopted budget. Of this, $178 million went toward federally mandated social programs, including community development grants, Head Start preschool programs and energy subsidies. An additional $283 million was money earmarked for special school programs. The city also received more than $60 million for job training.
"There is virtually no discretionary spending in there," Mr. Rosen said.
Critics of the administration have said the one front where Mr. Dinkins might have held the line was labor negotiations. Before settling with the largest municipal unions in January, Mr. Dinkins had insisted for many months that all wage increases should be financed through increased productivity. But in the end, the city gave workers a modest wage increase of 8.25 percent over 39 months with no concrete work-rule changes that would save money.
"He hasn't made any real fundamental changes in the way the government works," said Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, who is challenging Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic mayoral primary. "There has been no structural reform, no productivity."
Councilman Herbert E. Berman, the Finance Committee Chairman, said Mr. Dinkins has apparently decided to spend whatever new revenues he could find -- mostly on labor settlements and overtime -- instead of pruning the bureaucracy more to pay for the unanticipated costs.
"I would have cut more," he said. "There is a pervasive reluctance on the part of the bureaucracy to examine itself."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Higher Teacher Salaries Mean Better Schools

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I find it astonishing that "Higher Salaries for Teachers?" (editorial, May 10) flatly rejects the findings and recommendations of a New York State-appointed independent panel of experts that investigated the United Federation of Teachers contract impasse. Three respected, experienced arbitrators heard more than 40 hours of testimony from economists, educators and officials of New York City, the Board of Education and the teachers' union. They studied more than 200 documents on city finances, past settlements and comparable wages. 
 And yet you dismiss their conclusions on three key issues:
(1) They found that the surrounding region, and not other large cities, was the relevant labor market and the appropriate basis of comparison. You disagree.
(2) They rejected every one of the city's proposals for givebacks to finance a raise for teachers, mostly on educational grounds. You disagree.
(3) They recommended that "an appropriate payment" of state aid be used to supplement the salary package, "consistent with past practice." You disagree.
You also dismiss the evidence of research and the city's admission that teachers are the "single most important resource of any school district." To quote a recent city and Board of Education legal brief: "The quality, training and effort of these individuals determine, more than any other factor, the quality of a school's instructional program."
And the largest study of the results of educational investments (Ferguson, 1991) concludes that raising teacher salaries to attract more and better teachers is the most effective action a school district can take to improve student performance.
So, contrary to your assertion, higher teacher salaries and better schools are not separate choices; they are one and the same. Quality teachers mean quality education. And you can't attract and keep quality teachers without paying them fair salaries.
 
SANDRA FELDMAN
President
 
United Federation of Teachers
New York, May 11, 1993
