HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Duke Graduates Urged to Help Others

 BODY:
H. Keith H. Brodie, who will retire June 30 after eight years as president of Duke University, conferred degrees on 1,428 undergraduates and 1,553 graduate and professional students yesterday at the college's 141st commencement exercises. The ceremony was held at Wallace Wade Stadium on the campus in Durham, N.C.
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, delivered the main address. A Rhodes Scholar and professional basketball player before his political career, he was awarded an honorary doctor of laws degree. 
 Mr. Bradley urged the graduates to use their education to help others. "As you go out into the world with your Duke degree, only you, with your conscience and mind, can determine what you owe another human being simply because that person is a human being," the Senator said.
Duke also awarded these honorary degrees: Sylvia A. Earle, a marine botanist and biologist, doctor of science; Dr. David A. Hamburg, a psychiatrist and educator, doctor of humane letters; Juanita M. Kreps, Secretary of Commerce in the Carter Administration, doctor of laws, and William J. Raspberry, a columnist with The Washington Post, doctor of humane letters.
University of Notre Dame
The University of Notre Dame held its 148th commencement yesterday in the arena of the Joyce Athletic and Convocation Center in South Bend, Ind.
The university awarded degrees to 1,872 undergraduates and 572 graduate and professional students.
Tom Brokaw, the anchor and managing editor of "NBC Nightly News with Tom Brokaw," was the main speaker.
Mr. Brokaw told the graduates to use their education to help society. "What do you think a young Czech would do with an education comparable to yours, or a young black South African, or Chinese?" he said. "Would they clutch it to their breast, would they lie low? Or would they use it as a national resource for the common welfare?"
Notre Dame awarded honorary doctors of law degrees to Mr. Brokaw; Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania; Shirley S. Abrahamson, the first woman to sit on Wisconsin's Supreme Court; Cahal Cardinal Daly, the primate of Ireland; the Rev. Henryk Jankowski, the spiritual leader of Poland's Solidarity labor union, and Alan C. Page, the former defensive tackle for the Minnesota Vikings who now sits on that state's Supreme Court.
Morehouse College
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia was the keynote speaker last night at the 109th commencement of Morehouse College in Atlanta.
The university awarded 526 undergraduate degrees. An honorary doctor of laws degree was awarded to LeRoy T. Walker, president of the United States Olympic Committee, the first black to hold that position.
Morehouse was founded in 1867, as a private, liberal arts college for black men.

Spelman College
The talk-show host Oprah Winfrey addressed 362 graduates yesterday at Spelman College's 92d commencement exercises at the Atlanta Civic Center. Ms. Winfrey was also awarded an honorary degree.
Eugene M. Lang, the New York philanthropist, was this year's recipient of the trustees' Award for Community Service.
Spelman College, founded in 1881 as the Atlanta Baptist Seminary, is a liberal arts college for black women.
Haverford College
Haverford College awarded four honorary degrees at its 160th commencement yesterday, including one to the late Arthur Ashe. The ceremony for 300 graduates was held outdoors at the campus in Haverford, Pa.
James Wood, a friend of Mr. Ashe, accepted the honorary doctor of humane letters degree on Mr. Ashe's behalf. Mr. Wood graduated from Haverford in 1950 and is a member of the college board.
Haverford also awarded honorary degrees to Anthony G. Amsterdam, a 1957 graduate of Haverford who is a lawyer and consultant for several civil rights groups, and Nina Totenberg, the legal affairs correspondent for the National Public Radio.
Bryn Mawr College
Alice M. Rivlin, deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, gave the convocation speech yesterday at Bryn Mawr College's 108th commencement.
Ms. Rivlin, a 1952 graduate of Bryn Mawr, helped develop President Clinton's budget plan. She is a former director of the Economic Studies Program at the Brookings Institution.
The college conferred 299 undergraduate degrees and 174 graduate degrees in ceremonies yesterday under a tent on Merion Green.
Pennsylvania State U.
Pennsylvania State University awarded degrees to 7,300 graduates over the weekend at 30 ceremonies.
The ceremonies, held Friday, Saturday and yesterday at 17 campuses across the state, marked Penn State's 132d commencements.
William A. Schreyer, chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, told graduates of the Smeal College of Business Administration that their future success would hinge on their ability to win trust and hold it and that "there's only one way to that: through the personal example of integrity you set every day in your dealings with customers, fellow workers, government regulators and fellow citizens."
Other speakers included Dr. K. Jane Cutler, deputy administrator for higher education programs at the Department of Agriculture, who spoke at the College of Agricultural Sciences, and John Seffrin, executive vice president and chief executive of the American Cancer Society, who addressed the College of Health and Human Development.
Smith College
Ellen Goodman, the Pulitzer Prize winning columnist, was the keynote speaker yesterday at the 115th commencement exercises of Smith College.
The college conferred 705 bachelor and 72 graduate degrees at a ceremony held on the campus in Northampton, Mass.
Ms. Goodman, who spoke about the evolution of the women's movement, received an honorary doctor of humane letters degree.
The college also awarded these honorary degrees: Reatha Clark King, chairwoman of the American Association for Higher Education, a doctor of laws degree; Maya Lin, an architect, a doctor of fine arts degree, and Dr. Anne Gershon, a professor and doctor of pediatrics, a doctor of science degree.
Boston University
Boston University's 120th commencement exercises were held yesterday at Nickerson Field in Boston. The university conferred 2,834 undergraduate degrees and 2,440 graduate and professional degrees at the outdoor ceremonies.
The Rev. Dr. Johnny Ray Youngblood, a senior pastor at St. Paul Community Baptist Church in Brooklyn, delivered the main address to more than 15,000 guests. Dr. Youngblood received an honorary doctor of divinity degree.
The university also awarded honorary degrees to Dr. Joseph H. Hagan, president of Assumption College; Dr. C. Everett Koop, former Surgeon General, and Derek Walcott, the 1992 Nobel Laureate for Literature and a Boston University professor.
University of North Carolina
Ted Turner, chairman and president of Turner Broadcasting System, addressed 3,957 graduates of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill yesterday at the university's 191st commencement.
Mr. Turner spoke at ceremonies held outdoors in Kenan Stadium..
Honorary degrees were awarded to Katherine Dunham, performing artist; Dr. Eugen Merzbacher, Kenan professor emeritus of chemistry; Carl T. Rowan, author, and Nelson Ferebee Taylor, chancellor emeritus.
College of William and Mary
In the 300th anniversary of the founding of the College of William and Mary, 1,273 undergraduates and 572 graduates received degrees yesterday. The ceremony was held in the Walter J. Zable Stadium at the campus in Williamsburg, Va.
The comedian Bill Cosby gave the main address, and was awarded an honorary master of arts degree.
An honorary degree was also awarded to William Styron, the Pulitzer Prize winning writer and novelist.
University of Wisconsin
The University of Wisconsin at Madison conferred 5,000 degrees at graduation ceremonies over the weekend.
Seven ceremonies were held for the university's 140th commencement at the field house on campus.
Richard J. Sauer, chief executive of the National 4-H Council, addressed some of the 1,500 students receiving graduate degrees yesterday.
Harold Scheub, a professor of African languages and literature at the university, was the keynote speaker for the 3,500 undergraduates receiving degrees on Saturday.
Honorary degrees were presented on Friday to Linda H. Aiken, a nurse and sociologist; Ody J. Fish, an industrialist; Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley of Chile, and Gertrude B. Elion, who discovered drugs to treat leukemias and assist organ-transplant recipients.
Hofstra University
Hofstra University will award 1,900 undergraduate and graduate degrees in several ceremonies during the university's 106th commencement.
The first of the graduation exercises took place yesterday morning at the campus in Hempstead, L.I., for the 1,100 undergraduates.
Cynthia Gregory, a prima ballerina, was the keynote speaker and received an honorary doctor of humane letters degree.
Shari Lewis, the ventriloquist and puppeteer, addressed graduates of r the School of Education in an afternoon ceremony yesterday. Ms. Lewis received an honorary degree.
The School of Business will hold two graduation ceremonies today, and the School of Law will hold its graduation on May 24.
Adelphi University
Dr. Carolyn Reid-Wallace, Assistant Secretary of Education in the Bush Administration and an Adelphi alumna, addressed the 2,300 graduates yesterday at the 97th commencement of Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I.
Dr. Reid-Wallace told the graduates that through their college experience "you will carry with you the seeds for lifelong cultivation of the intellect." She received an honorary doctor of humane letters.
Adelphi awarded 1,000 undergraduate degrees and 1,300 graduate and professional degrees.

HEADLINE: Newborn Countries Tackle Embassy Life in Washington

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
The Croats are buying the Austrian Embassy, the Kazakhs just bought a big house and the Czechs share space with their former half, Slovakia, which is not to be confused with Slovenia, which wants to buy its own.
With 19 new countries recognized by the United States in the last 18 months, Washington is seeing the biggest explosion of new embassies here since the end of most European colonialism in Africa in the mid-1960's. 
 But the new diplomatic life is hardly all luxury and limousines.
 
Red Tape and Carpenters
 There are local zoning boards and contractors to contend with, stringent budgets from the home country and approval to be gotten from the State Department for every aspect of daily embassy life, from car registration to the location of the embassy itself. All this while getting the attention of the United States Government when arranging visits for officials from the home country, who figure that is why there is an embassy in Washington in the first place.
"It's not the diplomatic life you read about in the books, with chauffeurs and big parties," said Kresimir Cosic of the Croatian Embassy. "In this business, whenever there is a crisis everyone has to focus on solving the crisis. Of course, that puts you behind on everything, so you're permanently in crisis."
Dmitro Markov, a former journalist who is the press secretary of the Ukrainian Embassy, said that after his embassy was established in January 1992, he felt a little like the comedian Rodney Dangerfield, who complains that he gets no respect.
 
Nuclear Weapons Win Attention
 "We were sort of living in the shadow of the Russian Embassy," he said. "The Russian diplomats were involved in something, were informed of something, but we didn't get information from this or that agency."
It helps, Mr. Markov said, that people have now learned that the Ukraine has 52 million people, that it is as large as France and "that we have nuclear weapons." Ukraine is one of the few countries able to raise enough money to purchase a grand old building for an embassy, the historic Forrest-Marbury House in the Georgetown section of the city, to which it will move.
Instead of the elegant mansions, historic estates or grand buildings occupied by the embassies of Britain or Egypt on traditional Embassy Row along Massachusetts Avenue, many of the newcomers have had to settle for nondescript digs in nondescript buildings downtown.
Take Albania, for instance -- a country that is far from new, but had no diplomatic relations with Washington from 1939 until 1991. Only recently did the embassy acquire a sign to differentiate it from the many dentists' offices that occupy the bland K Street office building where it makes its home. Ambassador Roland Bimo's office has the look of a stark Dali landscape.
"It takes more time to do things than one thinks," Mr.building right now."
"We'll soon have flags, handicrafts and other decorations to show the culture of our country, but financially we just can't afford an embassy building right now."
That is nowhere near the frustration faced by Ljubica Z. Acevska, the American representative of the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia. Macedonia is recognized by 30 countries, but not by the United States. Ms. Acevska runs a one-person operation out of a room in the office of a development company, a business in which she was once a partner.
"My goal is to get the U.S. to recognize Macedonia," Ms. Acevska said. "But everywhere I turn, I hit a brick wall. I don't exist."
For those embassies that do, forget high-powered diplomatic negotiations. The lot of most of the embassy staffs is made up of the daily details of setting up shop: administrative tasks, budget and payroll questions, health insurance, arranging to pay electric bills, keeping fax machines up and running.
At almost every new embassy, many representing new countries with no existing diplomatic or governmental infrastructure, staff members handle myriad jobs under a single title.
"I, for one, am doing the press and information job, I'm the cultural attache and I do all the educational things," Mr. Markov said.
Carol Karabashian, press secretary at the Armenian Embassy, said: "We've had at least dozen visits so far. It's an amazing feat that we've been able to juggle all these different tasks with such a small staff."
Many of the new embassies are results of the convulsive breakups of the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, but Czechoslovakia's division into Slovakia and the Czech Republic was peaceful and relatively smooth, the outcome of 1992 elections.
At the former embassy of Czechoslovakia, which the two embassies now share, the split has been just as peaceful, even during the visits of both countries' Presidents for the opening of the Holocaust Museum. While the Slovaks look for a separate property, the bifurcated arrangement is evident in the announcement on the automatic answering system:
Thank you for calling the Czech Embassy. For general information, press 1; for information about the Slovak Embassy, press 2; Slovak visa and consular information, press 3; for the Czech press department, press 4, and so on.
"It's a little bit strange," said Monika Nemcokova, the press secretary at the Slovak Embassy. "Sometimes I'm talking to someone 20 minutes about travel and then it appears that they are going to Prague, not Bratislava."
Daniel Vesely, press secretary and the assistant to the Ambassador at the Czech Embassy, said he was surprised at how quickly the embassy began to function as two embassies.
"Of course, we are meeting in the corridors here, but we really started working as separate embassies one day before the division," he said.
 
Waiting for the Plumbers
 The embassies that have been able to buy buildings or houses to which they plan to move have also discovered the bane of every homeowner who has been assured of a guranteed move-in date.
The Croats, for example, who occupy a temporary office on Capitol Hill, bought the old Austrian Embassy on Massachusetts Avenue. They hoped to move in two months but have already learned the independent ways of American plumbers, painters and contractors.
"They're above any law," groused Kresimir Cosic, the Deputy Ambassador. "Whoever says two months, he's watching too many cartoon channels."
For the moment, Mr. Cosic is resigned to the sardine situation of temporary headquarters, comparing the startup to that of a Silicon Valley product.
"If Macintosh could start in a garage, we can start in temporary offices," he said. "Considering the beginning, we're doing better than Apple."
Starting an embassy when you are also starting a country is a continuous learning experience, according to several newly minted diplomats.
Nick Brown, the press attache at the British Embassy, was sympathetic to the plight of the newcomers.
"It's expensive and difficult to set up a new embassy these days," he said, noting that the British were establishing new embassies in the former republics of the Soviet Union by pooling their resources and sharing buildings with the Germans. "It isn't easy to conduct elegant diplomacy when you're crammed in one room."
Spokesmen for the new embassies were diplomatically silent on what their accommodations cost, whether they were renting or buying.
"We are the country of boundless resources, but we are paradoxically a poor country" said Mr. Markov of the Ukrainian Embassy. "It is difficult to raise sufficient money in an expensive city in an expensive country. But the Ukrainian Government believes that it is worth the investment, because we are building a country."
The political humorist P. J. O'Rourke thinks the arrival of all the new embassies is good for the local economy. "All these consonant-stans is very good for the real estate market," Mr. O'Rourke said. "And it's wonderful good news for flag makers."

HEADLINE: Medical Schools Gaining An Unexpected Popularity

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
In spite of expectations of reduced earnings for doctors and restrictions on professional autonomy under the health-care changes expected to be proposed by the Clinton Administration, people are applying to medical school in record numbers.
According to the Association of American Medical Colleges in Washington, applications for the 1993-94 school year are at an all-time high. Final tabulations of applications for next year will exceed the record of 42,621 set in 1974-75, the association says. There are now 16,500 places available. 
 Success in overhauling the health-care system will depend in large part on the cooperation of doctors. The resurgent popularity of a career in medicine augurs well for the overhaul that the Clinton Administration is expected to propose, because many applicants said they were optimistic that the good of the reforms to society would outweigh any hardships for them.
Yet the applicants also expressed reservations that if the patient-doctor relationship or professional autonomy seriously erodes, future applicants would begin to look elsewhere, sinking the popularity of medicine in a very short time.
 
Steady Increase
 Beginning with applications for the 1990-91 year, the increase has been steady, reflecting a stunning reversal of the decline in popularity of medicine as a profession among young Americans. As recently as 1988, applications to medical schools had plunged to the lowest level since 1970.
The drop was attributed to a number of factors, including fear of contracting infectious diseases like AIDS from patients.
Another factor was the discontent expressed by older doctors about the growing bureaucracy and resulting paperwork, including the requirement that they get prior approval for many diagnostic tests, surgical procedures and admission of patients to a hospital. Older doctors reportedly advised their children and other younger Americans to do anything except become doctors.
In welcoming incoming students to Washington University Medical School in St. Louis last fall, Dr. William A. Peck, the dean, asked how many of the students had talked to someone who had tried to discourage them from becoming a doctor. "Virtually all raised their hands," Dr. Peck said.
But Dr. Robert G. Petersdorf, the head of the Association of American Medical Colleges in Washington, said, "Students aren't taking the advice, they keep on coming, and at colleges the lines outside premed advisers' offices are long."
"This is a bumper year," Dr. Petersdorf added. The 16,500 places being offered this year are about the same number that have been offered since 1980, and about double those offered in the 1960's. The number of places in 1974, the second highest year for applications, was 14,576. The quality of students is also very high, based on test scores, medical school officials said.
 
Rapid Turnaround
 The average medical school applicant applies to 11 medical schools. There are 2.6 applicants for every one place, which approaches the record high ratio of 2.8 to 1 in the mid-1970's. The ratio jumps to 70 to 1 for a place at a small, selective school like the Mayo Medical School in Rochester, Minn. At the three schools with the highest number of applications -- Georgetown and George Washington Universities in Washington or Chicago Medical School -- where applications this year exceed 10,000 each, the ratio is almost as high.
Medical and educational leaders interviewed said they were puzzled by the rapid turnaround in the popularity of a medicine as a career. But the applicants themselves, as well as officials of medical schools and colleges, offered a number of explanations for the turnaround in interviews.
Medicine, they say, offers both a degree of economic security and, in viewing health as a way to help people, a chance to do good for the community. An additional attraction is the excitement of new technology, like gene therapy. And many students are optimistic that things will somehow improve for doctors, though most offer little in the way of specific predictions.
Applicants are also realistic. In a generally inhospitable job market, they see medicine as a surer way of earning an income.
"There is going to be an enormous demand for doctors in the future," said Cynthia Shoemaker, a sophomore at Wellesley College who plans to apply to medical school after returning from a year at Oxford University. "Whether there's money or not, people are still going to be sick and dying."
Many applicants have relatives and friends who have been laid off at I.B.M. and other corporations that had been seen as bastions of stability. "Interest in engineering, computer science, banking, business and law has fallen off with the end of the boom," said Dr. Gerald Foster, director of admissions at Harvard Medical School. Medicine, he added, is seen as recession-proof.
 
Diversity in Applicants
 The incoming class will probably much more closely resemble the American population in sex and ethnic background than past classes. This year about 42 percent of the applicants are women, 18 percent Asians, 8 percent blacks and 5 percent Hispanic people.
As in the past, the overwhelming majority of those entering medical school next fall will come straight from college. But officials of several medical schools said they hoped to admit a small number of students who have done something else since graduating from college.
"The student who breaks step, even for a year, is a different student, especially if they did it by choice," said Dr. D. Daniel Hunt, a dean at the University of Washington in Seattle. "You just can't get away with saying sit down and take notes, and they keep the teachers more honest than someone right out of college who tends to accept what is said."
Among those who have already been accepted in this year's pool of applicants are a National Basketball Association player, an Orange Bowl queen, nuns and other clergy, commercial airline pilots, bankers and a massage therapist who had worked with AIDS patients. Some said they have made enough money in the years since graduating from college to pursue the career in which they were most interested, medicine.
"It's ironic that as medicine is becoming more and more restricted in independence, it is becoming increasingly competitive and popular," said Dr. Barry Stimmel, a dean at Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York.
Most of those entering medical school next fall had filed their applications before Bill Clinton was elected President. The deadline for applications came before he moved into the White House and made overhauling the health-care system a major priority.
"You have to realize that most of us who are going to medical school next year made our career decision four years ago, long before this debate started," said Ruby K. Nagpal, a 22-year-old premed student at Emory University from Stone Mountain, Ga.
Sang Kim, a senior at Yale who plans to enter New York University Medical School in the fall, is among the applicants who said they were not concerned about how they will be affected by changes in the health-care system. She said she was "just hoping for the best."
At age 38, Lynne Kelley is resuming the premedical studies that she dropped as a student at Boston College, in part because she became disenchanted with students who just wanted to make a lot of money, she said. But she predicts that although applications are up, "if what Hillary Clinton is planning goes through, I think the number will drop."
Cyndi Robison, a senior at Stanford University from Idaho who plans to enter the University of Washington Medical School in Seattle, said: "I don't want to be pushed into a position where I don't have patients who come back to me. If you take the personal aspect out of it, no one is going to be happy."
Many applicants have shown a commitment to community service by having organized soup kitchens or worked in shelters for the homeless, said Dr. Sara J. Kremer, a dean at Albany Medical School. She and other officials said that many students now enrolled in medical school have organized AIDS prevention instruction programs for high school students and clinics for the indigent.
Like many doctors before them, some are seeking a medical career because of their own experiences with doctors. Derek Young, a 21-year-old student at the University of Texas at Austin, said he hoped to improve on the care he received when he had open heart surgery as a 4-year-old.
"I had trouble communicating with my pediatrician," Mr. Young said. "I want to be able to give an understanding ear to a child and make them feel like they are being heard. By helping kids I can help the future."
Among those who have rejected parental advice in applying to medical school is Scott Sidney, a 21-year-old junior at Amherst College from Des Moines. Mr. Sidney's parents, his stepmother and his grandfather are all doctors.
"I've been counseled against becoming a doctor by my family because of all the problems they already see," like the growing bureaucracy of medicine and "the loss of physicians' individual rights," Mr. Sidney said.
"Yet I can't think of a career that would be more intellectually challenging," he said.
Mr. Sidney said he expected to earn less than his doctor-parents and, by the time he is finished medical school, to owe from $60,000 to $100,000 in student loans. The annual tuition ranges from $2,230 for residents attending a state school to almost $28,000 at some private schools. The average debt after four years of medical school is $50,000, but the total can reach $150,000, medical school officials said..
When applications were at a peak in the 1970's, many of those rejected by American medical schools went to foreign ones. No one knows how many rejected applicants will go to foreign medical schools now because no one keeps track of such data, officials said.
Medical school officials are pleased with the flood of applications but find it hard to explain rejections of the many qualified individuals to disgruntled parents, alumni, influential members in the community and legislators.
Dr. Anthony P. Tartaglia, the dean of Albany Medical School, said: "With the dramatic increase in applicants, we now are rejecting younger siblings of someone who got into medical school several years ago with a worse academic record. And it's tough explaining the facts."

HEADLINE: Administration Seeks Ways to Ease Africa's Wars and Debt Burden

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, after fixing its foreign policy focus on Russia, the former Yugoslavia and Haiti, is beginning to turn its attention to Africa.
The development comes as civil rights leaders and the Congressional Black Caucus have been lobbying for a greater emphasis on the continent. Administration officials say that they are starting to look at such issues as Africa's crushing debt and the civil war in Angola, an 18-year conflict that has been as brutal as that in the Balkans and has lasted far longer. 
 "We're trying to aggressively change the perception that Africa is always the continent that is ignored," a senior Administration official said.
 
Symbolism and Substance
 Much of the Administration's activity has been more symbolic than tangible. But there have been a few concrete proposals.
During the last month, American, Portuguese, Russian and United Nations envoys have proposed a plan to end the fighting in Angola, where a civil war originally fueled by cold war rivalries and still driven by ethnic tensions has left an estimated 30,000 people dead, nearly 300,000 refugees in nearby countries and countless others displaced.
On Friday, representatives of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, the guerrilla group headed by Jonas Savimbi that has fought the Government since 1975, refused to agree to several crucial components of the peace plan, including the withdrawal of its troops from territories it recently won. The refusal by Unita could cause the peace talks to collapse, placing further pressure on the Administration to recognize the Luanda Government of Jose Eduardo dos Santos, as a number of civil rights leaders and liberals have been urging.
In elections held last September, Mr. dos Santos beat Mr. Savimbi but failed to win a clear majority, forcing a runoff between the two. Refusing to accept the results of the first round of voting, Mr. Savimbi renewed his guerrilla operations.
 
Recognition Under Review
 Administration officials say the question of recognition is under intense review. One official who asked not to be identified said a decision on recognition could occur "very soon."
The White House has also decided to ask Congress for $21 million during the next three years as Washington's contribution to a international effort on debt relief for 21 of the world's poorest countries, 18 of which are in Africa south of the Sahara. Because these countries' debts would be steeply discounted when sold on the world debt markets, the $21 million contribution would wipe $900 million worth of debt from these nations' balance sheets.
"We look forward to working with our partners to eliminate the debt overhang in low-income countries over the next several years," Lawrence E. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said recently in a speech in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
Recently, the White House tried to signal its new focus on Africa by having Anthony Lake make the continent's political, social and economic problems the focus of his first public address since assuming his job as the President's national security adviser.
And this week a number of high-level Administration officials, including Secretary of State Warren Christopher, plan to address the African-American Institute, a 40-year-old private organization that fosters closer ties between the United States and Africa. No Secretary of State has ever appeared before the group, though others have been invited in the past.
The new focus comes as civil rights advocates in and out of Congress were complaining about what they perceived as the Administration's inattention toward Africa. Two weeks ago, a delegation from the Congressional Black Caucus met with Mr. Lake to present its views on American policy regarding Angola, Zaire and African debt relief, as well as Haiti. The delegation said it hoped to meet with President Clinton himself.
"We have deferred with due respect to the fact that he has not been on the job too long," said Representative Kweisi Mfume, a Maryland Democrat and chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. "But the problems are so urgent that we feel it is high time that the Administration hears us. We expect a kind of meeting that we and the President will leave from with some kind of plan of action."
Mr. Lake has also met with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Randall Robinson, the executive director of TransAfrica, a public policy research organization that specializes in African and Caribbean issues. Both Mr. Jackson and Mr. Robinson have been vocal critics of the Administration's policies on Africa.
Mr. Robinson said that while he welcomed the speeches by Mr. Lake and Mr. Summers, he would like to see specific actions. "And we have yet to hear from Clinton himself," Mr. Robinson said.
Last Monday, Mr. Jackson wrote to Mr. Christopher urging that the Administration recognize the dos Santos Government in Angola. American envoys have used the issue of recognition as a carrot to keep Mr. dos Santos' Government at the negotiating table and a stick to prevent Mr. Savimbi from bolting.
 
'Pariah Out in the Bush'
 "There is growing domestic pressure to go forward with recognition sooner rather than later," a State Department official said. "We've tried to educate Unita, saying it's better to be a member of a government that we're going to recognize than be a pariah out in the bush."
Mr. Jackson also recommended that the White House invite President Ibrahim Babangida of Nigeria to Washington for a state visit as a signal of the Administration's support for Nigeria's move toward multi-party elections, which will be held next month.
"The failure to meet with President Babangida is viewed as a real snub and a lack of respect by the Clinton Administration of the largest country and most substantial supporter" of American policies in Africa, Mr. Jackson wrote.
The Administration has yet to develop a strategy for a number of the continent's most nettlesome problems, such as Zaire. There, President Mobutu Sese Seko, a one-time American ally whose Government has driven his country into bankruptcy, clings to power despite urgings from the United States, Belgium and France that he step down.

HEADLINE: Mexican Chief Proposes Fully Free Central Bank

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 17

 BODY:
The President of Mexico today proposed a constitutional amendment that would free the nation's central bank from his control and allow it to independently manage the money supply.
If the amendment is approved, Mexico would join Chile as the only Latin American nations with central banks that are officially protected from political interference. 
 The move, made amid growing uncertainty over the passage in the United States of the North American Free Trade Agreement, is being seen here as a way for the Government to secure investor confidence, no matter what happens to the treaty.
The amendment, some economists said, was likely to have somewhat limited effects because the Bank of Mexico, under its director, Miguel Mancera Aguayo, has moved with a degree of independence for the last several years in issuing currency, setting interest rates and supervising credit decisions.
 
President Can't Succeed Himself
 Still, a constitutional amendment would codify some of the sweeping changes put into effect by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who is prohibited by the Constitution from running for re-election when his six-year term ends next year.
Though Mr. Salinas will pick his party's candidate to succeed him, a new president could turn out to be several degrees different in style or substance from Mr. Salinas, who has been an advocate of private enterprise and industrial growth.
Economists said that the proposed amendment, especially in the absence of a trade treaty, would give investors a measure of confidence that Mexico's economy was being shielded from sharp political change.
 
A U.S. Hypothesis
 At present, the central bank's relationship with the Government is as if Lloyd Bentsen, the American Treasury Secretary, had the authority to control or dismiss Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
Adoption of the amendment requires a two-thirds vote in both houses of the Mexican Congress. Mr. Salinas's party has overwhelming control of the Senate but not quite two-thirds of the lower house, the Chamber of Deputies.
Enrique Jacob, a member of a legislative committee that will consider the amendment, said he expected the ruling party to round up the votes to adopt it this summer.
The stock market here reacted positively today to Mr. Salinas's announcement, with the Bolsa index gaining about 1.5 percent.
Independent economists in both Mexico and the United States were enthusiastic as well, saying they expected the amendment to assure a degree of independent control over inflation because the Government could not order the bank to increase the money supply.
 
Further Limits on Government
 The amendment would also lengthen and stagger the terms of the bank's board of governors, making it difficult for any president to stack the board in his favor.
Mexico has already gone a long way toward taming inflation, which fell from a 160 percent annual rate in 1987 to 11.9 percent last year, according to Government figures. Many economists think that Mexico will succeed in its goal of reducing the inflation rate to single digits.
"This would guarantee that after all Salinas's sweat and effort in bringing down inflation, it would be hard to go out of that track again," said Jorge Suarez-Velez, director of Latin American research for Nomura Research Institute America. He said, however, that a continuing trade imbalance, with imports exceeding exports, would probably prevent Mexican bonds from receiving investment-grade ratings.
Alejandro Hernandez Delgado, director of economic research at the Autonomous Technological Institute of Mexico, said it appeared that the Government was "just giving up power" and that "the flow of international investment into Mexico is important and something the Government wants to insure."
 
Budgets Coming Into Line
 Mexico has tinkered with its central bank several times since it was founded in 1925, but the Government has not previously been willing to totally give up control. One reason for that, said Jonathan E. Heath, chief economist with a private consulting concern here, is the nation's recurring high budget deficits.
But recently that has changed. Last year, Mexico showed a slight surplus, equivalent to five-tenths of 1 percent of the gross domestic product. And today, data for the first quarter of 1993 indicated a widening surplus compared to the same three months of 1992.

HEADLINE: U.S.-KOREAN TALKS SOUGHT ON A-PACT

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
American and North Korean diplomats met quietly in New York today to begin planning for high-level talks intended to resolve the dispute caused by Pyongyang's withdrawal from the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, State Department officials said.
Although the details remained to be worked out, the officials said it now appeared that North Korea would agree to take part in such talks, which the Clinton Administration regards as the most promising route toward ending the two-month-old dispute. 
 A senior Administration official said tonight that high-level talks on North Korean nuclear weapons issues "could fall into place very soon." He said the proposed session would allow the United States "to pressure the North Koreans more directly" into rejoining the accord and opening its nuclear installations to international inspectors.
But other officials said a more important purpose of the talks might be to give Pyongyang a face-saving forum. North Korea has made clear that it will not submit to pressure from the United Nations Security Council, saying the issue should be resolved between itself and the United States.
Robert Gallucci, the Assistant Secretary of State for Political-Military Affairs, would probably head an American delegation, officials said.
The meeting today between State Department officials and representatives of the North Korean mission at the United Nations was the first to be held in the United States since Pyongyang announced its withdrawal from the nuclear treaty on March 12.
Three other meetings between low-level North Korean and American diplomats have been held in Beijing. The session today was intended explicitly to plan for the higher-level talks, and State Department officials said afterward that they were waiting for a formal response from Pyongyang.
The North Korean Foreign Minister, Kim Yong Nam, today expressed willingness to join in the direct talks but threatened dire consequences if the United Nations takes new action against Pyongyang.
The Security Council is considering whether to impose economic sanctions against North Korea, whose withdrawal from the nuclear accord takes effect June 12. Mr. Kim, speaking in Jakarta, Indonesia, accused the United States of seeking to use the United Nations to "stifle and smash" his country, Reuters reported.

HEADLINE: Her Father's Daughter and Her Party's Luminary;
Molinari Finds Herself on National Stage in Republican Spotlight, on Her Own Terms

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A blur slides across Independence Avenue toward a side entrance to the Cannon House Office Building. A momentary pause and it takes shape. The Representative from Staten Island applies her warmest grin. "Hi. Remember me? Congresswoman Susan Molinari."
A smile from a startled guard, then she's gone, skipping the drill of the metal detector, swinging through her office doors, scooping up a pile of papers and heading for the phone with the look of a slightly hyper college student running late for class. 
 There are several truisms about this 35-year-old inheritor of the "Molinari machine" set in motion by her grandfather, a one-term State Assemblyman; oiled and revved by her father, Guy V. Molinari, the former Representative turned Staten Island Borough President; and now wheeled into prime time by this ebullient former cheerleader who once longed to be a journalist but now is often mentioned for a run for higher office.
She is young. She is outspoken. She is a woman. She is "pro-choice."
And she is a Republican.
Yet because she is an anomaly -- a Republican woman who backs abortion rights -- she is in danger of becoming her own worst cliche. And so she must be wary, always, of becoming just a sideshow, appealing and graced with a gift for sound bites, but not a player with influence on party politics or floor votes and perhaps even in danger of alienating some in her own constituency.
An iconoclast in a staunchly conservative district, she won re-election by only 56 percent of the vote last fall, and her approval rating can sometimes seem higher on the nightly news than in the backyards of her own district. Her father, a vocal opponent of abortion and an old-timer on the rubber bagel circuit, says friends sometimes tell him they are loyal and true blue, but cannot bring themselves to vote for his "pro-choice daughter." She is criticized in other quarters for being too much like him, an old-style politician inclined to stroke the hands that feed.
On the national stage, meanwhile, she has been thrust into the limelight by a party keen on softening an image of intolerance ossified last year at the Houston convention. Day by day she is trotted out for the television shows ("Larry King Live" and the evening news among them), courted by such senior Republicans as Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, and touted by none other than Rich Bond, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, as a candidate with only the sky -- or the White House -- as a limit.
Trying to strike a difficult balance between her personal priorities and her party's politics, she bridles at any suggestion that she is out of the mainstream. She snaps that she's no angry feminist, no liberal, no daddy's girl who inherited her father's Congressional seat through a Machiavellian plot that left him running Staten Island and her snug in his old leather chair on Capitol Hill.
She argues, instead, that she is conservative to the core, a real Republican who differs with the party on some issues only because she is part of the Pepsi generation, and wants to wake up some party elders. At every turn she deftly praises mentors like Senator Dole and picks away at President Clinton's economic package. She is fiscally conservative, she stresses, a hawk on defense and is against lifting the ban on gay men and lesbians in the military. She even has a dog named George, after George Herbert Walker Bush, a mentor.
Still, her high-pep style and atypical political profile have given her national name recognition out of proportion with her scant seniority.
She is renowned on both sides of the bipartisan divide for swimming against the Republican tide on such issues as abortion and gun control. She says, not without a quirky pride, that the National Rifle Association dubbed her "traitor" when she voted for the Brady Bill after the N.R.A. had backed her with free mailings in 1990.
 
Some Deep Divides
 There are fiercer battles within the party, ones that sometimes leave Ms. Molinari standing out, if not alone. Henry J. Hyde, a Representative from Illinois who firmly opposes abortion, last week cautioned that 1992's campaign results were "an electoral aberration" and advised the party to resist lurching toward more liberal social stands. A memo from the House Republican Study Committee expressing outrage over a proposal to allow women into combat exposed another deep divide. Steaming over the memo's tone and content, Ms. Molinari snapped: "I mean c'mon! Isn't this just a little nanny, nanny, boo, boo? I wish they would remember there are women in the party, too."
Not many. The Republican Party counts only 12 women among its 176 Representatives in the House. Ms. Molinari wants more. A bumper sticker on her desk ("50/50 by 2000") calls for even numbers of men and women in Congress by the year 2000, hardly a Republican priority.
On women's health issues she can be equally out front. "When I first got here," she said of her arrival in Congress in March 1990, "every time you'd say 'breast feeding' on the House floor there would be a snicker. I mean, this has been happening since creation. Could we finally get a grip on it?"
She can be equally passionate, though, on matters far from home. She has become a high-profile commentator on the situation in Bosnia, weighing in on the merits of air strikes and United Nations involvement. Her interest, she said, derived not from a committee assignment, but over a series of sessions with her Armenian hairdresser who filled her in on the region's troubled history. It is a weird explanation for an introduction to foreign affairs. But it is vintage Molinari, personal to the point of folksy.
 
Influential Friends
 Tanya Melich, a Republican political consultant who has worked with female candidates for years, believes Ms. Molinari combines a perfect ethnic profile (she is an East Coast Italian Catholic with traces of Irish, Czech, Australian and Chinese) blessed with perfect political pitch. "You look at her bio and, wow, that's textbook," she said. "It's really wonderful. She did the kind of things we teach women to do in training sessions. Susan's got a power base. She's got a national constituency in terms of women who identify with her. She's got a leadership role in the Republican pro-choice circles. She's got a solid base on Staten Island."
She also has some very influential friends, both in New York and beyond. One of them is the man she dates, Representative Bill Paxon of Williamsville, a Buffalo suburb, who is chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, the campaign arm for Republican House races.
She constantly and carefully nurtures contacts up and down the party line. Last year, when her father scrapped a long friendship with Mr. Bond by telling reporters that Dan Quayle was "a liability" to President Bush's run for re-election, his daughter was more circumspect. She said she had "mixed feelings" and then dropped a perfect bomb. "Whether public perception is right or wrong, it is the political reality," she said of Mr. Quayle's poor standing. Her father and Mr. Bond have not spoken since. Ms. Molinari headed for the telephone. "He called screaming," she said. "I called screaming. And after that we made up." No burnt bridges.
It is not always that easy. Her fierce support of keeping the Navy home port open on Staten Island, a constituent-pleaser that guarantees jobs and Federal financing, has aggravated some critics who wish she would broaden her view of the national interest. After a meeting on the issue last week, Thomas S. DeLuca, the former head of the Coalition for a Nuclear Free Harbor, complained that no one supporting the port closure was allowed time to speak.
 
Politics vs. People?
 A handful of elderly people who visited Ms. Molinari's Brooklyn office in Bay Ridge also went away less than satisfied. After Ms. Molinari politely refused to sign on to a health bill they backed, Shirley Genn, the executive director of the Brooklyn-wide Council of the Aging Inc. said she thought the Representative was putting politics ahead of people, just as her father might have.
"The last time I saw her there were 30 people and only one -- me -- was there representing the consumer," Ms. Genn explained. "The others all represented providers. She's extremely well-informed. She's bright, she's caring, perhaps, but when push comes to shove it is my observation that her decision will be on political grounds, not human needs."
On the subject of his successful successor, Mr. Molinari rejects everything but abject praise. "I'm pro-life," he said of his one major area of disagreement. "We've had some trouble with that. But I know that my stand politically alienates some people." On other matters, he said, the two mostly "share issues." At times, they even share office space. So close is their relationship that staff members at Ms. Molinari's office say that when her father is in town he sets himself up at his old desk while his daughter retreats to the office couch.
That casualness is one of his daughter's trademarks. Her style is so quintessentially New York, so unvarnished and unself-conscious, that when she was distracted by a ringing telephone in her Brooklyn district office recently she reacted with a Staten Islander's flair, winging it impatiently around in the air, then dropping to her knees to yank the cord from a wall socket.
 
'Has Always Been Different'
 "She seems to have lost the caution gene somehow," Ms. Gorlin said. "She still thinks that it's sort of fun to be in Congress. But at a certain level it's not fun and I'm not sure she knows what that's all about."
Until she does, she rocks through Washington, complaining that the capital is not a real city since it has "no ugly people, no fat people, no old people and no dogs."
Mr. Bond, a New Yorker himself, loves that bluntness. "She has always been different," he said of her days at the Republican National Committee's political division as a recent graduate of State University of New York at Albany.
"From the start," Mr. Bond said, "she wasn't this demure Laura Ashley Washington type. She used to wear black high-top Converse sneakers and there was a certain degree of derisiveness about that down here in La La Land."
 
Raised on Politics
 But she has stuck by her ways. She was the first woman ever to wear pants on the House floor, a scandal at the time. And she still gives her mother heartburn when she bolts off to a nationally televised debate wearing sneakers. Her former administrative aide, Dan Leonard, now the director of communications at the National Republican Congressional Committee, said he was shocked recently when he saw her carrying a purse (usually she just packs her wallet).
That spiritedness perhaps comes from having politics on the brain and in the bloodstream. In the Molinari household of the 1960's, the Molinaris and their only child held weekly elections for house president, her father recalled. Later she would apply those talents in the New York City Council, a "boring" post she held for five years before taking over her father's abandoned seat in Congress.
In recent months Mr. Molinari has weighed a run for governor. But if his daughter wanted to run, he said, he would defer. "There are things about her that would make her the better candidate," he said. "She is younger, she is a woman, she's pro-choice."
That's the rub. Only a run for wider office could answer one question: whether the Republicans really see her as the torchbearer for the next generation, or if they just applaud because, for now, she provides what many Republican strategists say the party so badly needs, an antidote to the toxins of last summer.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 6.92 in Subdued Trading

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market was largely subdued yesterday after two straight days of decline and closed modestly higher.
Traders may be holding back, waiting to glean how the Federal Reserve Board would react today to last week's discouraging inflation reports. A cut in interest rates before the summer seems out of the question now, so many traders would be relieved if the Fed simply did nothing. A rise in rates would rattle already-nervous traders. 
 Yesterday, computerized buy programs probably accounted for much of the market's gain, rather than investor sentiment.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 6.92 points, to 3,449.93, while the Standard & Poor's 500 was up 0.81 point, to 440.37. Most other indexes were also higher.
The big exception, however, was the Dow Jones transportation average, which lost 15.91 points, to 1,567.66.
 
Twists in Economic Outlook
 The transportation average is made up of airline, railroad and trucking companies. Its prices have vaulted or fallen with every new twist in the economic outlook and hence the prospects for carrying goods and people. The Dow transports have been in a downward trend since April 16, when they hit a record 1,683.08.
Yesterday, the transportation average was dragged down by several stocks that declined 1 point or more. The leading transport decliner was Xtra, a trucking company, down 4 1/8 points, to 80 1/4, on no discernible news. Another trucking company, Consolidated Freightways, fell 1, to 17.
Among the airlines, meanwhile, AMR, the parent of American Airlines, lost 1 1/2, to 70, while UAL, the parent of United, slipped 1 3/4, to 138 1/2.
Investors did not appear to be trying too strenuously to recover yesterday from the broad retreat of 34 points in the Dow Jones industrial average Thursday and Friday's decline of nearly 5 points.
Trading was light until noon on the New York Stock Exchange when there was a large run-up in volume to a relatively heavy 227.6 million shares, compared with Friday's volume of 252.9 million shares and Thursday's volume of 293.9 million shares.
No individual stocks or groups seemed to dominate trading, although Royal Dutch Petroleum again showed enormous volume at 17.4 million shares, but far lower than Friday's volume of nearly 45 million shares. It was the most-active stock on any exchange.
Royal Dutch, which owns 60 percent of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, closed down yesterday 1/8 point, to 90 1/2, following news that Shell had repaired a Louisiana refinery and was planning to reopen it.
If that was not the news accounting for Royal Dutch's drop, the shares may also be changing hands as part of last week's dividend play. Big investors, depending on their tax profile, can either buy or sell stocks with hefty dividends like that of Royal Dutch to minimize their tax bills. The company also reported surprisingly strong quarterly earnings.
Time Warner yesterday announced a major venture with U S West, a large local-telephone company, which agreed to invest $2.5 billion in Time Warner's operations. Time Warner's stock closed up 1 1/2 point, to 35, on unusually heavy volume of 5.95 million shares. It was the second-most active stock on the Big Board.
U S West dropped 1/2 point, to 40 5/8, on volume of only 1 million shares. U S West said the deal would dilute earnings.
Among the other market indicators, the New York Stock Exchange composite index was up 0.24 point, to 243.58, while the Nasdaq composite index, made up of smaller capitalization and high-technology stocks, closed up 1.59 point, to 677.96. The American Stock Exchange market value index closed unchanged at 427.46.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
GPA Directors Support $50 Million in Payments

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: LONDON, May 17

 BODY:
GPA Group P.L.C. said today that its directors had voted to make $50 million of interest payments due today and a principal payment due Tuesday to bondholders, saving the group from examinership and clearing the way for the GE Capital Corporation's acquisition plan to proceed.
GPA's board members have been meeting at the investment bank Schroders P.L.C. here. If the company had defaulted, the world's largest aircraft leasing group would have gone into examinership, Ireland's equivalent of Chapter 11 in the United States. 
 The announcement clears the way for GE Capital to acquire 45 aircraft from GPA for $1.35 billion and buy 60 percent to 80 percent of the group over the next four years. The deal's advancement depended on the bondholders' payment being made.
GPA has $3.5 billion of secured bank debt and $2.5 billion of unsecured debt to bondholders. Through June 30, GPA must make a total $300 million of interest and principal payments to bondholders.
 
Bridge Loans for the Company
 GPA said some of its bankers and shareholders had indicated in writing that they would provide bridge loans to the company. The amount was not disclosed.
GPA also said it had received "assurances" from some banks on restructuring the company's bank debt, including deferral of 1993 and 1994 amortization payments. That hinges on completion of the GE Capital transaction and GPA's receiving a loan from shareholders, the company said.
A proposed timetable for the transactions, including shareholder approval, will be announced when agreed upon, GPA said.
The board's decision buys GPA time but does not guarantee the company will survive over the long term, said Jack Hersch, an analyst at M. J. Whitman, a trader of distressed bank debt and securities.
In a presentation to bondholders on Friday, GPA said the GE Capital transaction and restructuring of bank debt were expected to provide enough cash "to pay all unsecured debt obligations for the next 18 months," according to a filing with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission.
GPA directors apparently believe that the GE deal will close, Mr. Hersch said. "They agree that 18 months is enough time for the company to get back on its feet," he said.
Mr. Hersch says, however, that it is "quite a bet," given that interest rates are rising on concern about inflation today and that the aircraft market remains in a slump.
The Boeing Company, the Seattle aircraft maker, has already lent GPA $569 million, according to the S.E.C. filing. "The move by the banks and Boeing emanates from their concern about allowing this company to go into examinership," Mr. Hersch said. "There's a perception that examinership could lead to a meltdown that would put 460 GPA airplanes up for sale."
"The board's decision today is a window into whether the GE deal will go through," Mr. Hersch said. GPA bonds jumped earlier this afternoon on speculation that the company had decided to make the imminent bond payments. GPA Delaware Inc. 8.75 percent bonds due 1998 were quoted at 58 cents on the dollar, up from 54 cents at the opening of trading, according to traders at Mabon Securities in New York.
GE officials were unavailable for comment.

HEADLINE: States Turn Entrepreneurial To Augment Tourism Funds

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFORT, Ky.

 BODY:
It may not be as catchy as "Virginia Is for Lovers" or as imitable as "I <heart> New York." But in a quest for higher name recognition and tourist dollars, Kentucky recently licensed its new logo -- a stylized horse incorporated in the word "Kentucky," followed by the tagline "What you've been looking for."
As a result, a line of T-shirts, sweatshirts, golf shirts and caps bearing the logo is being shipped to gift shops in most of Kentucky's state parks. If the merchandise proves popular, it will also be sold in retail stores throughout the state. 
 "We don't know how much money it will bring, but it will give us exposure," said Bob Stewart, the Commissioner of the Kentucky Department of Travel Development. "And it's another example of how tourist agencies in most states are adopting the profit motive and forging partnerships with the private sector."
 
Shrinking Budgets
 Many public-private alliances result from desperation on the part of the states, whose tourism-advertising budgets have been slashed as much as 80 percent in recent years. Sixteen states plan to trim tourist budgets this fiscal year, according to the Washington-based United States Travel Data Center, and ad budgets for all states will decrease an average of 5.3 percent from last year. At the same time, the initial trickle of public-private partnerships has become a veritable flood.
While some tourism officials caution against embracing the private sector too tightly, or without having a coherent long-range strategy, the majority of officials see the alliances as a way out of budgetary straitjackets.
"A lot of state tourist directors came out of the private sector," said Carl Wilgus, Idaho's administrator of tourism, "and they're used to trying to leverage their marketing punch."
Virginia, seeking to make its 10 welcome centers self-sustaining, charges hotels, restaurants and attractions $25 to $55 to distribute their brochures in each center, and charges $650 for them to advertise on the centers' overhead displays. In addition, it charges owners of bed-and-breakfast lodgings a 10 percent commission for making reservations; that income partly pays for the state's office in Washington.
 
Remembering a Trail
 Corporate sponsors are picking up much of the tab for the yearlong Oregon Trail celebration, to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the 2,000-mile wagon train route from Missouri to the Oregon Territory.
The six New England states joined with Harrods department store in London last Christmas to promote tourism to their region, which already receives 250,000 British tourists a year. The Nashville airport, and the Memphis and Nashville convention and visitors bureaus have joined with the privately owned Opryland Hotel in Nashville and Graceland, Elvis Presley's home in Memphis, to attract tourists from Britain.
Florida's special-events calendar is underwritten by Holiday Inns, and the state's guides for Japanese, Spanish, French and German visitors are underwritten by Coca-Cola. An Arkansas program to encourage Arkansans to vacation in their home state is also getting financial support from Coca-Cola.
 
Getting Others to Pay
 The State of Washington saved thousands of dollars last year by privatizing its annual tourism conference. Local visitors and convention bureaus organized it and allowed private businesses to attend for a fee. Washington expects to save up to $50,000 this year by letting the hotel and motel association produce its statewide lodging and attractions guide, supported by advertising.
At least a dozen states have recently begun accepting advertising in their tourist publications. Tennessee, for example, did so partly because its state ad budget was cut $1.5 million in the current fiscal year. And New Jersey has saved $850,000 in each of the last two years by having its three major tourist guides published by private magazines that sell ads for them.
Pennsylvania has also realized substantial savings.
"Three years ago we were spending about $1 million a year on our visitor's guide," said Ron Jury, a spokesman with the Pennsylvania Department of Commerce. "When we began accepting advertising, private industry contributed about $500,000 the first year. The second year, industry paid more than $700,000, and we increased the size from 192 pages to 232. We hope we get to the point where the guide is self-sustaining."
 
Making Pitches Abroad
 Eager to lure international visitors, many states put together discounted tour packages for foreigners with airlines, hotels and rental car companies.
Tennessee, North Carolina, West Virginia and Kentucky jointly developed discount packages sold through German travel agencies, promoting Appalachia to German tourists. Rhode Island and Pennsylvania are also partners with private operators in offering tours to Germans.
Rhode Island has also developed tours for Canadian visitors in conjunction with Collette Travel Service and Conway's Bus Service. California has lured Canadian tourists with discount packages put together with Air Canada and Canadian Airlines International, while Oregon has lured Canadians with promotions through Horizon Air, a regional carrier.
Oregon has also recruited Nike, Bank of America, Delta Air Lines and Columbia Sportswear to serve as party hosts for events like the Tournament of the Americas, a qualifying event for the Olympic Games, and for groups of travel agents or Hollywood scouts looking for movie locations.
"Every promotion we've been involved in during the last two years has had some private-sector involvement," said Susan Bladholm of the Oregon Tourism Division.
 
Measuring the Payback
 Although tourism officials say they understand that they could not escape the budgetary cutbacks that have befallen many other state agencies, they also say that deep cuts are self-defeating, pointing to independent studies that show that states receive an average of $9 in tourist spending for every dollar spent on tourist advertising. In Alabama, the ratio is $25 to $1.
Nevertheless, Kentucky's advertising and marketing budget for tourism was cut from $2.5 million last year to $1.6 million this year, even though tourism is the state's second-largest industry (with a $5.3 billion impact) and third-largest employer (133,000 people).
Thus, in addition to licensing its logo, for which it will receive 70 percent of the profits, Kentucky is trying to get private-sector money to encourage greater tourism. For example, it is linking up with Toyota and Ford, both of which manufacture vehicles in the state.
Toyota put photos and videos of Kentucky in many showrooms in Japan, and customers who bought the Scepter wagon received a basket of Kentucky handcrafts, as well as a "Made in Kentucky" license plate. Ford is promoting Kentucky in a sweepstakes contest, with the prize being an Explorer built in Louisville. The state, which is co-sponsoring the sweepstakes, is featured in the Ford television advertising, and the tourist bureau plans to send each contestant its guide to Kentucky outdoors
In New York State, where tourism is the second-largest industry ($19.2 billion) and accounts for 10 percent of all private-sector jobs, the advertising budget -- $15 million as recently as 1988 -- was slashed to $3 million in both 1991 and 1992. The 1993 advertising budget was doubled to $6 million.
 
Wooing Germans
 New York State and Delta recently forged a partnership designating Delta the official "I <heart> New York" airline from Germany. Each partner will invest about $250,000 in joint promotions in international publications, tourist brochures, trade-show exhibits and tours of New York for foreign travel agents and tour operators. The state has a similar tie-in with Alitalia, the Italian carrier, and is negotiating one with Japan Airlines.
Reflecting the dominant view of public-private partnerships, Richard Trammel, the head of tourism in North Carolina, said, "In today's climate any revenue that helps tourism and promotion is likely to be good revenue."
Nevertheless, some state officials caution that outside funds are no substitute for a state budget that is not pared at every sign of economic downturn.
New York officials, for example, note that the "I <heart> New York" logo has earned only slightly more than $100,000 a year since it was licensed in the United States two years ago.
"That will grow, but there was an expectation that the logo was like California raisins, and would generate millions of dollars, " said Steve Morello, deputy commissioner of advertising and marketing for the New York State Department of Economic Development. "But that's not the nature of licensing, although it is a way to raise extra cash."
 
A Note of Caution
 John Savich, tourism director for the State of Washington, probably has more reservations than most of his counterparts, warning that such relationships can be seductive -- or, as he put it, like buying things on sale that you don't need.
"Just because it's a good deal financially, it's important to remember that public agencies have public-policy objectives," he said. It is also important, he added, not to let the tourist literature be dominated by advertisers in one part of the state.
"I don't think I'd want to sell advertising for our seasonal guide," he said, "because we want every page of it full of activities and maps that will generate the most off-season travel, not the most ad dollars. Tourism can't just be about more. It has to be about when and where."
Lisa Shivers, director of the Alabama Bureau of Tourism and Travel, pointed out another problem: "When you explain to your legislature that you can keep costs down for your tourist publications by accepting ads, they say, 'Great, we can cut your budget by that much.' "

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Speculation Interest Rates Will Increase

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against other major currencies yesterday amid speculation that United States interest rates soon might head higher.
Gold prices finished mixed after surging last week on inflation concerns. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery shed 20 cents a troy ounce, to $367.50. The Republic National Bank quoted a late gold bid of $366.50 an ounce, down 80 cents. 
 Currency dealers said the dollar traded near the top of its recent range and ended the New York session well above its opening levels. There were no market-moving developments but a perception that interest rates might move higher at least in the near term provided some incentive to buy dollars, dealers said.
Higher United States rates would enhance returns on dollar-denominated investments.
 
Wait-and-See Attitude
 But the buying was restrained in part because financial markets were not convinced that rates would make a decisive upward move.
Forecasters believe Federal Reserve policy makers will take a wait-and-see approach when they meet in a closed session today. Worries about inflationary pressures building in the economy will be weighed against signs of sluggish growth, analysts said.
Traders were cautiously awaiting the outcome of Danish voting on a treaty on closer European union. The treaty was already rejected once by Danish voters and today's referendum could decide the course of the European Community's progress toward creating a tighter political and economic bloc.
Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Mitsubishi Bank, said it was widely expected that the Danes would endorse the treaty. But an unexpected "no" vote could unsettle financial markets.
The dollar moved lower against the Japanese yen in Tokyo trading. It closed in Japan at 110.77 yen, down 0.88 yen from Friday's close. But later in London, the dollar was quoted at 111.40 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar stood at 111.30 yen, up from 110.80 yen on Friday.
The British pound fell to $1.5320, from $1.5387 late Friday. Sterling also declined in New York dealing where the pound fetched $1.5360 at 4 P.M. compared with $1.5385 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
North America's History, One Person at a Time

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Wilderness at Dawn
The Settling of the North American Continent
By Ted Morgan
Illustrated. 541 pages. Simon & Schuster.
$27.50. 
 In his latest book, the writer Ted Morgan turns from the biography of an individual (Winston Churchill, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Somerset Maugham, William S. Burroughs) to the biography of a continent. His subject in this sprawling, peripatetic volume is the settling of North America, from the advent here of early man, who strolled over the Bering land bridge from Asia around 40,000 B.C., through the 17th-century European colonization of the eastern shore and the post-Revolutionary War conquest of the Middle West. A second volume chronicling the settlement of the remainder of the United States and Canada is in the works.
In his autobiography, "Rowing Toward Eden" (1981), Mr. Morgan described his episodic sense of the past: "We have shafts of memory between dark spaces," he wrote, "so that life remembered takes on the features of an archipelago, mostly submerged, with points of land rising above the sea's surface." A similar eagerness to dwell on isolated moments in time informs "Wilderness at Dawn." Though the major events of early American history, familiar to the reader from high school textbooks, are glancingly recounted here, the focus is narrow, not wide-angled. It is through the reminiscences of individual and often little-known explorers, settlers, slaves and entrepreneurs that Mr. Morgan recounts the bulk of his story.
That story somewhat unnecessarily begins, much like a parody of a Michener novel, with the presence of dinosaurs and three-toed horses on the North American continent, followed in due course by the first humans. These earliest settlers left Central Asia, Mongolia and northern China and eventually became the ancestors of the North American Indians, as well as the Mayas, the Aztecs and Incas.
From here, Mr. Morgan moves on to the famous voyages and explorations of Columbus, Vespucci, de Leon, Magellan, Cartier, de Soto and Coronado. These accounts, well-written but highly compressed orchestrations of incredibly familiar material, are followed by equally familiar accounts of the Jamestown settlement in Virginia, the Pilgrims' arrival at Plymouth, Mass., the landing of the Dutch in New York Harbor and the so-called great migration, which saw the arrival on American shores of thousands of English settlers fleeing economic depression, unemployment and religious persecution.
As Mr. Morgan chronicles the gradual westward expansion of the European settlements, his narrative grows dense with colorful anecdotes detailing the texture of daily life in the New World. The reader hears frontier stories about a captive Indian woman being "ordered to be torn to pieces by dogs" and about four Indian boys being sent to Harvard College. Smallpox epidemics, violent confrontations with Indians and harrowing encounters with frostbite and starvation are all recounted through the eyes of individual witnesses.
The reader meets people like John Gyles, the son of a strict Puritan, who spent six years as an Indian captive and who eventually returned to Boston, thankful he had seen, in Mr. Morgan's words, "much of the goodness of God at an early age." There is William Byrd, one of Virginia's richest men at the end of the 17th century, who left a detailed journal of his sexual and culinary appetites; Eliza Lucas, a frontier woman who pioneered the cultivation of indigo as a cash crop, and Jacob Weber, a Swiss immigrant who founded a short-lived sect in which he set himself up as God (and his two chief disciples as the Son and the Holy Ghost).
The large, momentous events that shaped the fate of America -- the French and Indian War, the Stamp Act, the defeat of the British at Saratoga -- happen, for the most part, offstage or in the background, as Mr. Morgan increasingly focuses on smaller everyday struggles. He gives the reader an often intimate sense of what daily life was like in both the increasingly genteel part of the country that had established law and government institutions and the rough-and-ready frontier, where outlaws and Indians continued to pose a daily threat.
In keeping with recent efforts to create more balanced, multicultural accounts of America's history, Mr. Morgan makes every effort to present the point of view of Indians, blacks and women. The reader finishes the book with a poignant sense of some of the terrible costs incurred in the establishment of this nation and a solid appreciation of the ways in which Indians and slaves were frequently used as pawns in the struggles between the European powers (France, Britain and Spain) and later between the Colonies and Britain.
Filled with vivid incidents and written in hearty, nimble prose, Mr. Morgan's chronicle makes for highly compelling reading. What the book most noticeably lacks is a point of view that might lend the narrative's copious details a sense of historical direction. Although some tired and cursory references are made to Frederick Jackson Turner's famous frontier thesis (the argument that the American sensibility was definitively shaped by the possibilities afforded by seemingly limitless land), Mr. Morgan never amplifies these observations. Nor does he bring a fresh perspective to his material that might pull his random observations into a coherent thesis. As a result "Wilderness at Dawn" remains more of a readable collection of absorbing anecdotes than an original work of historical interpretation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ted Morgan (Julie Thayer/Simon & Schuster)
