HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Continue Decline

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Inflation fears continued to drive Treasury prices lower yesterday, and the yield on the 30-year bond inched closer to 7 percent. As a result, more and more traders and investors were talking about the end of the bond market rally of 1993.
Short-term interest rates, meanwhile, moved sharply higher as investors wondered whether the Federal Reserve would push up rates to curb any increase in inflation. The Fed's monetary policy committee -- the Federal Open Market Committee -- is to meet in Washington today to set that policy for the next six weeks. 
 While the Fed is not expected to increase short-term interest rates at this meeting, the discussion is likely to focus on inflation. As such, more analysts seem to expect that the Fed will have to raise interest rates before the end of the year.
 
 
'A Sea Change in Sentiment'
 "It is a sea change in sentiment that they are even asking that question," said Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities. He said he had been trying to persuade customers and traders that the Fed would not decide to raise interest rates at today's meeting.
Lawrence A. Kudlow, the chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, argues that the recent rise in the price of gold, which has surged more than $25 an ounce over the last two weeks, is a sign that investors think the Federal Reserve is being too easy with monetary policy. He also said that if the Federal Reserve did not act soon to raise interest rates, "they risk a takeoff in speculation in gold."
Mr. Kudlow does not watch the popular measures of the nation's money supply, which have been surprisingly weak this year. He thinks they are distorted by the fact that investors have been taking their money out of banks and putting it in mutual funds. His concern is the broader monetary base and the Fed's purchases of Treasury bills and notes, which he says are growing much too fast.
 
 
Mild Inflation Expected
 "There is a big shift in expectations," he said, after the surprisingly large jumps in the producer and consumer price indexes for April, which were reported last week. "Interest rate expectations are now changing from lower interest rates to higher rates," he added. "Inflation expectations are changing from deflation to at least mild inflation."
In trading in the secondary market, the price of the 7.25 percent bond that matures in February 2023 was off 8/32 as the yield rose to 6.96 percent, up from 6.94 percent on Friday. This is the highest yield on the long bond since early April. And since last week's inflation reports, the yield has jumped from 6.81 percent, or 15 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
 
Rise in Short-Term Rates
 The rise on short-term interest rates has been just as striking. At the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rate on the three-month bill was 3 percent, up from 2.89 percent a week earlier. The average discount rate on the six-month bill was 3.10 percent, up from 2.99 percent a week earlier.
The interest rates on bills are also rising because the size of the weekly auctions has grown. In the beginning of the second quarter, the size of the bill auctions was cut because the income tax revenue that was coming in cut the Government's borrowing needs temporarily.
As a result of the cutbacks in the bill auctions, as well as the belief at that time that the Federal Reserve might push interest rates even lower to maintain economic growth, the discount rate on the three-month bill had dropped to 2.77 percent, while the rate on the six-month bill had fallen to 2.90 percent.
 
Samurai Bonds
 New York City will be pricing $917 million of bonds today or tomorrow, including $205 million of bonds denominated in yen. The so-called Samurai bonds are another example of how governments are trying to lower their borrowing costs by inventing new types of bond and derivative products or by trying to find a new market for their bonds.
The sale of the Samurai bonds has been planned since the beginning of the year, when City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman traveled to Japan to test the market there and to promote the city's securities.
The New York sale will be the largest part of what is expected to be about $3 billion of new tax-exempt issues to be sold today. How prices hold up against this onslaught of supply will be a good test of the allure of tax-exempt issues, which analysts say have yet to rally as much as they should, considering that an increase in tax rates is expected to be approved this year as part of President Clinton's deficit reduction plan and economic program. Prices in the municipal market were little changed yesterday.
Following are the results of the Treasury auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday:

HEADLINE: Clinton Stumps For His Program In '92-Like Blitz

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, May 17

 BODY:
Rock music blared from loudspeakers on stage in New Mexico. The audience was packed with the mandatory shrieking school children who were bused in from all over the state. The visiting politician toured a local point of interest and pronounced himself awed by machines that made good props for his message of the day.
The feel of a campaign rally was in the air today, possibly more than at any other event since President Clinton took office, as he visited a high school in Los Alamos, N.M., to promote his economic program and toured the laboratory where the atomic bomb was made -- and where the machines of war are now being used for peaceful purposes. 
 Then he arrived here, recalling last year's campaign to a crowd of more than 1,000 supporters at the airport. "We will not stop," he declared, "until we've turned this state around."
Mr. Clinton plugged his plan for the economy at his final stop in San Diego, his second prime-time town meeting since taking office. Asked what happened to his promised middle-class tax cut, the President said, "Give me four years to try to deliver on the middle-class tax cut."
As he hit the road for the second time in a week, the President even made one of those small mistakes that plague candidates as they stump from town to town. He drew teasing jeers from the audience in New Mexico when he called the city "Los Angeles."
 
Defining His Presidency
 As he seeks to regain control of the public presentation of his Presidency and his programs, Mr. Clinton turned back to the sort of events that defined his candidacy: the made-for-the-cameras tour of a high-tech plant, the raucous outdoor rally and the televised town meeting tonight in San Diego. On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton is to tour South-Central Los Angeles, an area he last visited on the heels of the riots that broke out there last year.
It would have been impossible to mask the political nature of this week's schedule; the President is expected to travel this weekend to New Hampshire, the site of the first Presidential primary, to deliver a commencement address at the New Hampshire Technical College.
But White House aides made no attempt to disguise the notion that politics was driving the trip out West. More than any other state, perhaps, California is the one Mr. Clinton cannot neglect if he is to be re-elected in 1996.
The events, the first half of a two-day Western swing, left little opportunity for the President to stray from a carefully scripted effort to promote his economic program and to avoid questions about Bosnia, the fate of his long-awaited health-care program, fights with Congress and other political battles that he has confronted lately. At the town meeting here tonight, Mr. Clinton was spared questions on those issues; he was asked mostly about how he would try to turn around the economy.
After touring Los Alamos National Laboratory -- he seemed particularly intrigued by a model of a car that runs on fuel cells -- Mr. Clinton sought to highlight the importance of military conversion in developing a postwar economy in a speech at Los Alamos High School.
"We must change our priorities, no matter how difficult it is," he declared to a flag-waving crowd of 10,000 gathered in the school's football field. "That is the challenge of this day, and we must meet it."
The only twist from a typical campaign event was the bipartisanship: Perhaps having learned a lesson from the Republicans' scuttling of his economic stimulus plan in the Senate, the President took Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, along with him on Air Force One for the flight from Washington to Albuquerque.
Mr. Domenici and the state's junior Senator, Jeff Bingaman, a Democrat who also flew in with Mr. Clinton, stood on the stage with the President at the high school. Senator Domenici expressed his gratitude for the time he got with Mr. Clinton. "I want to thank you for the most pleasant ride home I've ever had," he said as the crowd roared.
 
'Gliding Over Our Differences'
 When he took his turn on the podium, the President put in a good word for the Republican. "I thought Senator Domenici did a pretty good job of gliding over our differences and getting it right in there," he said with a laugh.
Citing the 50th anniversary of Los Alamos National Laboratory, which is situated on 43 square miles of mesas and canyons about 35 miles northwest of Santa Fe, Mr. Clinton said, "When we needed the muscle to win the cold war, the long and costly effort to contain and then to triumph over Communism, the ideas that made that possible came out of these laboratories."
He then told how Los Alamos laboratory, which is managed by the University of California for the Department of Energy, is retooling for civilian high-tech uses. It has an annual budget estimated at $1 billion and about 7,500 employees. Federal officials have said that 300 to 400 of those jobs will be cut in the next year, many through early retirement.
It is time, Mr. Clinton said, for research and development installations to follow the lead of Los Alamos and explore new technologies.
 
It's the Economy. Period.
 As did a handful of other speakers, Mr. Clinton mentioned that "President Kennedy stood in this very spot just over 30 years ago and saluted the great patriots of Los Alamos."
At every stop, White House officials said, the aim was to convince the public that the budget deficit is a big problem -- and one that Mr. Clinton inherited.
Asked if the President would veer from his economic message, one White House official replied incredulously, "Not if my life depends on it -- this is purely straight up on the economy."
The cheering partisans in New Mexico seemed to follow along with the White House script. Several people said in interviews that they were as excited about Mr. Clinton as they were during the campaign.
"He's a real fine fellow," said Travis Wood, a retired postal worker from Roy, N.M., who put his age at "past 80." "I think he ought to have a little more cooperation from the other side of the aisle."

HEADLINE: Leading Conservative Democrat Criticizes Clinton

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17

 BODY:
Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, one of President Clinton's earliest supporters and a leading conservative Democrat, accused Mr. Clinton today of betraying the spirit of his Presidential campaign and governing like a traditional liberal.
Mr. McCurdy warned in a series of interviews that a growing number of Democratic members of the House had told him that they opposed Mr. Clinton's proposed tax increases, a movement that Mr. McCurdy suggested could torpedo the Administration's economic package. 
 Moderate and conservative Democrats, the Congressman said, "are shaking their heads that the deficit at the end of the Clinton Administration -- after the largest tax increase in history -- will be as large as during the Bush Administration. The soulmates are feeling left out."
Mr. McCurdy's disappointment with the Administration has recently been expressed by other lawmakers, but not for publication. One member of the Democratic House leadership said last week, "At this point, we don't have the votes" to pass Mr. Clinton's package of taxes and spending cuts.
Mr. McCurdy and two other Democratic lawmakers, Timothy J. Penny of Minnesota and Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, are threatening to oppose the package unless party leaders let them offer amendments adding over $50 billion in budget cuts and capping the growth of benefit programs like Medicare and Social Security.
 
Evidence of Erosion
 Nevertheless, most Congressional strategists say that when push comes to shove, the Republicans will fall short of winning over the 40 or so Democrats they would need to defeat Mr. Clinton's economic program. The more serious challenge is expected in the Senate.
Even if Mr. McCurdy's public display of frustration is not a sign that the Administration is heading for a major defeat in the House, it is evidence that Mr. Clinton's original base of Democratic conservatives and moderates may be eroding. The extent of Mr. McCurdy's discontent may become more apparent on Tuesday when Howard Paster, the chief White House lobbyist, meets with the Mainstream Forum, a group of 50 moderate and conservative House Democrats that Mr. McCurdy heads.
The meeting was organized after members of the group complained that they were not receiving a sufficient hearing from the White House.
"Much of the President's appeal during the campaign was campaigning as a new Democrat," Mr. McCurdy said. "The rhetoric has been new, but the programs have been old."
The Congressman expressed particular disenchantment with the proposed energy tax, noting a University of Oklahoma study predicting it would cost his oil-producing state 11,000 jobs.
 
Longtime Clinton Supporter
 Mr. McCurdy, like Mr. Clinton, has long been active in the Democratic Leadership Council, a group designed to move the party to the center. He endorsed Mr. Clinton's Presidential candidacy long before the New Hampshire primary and served as an important adviser during the campaign.
The lawmaker said he had had several frank conversations with both the President and his wife, Hillary, in recent months, in which he criticized the Administration for its tax program and its failure to consult with moderate Democratic lawmakers on social issues like the proposal to let foreign AIDS patients enter the United States.
Mr. McCurdy has a history of criticizing senior members of his party, for which Speaker Foley punished him late last year by refusing to reappoint him as chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence. Mr. McCurdy initially earned Mr. Foley's ire by denouncing to other lawmakers the Speaker's performance during the House bank scandal. He then privately asked senior military officers to lobby for his appointment as Secretary of Defense; naming him rather than Les Aspin, Mr. McCurdy argued, would prevent Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a liberal from California, from succeeding Mr. Aspin as chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

HEADLINE: Henry Arthur, 89, Harvard Professor Of Business Ethics

 BODY:
Henry Bradford Arthur, professor emeritus at the Harvard Business School and an expert on agribusiness and business ethics, died on Sunday at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 89.
He had been ill for a long time, the business school said yesterday. 
 Professor Arthur joined the Harvard faculty at age 56 after a career as an economist in industry and government. He joined Harvard in 1960 as its first George M. Moffett Professor of Agriculture and Business. Until his retirement in 1970, he developed courses on agribusiness management and created doctoral and executive-education programs.
In recognition of his work, the business school established a Henry B. Arthur Fund for Business Ethics to support research and teaching in ethics and corporate responsibility.
A native of Gloversville, N.Y., he graduated from Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., where he majored in mathematics and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. After receiving his master's and Ph.D. degrees at Harvard, he started a career at Swift & Company, the food processor, and became its chief economist in 1939.
He took leave from the company to hold Federal positions. In the late 1940's, he was chief of the Marshall Plan's program review division in Paris, and he was appointed to the Wage Stabilization Board during the Korean War.
Professor Arthur's first wife, the former Charlotte Beals, died in 1980. He is survived by his second wife, Eunice P. Howe; a daughter, Janice Arthur McCoy of Pacific Palisades, Calif.; a son, Bradford, of San Francisco; a brother, Richard S., of Schenectady; two stepdaughters, five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

LENGTH: 446 words

HEADLINE: Schools Can't Learn a Think From Post Office;
Decentralization's Fault

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"The School Mess, Getting Worse" (editorial, May 1), commenting on a report for the New York City schools that details blatant corruption in a Bronx school district, holds no surprise for me. I can only wonder why it took so long to discover that "the present system of school governance undermines education."
In 1968, as president of the Board of Education, I wrote the minority report against decentralization. I called it a political answer to a failing education system, arguing: "local autonomy in school, as in other government affairs, inevitably will lead to ward politics, to corruption and to inefficiency." The press and some community organizations criticized me. 
 Five years later a group of educators asked, "What has New York learned about decentralization?" Here are some of the answers: "It makes for waste and inefficiency, it has not improved education, it has encouraged political corruption and mismanagement of funds."
In May 1972 you published a letter from me in which I quoted Dr. Kenneth Clark, the psychologist, who was an ardent supporter of community control. When realizing its failures, he wrote: "School decentralization is failing because local boards were more interested in power than in better schools."

 Investigations of the excesses of these boards have been made over the years, and nothing has been done to correct the problem. In a January 1987 editorial, "Yes, Review School Decentralization," you quoted Robert F. Wagner Jr., then president of the Board of Education: "The system has become so mired in politics and patronage as to stifle educational reform." Again nothing was done!
The school mess is getting worse and will continue to worsen until all parties involved come to the realization that decentralization is a simplistic answer to a problem that is deep and complex. Scientific studies have indicated that the quality of the school in any district is closely tied to the economic and educational levels of that district. Those who are diverting attention from poverty, which is the major cause of the low achievement of children, are doing a disservice to both children and society.
Decentralization makes it possible for extremists from the right and the left and those with vested interests to take control. Responsibility for the school system should rest with the Mayor, who with the assistance of a distinguished review panel, should have the power to appoint nonsalaried, nonpolitical people to the board. Serving on the board should be considered a public service by those whose only interest is the welfare of the children.
 
ROSE SHAPIRO
Lauderhill, Fla., May 5, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1996 words

HEADLINE: New York's Blacks Back Dinkins But Whites Don't, Poll Indicates

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Six months before the mayoral election, black New Yorkers continue to express overwhelming approval of Mayor David N. Dinkins's stewardship of the city, while whites overwhelmingly disapprove, according to the latest New York Times/WCBS-TV poll.
In the meantime, his support among Hispanic New Yorkers has faded so much that they are now evenly divided in their views of him and are shaping up as a crucial swing vote, according to the poll. 
 By contrast, a preponderance of New Yorkers of all ethnic and racial groups say they believe conditions in the city are worse than they were four years ago and will become still worse over the next 10 to 15 years, with blacks only slightly less pessimistic. Residents cite crime as the problem that they most want the next mayor to focus on, followed by the economy, unemployment, homelessness and race relations -- and Mr. Dinkins's handling of each prompted lukewarm-to-negative ratings, except race relations.
Mr. Dinkins remains the strong favorite in the Sept. 14 Democratic primary, outpolling his nearest rival, City Council President Andrew J. Stein, by more than 30 percentage points among registered Democrats.
 
Strength in the Boroughs
 But if the general election were held today rather than on Nov. 2, the survey showed it would be a tossup between Mr. Dinkins and his Republican-Liberal challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani, with 45 percent of registered voters backing Mr. Dinkins and 44 percent favoring Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Giuliani leads in Queens and Staten Island -- the two boroughs he carried in 1989, when he lost to Mr. Dinkins by 2 points citywide -- but now his margin over Mr. Dinkins in Queens is about half what it was then. But he shows surprising new strength in Brooklyn, which is the city's most populous borough and the one with the largest black population.
The telephone poll of 1,273 adult city residents was conducted May 10 to 14 by The Times and Channel 2 News and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Like all polls, the survey is just a snapshot. Mr. Giuliani has largely coasted on the momentum of his narrow loss, has not yet faced daily scrutiny in his campaign and could easily stumble. The Mayor is an incumbent, burdened by all the vicissitudes of three and a half years of governing, and is equipped with powerful advantages in fund-raising and access to the media, and events beyond the control of either could sharply redefine the race overnight.
Yet the survey revealed many troubling signs for the Mayor. While New Yorkers overall are split over the way Mr. Dinkins is handling his job -- with 41 percent approving and 42 percent disapproving -- there is deep cleavage along racial lines. Just 28 percent of whites approve of his performance in office, while 57 percent disapprove. Among blacks, 71 percent approve, while just 15 percent disapprove -- a 43-point gap between the races.
 
Hispanic Voters Split
 But by every measure, Hispanic New Yorkers are narrowly divided in their judgments of the Mayor, with 40 percent approving his job performance compared with a statistically indistinguishable 36 percent disapproving. Thirty-two percent called his term a success, while 34 percent said it was a failure, and 35 percent hold a generally favorable view of him while 32 percent have an unfavorable opinion.
In a matchup with Mr. Giuliani, Hispanic voters split their support exactly like the electorate as a whole, with 45 percent favoring the Mayor and 44 percent favoring Mr. Giuliani. By contrast, surveys of voters leaving the polls in 1989 showed Mr. Dinkins won about two-thirds of Hispanic votes cast, while Mr. Giuliani received one-third. Voters who identified themselves as Hispanic made up 13 percent of the electorate then, according to the surveys, blacks accounted for 28 percent and whites 56 percent.
In the poll, shifts among Hispanic voters accounted for some of the gains that Mr. Giuliani has made since 1989. He is now running even with Mr. Dinkins among female voters, who constitute a majority of the electorate, a group that he lost by eight points last time. That may also reflect the fact that he grappled for a clear stand on abortion early in his last campaign, before finally saying that he unequivocally supported a woman's right to choose.
On the other hand the closeness of the race suggests that the Mayor has consolidated his support slightly among skeptical white voters who may have feared that he would favor blacks if elected. On one of the most publicized controversies of his administration -- conflicts between blacks and Jews in Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- 60 percent of whites said he had treated the groups equally.
 
'The Race Is Stalemated'
 "The Mayor does seem to have gained some ground among the white ethnic groups, perhaps by being seen as evenhanded," said John Mollenkopf, a political science professor at the City University, who has published extensive studies of the 1989 elections. "Right now, the race is stalemated, and I think it'll continue to be until something happens to knock one down, or until one or the other succeeds in galvanizing the ambivalent voters with a vision for the city."
Under all the obvious bad news, the survey disclosed some strength in opportunities for Mr. Dinkins. Asked to name the best thing he had done, respondents chose two of the issues that he himself has most stressed -- improving race relations and hiring more police officers, each cited by 10 percent of respondents. Conversely, when New Yorkers were asked to cite the worst thing he had done, no one thing stood out; all items mentioned were in single digits and no one thing was cited by more than 5 percent of those surveyed. So Mr. Dinkins's opponents have the task of trying to sharpen this focus and persuading voters that the whole of the Mayor's shortcomings is greater than the sum of their parts.
If all politics is local, Mr. Dinkins may also benefit a bit. While 6 in 10 New Yorkers say the city is less safe today than four years ago, only 4 in 10 say their own neighborhood is less safe. At the same time, 4 in 10 say they see more police officers walking in their neighborhoods.
 
Issue of Race Relations
 Significantly, Mr. Dinkins's reputation as a racial conciliator cuts both ways. While respondents approve of the way that he is handling race relations by a margin of 5 to 3, only 47 percent of those surveyed now believe that is something a mayor can do much about, compared with 57 percent who said a mayor could do a lot about race relations during the 1989 campaign, suggesting that the high hopes that greeted Mr. Dinkins's election have markedly dissipated.
The Mayor compares favorably on this point with Mr. Giuliani, however. Voters were evenly split -- 23 percent to 20 percent -- on whether race relations would get better or worse if Mr. Dinkins were re-elected, while the other half said they would stay about the same. In contrast, 28 percent said race relations would get worse if Mr. Giuliani won, nearly twice the 15 percent who said they would get better. Forty percent said they would stay about the same if Mr. Giuliani were elected and 17 percent said they did not know.
The poll cannot measure the potential effects of turnout, enthusiasm or voter-registration efforts. No first-term incumbent black mayor of a major American city has been defeated in a re-election bid, and both camps sounded cautionary notes yesterday.
"These things are not going to remain steady," said David Garth, Mr. Giuliani's chief strategist. "I expect to go down substantially before we pull this off. I'm worried about powers of incumbency and vote-pulling operations. But whatever happens, it's going to be a horse race. The Mayor's base of strength is obviously not as strong as it was."
 
'Got My Attention'
 The Mayor's campaign manager, Bill Lynch, expressed concern at the poll's findings, particularly at the close race in Brooklyn and among women and Hispanic voters. "You sure got my attention on Brooklyn," he said.
Mr. Lynch added: "I don't know just what to make of it. We've really got to get out there pushing. This is a dead heat right now. But I don't want to do that at the expense of being complacent in the primary, and that's our first priority."
Mostly because of his cast-iron support among black voters, the Mayor retains a considerable advantage in the Democratic primary, with 49 percent of registered Democrats saying they would vote for him, compared with 16 percent for Mr. Stein, 8 percent for former Representative Herman Badillo, who announced his withdrawal in the middle of the survey to consider running for comptroller on a multiparty ticket perhaps in alliance with Mr. Giuliani, and 6 percent for Roy Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality.
But there is another worry for the Mayor. In recent years poll takers have frequently overstated black candidates' standing in pre-election polls when compared with the outcome on Election Day, even in contests with incumbents. Analysts at the Gallup Organization examined nine contests between 1982 and 1990 in which black and white candidates faced one another and concluded that when a black candidate led by fewer than 8 percentage points in the polls chances were he did not have a lead at all.
During the last two days of the survey, when voters were asked how Mr. Badillo's support for Mr. Giuliani would affect their support for Mr. Giuliani, nearly two-thirds said it would make no difference.
In another good sign for Mr. Dinkins, the Mayor led Mr. Giuliani by a margin of 2 to 1 among voters who said they knew someone who was gay, believed homosexuality was an acceptable life style, favored legalizing longterm homosexual relationships and teaching tolerance for homosexuals in the schools. That is significant because Mr. Dinkins has enjoyed strong gay support in the past and Mr. Giuliani has taken particular pains to urge tolerance for gay people.
The poll also offered an historical twist. In a testament to the passage of time and political fortunes, it showed that former Mayor Edward I. Koch would now defeat Mr. Dinkins by eight percentage points among all registered voters, virtually the reverse of the nine-point margin by which Mr. Dinkins defeated him in the 1989 Democratic primary.
 
How the City Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 10 to 14 with 1,273 adults in all parts of New York City. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, race, sex, and age.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New Yorkers.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus 5 percentage points for white registered voters, 7 points for black registered voters, and 9 points for Hispanic registered voters.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Clinton Trying to Claim West Coast as His Turf

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 18

 BODY:
From his morning jog on the Pacific shore near San Diego to his afternoon visit to a basketball court in riot-torn South-Central Los Angeles, President Clinton set out today to make the West Coast his political stronghold, much as the South was for President Ronald Reagan.
But success is far from assured because of the faltering economy here and the sustained popularity of Ross Perot. 
 As if Election Day were tomorrow, Mr. Clinton geared his speeches, television appearances and private meetings in the last 24 hours to a message tailor-made for the state: he will use the powers of his office to save California from economic devastation.
Noting that he had dispatched his Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, to lead a group that will try to bolster the state's economy, Mr. Clinton declared at a rally in San Diego: "We will not start until we have turned this state around and moved this state forward."
 
No Easy Task
 It will not be easy. Mr. Brown, who has visited California seven times since taking office (and who shed his tie to join the basketball game), described a tough political task: "We have a lot of work to do. We want to demonstrate we're here over time. We're not here to impose anything on the state."
Not all the residents in this state of 54 electoral votes were impressed with the attention. As he sought to promote his economic program this afternoon at Los Angeles Valley College in the Van Nuys district, he was heckled by a dozen or so demonstrators shouting, "No New Taxes!" and "You're breaking your promises!"
Cutting off his critics, Mr. Clinton said: "We tried their way for 12 years. Look where it got us. You know what the no-new-taxes crowd did for 12 years? They cut taxes on the rich, raised taxes on the middle class and ran the country into a ditch."
Mr. Clinton also had to defend his record on Monday night at a televised town meeting in San Diego. Lorne Fleming, a businessman, challenged him in the opening question.
 
Promise Recalled
 "President Clinton, I believe that you were elected largely on the basis of your promise of a middle-class tax cut," Mr. Fleming said. "But for the last 90 days or so, we've seen both you and the Congress transforming that promised middle-class tax cut into an unprecedented round of more taxes and new spending. There's no end in sight, and a malaise is beginning to set in our country, like the Carter era."
Mr. Clinton responded with a long defense of his efforts to cut the budget, and said he had not given up on his drive for a middle-class tax cut. "We've got to get a hold of this deficit," he said. "It's going to kill us if we don't."
At the end of the forum, Mr. Clinton sought to spread the largess by suggesting that he would do what he could to come up with $3 million to fix San Diego's rusty sewer system. "I thought you were going to ask me about the problems with the sewage treatment in Tijuana," he told a questioner. "I'm also going to try to deal with that."
Before he flew back to Washington tonight, Mr. Clinton ventured into local politics by appearing at a news conference with Michael Woo, the Democratic Mayoral candidate whom he has endorsed and who faces a tough race against Richard Riordan, a moderate Republican. Some aides had urged Mr. Clinton to stay neutral because Mr. Riordan's campaign is headed by William Wardlaw, who ran Mr. Clinton's campaign in California.
 
'I Just Like Him'
 "I endorsed Mike Woo not because I had something against his opponent -- I don't," Mr. Clinton said as Mr. Woo looked on.
"I just like him and I like him for some very good and substantive reasons," he said about Mr. Woo. "I feel a personal affinity for him because he supported me early in the race for President before the New Hampshire primary." He also said he was impressed with Mr. Woo's ideas for the city.
After days of deliberations, White House officials said, Mr. Clinton sided with advisers who said his backing Mr. Woo could strengthen his support among local Democrats and lower the prospects that Mr. Riordan would emerge as an important Republican player in Southern California politics.
"This isn't really about Woo," a White House official said. "The President can't save him. It's about Clinton. It's a political decision for the President to keep his ties with the community."
Although Mr. Clinton was the first Democrat to win California since 1964, his strategists are not fully reassured by his margin of victory in November: Mr. Clinton won the state with 46 percent of the vote, to 32 percent for President Bush and 21 for Mr. Perot.
Martin P. Wattenberg, a political scientist at the University of California at Irvine, said there was little evidence so far that Mr. Clinton's showering of attention here would do him much good. "I doubt that all the rhetoric and all the concern about California is going to get him anywhere if the economy doesn't improve," he said. "I think the electoral margin he got overstates his popularity. It was an anti-Bush vote."
But there was no letting up today as Mr. Clinton reminded voters in the South-Central district that he had visited the neighborhood long before he was a candidate for President. He pledged to push for "empowerment zones" to help rebuild troubled neighborhoods.
It was unclear whether Mr. Clinton won much good will on what aides said would be the first of many trips to the West Coast. But if anything, he showed some basketball prowess. After donning high-top athletic shoes, the President of the United States took three shots from the top of the key. One even went in.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton playing basketball at the Playground yesterday in South-Central Los Angeles. He was on a two-day visit to the West Coast. (Scott Robinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Soars to 2-Year High On Fresh Fears of Inflation

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The price of gold soared yesterday to its highest level in two years on signs that inflation was heating up again. In lively trading, gold for June delivery leaped $8 an ounce, to close at $376 on New York's Commodity Exchange. Nervous investors rushed to load up on what appears to be an increasingly precious metal.
"The mood has changed," one analyst said. "The potential for big spikes is there. We haven't seen circumstances like this for a long time." 
 On other commodity markets, grain prices surged as analysts said late-developing crops might be more vulnerable to a summer dry spell. Sugar fell, coffee prices rose, lumber jumped and oil dipped slightly.
Gold has been gaining ground since March 10, when it sank to an eight-year low of $326.90 an ounce. The advance has recently picked up additional momentum amid worry that inflation may be recurring.
News last week that consumer and producer prices jumped in April spurred inflation fear even amid a stuttering recovery from recession.
 
Gold as Classic Hedge
 Investors have traditionally bought gold in times of inflation on the theory that the metal provides protection against the declining purchasing power of currencies.
In 1980, the price of gold reached an all-time high of $850 an ounce on a combination of inflation, recession, political fears stirred by Iranian revolutionary politics and the continuing Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. By mid-1982, prices fell all the way to $300 before rebounding $200 worth in the next eight months. The gold market retreated again to the $300 level over the two years that followed, only to touch $500 once more after the stock market's October 1987 free fall.
Some say there are now more sophisticated ways of hedging against economic and political uncertainty, such as using government-bond, currency, interest-rate or oil markets.
Lately, gold has benefited from a surge in global demand for its use in making jewelry, especially in the Middle East and Asia, and a leveling of world output, which had steadily increased in the 1980's.
The prices of other precious metals were buoyed by gold's rise yesterday. The spot price of silver soared 20.3 cents, to $4.606 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Platinum gained $5.60, to close at $391 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: 500 FOREIGN POLICE READIED FOR HAITI

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 18

 BODY:
After a delay of several days caused by a strongly negative initial reaction to the idea in Haiti, senior diplomats here say they are completing plans for an international police force whose deployment in Haiti they say will soon be proposed before the United Nations Security Council.
Diplomats involved in the planning of the force, which would number about 500 officers, to be drawn mostly from French-speaking countries, say the police deployment is a key element in efforts to bring about a negotiated settlement of Haiti's long political crisis. 
 President Jean-Bertrand Aristide has been in exile since being forced from office in a September 1991 military coup, and is seeking to regain power.
If an agreement from the Haitian authorities is forthcoming, as is hoped, diplomats said President Clinton's special adviser on Haitian affairs, Lawrence A. Pezzullo, and the United Nations mediator for the Haitian crisis, Dante Caputo, could visit Haiti in coming days to receive the final authorization for the deployment needed before any Security Council action.
 
Plan for New Government
 Almost immediately after an agreement on this issue, diplomats said, work would begin on the formation of a new government in Haiti and the details of a large economic recovery program being prepared for the country.
At the same time as Haiti's economy is being resuscitated, plans are afoot to engage soldiers in a large construction effort and to build from scratch a new justice system that would meet international standards.
After private consultations with many Haitian leaders outlining these ideas, diplomats said they now were hopeful of quickly obtaining a broad consensus in favor of the police force. One diplomat warned, however, that "we will not simply go back to the drawing board and start all over" if the Haitian authorities reject the idea. Instead, he suggested, a range of new penalties to supplement an ineffective hemispheric embargo would have to be imposed before securing the peaceful restoration President Aristide.
 
Resentment of Foreign Role
 When the idea of an international police force was first disclosed last week, political and military leaders across the ideological spectrum here strongly condemned the idea as a disguised form of foreign intervention that many said conjured bitter memories of the 19-year American military occupation of Haiti that ended in 1934.
To calm apprehensions like these, a senior Western diplomat said here today that the police force, which would mostly consist of Canadian, French and Caribbean officers, would only take place with "the agreement of President Aristide and all the other responsible sectors here."
Under the planned deployment the role of the international police would be to work side by side with their Haitian counterparts and, as one diplomat said today, "be a visible sign of the commitment of the international community, and, we hope, have a dampening effect on the violence."
The international police would be armed only with sidearms and would not perform law-enforcement functions.

HEADLINE: House Democrats Rush To Extinguish Rebellion

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
House Democratic leaders scrambled today to quash a move by three of their party's conservatives to add strict controls on Medicare and Social Security spending to President Clinton's economic package.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington continued to predict that the House would pass the Administration's package of $246 billion in new taxes and $97 billion in spending cuts before the end of the month. But other leaders expressed concerns that defections among the always fractious Democrats might still snowball. 
 The leaders are mainly worried that public support for President Clinton's economic policies is slipping and that a growing number of Democratic lawmakers are having trouble defending the adoption of new taxes that are to take effect before budget cuts do. But they are also concerned that satisfying the conservatives by allowing a floor vote on additional spending cuts could lead to a rebellion by the liberals.
The tax portion of the economic package sailed through the Ways and Means Committee last week on a party-line vote, and most Congressional analysts believe it will not face its first real test until it reaches the Senate Finance Committee next month.
 
Floor Vote Sought
 But three Democratic conservatives, Representatives Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, Timothy J. Penny of Minnesota and Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, have suggested that they and other conservatives may vote against the package unless the leadership allows a floor vote on spending limits for programs like Social Security that automatically entitle people to benefits. The leadership is likely to refuse their request, since such an amendment might attract Republican support and inspire a revolt by liberals.
The three conservatives have 20 to 40 allies, but their effort to make significant changes in the budget earlier this year fell flat. They have occasionally forced the leadership's hand, as when they successfully threatened to join the Republicans in September to kill a bill to finance Government operations if the Speaker did not allow a floor vote on a modified line-item veto bill.
Howard Pastor, the chief White House lobbyist, tried to ease friction in the House by meeting today with more than 50 moderate and conservative Democratic members.
At the meeting, some lawmakers complained that the Administration was doing a poor job of selling its package, and others expressed criticism that the package was top heavy with taxes.
"We're giving him an earful of what we're hearing from our constituents," said David Mann, of Ohio.
"Negative feelings are running pretty high," Mr. Penny said in an interview today. "There is real concern about voting for a tax bill unless we can guarantee that the deficit will steadily decline."
Mr. Penny said that without capping spending on programs like Social Security and Medicare at the amounts outlined in the five-year budget resolution passed this year, "we run the risk of them eating up the new taxes."
Mr. Foley and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, dispatched their whips to the floor in the afternoon to take a count of how many members were following the three conservative Democrats. In addition, White House officials said today that Mr. Clinton would go to the Capitol on Wednesday to confer with the Democratic caucus.
Even with unified opposition of House Republicans, the Democrats can afford to lose up to 40 or so of their 257 votes and still pass the economic program.
Representative Mike Synar, a Democratic whip from Oklahoma, said the conservatives were merely posturing to gain political cover back home before ultimately supporting the President's economic plan. "This is the typical food fight that goes on in this place," he said.
But other leaders expressed concern. At a leadership meeting of Senate and House Democrats this morning, they noted that opposition to the energy tax was growing because consumers were worried that utility bills would rise.
"The problems are mounting," said Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico. "I was in New Mexico this weekend, and I got hit unmercifully by the perception that we are raising taxes."
More problems were brewing among liberals, particularly among members of the Congressional Black Caucus, who are still angry about the defeat of the $19 billion stimulus package.
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, warned that if Mr. Foley bent to the pressure of the conservatives, liberals might revolt.
"I don't blame Stenholm and McCurdy for raising their skirts," he said, "but if they are going to hold the Democratic Party and the President hostage, then we, too, have to be heard."

Among them was Representative Dave McCurdy, left. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Russian Official Insists Serbia Still Backs Vance-Owen Peace Plan

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 18

 BODY:
Insisting that the President of Serbia still backed the international peace plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina despite its rejection by Bosnian Serbs, Russia's Foreign Minister said today that he hoped the United States would yet agree to a Security Council meeting to carry out the plan.
The Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, met with President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia here after seeing the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, in the Adriatic resort of Split. Mr. Kozyrev said that the Croatian leader agreed to accept an international monitoring force along the Croatian-Bosnian border. 
 Mr. Milosevic earlier this month renewed an offer to accept an international group of monitors along the Serbian-Bosnian border to verify his claim that Serbia is not supplying the Bosnian Serbs who are fighting Muslim-led Bosnian Government forces there. So far, neither Russia nor the United States has agreed to provide troops for such a monitoring force.
Asked today whether the Serbian President stood by the offer to accept such a monitoring force, Mr. Kozyrev said: "We discussed the idea but they have their own plan of decision-making. President Milosevic firmly reiterated his decision not to supply anything but humanitarian aid and medicine to the Bosnian Serbs as long as they object to the peace plan."
After the 90-minute meeting, Mr. Milosevic told the Government-controlled television that the Russian view of the crisis was "more objective" than those expressed by some Western leaders who called for outside military intervention to stop the fighting. Russia has historic ties with the Serbs.
"Mr. Kozyrev shares the opinion that the use of force will only deepen the crisis," the Serbian President said.
There was considerable interest here in what the Russians were up to with their growing diplomatic activity in the Balkans. The Russian Deputy Defense Minister, Boris V. Gromov, came with Mr. Kozyrev. He conferred with Dobrica Cosic, president of the Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro before the two Russian ministers talked with the real power here, President Milosevic of Serbia.
There was also considerable confusion about just what the American position was following the announcement Monday that Secretary of State Warren Christopher would not attend a Security Council meeting of foreign ministers called for Friday to discuss the peace plan. The Friday meeting was canceled in the face of the American refusal to attend, saying it could not support pushing ahead with a peace plan that the Bosnian Serbs rejected in the referendum.
Mr. Kozyrev belittled the referendum, saying it had been held in the middle of a war and could not be allowed to wreck the results of negotiations.
"We are in close and constant touch with Christopher and other members of the Security Council," Mr. Kozyrev said today. The Russian said he expected to go to Washington later this week for further discussions.
Although the United States failed to persuade its European allies on a campaign that could include air strikes against Bosnian Serb military targets while lifting the arms embargo on the Muslim-led Bosnian Government forces, the threat of Western military action apparently did have an effect on the Serb leaders in Belgrade who are seeking to have international economic sanctions lifted.
Today in Belgrade, where the sanctions and the effects of war have now brought the cost of a cup of coffee to well over a hundred thousand dinars, every leader Mr. Kozyrev spoke to swore allegiance to the peace plan.
"Vance-Owen is not the end of the road, but a mechanism to reach peace," the Russian Foreign Minister said. "I am encouraging the United States not to lose the momentum created by the Vance-Owen plan being approved by everyone, including Mr. Milosevic."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Council Session Canceled
 UNITED NATIONS, May 18 (Special to The New York Times) -- Russia has postponed its attempt to convene a meeting of the Security Council at the Foreign Minister level on Friday to discuss the war in Bosnia.
The reason given for the postponement was to allow the Foreign Ministers to continue their "intensive consultations" on the Balkans crisis, but the meeting was effectively canceled when the United States declined to attend to discuss a peace plan that one side had already rejected.
The Security Council now plans to vote later this week on sending an international force to monitor Serbia's border with Bosnia to make sure President Milosevic of Serbia is really cutting off military supplies to the Serb nationalists in Bosnia, as he has vowed to do.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Muslim-Croatian Accord
 MEDJUGORJE, Bosnia and Herzegovina, May 18 (Special to The New York Times) -- After two months of bitter fighting and two stillborn peace accords, Bosnian Croat and Muslim leaders agreed today to begin carrying out a United Nations peace plan in parts of this war-torn republic.
"Those people, who have signed the peace plan, are now going to carry it forward in those areas of the country which come under their main control," said Lord Owen, the European Community's mediator on the Balkans and the co-author of the international peace plan with Cyrus R. Vance, the former United Nations envoy.
The leaders of Bosnia's Croats and Muslims signed the peace plan earlier this year. The Bosnian Serbs, whose forces now control 70 percent of Bosnian territory, rejected the plan in a referendum last weekend.
Lord Owen said the peace plan would be put into effect starting in provinces centered around the towns of Mostar, Travnik and Zenica, with the Muslims and Croats allocated seats in provisional governments according to the regions' ethnic population and vacant seats left for the Bosnian Serbs.
Alija Izetbegovic, the Bosnian Muslim leader, will remain as president under the accord signed today. Bosnia's new prime minister-designate will be Jadranko Prljic, present head of the main Croatian militia in Bosnia.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Croatian-Serbian Talks
 ZAGREB, Croatia, May 18 (Special to The New York Times) -- With some help from the Russians, the United Nations reconvened talks today between rival sides in what some diplomats here now describe as the Balkans' "forgotten war," the battle between Croats and Croatian Serbs over the rugged Croatian hinterland.
In a meeting in the town of Topusko, inside Serbian-controlled Croatia, a delegation of Croats and Croatian Serbs met for more than six hours and agreed to recommend that military authorities declare a cease-fire as of noon Thursday. They also promised to meet next week in Zagreb.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Mexican Non-Peso Bond Is Rated Investment Grade

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 18

 BODY:
Signaling both confidence in the short-term ability of Mexico to pay its debt, and the lengths to which its Government will go to raise its rank in the financial world, Mexico for the first time won an investment-grade rating on non-peso denominated bonds.
But the rating does not come from one of the two best-known American ratings companies, and its significance is expected to be limited. 
 The rating, scheduled to be announced on Wednesday, comes from Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company.
The Chicago company has given a three-year Mexican Government offering of about $85 million worth of yen-denominated notes a preliminary rating of BBB, its next-to-lowest investment-grade rating. Previously, all non-peso issues have been given speculative ratings that reflected a the view that there was a high degree of risk as to whether Mexico could repay the money on schedule.
In Latin America, Chile is the only nation with an investment-grade rating from a major company, Standard & Poor's. Although Mexico's peso-denominated offerings usually receive investment-grade ratings because the Government can print pesos, its hard-currency issues have never been considered so safe.
"If we were going to say that Mexico is investment grade, end of discussion, that would be going out on a limb," said Daniel J. Donoghue, senior vice president of Duff & Phelps. "What we're saying is that we have every degree of confidence that in three years they will have no problem in paying off this debt issue."
While Duff & Phelps did have time to consider Monday's announcement that the Mexican Government is planning to to make the Mexican central bank autonomous, the rating rationale was based on Mexican efforts to control inflation and reduce the nation's foreign debt.
But the most important factor, Mr. Donoghue said, was the comparatively short, three-year maturity of the issue rather than the more standard 10 years. The notes will come due during the early stages during the term of Mexico's next president, who will succeed President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in December 1994.
While the rating marks what Mexican finance officials hope would become a benchmark, it is likely to be overlooked by some investors because Duff & Phelps is a relative newcomer to the foreign debt market, having customarily focused on corporations, especially utilities. Only in the last year has it rated sovereign debt -- the way any government pays off its debt.
The two major American rating services -- Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's -- are not expected to rate the new yen notes until several weeks after they are issued, in keeping with their practice. The notes may be issued next month.
Ratings have become a sensitive issue for developing nations, who say that the two major services are too conservative. Duff & Phelps has entered the field with a reputation for being more open to emerging markets, and for being willing to rate medium-term issues before the deals are actually completed.
Analysts familiar with foreign debt said that it seemed the Mexican Government had decided to shop for the best rating it could get. And they said, by issuing the notes in yen -- for the first time since 1978 -- Mexico played down the potential negative effects of having used a comparatively unknown rating service.
Ministry of Finance officials denied that they had shopped for the rating. , "They came to us," one official said.

HEADLINE: Hawaii Health Care Is Called a Model for U.S.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 18

 BODY:
Hawaii's universal health-care system, which insures 96.5 percent of the state's residents and costs less than health care in other states and Canada, could serve as a national model, health officials from Hawaii say in a new report.
The report also says that requiring employers to provide insurance for employees who work at least 20 hours a week has not bankrupted small businesses, as some feared when the plan went into effect 19 years ago. 
 "In fact, some indirect indicators suggest that the effect may be positive," said the report, to be published on Wednesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
Unemployment since 1974 has markedly declined in Hawaii, where 97 percent of businesses have fewer than 100 workers, the report said. By 1990, new-business start-ups per capita had reached the third highest rate in the nation, it said.
 
Near Top in Health Status
 Only 3.5 percent of Hawaii's 1.1 million residents lacked health insurance in 1989, compared with 11.7 percent who lacked hospital coverage in 1971 and 17.2 percent who lacked physician coverage then, the report said.
Hawaiians rank at or near the top in health status compared with other Americans, the health officials said.
"We believe a considerable amount of this success is attributable to direct and indirect effects of Hawaii's employer mandate," they said, adding that the state's approach receive serious attention as a task force headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton considers health-care changes.
Hawaii's health-care system emphasizes prevention and early treatment. Without rationing or a ceiling on costs, Hawaiians are hospitalized only 90 percent as often as other Americans, undergo surgery only 61 percent as often and visit emergency rooms only 48 percent as often, the report said.
 
Comparing Heat-Care Costs
 Health-care costs, including government expenses for Medicare and Medicaid, were only 7.8 percent of the gross state product in Hawaii, compared with 11.2 percent of the gross national product for the United States, a 1992 study found. The figure was 8.6 percent in Canada, 9 percent in Sweden, 8.5 percent in the Netherlands and 8.2 percent in Germany, the report said.
The health officials dismissed the argument that Hawaii was a special case because of its mild climate and a healthy genetic stock of Asians and Pacific Islanders. Rather, they said, Caucasians have the best relative health among racial groups, and the state's reduced health-care expenses from lack of cold weather are offset by higher rates of skin cancer and ocean injuries.
Because Hawaii is a gateway for immigration from Asia and the Pacific islands, it has the nation's second highest rate of tuberculosis and ranks among the top 10 states in new AIDS infections, the officials said.
Hawaii is seeking Federal approval to combine its Medicaid and state insurance programs for those who do not qualify under Medicaid or the employer mandate. Gov. John Waihee 3d, a Democrat, hopes that will save even more.
But Walter Zelman, an adviser to the Clinton Administration's task force on health care, said in a telephone interview from Washington that Hawaii's system was not directly applicable to other states.
Hawaii is in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, he noted, so businesses that dislike its laws cannot easily move. And Hawaii's two biggest insurers are not-for-profit companies, so the state is free of some "predatory" practices found elsewhere, he said.
"There's a lot to be learned from Hawaii," Mr. Zelman added, "but it may not provide the whole answer."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Washington State Plan Enacted
 SEATTLE, May 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Clinton listened in via satellite today as Gov. Mike Lowry of Washington signed a state health-care law that contains the basic elements that she said "mirror essential elements of the national package" now being drafted.
It includes a uniform benefits plan, increased access to health care, cost controls and a partnership of employers, insurers and government. A centerpiece of the new law is the requirement that employers contribute at least half of their workers' premiums.
A state commission will regulate the health-care industry like a utility, requiring insurers and providers to compete for pools of patients.
New taxes on the health-care industry, tobacco and alcohol will subsidize coverage, first for about 150,000 people without insurance and later for thousands more as the new taxes grow to an expected $500 million a year.

HEADLINE: Treasury Bond Yield Above 7%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Interest rates surged yesterday, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumping above 7 percent. As a result, many investors may switch their focus to how much higher interest rates might go rather than how much lower.
While 7 percent itself is not an important number economically, it can be seen as the psychological threshold between a market rally and a selloff, especially given the new concerns about inflation, worries about the fate of President Clinton's economic program and guessing over whether the Federal Reserve will now move to raise short-term interest rates to combat renewed inflation. 
 Inflationary concerns were increased, traders said, by a sharp rise in the price of gold, which jumped $8 an ounce yesterday and is up about $40 since April. [Page D17.]
 
Panic With 'Capital P'
 "The name of the game today was panic with a capital P," said Jay Goldinger, a bond trader at Capital Insight in Los Angeles. "The problem with the market is that the gold rally has hit the market hard, and retail buyers are scared." A separate jump in the Commodity Research Bureau index of commodities, which is another inflation barometer, added to the selling in the bond market, forcing yields higher.
Treasury prices also came under pressure from the hangover from last week's $35 billion Treasury auction. The quarterly auction was disrupted by disturbing reports on April inflation and left dealers with a lot of debt securities that they may not have wanted. One way to get rid of these securities was to cut prices.
In trading yesterday, the price of the 7 1/8 percent 30-year bond maturing in February 2023 was off 22/32 , to 10111/32 , as the yield jumped to 7.02 percent from 6.96 percent. Prices fell and yields rose on Treasury notes as well, but not as sharply.
"I think the markets are very emotional," said William Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. He said the bond market had overreacted to the surprisingly sharp increase in both consumer and producer prices for April and the speculation that immediately followed on whether the Federal Reserve, instead of easing interest rates to help a sluggish economy, might have to raise them.
The Fed's policy-making committee met yesterday in Washington and added to the apprehension in the market.
"I think we go another month, and then we get better inflation news and the fear of Fed tightening will go away," Mr. Dudley said. He said Goldman still thought the economy was weak, that there was not any fundamental inflationary pressures and that the yield on the long bond would fall through 6.5 percent.
Mr. Goldinger also argued that the market was overreacting. "There is a fear of inflation, but its mostly an anticipatory fear. The economy is not different than it was a month ago.
"I think yields are going to steady here," he added, "There is no question that sentiment is bearish. Can yields go to 7.10 percent? Sure they can. But you can't get carried away because the economic fundamentals have not changed."
 
The End of the Rally
 Mr. Goldinger reflects a growing consensus that the bond market rally of 1993 may be over for now but that if it is, it does not mean that interest rates are going to go much higher.
The main reason for this view is that the economy is still weak -- it grew at a 1.8 percent annual rate in the first quarter -- and will not create a lot of inflationary pressures. The other factor is that even if inflation winds up higher than last year's 2.9 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index, most anlaysts do not expect it to be much higher.
"If you don't reinforce the market fears quickly, the market is going to have to retrace some, and yields will have to come back down," Mr. Goldinger said.
The last time the bond yield rose above 7 percent was on Friday, April 2, at 7.05 percent, and Monday, April 5, at 7.02 percent. After that jump in rates, which was also caused by an inflation scare, yields dropped again after the March inflation reports turned out to be surprisingly low.
 
New York Bonds
 Yesterday was not the best day for a bond sale, but New York City still sold $917 million of bonds, including the first sale ever by a major city of bonds denominated in Japanese yen.
As Treasury market yields rose in the day, the city and its underwriters, lead by Bear, Stearns & Company, had to cut prices and push up yields on the longer-term maturities by as much as 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
"We ended up having to cheapen the bonds a little bit, but we were pleased with the deal," said Michael Geffrard, director of public finance for the city.
The yen sale totaled just more than $200 million. The bonds were sold to institutional investors in Japan, including insurance companies and trust banks. For New York City, the idea of selling bonds abroad is one type of innovation that is being used more often in local financing to cut interest costs. According to Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City Comptroller, the lower interest rates the city was able to pay in Japan will enable it to save about $3.8 million over 10 years.
The sale also included popular bonds that sell at a deep discount to the face value so small investors can afford them. For example, the bonds maturing in 2012 sold for $305 for a bond that will pay $1,000 at maturity.
The rates on the $481 million in tax-exempt fixed-rate general obligation bonds ranged from 3.20 percent in 1994 and 5.70 percent in 2004 to 6.25 percent in 2015 and 6.25 percent in 2021. The increases in yields ranged from 5 basis points in 2011, to 6.15 percent, and 10 basis points in 2016, to 6.25 percent.

HEADLINE: Interest-Rate Concerns Push Dow Lower by 5.54 Points

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Chilled by the uncertainty of future interest rates, stock market investors returned yesterday to the trading range that has characterized the market for the last several weeks.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell slightly, while other major indexes were mixed in relatively heavy trading. 
 Meanwhile, gold and gold stocks surged yesterday. Gold for June delivery jumped $8, to $376 an ounce, while Echo Bay Mines, the most active stock on the American Stock Exchange, climbed 1 1/4, to 12 1/8.
The most active stock of the day was Spectrum Information Technologies, with volume of 11.5 million shares in Nasdaq trading. It rose 1 17/32 to 9 1/32 , its sixth winning session in a row. The tiny company recently signed a licensing agreement for wireless data transfer technology with A.T.& T., and other major companies are signing up as well.
The Dow industrials closed down 5.54 points, to 3,444.39, after dropping more than 24 points at midafternoon.
Meanwhile, the Dow Jones transportation average, which fell 15.91 points on Monday, lost another 7.66 points, closing at 1,560.00.
But the Nasdaq composite index, made up mainly of smaller-capitalization and high-technology stocks, closed up 2.82 points, to 680.78. The American Stock Exchange market value index closed up 0.76, to 428.22.
Among other indexes, the New York Stock Exchange Composite Index closed down 0.05, to 243.53 points. Losing stocks on the Big Board outnumbered winners by 1,082 to 833. The Standard & Poor's 500 closed down 0.05, to 440.32 points.
In the last four sessions, the Dow Jones industrial average has closed around 3,450, down from the May 12 peak of more than 3,480. For the same period, closes for the Standard & Poor's 500 have hugged a range of around 440.
On Thursday, following two days of disturbing inflation reports, stocks fell sharply as traders focused on what the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee would do on interest rates. The committee met yesterday and its intentions will become known within the next few weeks, either through guesswork from public documents or news leaks.
A report on the financial cable television channel CNBC yesterday morning before the opening bell helped to sharpen the market's anxiety. Three Fed governors, according to CNBC, advocate higher interest rates to fight inflation. The move would hurt stocks as well as bonds, and, by extension, raise business's borrowing and operating costs.
The decline in the Dow was across the board, with a startling 21 out of 30 index stocks declining in price. The leading decliner in the Dow was General Electric, down 1 3/8, to 92 1/4, on no discernible news.
Royal Dutch Petroleum, which owns 60 percent of the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group, topped the most-active list on the Big Board with 11.13 million shares. It closed down 5/8, to 89 7/8, partly on news that Nederlandse Gasunie, a natural-gas distributor of which Shell is a part-owner, expects lower sales.
Hewlett-Packard, the third-most- active stock on the Big Board, closed up 5 1/8, to 84 3/4, on surprisingly strong earnings. Tucson Electric Power, the second-most-active, was up 1/8, to 3 1/2, on no discernible news, but it reported a narrower quarterly loss last week.
