HEADLINE: Newest Airlines Find Conditions Ripe to Succeed

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
In the life cycle of airlines, the season is changing from winter to spring. After a decade that saw far more airline deaths than births, 15 new airlines, including Kiwi International and Reno Air, have begun flying.
Conditions are fertile for the upstarts largely because of the demise of Pan American World Airways, Eastern Airlines and Midway, among others, and cutbacks by majors like American, Delta and United. Laid-off pilots, mechanics and flight attendants are eager to get back to work -- even at a fraction of their former pay. Planes sitting idle in the Arizona desert can be leased cheaply, underused hubs and routes are available and passengers are eager to buy cut-rate tickets.
 
New Federal Policy
 And importantly, Secretary of Transportation Federico F. Pena has warned the industry that anticompetitive practices will not be tolerated, and his department has been working with the Justice Department to make sure that new carriers -- in addition to the 15 already flying, 11 more are planned -- are not knocked out before they have a chance. 
 The new airlines, which account for less than 2 percent of industry capacity, are tiny compared with the major carriers. American and Delta, for example, have 400 to 500 aircraft apiece. In contrast, Kiwi flies six Boeing 727's to Atlanta, Chicago and Orlando from Newark; Reno Air has 10 McDonnell Douglas MD-80 planes, which it operates from Reno to San Diego, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Portland, Ore., and Seattle, and most of the upstarts are even smaller.
New carriers had received almost no protection from the Reagan and Bush Administrations, and hundreds went out of business, leaving entrepreneurs and investors wary of new proposals. The Clinton Administration takes a different view.
"While we will do whatever we can to support our existing carriers," Mr. Pena said, "so too will we do whatever we can to make sure fledgling carriers have a fair shot."
The new carriers have already forced down fares in selected markets by setting low rates that the majors feel compelled to match, even though they generally make available only a small and controlled number of seats at the lower prices and impose restrictions on the unprofitable tickets.
Kiwi International Airlines, for example, charges $119 one way for its three daily flights between Newark and Chicago. United, American and Continental Airlines have matched the fare for a limited number of seats on their 30 daily flights, on which the full one-way coach fare was $340 before Kiwi entered the market. The majors' fare from La Guardia to Chicago is still $365 one way.
 
Going for the Niches
 The new carriers' managers, painfully aware of new airlines' high failure rates, are wary about taking on the large carriers in major markets, despite Secretary Pena's vow to protect them.
Most plan to remain niche players for now, stepping in where there is a vacuum the way Reno Air did, or keeping a low profile like Kiwi, which limits the number of its flights.
"The only defense against the big guys was to stay below their radar screen," said Robert Iverson, president and chief executive of Kiwi, in an interview in his office overlooking a runway at Newark International Airport. "Now we don't have to worry about that so much," with Mr. Pena's protection, he said. Still, he is not stepping up Kiwi's expansion.
Nevertheless, the potential for the new carriers -- phoenixes that have risen from the ashes of airline deregulation -- could be promising.
One reason is that American and United, for example, plan to pull back from many of their short-haul markets, creating a need for other carriers to provide connecting flights, and even to sell off new hubs, a move American is considering at Raleigh and Durham, N.C.
 
New Cooperation Foreseen
 "Instead of the big guys trying to kill the small guys, we will see the big guys working with the small guys," said Ray Neidl, an airline analyst for Furman Selz in New York.
The upstarts include five with scheduled passenger service. In addition to Kiwi and Reno, they are: Morris Air, which feeds Delta routes from a Salt Lake City hub; Private Jet, which offers unrestricted $99 flights from Atlanta to Miami and Chicago, and Ultrair, a Houston-based carrier that offers first-class amenities at coach rates. Another five are charter operators, and five more are cargo carriers.
Patrick Murphy, an Acting Assistant Secretary of Transportation, said that three more carriers had been given authority to operate, and eight more were seeking clearance.
"There has been increased interest by venture capitalists in starting and expanding new entrant airlines," Mr. Murphy said. Investment bankers and financiers are also looking more favorably on the high-risk ventures.
Getting capital is the biggest hurdle for most upstarts. New carriers must fly at huge losses until they build up a following.
Reno Air used Paradise Valley Securities, a small regional firm, as an underwriter and was able to raise $5.8 million in cash from the public and $5.1 million by selling convertible notes.
The airline, which has grown faster than it expected, generated about $2 million in cash last year and now has enough to finance its growth for the year. It is even getting unsolicited offers of money, Jeff Erikson, Reno's president, said.
 
Re-emergence of Lorenzo
 The boom climate has attracted some familiar, if controversial, figures. Frank Lorenzo, whose bitter battles with the airline pilots' and machinists' unions were part of the undoing of Eastern Airlines, is seeking to get a certificate from the Department of Transportation to set up Friendship Airlines.
The department has turned the certification over for a review by an administrative judge, making it uncertain that Mr. Lorenzo will get his venture off the ground.
In another case, the department told Barry Michaels, a former Los Angeles businessman who is a founder of Family Airlines, that his airline would not be allowed to fly unless he and his wife severed their ties to the carrier.
Mr. Michaels, who served several months in an Arizona Federal prison after conviction for mail fraud, recently agreed to give up control, enabling about 100 pilots who invested $3 million to continue to seek certification.
For those who do pass muster, conditions have not been so favorable since deregulation began in 1979. Leasing rates for planes are about half what they were two years ago. Mr. Erikson said that in some cases the lessors had put up as much as $1 million to convert some of their idle MD-80's, on which they were previously paying storage.
 
Cheap and Willing Labor
 Thousands of pilots, flight attendants and mechanics who lost their jobs when Eastern, Pan Am and Midway went out of business are willing not only to begin new careers at much lower salaries, but also to donate somew of their time during the start-up phase.
Their incentive to do so is particularly strong at Kiwi. The airline's capital came mainly from investments of at least $50,000 each from more than 100 pilots. The New Jersey Economic Development Authority provided $1.6 million in loan guarantees. The carrier, which is owned and operated by its 420 employees, most of whom came from one of the liquidated carriers, is considering a stock offering.
"We chose to take experience at every level we could, so that's why we have reservation agents with 25 years experience," said Codie Bell, Kiwi's chief financial officer. "Eastern had 1,800 reservation agents in New York, and we needed 25. So we took the best 25 people."
The carrier also had its pick of senior managers and turned to a group of former senior Pan Am executives for the accounting staff.
The lack of an adversarial relationship between labor and management, which is the norm at the major carriers, is a major advantage for Kiwi, giving the airline great flexibility in using its work force.
Pilots gladly help load bags, visit travel agents to sell the airline or pitch in to help flight attendants.
Some senior pilots, who once earned more than $100,000 a year, are now flying for $48,000 a year at Kiwi, giving the carrier a low operating cost of about 9 cents a seat-mile, in contrast to major carriers, which range from 12 cents to 15 cents a mile, and it is expected to be a long time -- if ever -- until the new carriers reach that level.
Kiwi pays $40,000 to $150,000 a month to lease its 727-200 planes. They were formerly flown by Lufthansa, which is known for quality maintenance.
Kiwi's fares are $99 to $139 one way without restrictions, and it offers amenities like fresh salads and custom-blended coffee.
 
Recollections of People Express
 Both Kiwi and Reno, now almost a year old, have come through the hazardous start-up phase and are now reaching the break-even stage.
The danger for start-up carriers comes at this phase. If they are tempted to abandon their niche strategy and expand into major markets, taking on big carriers directly, they could be wiped out. People Express, for example, failed when it tried to become a major national carrier.
Before Mr. Pena's crucial intervention, the new carriers' officers and staffs lived in peril, knowing that the major carriers could knock them out of the market if they wanted to, simply by putting in many more frequent flights at the same fares without limits on the seats.
Kiwi executives said -- and Transportation Department officials confirmed -- that the department had begun a quiet investigation to see if Kiwi's huge rival, Continental Airlines, had set fares below the levels at which it could make money to drive Kiwi out of Newark and elsewhere.
Mr. Pena also warned Northwest Airlines not to try to knock out Reno Air's entry into Minneapolis, its major hub, by putting in jumbo aircraft. But Reno announced this week it would abandon Minneapolis and Kansas City service for lack of traffic.
Under the Reagan and Bush Administrations, Mr. Erikson recalled, Section 441 of the aviation code, which is aimed at preventing carriers from engaging in predatory pricing, was largely ignored.
One of the original main goals of deregulation was to open entry for new competitors, which would challenge the large carriers, bringing down fares and providing greater choices for travelers.
Mr. Erikson said that under the last two Administrations that section "was absolutely gutted because it was not enforced." Now Secretary Pena's action, he said, "is a clear signal that the Government has the will that the new entrants can play with the big guys."


GRAPHIC: Starting an airline is a tricky proposition. Below is a broad outline of the major hurdles. But be prepared to attend to a thousand other details ranging from printing operating manuals to obtaining liquor licenses if you plan to serve drinks on board. Oh, and don't forget to develop a marketing strategy.
 
You'll Need: Permission
 
Pointers: The Department of Transporation must certify that you are fit to operate an airline. The Federal Aviation Administration wants to make sure you will meet saftety standards. The Government also want proof that the airline is not under foreign control. The department can be tough; It is holding up Frank Lorenzo's permission to start Friendship Airlines while is reviews his record at Eastern and Continental.
 
You'll Need: Money - lots of it
 
Pointers: Don't count on old-line venture capital firms to pull out their check-books, nor on Wall Street to take you public. Too many high-flying airlines have left investors holding the bag. Entrepreneurs are turning to sources of capital that barely existed years ago: suppliers of labor and aircraft who have strong economic incentives to see new airlines come on stream. Government agencies may also lend a hand.
 
You'll Need: Airplanes
 
Pointers: You can buy one for as little as $800,000, but nearly everyone leases planes at first. Expect to pay from $40,000 to $150,000 a month for each plane, 20 percent less than two years ago. Whether you buy or lease, you pay more for a plane that is equpped to fly over water, and more for one formerly owned by Lufthansa, the airline equivalent of the little old lady from Pasadena, than one that belonged to, say, Eastern.
 
You'll Need: A work force
 
Pointers: The unions that represented Pan American, Midway and Eastern employees can put you in touch with hundreds of experienced people who were left out of work when those airlines stoped flying. All 25 of Kiwi's reservation agents hail from Eastern while its accountants come from Pan Am. Many of Reno Air's people are Midway alumni. (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: New-Home Starts Rose 6.7% in April

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Home building perked up in April, particularly in the Northeast. It was another sign that the economy has regained some momentum after a harsh winter and that the modest housing recovery is still alive.
But despite the lowest mortgage rates in nearly two decades, nobody is counting on another 1980's-style housing boom. 
 Housing starts jumped 6.7 percent in April, the biggest monthly gain since August, after dropping 3.6 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. The April pace -- 1.2 million at an annual rate -- was a shade above last year's average, but still shy of the 1.3 million pace of December, which economists hope will be the average for 1993.
 
'Signs of Improvement'
 "Things are still pretty miserable, but we're starting to see signs of improvement, especially in Texas," said Ronald Foell, president of Standard Pacific, a big home builder based in Costa Mesa, Calif.
"It's a step in the right direction," said David Lereah, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington.
Builders started new projects at a faster pace everywhere except the Midwest, where starts were flat. Starts zoomed 22.6 percent in the Northeast, 9.5 percent in the South and 3.4 percent in the West.
Mr. Foell noted that sales of land by the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is disposing of assets from failed savings and loans, had helped bolster home building. "Some builders have been able to buy parcels at very low prices and in turn to offer homes at attractive values," he said.
 
New Permits Are Up
 In Texas, where the residential real estate market is in pretty good shape, Mr. Foell said Standard Pacific had 15 new projects -- mostly in Houston, Dallas and Austin -- and, with its sales backlog growing, was trying to start more. Developments range from several dozen to several hundred new homes.
The issuance of building permits, a good indicator of future construction, bounced up 5.8 percent in April, the largest monthly amount in nearly a year and a half, the Commerce Department said.
Other signs of future housing activity were also fairly good.
Though inflation jitters have lately nudged interest rates higher, mortgages are still close to a 19-year low, around 7.5 percent for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, making houses more affordable than at any time since the early 1970's.
The volume of mortgage applications, a weekly survey by the Mortgage Bankers Association shows, remains very strong by historical standards -- three times higher than in the recession.
And job growth, though still very modest, has been better in the last six months than in the first year and a half of the economic recovery.
Nonetheless, most developers and housing experts expect home building to remain more subdued in the next few years than in the boom years of the 1980's expansion.
For good reason, says Mark Lasky, a housing economist at DRI/McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass. Americans are forming fewer new households. Because of the "baby bust" that began in the mid-1960's, the number of Americans in the prime household-forming ages of 25 to 35 is shrinking.
There is also less bottled-up demand for homes now than in the wake of the 1981-82 recession, when mortgage rates soared above 16 percent in the Federal Reserve's battle against double-digit inflation.
"People weren't squeezed out of the market by high rates," Mr. Lasky said of the recent downturn.
 
Less Government Help
 Potential home buyers are also getting less help from Washington these days. Most of the once-generous tax incentives that helped a boom in condominiums and rental apartments were abolished by the Tax Reform Act of 1986. And the middle class will not be getting an income tax cut like the one Ronald Reagan delivered in 1981.
But builders of single-family homes still have reason for optimism. The demographic trend that is slowing household formation is likely to most hurt builders of rental apartments and starter homes, not those who cater to the more middle-age move-up market, which is expanding as members of the "baby boom" generation head into their 40's and 50's.
DRI/McGraw Hill's long-term projections call for housing starts to average just more than 1.3 million a year the next 10 years, versus 1.7 million a year in the 1983-88 boom. But the forecasting firm expects slightly more single-family starts, 1.1 million a year for the next 10 years, compared with a million a year the last 10 years.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Danish Vote And Higher Rates in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday, strengthened by higher United States interest rates and Danish voters' approval of the European unity treaty.
Underlying the dollar's strength was growing sentiment that interest rates in the United States were poised to rise and foreign rates were headed lower. Higher domestic rates tend to make a nation's currency more attractive to investors. 
 That view was supported yesterday by two events: Denmark's approval of the treaty on closer political and economic ties among the 12 nations of the European Community, and a jump in the yield on the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond to above the key 7 percent level.
 
Stocked Up on Marks
 Some traders had bought German marks Monday on lingering fears that a Danish "no" vote could scuttle plans for political and economic unity, easing pressure on Germany to cut its currently high interest rates.
But those who had stocked up on marks began selling on expectations of the Danish approval, which came during afternoon trading in New York.
The general perception was that the approval might pave the way for lower interest rates in Europe, said Michael Malpede, senior analyst at Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago.
In European trading, the dollar broke through a key psychological level of 1.6210 German marks to close at 1.6240 marks, up from 1.6165 late Monday. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was worth 1.62425 German marks, up from 1.6130.
Traders also sold Swiss francs on sentiment that Switzerland might cut its interest rates again, analysts said.
But the pound posted smaller losses against the dollar because Britain is keeping interest rates high compared with other European nations, said John Nelson, director of foreign exchange at Barclays Bank P.L.C.
The dollar continued to trade in a range against the Japanese yen, which was sidelined by the action among European currencies. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 111.28 yen, up 0.51 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 111.55 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was worth 111.445 yen, up from 111.30.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Hotel Profits for 1992 Show A Slow but Steady Recovery

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
In a sharp, unexpected turnabout, more than half the nation's hotels turned a profit last year -- the first time since 1989 that more than 50 percent were profitable.
A study released yesterday by the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand, a leading consultant to the United States hospitality industry, showed that 51.5 percent of hotels were profitable last year, up from 39.9 percent in 1991. 
 In another indication that a slow, steady recovery is under way in the industry, room occupancy in the first quarter rose to 58.5 percent -- the highest rate of any first quarter since 1990. The two percentage point increase in occupancy over the 1992's first quarter was the biggest of any comparable period since 1989. The occupancy statistics were compiled by Smith Travel Research of Gallatin, Tenn., for the American Hotel and Motel Association.
 
Rate Increases Expected
 "What this means," said Bjorn Hanson, chairman of hospitality industry consulting at Coopers & Lybrand, "is that the hotel recovery is under way and there's a good chance that in 1995 room rates will increase greater than the rate of inflation."
Hotel rate increases have trailed the rate of inflation since 1987, Mr. Hanson said, and next year, they are likely to lag behind slightly. "But rates should be slightly higher than inflation in 1995," he added, "and occupancy should be close to 68 percent, compared with 62.2 percent last year."
The Smith Travel Research data show that room rates in the first quarter, historically the slowest in the lodging industry, averaged $61.35, or 2 percent more than the $60.07 average for the similar 1991 quarter. Smith also noted that while the Consumer Price Index rose more than 13 percent from the first quarter of 1989 through the first quarter of 1993, room rates increased only 5.5 percent.
Recovery appears to have been in the wings for at least several months. December's 48.1 percent occupancy rate was the highest for that month -- the industry's slowest -- since Smith Travel began compiling such figures in 1986. And in February, a report by the real estate services group of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen & Company said the industry might be heading for recovery.
Still, Mr. Hanson said, "I think the industry didn't expect there would be such an improvement in one year."
He attributed the increase in hotel profitability to the higher occupancy rates, the decline in interest rate burdens, because many hotels had restructured delinquent loans, and cost-containment measures, including lower taxes resulting from property tax appeals.
The Coopers & Lybrand report noted that the American Council of Life Insurance had said that the percentage of delinquent principal on hotel loans fell to 14.29 percent at the end of 1992 from a peak of 15.89 percent in the second quarter of 1992.
Limited-service hotels continue to do better than full-service hotels, the report said. Last year, 28.5 percent of limited-service hotels lost money, an improvement from 40.3 percent the year before. In 1992, 57.1 percent of full-service hotels recorded losses, an improvement from 68.4 percent in 1991.
Lenders will still be wary about investing in hotels until at least 1997, Mr. Hanson said, and not all hotels will benefit equally from the recovery. "There are still many hotels that are the wrong product and built on the wrong site," he said, "and they may never be successful."
Many such hotels were built primarily as tax write-offs, but the Tax Reform Act of 1986 eliminated most real estate tax shelters of that type.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Honda Net Falls 41% in Year Amid Sales Slump in U.S.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 18

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company said today that profits fell 41 percent in the 1992 fiscal year as revenue dropped 5.9 percent amid slumping sales in the United States.
The results, the first released by a major Japanese auto maker for the year ended March 31, also reflect how the Japanese car industry is suffering from a high yen and recession at home, analysts said. 
 Honda's net profit for the year was 38.3 billion yen, or $329 million, compared with 64.88 billion yen in the 1991 fiscal year.
Revenue fell 5.9 percent, to 4.13 trillion yen, or $35.53 billion. Honda's total revenue is third among Japanese auto makers after Toyota and Nissan.
Honda's passenger car sales in North America plummeted 17 percent, to 794,000, reflecting the new popularity of American models like the Ford Taurus, which edged out the Honda Accord as the top-selling car in the United States in 1992.
The higher yen was also a blow to Honda. As the dollar has fallen from around 125 yen early this year to the 111-yen level, Honda's dollar-denominated profits from sales overseas have dropped when translated into yen.
Like all Japanese makers, Honda has raised prices in the United States to compensate for the yen's rise, but that has reduced its competitiveness.
"Japanese car makers have become unable to win" on price against American makers, one industry analyst said.
Meanwhile, the slowdown in Japan's economy helped cut Honda's domestic car sales 7.9 percent, to 616,000.
The outlook for the 1993 fiscal year is clouded by the yen's continued high level, Honda officials said. The company forecasts profits will be down 40 percent and sales down 3.2 percent this year, and those figures could be further revised downward, said an auto analyst, Takahisa Izawa of the Nomura Research Institute.
Honda, which makes nearly 45 percent of its sales in North America, will also be challenged by new models from the Chrysler Corporation that are expected to compete with Honda's Civic, analysts said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
DAYTON HUDSON (N)

 BODY:
As it warned Wall Street two weeks ago, the Dayton Hudson Corporation yesterday reported a 14 percent decline in first-quarter earnings.
The company said sales have been weak since the middle of February. "Consumers are very cautious," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of Dayton Hudson, which operates the Target and Mervyn's chains as well as three department store chains. "Part of that is due to pervasive economic concerns, such as uncertainties about job security, tax increases and the cost of health-care reform." 
 Mr. Macke noted that the first quarter typically represents only a small portion of a retailer's sales and profits but cautioned that the company did not expect real improvement until the second half of the year.
Dayton Hudson has been particularly hit by the economic illness infecting California, where it has many stores. Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc., said the opening of between 50 and 65 new stores this year and efforts to provide shoppers with a trendier merchandise mix would enable Dayton Hudson to post better earnings as the economy gained momentum.

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
The Cream Of Folk, Reunited For a Cause

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Pete Seeger has always had a gift for cutting to the essence of things in an easygoing, unpretentious way.
"There are as many kinds of folk songs as there are folks," he observed in the opening moments of "Folksongs U.S.A.," a benefit concert for the 92d Street Y on Monday evening that reunited many stars of the folk-music movement of the 1940's, 50's and 60's. 
 Mr. Seeger's point was that in today's climate of multiculturalism, the distinctions between folk and non-folk music seem increasingly tenuous. Doesn't every musical style have a specific association with some cultural or socio-economic group? And what music could be a more direct, outspoken expression of populist sentiment than rap, a genre that doesn't fit at all into the conventional definition of folk?
Mr. Seeger and the other performers who appeared -- Burl Ives, the Chad Mitchell Trio, Art Garfunkel, Eric Weissberg, Tom Paxton, Odetta, Theodore Bikel, Oscar Brand, Josh White Jr. and Paul Robeson Jr. -- all belong to a tradition that once shared a common definition of folk music.
It was assumed to be a body of work that had been handed down orally from generation to generation without the taint of commercialism. Homemade and unsophisticated, this time-tested music of the people, which comprised everything from lullabies to work songs, was taken as a purer alternative to the mainstream of popular song.
And in the political context of the folk movement, with its passionate commitment to civil rights and other liberal causes, folk singing was a powerful musical bond uniting diverse peoples who shared a common agenda.
That spirit shined through many of the performances and speeches in the show, which featured two notable reunions. One was the teaming of Mr. Seeger and Mr. Ives, who had not performed together for four decades, in a rendition of "Blue Tail Fly." Mr. Seeger, at 74, is still a robust performer. Mr. Ives, at 83, is not.
The other reunion was the first New York performance in more than three decades by the Chad Mitchell Trio. Until it broke up in 1965, the trio, which also includes Joe Frazier and Mike Kobluk, was the most musically polished and politically pointed among the many 60's male folk groups to cultivate a post-barbershop collegiate style. Their performance of the satirical song "The John Birch Society" showcased the trio's rough-and-ready style. The wistful "I Can't Help but Wonder" featured Mr. Frazier's still-superb folk-pop crooning.
Also outstanding were Mr. Garfunkel's renditions of "Scarborough Fair" and "April Come She Will," accompanied by Mr. Weissberg on guitar. Mr. Brand's jocular storytelling gave the show a note of humor, while Mr. Bikel's performance of a Russian gypsy song added a note of cheery exoticism. Odetta's two unaccompanied numbers connected folk music to old-time spirituals. Mr. Paxton, who has almost singlehandedly perpetuated the tradition of the topical broadside, delighted the audience with "Yuppies in the Sky," his dry satire of 1980's greed. Mr. White, with a stirring rendition of Billie Holiday's "Strange Fruit," and Mr. Robeson, in a formal speech remembering his father, each offered forceful reminders of the folk movement's role in the struggle for racial equality.
Of all those who weren't there, two whose presence was deeply felt were the folk legends Woody Guthrie and Leadbelly, who were remembered in audience sing-alongs of "This Land Is Your Land" and "Goodnight, Irene."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
Mondavi on Wall St., Wine in the Limelight

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
WHEN the time comes to write the history of the wine business in the 1990's, the turning point may well prove to be the Robert Mondavi Winery's first public offering of shares of stock. If the sale goes well, as wine industry analysts are predicting, it will be a sign of market confidence in an industry that has had little to get excited about for close to a decade.
Proceeds from the sale of 3.7 million shares will be used to repay bank debt and clear the way for a new line of credit. The offering is scheduled for early June. The Napa Valley winery, eighth largest in production in the country, has said it expects to spend $70 million in the next four years, $20 million of it to replant vineyards destroyed by phylloxera. 
 Mondavi, which according to an advance copy of its prospectus expects an opening price of $14.50 a share on the Nasdaq, is only the third commercial winery in the United States to go public. It follows the Chalone Wine Group of San Francisco and the Canandaigua Wine Company, based in New York.
For a variety of reasons, banks have been reluctant to lend money to wineries in recent years. So if Mondavi's offering is successful, other large wineries are expected to follow suit. One trade publication mentioned Sutter Home and Glen Ellen Winery as possible candidates.
Jon Fredrikson, an industry analyst in San Francisco, said Mondavi's timing was excellent. "When C.D.'s were paying 10 percent," he said, "the wine industry, which averages about 5 percent on assets, wasn't such a good deal. With C.D.'s paying 3 and 4 percent, it's a different picture.
"Also, the stock market is booming and Mondavi's numbers are impressive. Their sales are up 50 percent over the last two calendar years and, for two years in a row they had the best performance of any premium winery."
From the mid-1980's until very recently, news about the American wine industry has been unrelentingly bad. To a degree it was a reaction to the euphoria of the 1970's and early 1980's, when double-digit expansion was the norm; when it seemed as if the country was on its way to becoming one of the important wine-consuming nations of the world.
Then, gradually but inexorably, the increase in consumption slowed, leveled off and began to decline. Concern about health, vigorous campaigns against drunken driving, and a heightened awareness of the social implications of drinking all took a toll. Moreover, the industry began to realize the United States would never be like Italy, where wine is part of the culture.
At the same time, it seemed that nature and the economy had begun to turn against the wine industry.
First, beginning in 1986, came a six-year drought that affected most of Napa and much of Sonoma and Mendocino counties, the heart of California's premium wine region. Then, phylloxera, the parasite that destroyed much of the world's vineyards in the 19th century, returned. It was first detected in 1983, but by 1990 it was clear that the bug would eventually destroy thousands of acres of prime West Coast vineyards. Uprooting and vine replacement will cost millions of dollars. One analyst calls phylloxera "the billion dollar bug."
Then, mostly because of bad real estate deals, banks no longer took wine makers' calls. Panic set in. Some wineries went bankrupt; others were sold to stronger neighbors.
All during this time, however, there was a strong countertrend. Over all, wine sales were off drastically, but sales of premium wine -- good table wines -- never stopped growing. Then came news reports of the "French paradox," including the assertion on the CBS News program "60 Minutes" late in 1991 that moderate amounts of wine could, in some circumstances, contribute to good health.
Sales of premium wine, especially red wine, soared in 1992; it was the industry's best year in a decade. Table-wine shipments in 1992 were worth $3.2 billion, or 10 percent over the previous year, the largest increase in a decade. Shipments of premium wines, those costing about $4 or more a bottle, were up 16 percent for the year, to $1.6 billion. For the year ending June 30, 1992, revenue was $154 million, up 23 percent from $125 million the year before.
Mondavi's high-profile image in the wine industry is enhanced by Robert Mondavi himself. Mr. Mondavi, 80, is unquestionably the best-known figure in the American wine industry, a master salesman not only for his own wines but for American premium wines in general. (Upon the consummation of the offering, members of the Mondavi family will retain a majority of the outstanding shares.)
The Mondavi company is more than just the mission-style winery founded in the Napa Valley in 1966. That winery produces 700,000 cases of wine a year. Robert Mondavi Wood ridge, the company's winery in the Central Valley, founded in 1979, produces three million cases a year. The Vichon Winery, an operation purchased in 1985, produces 40,000 cases of Napa Valley wines and 60,000 of Coast Selection wines made from grapes grown by the Mondavis in vineyards 300 miles south of Napa.
In 1979, the Mondavis entered into a joint venture with Chateau Mouton-Rothschild of Bordeaux. The result is Opus One, a winery in the Napa Valley that produces a single $50-a-bottle wine in the Bordeaux style. Annual production is 18,000 cases. A separate Opus One winery was built at a cost of some $20 million.
In 1987, the Mondavis purchased a portion of the large Tepusquet Vineyard, at Santa Maria in Santa Barbara County. In 1990, they bought the Byron Winery and 640 acres of grapes in the same area. Byron now produces 25,000 cases a year.
The two other publicly traded winery stocks (both on the Nasdaq) have not performed spectacularly. Chalone's share price fell 50 cents yesterday, to $6.75, compared with a high of $9.50 in April 1992. Canandaigua closed at $19.25 a share, up 25 cents on the day but down from a high of $25.50 in May of last year.
Canandaigua is a large business, producing 18 million cases of wine and wine coolers annually under more than 70 labels. It's best-known product is Wild Irish Rose, an inexpensive, fortified wine. The Chalone group includes three small premium California wineries -- Chalone Vineyard, Acacia Winery and Carmenet Vineyard -- and two partnerships, the Edna Valley Vineyard, in the Central Coast region, and Canoe Ridge Vineyard, near Walla Walla, Wash., a joint venture with a group of Washington State investors.
Chalone also has a cross-investment arrangement with Domaines Barons de Rothschild, owners of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild and other wine properties in France, Chile and Portugal. The Domaines Barons de Rothschild have no connection with the branch of the family that owns Chateau Mouton-Rothschild, with whom the Mondavis operate Opus One.
In promoting its stock, Chalone has never emphasized dividends or long-term appreciation. Rather, its quarterly statements talk about wine bargains available only to shareholders and list shareholder trips to Chateau Lafite-Rothschild or Los Vascos, the Rothschild's Chilean property. Chalone's annual meeting is a social event held at one of the more picturesque wineries, with not too much emphasis on financial matters.
The Mondavi share offering, prepared by Goldman, Sachs and Company and the California underwriters Hambrecht & Quist Inc., makes no mention of junkets. But given the Mondavi flair for showmanship, and Robert Mondavi's abhorrence of being second to anyone, the winery's new role as a public company should be fascinating to follow.
 
TASTINGS
Gewurztraminer, Late Harvest, 1989, Navarro Vineyards, Anderson Valley; Sweet, Cluster Selected; about $15.
 
With a name like this, a crib sheet might be in order. But first, it really is a good wine. You probably know gewurztraminer. It's the intensely fruity, spicy grape that made the Alsace region of France famous. Late harvest means that the grapes were left on the vine well after the regular picking season. In good years, they shrivel up, becoming almost pure sugar with intense flavors of the grape. Navarro Vineyards, in Mendocino County in California, has built a reputation for producing quality dessert wines. The sweetness is balanced by natural acids. "Cluster selected" means that the pickers took only those clusters of grapes that are ripe enough for a late harvest wine. The wine is sold in half bottles because it is a rich, almost syrupy after-dinner drink. It is also a bargain, compared with the German and Alsatian equivalents.

HEADLINE: Fresh, Low-Fat, Healthful Food (On a Plane?)

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
AS planes settle into their cruising altitudes for the high travel season this summer, vacation-bound travelers may be surprised at what flight attendants dispense from the food carts.
There could be pizza from Pizzeria Uno on American Airlines, Muslim dinners for some passengers on Kiwi International Air Lines, kosher hamburgers for children on El Al, salt-free grilled tournedos for a passenger with high blood pressure flying in Air France economy class and a choice between Western and Indian meals on Air India. 
Airline food has fought an image problem longer than Rodney Dangerfield has, even though, compared with root canal or lost luggage, dining 6 or 8 across at 35,000 feet is not all that bad.
In response to food trends and concerns about diet, a number of airlines have started serving food that is fresher, lighter and lower in fat. Breakfast, lunch, dinner and snacks are starting to reflect contemporary tastes -- frozen yogurt for dessert instead of gummy cake with a maraschino cherry, for example. The change is happening in economy class as well as in the more expensive first and business classes.
At the same time, people whose diets are restricted because of medical or religious reasons are taking advantage of an expanded array of meals tailored to their needs, which most airlines offer by advance reservation. Some travelers, especially those who fly frequently on business, order special meals like seafood or vegetarian plates for variety.
These choices, plus new meals for children, like McDonald's cheeseburgers on United Airlines flights to and from Orlando, Fla., have evolved from requests by passengers. And in the cutthroat contest to fill seats, an airline that does not provide a special meal for a customer with special needs could lose that passenger to the competition. Possibly for good.
In surveys, passengers say they pay relatively little attention to meals when choosing a carrier. Nevertheless, when it comes to customer satisfaction, airlines have found that food is a factor. Even though many people can drive an automobile for two hours in bumper-to-bumper traffic with nothing to eat, in the sky they want food. It keeps children quiet, and business travelers can go directly from the plane to a meeting without stopping for a meal.
On long flights, food is twice as important as on shorter hauls, according to a study conducted among 6,339 frequent travelers last fall by J. D. Power & Associates, a marketing and information company in Los Angeles. That study also showed that having a choice in meals is actually more important to passengers than how good the food actually is (but it is less important to them than getting a comfortable headset).
Airlines, determined to keep customers content, have listened. "It's a reaction to consumers who want healthier food," said Joel Crawley, a spokesman for American Airlines.
Economics plays a part, too. Lower fat -- pasta instead of beef at dinner, cereal and a muffin in place of a cheese omelet for breakfast -- coincides with lower cost. "On American, United and Delta, they have found they can make cheaper food better," said Lisa Sanders, associate editor of Frequent Flyer magazine, a monthly consumer publication.
American Airlines began a new meal program in January that emphasizes pasta, chicken, grains and vegetables. In coming months, Delta Air Lines, which revised its menus in first class in early April, serving grilled skinless chicken instead of chicken in a thick sauce, for example, will be making similar changes in economy class.
Kiwi International, a fledgling American airline that began service from Newark Airport in September, emphasizes the quality and freshness of its food. A typical offering might be marinated grilled chicken, brown rice, ratatouille, salad, cheese and crackers, fruit and pastry, served with a glass of mineral water.
In April, Thai Airways, which had served Western food unless a special request was made, started offering a choice of Thai or Continental food in all classes. "Thai has become an 'in' cuisine," said Pandit Chanapai, the general manager of the airline. "So we thought it would be good to give people a taste of Thai cuisine."
On July 1, United Airlines, which began a meal overhaul last fall, will introduce more special meals, including high-fiber meals and ones made specifically for people with gout.
"You can do a lot with vegetarian meals to make them look good," said Kurt Lackner, director of catering operations for United. "You can serve couscous, Basmati rice and grains like that so it's not always just carrots and plain white rice."
Not everybody is convinced. "In some cases, the food is improved," said Ms. Sanders of Frequent Flyer magazine. "It's simpler -- they have eliminated the heavier sauces and the London broil you can't identify -- but it's still airline food, so how good can it be?"
Airline executives say they have offered special meals as long as they can remember. But the number of choices -- including kosher, Muslim, Hindu, diabetic, lactose-free, gluten-free, low sodium, low cholesterol, baby food, peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and lacto-ovo vegetarian -- has grown in recent years.
Among the more exotic special meals are the pepper-free meal on Japan Air Lines and the raw vegetarian meal on Lufthansa German Airlines. The Greek Orthodox and Ethiopian meals served on El Al for Lent or other special observances are also kosher, as is all the food on that airline. Some of the airlines that serve the Far East have noticed that an increasing number of Western passengers order Asian meals.
Over all, a relatively small percentage of passengers -- no more than about 5 percent -- request special meals. They're the passengers flight attendants single out between drinks and dinner, and it's rarely more than a handful on any given flight. But some airlines, notably Lufthansa, Delta and United, report that this number is increasing.
"Some people ask what they can get instead of the regular meal," said Robert Kunikoff, a travel consultant with Mark Allan Travel, an international travel agency with headquarters in New York. "It's not a restaurant, but there are some good choices."
Paradoxically, in the five months since American Airlines began revamping its food, the airline has seen the number of requests for some special meals decrease.
"These days, someone who specially ordered a low-fat or vegetarian breakfast may see his seatmate being served the cold cereal and a bran muffin that the rest of the cabin is getting and may regret the special order," Mr. Crawley, the spokesman, said. "People remember the old days, when it was always something greasy."
Connie Baird, the senior analyst for menu design at American Airlines, said the carrier was trying to make food healthier and more appealing. "At the same time, we've actually simplified all the food we serve, and we've become more realistic about what we can do," she said.
Both United and American enlisted the services of top chefs like Charlie Trotter, Larry Forgione, Alice Waters and Wolfgang Puck to help with menu overhaul. Trying to make the food fresher was one result.
Ho-hum. From time to time, one airline or another has announced with great fanfare that its first-class meals were being planned by some famous chef, but such arrangements have rarely had any impact on the food in the main cabin. This time, however, the airlines' efforts appear to be reaching all classes of service.
Neil Monroe, a spokesman for Delta, where requests for special meals have doubled in recent years, said that by providing healthier, lighter food, the carrier hoped the need to provide some special meals would decline. "The special meals themselves may not be more expensive, but the extra handling required on the ground and in the air adds to our costs."
On some flights, like the New York to Miami route, where many of the passengers are elderly and have special dietary requirements, special meals can account for up to 40 percent of the cabin. "Serving special meals is usually not a problem, and it's a way to accommodate the passengers," said Tracy Brog, a flight attendant for Delta. "But on a short flight like from La Guardia to West Palm Beach, when you have 300 passengers and 100 special meals, it gets pretty hectic."
The average cost for food on a major American carrier was $5.86 a passenger last year, up from $5.70 in 1991 and $4.21 in 1985, according to Avitas, an airline consulting company in Reston, Va. The growing use of brand-name products, like cups of "I Can't Believe It's Yogurt" on American Airlines, added to the expense. Most American carriers will not disclose how much they spend on a coach dinner. But at Kiwi International, an average dinner costs $6.
At Air France, which prides itself on its food and has a division that buys ingredients for the caterer in order to maintain control, the cost of dinner in coach is $12, said Pierre Magat, the regional catering manager for North America.
But by responding to consumer demands, many airlines are starting to prove that even a $5 dinner can be healthier and more satisfying than in the past.
And for those travelers who still might not be satisfied because the pasta is not al dente or the grilled mesquite chicken is dry, there is always the option of ordering the Western vegetarian meal, the seafood dinner, a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, a fruit plate, a Hindu meal. . . .

HEADLINE: A Channel for Culture To Be Offered to Cable

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
Think of it as C-Span for the intelligentsia, ESPN for mind games or MTV for fans of heavy reading.
The Public Broadcasting Service, together with its two flagship stations, WGBH in Boston and WNET in New York City, announced yesterday that it was starting a cable channel devoted exclusively to cultural affairs. The new channel, called Horizons TV, will show events like university lectures and debates, museum symposiums, public readings and forums on the arts. 
 The sponsors of Horizons TV said they hoped to have the channel up and running by the end of 1994. They said virtually all of the channel's programming would consist of taped events, at least initially.
At a news conference yesterday at the New York Public Library, Lawrence K. Grossman, the former president of PBS and of NBC News, who is the president of the new venture, said, "There's a wealth of great minds, and an opportunity to bring them to a greater audience is irresistible." What C-Span did to increase the visibility of the average Senator, Mr. Grossman said, Horizons TV will do for Nobel laureates and National Book Award winners.
The promotional video for the channel has lectures by Kurt Vonnegut, Stephen Jay Gould and Walter Cronkite, and readings by Alice Walker and Eudora Welty.
While the organizers of Horizons TV acknowledged that the public appetite for academic topics was limited, they said that the channel's programming could be produced so inexpensively that it would need only a modest audience to support it. They said they would start the channel once cable systems serving 5 million subscribers had agreed to carry it. Nationwide, about 60 million households subscribe to cable television.
Mr. Grossman said that the channel had no commitments from cable operators yet but that many had expressed interest. He said individual cable systems would decide whether to offer the channel as part of a basic cable package or to charge extra for it.
Mr. Grossman said Horizons TV would not receive Federal money. He said it would rely on cable subscriber fees and advertising but would not allow advertising to interrupt programming. He said projections called for the channel to be self-supporting after four years.
Cable analysts yesterday voiced some skepticism about the project. While the cable industry is laying plans for a world of 500 channels, most cable systems are filled up now. They are also confronting the economic uncertainties of re-regulation and are looking for programming that will maximize their profits.
"If it doesn't really help a cable company, why would you get a lot of carriage?" said John Tinker, a media analyst for Furman, Selz.
Market research sponsored by Horizons TV shows that many of the viewers who would be most interested in the channel are those who do not watch much television or even subscribe to cable. This could discourage cable systems from carrying Horizons TV. Or, as Marshall Cohen, who conducted the research, argued, it could encourage them to carry the channel in the hopes of attracting new subscribers.

HEADLINE: Girl, 6, Hit by Car and Critically Injured on the Way to School

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
A 6-year-old girl whose mother was walking her to school on the Upper West Side yesterday morning was critically injured when a van forced a car up onto a sidewalk, hitting the girl, the police said.
The driver of the van, who was ticketed for making an unsafe lane change, had a history of moving violations and was involved in a personal injury accident in August, the police said. He had accrued eight license suspensions over several years, which he resolved by either paying outstanding tickets or scheduling court appearances. 
 The accident occurred shortly after 8:30 A.M., when the streets were teeming with people on their way to school or work.
The girl, Sunya Margulies, described by neighbors as friendly and intelligent, was walking with her mother, Vicky, to Public School 87 on West 78th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, where she is a first grader.
 
Friendly With Neighbors
 A neighbor of the Margulieses, Lynn Rosenzweig, 23, who said she sometimes baby-sits for the little girl, heard about the accident and said, "Oh my God, that's the girl I babysit for."
Ms. Rosenzweig, crying, called Sunya "an adorable, wonderful girl" and "very, very intelligent."
"I felt an immediate bonding with her," she added.
The doorman at the apartment building where the Margulieses live at 800 West End Avenue said Sunya is "a very friendly" child. "She's talking with me every time she comes around," said the doorman, Domingo Baez. He said she and her mother had recently moved in to the building from an apartment near the scene where she was hit yesterday.
A police spokesman, Detective Joseph K. McConville, said the accident occurred when an 1981 Chevrolet van driven by Luis Deno, 35, of 736 Riverside Drive, was heading south on Broadway and cut off a car driven by Sermy Onelien, 54, of 200 West 81st Street. Mr. Onelien's car swerved out of control, hit Sunya and slammed into La Caridad, a popular Cuban-Chinese restaurant on the southwest corner of Broadway at 78th Street.
The driver of the van drove away as a witness wrote down his license plate number, but he turned himself in to the police a little later. He was charged with moving from a lane unsafely, punishable by a maximum $100 fine and 15 days in jail. The driver of the car was not charged.
Mr. Deno, who came from the Dominican Republic a couple of years ago, is an unemployed cabdriver who has a wife and three children, his brother, Emerson, said last night.
He said his brother was driving around and was not aware at first he had caused an accident. He only learned of it when his sister-in-law beeped him to say reporters were showing up at his apartment. When he learned he was being sought by the police, he went to the nearest station house.
"My brother said he was just driving and he didn't see nothing," Emerson Deno said.
 
Smashed Gates and Glass

Late yesterday, Sunya was in stable but critical condition with head injuries in the pediatric intensive-care unit at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, said a hospital spokeswoman, Barbara Quinn.
Last night, in the lobby of the Margulieses' apartment house, Lucchi Grant, a painter from France, said that Sunya is the center of her mother's life. "She was so sweet, that little girl," she said. "She seemed so grown up. She had a wisdom about her."
Another neighbor, Minnie Johnson, recalled: "I'd see her in the morning, walking hand in hand with Sunya down the street to the bus stop. It was really cute."

HEADLINE: Time to Discipline the Democrats

 BODY:
Representatives Dave McCurdy, Charles Stenholm and fellow moderate-to-conservative Democrats are disgruntled. They're threatening to vote against President Clinton's economic plan because, they contend, it betrays the "New Democrat" logo of the campaign in favor of the party's liberal penchant for tax-and-spend.
The threat is serious and, if mismanaged, could cripple the Clinton Presidency. Voters put Mr. Clinton and a Democratic Congress in office with the expectation that the Democrats would behave like a party -- ending gridlock and enacting the President's economic package. The leadership credentials of both the President and his party will surely suffer if he and the party's Congressional leaders cannot soon whip their colleagues into line. 
 Messrs. McCurdy and Stenholm are responding to middle-class constituents who complain, with justification, that they elected Mr. Clinton because he vowed to lower their taxes, cut wasteful Federal spending and reduce the oversized deficit. What Mr. Clinton now offers them instead is a hundred-billion-dollar tax hike, minimally reduced Federal spending and a deficit barely below George Bush's levels.
These are legitimate concerns. The response is misguided. The oversimplified, Perot-like remedy Mr. Stenholm offers -- a cap on entitlement spending -- hits the wrong people at the wrong time for the wrong reason. That's a powerful set of wrongs.
An expenditure cap will victimize the poor. It will also victimize the economy. During economic slowdowns, outlays for food stamps, unemployment compensation and welfare rise automatically; the increased spending serves the dual purpose of helping the disadvantaged and pumping up private spending just when the economy is suffering. The way Mr. Stenholm structures the cap threatens these important protections.
Further, Mr. Stenholm ignores the reasons entitlements have spiraled out of control. Non-medical entitlements other than Social Security have actually fallen after accounting for inflation. Health benefits under Medicare and Medicaid have exploded because of overall inflation in medical costs. If, as Mr. Stenholm proposes, Congress goes after only the Federal programs, leaving private insurance alone, it would interfere with the overall reform the White House is about to put before Congress. Indeed, if there are savings to be made by reforming Medicare and Medicaid, the task force will grab every penny to pay for extending coverage to the uninsured -- the key component of its plan.
If entitlement caps aren't the answer, how about big hits at non-defense discretionary spending? Congress, at Mr. Stenholm's insistence, has already knocked about $50 billion out of Mr. Clinton's long-term budget plan -- probably forcing it to gut Mr. Clinton's proposed investments in infrastructure and training that make up the core of the "New Democrat" package the two Congressmen profess to admire.
So here's Mr. Clinton's dilemma. He can't cut discretionary spending (a) because Congress has whacked away too much already and (b) because programs to invest in America's capital base are crucial to long-term economic recovery. He can't cut entitlement spending without reforming health care, which will take years to accomplish. He could rightly propose steeper defense cuts, but that would not endear him to his party's conservative wing.
That leaves Mr. Clinton only one, unpleasant option: Fight off Mr. Stenholm's misguided challenge. Mr. Clinton must persuade Mr. Stenholm and friends to back off or threaten them into it. This is no time to coddle those who break ranks. It is time for Thomas Foley and other Congressional chieftains to enforce discipline and exercise the leadership that comes with their exalted station.
For his part Mr. Clinton could help by making believable pledges that health-care reform will eventually produce big savings and that he will return after the 1994 elections to the task of bigger spending cuts.
Mr. Stenholm's and Mr. McCurdy's sentiments are understandable, but their responses are poorly conceived, illogical and aimed more at their own aggrandizement than the success of their President and party. Mr. Clinton needs to calm the dissidents, and they need to think a lot harder about what's good for the country.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Tax Break Fattens the Banks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Puerto Rico Fighting to Keep Its Tax Breaks for Business" (front page, May 10) misses an important point in describing the role of banks in the island's economy. 
 While major mainland financial institutions have established offices in Puerto Rico to satisfy the needs of the Section 936 companies that operate here, their intent is not altruistic. Like the Fortune 500 corporations who shift mainland profits to Puerto Rico to minimize their tax liability, banks have discovered means to use 936 to their advantage.
Banks are allowed to count 936 deposits in their island operations as part of their total United States holdings. Using this to their advantage, mainland banks use deposits originating on the island to fulfill reserve requirements for the Federal Reserve, thus freeing mainland-derived funds for more lucrative long-term investment opportunities abroad.
What's more, little of the available capital in the banks is used to build Puerto Rico. While investigating the potential impact of the loss of 936, the Puerto Rico Senate concluded that the vast majority -- more than 90 percent -- of investments of 936 funds in the island are for a duration of 90 days or less. How can anyone seriously contend that such investments play a positive, essential role in the Puerto Rican economy?
As the banks and corporate America grow fatter, investment in the Puerto Rican infrastructure is sorely lacking. Our drinking water system is unreliable. The sewage treatment is inefficient. The roads that Section 936 employees use to get to work are poorly maintained. Clearly, the "economic miracle" of 936 is not shared by all. As United States citizens, the 3.6 million residents of Puerto Rico deserve better than third-world living conditions. Reforming this inefficient and costly tax credit will bring additional revenue to the United States Treasury and clear the way for a new economic stimulus program that builds Puerto Rico for the benefit of all.
 
MIRIAM RAMIREZ DE FERRER
President
Puerto Ricans in Civic Action
Mayaguez, P.R., May 11, 1993

HEADLINE: Punishing China on Trade Hurts Wrong People

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There must be more productive ways for President Clinton to pressure China on human rights issues than by not extending most-favored-nation trade status, which you propose in "Favor Freedom in China" (editorial, May 10). 
 The revocation of most-favored-nation status could prove so destructive to the growing free-market sector in China that those whose rights we wish to protect would be most harmed. Meanwhile, extending this trade status will further nourish those pushing political and economic reform so that these free marketers will one day have a chance to become the leaders of China who pursue human rights as they make China a responsible world citizen.
While we are all still repulsed by the deaths in Tiananmen Square, do not forget that more than 1 million Chinese demonstrated more than six weeks there. Would such a protest have been possible if not for the influence of the United States in the 20 years since we opened the door to China? Mr. Clinton, by revoking most-favored-nation status and threatening China's economy, risks giving Chinese hard-liners, whose positions would best be served by a return to a state-controlled economy, an excuse to close that door. What say will we then have on human rights in China?
 
GARY DRAKE
Denver, May 11, 1993

HEADLINE: Punishing China on Trade Hurts Wrong People;
Faulty Jobs Argument

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "China Steps Up Spending To Keep U.S. Trade Status" (front page, May 7), I was dismayed to see the assertion quoted that failing to renew most-favored-nation status for China would cost 150,000 American jobs. 
 This argument is based on a Commerce Department estimate that 20,000 American jobs are needed to produce $1 billion in exports. By the same logic, 20,000 American jobs would be gained by forgoing $1 billion in imports. So trading with China, where we run a $15 billion trade deficit, costs us some 300,000 jobs.
That logic is faulty. There is no reason to assume that part or all of the goods we produce for export to China couldn't be exported elsewhere or sold domestically. Likewise, imports are a net benefit to the economy if you factor in the jobs created in importing and the benefit to consumers of cheaper Chinese products.
The marginal benefit of trade with China is important to the United States, but so are human rights and so is avoiding proliferation in missile technologies.
 
MATTHEW CHANOFF
San Francisco, May 7, 1993

HEADLINE: When Disabled Students Enter Regular Classrooms

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHNSON CITY, N.Y.

 BODY:
Merari Vazquez's fellow second and third graders are learning about perimeters. Measuring is hard for Merari, who is mentally retarded and does not speak. But she is part of the group, and her classmates need to find a way she can work with them. They coax her to lie down on a big pad, using her to do their measuring.
Merari is part of a bold but hotly debated educational experiment: teaching even severely handicapped children in regular public-school classrooms instead of separate ones. The idea goes far beyond "mainstreaming," which usually involves milder disabilities; at schools like Merari's, no heads turn at children using wheelchairs, feeding tubes or oxygen tanks. 
 Schools like those in Johnson City, in south-central New York, are rare; no one keeps a nationwide count. But experts say their number is growing. And as it grows, the movement toward "inclusion" is dividing advocates for disabled children. Some hail it as an ethical and educational breakthrough; others believe children's individual needs are being sacrificed in a crusade.
At schools in places like Johnson City and Redmond, Wash. -- which pay for extra aides, special education teachers to modify lessons and teacher training -- children with disabilities from autism to Down's syndrome are flourishing socially and educationally. Their classmates, too, learn empathy and tolerance for those who are different. Moreover, because many schools use the money they would have spent on special education classes to pay for the extra help the disabled students need in regular schools, inclusion does not have to cost more.
But some studies show that in schools that offer inclusion programs with little extra help to these students, children are failing. Some children, particularly those with emotional problems, strain regular classrooms; others may need the smaller, quieter and more individual settings of special education. And inclusion seems to be a daunting task in inner cities, where many teachers face overcrowded classrooms already full of troubled children.
"I'm very pro-inclusion on a philosophical basis, but it isn't working well," said James Ysseldyke, a professor at the University of Minnesota who worked to introduce inclusion in Minneapolis schools as part of a four-year federally financed project. "It's being used with every good intention to do some terrible things to kids."
 
With Training, A Program Works
 Johnson City is a small, largely blue-collar suburb of Binghamton with 3,000 children enrolled in its four schools. The school district has been innovative for 20 years, recognized by the Education Department as a national model, both for its students' high test scores and its creative teaching methods. Since 1986, Johnson City has moved all but 14 of its nearly 200 special education students to regular classrooms; as many as 10 percent of the students in any given class may be disabled in some way.
Though no one knows exactly how many schools like Johnson City's there are now nationwide, partly because there are so many forms of inclusion, they are clearly reaching thousands of children. In the 1989-90 school year, the last year for which figures were available, 6 percent of children with multiple disabilities and 6.7 percent of mentally retarded children, for example, were in regular classrooms, according to the Education Department.
But statistics can be misleading, particularly because states or schools with low percentages of children in special education do not say whether disabled students receive extra services in regular classrooms.
In New York City, where 15,000 students with severe disabilities are taught in separate schools, 30 are being placed in regular kindergarten and first-grade classrooms in six schools as part of an experimental program.
Johnson City schools are full of sights that in other schools would be extraordinary. Some of the desks have charts with letters and numbers, for children who cannot speak and need to point to communicate.
A classmate casually tucks C. J. Shearn's books in the back of his wheelchair as C. J. rolls himself to his next sixth-grade class, pausing as other students slap him five. When Bobby Westcott needs to stop playing to breathe with his oxygen tank, his kindergarten classmates matter-of-factly take a break, too.
At the Emily Dickinson School in Redmond, an affluent suburb of Seattle, Andy Heilman, 12, plans to share a bunk at summer camp with Cameron Archibald, who cannot read or write, must be fed through a tube and suffers from seizures. The other day, when Cameron was upset at having to leave class to return a book to the library, Andy took his arm. 'I'll be here when you get back, okay, Cam?" Andy said.
Such comfort and friendliness do not come automatically. Students in Redmond were given training in sensitivity before the special-education students entered their classrooms. And in Johnson City, teachers show children how to treat on another.
Lori Sinicki, a special education teacher who teaches in inclusive classrooms at Johnson City Senior High School, says it is attitudes like these that set Johnson City apart. "We're demystifying disabilities," she said. "But we don't just say we're putting kids in the classroom for socialization. There has to be learning going on."
Indeed, a study of the district by Christine Salisbury, then a professor at the State University of New York at Binghamton, found that test scores of both disabled and regular students continued to rise over a three-year period after they were put in the same classes. She has not measured beyond that period.
To make sure all children learn, Mrs. Sinicki and other special education teachers work closely with regular teachers. Disabled children are placed with others their own age. The teachers change teaching materials, making tapes of books for children who have trouble reading or adding maps and charts for children who need a visual presentation of information. They alter tests, making some multiple choice so that children who cannot write can point to the right answers. Teachers set different goals for different students; some might get top grades if they learn part of the material.
Parents say they are delighted. Pat Poliziano's son Andrew, who has multiple handicaps, spoke his first words and made friends in his first-grade class at Lincoln Elementary School in Johnson City. "He progresses better when he has an example," she said. "When we were kids, they trotted kids like him into a special bus and they were never put on view."
 
Seeing Perils In Larger Programs
 But a large chorus of skeptics say that the successes in Johnson City and Redmond are the shining exceptions to a dismal rule. These are small, relatively homogeneous and innovative districts. But in most schools, they say, inclusion means depositing children in regular classrooms without extra help for them or specially trained teachers.
"Take the teacher where 20 percent of her kids speak Spanish, 10 percent Hmong; she's got 37 kids in her classroom now. Talk to her about including a kid who needs an aide, and she'll look at you crosswise," said Dr. Mary Wagner, director of the National Longitudinal Transition Study of Special Education Students, the largest such study of students' academic results.
Her study of high schools found that while disabled students in regular classrooms made more friends and fitted better into groups, the longer they spent in regular classrooms, the more likely they were to fail and drop out. For example, 61 percent of students who had learning disabilities failed at least one class when placed in regular education, as against 14 percent who remained in special education classes.
Dr. Wagner and many other advocates for disabled children worry that the inclusion movement will mean that these children will lose what is theirs by Federal law -- the legal right to get special services and the extra money needed to pay for them. With schools under financial pressure, these advocates worry that districts will abolish special education as an economizing device and fail to put the money into support services.
The 1975 law establishing handicapped children's rights to special services called for placing such children in regular classrooms whenever possible, but including a "continuum of services," or a range of programs, including separate schools and separate small classes offering individual help. Several organizations for disabled children, including the nation's largest, the Council for Exceptional Children, say they support inclusion whenever sensible, but insist on keeping separate classes for those children who need them.
"Inclusion doesn't make sense for all kids," Professor Ysseldyke said.
Even in Johnson City, there are dissenters. Howard Rhodes, a special education counselor, says he believes in the ideal of inclusion but adds that Some children do not benefit from it.
To do a better job, he said, the district should offer many more services, including psychiatrists, family counseling and remedial classes.
Dr. Ed Martin, president of the National Center for Disability Services in Albertson, L.I., and a chief architect of the 1975 law, says he has come to believe that separate schools for disabled children have the same legitimacy as historically black colleges. Many of the children he sees in the center's Henry Viscardi School for those with severe disabilities do strikingly better academically and socially. "They rattle off a litany of disappointing experiences they had," he said. "They say, 'I felt left out; kids made fun of me; it didn't work for me.' "
 
Where No Child May Feel 'Inferior'
 The debate over inclusion is consuming the politically active special education community, with true believers on each side. But for many parents, particularly those whose children did not thrive in special education, inclusion offers hope that schools can be changed so they are more hospitable places for their children.
Mary Roadcap, who works as an aide in Johnson City, has a disabled son who dropped out of school. "If my son had been at this place," she said, "he wouldn't have felt inferior." She spent her day helping Darran Caswell, a fourth grader who could not speak and has trouble walking. When children spoke to her, she gently told them that Darran could hear them. She coaxed Darran to participate in the measuring class, and praised him when he lay down on the pad by himself.
"Other school systems don't know what to do with a child who's a little different," she said. "If I can help one person here, it's enough, because nobody cared about my son."

HEADLINE: Congress Gets Briefing On Bank Subsidy Plan

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today told lawmakers for the first time the details of its plan to create a scaled-down Federal fund to subsidize community development banks, which lend and invest in needy neighborhoods.
At a briefing for Democrats on the House Banking Committee, senior Administration officials described a new Community Banking and Credit Fund that would provide hundreds of millions of dollars in capital and technical assistance to specialized financial institutions promoting business, housing, and employment opportunities in deprived communities. 
 The briefing came on a day when President Clinton, touring Los Angeles, was emphasizing the urban-aid programs in his budget proposals.
But the program, outlined by Robert E. Rubin, the President's assistant for economic affairs, and Frank Newman, an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, falls considerably short of what Clinton officials had envisioned before and after the election, when there was talk of creating 100 community development banks and spending as much as $850 million to finance them in the first five years.
 
$382 Million Requested
 The Administration's proposal, as presented today, emphasizes the role of existing financial institutions in community development, including federally insured banks, savings associations and credit unions, and asks for $382 million through the fiscal year 1997, including $60 million in the fiscal year that will begin Oct. 1.
One member of the committee, Representative Bobby L. Rush, Democrat of Illinois, argued that the proposal "does not have a sufficient amount of dollars, particularly given the vastness of the lack of credit in the cities." Mr. Rush, who represents a Chicago district, rose to political visibility nearly a generation ago as a leader of the Black Panther Party
Bankers, who had worried that the Administration was going too far with its initial concepts, welcomed the current approach. "They are not inventing a new system; they are building on the current system," said Edward L. Yingling, a lobbyist for the American Bankers Association. "We feel very good about that."
At the briefing, some Democrats worried that there would not be enough assistance for new organizations that are struggling.
And some Republicans complained about the Administration's proposals.
"There were far better ways to use the community development bank concept to address the needs of distressed communities than this one," said Representative Tom Ridge, Republican of Pennsylvania. "So much for reinventing government," he said. "We have another centralized approach."
Under the Administration's proposal, the money would flow through the newly established fund. The fund would be federally chartered and tax-exempt but would not be a Government agency and would not offer loan guarantees or otherwise make the Government liable for the failure of the new community lenders.
The development banks -- patterned on models like the South Shore Bank of Illinois or the Elk Horn Bank of Arkansas, both of which were often cited by President Clinton during the campaign -- would be expected to invest in some enterprises that traditional bankers might avoid.
The Federal fund would be able to contribute capital, issue grants, make loans, provide deposits and otherwise strengthen the financial underpinnings of the development institutions, according to a memorandum prepared for the Administration's Congressional briefing.
But if there is an equity investment, the fund would not be allowed to control the institution that is being assisted.
And the local institutions must make matching grants: $2 of private money for every dollar of Federal aid, except in the case of loans, where only the interest rate subsidy will have to be matched, dollar for dollar, with private aid.
There are already many kinds of financial institutions that would appear to qualify for aid under the Clinton plan, including loan funds that are nonprofit organizations rather than deposit-taking banks; housing organizations sponsored by the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation, a federally chartered nonprofit organization set up in 1978; and credit unions specializing in community development, sometimes with the help of a revolving loan fund administered by the National Credit Union Administration.
The Administration's program appears to some extent to favor federally insured institutions like banks, since they would be allowed as much as $5 million in direct aid. Uninsured financial institutions would be allowed no more than $1 million each.
Chris Lewis, who researches community credit issues for the Consumer Federation of America, said the emphasis on insured institutions might be one weakness of the plan, since other institutions might merit more assistance than ordinary banks.
"When does a helping hand turn into yet another bankers' handout?" he asked.
