HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Hewlett Net Tops Wall St. Expectations

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company, propelled by its revitalized computer business, reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that surpassed Wall Street's highest expectations -- no small feat given the computer industry's recent financial doldrums.
Investors flocked to the company's shares, which rose $5.125 to close at $84.75 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, where Hewlett-Packard was the third-most-active stock. 
 The maker of computers and electronic equipment said second-quarter net income rose 7.4 percent, to $347 million, from $323 million a year ago. The earnings amounted to $1.38 a share, up from $1.27 a share a year earlier. Financial analysts' estimates for the quarter had ranged from $1.10 to $1.35 a share.
 
Revenues Set a Record
 Net revenues in the latest quarter were up 21 percent, to $5.1 billion, compared with $4.2 billion a year earlier. The latest quarter was the first in the company's history in which revenues exceeded $5 billion.
"This company is a monster company; so when they report these kinds of results, it's a stunner," said Laura Conigliaro, a Prudential Securities analyst, referring to Hewlett-Packard's size and diversity of products. Ms. Conigliaro reaffirmed her buy recommendation on the stock.
The company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said orders in all of its businesses -- computers, test and measurement equipment, medical products and components -- improved during the quarter and hit a record $5.4 billion, compared with $4.2 billion a year earlier.
The strongest growth came in computers, electronic components and medical products. Computer orders rose 33 percent, a broad-based resurgence that went beyond the continually popular high-speed HP Deskjet and HP Laserjet printers to include the company's personal computers, work stations, mini-computers and networking products.
Orders for medical products climbed 32 percent because of demand for electronic patient-monitoring and health-care information systems, while demand for telecommunications products pushed components orders up 33 percent.
"They've got two things going for them that their competitors don't," Ms. Conigliaro said. "They've got a lot of new products, and they have products in areas where the trends are their friends. For example, their printer business is very, very strong."
Despite the gains, Hewlett-Packard officials sounded a cautious note in assessing the future.
 
Caution From an Executive
 "We're pleased with the company's order strength and our product programs have never been more competitive," Lewis E. Platt, Hewlett-Packard's president and chief executive, said in a statement. "But we face a very mixed and uncertain economic environment, as well as intense competition and rapid change in our markets. We also believe that upward pressure on cost of sales is likely to continue."
Hewlett-Packard's cost of goods sold was 58.8 percent of net revenue. That was up from 53.6 percent a year earlier and 58.3 percent in the first quarter, because of competitive pricing pressures and manufacturing preparations for new products.
But analysts said that Hewlett-Packard was characteristically cautious and that the company's costs were well within industry norms.

HEADLINE: BLUE CROSS CHIEF IS REPORTEDLY OUT

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH

 BODY:
Albert A. Cardone will step down as the head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the financially troubled insurer of 8.5 million New Yorkers, a state government official said yesterday.
Mr. Cardone's fate was determined yesterday at a meeting of Empire's board of directors, but the terms of his departure were not known. Mr. Cardone served as both chairman of the board and chief executive of the company, positions he has held since 1987. 
 His departure follows the most difficult period in the company's history. In the last two years, Empire has lost $250 million and its reserves have fallen far below the amount that state regulators consider safe. Last year, the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association put Empire on notice that it must improve its financial position or face ejection from the organization.
 
Statement Expected
 A statement from Empire was expected this morning, according to three board members who were at an unusual meeting that lasted into the evening yesterday. The board members declined to discuss what had happened at the meeting.
The state official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said he was informed by a participant in the meeting that Mr. Cardone was leaving the company.
Throughout the late afternoon and evening, officials and board members gathered in Empire's executive offices on the 26th floor of the company's headquarters on Third Avenue in midtown Manhattan. Some passed reporters as they left the building, refusing to talk. A few hid their faces behind newspapers or books.
Spokesmen for Empire did not return repeated telephone calls last night, and a woman who answered the telephone at Mr. Cardone's home said he was not there.
Empire, the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer, provides medical insurance for people in 28 counties from the New York City area to Albany. It handles about $7 billion in claims for those clients.
In addition, Empire administers Medicare claims under two contracts with the Federal Government.
As the company's finances have worsened, Mr. Cardone has had to seek repeated rate increases from the state. Last December, the Insurance Department approved a 25 percent rate increase.
Mr. Cardone's stewardship of the company has come under attack in recent months on a variety of issues, including poor handling of Medicare claims, allegations of fraud brought by a major corporate customer and complaints of an autocratic management style.
His tenure has been marked by internal turmoil, and his blunt and confrontational style has angered many top executives. Dozens have quit or been forced out in recent years.
 
Cardone Is Faulted
 In recent weeks, the state insurance superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, has criticized Mr. Cardone for failing to keep the board informed about problems in the company. Mr. Curiale has urged that Mr. Cardone step down as chairman of the board if he is to continue as the company's chief executive.
Two developments this month have caused headaches for Mr. Cardone, and an official speculated that board members were angered that they learned about the problems in the newspaper, rather than from him.
One was that the Federal Government had notified Empire that its handling of $1.7 billion in Medicare claims for doctors' services was so poor for the last three years that Empire's contract for the processing might be canceled.
The other was that American Telephone and Telegraph had accused Empire of defrauding A.T.&T.'s medical benefits plan for nearly a decade by sending the company inflated hospital bills and pocketing the difference.
In March, The New York Times reported that Empire lost tens of millions of dollars over the last decade through a series of management mistakes, offered lucrative contracts to insiders and spent freely on management perquisites. Mr. Cardone receives $600,000 a year, travels first class and is provided with a chauffeur-driven Lincoln Town Car.
Blue Cross and Blue Shield organizations around the country are under increasing scrutiny for their management and spending practices. Congressional investigators, who in the last year have looked into the financial and business practices of several Blue Cross organizations, are now looking into whether management problems have played a role in Empire's recent losses.
Empire is the subject of an inquiry by the Senate permanent subcommittee on investigation, which has subpoenaed records from Empire and the New York State Insurance Department.
Mr. Cardone had said in recent interviews that Empire was shoring up its reserves and that by the end of the year it would meet criteria set by the national association and by the New York State Insurance Department.
Losing the Medicare contract, which Empire and its predecessors have held for decades, could cost the company $63 million.
 
Performance Criticized
 In a letter sent to Empire on April 27, the Health Care Financing Administration, which is part of the Department of Health and Human Services, sharply criticized the insurer and called some aspects of its processing of doctors' bills "abysmal."
Empire has fallen to 45th place in the financing administration's ranking of service provided by the 47 companies around the country that handle Medicare claims for doctors' bills. And it has dropped to 46th in the ranking of 51 handlers of Medicare claims for hospital bills.
The A.T.&T. charges were made in a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Newark, which A.T.&T. filed after Empire repeatedly blocked attempts by A.T.&T. auditors to examine Empire's records. The lawsuit also named six other Blue Cross organizations for which Empire handled billings.
The dispute between Empire and one of its larggest corporate clients comes at a time when the financially troubled nonprofit insurer is losing some of its best corporate customers to commercial insurance companies that offer lower rates and say they provide better service.
Michael Blumenfeld, a spokesman for Empire, said earlier this month that the fraud allegations were unfounded, and noted that Empire had agreed to permit A.T.&T. to examine its records.
The suit accuses the insurers of fraud and racketeering under provisions of Federal civil law and seeks an unspecified amount of damages from Empire and the other Blue Cross affiliates.
A.T.&T. has declined to say how much it believed it has been overcharged. But the fact that A.T.&T. has gone to court over the matter and the fact that the allegations cover nearly a decade indicate that the amount of money at stake is substantial.
 
Scrutiny Rises
 Last month, a long-awaited audit of Empire ordered by the state concluded that its management had been slow to react to accelerating changes in the insurance marketplace. Among other findings, the audit maintained that Empire trailed the rest of the industry in expanding its managed-care programs and in developing modern computer systems, both of which contributed to heavy losses in recent years.
But the audit, performed by Arthur Andersen & Company, maintained that Empire's poor financial performance had resulted primarily from economic forces beyond the control of management.
Empire officials said they were gratified by the audit's support for their contention that the company's losses of $250 million over the last two years were largely unavoidable. But the audit stopped far short of giving Empire's management a clean bill of health.
"In a dynamic, volatile health care market, Empire has been an autocratic, functionally organized, hierarchical organization that has been slow to react to the pace of change," the audit stated. "In an earlier era -- when the pace of change was slower and competition less intense -- Empire's culture and operating environment may have served it well. Today Empire is neither organized nor managed to become a market leader in innovation or quality improvement."
Mr. Blumenfeld, Empire's spokesman, said last month that the board would seriously examine all of the audit's recommendations, including the division of Mr. Cardone's responsibilities.
The larger issue may have been whether the board ultimately lost confidence in Mr. Cardone, who has become a lightning rod for criticism of the company. Mr. Curiale, the insurance superintendent, has said that Mr. Cardone is "his own worst enemy" and has created huge public relations problems for the company through what appears to many ratepayers as an extravagant corporate life style. He received a $60,000 retroactive pay raise in 1991, shortly after appealing to the state for a large rate increase, Mr. Curiale pointed out.
But the audit may have supported Mr. Cardone's case, to some extent. It dismissed as unjustified the recurring criticism of the company's salary levels and administrative expenses.
But the audit concluded that, "based on comparisons to various insurance executive compensation surveys, Empire's officer-compensation levels are reasonable." And with regard to travel and entertainment expenses, it found that "Empire's policies are stringent when compared to comparable private corporations and in fact may impair the ability of Empire's marketing and sales organization to compete in the larger group market."

HEADLINE: CLINTON PUTS DOWN DEMOCRATIC REVOLT ON ECONOMIC PLAN

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Backed by his party's Congressional leadership, President Clinton appeared today to have quelled a revolt by conservative Democrats in the House who had demanded more spending cuts, fewer taxes and caps on benefit programs like Medicare.
But some of the rebellious Democrats insisted, at least for public consumption, that the White House still lacked the votes to pass the President's economic package. And no sooner had the Democratic leadership declared the revolt among House Democrats over than a similar challenge began to take shape among a group of conservative Democrats and moderate Republicans in the Senate.
 
Boren Leads Dissent
 In what threatened to be a serious setback for the President, the bipartisan group, led by David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, reached agreement tonight on a plan to swing the Clinton budget sharply away from higher taxes and toward more spending cuts. 
 Their plan is to be announced Thursday at a news conference in the Capitol by Senator Boren and by Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri.
Aides to the Senators said tonight that the bipartisan plan was not meant to scrap the Clinton budget, but to remove provisions that they see as insurmountable obstacles to its passage.
They said that the spending cuts in the Boren-Danforth plan would lead to greater deficit reduction, not simply replace revenues from proposed tax increases -- increases they hope to trim. The aides said the plan would "dramatically" increase the cuts in spending programs, particularly entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security, which would be capped.
 
Visit From Perot
 Such a coalition could pose a formidable challenge to the President's tax bill when it reaches the Senate Finance Committee, after its expected passage in the House next week.
While Mr. Clinton was trying to hold his Democratic coalition together, Ross Perot, the independent who has harried the Administration since it took office, was just down the hall telling a group of freshmen Republican Congressmen that the Clinton budget was the old "tax and spend, and that's not what the American people want."
Mr. Perot, who had been invited by the House Republicans to express his views, said Mr. Clinton's proposal to create a deficit-reducing trust fund was "the biggest hat trick in years." [Page A18.]
Only a few House Democrats had publicly declared their intention to vote against the President's program and were demanding a vote on a proposals to limit increases in Medicare benefits. But dozens more have said that the program is top-heavy with taxes and does not cut spending sufficiently.
With virtually all 176 House Republicans expected to vote against the tax bill next week, it would only take roughly 40 Democratic defections to give Mr. Clinton what would be a crippling defeat.
Clearly concerned about the potential for trouble, Mr. Clinton, who returned at 1 A.M. from a two-day Western trip, rushed to Capitol Hill less than nine hours later to rally support for his budget package in the House. After meeting with the Congressional Democratic Caucus and party leadership, the President held firm to his program, saying his budget already "does a lot of what they want."
He won a strong public show of support from the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, and the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine.
 
Talks to Continue
 After Mr. Clinton's morning meeting with House Democrats, Mr. Foley told reporters, "I think the caucus today indicated very strong support across the spectrum of our party in support of the President's program, and I think that there is a clear indication that we will pass the bill next Thursday."
Mr. Foley added, though, that there would be continued discussions with conservative factions of the party about "various means of insuring that the deficit is reduced," like controlling Medicare spending through Mr. Clinton's pending health-care proposals, or through some other more flexible spending cap that could be introduced outside the budget "in the future."
But for now, Mr. Foley quickly added that "we're going to go forward" with Mr. Clinton's proposed budget. "We have no plans at this point to change the basic program before it's voted on next week," he said.
 
Disagreement on Support
 Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, who, along with Representative Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, led the conservative Democratic challenge, disagreed with Mr. Foley's vote count.
"The President was very good today," Mr. McCurdy said. "He may have helped a number of people make up their minds who were undecided. But my read is that unless there is a change on the entitlement cap, and some recognition that we need to work with the Senate on the energy tax, that the votes are not there. Every time I talk to people they say they are not going to vote for it."
Mr. McCurdy, who was removed as chairman of the House Intelligence Committee earlier this year by Mr. Foley after openly seeking a post in the Clinton Cabinet, added, "We are placed in the position of looking like rebels when most of us were the earliest supporters of Bill Clinton."
Under House rules, the leadership tightly controls whether an amendment altering the budget is brought to the floor for a vote, and with the Democratic leadership apparently backing the President, such a vote now seems highly unlikely. The Republicans and conservative Democrats together would not appear to have enough votes to make a serious challenge.
Representative Stenholm said after today's meeting with the President that he was not backing down and that he was going to continue to try to push his case because he believed it would actually help the President.
 
Few Will 'Go to Wall'
 He said that there were 60 to 80 House Democrats who shared his views, but he conceded that only "a smaller number" would really be ready to "go to the wall" and spurn the President. Mr. Stenholm said that he opposed the President's proposed energy tax, but that if he failed to get it killed he would still vote for the budget.
In the Senate, however, the Democratic leadership does not have such tight control as in the House, and the alternative Boren-Danforth proposal would present a major problem. Mr. Boren is a crucial swing vote on the Senate Finance Committee, where the Democrats hold only an 11-to-9 majority.
Mr. Boren and Mr. Danforth drew up the alternative budget in his office late today with Senators John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana; Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota; John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine. All but Mr. Cohen are members of the Senate Finance Committee.
It is not clear whether all members of the group fully support the Boren-Danforth proposals.
 
Standing by Energy Tax
 Asked about an alternative to his energy tax, Mr. Clinton told reporters after meeting House members: "Let me remind you that when Secretary Bentsen announced that we would support a deficit reduction plan that included an energy tax that would promote energy efficiency and environmental responsibility, that's when the interest rates started to drop. So I think we ought to stay there with it. I think it's a good part of the program, and I think we can pass it."
During the House caucus, one of the biggest fears raised by many Democratic Congressmen was that they would vote in favor of the energy tax in the House, pay a political price back home and then see Mr. Clinton compromise when the bill gets to the Senate in order to win Republican support. That, they feared, would leave them in the worst situation: having voted for an unpopular provision that the Republicans would be able to take credit for killing.
At one point Representative Charles Wilson of Texas told the President: "I don't like it, but I'll go out on a limb."
Participants in the meeting said Mr. Clinton responded, "If you'll go out on a limb, I'll go with you." The Democratic Congressmen erupted in applause and cheers, the participants said.

HEADLINE: New Tally of World's Economies Catapults China Into Third Place

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Saying that traditional measures underestimate the economies in developing countries, the International Monetary Fund has concluded that China's economy is more than four times as large as previously measured. That makes it the third largest, behind the United States and Japan.
The new study, to be released next week, also greatly increases estimates of the economies of India, Indonesia, Mexico, Brazil and other developing countries. 
 Until now, most studies have measured each country's output by valuing its goods and services in dollars, using international exchange rates. Thus, if China's currency weakened, its economy appeared to shrink.
But in the new method, national output is calculated by what goods and services a country's currency will buy, compared with the purchasing power of other countries' currencies.
By this method, the I.M.F. found, China produced about $1.7 trillion in goods and services last year, far greater than most previous estimates of about $400 billion.
 
An Influence on Foreign Aid
 The recalculation means that China's economy, one of the fastest growing in the world, is just slightly smaller than Japan's -- and not No. 10, as previously calculated. It is less than half the size of the United States economy.
Many economists say the new calculation is long overdue and gives a much more accurate picture of the developing world's economy. The study could have far-reaching repercussions in international aid programs, where per-capital income is crucial in determining assistance.
If China's prodigious growth continues, the World Bank said, the combined economies of China, Hong Kong and Taiwan will be larger than the United States economy in less than a decade.
"The main importance of this is geopolitical," said Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "It's a reminder that China is a great power already, which is something many people haven't quite grasped yet."
The new estimates, many economists say, will push policymakers to stop thinking of the world economy as having just three poles -- the United States, Europe and Japan -- and encourage them to add a fourth: China.
"You have over a billion people there, and even with per-capita income that's pretty modest, you have a pretty big overall economy and a growing market for imports," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics.
With China playing a larger role on the economic stage, some economists are wondering whether it should be invited to join the Group of Seven industrial democracies.
"China will have a very different viewpoint from the Group of Seven," said Mr. Bergsten. "It's a developing country; its per-capita income is just an eighth or so of that of the G-7 nations. Besides, China is neither industrial nor a democracy."
 
All That Non-Money Can Buy
 In its new study, the I.M.F. does not measure an economy's size in the traditional way, by translating the local-currency value of output into dollars. Instead, the fund uses purchasing-power parity, which compares currencies according to what they buy at home.
The measure looks at prices of a bundle of goods and services, including food, clothing, housing and transportation, using that yardstick to compare the total value of output in different countries.
Many economists favor this measure, noting that if a country's exchange rate drops 10 percent against the dollar, this should not automatically reduce the size of that nation's economy by 10 percent.
"It's a great triumph that the I.M.F. has made this change, because it gives a more accurate reflection of the world economy," said Robert Summers, an economics professor at the University of Pennsylvania, a leading authority on this measuring method. "Purchasing-power parity has long been the accepted method in the academic community. This measure helps change people's perception of the world, although we should remember that all the distended bellies are still there."
 
Car Is Not a Car Is Not a Car
 Some economists say they will still measure economies using current exchange rates because they they do not fully trust purchasing-power parity. They say it is hard to compare the value of goods in different countries, for instance, to weigh the value of a Chinese car with that of an American car, or of a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan with one in Beijing or Tokyo.
I.M.F. officials said they would now rely mostly on purchasing-power parity in measuring economies, but added that they would not abandon use of exchange-rate measures.
Using the fund's new measure, per-capita income in China was about $1,600 last year, compared with $370 using estimates based on exchange rates. Based on purchasing-power parity, per-capita income in the United States was $22,204 in 1991, the last year for which a range of comparable figures is available.
Using the new measure, India's economy soared in 1991 to $996 billion, the sixth largest, from $285 billion using exchange rates. India's per-capita income in 1991 was $1,150, rather than the $330 calculated using exchange rates.
World Bank economists apply the purchasing-power parity somewhat differently, and their estimate of China's total output is even higher than reckoned by I.M.F. The bank puts the figure at $2.2 trillion in 1990. If one allows for China's brisk growth over the last two years, its output reached $2.35 trillion in 1991 and the $2.6 trillion in 1992, pushing it past Japan to No. 2 position.
Using the new measure, the share of the developing world in global output almost doubled in 1991, to 34 percent, from 18 percent under the older reckoning.
Officials from some developing countries object to using purchasing-power parity because World Bank rules state that countries with annual per-capita income of more than $765 cannot qualify for loans under the most favorable terms, usually 35 years with no interest.
But the World Bank continues to measure economies by exchange rates, and officials said that if they adopted purchasing-power parity, they might have to raise the per-capita ceiling for cheap loans.
The new measure is contained in an annex to the I.M.F.'s World Economic Outlook, which was released in April. The annex, which is to be published next week, puts China's economy at more than 6 percent of worldwide output in 1990, the last year for which global figures are available, up from slightly under 3 percent in 1970. In comparison, the United States represented 22.5 percent of world output, Japan 7.6 percent and Germany 4.3 percent.
The former Soviet Union accounted for 8.3 percent of world output in 1990, but the annex gave no separate figures for Russia's economy.
After several years of internal debate, I.M.F. officials have begun using purchasing-power parity because they are convinced that traditional measures produced invalid results. For example, measuring output by exchange rates indicated that China's economy had shrunk to slightly less than 2 percent of global output, from slightly more than 2 percent two decades ago, even though its economy had grown twice as fast as the world economy.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PULSE: New Jersey;
New Jersey Slump: Go-Go Suburbs Went

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 16

 BODY:
For two decades, New Jersey has been reshaping the American suburb into a powerful magnet for economic growth. But with a four-year recession that is proving deeper for this state than for any other, its grand suburban experiment has hit a roadblock as wide as an 18-wheeler jackknifed across Interstate 80.
It was around Morristown, Parsippany, Secaucus, Edison, Princeton, Mount Laurel and other suburbs that developers and corporations, beginning in the 1970's, began transforming rural towns and sleepy bedroom communities into something much more diverse: places for people to pursue corporate careers, shop, dine out and raise their families far beyond the congestion and blight of the region's big cities.
 
'Models for the World'
 In Central and Northern New Jersey, office parks replaced farmland. Glittering shopping malls eclipsed suburban Main Streets. Thousands of workers began commuting from suburb to suburb instead of into New York City, Philadelphia, Newark and Trenton. 
 So dazzling was the growth of the new suburbs, most of them strung along New Jersey's interstate highway corridors, that they have emerged as textbook studies for urban analysts.
"They are models for the world," said a 1991 book, "Edge City: Life on the New Frontier," by Joel Garreau (Doubleday), which has found its way onto the shelves of planners, scholars and city officials. Analyzing suburban development around a dozen of the largest United States cities, it described New Jersey as Tomorrowland.
Now, tomorrow looks more like the morning after.
In Morristown, Ted Goodman, the town planning director, said a milestone was reached in May, when the monthly meeting of the town Planning Board was canceled for the first time in years. No one was seeking approval for a development.
"In the 1980's, there were so many applications that these meetings would go well past midnight," Mr. Goodman said. If they were to meet, Morristown's planners would probably discuss their problems with existing developments, not new ones.
There is the 16-story office tower, next to Morristown's 170-year-old Green, that was vacated in a corporate reorganization in 1991 by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Across the street is another reminder of the recession's toll -- the Macy's department store, Morristown's largest, which is due to close next month.
 
Scattered Growth
Exacts Fiscal Price
Even among New Jersey fastest-growing suburbs, commercial development has been postponed. And while no one is giving up on the state's "edge cities" as the focus of future growth, economists, business executives and government officials say the edge cities have done little to shield New Jersey from the recession and indeed may be prolonging it.
Experts say that long-term constraints on economic expansion in New Jersey's suburban business centers -- traffic congestion, inadequate sewer and water services, high housing costs and overburdened schools -- are only now catching up with the state. They may persist as obstacles even when the economy improves.
"Only so much can be accomodated in those towns," said Regina Armstrong, an economist for the Regional Plan Association, which analyzes land use and planning in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
For years the association has criticized the region's scattered patterns of business development: They fail to take advantage of existing rail links, destroy open space, force far too much traffic on narrow rural highways and move employment opportunites away from the urban centers.
"The infrastructure is not there," she said. "Growth opportunities in New Jersey have been restricted."
Some New Jersey business people agree. One is Robert Bildner, a 42-year-old entrepreneur who founded his salad and fruit company, RLB Food Distributors, in West Caldwell at the height of the boom in 1985.
In his first year, he said, the fledgling company found a ready market at the specialty foods counters of shopping malls, delicatessens and groceries that were springing up across New Jersey's suburbs. But eight years later, many of the same specialty counters no longer exist.
Although his company is a survivor, Mr. Bildner says the state's economic downturn has only worsened RLB's problems with high housing costs, forcing many of his employees to commute from Pennsylvania, and highway congestion that its delivery trucks battle each day.
"Everywhere you turn there is an obstacle to growth," he said. "I don't see a single thing in this business environment that is encouraging."
 
Optimists Call It
A Breathing Spell
To be sure, many people say the downturn of corporate expansion in New Jersey's growth centers may have opened up future opportunities when the economy strengthens. Some New Jersey towns are taking advantage of the slowdown to widen roads and add water hookups.
"The edge city lives," said Richard W. Roper, director of the Office of Economic and Policy Analysis of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "These communities have become very important players in the New Jersey economy, and they will be the focus of future growth."
Most of the suburban business centers fared far better in the 1980's -- even after the onset of the recession in 1988 -- than other parts of the state, researchers at Rutgers University in New Brunswick found in a study late last year. Ranking job growth by townships and municipalities, it found that most of the 20 top performers were suburban or rural areas far removed from New York and Philadelphia.
Topping its list was Edison, which gained 20,166 jobs. Others among the top 10 were Franklin Township, Parsippany-Troy Hills, Mount Laurel, Morristown and Dover Township.
But since the beginning of 1990, as New Jersey has sunk deeply into recession, many of the fast-growing towns have changed course. Data from the New Jersey Department of Labor, available only up to last June, shows that Edison lost 2,600 jobs, Morristown lost 3,500 jobs and Dover Township lost 1,000 jobs.
 
The Other Side
Of What Goes Up
"It is probably the case that many of these communities will be poised for expansion when the economy picks up," said Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics at Rutgers. "For now, we are frozen in time."
Although experts differ over how much blame, if any, to assign to New Jersey's scattered patterns of suburban business, the state's recession is both persistent and deep. In April, when unemployment in New Jersey jumped to 9.1 percent from 8.3 percent, the state eclipsed California for the unhappy distinction of having the worst unemployment rate of any large industrial state.
During the heady growth of the last decade, New Jersey outpaced almost every other state in personal incomes, job growth and real-estate development. Now, most of the economic engines responsible for that growth are moving in reverse.
"Because the boom went higher, the bust is deeper and lasting longer," said Dr. Seneca. His research shows that New Jersey's recession has lasted 46 months, nearly four times as long as any other since World War II.
The biggest drag is among its chemical plants, auto assembly lines and machine shops and other manufacturers that have been in decline for decades. The process simply speeded up in the last four years. Federal data shows that New Jersey has lost 200,000 jobs since 1989, and 130,000 of the losses were in manufacturing.
 
Building for Tenants
That Never Arrived
The other major industrial decline was in construction, accounting for another 70,000 job losses since 1989 after a boom-and-bust cycle. Home building has slowed sharply and the construction of offices and shopping malls has collapsed.
Most of the overbuilding occurred along New Jersey's interstate highways, and in the same suburban growth centers that attracted the biggest waves of corporate expansion in the 80's, but where the growth has now stopped. Tenants that did not materialize included banks, insurance companies, electronics and telecommunications businesses, and securities firms.
The building binge of the 1980's left vast vacancies. According to Cushman & Wakefield, a real-estate concern, the office vacancy rate in March in Northern New Jersey, including Morristown, Parsippany and several other growth centers, was 25.2 percent, one of the nation's highest.
Economists say another problem has come in spite of the scattered patterns of business development. Because of its ties to New York City, where more than 250,000 New Jersyans still commute to work, many of the more affluent suburbs are dealing with a second recession on their eastern front.
Some New Jersey officials say the state's problems are an outgrowth of a boom in consumer spending that flowed into everything from new-car purchases to electronic toys, real-estate investment and corporate expansion.
 
'Flash in the Pan'
Or Business Saviors?
"There was no significant area of expansion that could be sustained," said Raymond L. Bramucci, the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Labor. "The growth of the 1980's was a flash in the pan."
A major question is whether the growing importance of New Jersey's suburban growth centers has been a fleeting economic windfall, or whether the business corridors that have taken shape along the interstates will, as many suggest, eventually emerge as saviors for the state.
Near Morristown, several edge cities lie along Interstate 287, where business people and municipal officials say they are confident economic expansion will resume sometime in the 1990's. But the recession shows few signs of lifting.
In Bridgewater, 20 miles south of Morristown along the interstate and at the intersection of three other major highways, a large shopping mall opened in 1989 after 10 years of planning. Town officials hoped it would provide a social and retail anchor for a community with no downtown.
The mall, Bridgewater Commons, has by many measures accomplished its mission, as was apparent to any visitor today. Thousands of shoppers trodded between such fashionable stores as Brooks Brothers and Laura Ashley.
But four years after it opened, not all is what was supposed to be in Bridgewater. A large Sheraton Hotel and two office towers, which the town approved to enhance the mall as its new downtown (and which were described in 1991 as being in place in "Edge City"), have not been built. They are among the hundreds of New Jersey real-estate ventures being postponed because of the recession.
 
Mall 'Waiting Out
The Economy'
The hotel and offices "are waiting out the economy," said Kurt Sullivan, the general manager of Bridgewater Commons. A more immediate concern, he said, is that sales by the mall's 165 stores, surprisingly robust during Christmas and earlier this year, have fallen over the last month.
"The jury is still out on whether this is just a glitch, or something bigger, with people reassessing the economy and concerned about their jobs," Mr. Sullivan said.
Elsewhere in New Jersey's edge cities, people debate whether they really want the robust expansion of the 1980's to return.
"The development has gotten way out of balance," said Thomas P. Frascella, the newly elected Mayor of West Windsor, which borders Princeton and is one of a string of communities along Route One in central New Jersey. That area was among the state's fastest-growing corporate centers in the 1980's.
West Windsor rewrote its zoning rules in 1979 to accomodate a surge of development, but less than half the amount of new office and commercial space it had anticipated was built before 1988, when all commercial development came to a halt.
But Mr. Frascella says residential developers have continued to build, even during the recession, and an influx of young families has overburdened the town's schools. As Mayor, he intends to promote West Windsor among office developers, but enact new laws to slow home building.
"Growth is not bad, but unmanaged growth has proven a problem here," he said.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

EMPIRE CHIEF IS LEAVING
Albert A. Cardone will step down as the head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the financially troubled insurer of 8.5 million New Yorkers, a state government official said. Mr. Cardone's fate was determined at a meeting of Empire's board of directors, but the terms of his departure were not known. Mr. Cardone served as both chairman of the board and chief executive of the company, posts he has held since 1987. A1.
 
RECESSION SETTLES IN SUBURBS
For two decades, New Jersey has been reshaping the American suburb into a powerful magnet for economic growth. But with a four-year recession that is proving deeper for this state than for any other, its grand suburban experiment has hit a roadblock as wide as a semi-trailer jack knifed across Interstate 80. A1.
 

MUCH MONEY AND LITTLE WORK
The investment house owned by Gov. Jim Florio's chief aide and another Florio political associate earned more than $1 million in three years even though the firm performed little underwriting work, and in some cases none at all, for the money, according to Wall Street executives, lawyers and government officials who did business with it. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
ELECTION RESULTS
Overshadowed in the community school board races by citywide battles over sex education and school corruption were a series of other, local clashes, many of them about ethnic transition. And from the election results -- which remained incomplete -- a mosaic of gains and losses for minority candidates is emerging. B3.
 
COUNCILMAN CHARGED WITH ASSAULT
Councilman Rafael Castaneira-Colon, a veteran Bronx lawmaker, was arrested and charged with assaulting a woman with whom he has a daughter in a dispute over child-support payments, the police said. At 8 A.M., Mr. Colon, who is 57, surrendered to the police with his lawyer, Murray Richman, at the 43d Precinct, in Soundview. B3.
 
REGION
 
CASINO VOTE IS NEAR
With five days left before the first vote in the Connecticut House of Representatives on whether to legalize a gambling casino for Bridgeport, the measure is still considered a long shot. But a new round of maneuvering in the Capitol has made the question suddenly more volatile. B6.
 
AN OUTSIDER'S CAMPAIGN
For years J. Patrick Gilligan has been telling anyone who would listen how New Jersey's tax system should be overhauled. He said he won praise from some fellow Republicans but no action and that is why, at the age of 72, he is running for governor. "People would listen and promise to bring my ideas before the state party leadership and the Legislature but they never did," he said. "Going through channels hasn't worked, so I'm going right to the people."B6.
 
MINIMUM WAGE STUDY RELEASED
A new study by two labor economists at Princeton University on the effect of a higher New Jersey minimum wage on employment in the state's fast-food restaurants. B7.

HEADLINE: Hurdles for Tax Plan;
Sailing May Turn Smooth in House, But Rough Seas Lie Ahead in Senate

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
President Clinton was able to win support for his tax proposals from Democratic members of the House of Representatives at their meeting in the Capitol this morning because he allayed their worst political fears.
But the flame of opposition he managed to extinguish in the House was a precursor to the serious problems his program faces in the Senate. Unlike the situation in the House, where Mr. Clinton was on firm footing from the start, the rules, style and committee structure in the Senate work to his disadvantage. 
 In public, the opposition of some conservative Representatives to the President's tax plan was generally expressed in substantive terms. Some lawmakers said they wanted deeper cuts in spending and limits on what could be spent on programs, like Medicare and food stamps, in which payments are automatically made to everyone who meets eligibility requirements. Other lawmakers objected to a particular tax, especially the one on fuel, which would hit some industries hard and pinch middle-class families.
 
Fears of Political Risks
 But underlying the substantive opposition were political fears. Rank-and-file Democrats were nervous that the President's plan would not end up actually lowering the deficit. They were even more concerned that they would cast a courageous vote in Mr. Clinton's behalf, and he would then cut a deal in the Senate that undercut those who risked supporting him in the House.
In either case, they foresaw having to defend unpopular votes to raise taxes in their re-election campaigns.
Mr. Clinton's political advisers had spotted the problem, and he dealt with it head on this morning, lawmakers said. This time, he told the Democrats, they would not face what Representative Martin Olav Sabo, the Minnesota Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, calls "the 1990 problem." Pains were taken, Mr. Clinton said, to make sure that his economic projections were not optimistic and that the deficit really would go down.
 
Memories of 1990
 In 1990, after tortuous negotiations, President George Bush and Congressional leaders agreed on a plan of unpopular tax increases and spending cuts that were supposed to lower the deficit by nearly $500 billion over five years.
Unfortunately, no account was taken of the recession that would reduce tax revenues and drive up costs for programs like welfare and unemployment compensation. As a result, while the deficit was indeed smaller by the time of the 1992 election than it would have been in the absence of the budget agreement, it was no lower in terms of actual dollars. That proved to be acutely embarrassing to many politicians, and contributed to the defeat of Mr. Bush and some lawmakers.
The fear that Mr. Clinton would sell Democrats down the river after they supported him with politically risky votes resulted from some cases earlier this year. In one instance, Representative George Miller, the California Democrat who is chairman of the Interior Committee, persuaded fellow Westerners to back the President's proposal to raise fees for grazing and mining on Federal lands. No sooner had they voted to do so than the President withdrew the proposal in the face of opposition from a few Western Senators.
Representative Charles Wilson, Democrat of Texas, said today that voting for a higher tax on fuel would be difficult for him because of the large petrochemical industry in his district. What worried him most, he said, was that he would stick by the President and that Mr. Clinton would then "cut our feet out from under us by compromising with the Senate." Then, he said, Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, would "go home and say, 'Charlie taxed you, but I saved you.' "
Mr. Clinton apparently persuaded the lawmakers that if they went out on a limb, he would not abandon them.
 
Different Situation in Senate
 Such political stroking may not be sufficient in the Senate.
In both the House and the Senate, Republicans are united against the President's program. So Mr. Clinton must rely on Democratic votes alone. And the Democratic majorities are similar -- 59 percent of the seats in the House and 57 percent in the Senate are held by Democrats.
But the House is run by a handful of Democratic generals. All the rest of the members are foot soldiers. Occasionally, one of the troops gets out of line the way Representatives Timothy J. Penny of Minnesota, Charles W. Stenholm of Texas and Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma have this week. When that happens, the rest of the Democrats normally march over them in lock-step.
In this case, Mr. Clinton's tax bill was written by Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois and the other Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee. It would have been futile for one or two of them to break ranks, since the Democrats hold a 24-to-14 majority.
So the measure was approved by the committee last week on a straight party-line vote. And it will almost certainly be voted on by the House next week under procedures set by the Democratic leadership that prohibit or strictly limit amendments. For the bill to go down, about 40 Democrats would have to join with the Republicans, and that is not likely to happen.
 
Unwieldiness of Senate
 The Senate is much more unwieldy. Although the rules on this particular legislation preclude a filibuster like the one by Republicans that killed Mr. Clinton's jobs and stimulus bill last month, the President is starting off in a hole.
There are no foot soldiers in the Senate. Senators march to their own individual beats. In point of fact, there are probably a dozen Democratic Senators who genuinely believe that they and not Bill Clinton should be President. And amendments in the Senate are basically unrestricted.
In addition, the committee ratios in the Senate are much narrower. On the Finance Committee, which handles tax legislation, the Democratic margin is only 11 to 9, meaning that if only one Democrat defects, the bill goes down.
Three of the Democrats on that committee -- David L. Boren of Oklahoma, John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Kent Conrad of North Dakota -- have announced that they oppose one main part of the Clinton bill or another. Mr. Clinton will at the least have to make some concession to bring them around.
This afternoon, these three Senators met with some Republicans to see if they could put together a bipartisan alternative to Mr. Clinton's proposals. This is not a particularly unusual occurrence in the Senate. It would be unheard of in the House.

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Columbia Chief Stresses Role of Teacher

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
Delivering his 13th and final commencement address, Michael I. Sovern, Columbia University's president, called on America's universities yesterday "to tilt the balance back toward teaching" as they wrestle with fiscal problems and strive to fulfill responsibilities in research and public service.
"Our best universities must all acknowledge that we cannot continue to increase the price of a college education and deliver less of the faculty our students' tuition dollars are supporting," said Mr. Sovern, who will step down as Columbia's 17th president on June 30 to return to teaching at Columbia's law school. 
 As students created a blizzard of confetti, streamers and graduation caps, Mr. Sovern conferred nearly 8,000 degrees in commencement exercises for the university's 15 schools and its affiliated institutions, Barnard College and Teachers College.
 
Stephanopoulos Honored
 About 33,000 people attended the commencement ceremony, which was held on the broad plaza of Low Memorial Library on the Morningside Heights campus in upper Manhattan.
Jubilant students, dressed in slate-blue gowns, cheered not only themselves but also George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director and a 1982 graduate of Columbia College, who received the University Medal for Excellence.
The students also became the chorus for Harry Belafonte, the entertainer and human-rights leader, who was one of eight recipients of honorary degrees. Mr. Belafonte roused the graduates into a sing-along of his 1950's hit "The Banana Boat Song (Day-O)."
In a poignant moment, Arthur R. Ashe Jr., the champion athlete and social advocate, was awarded a posthumous honorary doctor of laws degree. The award was accepted by his widow, Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe, who received a standing ovation.
The other honorary degree recipients were: Mary Robinson, the President of Ireland; Susan Sontag, the essayist, novelist and social critic; Gary S. Becker, the Nobel Prize-winning economist; Seymour Milstein, a business leader and philanthropist; Gilbert Stork, a chaired chemistry professor at Columbia, and George E. Rupp, the president of Rice University, who will succeed Mr. Sovern as president of Columbia.
 
540 Graduate From Barnard
 In a separate graduation ceremony for Barnard College, 540 students received undergraduate degrees on Tuesday. Ellen V. Futter, the Barnard president, gave the commencement address. Cyrus R. Vance, a former Secretary of State and United Nations Special Envoy, was among five people to receive a Medal of Distinction, the college's highest honor.
The other recipients were Mr. Ashe; Dr. Elizabeth Davis, the founder of the Harlem Hospital Center's department of psychiatry and a community mental health advocate; Bette Bao Lord, an author and human rights advocate, and Helene L. Kaplan, an attorney, public servant and chairman of the Barnard College Board of Trustees for a decade until 1993.

HEADLINE: Perot Joins With House G.O.P. in Attacking Clinton

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Ross Perot lent his voice to the Congressional rebellion against President Clinton's economic plan today, visiting with freshman House Republicans and embracing their cause as his own.
Opinion polls show that the public holds Congress in low regard, and Mr. Perot has visited Capitol Hill several times since the Presidential election to express his own complaints. But today he saved his sharpest barbs for the man who defeated him in November, delivering them at a news conference made all the more provocative by Mr. Clinton's presence one marble staircase away. 
 Surrounded by more than a dozen admiring freshman Republicans, Mr. Perot mixed dollops of advice with stinging sarcasm as he criticized Mr. Clinton's handling of everything from Bosnia to the Treasury. He called the President's economic package "tax and spend," characterized his proposed deficit-reduction trust fund as "the biggest hat trick in years" and warned that the coming health-care plan would be "a nationwide failure."
Mr. Perot had accepted an invitation from the Republican freshmen days before the President decided to travel down Pennsylvania Avenue to rein in his troops. But once their paths had crossed, Mr. Perot clearly enjoyed competing with Mr. Clinton for attention. The former independent Presidential candidate had been invited to endorse the Republicans' efforts to overhaul Congressional procedures and to enact a line-item veto. The President showed up to deal with challenges from conservatives in his own party that echoed Mr. Perot's own crusade against the deficit.
 
3-Step Program Offered
 Mr. Perot outlined a three-part elixir for the Administration's woes: "Step 1: Get Organized. Fill the slots so you can begin to govern. No. 2: Focus. Do a few things well. And No. 3: Don't fall into the Washington trap of watering everything down like your campaign reform bill."
Lawmakers were divided over the impact of Mr. Perot's visit. Representatives Gerald D. Kleczka, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, said Mr. Perot's effect had been blunted by his failure to offer alternative programs.
Representative Timothy J. Penny of Minnesota, a conservative Democrat who is pressing Mr. Clinton for additional budget cuts and a cap on Medicare and Social Security spending, said Mr. Perot's visit might help his efforts to rework the President's package.
"He turns up the heat a little bit," Mr. Penny said. "He reinforces the image with the public that the President's plan is not serious enough."
Representative Howard P. (Buck) McKeon of California expressed hope that the publicity generated by Mr. Perot's meeting with almost all of the 48 party members of his class would help them build a coalition with conservative, reform-minded Democratic freshmen.
Their invitation to Mr. Perot, Mr. McKeon added, was evidence that they would continue to "break the rules to change Washington."
So far, the Republican freshmen have been stymied because they are a minority inside a minority.
Nevertheless, the Republican freshmen won an intraparty battle to put their party on record for term limits for ranking committee members. They also led the fight to abolish four select committees to save money.
Mr. Perot stopped short of endorsing the Republican freshmen's entire 19-point plan, which would impose term limits and sharp cuts in spending on Congressional operations.
Declaring their fight his own, Mr. Perot said he agreed with their prescription of "let's do chemotherapy" to cure the ills on Capitol Hill. He criticized the seniority system and House procedural rules as undemocratic, saying they are applied by Democratic leaders to throttle the power of backbenchers and the Republican minority.
 
Vow to Spread a Message
 Mr. Perot asked the Republicans to prepare a videotape describing their criticisms of House procedures. He offered to refine the video after showing it to focus groups, and then circulate it around the country.
More senior Republican lawmakers have voiced concerns that Mr. Perot would field third-party Congressional candidates in 1994 who could split their constituency and help elect more Democrats. Mr. Perot said today that he would not support any third-party candidates -- unless neither of the Congressional contenders of the two major parties supported sweeping reforms.

HEADLINE: Finance Officer Who Quit Kodak Will Join Citicorp

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Christopher J. Steffen, whose efforts to streamline the Eastman Kodak Company ended abruptly with his resignation last month, will become a top executive at Citicorp in June, responsible for making the nation's largest banking company more efficient and more profitable.
Mr. Steffen will join Citicorp's six-member management committee as a senior executive vice president and will also be nominated to the board, John M. Morris, a Citicorp spokesman confirmed last night.
 
 
2d Recruitment Try
 John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman and chief executive, tried to recruit Mr. Steffen before he joined Kodak earlier this year, Mr. Morris said. Mr. Reed resumed his efforts after Mr. Steffen resigned as Kodak's chief financial officer. 
 Mr. Morris said Mr. Steffen, who has a reputation as a tough assets manager, would be responsible for improving the productivity of Citicorp's internal operations. With intense competition among banks, profitability has become more dependent on speed and economy in handling deposits, checks, funds transfers and computer operations.
"We've come through a two-year program in which we reduced costs by $1.3 billion" a year, Mr. Morris said. "We are now poised to make what had been a crash diet a way of life."
 
 
An Industrial Background
 Mr. Steffen's background is industrial, not financial, and Mr. Reed has said that he wants to bring industrial management skills to Citicorp.
Another executive at Citicorp suggested that the company's board, which met Tuesday, had urged the hiring of Mr. Steffen. The Citicorp board includes Colby H. Chandler, a former Kodak chief executive who has remained on the Kodak board.
Mr. Steffen, 51, was hired by Kodak in January to the loud applause of Wall Street, which remembered his record of shaping up operations at Honeywell Inc. and Chrysler. As a result, investors added billions of dollars to Kodak's market value as they bid up the stock, which had lagged the market for years.
But on April 28, the stock fell nearly 10 percent, losing more than $1.5 billion in market value, after Mr. Steffen's resignation was announced. His departure followed a dispute with Kodak's current chief executive, Kay R. Whitmore, over the pace of the cutbacks and other changes that Mr. Steffen had demanded.
Since then, Mr. Whitmore, under pressure from major shareholders, has pledged to carry out many of these measures himself.
 
 
Abrasive Ways
 It remains to be seen whether Mr. Steffen, known for his abrasive ways, can better fit into the Citicorp culture.
Mr. Steffen could not be reached for comment last night. A Christopher Steffen registered at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan did not answer telephone calls or return messages left for him.
Citicorp plans to announce Mr. Steffen's hiring this morning and have him meet with other top executives of the company.
Citicorp's drastic cutbacks have helped the company's stock recover from sharp losses in recent years, with its price plunging as low as $8.50 in December 1991. Yesterday, the stock closed at $28.25, up 75 cents for the day, but still below its all-time high of $35.375 in October 1989.

HEADLINE: Turkey Off Balance as Death Ends a Long Rivalry

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, May 19

 BODY:
The election of Suleyman Demirel to the presidency this week after the sudden death of Turgut Ozal in April has thrown Turkey's political system off balance, reduced the country's regional influence and signaled an end to the three-decade-long grip on power of many of the nation's aging political leaders.
"This opens up a new political era," a Western diplomat said. "The dramatic removal of Mr. Ozal from the political scene has ended the confrontation between Mr. Ozal and Mr. Demirel that has defined the political process for years. It has removed the country's two most important politicians from the daily political process and, since neither man prepared a successor, created a degree of instability and confusion." 
 The public battles between President Ozal and Mr. Demirel, who was Prime Minister for the last 18 months, were as much a clash of personalities as policies. While the blunt and often abrasive Mr. Ozal championed broad, expansive schemes to link the country to the central Asian republics and establish close ties with Europe and the United States, Mr. Demirel has always preferred the crafty internal political maneuvering that makes him a consummate deal maker.
Few expect the new President, who took office in a quaintly anachronistic ceremony that included a top hat, white tie and tails, to remove himself completely from politics. But at 68, associates say, he is tired and wants to dedicate the final years of his public life to strengthening the democratic system.
 
President's Only Concern
 "President Demirel wants to make sure the office of the presidency is placed above politics, and he believes this was not always the case in the past," said Akin Gonen, a Cabinet minister and close associate. "This is the only thing that concerns him now."
Much of what Mr. Ozal began -- market reforms, the safeguarding of freedom of expression and respect for human rights -- still falls short of European and American standards. The Government's bill on judicial practices, approved last year and intended to safeguard the rights of defendants, has yet to extend to cases involving terrorism.
Human rights groups continue to charge that the security forces in the southeast, where a state of emergency remains in place to combat attacks by Kurdish rebels, engage in torture and extrajudicial detentions. There is currently a cease-fire between the Government and the rebels.
Mr. Demirel, a conservative, has repeatedly bounced back from political obscurity to prominence. In three decades of political life he headed seven governments. He was deposed by military coups in 1971 and 1980. But his election by the Parliament on Sunday to a seven-year term as President, with 244 of 450 votes, was undoubtedly his greatest triumph. As he was sworn into office, military chiefs, some of whom once plotted against him, watched mutely from the balcony in the chamber.
"This is a victory for democracy," an exuberant Mr. Demirel said.
 
Final Link Is Broken
 But while the loss of Mr. Ozal, who collaborated with the military Government that took power in 1980, cuts the final link between the current political leaders and the old military Government, it also takes from Turkey its greatest visionary since Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder and head of modern Turkey until 1938.
Turkey has also lost much of its importance to the West with the end of the cold war, a fact that seems to have been more quickly accepted by Mr. Demirel than his predecessor. Turkey is no longer a front-line outpost against Soviet expansion or as important a staging area for NATO. Germany is phasing out its military aid and the United States, which gives $450 million a year, is expected to cut back its allocations.
Mr. Ozal died of a heart attack on April 17, shortly after returning from a punishing trip to the central Asian republics. He hoped these would one day fall under Turkish influence, making his country, as he liked to say, the most prominent power "from the Adriatic to the Great Wall of China."
 
The Reluctant Republics
 He was working to establish a vast network of highways, railroads, oil and gas pipelines, and telecommunications systems, as well as trade and cultural links, that would bind the republics to Turkey.
Although he had lost his political mandate after Mr. Demirel's True Path Party defeated his Motherland Party at the polls in 1991, Mr. Ozal continued to advocate a more aggressive foreign policy. The former President, who backed the coalition effort against Iraq, called for Turkish military action in Bosnia and Herzegovina and along Turkey's borders to stop Armenian attacks against Azerbaijan.
Mr. Ozal frequently used his office to delay legislation and major appointments he did not support, provoking angry denunciations from the Prime Minister.
These grand schemes now have few champions, especially as Turkish leaders have discovered that many of the republics are not as keen as they are to forge ties, and that the infrastructure, after 70 years of Soviet ineptitude, is too devastated to rebuild with Turkish resources alone.
Mr. Demirel's Government did grant $1.1 billion in credits to the central Asian republics, and was negotiating with Kazakhstan to extend an oil pipeline from Baku to the Turkish port of Iskenderun, but he was always unwilling to take part in Mr. Ozal's empire building.
During his time as Prime Minister, Mr. Demirel ignored the flamboyant demands of the President, refusing, for example, to go beyond the restrictions imposed on Bosnia by the United Nations. His Government also worked with the United States and Russia to seek a negotiated settlement to the Armenian-Azerbaijani conflict.
 
'A Classical Tactician'
 But his pragmatism and emphasis on domestic affairs worries many Western diplomats, who had hoped that Turkey would become a counterweight to Iran in the region.
"The country has lost in Mr. Ozal an original mind and a unique thinker, who had a boldness and a vision that was rarely seen in modern Turkey," a Western diplomat said, "and what Turkey is left with is a classical tactician who focuses on short-range political goals."
There are serious domestic problems, ranging from a 60 percent inflation rate and large, inefficient state-controlled industries, to continuing friction with the Kurdish minority in southeastern Turkey. The budget deficit increased to $3.2 billion in the first quarter of 1993, or more than half of the Government's total deficit target for this year. And labor unions say they will demand annual salary increases exceeding 100 percent for more than 500,000 employees in the public sector, whose two-year contracts are scheduled to expire this year.
 
Municipal Elections Awaited
 While Turkey had the highest growth rate, 5.9 percent, in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, its population of 60 million is growing by 2 percent a year. And the flight from rural areas to the urban centers, which saw the proportion of people living in the cities jump from 53 percent to 59 percent from 1985 to 1990, has created masses of idle laborers and a black market economy that escapes taxation.
The coalition Government, widely attacked for failing to adhere to election promises, will face nationwide municipal elections next March. General elections are scheduled for 1996.
The Social Democrat Party, headed by Erdal Inonu, which holds power with Mr. Demirel's True Path Party, is expected to see its mandate reduced, perhaps endangering the coalition, Western diplomats say.
The True Path Party holds 182 seats in the 450-member assembly. The Motherland Party has 94 seats, the Social Democrats have 54 and the religious Islamic Welfare Party has 40. The rest of the seats are held by smaller parties or independent candidates.
Many Western diplomats expect the economic frustration to translate into gains for the Islamic Welfare Party, which has already begun a sophisticated and well-coordinated campaign.
On taking office Sunday, Mr. Demirel promised the country that political and economic reforms would be a priority.
 
Corruption Called Prevalent
 But the country's political system, fragmented by 10 warring political parties, is often paralyzed by indecision. Parliamentary debates are sparsely attended and Western diplomats say the Government remains riddled with corruption.
The removal of Mr. Demirel and Mr. Ozal, and many of their close associates, from the daily political life of the country is expected to give new, younger political leaders an opportunity to exercise power. But some diplomats worry that the process, which could take months if not years, could see Turkey's external influence wane and the economic problems grow.
The True Path Party will meet in June to choose a new Prime Minister, and the Motherland Party, founded by Mr. Ozal, has begun a resurgence. But none of the names touted as possible successors to the two men have yet to capture the imagination of the public.
"The country must redefine itself," a European diplomat said. "The problem is that if this takes too long Turkey's many problems, from the economy to the unrest along its borders, could all swing out of control."

HEADLINE: As Casino Vote Nears, Jockeying Intensifies

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 19

 BODY:
With five days left before the first vote in the House of Representatives on whether to legalize a gambling casino for Bridgeport, the measure is still considered a long shot.
But a new round of maneuvering in the Capitol in the last 24 hours has made the question suddenly more volatile, and legislators on both sides said that no one should rule out large shifts of votes and further changes in tactics as the final hour nears. 
 On Tuesday, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the state's leading opponent of expanded casino gambling, offered to provide a $6.5 million tax break to struggling jai alai frontons and a dog track, which have said they will go out of business unless the state lets them have slot machines.
Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman of Mirage Resorts of Las Vegas, Nev., which has undertaken one of the most expensive lobbying campaigns ever in this state to convince residents that casinos would generate new jobs, said in response that he wouldn't want slot machines anyway, and would still build a $350 million casino in Bridgeport offering table games only, like blackjack and roulette.
Today, each side accused the other of duplicity or cynicism. A spokesman for Mirage called Mr. Weicker "the Dr. Kevorkian of governors," easing the death pains of the struggling jai alai operators without helping them find new sources of revenue.
"The Governor has fought this, practically, to his death," said Alan M. Feldman, the Mirage spokesman.
The Governor's allies said Mr. Wynn's move was simply a Trojan horse: the casinos would demand slot machines next year or the year after, they said, and no one should be fooled.
"They'll come on like a steamroller," said the minority leader in the House, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol and an opponent of expanded gambling. "They have to."
The deeper questions are whether Mr. Wynn, in making his new move, will be seen by legislators to be dealing from strength or weakness, and whether the representatives who favor the tax break for gambling operations in their areas will now abandon the casino plan.
Mr. Weicker has vowed to veto any casino bill, and overriding his veto would require a two-thirds majority. He played his big card in January: a pact with the Mashantucket Pequot Indians, who won the right to have slot machines at their casino in Ledyard and agreed, in return, to pay at least $100 million a year to the state as long as they kept a monopoly on that form of gambling.
Mr. Wynn, who had offered to spend $700 million building casinos in Hartford and Bridgeport, last week trimmed the list to just Bridgeport. His latest offer is for a casino with just table games, competing with the Pequots and their full-service casino an hour's drive away. But by eliminating slot machines from his package, Mr. Wynn has also insured that the Pequot monopoly, and their payments to the state, would continue.
"All these maneuverings ought to make the casino more attractive," said one casino supporter, Representative Richard T. Mulready, a Democrat from West Hartford. "But the unintended consequence is that they tend to make their position look weaker. People say, 'Why should I vote for this thing?' "
Mr. Krawiecki said, however, that he believed the casino plan might have been "watered down" sufficiently that it could be advertised as a way to promote economic development in Bridgeport.

HEADLINE: Wilderness Campaign: Anyone Listening?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 19

 BODY:
For years J. Patrick Gilligan has been telling anyone who would listen how New Jersey's tax system should be overhauled. He said he won praise from some fellow Republicans but no action and that is why, at the age of 72, he is running for governor.
"People would listen and promise to bring my ideas before the state party leadership and the Legislature but they never did," he said. "Going through channels hasn't worked, so I'm going right to the people and hope enough of them will agree with me and something will change." 
 Mr. Gilligan's message is easily the most radical one being heard in the campaign for the Republican nomination for governor. He does not simply want to roll back the rates of the state's sales and income taxes. He wants to get rid of them altogether.
He would make up the revenue for the state budget by enacting a graduated state income tax based on a percentage of a taxpayer's Federal income tax. He would pay for all state services, including all public school costs, out of this tax, so property taxpayers would also see a dramatic drop in their municipal taxes, he said.
 
Knocking on Closed Doors
 "We cannot continue a policy that taxes middle- and lower-income residents more severely than those with greater resources," he said. "Taxes should be based on ability to pay."
Mr. Gilligan, who has been a member of the American Stock Exchange since 1946, has been traveling to every Republican forum and public meeting he can find, but sometimes the doors are closed.
A recent campaign debate sponsored by the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce and televised over the state's cable network was limited to the three candidates who have raised enough money to qualify for matching state funds: Christine Todd Whitman, the former president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners; Cary Edwards, a former State Attorney General, and Jim Wallwork, a former State Senator.
While the three will raise and spend millions of dollars by the June 8 primary, Mr. Gilligan said he will spend less than $10,000.
A few days later, members of the United We Stand organization linked to Ross Perot held a forum for the Republican candidates in Westhampton in Burlington County, and again Mr. Gilligan was not invited.
Even on the occasions when Mr. Gilligan does get to the speakers' platform, he sometimes finds that it is not easy to make converts. At a Republican organization meeting in Florham Park, Mr. Gilligan gave his campaign address and called for questions. "It was a good group and we each got five minutes to speak," he said. "But at the end no one would ask me any questions."
Although forcing a change in New Jersey's fiscal policy is his chief aim, Mr. Gilligan has adopted provocative positions on a number of issues.
 
No Patience on Insurance
 He said he was appalled that the state spends $29,000 to house each prisoner for a year, while spending only $9,000 for each pupil's education. "We put convicts in prisons that resemble motels," he told an audience at candidates' night at Ramapo College. "We should put them in isolated areas in facilities that resemble prisoner-of-war camps."
To control health-care costs, Mr. Gilligan said he would encourage all dentists and doctors licensed in New Jersey to contribute one or two days a month providing free care for the poor. In return they would receive a credit on their income tax.
Mr. Gilligan is not the only Republican candidate who has campaigned in relative obscurity. Charles P. Hoffman, 48, of Brick Township is also on the ballot, although he announced this month that he would no longer actively campaign and was throwing his support to Mr. Wallwork.
