HEADLINE: Justice Post Nominee Says He Has Quit Golf Club

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Webster L. Hubbell, the Clinton Administration's nominee for the third-highest post in the Justice Department, said today that he had resigned from an Arkansas golf club that had been all white until last year, when it recruited its first and only black member.
Mr. Hubbell, who had been under fire for his membership in the Country Club of Little Rock, said at a Senate confirmation hearing that he had decided to resign after concluding that his membership could be a liability. He said he sent a resignation letter on Tuesday. 
 "I have come to realize that there remains in the minds of some people the perception that my continued membership reflects some lack of sensitivity," said Mr. Hubbell, who, if confirmed as associate attorney general, would supervise the civil rights division. "I think it's important that that perception not distract from the job that I hope you will allow me to undertake. Therefore, I have resigned my membership in the Country Club of Little Rock."
 
Other Officials to Resign
 Today at the White House, a spokeswoman, Ricki Seidman, said that three other Administration officials who belong to the club also planned to resign. They are Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House Chief of Staff; Vince Foster, a deputy White House counsel, and William Kennedy, an associate counsel.
Mr. Hubbell's announcement drained today's hearing of the drama raised by the possibility of a serious fight over an issue that had ensnared nominees of the Reagan and Bush Administrations. Instead of confrontation, the hearing ended with Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who is the panel's chairman, predicting that Mr. Hubbell would be easily confirmed by the full Senate.
Mr. Hubbell, a close associate of President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, told the panel that for years he had "worked within the club and with the African-Americans in our community to bring about diversity in the club."
"I would have resigned immediately from the club if I had believed an application would have been rejected on the basis of race," he said.
Mr. Hubbell, who has been Mrs. Clinton's law partner, a mayor of Little Rock and one-time chief justice of the Arkansas Supreme Court, encountered few hostile questions. Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, the panel's ranking Republican, set the genial tone of the hearing, praising Mr. Hubbell as a "honorable and decent man" who did not "have a discriminatory bone in your body."
Carol Moseley-Braun, the Illinois Democrat who is the committee's only black member, said, "Webb Hubbell's resignation from the club is not an admission of his guilt but a demonstration of his sensitivity."
Mr. Hubbell joined the club in 1978. In letter to the committee earlier this month, he said the club's bylaws did not restrict membership in any way, and that it had Jewish and female members. The first black to join the club is Howard Curtis Reed, now a senior economist at the office of the United States Trade Representative.

Hubbell, center, told members of the Senate Judiciary Committee considering his nomination to a top Justice Department post that he quit a golf club because his membership could be seen as a liability. He was introduced by Senators from his home state, Dale Bumpers, left, and David Pryor. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widens by $10.21 Billion

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit ballooned in March to $10.21 billion, the widest gap in nearly four years, as imports from Japan and China grew sharply while exports increased slowly, the Commerce Department announced today.
The widening of the deficit, from $7.9 billion in February, mainly reflected a $4.4 billion jump in imports to a record $49.2 billion. 
 Stephen L. Cooney Jr., a trade analyst at the National Association of Manufacturers, said the increase in goods entering the United States in March indicated that American merchants placed many orders for imported goods last winter, betting that the economy would recover and consumers would spend more.
"There are big increases in all of the Kmart and other bargain store products -- footwear, toys, games, sporting goods" and other low-priced consumer goods, he said.
 
Evidence of Growth
 Jeffrey J. Schott, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, a not-for-profit Washington research group, said the rising imports indicated that the American economy was growing faster than other countries' economies, so that American consumers were more able to buy imported goods.
"This may come as a surprise to many Americans, but we're actually doing much better than most of our trading partners," he said.
The trade figures come at a politically inopportune time for the Administration -- two weeks before President Clinton has to decide whether to renew China's favorable trade status for the coming year and six weeks before he meets in Tokyo with the leaders of the world's other large industrial nations.
Administration officials say that President Clinton is virtually certain to renew China's trade status with some conditions, though no consensus has been reached on what those conditions should be.
Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of New York, has promised to use an obscure legislative rule to force a politically awkward vote on the House floor this summer on China's favorable trade status unless the President cancels the status entirely.
The nation's trade deficit with China widened to $1.46 billion in March from $1.17 billion in February.
The deficit with Japan also grew, to $5.26 billion from $4.13 billion in February. The deficit is the third-largest monthly deficit ever with Japan, according to Commerce Department figures, exceeded only by a $6.4 billion deficit in November 1986 and a $5.4 billion deficit in October 1987.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown noted today that the trade deficit with Japan had reached 64 percent of the total American trade deficit in March.
By contrast, the overall American trade deficit in March was not close to ranking in the top 10. The reason is that American trade deficits have shrunk with most of the world in recent years but not with Japan.
 
Not a Good Time
 But the large American-Japanese deficit announced today comes at a bad time for the Administration, too late for the recent visit to Washington of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan and too early for the Group of Seven meeting in Japan.
Administration officials say they had secretly hoped for a large February trade deficit, which was announced the same day in April that Mr. Miyazawa met Mr. Clinton, so as to put pressure on Tokyo for concessions. But they were disappointed when the February deficit was virtually unchanged from January.
Today's large deficit is also too early to give the President ammunition for his trip to Tokyo on July 7. The April trade deficit is due to be announced before then.
Mr. Brown said today that "this surge in imports was a one-month deviation from more moderate trends." Much of the increase in March reflected the expansion of American merchants' inventories of imported goods, he said.
 
Reason for Reference
 James P. Desler, the acting press secretary for Mr. Brown, said the reference to inventories was made not to play down the size of the March trade deficit but rather to prepare the public in case next month's trade deficit was smaller. "We expect that imports will decline next month, but there are long-term, systemic trade problems that need to be addressed that will still be pressing regardless of next month," he said.
Paula Stern, a former chairwoman of the International Trade Commission, said that for Japanese negotiators, "if there is a bad number that comes out, it's far better that it comes out after the Miyazawa visit and before the G-7 summit."
Ms. Stern pointed out that the deficit might continue to widen because of the recent decline in the value of dollar, especially against the Japanese yen. Because the volume of goods imported tends to respond slowly to currency moves, a falling dollar temporarily means that imports cost more and the trade deficit tends to widen.
In the long run, economists say, a falling dollar will tend to reduce the deficit as imported goods become more expensive for Americans and American goods become more competitive in foreign markets.
 
Impact on Economy
 Economists differed today on what the trade statistics indicated about the health of the United States economy. Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley, said that the overall trade deficit was alarming because it showed that imports were outcompeting American-made goods in the United States market.
"The number is a shocking number," he said. "It does indicate that the first quarter was weaker than the preliminary estimate of 1.8 percent" growth in American economic output.
The Commerce Department issued the preliminary estimate of gross domestic product on April 29 and is to issue a final estimate on May 28.
But Mr. Cooney disagreed, saying that the large orders for imported goods were a sign of confidence by American companies that the economy would continue to expand and the goods could be sold.
Imports rose to $49.2 billion in March from $44.83 billion in February, while exports climbed to $39 billion from $36.93 billion.

HEADLINE: High New Jersey Minimum Wage Doesn't Seem to Deter Fast-Food Hiring, Study Finds

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Despite sharp opposition from business, New Jersey last year increased its minimum wage to $5.05 an hour, the second highest in the nation and a level well above those in nearby states.
The increase in April 1992, from $4.25 an hour, came amid a slump in the state's economy, and at a time when employers were already under financial pressure and often unable to pass added labor costs on to customers in the form of higher prices. 
 Now, with New Jersey's unemployment rate at 9.1 percent, the highest of all the leading industrial states, the steeper minimum wage would seem a natural suspect in explaining why so many workers cannot find jobs.
But a new study by two labor economists at Princeton University on the effect of the higher minimum wage on employment in the state's fast-food restaurants -- one of the major employers of young workers who earn the minimum wage -- suggests that it has not been a significant deterrent to hiring.
"This is the situation you'd really expect the minimum wage to matter," Prof. Alan B. Krueger, an author of the study said. "But it didn't seem to have an effect in the fast-food industry and, besides, the industries that are really hurting in New Jersey are high paying ones like pharmaceuticals."
Data from New Jersey's farms, another big employer of low-wage workers, suggests the same. Even though seasonal hiring dropped right after the increase took effect, it fell less than in neighboring Delaware, where the minimum wage stayed put.
Whether the New Jersey law has cost jobs has political implications. South Jersey farmers and their legislative representatives are negotiating with Gov. Jim Florio for $12 million worth of concessions on a wide range of taxes and fees to compensate them for the higher minimum wage. Mr. Florio is running for re-election this year.
Washington is also watching New Jersey's experience with the higher minimum wage as the Clinton Administration tries to decide how hard to lean on employers as a route for delivering benefits to working Americans. The Federal minimum wage, covering employers in interstate commerce, is $4.25, and Federal law establishes that as a floor nationally. Individual states are free to set theirs higher.
 
Conventional Notions Upset
 Decades of research suggests that raising the minimum wage gives workers at the bottom of the ladder a better shot at supporting themselves, but discourages employers from hiring. The Princeton economists were surprised when their wide survey in the fast-food industry did not conform to their expectations.
"Nobody knew until the last minute that this law would go into effect, which means that it should have had a bigger impact because employers couldn't digest it in advance," Professor Krueger said. "Also relevant was that New Jersey deep recession. So we really expected to find effects; we suspected it would show the opposite."
He and the other researchers caution that this study, in itself, should not be seen as a blanket rationale for raising minimum wages nationwide. Most economists favor helping the working poor through tax credits rather than imposing new regulations on businesses, and the researchers advise studying other industries and other states.
But they and others say that the New Jersey findings, besides being striking per se, track recent findings of the effect of an increase in the Federal minimum wage in other states including California, Texas, Mississippi and North Carolina.
The Princeton team interviewed managers at 410 Wendy's, Burger King, KFC and Roy Rogers outlets two months before and nine months after the April 1992 increase. They reasoned that if effects were to show up, they would first appear in the fast-food industry because such places rely more heavily than other retailers on low-paid workers. They compared before and after results of New Jersey restaurants with a control group of Pennsylvania restaurants.
"The fast-food industry has the highest proportion of minimum-wage workers and has, on average, the youngest workers," said David Card, the study's other author. "If the minimum wage had a big negative effect, that's where you'd expect to see it."
The researchers had expected that the increase would prompt businesses to dismiss the least skilled workers, push those remaining to work harder, and substitute machines for new hiring where possible.
Instead, the restaurants added 2.5 workers per store, on average. To be sure, a large minority of the New Jersey restaurants trimmed the number of workers, but the majority added some. There was no sign that employers cut fringe benefits like free or bargain meals, nor was there evidence that they canceled scheduled raises.
With the Pennsylvania control group, the average number of workers per restaurant edged down roughly 2 percent, despite the fact that the minimum wage there had not changed.
"The higher minimum wage isn't the factor that's pushed many restaurants that did go out of business in the past couple of years," said Larry Fidel of the New Jersey Restaurant Association.
 
An Unhappy Employer's View
 Not everyone agrees, though, that the increase hasn't had the anticipated negative effects.
"The creeping socialism begins at the $5.05 level," said Eric Mund, general manager of the Mega Management Corporation, a Burger King franchise in northern New Jersey. Mr. Mund says that the higher minimum caused him to cut back hours and to stint on service a bit. "Unfortunately, people have to wait longer and that doesn't make me happy."
And Richard Berman at the Employment Policies Institute, a Washington-based business group, said: "You see a lot of stories that the economy is coming back but jobs aren't. Mandated benefits and high labor costs are at the heart of that. Employers are trying to find ways to deliver services and products with fewer workers."
But employment trends in New Jersey do seem to illustrate the absence of a broad deterrent to hiring from a higher minimum wage. The employment rate among adults -- those 20 and older -- declined in the nine months after the higher minimum was imposed, but no more than in New York.
Of course, adults were potentially less vulnerable than teen-age workers since only 5 percent of the adults questioned in New Jersey earned less than the new minimum wage, while one-third of all working teen-agers were below that level.
Nonetheless, even among teen-agers, employment rates in the nine-month period -- April through December -- actually fell less in New Jersey in than in nearby states -- by only 0.7 percent, compared to more than 2.5 percent in New York, Pennsylvania and Connecticut.
Conventional economic models suggest that the effect of raising the minimum wage by 18.8 percent should have been a decline of 2 percent to 5 percent in teen-agers' employment.
Some economists, including the researchers who conducted the New Jersey study, caution against using the New Jersey results as a policy guide, even if confirmed by further studies. New Jersey has long been one of highest wage states in the United States, and a smaller proportion of both teen-agers and adults were being paid below the new minimum than in most other states.
 
Study's Potential for Error
 The study did not rule out the possibility that some other unidentified factors might have influenced the hiring in New Jersey and in Pennsylvania. It could turn out, for example, that fast-food restaurants expanded more in New Jersey than in Pennsylvania because, say, New Jersey was less saturated with such establishments, and was catching up through expansion.
"They haven't accounted for differences in the labor markets," said James Heckman, a labor economist at the University of Chicago. "That could make a big difference."
A separate study by Professor Card showed that teen-agers' employment in California did not fall, relative to similar employment in a number of Southwestern states, despite California's higher minimum wage.
But a study by Lowell Taylor, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon Univeristy of Pittsburgh, suggests that were it not for the higher minimum wage, jobs for California youths would have increased more, in comparison with the other states.
And there is the further question of how typical fast-food stores are of the larger world of retailing.
Whatever the limitations of the fast-food industry study, data from New Jersey agriculture seem to point in the same direction.
 
Farmer Prefers Long Days
 Farmers have complained that the higher minimum wage has inhibited their ability to hire. A third-generation grower, John Rigolizzo, for example, says that 10 of his South Jersey neighbors are not farming this year, and attributes this to the minimum-wage increase. He said that was also why he and his father had hired fewer hands and were working 15-hour days.
The number of paid agricultural workers in New Jersey was 6 percent lower in June 1992, after the new law was enacted, than a year earlier, according to the state unemployment insurance office.
But in Delaware, where, like New Jersey, farmers grow everything from peaches to pumpkins, agricultural jobs fell by a much larger 17 percent last summer, despite the fact that the minimum wage there did not budge.

HEADLINE: New Japan-Trade Policy May Split Power Among Agencies

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 19

 BODY:
Top Clinton Administration officials are in the final stages of drafting a new American trade policy toward Japan that would call for five Cabinet agencies to begin immediate negotiations to open the Japanese market, American officials and Washington trade experts said today.
A series of secret meetings have been held in the last six days at the White House to draft the new policy, which would split the negotiating authority among the Treasury, State, Defense and Commerce Departments and the Office of the United States Trade Representative. 
 President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan announced during Mr. Miyazawa's visit here last month that the two countries would draft a new framework for discussions of Japan's persistent trade surpluses with the United States. But the new framework now being devised largely resembles that used by the Bush Administration, which some Congressional Democrats had criticized as too weak.
By dispersing authority over trade matters, the new policy also may dilute the influence of Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative.
A delegation of senior American officials will visit Tokyo in the next several weeks to present the new interagency policy, which is still subject to approval by President Clinton and the Cabinet, Washington trade experts said. No date for the trip has been set.
The new policy involves up to five "baskets" into which issues would be grouped. The first basket would consist of specific industry issues, such as trade in cars and computer chips.
The second basket would include questions of how each country's economy is organized, including American charges that the convoluted Japanese retail-store system discriminates against American goods.
The third basket would be made up of global economic issues, such as the value of the yen, while the fourth basket would work on foreign investment issues, like the difficulties that American companies have faced in trying to buy factories in Japan.
The last basket would handle national security issues that overlap with economic issues, like purchases of military equipment and Japanese payments to cover the cost of American soldiers stationed there.
Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman has played a leading role in drafting the new policy. But a senior Administration official, who only spoke on condition of anonymity, said that it was still unclear who would lead the trip.
Bowman Cutter, a deputy assistant to the President for economic affairs and a senior staff official at the National Economic Council, has been running the interagency meetings, said the official said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Policy becomes fuzzy when jobs enter the advanced-TV picture.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
CANDIDATE Clinton said he believed in industrial policy, and now President Clinton is proving it: The Federal Communications Commission's decision on a technical standard for high-definition television, wrote Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary and very close Friend of Bill's, "should turn, in part, on an assessment of which system would make the greatest contribution to domestic high-wage employment."
Well, that is not quite proof. While Secretary Reich's letter to the chairman of the commission has been widely interpreted as a plug for the French-Dutch consortium promising to build the new television sets in America, sources close to Mr. Reich say he was only repeating his long-held belief that good jobs matter. But the fallout illustrates both the theoretical attractions and practical difficulties of picking industrial winners. 
 Four different standards for delivering razor-sharp television images are now being considered by the F.C.C. All four, argues Chuck Jackson, an engineering consultant with Strategic Policy Research in Maryland, are excellent. Indeed, says Mr. Jackson, a member of an independent advisory committee to the commission, "no standard has attributes that clearly lift it over the others."
Mr. Jackson, along with Richard E. Wiley, the head of the advisory group and a former chairman of the F.C.C., would like the competitors to combine their intellectual capital and hammer out a formula for sharing the gravy. Until very recently, that seemed a likely prospect.
But since the Reich letter -- along with an unsubtle "me-too" follow-up from Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader -- all bets are off. If a second round of tests begins late this month before tempers cool, time may run out on a compromise.
According to those sympathetic to Mr. Reich, the intervention amounted to less than met the eye. Approached by organized labor to back the Advanced Television Research Consortium, whose foreign partners (Thompson Consumer Electronics and Philips Electronics) assemble TV's in Indiana and Pennsylvania, the Labor Secretary simply wrote a "constituents' letter" to get them off his back. Nothing Mr. Reich has said in the past, they note, would suggest he thinks America's future lies in the protection of unskilled assembly line work -- or that his heart belongs to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
But how should one interpret Mr. Reich's call for a standard that generates "high-paying jobs"? Peter Pitsch, an economist at Pitsch Communications in Washington and a former senior staffer at the F.C.C., believes any attempt to "skew this decision toward jobs is myopic." So much is at stake in the HDTV decision in terms of the ultimate value to consumers, he contends, that picking the wrong system "could cost millions of dollars for each job created."
There are economists, however, who impute more method than madness to the industrial policy rap. Choices at the technological crossroads, argues Paul David of Stanford University, can have far-reaching effects on productivity in related industries. Technology can spill from business to business, especially if the innovation is taking place in geographic clusters like Silicon Valley. "There is a lot to be said for the strategic view," he argues -- the view that government has an important role to play in nudging innovators toward the biggest social payoffs.
The catch is that no one is certain where these payoffs lie. "We're always better at predicting the past," Mr. David conceded.
Mr. David's own guess is that timing is key. Once an HDTV system that is pretty good is adopted in a major market, it will probably dominate laggards even if they are better. This might argue for picking the standard that would create working equipment soonest. Then again, it might not: Japan spent heavily to be first, only to end up with an HDTV system that was dead on arrival because it hogged so much of the broadcast spectrum.
Edward Horowitz, the chairman of Viacom Broadcasting, thinks the critical linkage is with computers. He envisions the day computer makers put television tuners in their portables and use broadcasting for huge one-way data flows. This would require an HDTV standard that yields a "progressive scan" picture, viewable with comfort from a few inches. Or perhaps not: what counts in the end, Mr. Horowitz notes, is that the HDTV standard be "upwardly compatible," one whose limitations can be overcome down the road.
George Gilder, the author of "Life After TV," who predicted the Japanese debacle in HDTV when almost everyone else was anguishing over America's lost opportunity, believes these issues are rapidly becoming nonissues. "It is too late for the standard to have much impact," he claims. Microelectronics are becoming so cheap and so flexible, he argues, that innovators will be able to surmount any obstacles left in their path. "There'll be enough intelligence at the terminal," he expects, "to make the idea of standards obsolete."
What does that imply about industrial policy? If Mr. Gilder is right (again), the possibility of rational management of electronics technology by Washington may be ending just as it is coming back into fashion.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Profit Taking Brings Halt To Surge in Gold Market

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Gold prices retreated yesterday from a two-year high, as traders took some profits after a explosive rally.
Gold for delivery in June, which jumped $8 on Tuesday, settled down $1.80 an ounce, at $374.20, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Earlier in the day, gold for June had traded at $383.50 an ounce, its highest point since January 1991. 
 Adding to yesterday's pressures on gold was unconfirmed speculation that George Soros, the hedge-fund manager who had helped start the gold rally, was selling some of his gold holdings and buying bonds. A spokeswoman for Mr. Soros declined to comment.
"Obviously, someone was selling a lot of gold today, but the underlying fundamentals of this market are still very positive," said Leanne Baker, an analyst at Salomon Brothers.
 
An Early Rally
 Gold soared on Tuesday and in early trading yesterday as concerns about inflation drove investors from stocks and bonds. Investors often turn to gold as a hedge against inflation. But as gold retreated in late trading in New York, prices of stocks and Treasury bonds surged.
Still, several gold analysts did not see yesterday's decline in gold prices as a definite sign that the rally is over.
"This market has been up so persistently without a correction of any significance that almost anything could cause people with good profits to sell," Ms. Baker said.
Gold has gained more than $30 an ounce, or about 9.5 percent, the last two months.
Joseph Rosta, senior metals analyst with CPM Group in New York, predicted gold could rise to as high as $420 an ounce by the end of the year.
Mr. Soros added fuel to the gold rally in April when he bought a 10 percent stake in Newmont Mining for $269 million from the British financier Sir James Goldsmith. Sir James, in turn, used some of that money to buy gold options.
Among other metals yesterday, silver for July delivery settled 8.5 cents lower, at $4.54 an ounce, on the Comex. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, July platinum closed $5.20 lower, at $385.80 an ounce.
Also on the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for June slumped after the American Petroleum Institute reported an increase in American crude oil inventories. June crude oil settled 19 cents lower, at $19.15 a barrel. Heating oil finished 0.24 cent higher, at 54.04 cents a gallon, and unleaded gasoline was up 0.46 cent, at 59.12 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Stocks and Bonds Surge; Dow Hits 3,500;
30-Year Treasury Again Below 7%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
A rush of relief washed over the bond market yesterday, as the worst fears from Tuesday turned out to be wrong yesterday.
After a wrenching day of trading that saw prices and yields rise and fall sharply several times, probably costing some traders a lot of money, came a happy ending. 
 The yield on the 30-year bond surpassed 7.05 percent twice in the day before retreating, finishing at 6.97 percent. Short and intermediate Treasury prices also rallied.
Yesterday turned out to be better than Tuesday, when Treasury prices slumped and the 30-year bond yield breached 7 percent for the first time in a month and a half, to close at 7.02 percent, because the Federal Reserve did not signal any tightening of interest rates. Traders had feared that given surprisingly large jumps in April's key inflation indexes, the Fed might take some action during its policy-making committee meeting on Tuesday.
 
 
Gold Eases Inflation Anxiety
 In addition, the price of gold, which leapt to more than $383 an ounce early in the day, pushing prices lower and yields higher, settled lower for the day. This released some of the growing inflationary tension, which was heightened Tuesday, when the price of gold rose $8 an ounce, to $376. It settled yesterday at $374.20, down $1.80 an ounce.
But while tension has eased, the basic environment of the market has not changed much, a sign that prices and yield will still be trapped in a tight trading range. The six-tenths of a percentage point rise in the Producer Price Index for finished goods and the four-tenths of a percentage point rise in the Consumer Price index for April will stay on traders' minds. And while the Fed appears not to have lifted short-term interest rates, the general perception is that the central bank's next move will be higher and sooner than expected, unless the May inflation data are surprisingly good and the economy fails to pick up any steam.
"I would not say that the market is going back to its highs any time soon," said Ronald Connors, a senior managing director at Bear, Stearns & Company, referring to higher prices and lower yields.
 
 
'Fundamentals Are the Same'
 Jay Goldinger, a bond trader for Capital Insight in Los Angeles, said that he was cautious about overreacting to Tuesday's selloff and equally cautious about yesterday's buying.
"Yesterday, I didn't want to be too bearish and today I don't want to be too bullish," Mr. Goldinger said. "I don't think anything changed between today and yesterday. The economic fundamentals are the same."
The Federal Reserve's inaction gave the biggest support to shorter-term Treasury notes and bills. The discount rate on three-month and six-month Treasury bills, for example, were down 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.96 percent and 3.06 percent, respectively.
"I don't think they did anything," David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said of the Federal Reserve meeting on interest rates. "The market has recovered, particularly in the short end, because the scare is over for now on the Fed."
But Mr. Jones did not rule out the possibility that the Fed might have decided to write a policy directive that would shift the central bank from neutral on interest rates to a bias toward higher interest rates.
 
 
Possible Shift by Fed
 The effect of such an action is unclear. It could reignite the fear of higher rates, pushing up short-term rates and longer-term yields. Or it could reduce concerns about inflation by suggesting that the Fed was ready to do what was necessary to curb price increases.
Traders noted that while the drop in the gold price was reassuring, it was not just the result of reduced inflationary fears. The selloff appears to have been set off, in part, by a rumor, which was not confirmed, that George Soros, a speculator and hedge-fund operator who helped start the gold rally by announcing a major investment, had sold some gold to take profits and bought Treasury bonds.
Mr. Connors of Bear Stearns also said that buying was supported by reports of a big speculator in 30-year bond futures, which trade in Chicago. As the rally continued, a lot of speculators who had sold bonds thinking the decline would continue, had to scramble to cover their positions. That added to the steepness of the rebound.
 
 
Still Getting Orders
 Mr. Connors also said that despite the weakness in the tax-exempt municipal market, his firm was still getting orders in the afternoon for millions of dollars of Treasury securities that are used in the escrow funds established to pay off old higher-interest-rate municipal bonds.
In a separate development, the Treasury announced that it would sell $15.75 billion of two-year notes next week, an increase of $500 million from the last auction. The increase reflects the decision announced earlier this month to reduce the sales of 30-year bonds and to shift the borrowing to securities with maturities of three years and less.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines on Report Of Wider U.S. Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended broadly lower yesterday after the Government reported an unexpected surge in the March trade deficit and re-ignited speculation that it favored a weaker dollar.
The trade news dominated a market buffeted by conflicting influences, including continued fallout from the ratification by Denmark of the Maastricht Treaty on European unity and the failure of the German central bank to lower interest rates. 
 The report by the Commerce Department that the merchandise trade deficit in the United States soared to $10.2 billion in March, the worst showing in almost four years, sent the dollar plunging against the Japanese yen in morning trading in New York.
The dollar fell further, to an intraday low of 109.90 yen, on subsequent remarks by the Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, that part of the Clinton Administration's attempt to correct the deficit would include "market-driven exchange rate corrections."
The remarks revived speculation that the Administration was trying to use the currency markets to narrow the trade deficit with Japan. A weaker dollar and stronger yen make Japanese imports more expensive in the United States, and American-made products cheaper in Japan.
 
No Weak-Dollar Policy
 But the dollar recovered some of its losses after Mr. Brown clarified his remarks shortly before noon, telling reporters that the Administration had no official policy favoring a weaker dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 111.56 yen, up 0.28 yen from the close on Tuesday. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was worth 110.75 yen, down from 111.445 yen late Tuesday.
But the dollar was only slightly lower against the German mark, which suffered from continued reaction to the Danish vote on Tuesday. Viewing the vote as a signal of renewed stability in the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, traders were selling marks, considered the safe haven of European currencies, and buying secondary European currencies like the Danish krone.
The mark softened despite a decision by the German central bank, the Bundesbank, to leave interest rates at current high levels. Expectations of lower rates make a currency less attractive to investors.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Top Performers Lead Again In Money Market Yields

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The yields of most money market funds rose slightly in the latest week, with many funds that were in first place the previous week again performing near the top.
IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report said 7-day yields of taxable funds advanced, while 30-day yields declined. In the tax-exempt sector, both 7-day and 30-day yields increased. 
 "There has been a great deal of activity elsewhere in the fixed-income market," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist of IBC/Donoghue. "But the money market has been relatively quiet, reflecting the fact that the Federal Reserve has done nothing and there is no great expectation that it will."
The seven-day average compounded yield for taxable money market funds was up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a point, to 2.64 percent, while the simple yield rose 1 basis point, to 2.60 percent. Over a 30-day period, the average compounded and simple yields both dropped 1 basis point, to 2.64 percent and 2.61 percent, respectively.
 
Tax-Exempt Yields Rise
 As for tax-exempt yields, the average 7-day compounded yield increased 7 basis points, to 2.03 percent, while the simple yield advanced 7 basis points, to 2.01 percent. For a 30-day average, the compounded and simple yields both rose 2 basis points, to 2.01 percent and 1.99 percent, respectively.
"Not much is happening and tax-exempt yields continue to scrape bottom," Mr. Frank said. "This was part of a slight bounce from the bottom."
Total assets of taxable money market funds fell $2.6 billion, to $488.7 billion for the week, with the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios rising by 1, to 64. There was, however, a $4.7 billion decline in the assets of institutional funds, offset in part by an increase of $2.1 billion in retail funds.
 
Quick to Switch
 "Other money market rates went up this past week, and institutional investors switch quickly," Mr. Frank said. "With this competition, they shift their money out immediately and buy Treasury bills and other open-market instruments where they can get a higher yield."
Total assets of tax-exempt money market funds inched down $172 million, to $99.4 billion. The average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios was unchanged, at 48 days.
In its weekly survey of general- purpose taxable money market funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue noted that the best- performing fund was also the top performer the previous week -- the Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund, with a return of 3.42 percent. The top performer among tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million also repeated on top of the list -- the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market Fund, with a yield of 2.72 percent.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Torborg Leaves In State Of Acute Media Shock

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
The night's organizational dirty work had been done. Jeff Torborg, who had conceded that the city's intense news media focus had been the single greatest shock and obstacle he had faced as manager of the Mets, stood behind his office desk and faced the microphones and cameras once more.
There was humor and relief and a tiny hint of defiance to the end. Of course, the future for Torborg was not exactly desolate or impoverished. He has more than a million dollars coming, and his guaranteed contract with the Mets is not for personal services. He is not obligated to do anything but cash checks through 1995. 
 "I might," said Torborg, barely able to hold his smile, "try an afternoon radio show."
 
On the Air
 Radio shows, of course, had help unravel Torborg's reputation. He was on the air too often in 1992. He canceled for 1993. But the rest of the manager's problems weren't so easily solved.
"I feel empty," said Torborg, whose final record was 85-115. "I looked out there on the field all night tonight, and I still found it hard to believe this has happened to the team we put together."
Torborg realized for good how far it had all come apart when he walked through the clubhouse door after last night's 6-4, 10-inning victory over the Pirates and saw General Manager Al Harazin in the manager's office. The subsequent meeting was emotional. The rationale laid out for Torborg, though, was entirely comprehensible.
"Maybe it will take a new face to take some of the heat off these guys," said Torborg.
 
Caught in the Crossfire
 The heat of the news media attention is what will linger most disturbingly with Torborg.
"When I took the job, I didn't know where the challenge would come from," said Torborg. "But the media scrutiny was unlike anything I had thought or experienced in Chicago or Cleveland or with the Yankees. It wasn't even close. You get caught in the crossfire."
Torborg stood throughout, answered all questions, shook all hands. He then had to call his wife. Asked what he might call his imagined radio show, Torborg laughed. He suggested the name "Rip Everybody," then added, "Nah, not really."
The manager seemed beyond bitterness. He was just a half hour into unemployment, and it didn't feel too bad.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: It's Lights Out for Torborg After One Last Blast;
Green Is Hired To Hoist Mets Out of Cellar

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
Jeff Torborg worked his final game as manager of the Mets last night, a victim of his club's nonstop losing. He was officially dismissed after a rare and dramatic 6-4 extra-inning triumph over the Pirates. The final score, though, couldn't change the ugly numbers for the season, a 13-25 record and last place.
Dallas Green, the former Yankees and Phillies manager whose current job had been as a scout in the Mets organization, will succeed Torborg. Green was named by General Manager Al Harazin at a news conference at Shea Stadium after last night's game. Green's contract will run through the 1995 season, and the tough-talking 59-year-old with the reputation for mixing patience and intimidation will be in the dugout for the next game, tomorrow night at Shea against the Braves. 
 Harazin, who said that Torborg "failed to make it happen," was at once modest and confident about what Green had the potential to make happen.
"Dallas Green is a unique personality," Harazin said. "He will put his stamp here. I think he thinks he can turn the team around. I'm not looking for him to win 15 or 20 straight and jump us back into contention with the Phillies. But what I want to come from the rest of the season is the sense that the franchise is back going in the right direction."
 
Foote and LaRoche Also Go
 Along with Torborg, the Mets dismissed coaches Barry Foote and Dave LaRoche. Darrell Johnson, a special assignment scout for the Mets, was added to Green's staff. Green will make one further coaching appointment, perhaps John Stearns, a former Met.
Torborg, who insisted he had not been told of any change in status by management before the game, nonetheless knew what was coming. And he offered no excuses for his performance, saying he was embarrassed that he hadn't got the job done.
"I didn't want to leave the job undone," Torborg said after his dismissal. "But I understand."
The day the manager was fired unfolded as a strange and awkwardly handled event. Front office executives, who had been meeting all day, were unavailable for comment before the game, and according to Torborg there had been no effort to communicate with their doomed manager. Torborg thus was forced to deal with a news media army before the game, and even went on a pre-game television show to talk about his clearly compromised future.
"If it's my last game," he said, "I sure would like to win the damn thing."
He did, but it served more as a reminder of why the end had come for Torborg's reign: his wildly expensive, profoundly disappointing club had not won nearly often enough. After a 72-90 season last year, the Mets entered last night's game with a 12-25 record, the second worst in all of baseball. There had been defeats of every conceivable kind -- blowouts, an excruciating string of one-run losses, failures wrought by poor pitching one night, sorry defense the next, inadequate offense the next.
Despite all the recent speculation, the departure of Torborg is still nothing short of extraordinary. The 51-year-old manager, who had won the American League manager of the year award in 1990 after his dramatic turnaround of a youthful Chicago White Sox club, was hailed at his hiring in October 1991 as precisely what the Mets required. He was regarded as strong on discipline and preparation and adept at news media relations. He was awarded a four-year guaranteed contract worth $1.9 million, and the final two and two-third years of that package will make his sudden unemployment quite bearable.
 
A Rocky Tenure
 But Torborg's tenure was never smooth. He was every bit the prepared professional the Mets had thought they'd hired, but he seemed to fall victim to over-concern with news media coverage and his public image. A handful of players last year found him alternately overbearing and insecure, and by the end of the disastrous fifth-place finish, there was regular clubhouse sniping about his ability as a strategist. Then, there were suggestions from those who had hired him and then had let him go in Chicago that he had all along been a manager with faults.
Torborg, at the end of the 1992 season, confessed to mistakes -- conceding he had underestimated the complexity of managing in the National League, admitting his commitments to a daily radio show were ill-conceived and counterproductive, and saying he had for whatever reason been unable to spur a collection of talented players to collective success.
Asked if he was shocked at Torborg's inability to accomplish success, Harazin, who himself had staked his uncertain reputation as a general manager on Torborg's selection, turned up his hands.
"Disappointed is the word," Harazin said. "And I may be even more disappointed than Jeff is."
"I came into the job with my eyes open," said Torborg, who had served as a longtime coach with the Yankees before he was hired in Chicago. "And I've seen managerial changes before. Most of the time, it is not personal."
 
An Agonizing Decision
 Certainly, the decision by the Mets came after considerable agonizing. The club's owners as recently as two weeks ago expressed patience and empathy for Torborg and called all speculation about his status misguided. But the losing simply didn't stop for the Mets -- the club went into last night's game having lost 18 of the last 22 games -- and the owners, Fred Wilpon and Nelson Doubleday, evidently felt action had to be taken to send a message of some kind to the club's fans and avert the prospect of a financially devastating, competitively empty summer at Shea.
"The mix just didn't work out," said Harazin. "We have a lot of decisions to make, difficult decisions. It's going to take time to find answers."
The likelihood that Green can reverse the club's fortunes and redeem a season that has seen the Mets fall 14 games off the pace in the National League East appears remote. It was clear in recent weeks how unsound the Mets are.
 
Torborg Thanked Coaches
 The scene at Shea late this afternoon indicated that a change was coming. Torborg met with his coaches and thanked them. He spoke briefly with Frank Cashen, the former general manager, and talked about the weather. Torborg's son, Greg, had a duffel bag and was set to pack it.
The end came hours later, and now it is Green who will have to prepare for the enormous chore of manufacturing life and triumphs at Shea. Green, who managed the Phillies to a World Series championship in 1980 by shaking up a country club environment, enjoys a certain cachet as an imposing, even feared managerial presence. He is big and direct and unsparing in his critiques of players.
"He'll get in people's faces, and that means everyone's face, from the guy with the five-year deal to the guy making the major-league minimum," said Larry Bowa, who played under Green in Philadelphia.
"I found him to be fair," said Don Mattingly, who played under Green with the Yankees and who found himself openly criticized by the manager. "I didn't agree with everything he did. But it wasn't my job to judge him. My job was to play for him, and I didn't find that hard to do. At least he had an approach, and it was his alone. I though it fair."
"He'll stir it up," said Joe Torre, who managed against Green in 1980. "He's hands-on, very aggressive, a guy you can't ignore. You can't change the abilities of players, but you can change attitudes."
The Mets, of course, need an attitude adjustment. They also need a lot more than that. Jeff Torborg couldn't get it out of them.

HEADLINE: 'Yes' to Europe. But What Kind?

 BODY:
It was the idea of European union, rather than the specifics of the Maastricht treaty, that Danish voters finally said "yes" to on Tuesday. The ambitious Maastricht blueprint for a unified European foreign and defense policy and a single European currency seems increasingly unlikely to be realized, at least by the 1999 deadline.
Americans have little stake in the details of Maastricht, but a great deal in closer European cooperation. The events of the past year, from currency upheavals to Europe's disastrous fumbling of the Bosnia catastrophe, painfully underscore how far Europe still has to go. 
 The Maastricht treaty, drawn up at a meeting of European heads of government in December 1991, never attracted much popular enthusiasm. The treaty failed its first referendum test in Denmark and barely survived a referendum in France. Maastricht remains a hard-fought issue in Britain, where Parliament is to vote on approval today. And in Germany, ratification faces legal challenges.
European leaders made a serious mistake when they refused to develop democratic institutions to carry out the European Community's expanded role. That left real power with national governments that often failed to agree on common approaches. And it increased resentment of the Community's unpopular Brussels bureaucrats.
Maastricht's other great flaw was its failure to embrace the newly liberated countries of Eastern Europe. A more expansively defined Europe would probably have been less myopic about Bosnia and less protectionist toward countries like Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.
The smoothest way to move forward now would be to complete the ratification process in Britain and Germany, then proceed to radical revisions.
Community protectionism and the reluctance of West European governments to take responsibility for the Continent's security are the two most serious problems now afflicting the American-European relationship. A geographically expanded and democratized Community would offer hope of a less parochial, more enlightened Europe.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Iraqgate Giveaway

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If the Department of Justice wins a case to be tried in Atlanta this fall, then the U.S. taxpayer may be forced to cough up over $380 million to a corrupted Italian bank.
Whose side is the Department of Justice on? 
 Iraqgate buffs will recall how the Atlanta branch of Italy's state-owned Lavoro bank helped finance Saddam Hussein's military buildup with billions in loans guaranteed by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
Ostensibly to promote grain sales, the guarantees were James Baker's method of providing backdoor financing to Iraq, to which Congress was not about to give foreign aid.
When the flow of U.S. money to Iraq was disrupted by a tipoff to the F.B.I., Italy -- our go-between -- stood to lose billions. If it turned out that the bank's officers in Rome knew about the corrupt loans, then the Department of Agriculture need not make good when Iraq defaulted.
Italy's Ambassador, Rinaldo Petrignani (now with the law firm of Rogers & Wells), was cabled by Rome to "raise the case to a political level." He met with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh at the White House; our chief law officer, who happened to get a memo briefing him on the case in detail just three days before, said he did not remember the meeting.
The Bush Justice Department -- perhaps Mr. Thornburgh himself -- denied a request to send investigators to Rome. A couple of long years later, the local Atlanta manager was indicted; Justice's theory is that he alone is guilty and the bank headquarters in Rome is innocent. But the local fall guy changed his mind about taking the fall, withdrew his plea of guilty and charged the C.I.A. knew of Rome's involvement in the Iraqi financing; documents forced out of the C.I.A. by the Senate corroborate that.
So here we are with the Clinton Justice Department going to trial to prove Rome's bankers innocent, when Italian and American investigators know the opposite is true. That smells fairly fishy, and nobody at Agriculture or Justice wants to take the responsibility.
In an act of faccia tosta (that's chutzpah in Italian), Lavoro sued for its U.S.-guaranteed loan money in Federal claims court. Last week, Justice asked that a decision to pay be dismissed or deferred pending the outcome of the trial of Christopher Drogoul, Lavoro's Atlanta manager.
That covers posteriors at Justice and Agriculture. If Drogoul is convicted in Atlanta and bank headquarters is absolved, the American taxpayer will have to make good on Jim Baker's backdoor financing of Saddam -- but our bureaucrats can say, "The claims court made us do it."
Iraqgate -- the secret, unlawful American-British-Italian buildup of Saddam -- marches on. In London, another front-organization case collapsed when it came out that British intelligence was running Matrix-Churchill, the outfit that supplied Saddam's advanced technology. Paul Henderson, the purported spy heading the front, told me he could say nothing because he was writing a book. A British independent counsel, looking into that end of the global scandal, will presumably buy a copy.
Meanwhile, after a two-year delay by an assistant U.S. Attorney in Miami, Justice is finally moving against Carlos Cardoen, the merchant of cluster bombs to Saddam. According to Alan Friedman of The Financial Times, the arms dealer says this was also with the Bush Administration's guilty knowledge.
Ironically, when Representative Charles Ford of the House Agriculture Committee brought in a witness to brief the new Attorney General on a facet of Iraqgate, they were shunted off to Janet Reno's new assistant from Miami, Richard Scruggs -- the same guy who failed to aggressively pursue the Cardoen case.
Catch the pattern: Justice's Public Integrity Section chief, Michael Shepard, last month declined to prosecute the Commerce official who misled Congress on 68 export licenses to Iraq; he was just named U.S. Attorney in Chicago.
Ms. Reno, who spoke up for the Independent Counsel Act before Congress, has no idea how many career officials in her headless Criminal Division fear being called before a grand jury by an Iraqgate special prosecutor. She'll get the necessary new law; let's hope she resists the manipulations of her new colleagues.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Governor Has Let Cities and Towns Go Begging

 BODY:

To the Editor:
William Safire's column extolling the virtues of a Presidential run by Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts ("What About Weld?", May 6) needs some correction before yet another political myth is created.
Mr. Safire quotes Governor Weld's claim that he has "balanced three budgets without raising taxes or borrowing," thus proving that the conservative Governor Weld is able to do what Gov. Michael S. Dukakis before him and President Clinton were unable to do. 
 Perhaps Mr. Safire does not know that at precisely the same time the Commonwealth of Massachusetts achieved a balanced budget and investment-grade bond ratings, nine Massachusetts cities and towns were downgraded to junk-bond status, and several hovered near bankruptcy. Governor Weld's primary tool for The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters must include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that we cannot acknowledge or return unpublished letters. Those selected for publication may be shortened for space reasons.
achieving fiscal stability was cutting state aid to Massachusetts cities and towns. Passing the buck may be good politics, but it is certainly not proof of good public management.
As to Mr. Safire's claim that Mr. Weld "rejuvenated the Massachusetts economy," one need only look at the loss of 130,000 jobs in Massachusetts since Governor Weld took office. It would not be fair to blame Governor Weld for the economic woes of Massachusetts, just as it would be unfair to credit Governor Dukakis with the "Massachusetts miracle."
But characterizing buck-passing tax policy and continuing job losses as qualifications for the Presidency is unreasonable.
 
JEROME E. RUBIN
Boston, May 10, 1993

HEADLINE: End the War in Bosnia - Peacefully;
Send NATO Troops to Bosnia

BYLINE: The author of this article is a U.S. official who requested anonymity.

 BODY:
An extraordinary combination of circumstances makes this a propitious moment for a new effort to end the cruel war in Bosnia. It is not a time to step back, although the temptation to do so is strong.
After the defiant vote of Bosnian Serb leaders to reject the Vance-Owen peace plan, and under intense pressure from economic sanctions and President Clinton's credible threat of force, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia has suddenly stopped encouraging his allies in Bosnia. Boris Yeltsin has made it clear that he supports international peace efforts and will not throw a life preserver to Serbs in either Bosnia or Serbia. Finally, recent fighting around Mostar has reminded the world that Croatia as well as Serbia must be brought to heel if there is to be progress toward peace. 
 If the U.S. and its allies can agree on a strategy to take advantage of these circumstances, they can fashion a new approach that could break Bosnia's spiral of death, prevent a spill-over of the conflict to neighboring lands and discourage nationalist extremists who hope to provoke similar conflicts elsewhere. This would have to be a comprehensive strategy, not a piecemeal approach like those attempted so far, and it would have to be given time to work.
In order to be successful, any framework for peace in the Balkans must meet several tests: It must guarantee respect for internationally recognized borders, though it could hold out the possibility of future adjustments through mutual agreement. It must not reward those who have engaged in odious "ethnic cleansing" in pursuit of racially pure nation-states. And it must strengthen rather than weaken NATO by attracting support from both the United States and its European allies, as well as from Moscow.
Unless such a solution can be found, the carnage in Bosnia will worsen and the message of international impotence will encourage similar conflicts in other parts of Europe and in the former Soviet republics.
Whatever the merits of aerial bombardment against Serb supply lines and artillery positions, it is now clear that European governments will not support it. Nor will they accept a lifting of the arms embargo against Bosnia's Muslim-led Government. The challenge in Bosnia is not to introduce new weaponry but to find ways of reducing the vast arsenals already there.
One promising approach is the idea of "safe havens," which has been raised by the Security Council and finds especially strong support in France. Simply declaring certain besieged cities to be havens and demanding that fighting there cease, however, is not enough. A multilateral ground force is needed to enforce peace in these havens and to show warring factions that it is to their advantage to silence their guns.
This ground force could not succeed unless it included troops from the U.S. President Clinton has, until now, opposed the commitment of American troops in the absence of a peace settlement, but if they were used to help protect safe havens, their role would be essentially defensive, rather than offensive. They would, of course, be in harm's way, as were the 40 U.N. soldiers from other lands who have already lost their lives in the former Yugoslavia. European leaders, however, are right whenthey say that American concern over the killing in Bosnia cannot be taken fully seriously as long as the U.S. is unwilling to share all the risks.
To be credible, such a military force, of 25,000 to 50,000, would have to cooperate with NATO and include Russian troops. It would need a U.N. mandate stronger than the one under which the forces in Bosnia are now
 
 
 




 
operating. The mandate should allow blue-helmeted soldiers to operate under Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, which authorizes troops to enforce their will rather than serving simply as observers, mediators and protectors of aid convoys.
This force would first establish a presence in the designated havens, which would include Sarajevo. It would then pursue the urgent goal of silencing the artillery that is pounding these unfortunate communities. To achieve this, the West should introduce a carrot-and-stick policy that, unlike past policies, would seek to increase both the costs of continued defiance and the attractiveness of cooperation.
Within the safe havens, civilian and military authorities would be pressed to comply with the Vance-Owen plan, including disarmament. As soon as they do so, their communities would qualify for protection against further aggression, protection that could include air strikes against artillery positions. In addition, these communities would be offered generous aid for reconstruction. Water and electric supplies would be restored, destroyed homes and public buildings rebuilt and a semblance of normal life restored. Refugees would be invited back.
The considerable costs of reconstruction should be borne by a specially created bank. Since the first havens would be predominantly Muslim, the bank should be financed in large part by wealthy Muslim countries that have expressed willingness to help but have not yet been given a format.
At the same time, hostile forces surrounding the havens must be completely isolated from outside support. Observers with modern monitoring equipment should be posted along Bosnia's borders. No supplies of any kind, with the exception of basic foods and medicine delivered by international agencies, should be permitted to reach fighters who refuse to lay down their weapons or civilian communities that back them. The holdouts would soon find it impossible to grow, produce, buy or sell almost anything at all.
The contrast between relative prosperity within regions that accept the Vance-Owen plan and steep decline in conditions outside them would soon become stark. U.N. troops would seek gradually to expand the size of the havens by promising those outside an end to privation if they cooperate.
President Milosevic should be tested to see if he is really serious about ending support for the Bosnian Serbs. Remembering his record of mendacity, we should proceed warily. But if international monitors verify that he has cut Belgrade's lifeline to the Bosnian Serbs, foreign governments should agree to discuss easing the sanctions that have crippled his country.
President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia should be put to a comparable test. Croatia has regular Army troops fighting in Bosnia, holding down front-line positions against Serb fighters but also terrorizing civilians in Mostar and central Bosnia. Mr. Tudjman should be told that if he does not withdraw them and stop supplying Croatian militias, who are engaged in their own "ethnic cleansing," his country will be punished with sanctions as harsh as those that have been applied against Serbia.
Another incentive should be the presentation of all war crimes cases to the U.N. tribunal to be established for this purpose. Hatred among the three warring sides has reached such a level that there is little confidence in the ability of any of them to prosecute these cases fairly. Turning them over to a body that could guarantee due process would build confidence in the Vance-Owen process and ease fears that the trials would degenerate into orgies of political revenge. The tribunal could also hold out the possibility of amnesty if it could be negotiated by the parties.
This strategy would require re-thinking some assumptions. It would require President Clinton to modify two conditions he has set in the past: He would have to accept the involvement of American ground troops before the signing of a comprehensive peace treaty, since European countries alone would be unwilling to launch such an ambitious new effort. And he would have to permit the deployment of these troops without a firm timetable for their withdrawal.
Another troublesome question is that of getting aid to the safe havens, which at least at the outset would be encircled by hostile fighters. Some aid could be dropped by air, but much would certainly have to be trucked across unfriendly territory. If Serb fighters continue to block these convoys, U.N. ground troops might have to use force to bring them through, increasing the likelihood of casualties.
There are two important reasons to commit military and economic resources to a multilateral effort to bring peace to Bosnia. The first is one to which Americans have already responded, which is the crying need to relieve unimaginable human suffering. The second is that American national security interests are at stake. NATO and the United Nations, the institutions best equipped to keep international peace, have been badly battered by this crisis. If they cannot act now, the world will be even more poorly equipped when the next similar crisis erupts in Eastern Europe or the former Soviet republics.

HEADLINE: New Chief: Computers And Sports

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Donald L. Morchower, who was named acting chief executive of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield , is a former semiprofessional basketball player experienced in computer and systems technology.
"I think I'm in shock; this whole thing has just come so quickly," Mr. Morchower said yesterday. "Now I've got 9,300 employees to be concerned about." 
 Until yesterday, Mr. Morchower was chief operating officer for Empire, focusing primarily on computer technology and customer service. He will serve as acting chief executive officer while the company conducts a search for a permanent chief executive. His salary remains $370,000 a year.
Mr. Morchower, 58, is a native of Bayonne, N.J., who now lives in Manhattan with his wife, Goldie. He graduated from Bayonne High School in 1952, then went to Georgetown University on a basketball scholarship, where he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in economics in 1956.
Mr. Morchower played semiprofessional basketball for local teams in the metropolitan region in the late 1950's and early 1960's, including several games against the Harlem Globetrotters..
 
A Computer Programmer
 For the first five years after his graduation from college, Mr. Morchower worked for the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America, first as a computer programmer, then as a systems analyst and eventually as manager of a systems unit.
In 1961, he went to work as a computer analyst in sales for the RCA Corporation. He was with RCA until November 1962, when he joined what was then Haskins & Sells, the accounting company that later became Deloitte & Touche. He worked first as a computer consultant but later was promoted to a partnership in the Haskin & Sells management consulting division.
Mr. Morchower later became the executive in charge of the company's national computer and technology consulting service, advising large corporations on the use of technology and the introduction of new systems. In 1984, he was named the partner in charge of the company's New Jersey management consulting services office.
Mr. Morchower was hired by Empire in July 1987 as chief information officer, in charge of all computer and technology-related activities. He was appointed chief operating officer of Empire in September 1990.
When he is not working "12-hour days," Mr. Morchower said, he likes to play tennis, read novels and travel. The Morchowers have one son, Matthew, 25, the head researcher for CBS-TV's coverage for the 1994 Winter Olympics.

HEADLINE: Senators Put Up A New Obstacle In Budget Fight

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
An influential bipartisan group of Senators threw a new obstacle in the path of President Clinton's budget plan today by offering an alternative proposal with fewer tax increases and deeper spending cuts.
The new plan itself stands no chance of passing in its present form, but it could provide a starting point for negotiations on changes to the President's plan. Its announcement raises new questions about whether the President's measures will command enough support to be approved by the House of Representatives next week and about the prospects when the legislation reaches the Senate.
 
President Calls Plan Unfair
 At the White House, Mr. Clinton denounced the alternative as a shift of the deficit-reduction burden "from wealthy Americans right onto the people just above the poverty line, the elderly and the working poor." 
 The central part of the plan is a rejection of the fuel tax that is one of the main revenue raisers in Mr. Clinton's program. Other spending cuts would come from placing a ceiling on Medicare and Medicaid expenses and limiting the annual cost-of-living increases for retired people getting Social Security and other Federal pensions above $600 a month.
The group offering the new plan was led by Senators David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, and John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, both senior members of the Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction over tax bills. They were joined at a news conference in the Capitol this morning by Senators J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, and William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine.
"This plan," Mr. Boren said, "represents a third option in addition to the unacceptable choices of either doing nothing about reducing the budget deficit or reducing it mainly through tax increases."
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, said he was still convinced that the President's plan would pass Congress largely intact.
 
Possible Effects in House
 But the immediate consequence of the proposal is that it could cause anxiety among wavering Democratic representatives, just when Mr. Clinton thought he had sewed up a majority in the House with his visit to the Capitol on Wednesday morning.
The House plans to vote on the Clinton proposal next Thursday. Some lawmakers who would like to support it worry that they will cast a politically risky vote only to have Mr. Clinton strike a compromise in the Senate.
Democrats in Congress overwhelmingly back Mr. Clinton's proposal, and almost all Republicans oppose any plan to raise taxes. But the four Senators could hold the balance of power.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, depicted their plan as the opening wedge in negotiations, a point disputed by most Democrats.
The four Senators calculated that their plan would lower the deficit by $542 billion over five years, more than the $496 billion proposed by Mr. Clinton, but the accuracy of their figures has not been completely reviewed by the Congressional Budget Office.
The new proposal would reduce spending by $2 for every $1 that taxes would be raised. The Clinton plan, by contrast, is divided evenly between tax increases and spending cuts.
In addition to the new fuel tax, the bipartisan group rejected Clinton plans to lift the $135,000 salary limit above which Medicare taxes are not owed and to increase the tax on diesel fuel for barges in inland waterways.
The four favor the higher tax rates on wealthy individuals and corporations that Mr. Clinton wants, but they would postpone the effective date for six months until June 30, 1993. They would also adjust the value of capital gains for inflation that occurs after the first of this year.
No other senators endorsed the plan. Several senators who had been negotiating with them for days, including John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Kent Conrad of North Dakota, both Democrats, and John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, a Republican, dropped out.
Congressional authorities said the Administration had won Mr. Breaux's support by promising him a tax break for exported petrochemical products and had turned Mr. Conrad around by supporting tax breaks for farmers. Mr. Johnston was not brought into the group until about 6 P.M. Wednesday.
Mr. Boren is the pivotal figure. He holds the swing vote on the Finance Committee, where Democrats have a majority of only 11 to 9. Since the Republican members have announced that they will vote against the Clinton budget, a bill cannot get out of the committee without Mr. Boren's vote.
His main motive and that of Mr. Johnston seem to be to kill the proposed fuel tax, which might damage the economy in oil-producing states like Oklahoma and Louisiana.
The Clinton plan would raise $72 billion over five years from a new tax on fuels based on the amount of heat they generate. To discourage their use, a surcharge would be placed on oil products, except heating oil. When fully effective, the Administration says, it would cause typical families about $200 a year. The cost to families with incomes below about $30,000 would be offset by income tax credits.
Opponents of the energy tax, especially the oil industry, have lobbied intensively against it. The aluminum industry and farming interests want exemptions from its provisions.
 
Prospects of Energy Tax
 Mr. Johnston proclaimed the energy tax "dead," saying it could never win a majority in the Senate. But the two Democrats, as well as Mr. Danforth and Mr. Cohen, were also responding to what seems to be a popular view in the country that more spending cuts are necessary if taxes are to be increased.
The cuts they proposed would be unpopular, striking at such sacred cows as Social Security, and slashing Medicare and Medicaid before President Clinton even offers his plan to restrain health care costs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David L. Boren speaking at news conference as a bipartisan group of Senators proposed an alternative budget plan. With him were, from left, William S. Cohen, J. Bennett Johnston and John C. Danforth. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
