HEADLINE: CHANGING HEALTH CARE;
CLINTON ADVISERS OUTLINE BIG SHIFT FOR MALPRACTICE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
President Clinton's advisers outlined a proposal today for sweeping change in the handling of medical malpractice lawsuits under which individual doctors would be relieved of legal responsibility for negligence.
Instead of suing their doctors, injured patients would sue insurance companies and health maintenance organizations that employ the doctors. 
 Dr. Robert Berenson, a senior member of the staff of Mr. Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, said the proposal was based on the idea of "enterprise liability." Corporate enterprises -- networks of doctors, hospitals and insurance companies -- would be legally responsible for injuries caused by a doctor's negligence, he said.
Under this approach, Dr. Berenson said: "Settlements would occur many years earlier in many cases. Patients would get the compensation they need, would get their rehabilitation and their lost wages, instead of having the sort of lottery that now takes five or 10 years."
 
Informal Hearings
 Health plans would be more likely to settle meritorious claims through informal hearings and other alternatives to litigation, he said. Now, 60 percent of the costs associated with malpractice represent court costs and payments to lawyers, not payments to injured patients, he said.
Further savings would be achieved by making health plans responsible for setting guidelines and monitoring the quality of care delivered by doctors, officials said. Doctors who follow the guidelines would not be as vulnerable to malpractice charges as they are now, they said. Many experts believe the guidelines themselves are likely to improve the overall quality of medical care and may also discourage doctors from performing unneeded tests and procedures.
Doctors have long sought changes in the handling of malpractice cases, and the White House apparently hoped to win their support. But doctors' groups complained today that the plan would lead to intrusive supervision of their care by insurance companies and other corporate enterprises.
The Administration contends that its proposal can reduce litigation costs, but does not envision huge savings. It does say the proposal can benefit consumers by giving health plans strong incentives to monitor and improve the quality of care.
Mr. Clinton will also ask Congress to establish certain legal standards and uniform procedures for the handling of malpractice cases, Administration officials said. The handling of such claims is now governed mainly by state law and, as a result, varies widely from state to state.
Dr. Berenson, the head of a committee working on malpractice, and Kathleen Hastings, a member of the committee, gave details of the Administration's thinking at separate conferences today.
Describing the proposal, Dr. Berenson said: "A health plan would be liable for the negligent acts of its contracted or employed practitioners and providers. The individual physician would not be personally liable for negligence, but rather the health plan would be."
President Clinton originally intended to send his health plan to Congress by May 3, but has fallen behind schedule, and the White House now says he will not unveil it before mid-June. Congress is sure to alter it, but lawmakers express confidence that they will pass legislation by the end of next year to remake the nation's health-care system.
 
No Final Decisions
 Mr. Clinton has not made final decisions about the details of his health plan. But Dr. Berenson said the staff of the task force had recommended the idea of enterprise liability to Mr. Clinton.
Dr. Berenson said he still favored the proposal despite opposition by doctors and insurance companies. Insurers dislike the proposal because they expect to form and operate many of the new health-care networks and they would be defendants in many malpractice lawsuits. Doctors and insurers fear that the number of lawsuits will rise because consumers will perceive big insurance companies as having deep pockets.
Kirk B. Johnson, senior vice president and general counsel of the American Medical Association, said that the White House was initially surprised at the doctors' opposition but that it was going full steam ahead with the proposal.
Doctors fear "there will be a very significant loss of physician autonomy" as corporate enterprises supervise the practice of medicine in minute detail, he said.
Dr. Berenson said the corporate enterprise, or the health plan, could establish and enforce guidelines for its doctors, so "there will be much more consistent oversight of practitioner activities."
Insurers do not relish such a role. "It gets us involved in the practice of medicine," said James W. McLane, chief executive of Aetna health plans, a unit of Aetna Life and Casualty. "It doesn't do anything but shift responsibility for malpractice from doctors and hospitals to another entity."
Consumer groups reacted cautiously, expressing neither strong support nor vehement opposition. They do not see the proposal as a big improvement or setback for consumers.
Linda A. Lipsen, chief lobbyist for Consumers Union, said the proposal for enterprise liability was better than proposals that would limit payments to patients injured at the hands of doctors and hospitals. The task force is apparently still considering such limits, long advocated by doctors groups.
Dr. Berenson said the task force proposal would cut the costs of litigation. "We would move to a single defendant as opposed to the current system, where we have multiple defendants, all sort of pointing the finger at each other," he said. "This structural change anticipates where the health system is going anyway. Health care is no longer a case of a single practitioner and a patient. For virtually any service, you're going to have integrated teams of professionals working together. In 10 or 15 years, the whole system is going to be this way. We want to juice the system a little bit and move it faster."
 
Program Called Untested
 But Mr. Johnson of the A.M.A. said enterprise liability had not been tested. "It's an academic concept that on paper achieves several goals, but in practice it raises very serious questions," he said. For example, he explained, doctors fear that corporate health plans will find it expedient to settle cases where the doctors met the prevailing standard of care.
Mr. Johnson said a health plan could usurp the doctors' authority by telling them, in effect: "You are an employee. You belong to us. We will decide if you performed negligently. We will settle the case for you."
Under the proposal described by Dr. Berenson, health plans would buy insurance to cover malpractice claims, or they could serve as their own insurers. Doctors would not have to pay premiums for such coverage, but they might get lower salaries if the health plan had to pay high premiums and large claims.
The cost of insurance would be a cost of doing business, and "the health plan would have to pass on its costs in its compensation package to physicians," Dr. Berenson said.
The Government says doctors spend $5 billion to $6 billion a year on malpractice insurance premiums, with hospitals spending half again as much. But malpractice premiums account for less than 1 percent of national health spending.
The American Medical Association says that defensive medicine, which includes extra tests ordered to protect doctors against legal claims, costs more than $15 billion a year. But the Congressional Budget Office says that many of those tests "would probably be undertaken for other reasons," and that "the threat of malpractice suits may have improved the quality of medical practice."

HEADLINE: Man Wins $1 Million Sex Harassment Suit

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 20

 BODY:
In what legal experts say is the largest judgment of its kind, a jury has awarded more than $1 million to a male former manager at a spa manufacturing company who sued his former female supervisor, claiming she had sexually harassed him daily on the job for six years.
Experts in sexual harassment and lawyers in the case said that while other men have successfully claimed sexual harassment by women superiors, they knew of no lawsuits involving such a large damage award. In part that is because California law imposes no limits on damages in such cases, whereas most other states and the Federal Government either ban or place strict caps on punitive damages when employees claim sexual harassment. 
 The case has drawn attention to a problem that some legal experts say has been overlooked in the current focus on harassment of women by male superiors.
"We believe that all persons, including men, have a right to a workplace free of the hostile and intolerable conditions of sexual harassment," said Gloria Allred, the lawyer for the manager, Sabino Gutierrez, 33, of Ontario, Calif. "Men are also entitled to freedom from sex discrimination and the emotional and economic harm that sexual harassment inflicts."
The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission reported that last year, 968 out of a total of 10,577 sexual harassment claims were filed by men. In 1991 the figure was 514 out of a total of 6,886. The commission figures do not indicate whether the claims were directed toward men or women.
Susan Estrich, who teaches sex discrimination law at the University of Southern California, said men were usually more reluctant than women to come forward with claims of sexual harassment. "Traditionally, our imagery is that men should enjoy this and should consider themselves lucky," Professor Estrich said. "The reality is that not all men do enjoy this."
The Superior Court jury of 10 women and 2 men voted unanimously on Tuesday to award Mr. Gutierrez $375,000 in compensatory damages for emotional distress and $82,000 for lost earnings and benefits. They also awarded him $560,000 in punitive damages, including $10,000 assessed against Mr. Gutierrez' former supervisor, Maria Martinez.

HEADLINE: Venezuelan Leader Quits to Face Trial

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 20

 BODY:
President Carlos Andres Perez said today that he would surrender his powers in order to defend himself against corruption charges in an impeachment trial.
The president of the Senate, Octavio Lepage, is expected to become Acting President on Friday. Within 30 days, Congress is to elect a President to serve until Feb. 2, the end of Mr. Perez's five-year term. 
 The latest Latin American leader to run afoul of corruption charges, Mr. Perez fell victim to a Supreme Court decision today recognizing that grounds exist to prosecute him on charges of embezzling and misappropriating $17 million in Government funds.
The Senate, which is controlled by Mr. Perez's enemies, is expected to vote Friday to authorize the impeachment trial, which seems certain to stretch far beyond Feb. 2.
 
'Never Any Crime,' He Says
 "I will hand over my office to the president of Congress," Mr. Perez said in a defiant television speech that reviewed his half-century of participation in Venezuelan politics. Saying he was "neither vanquished nor defeated," the President added: "There never was any crime."
Mr. Perez's fall from power marks the end of the career of a grand old man of Latin American politics, a 70-year-old survivor of jailings, exile, Communist guerrillas and, last year, two military coup attempts.
But residents of this capital greeted the Supreme Court vote with whistles and firecrackers and the banging of pots. With horns blowing, caravans of cars streamed through streets near the modern Supreme Court building, passing walls daubed with anti-Perez graffiti reading "Jail for the Big Rat Perez."
"Honesty has triumphed," bellowed an opposition congressman, Orlando Fernandez, as joyous crowds waved flags and celebrated outside the whitewashed neo-classical Congress building. At nightfall, the police fired tear gas to disperse a crowd of 1,000 people chanting anti-Perez slogans, but by late evening the streets seemed quiet.
Nevertheless, some business people worried about the political stability of Venezuela, which has the hemisphere's largest oil reserves. The country's 35-year-old civilian democracy is Latin America's oldest.
Venezuela is the second-largest source of United States oil imports, after Saudi Arabia, and per capita its 20 million inhabitants are Latin America's largest importers of American products.
Sometimes called "Miami with mountains," this highly Americanized capital is a mix of expressways, glass-sheathed high-rises and shantytowns, all cupped in a verdant bowl.
"The oil will keep flowing, but our concern is over the economic reforms," an American diplomat said today, echoing uncertainty here that Venezuela's next President will continue Mr. Perez's four-year-old campaign to dismantle state controls over the economy.
 
Cabinet Submits Resignations
 To smooth a seemingly inevitable transfer of power, all members of Mr. Perez's Cabinet submitted their resignations today.
Irrespective of the impeachment drive, candidates are already campaigning for Venezuela's presidential elections, which are to be held Dec. 5.
In a separate campaign, Mr. Perez promised tonight to stump the nation over the next six months, trying to clear his name "for history."
"I've never enriched myself," the embattled leader said in his address. "There has been a systematic, long and obsessive campaign against me and my Government."
During the trial, Mr. Perez will continue to enjoy the title of President and will live in the official residence, La Casona.
"We are going to have two presidents -- a titular president without any authority -- and a President elected by Congress, with all authority," Arturo Uslar Pietri, a prominent Venezuelan novelist, complained after watching the speech. "This will condemn the nation to anarchy and disaster."
 
Two Aides Face Trial
 According to prosecutors, Mr. Perez and two former aides, Reinaldo Figueredo and Alejandro Izaguirre, profitted from a multimillion dollar currency manipulation a few days after Mr. Perez took office in February 1989.
The prosecutors charge that about $10 million was made by first changing a discretionary fund into dollars at a preferential rate. After a 88 percent devaluation of Venezuela's currency, the bolivar, the dollars were changed back into bolivars. The two aides also face trial.
"Venezuela is undertaking a struggle against corruption -- not a personal persecution," said the author of the impeachment petition, Ramon Escovar Salom, the Attorney General.
Last week the president of Mr. Prez's party, Humberto Celli, told reporters that Mr. Perez's resignation would be "the least traumatic way out."
Seeking to instill more democracy in this nation, Latin America's wealthiest, Mr. Perez appointed independent judges to the Supreme Court, spoke out against corruption and pushed for democratic elections of state governors. To some here, Mr. Perez, often referred to as CAP, his initials, has fallen victim to these very forces of modernization.
Jose Vicente Rangel, a journalist and bitter opponent of the President, said: "The important thing is that CAP will be removed without one shot fired, without one garrison rising up. This shows the institutions of democracy are functioning."
 
Other Leaders Fall
 After two years of military uprisings and violent student street protests, Mr. Perez was finally brought down by the bane of Latin American politicians in the 1990's -- a corruption charge.
First, the Peruvian President, Alberto K. Fujimori, closed courts and the Congress in April of last year, charging that corruption had made the institutions useless. A wave of popular support greeted the moves.
In Brazil, President Fernando Collor de Mello was forced to resign in December after a Senate impeachment trial began on charges that he benefited from a multimillion-dollar kickback ring.
In Argentina, corruption charges forced several close aides to President Carlos Saul Menem to resign over the last two years.

 Feb. 2, 1989: Mr. Perez is inaugurated and quickly adopts a free-market economic plan, cutting subsidies and ending price and foreign-exchange controls.
Feb. 27, 1989: Riots break out in Caracas, with about 300 people killed.
Feb. 4, 1992: Rebellious army units attack the presidential palace and residence, killing about 40 people. Loyal troops quell Venezuela's first coup attempt in 30 years.
Nov. 27, 1992: Air force units rebel and bomb the presidential palace. Coup leaders accuse Mr. Perez of refusing to move against corruption and political cliques. Order is restored, but at a cost of about 230 lives.

May 20: Mr. Perez says he will surrender authority to defend himself after the Supreme Court rules that grounds exist to prosecute him on corruption charges.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says 165 Concerns Help Belgrade Defy U.N.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
Stepping up the economic pressure on Belgrade, the United States today identified a worldwide network of 165 Serbian companies that it said were being used by Belgrade to defy United Nations sanctions.
The Administration also barred American companies from doing business with the Serbian concerns and urged foreign governments to freeze the assets of the companies. 
 "Yugoslavia has continued to conduct its international trade and to earn hard currency through its network of foreign-located subsidiaries, branches and representative offices," said R. Richard Newcomb, director of the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control.
 
The Yugoslav Connection
 Mr. Newcomb said that naming the companies would "help expose and interdict the millions of dollars in Yugoslav Government assets flowing between private bank vaults abroad."
With the United States and its allies at odds over how to quell the fighting in the Balkans, economic sanctions remain the main form of leverage on Belgrade.
The Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, has said he has closed the Serbian border to Bosnia to all but food and medical relief. But some trucks continue to cross the border, and United States officials have expressed skepticism about Mr. Milosevic's intentions in his late support of the United Nations-European Community peace plan, which has been repeatedly rejected by his Serbian colleagues in Bosnia.
 
A Test for U.S. Allies
 Publication of the list of Serbian companies will not only increase pressure on Belgrade, but also effectively put many United States allies to a test. Russia and Western European nations, which have stressed the need to press Belgrade and the Bosnian Serbs to stop the fighting in the Balkans, are now being asked to freeze the assets of the companies on their territory.
Under the Security Council resolution adopted last month to tighten economic sanctions on Yugoslavia, United Nations members are required to take action against companies identified as working on behalf of Belgrade.
Many of the 165 companies named by the United States were once part of the state-run trading system of Yugoslavia, which now consists of Serbia and Montenegro. Although these companies are no longer state-owned, United States officials say, they are still taking orders from Belgrade.
"The companies named today either are organized or located in Yugoslavia or are owned or controlled by other Yugoslavia-based companies or the Yugoslav Government," the Treasury Department said in a statement today.
 
Source of Foreign Exchange
 The Administration says some of the companies have been a useful source of foreign currency for Serbia. By earning foreign exchange, the companies are able to finance attempts to buy and deliver goods to Serbia in violation of United Nations sanctions.
United States officials said that other companies listed as being under Belgrade's control are not currently believed to be actively involved in circumventing the trade ban. But the officials worry that some dormant companies controlled by Yugoslavia could be activated as other parts of the trading network are shut down.
Many of the companies are foreign branches of General Export and Inex-Interexport Ltd., Serbian-based trading companies. Others are individual companies located around the world.
The network reaches well into Russia and Eastern Europe. The Treasury Department named companies in Russia, Ukraine, Latvia, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria, Romania, Albania and Poland as being under the control of Yugoslavia.
 
Companies in West Europe
 Companies based in Western Europe that are controlled by Yugoslavia are located in Germany, Italy, Greece, Britain, Norway, France, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Austria, Belgium, Finland and Liechtenstein, the Treasury Department said.
A number of companies are in Cyprus, long a focus of concern because of Yugoslav banks and companies there. Some companies identified as being under Yugoslav control are in Arab and Islamic nations, which have been demanding that tough action be taken to protect the Bosnian Muslims against Serbian attacks.
Specifically, the Treasury Department listed companies in Kuwait, Syria, Egypt, Tunisia, Morocco, Iraq, Turkey and Libya as being under Yugoslav control.
 
Companies In Iran
 Export companies in Iran, which has been shipping arms to the Muslims, were also named, as were companies in Pakistan, Bangladesh and India.
Other concerns that have reportedly worked for the Serbs can be found in Israel, China, Mongolia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Armenia, the Sudan, Togo, Zambia, Cuba, Australia and Canada.
None of the companies listed today are based in the United States, though a dozen of them have done business with American companies, according to United States officials.
The Treasury Department also named five individuals as working on behalf of Belgrade. They include Bosko Kostic at AY Bank Ltd., the Anglo-Yugoslav bank in England. Another is Miodrag Zecevic at the Banque Franco Yugoslav in Paris.
A senior Administration official said the identification of the companies was likely to prompt Belgrade to "go covert" and establish a new underground network of companies to support sanctions-busting efforts.
"We will seek to identify the underground network as well, to the extent we have the resources to do it," the official said.
An assessment by the Central Intelligence Agency earlier this year concluded that sanctions alone were unlikely to halt the fighting in Bosnia, in part because the Bosnian Serbs had large stocks of weapons and were being resupplied by the Yugoslav Government. Some experts believe, however, that Belgrade could slow the fighting if Mr. Milosevic enforced the strict blockade on the Bosnian Serbs, as he has vowed to do.

HEADLINE: Budget Rebels Defy Parties' Leaders

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The first serious challenge to President Clinton's tax plan springs mostly out of an odd sort of no man's land between the two major parties, a wilderness where philosophies overlap and the residents have adapted to political survival without outside help.
It appears to be an exceedingly small place. 
 Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma is a fiscal conservative among the Democrats, who have embraced the President's plan for a record tax increase and a raft of bold and costly new Federal programs. Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri is a fiscal liberal, as Republicans go, in a party that has forsworn any increase in taxes, however dire the nation's budgetary straits.
Mutually aghast over the ballooning Federal deficit but in shock over Mr. Clinton's plans to deal with it, Mr. Boren and Mr. Danforth spent the last week scouring the Senate for like-minded lawmakers who would break ranks with their parties and endorse an alternative tax plan. In the end, they found only two: William S. Cohen, a Maine Republican, and J. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat.
"This is a group that gathered because of a sincere feeling that the President's package was lopsided on taxes and didn't have enough spending cuts," said Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, a Danforth-style Republican who flirted with joining them but elected this morning not to. "I have to commend anyone who's courageous enough to propose a solution."
 
Pivotal Political Battle
 Courageous, certainly, for they are defying their White House or Republican leaders in what is shaping up as the year's pivotal political battle. At least five others senators, all "deficit hawks" who want deeper cuts in the budget, flirted with the Boren-Danforth cabal, but demurred for political or ideological reasons. They included Democrats like Sam Nunn of Georgia and Kent Conrad of North Dakota and Republicans like Rhode Island's John Chafee.
But only fools rush in, and none of these Senators are fools. Their bravery is fortified by the security of a rock-solid Senate seat, the predominance of home-state opinion, the prospect of substantial political gain, or all three.
Republicans are at somewhat less political risk because their votes are not needed to enact Mr. Clinton's plan. And no Republican is less encumbered by political pressures than Mr. Danforth, who has said he will retire next year to return to private legal practice or the priesthood.
But none has been more outspoken about the threat posed by the deficit, either. "Danforth has warned about the danger of the deficit since the mid-80's," said one lobbyist who knows him well. "He's never worried about the politics; he just believes you ought to roll up your sleeves, do something and the heck with the consequences."
The other Republican, Mr. Cohen, shares Mr. Danforth's fiscal leanings and Mr. Boren's bent for independence. Befitting a state that gave Ross Perot one of his strongest showings in last November's election, Mr. Cohen is one of the Senate's least partisan Republicans. He also is a close friend of Mr. Boren, having served as vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee when he headed the panel in the last term of Congress. Never a strong Republican, Mr. Cohen risks little by advocating the same sort of deficit reduction that Perot supporters would logically favor.
 
Blessed With Safe Seat
 But Senator Boren, in particular, is taking a leap that friends say is rooted in principle but could produce big political gains. He is the swing vote on the Finance Committee, the Senate panel through which Mr. Clinton's tax-and-spending package must pass before reaching a final vote.
A senator since 1978 and Governor of Oklahoma before that, the 52-year-old Mr. Boren is blessed with one of the safest seats in the Senate -- and with that, has the ability to take on political tasks that might daunt less popular politicians. For example, he is the chief sponsor of Senate legislation to overhaul campaign-spending laws, a proposal many lawmakers enthusiastically favor in principle but would just as soon forget in private.
On campaign finance and many other issues, Senator Boren has worked to shape his own natural conservatism as much as possible to fit the Clinton Administration's policies.
Like the President, he is a Yale graduate and a Rhodes Scholar. But he broke ranks with Mr. Clinton on fiscal issues early this year. And with his latest protest, Mr. Boren is staking out a position as a Democratic pinch penny, a stand that could prove valuable if the President falters.
 
Opposed Stimulus Plan
 In March, Mr. Boren was one of two Senate Democrats who publicly opposed Mr. Clinton's proposal to spend $19 billion on an emergency package of jobs and public works projects, asserting that the President was raising the deficit before he cut the first cent from the Federal budget.
The White House scoffed, but the Senator proved prescient. Democratic leaders were never able to generate enough public support for the President's economic stimulus bill to break a Republican filibuster that eventually killed it outright.
In some other Democrats' view, Senator Boren and Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, another conservative Democrat, are the politicians who made opposition to the President a credible alternative when they spoke out against the economic stimulus package this spring.
And in the view of some Senate Republicans, it is Mr. Boren who is again making it conceivable -- even respectable -- to think of altering Mr. Clinton's tax plan, long after both houses of Congress had approved it in concept.
Mr. Johnston's motivations appear somewhat less lofty than Mr. Boren's.
Mr. Johnston has a reputation as one of the quietest and most adroit political tacticians in Congress. He is a relentless advocate of Louisiana's interests, and is chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, where policies affecting Louisiana's petroleum industry are cast.
Neither Mr. Johnston nor his junior colleague from Louisiana, Mr. Breaux, like the White House proposal to levy a tax on energy, and Mr. Johnston's decision to join Mr. Boren seems based as much on the prospect of changing that tax as on his concern about deficits. Indeed, Senate aides say Mr. Johnston did not join Mr. Boren's bandwagon until late Wednesday after his protege, Mr. Breaux, elected not to publicly oppose the President.

HEADLINE: Panel Expanding List for Base Closings

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
A Presidential commission studying which military bases to shrink or close is planning to add about 20 sites to the list the Pentagon has proposed, panel members said this week.
The Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission will consider the additional bases out of fairness to comparable installations that Defense Secretary Les Aspin has recommended be closed or reduced, commissioners said. The Pentagon had identified 43 large installations and 122 smaller sites for closing or consolidation. 
 The move reflects the arguments raised by communities that are home to bases on the Pentagon's list. Realizing that closings are inevitable in the post-cold-war era, many communities made detailed arguments to the commission on why their bases did a more efficient job than others handling comparable tasks.
 
Proposed Additions to List
 Commissioners also say they will probably suggest closing or reducing more bases than Mr. Aspin proposed in March. "We'll recommend more than Aspin, but I have no idea yet how many," said Beverly B. Byron, a commission member who is a former Democratic representative from Maryland.
Installations likely to be added for consideration include Fort Monroe, near Norfolk, Va.; Fort Gillem, Ga., near Atlanta; Fort Richardson, Alaska, and Plattsburgh Air Force Base in upstate New York. Additional Navy bases under consideration include those in Portsmouth, N.H.; Everett, Wash., near Seattle; Pascagoula, Miss., and Ingleside, Tex., near Corpus Christi. Commissioners will vote on which bases to add at a hearing here on Friday and perhaps Saturday.
Over the last two months the commission has already added for consideration the Monterey Presidio, Calif.; McClellan Air Force Base, near Sacramento, Calif.; the Great Lakes Naval Training Center north of Chicago, and the Agana Naval Air Station in Guam.
Several commissioners said in interviews that some bases on the Pentagon's list, including some in Charleston, S.C., and the San Francisco area, might be spared because of persuasive arguments that local politicians and business officials had made suggesting the closing of other installations that performed similar functions.
 
Deadline for Recommendations
 "Where the armed services have chosen to close a facility in favor of another, we ought to look, where prudent, to make a fair estimate of that choice," said Harry C. McPherson Jr., a commissioner who is a lawyer in Washington.
The seven-member commission has until July 1 to submit its final recommendations to President Clinton. The panel, which can add or subtract bases from the Pentagon's list, has until June 1 to identify bases for consideration this year. Installations left off that list are safe until the next round of base closings in 1995.
President Clinton and Congress must approve or reject the commission's final recommendations as a total package. But given the pressure to cut military spending, approval appears almost certain.
A sign of the consequences of base closings came today when the Pentagon announced the creation of a new post, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Economic Security. The official will oversee installation closings and programs to help military industries convert to civilian manufacturing.
The commission, set up to insulate Congress from angry constituents over base closings, has held a series of often emotional, raucous hearings in nine cities, from auditoriums packed with well-coached audiences in Charleston, to a dingy basement room in the Newark Symphony Hall on Mother's Day.
 
Criticism of Decisions
 From Boston to Birmingham, Ala., commissioners said, civic and political leaders have agreed that the military must cut costs but have criticized the Pentagon accounting that landed their hometown base on the list.
Most communities have stressed the local economic hardships that would result from a base closing, but the commission's criteria rest heavily on military utility.
"The more effective communities pointed out why we shouldn't close their base and brought up alternatives," said Hansford T. Johnson, a commission member who is a retired four-star general in the Air Force. "What we'll do on Friday doesn't presuppose the added bases will be closed, but it does put them at risk."
In Rome, N.Y., where the military has proposed reducing Griffiss Air Force Base, community leaders have held parades and rallies to sway the commission to select Plattsburgh Air Force Base, a refueling plane base in New York, instead. Griffiss advocates argue that the Air Force unfairly excluded the base from consideration for a new regional transportation command center, leaving it vulnerable to closing.
Commissioners said Charleston officials offered the most impressive presentation. A civic coalition armed with nearly $1 million in state, municipal and business contributions hired a Washington law firm and public relations company to help draft a cost analysis of closing several Navy installations in Charleston compared with others in Portsmouth, N.H., or Norfolk, Va.
 
Persuasive Arguments
 Speakers and a well-coached audience of 2,000 people held three dress rehearsals under the watchful eye of Elizabeth Inabinet, the president of the Charleston Chamber of Commerce, before the official commission hearings on May 1 and 2.
"Their presentation made a difference," said General Johnson. "They were in a class by themselves. We'll look very, very hard at Charleston."
Commissioners said some communities, including the Alameda Naval Air Station in the San Francisco Bay area, had reason to complain. "Alameda was scored as an air station, but has two piers for nuclear aircraft carriers that they didn't get credit for," Mrs. Byron said. "That's dumb."
Other bases that could be added to the list include Minot Air Force Base and Grand Forks Air Force Base in northern North Dakota, Ellsworth Air Force Base in southwestern South Dakota, as well as air logistics centers at Robins Air Force Base, near Macon, Ga., Tinker Air Force Base, outside Oklahoma City, Kelly Air Force in San Antonio, and Hill Air Force Base, outside Salt Lake City.

HEADLINE: Small Paragraph in Tax Measure Would Mean Bigger Bills for Some

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
A provision of the tax bill, inserted without debate as the House Ways and Means Committee drafted it last week, would draw many taxpayers into the highest tax brackets next year.
It would do this by delaying the usual annual adjustment of the tax tables to compensate for inflation. 
 At issue is what used to be known as bracket creep -- the tendency of wage earners to climb into higher tax brackets as their earnings kept up with inflation. Bracket creep ended in the 1980's, when tax brackets were adjusted to account for inflation.
The provision would reintroduce the risk of bracket creep next year for people whose earnings are near the thresholds of the top two, newly proposed tax brackets: one included single people with taxable earnings of $115,000 a year and couples with taxable earnings of $140,000 a year and the other includes those earning at least $250,000 a year, whether single or married. It is impossible to say how many people would end up in a higher tax bracket.
Some Republicans on the committee are enraged by the provision, which they said was never discussed during the committee's deliberations or disclosed in any of the papers explaining the bill's technical adjustments.
The provision, inserted as a technical adjustment by the committee's staff after the bill was voted on, would raise $1.6 billion over five years, the Republicans said today.
"There was no mention anywhere," said Representative Bill Thomas of California. "I can assure you, as you can imagine, that had that been announced, a debate would have ensued."
The loss of the adjustment for inflation, or indexing, even temporarily, is especially galling to Republicans because it was one of the hallmarks of the Reagan revolution in tax rates. Indexing, it was argued at the time, would eliminate a hidden tax increase that fueled Government spending.
Staff aides working for the committee's Democratic majority said that the provision was not a subterfuge but rather one of the innumerable compromises in technical language that are inevitable in a bill as complex as the 831-page document released today.
Democratic members of the committee, like Republicans, appear not to have given the matter much thought. Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, who participated actively in the drafting of the bill, said today that he was unaware of the provision.
Accountants poring over the details today said that they were startled to find this one.
Indexing has been mostly retained in the tax proposal issued last week by the Ways and Means Committee after a party-line vote. All Republicans opposed the measure.
But the two new upper income brackets -- the 36 percent bracket that affects individuals with taxable income of more than $115,000 and couples making more than $140,000, and the top-most bracket created by a 10 percent additional surcharge on taxes owed by individuals or couples with taxable income of more than $250,000 -- would not be adjusted upward to compensate for inflation until after 1994.
That means that an unmarried person whose taxable income is $114,500 in 1993, and who would be taxed at the 31 percent rate this year under the bill, could be vaulted into the 36 percent bracket in 1994 after receiving a raise pegged to the inflation rate.
And although the indexing of brackets would resume the next year, that person would be trapped in the higher bracket as long as the cost of living raises kept coming.
Republican members grumbled throughout the drafting sessions last week about procedural matters. But they were basically disregarded by the majority, led by the committee's chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who steered the package through.
A spokesman for Mr. Rostenkowski said that the chairman had not been made aware by any Republican members of the committee that they had any problems with the procedure.

HEADLINE: 26,000 Cubans Partly Blinded; Cause Is Unclear

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
A disease that impairs vision and affects the nerves has struck almost 26,000 Cubans, predominantly adult men, health officials in Havana say. The Government has invited foreign experts to investigate.
A neurologist from Columbia University's medical school who has examined patients in Cuba said the epidemic was apparently caused by a nutritional deficiency, probably a lack of vitamin B1, thiamine. 
 The Deputy Health Minister of Cuba, Jorge Antelo, has told the World Health Organization that the epidemic began in January 1992, amid harsh economic conditions and natural disasters.
Dr. Antelo said the 30-year trade embargo imposed on Cuba by the United States has been aggravated by an abrupt decline in trade with the former Soviet Union and its allies. Cuba also suffered heavy agricultural and industrial devastation from a tropical storm.
 
Syndrome Traced to 1888
 The epidemic is different from any ever reported, Dr. Antelo said, adding, "We cannot rule out the hand of the enemy in the origins of this disease as long as the cruel and heartless economic embargo remains in effect."
But American experts said the evidence seemed to point to a vitamin B1 deficiency known as Strachan syndrome, described by a British health officer, Dr. H. Strachan, in Jamaica in 1888.
The Pan American Health Organization in Washington has sent nine experts to Cuba to investigate the epidemic, which affected at least 25,959 Cubans as of April 30, Dr. Antelo said. The experts are expected to hold a news conference in Havana today, said Jose Ponce, a spokesman for the Cuban interest section in the Swiss Embassy in Washington.
Nearly 20,000 of those affected have suffered from a gradual loss of vision, Dr. Antelo said. About 5,500 have suffered burning sensations and other symptoms of peripheral nerve damage. Some have suffered an imbalance of gait known as ataxia.
 
The Therapy Required
 Thiamine deficiency is usually completely reversible if it is treated before the nerve damage becomes permanent and if the patient eats properly. Recovery from visual impairment and nerve damage may take time, depending on how promptly therapy is begun.
Tests have shown low amounts of thiamine in many patients, Dr. Antelo said, and this month health officials began giving multi-vitamins to the entire population.
Many patients have shown improvement, said Michio Hirano, a neurologist at Columbia University who spent a week in Cuba earlier this month, examining patients in Havana and Santiago.
Maurice Victor, an expert on nutritional nerve disorders at Dartmouth Medical School and a co-author of neurology textbooks, said that on the basis of the available evidence, "there is nothing mysterious about it -- it's Strachan syndrome."
The syndrome, well known to nutritionists, was found during the Spanish Civil War and affects many undernourished people and alcoholics in the United States and other countries, he said.
 
Hunt for a Cause
 The epidemic was first recognized in a tobacco-growing area of Pinar del Rio, in western Cuba. Investigators first suspected pesticides and other toxins but they later ruled out such causes, Dr. Antelo said. He also said health workers eliminated methanol or other toxins in home-brewed alcoholic beverages. .
The Government appealed for help, and the experts from the Pan American Health Organization have investigated a wide variety of drugs, chemicals, plants and other possible causes.
Dr. Antelo said Cuban officials were investigating the possibility that the outbreak was due to a virus, possibly from the Coxsackie group. But Dr. Victor said, "There are no viruses that I know of that fit this particular syndrome."
 
Changes in Diet
 Dr. Hirano said the Cuban diet underwent a drastic change after the collapse of trade between Cuba and the former Soviet Union, and that except for children under 7, consumption of thiamine-rich milk, meat and eggs was severely restricted. Thiamine is also found in vegetables, but many Cubans boil them and throw away the water that contains the leached vitamins.
Wheat, rice and other foods are not fortified with vitamin B1 in Cuba, Dr. Hirano said.
It takes at least six weeks for symptoms of vitamin B1 deficiency, or beriberi, to develop, Dr. Victor said.
Many cases have affected men who drank alcohol, which can hasten the onset of thiamine deficiency, particularly among those who do not get enough vitamin B1. It is not clear how many of the nearly 26,000 patients are alcoholics, Dr. Hirano said.

HEADLINE: Curt Riess, Author And Journalist, 90; Expert on Nazi Era

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Curt Riess, a refugee from Nazi Germany who returned as an American war correspondent to record the demise of Hitler's Third Reich, died on Wednesday at his home in Switzerland. He was 90 and lived in a suburb of Zurich.
Comfortable in English and German, he became a prolific trans-Atlantic author in both languages, producing a stream of newspaper and magazine articles, novels, biographies, screenplays and plays. 
 A former Berlin journalist, Mr. Riess drew attention in the United States in the 1930's and during World War II with his books and widely syndicated reporting about Hitler's Germany.
For instance, "The Nazis Go Underground" (Doubleday, 1944) described German espionage and what designs Hitler's associates might have for overseas after a defeat.
 
Wrote About Resistance
 Sales of another book in that area, "Total Espionage" (Putnam, 1941), soared after the United States entered the war after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. "Underground Europe" (Dial, 1942) was a dramatic account of the various anti-Nazi resistance movements in occupied Europe.
"The Berlin Story" (Dial, 1952) described the city as an epitome of East-West confrontation.
Curt Martin Riess was born in Wurzburg, Bavaria, and received his higher education in Berlin, Munich, Heidelberg, Zurich and Paris, focusing on literature and economics. He first turned to sports journalism, criss-crossing Europe to report for the Berlin press.
 
Left Germany for Paris
 With Hitler's rise to power, Mr. Riess left Germany for Paris. In 1934, Paris Soir, one of the Continent's largest papers, sent him to the United States. In the following years he shuttled between London, Paris, New York and Hollywood as a freelance journalist.
He was in Berchtesgaden, Hitler's favorite retreat in the Bavarian Alps, when the war ended. He then worked in New York and returned to live in Germany. He moved to Switzerland in 1952.
A biography of Joseph Goebbels, in English, was published by Doubleday in 1948; other subjects were Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Wilhelm Furtwangler and the actor Gustaf Grundgens.

HEADLINE: First Step in Journey;
After Chief Leaves, a Maze of Issues Still Confronting Empire Blue Cross

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
With the end of Albert A. Cardone's tenure as its leader, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield closed a chapter that increasingly was laced with charges of extravagance and poor management.
But in the face of mounting losses, investigations in Washington and Albany and accusations of serious organizational lapses, several monitors of the insurance giant said yesterday that his exit was only a step in a long journey to overhaul the company's image and the way it does business. 
 "It provides an opportunity for Empire to address the problems we've been talking about for the past two years and to take them out of the defensive mode they've been in," said State Senator Guy J. Velella, Republican of the Bronx and Westchester, who is the Senate Insurance Committee chairman. "But I would say the whole thing is a two-year process."
Among the issues the company has to address are how to shake up a management structure that outside auditors have criticized as outmoded and stultifying, how to cut back on management perquisites that are perceived as extravagances at a time of steady rate increases and how to compete against private insurers who are steadily plucking away some of its best customers.
 
Records Subpoenaed
 Looming most is the possibility of open hearings in Washington, perhaps as early as this summer, on the problems at the company and whether the State Insurance Department was remiss in carrying out its monitoring function. The Senate's permanent subcommittee on investigation has subpoenaed voluminous records from the company and the department in the course of its inquiry.
But more critical, Empire has to decide how to better deal with a daunting health-care and economic environment in which it has lost $250 million in two years despite steep rate increases granted by the state.
An audit ordered by the State Legislature last year found that even given its management problems, Empire would have been hard-pressed to compete more successfully in the face of spiraling medical costs and competition for its best customers. The uncertainty over what role insurers would play under a much-awaited health-reform package to be introduced shortly by the Clinton Administration only complicates matters.
"Empire needs to be repositioned to deal with the reality of the health-care market," Michael J. Dowling, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's director of health, education and human services, said. "That involves a lot of changes, and we don't know yet what else they're planning to do. I think it would be a mistake to think that all its problems could be solved by removing a C.E.O., but this is a sign that the board wants to project a new image."
With 8.2 million customers, Empire, which operates in 28 counties from the New York City area to Albany, is the largest health insurer in New York State and the largest of the 71 independent nonprofit companies that form the network of "Blues" around the country. It is one of 20 that still offer insurance to all who can pay for it, regardless of their health.
In exchange for playing this role, it gets a discount on hospital bills and its nonprofit status gives it an exemption from city and state taxes.
Despite these financial advantages and a steady stream of rate increases approved by the Insurance Department, the company's losses mounted over the past several years and its reserves shrunk to a point where it was placed on an informal watch list by the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
On top of this, the Federal Government cautioned Empire last month that its handling of Medicare claims for doctors' services was so poor that the Government was considering canceling a $30 million-a-year contract. And one of its biggest corporate clients, American Telephone and Telegraph, accused it in a lawsuit of defrauding its medical-benefits plan through a billing scheme.
The Legislature last winter came up with a $100 million Empire bailout package and the Insurance Department approved a rate increase that will raise the monthly premium for a major medical policy for a single person from $185.85, to $294.70. But accusations of big paychecks and perks -- including Mr. Cardone's $600,000 salary, chauffeur and Lincoln Town Car -- did nothing to make this aid go down easy with the public.
Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the state's Consumer Protection Board, credited Mr. Cardone with "trying to do some good things at Empire." But, he added, "the bottom line was he set a bad example."
"The tone," he said, "wasn't right. When subscribers are suffering, the executives have to make significant sacrifices and there was just no sacrifice at Empire at all. In the end I think that's what did him in."
Donald L. Morchower, Empire's chief operating officer and the executive who will fill Mr. Cardone's shoes while a search goes on for a permanent successor, said he hopes to polish the company's public image. As a start, he will turn down the Town Car and chauffeur for his Buick, which he said he would drive himself.
Beyond such symbolic gestures, however, Mr. Cardone's replacement will be faced with the task of digging deep into a management structure that the audit commissioned by the Legislature described as "autocratic" and "slow to react to the pace of change." Among other things, a three-part series in The New York Times this spring found it responsible for tens of millions of dollars in bad decisions involving computer systems and a poorly thought out health maintenance organization.
Many officials in and out of government have emphasized that even if these problems did not exist, the head of Empire Blue Cross might face migraines in the face of a fluid health insurance environment in which many of the "Blues" have sustained losses and other difficulties.
Mr. Cardone's departure still leaves fingers pointed at other individuals. Salvatore R. Curiale, the State Insurance Superintendent, harshly criticized Empire's nonpaid board members earlier this year, saying they "sat on their hands" while the company's woes mounted, and he urged that some of them quit.

HEADLINE: Jobless in Japan: A Special Kind of Anguish

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICHIBU, Japan

 BODY:
Since the factory where she worked for 30 years closed and left her without a permanent job, Kimiko Kanda has not left her home much and is too embarrassed to talk to friends who still work at her old company.
"Somehow, although I have done nothing wrong, I feel like a criminal," Mrs. Kanda said. "I have never heard of people being fired in my neighborhood or among my friends." 
 Mrs. Kanda is one person whose life has been uprooted by Japan's deep slump, which is fraying the system of lifetime employment and causing many people to lose their jobs for the first time.
 
Life and Work Entwined
 In Japan, in contrast to the United States, plant closings and dismissals are rare and the unemployment rate is a slender 2.3 percent. But when closings and job losses do occur, they can cause deep psychological distress because people so closely identify with their companies and because unemployment is considered such a shameful embarrassment.
Four individuals, three of whom have since found at least part-time work, agreed to interviews while they were unemployed. They talked about how their layoffs were carried out and how they were managing their finances, their hopes and their fears:
Work on the production line at the Ohkura Electric Company defined Kimiko Kanda's life. She started there at 16 and stayed for 30 years. When her two children were infants, she sent them to Ohkura Electric's day care.
Ohkura makes specialized telecommunications equipment for the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, one of Japan's corporate giants. But as N.T.T. has suffered from new competition and the recession, Ohkura's sales have plunged 25 percent during the last three years and it has suffered heavy losses.
One year ago, according to former employees, Ohkura offered to increase severance pay by 30 percent for workers who would retire voluntarily. But when that offer did not attract enough people, the company decided to shut the 45-year-old factory where more than 300 people made specialized communications terminals in this small city 35 miles west of Tokyo.
On the morning of July 27, company managers, without saying a word, laid a plain envelope at each employee's work space. When they opened them, about 180 people learned they had been transferred. The remaining 130 workers were told they could voluntarily resign and take the extra severance pay or they would be dismissed.
"Some people immediately began to cry on their desks," Kazumi Iwazaki, another former employee, said. "Some people rushed into the bathroom with handkerchiefs in their hands. Some people banged their desks in anger, saying, 'I devoted 30 years of my life to this place.' "
Mrs. Kanda, who was on vacation when the word came, got her notice by express mail.
"When I opened it, I got angry and really cried," she recalled recently, tears returning to her eyes. "While I worked very hard at the company, this was the way they treated me."
Since then, she said, she has destroyed or thrown out her company uniform, her badge and all other remnants of her life at Ohkura.
Mrs. Kanda, who had been earning about 5 million yen a year, or roughly $40,000, received a one-time severance of 12 million yen, or $100,000. Unemployment insurance payments, which amount to 60 percent of her monthly salary, ran out in mid-April.
The family is not in immediate trouble, but the future looks troublesome. Mrs. Kanda has found a part-time job working for the prefectural government, but the position will last only five months. Her husband, Isao, is a teacher at a driving school, but he will reach the mandatory retirement age of 57 in a few months. And with two children nearing college age, big education expenses are looming.
"Other than food, we almost never buy anything," Mrs. Kanda said.
 
A Programmer Tries to Resist
It is impolite to dismiss someone in Japan, but companies can go to great lengths to force people out. Take the case of a programmer for the NJK Corporation, a Tokyo software company.
When most of the company's programmers were sent out in the field to work with customers, he was assigned to headquarters, where for two years he sat in a vast office, all by himself except for the division chief.
"My salary was paid, but I had nothing to do," said the programmer, who spoke on the condition his name not be used because publication would make it harder for him to find a new job. The programmer, in short, had joined the ranks of the shanai shitsugyo, or in-house unemployed.
Last September, NJK told him that he would be sent to western Japan for retraining. Ostensibly to teach them good working habits, the workers were sent into the woods with axes and chainsaws and told to cut down trees. On rainy days, they were made to clean the toilets and kitchen of an old dormitory.
One by one, the workers in the training program disappeared; it turned out they had quit. But the programmer endured, despite suggestions from the trainers to "make yourself comfortable as quickly as possible" by going somewhere else.
"At my age, it would be difficult to find a new job," said the programmer, who is 44 and has worked at NJK since 1976. "In this industry people say 35 is the retirement age."
Finally, after a month, he was sent to a suburban Tokyo office, but was almost immediately told by the manager there that he would be sent for more training, this time on an electronics assembly line. Again, the manager suggested he "restart" his life, and, again, the worker declined.
But last November, after about a week on the assembly line, the programmer quit. He said he was told to write a letter stating he was resigning for personal reasons so that his departure would be classified as a voluntary retirement. An NJK official said the company had no comment on what the programmer said.
The programmer, whose annual salary was about 6.7 million yen, or more than $55,000, received a retirement payment of 800,000 yen, or less than $7,000. His wife's part-time job and tapping into their savings, which are almost depleted, kept the couple and their two children financially viable, he said. His wife said in a recent tele phone call that the programmer now had a job in a completely different field.
 
Fashion Salesman Adjusts to Fate
His silk tie, gold watch and well-cut suit mark Sei-ichiro Sakaguchi for the fashion salesman he is -- or was. At 45, Mr. Sakaguchi was the section chief at a women's blouse maker until last November, when the company called a meeting and announced that it would cut its work force by more than 40 percent, to 200, because of a sales slump.
While most employees had braced for such an announcement, one young worker, screaming that the layoffs were management's fault, rushed to the front of the room and tried to attack the company president. He had to be restrained by three men.
Mr. Sakaguchi protested at first, though more peacefully, but then, he said, he realized that if he argued too much, it would ruin his reputation in the industry, making it harder for him to find another job.
Mr. Sakaguchi registered at three job banks. "I'm looking for any sales job," he said during his job search. "I'm not even stressing I should get a management job." Still, he had almost no job interviews in the four months he was unemployed.
Mr. Sakaguchi said unemployment did not cause any great financial difficulty because his wife is from a wealthy family. Rather, the shock was psychological. "I have to keep my face toward my children," he said. "I get mad when they ask me, 'You haven't found a job yet?' "
A recent telephone call to his house was answered briefly by someone who said Mr. Sakaguchi now had a job, but the person would not give any details.
 
Quality Tester Goes to Court
When Ohkura Electric informed Mrs. Kanda and here co-workers that it was shutting its factory, Kazumi Iwazaki refused to go along and has sued to get his job back.
"We should not allow the companies to dismiss workers so easily," said Mr. Iwazaki, a quality tester who worked at Ohkura for more than 20 years and met his wife there. "If we allowed that to happen, that type of attack will occur all over Japan."
While most of the others "agreed" to resign and get the higher severance pay, Mr. Iwazaki refused, thereby forfeiting the pay. And while most workers immediately began claiming their remaining vacation days, Mr. Iwazaki continued to report to work each day until the plant finally closed a month later.
Once Mr. Iwazaki's unemployment benefits expire there will be little to support his wife, three children and his 82-year-old father. His wife, Michiko, who retired last year when she felt her health was no longer up to factory work, has found a part-time job. And his daughters, age 21 and 19, have also taken jobs to support the family.
In order to devote full time to his lawsuit, Mr. Iwazaki, 44, is not looking for another job. To insure he keeps his house, he paid off his entire loan, draining his savings in the process.
Mr. Iwazaki and the seven other plaintiffs are trying to support themselves and their cause by selling boxes of Japanese noodles. In true Japanese style, the have also printed up business cards identifying themselves as the "Ohkura Electric Labor Struggle Group."
Toru Fukuda, the Tokyo labor lawyer representing the workers, said that based on court precedents, a company has to meet four tests to justify a mass dismissal of workers: the layoffs must be absolutely necessary; the company must have made every effort to avoid job losses; it must have consulted with the union, and the selection of those to be dismissed must not have been done in a discriminatory manner.
Mr. Fukuda intends to challenge Ohkura on all four aspects, contending, for instance, that Ohkura's profits in the good years were ample enough to make layoffs unnecessary in lean times.
Ohkura said it would have no comment because of the lawsuit.
The lawsuit is expected to take years to decide. In the meantime, a lone guard watches over the products still stored inside the empty factory. The union hall on the factory grounds has been torn down, in part, Mr. Iwazaki said, because television news crews would gather there. Of the 130 employees who lost their jobs last summer, only 47 had found new ones as of recently.
"When my wife gets really worried she says to me, 'How can we make it in the future?' " Mr. Iwazaki said. "Sometimes I can't offer her a clear vision."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Introducing Bonds of the Half-Century

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Just as the United States Treasury is cutting back on 30-year bonds, corporations are edging into the 50-year bond business.
It may not yet be a trend, but it is no longer an oddity. Three 50-year bonds have been sold by companies this year, including the $250 million 50-year issue sold late on Wednesday by the Consolidated Rail Corporation. The sale comes just weeks after the Treasury announced it was slashing its annual auctions of 30-year bonds by 40 percent. 
 "It will be interesting to see if other corporate issuers follow," said Mark A. Seigel, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company, the lead underwriter for the Conrail issue. "This is more than a novelty."
 
Popular in 19th Century
 Fifty-year bonds are not a new idea. But they have been rare recently. More than a century ago, 50-year debt and longer maturities were sold regularly. Some railroads issued 999-year bonds; one such bond of a railroad now owned by Canadian Pacific is paying 4 percent interest and is due in 2883.
Since the 1950's, the 50-year gamble seemed to run out of steam. The Tennessee Valley Authority got a lot of headlines with a 50-year issue last year, but then it was a novelty.
With long-term interest rates at their lowest levels in nearly two decades, the longer-term bet for corporations would seem like a good idea. Mr. Seigel said that for Conrail this bond issue was almost like equity, "quasi-permanent capital at extremely attractive interest rates."
Some buyers of this debt, however, may not be showing as much confidence in the corporate and economic outlook as the 50 years might imply. In fact, the bet some buyers are making does not seem much greater than the gamble made with the much more common 30-year bond.
"It is enough of a step to buy a 30-year bond," said Geoffrey Kurinsky, a senior vice president for corporate bonds at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston and a buyer of 50-year bonds. "The extra 20 years is not saying much more."
Mr. Kurinsky said the interest-rate volatility of a 50-year bond was not much greater than that of a 30-year bond, which means the potential for loss is not much larger. In fact, in portfolio terms, the difference in the so-called duration of the two bonds is a year and a half rather than 20 years.
 
Not 'More Bullish'
 "It is going to trade like a 30-year bond," he said. "It is not a statement of my view on interest rates; it is not a more bullish bond."
Another factor driving the purchase of these 50-year bonds is the need of managers at insurance companies and pension funds to match their long-term cash flows and liabilities. The 50-year bond offers them a long-term match that is hard to find.
In addition, money managers who try to keep a set level of duration in their portfolios have had trouble recently. Duration is a measure of the weighted average of the time over which all the cash flow -- interest and principal -- from the securities in a portfolio will be paid.
Because of the decline in interest rates, many mortgage-backed securities in portfolios have been paid off much sooner than expected as homeowners refinance. These payoffs have lowered durations quickly and one way to offset that decline is to buy longer-term debt, including 50-year bonds.
 
Issued by Boeing and Texaco, Too
 Of the three 50-year bonds sold this year, two, the Conrail bond and the bond sold by the Boeing Company, are not callable for the life of the bond. The 50-year bond issued by Texaco Inc. is callable by the company after 20 years, which means it could pay it off if interest rates decline. And for many in the market, this is really a 20-year bond in the way it behaves.
The Conrail bond, which Morgan Stanley said was the largest industrial 50-year issue in history, has a coupon of 7.875 percent and was priced to yield 7.891 percent. That was 87 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the rate on the 30-year Treasury bond at the time of the sale.
Mr. Kurinsky said that while for him it was very much like buying a 30-year bond, it was cheaper. He got about 15 basis points more of interest, which means he paid a lower price, than on a current 30-year Conrail bond. This means that Conrail also got a benefit because it had to pay only 15 more basis points to get money for 20 more years.
 
Treasury Market
 Treasury prices fell and yields inched higher yesterday, as trading settled down a bit after two boisterous and volatile sessions.
The yield on the 30-year bond due in February 2023 rose to 6.99 percent, from 6.97 percent on Wednesday, while the price dipped 10/32 , to 101 20/32 .
Trading was in a narrow range until the very end of the day, when a surprising jump in the weekly money supply data added a burst of selling.
Traders said that earlier in the day, prices and yield seemed to be stymied by offsetting data and rumors. On the positive side for the market, initial jobless claims rose a bit more than expected and the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank indicated manufacturing growth was slowing.
But on the negative side, there was more speculation about what the Federal Reserve did to its interest rate policy at its meeting Tuesday. While it is not expected that it agreed to increase short-term interest rates now, the concern was that the Fed may have shifted its bias toward higher interest rates.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Broad Loss; Gold Is Mixed Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined yesterday in global trading, as the market's recent wave of bullish sentiment lost momentum.
The dollar's weakness was exaggerated by a lull in European activity, where many financial markets were closed in observance of Ascension Day. But the German mark's gains against the dollar were muted because of cross-trading, or nondollar trading, in which players sold marks to buy British pounds. 
 Gold rose in New York after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery gained 50 cents an ounce to $374.20. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $374 an ounce, up $1.20.
A modest jump in the number of people filing first-time claims for jobless benefits and a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia about the region's economic activity had little impact on yesterday's trading. The bank said the area economy was growing, but at a slower pace.
In addition, the chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, told reporters that the growth rate of the gross domestic product in the first quarter would probably be revised downward from the preliminary estimate of 1.8 percent.
Also hurting the dollar was its inability to recover fully from a plunge against the yen on Wednesday, when an unexpected surge in the March trade deficit renewed speculation that the United States was pushing for a lower dollar to help improve its trade position.
"The dollar's inability to rebound vs. the yen yesterday was a good reason to lighten up on long dollar positions vs. European currencies," said Stephen Flanagan, vice president in foreign exchange at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
The pound spurted against the mark yesterday after the release of figures showing unemployment in Britain dropped in April for the third straight month. That seemed to decrease the likelihood that the Government would need to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy. Lower interest rates make a currency less attractive to investors.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed sharply lower at 110.40 yen, down 1.16 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 110.50 yen. In late New York trading, the dollar fetched 110.65 yen, down from late Wednesday's 110.75 yen.
Other dollar rates, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.6139 German marks, down from 1.6240; 1.4650 Swiss francs, down from 1.4747; 5.4365 French francs, down from 5.4770; 1.8090 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8213; 1,468.00 Italian lire, down from 1,472.25, and 1.2682 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2676.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
The number of newly laid-off workers filing claims for jobless benefits rose by 7,000 last week, the Government reported today. "We're drifting along aimlessly," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. "It's consistent with employment growth, but growth of a subdued nature." First-time claims for unemployment insurance rose to 344,000 last week, from a revised 337,000 a week earlier, the Labor Department reported. It initially had estimated that claims totaled 339,000 in the week ended May 8.
