HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Ever-Shifting Odds At Cannes Festival

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

DATELINE: CANNES, France

 BODY:
"JUDGMENT," Jack Valenti said here the other night, "is the elf who acts like a computer when you get to that fork in the road."
If that's true, and there's no reason to disbelieve the president of the Motion Picture Association of America, then it's apparent that a lot of elves are at the point of nervous breakdown as the 46th Cannes International Film Festival enters its final days. 
 Mr. Valenti, speaking in his own memorable syntax at a black-tie dinner, was toasting a colleague for the consistency of his wisdom and vision in matters relating to the American movie business in Europe. The judgment of Mr. Valenti's colleague may still be firm, but elsewhere in Cannes, judgments are as unreliable as they are unpredictable. Neither elves nor computers work well here.
Two days ago, it seemed as if "The Piano," Jane Campion's period romantic comedy with a modern sensibility, would be a cinch to win the Palme d'Or, the festival's top prize, when the awards are announced on Monday night. Today, all that has changed. If the local reviews are any indication of how the jury may vote, then "The Piano" has a formidable rival in Chen Kaige's "Farewell to My Concubine," the only Chinese entry in the main competition.
"Farewell to My Concubine," screened on Wednesday night, is a nearly three-hour epic covering 50 years of recent Chinese history in sexual, social and political terms that would have been unthinkable in a Chinese film just a few years ago. It's a handsome, exotic, beautifully acted film, full of the kind of humanism that festival juries like to commend. It's also one of the few films seen at the festival so far that are worth serious discussion.
Shown in competition on Thursday night was "Splitting Heirs," the genially slapdash, neo-Monty Python English farce that opened in New York City a few weeks ago. The main attraction on Thursday night was the out-of-competition screening of Sylvester Stallone's latest action film, "Cliffhanger," the proceeds from which are to go to AIDS research.
Almost as big a surprise as the popularity of "Farewell to My Concubine" has been the hostility with which the European press has greeted "Far Away So Close," a decidedly serious, elegantly made new film by Wim Wenders, who can usually do no wrong at Cannes. Among other things, he won the Palme d'Or for "Paris, Texas" in 1984. "Far Away So Close" is the German film maker's follow-up to his immensely successful "Wings of Desire," for which he was given the best director's prize at the 1987 festival.
Although he resolutely denies that "Far Away So Close" is a sequel to "Wings of Desire," it shares with the earlier film the same concerns and many of the same actors (Bruno Ganz, Otto Sander, Peter Falk and Solveig Dommartin) playing the same roles. It is also based on a strikingly similar situation: an angel's seduction by earthly love and the concept of mortality. In "Wings of Desire," it is the angel played by Mr. Ganz who falls to Earth to stay in West Berlin; in the new film, it is the angel played by Mr. Sander. The setting is today's reunified Berlin. The new film also features Willem Dafoe and, as a new angel, Nastassja Kinski.
The news conference after the screening got off to a confrontational start when a German critic asked the director, "How does it feel to run out of ideas?" His reply: "It's a terrible feeling, especially for a journalist." It was all sort of spiteful and unrewarding, although it was a change. At most such news conferences, grown-up men and women, in their capacity as critics, spend less time asking questions than congratulating the person on the dais.
Clearly a disappointment to admirers of Steven Soderbergh, though not a film to be ashamed of, is his new "King of the Hill." The Cannes festival has an almost parental regard for the young American director. He came to international attention here in 1989 when his first feature, "Sex, Lies and Videotape," won the Palme d'Or.
The source material for the new film is A. E. Hotchner's memoir of growing up poor and often untended in a seedy St. Louis hotel in the Depression. There's nothing drastically wrong with the movie, but also nothing that's especially arresting or distinctive. Jesse Bradford, who plays Aaron, the teen-age Hotchner surrogate, has the kind of idealized good looks that suggest a generic rather than an idiosyncratic character. Even more troublesome is the manner in which the movie seems not to recognize the truly dark circumstances in which Aaron finds himself.
Because the family is so hard up, Aaron's beloved younger brother is sent away to live with relatives. After his tubercular mother is put into a sanitarium, Aaron's father, who is not supposed to be unfeeling or stupid, blithely goes off to sell wristwatches in Nebraska. He leaves the boy to fend for himself without money or anyone to call on for help. Somehow, Mr. Soderbergh misses both the serious comedy and the drama of the situation. The movie is sweet and unsentimental, but it frequently appears heedless.
The economic and political chaos in the rest of the world has taken its toll on Cannes this year. Movie makers seem to be either ignoring the world, incapable of coming to grips with it or unable to find the money and facilities with which to work. Aleksandr Khvan's "Douba-Douba," the only Russian film in competition, is both melancholy and morally muddled. It's about a conscience-stricken young screenwriter who turns to robbery and murder to bail his former girlfriend out of prison, where she's serving time for a crime she didn't commit. The film is not about spiritual and emotional confusion. It's a demonstration of it.
In the unreal circumstances of such a festival, which is like spending 12 days on a determinedly carefree cruise to nowhere, a small, solid, unspectacular film like Raoul Peck's "Homme sur les Quais" ("Man on the Quays") comes close to being a momentous event. Without tears or much dramatic artifice, the Haitian-born Mr. Peck recalls a terrifying childhood in the Haiti of Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier's dictatorship. The film, shot in the Dominican Republic, looks and sounds authentic.
"Farewell to My Concubine" has the scope, breadth and something of the detachment of a big, carefully researched historical novel. The story it tells is a good one about the intense, long-term relationship of two men, apprenticed to the Beijing Opera as boys in the 1920's. The film records the evolution of that relationship through the Japanese occupation of China in the 1930's, the fall of the Nationalist Government, the consolidation of power by the Communists and, finally, the chaos of the Cultural Revolution. A lot of ground is covered with efficiency.
At the center of the film is the unrequited love of one of the men for the other, and how, during the Cultural Revolution, each is driven to denounce the other, for different reasons. The movie is full of event, period detail and arcane information about the life and traditions of the Beijing Opera. It doesn't dawdle. Like James A. Michener, Chen Kaige can be called a good read; the film's subtitles are voluminous. The images also are lovely.
One of the most enjoyable films here is not even in the main competition, but in the Directors' Fortnight, a side event. It's "The Snapper," a rowdy Irish comedy directed by Stephen Frears and adapted by Roddy Doyle from his own novel. "The Snapper" is from the same trilogy of Doyle novels that provided the basis for Alan Parker's film "The Commitments."
In "The Snapper," the amazingly resilient and good-natured members of the lower-middle-class Curley family must come to terms with the accidental pregnancy of the unmarried eldest daughter. Mr. Frears appears to have had a picnic with the material, which is exceptionally funny in the ways sitcoms are supposed to be but seldom are. "The Snapper," which has no need of a laugh track, will be coming to the United States soon.
Sally Potter has been cheering up Cannes for several days. Ms. Potter, who adapted and directed the remarkable film version of "Orlando," was last here six years ago trying to raise money for the Virginia Woolf project. Now she's just having fun going to movies. Her particular must-sees: Jane Campion's "Piano" and Mr. Wenders's "Far Away So Close." She's still brooding about her next project. That is, she's not talking about it. She is talking, with infectious pleasure, about the unexpected success of "Orlando." For three weeks, it was No. 1 at the London box office, beating out "Scent of a Woman." Or was it "Indecent Proposal"? Who cares? "Orlando" was on top.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
It's Teflon Harazin, For the Time Being

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
In announcing the dismissal of Jeff Torborg as the Mets' manager, Al Harazin said no one person should be singled out for blame for the team's dreadful start. "I certainly accept my share," said the general manager, the chief architect of this failure of a team.
But while Torborg will not go to Shea Stadium today to take his seat in the Mets' dugout, Harazin will be sitting in his office in the executive suite. He still has a job. 
 Harazin's status was one of the issues raised yesterday in the aftermath of the managerial change from Torborg to Dallas Green. It spawned several questions:
*Did Harazin act before he could be acted upon?
*Is he in jeopardy of losing his job?
*Should he at least be on probation?
*If Harazin is guilty of putting together this enigmatic team, did its creation actually begin earlier, with the trade of Lenny Dykstra in 1989 or at least with the decision to let Darryl Strawberry leave as a free agent in 1990 and to sign Vince Coleman instead?
Fred Wilpon, the Mets' co-owner, gave a quick and firm answer yesterday concerning Harazin's status.
"We have not discussed Al's status," Wilpon said in a telephone interview. "I don't believe he is in jeopardy." But, he added, "I think Al is accountable, as is everyone else in the organization."
It would be easy to say that Harazin, in his first two years as general manager, provided Torborg with proven veterans -- Bobby Bonilla, Bret Saberhagen, Eddie Murray, Tony Fernandez -- and that the manager failed to get them to produce at their previous levels. But no manager should have to do anything to get such veterans to produce.
Maybe no one should question Harazin's decision to acquire those players. When he signed Bonilla and Murray as free agents and traded for Saberhagen in a two-week period late in 1991, he was saluted for dramatically reviving the club.
"When Al made all those moves, he was applauded as the great trader Al," Wilpon said. "Nobody questioned his abilities then. It hasn't worked out. We're all disappointed."
Maybe it hasn't worked out because Harazin unwittingly concocted an ill-conceived plan, as ill-conceived as Frank Cashen's decision to shed Strawberry after a season in which he hit 37 home runs and had a career-high 108 runs batted in. The Mets opted for speed instead, bringing in Coleman with his sour demeanor and his overrated reputation as a catalytic leadoff hitter.
In adding Murray to the clubhouse mix, Harazin further eroded the freespirited, extroverted environment that had existed with Dykstra, Wally Backman and that bunch. Murray produces on the field and gets along with his teammates, but he has no use for outsiders, such as reporters, and he infects other players with his view.
A friend of Bonilla said the player apparently has allowed himself to be sucked into that type of behavior, and that his resulting obsession with what was being said and written about him caused him to lose sight of his role on the field.
Harazin would not second-guess any of the deals he has made. "Anybody can go back with 20-20 hindsight and, if guys slump, say that was a dumb deal," he said. "All I ask is that people be logical and think of what made sense in the context of the time."
Harazin also said he had no thought of firing Torborg before anyone could question the general manager's role.
"I had no indication of anything," he said. "I've had nothing but great support from our owners."
As for the loss of his support for Torborg, the general manager said: "I can only go by what Jeff said and what I saw. He said, 'Frankly, I haven't been able to make this work. If I were sitting in your spot, I'd do the same thing.' I applaud and admire his candor."
Wilpon said Harazin recommended the change, a decision he and Nelson Doubleday discussed and approved last Saturday.
Asked if he and Doubleday would assess Harazin's position at the end of the season, Wilpon said, "We are reasonable business people. We always reassess."
A general manager of another team speculated yesterday that the new manager could eventually become the new general manager. The dugout, he said, is the best place to evaluate players. At the end of the season, his thinking went, the Mets could give Green his choice of remaining as manager or moving into the front office, where he could act on his evaluation.
"That is not part of any conversation we have had," Wilpon said. "We wanted to make sure that Dallas has fire in his belly to manage, that he didn't want to be something else in baseball, a general manager or president of a league. The answer from Dallas was he wants to manage."
If the owners, in their reassessment, find that Harazin, like Torborg, was lacking, they could reinforce the office by bringing back Joe McIlvaine, who left for San Diego before he could join Harazin as a two-headed replacement for Cashen.
McIlvaine himself comes up for evaluation by the Padres' owners at the All-Star Game break, halfway through his five-year contract, and he has told friends in baseball that it doesn't look as if they will retain him.
McIlvaine did not want to discuss his status. But the Padre owners are known not to care for McIlvaine's candid comments about the economically forced decimation of a once-promising team.
The Mets once were promising, too. Something other than economics has decimated them.

HEADLINE: Dusk's Magic: As the Day Ends, the Fun Begins;
Dining

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
As dusk falls over the city, so too do menu prices in many prominent restaurants. The economic slowdown of recent years has compelled dining establishments of all kinds to attract new customers with pre-theater menus, post-theater specials, Sunday discounts and early evening packages.
All of this has led to a dining trove for those who are flexible with time. At 6 P.M. dining rooms are quieter and generally more efficient. Servers are underemployed and have not yet become frazzled, so you get attentive service. Moreover, most early specials include dishes from the regular menu but at two-thirds the price or less. 
 Here are some noteworthy early-bird dinners and several evening teas and assorted activities, all in Manhattan.
ANGLERS AND WRITERS, 420 Hudson Street, at St. Lukes Place, West Village, (212) 675-0810. This enchanting little American restaurant resembles a New England antiques shop. The owner, Craig Bero, takes his tea seriously and service begins right after lunch, from 3 to 7 P.M. daily. You have a choice of the American high tea ($12.50) or just a pot of tea ($2.25). The high tea, served in antique pots with turn-of-the-century English china, includes fruit scones with clotted cream and homemade berry jam, Danish open-face tea sandwiches and warm apple crumble, petits fours or strawberry buttermilk shortcake. Mr. Bero recently opened a tea shop next door, called Be-Speckled Trout, which sells teapots, sterling tea strainers, loose tea, honey and the like.
BELLINI BY CIPRIANI, 777 Seventh Avenue, near 51st Street, (212) 265-7770. Convenient to the theater district, cosmopolitan and authentically Venetian, this midtown spot, owned by the namesake of Harry's Bar in Venice, is a bit pricey for the average diner's blood. But between 5:30 and 7 P.M. a three-course meal is offered for $29.50. A recent menu started with tagliolini with pesto or baked veal ravioli with ham; offered as entrees were free-range chicken with asparagus or fried calamari with a mixed salad; then dessert.
BOOK-FRIENDS CAFE, 16 West 18th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-7407. This snug little bookstore and cafe is a relaxing and civilized place to end the day. The main room has creaky-old appeal, with book-lined shelves and pine green walls. The store specializes in old and rare editions from 1890 to 1940. From 3 to 5 P.M. nearly a dozen kinds of tea are served along with scones, sandwiches and pastries ($12.95). Every other Wednesday at 7 P.M. old-fashioned tea dances are held with live music ($5 admission). The next tea dance is June 2. In addition, authors frequently lecture about their work; a schedule is available upon request.
GABRIEL, 1370 Lexington Avenue, near 90th Street, (212) 369-9374. If you are attending an event at the 92d Street Y, this cozy neighborhood spot could be a good early evening bet. Gabriel has never been known for distinguished cuisine -- pastas seem to be the best bets -- but if you stick to simple fare it can be enjoyable. From 4:30 to 6 P.M. it offers what it calls a sunset special, a $17.50 three-course meal. The menu includes wine, soup or salad, pasta (or another entree), dessert and coffee.
THE HUDSON RIVER CLUB, 250 Vesey Street, 4 World Financial Center, (212) 786-1500. Sunset on the water with a glass of wine or a meal is a rare commodity in Manhattan. The Hudson River Club offers both, and at discount prices between 5 and 7 P.M. Mondays through Fridays (5 to 6 P.M. on Saturdays), when a $24.93 dinner is available in the glass-fronted dining room overlooking the river. The food at this hour is not so exciting or diverse as that on the regular menu, but it is well executed: grilled salmon with herb-and-lemon-butter sauce, fillet of beef with Hudson Valley wine sauce, and stewed chicken with wild mushrooms. Pumpkin-apple soup is a must for starters.
MARK'S, the Mark Hotel, 25 East 77th Street, (212) 879-1864. One of the more refined hotel dining rooms in New York City, Mark's recently made available a $26 prix fixe dinner with one seating between 6:30 and 7 P.M. The dining room has a sumptuous English feeling, with classical prints and gold-framed mirrors on dark wood walls. The food is classical French with contemporary flourishes. Service excels.
THE RAINBOW ROOM, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, 65th floor, (212) 632-5100. This is one of the most popular and hard to reserve restaurants in New York City. But if you are willing to go early, some bargains can be had. Starting at 4 P.M. and continuing until closing around midnight, the Rainbow Promenade (a k a the bar) serves tasting plates of international foods. The view is arresting as the sun sinks below the steel-and-glass towers of Manhattan. Three plates run about $25. Reservations are not accepted.
In the Rainbow Room itself, a $38.50 pre-theater dinner is offered with seatings between 5:30 and 6:15 P.M. You are in the grand ballroom with the revolving piano, and piano entertainment is provided. After 7:30 P.M. a music charge of $15 is added.
RENE PUJOL, 321 West 51st Street, (212) 246-3023. A solid, comfortable, amiable French restaurant, one of the last survivors of the postwar West Side Frenchtown community, Rene Pujol has considerable charms. Unlike many establishments that severely limit prix-fixe meals, the $32 discount menu here is nearly as large as the regular one. The prix-fixe menu is available from 5 P.M. until closing daily. (The regular menu is available at 8 P.M.) Free hors d'oeuvres are served at the bar. Among the recommended dishes are warm garlic sausage with lentil salad, onions and fresh thyme in a phyllo tart, roasted cod in a mustard-basil crust, braised rabbit legs Provencale and roasted tenderloin of beef with shallots. Wine fanciers will note that Rene Pujol has an exceptionally strong inventory of Burgundy and Bordeaux, some at excellent prices.
THE SEA GRILL, 19 West 49th Street, (212) 246-9201. One of the more awe-inspiring spots for a snack or early evening dinner is the outdoor garden in Rockefeller Center. Three restaurants share the space -- the Sea Grill, the American Festival Cafe and the Bar Carvery -- which is filled this time of year with umbrella-shaded tables and an outdoor bar. Off to one side, the fountain of Prometheus sparkles in changing colors.
The Sea Grill is the best of the three, and service begins at 5 P.M. both inside the dining room and outside in the garden. A $35 complete dinner includes items like Thai chicken soup with fried cilantro, grilled salmon paillard with spinach and pine nuts, and Key lime pie with lime sorbet. A selection of wines chosen for each course is available for $15.
TATOU, 151 East 50th Street, (212) 753-1144. The setting resembles a turn-of-the-century music hall, with a 32-foot-high ceiling, ornate woodwork, giant chandeliers and faux antique windows. Live music is featured during normal dinner hours; after 11 P.M. the place turns into a nightclub. One does not expect to find ambitious cooking at a place like this, but American fare by Scott Cohen, the executive chef, is consistently rewarding. From 5:30 to 6:45 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays, a $19.93 menu includes dishes like a deviled crab cake with cilantro mayonnaise, lobster chowder, a roasted vegetable tart, honey-mustard roasted salmon, and aged New York shell steak with french fries.
VOULEZ-VOUS, 1462 First Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 249-1776. Regional French bistro food is the specialty of this worthy spot with an exceptionally congenial staff. Diners who arrive between 5:15 and 6:30 P.M. can find remarkable value: a $17.95 prix fixe dinner that includes three courses and dessert. Among the dishes to look for are the house terrine, leeks vinaigrette, brandade de morue, shrimp-and-couscous salad and coq au vin.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Cambodians' Turn for Children to Turn American

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"Why did the Cambodian people have to leave their own country to live in this strange, foreign land?" a woman asks at the start of "Cambodians in America: Rebuilding the Temple." The question, not unfamiliar in the United States, is at the heart of tonight's affecting hourlong report on the adapting pains of the latest immigrant group to discover that the freedom, security and economic opportunities that brought them to America carry a high price in the traditions that sustained them at home.
The answer to "Why?" goes back to the Khmer Rouge, the Maoist-inspired Cambodian guerrillas who killed a million of their own people in the 1970's. The 1980's brought invasion from Vietnam and a civil war that keeps driving refugees to Thailand and from there around the world. About 140,000 Cambodians have found their way to the United States. 
 A favorite target of the Khmer Rouge was the Buddhist religion, Cambodia's main faith, which most of the immigrants interviewed tonight agree is just as difficult to reconcile with the American drive for success as with Maoist doctrine. A Buddhist priest in Providence, R.I., says, "Buddhist people are very gentle, very soft," but in America "it is not so soft, not so gentle." A newcomer who sells insurance in New England laments the pressure "to be No. 1."
The program tells of efforts in several American cities to build temples and even shows a young man having his hair shaved in preparation for becoming a monk. But most young Cambodians are keeping their hair, and some are converting to Christianity. Instead of learning to appreciate and perform classical dances, the most revered of Cambodian arts, they are out discoing.
So families already struck hard by the Khmer Rouge are being further unraveled as the young move into the American mainstream. The program's narrator does not acknowledge how common the generational divide has been among immigrants, but the fact that other groups have been shaken by America cannot be much consolation to the latest people to find themselves between two cultures.

 
Cambodians in America
Rebuilding the Temple
PBS, tonight
(In New York, Channel 13 at 9)
 
Produced, written and directed by Claudia Levin and Lawrence Hott. Narrated by Linda Hunt. A production of Florentine Films in association with the Wisconsin Academy of Sciences, Arts and Letters.

 BODY:
A map yesterday with a front-page article about the New Jersey economy showed an incorrect location for Dover Township, one place in New Jersey where jobs grew most quickly in the 1980's. It is in Ocean County, and includes Toms River; the town of Dover is in Morris County.

HEADLINE: The Value of Colon Cancer Tests

 BODY:
Science finally confirmed last week that laboratory screening tests can help reduce the death toll from colon and rectal cancers. The National Cancer Institute and the American Cancer Society have been recommending that Americans age 50 and over get an annual test for hidden blood in stool samples. But there was precious little evidence that it saved many lives. Five trials, enrolling more than 300,000 patients, failed to demonstrate a reduction in mortality.
But last week, in the most definitive study yet, researchers reported that annual testing for hidden blood in the stool could help doctors cut the mortality rate for colorectal cancers by a hefty 33 percent. Applied widely, the test could thus save 20,000 lives from among the 60,000 deaths from colorectal cancer in the U.S. each year. The tests enable doctors to detect tumors and precancerous polyps at an early stage, when they are easiest to remove and most curable. 
 The Minnesota Colon Cancer Control Study followed more than 46,000 patients for 13 years. Some were screened with laboratory tests every year, some every two years, some not at all. If the screening test was positive, they were given a colonoscopy (inspection of the colon through a flexible scope) to see if cancers were really there, or if something else was responsible for the bleeding. Any tumors or precancerous polyps were removed.
The reason this study was able to reduce mortality may be that the stool samples were treated with a drop of water before being tested, thereby quadrupling the rate of positive tests and increasing the number of cancers detected. The water apparently makes the samples, which are often dry and hard by the time they reach the laboratory, more permeable to the reagents.
The only hitch is that adding the drop of water also produces a lot more false positive results in which the test flashes a warning but the person has no cancer. Bleeding, after all, has many causes, including hemorrhoids and ulcers. And the test can register falsely positive if the patient has ingested certain foods or medications.
The study found that 1 of every 10 people tested positive. But within that group with positive tests, only 2.2 percent were found to have cancer and only about 30 percent had the kind of polyp that sometimes develops into cancer. So a lot of very expensive follow-up colonoscopies were performed on people who had no cancer and would not have gotten it. Economists are now wrestling with the question of how the health gains from using the tests compare with the costs of administering all the follow-up procedures. Some experts think the tests could prove as helpful as the mammograms widely used to detect breast cancer.
Eventually, scientists may come up with better laboratory tests that can specifically identify the presence of tumors, not just the presence of blood. Meanwhile, the stool-blood test is the best available, and people over 50 have the best reason yet to get one annually. But they should probably ask the lab to add that drop of water.

HEADLINE: A Bipartisan Disservice

 BODY:
Senators David Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, and John Danforth, Republican of Missouri, proposed a deficit reduction plan yesterday that would, they say, cut about $120 billion of hated taxes and $160 billion of spending out of the Clinton budget plan.
And it would. But what the Senators -- joined by the Democrat J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana and William Cohen, a Maine Republican -- didn't say is that their plan would also shift tax burdens from South to North and from the rich to the middle class. It would also victimize some elderly poor and disabled families. 
 For what end? To eliminate Mr. Clinton's proposed energy tax, which, they say, hurts middle-class families. More accurately, it hurts oil-producing states like Oklahoma and Louisiana.
The most remarkable feature of the plan is its poverty of worthy ideas. Yet it poses an instant threat to President Clinton because Senator Boren is the swing vote on the all-powerful Senate Finance Committee; if he sides with the Republicans, Mr. Clinton's budget won't get past the committee.
The Senators would cut spending by capping entitlements, reducing tax credits for low-paid workers and cutting back cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security benefits. Each idea is unfair and unwise.
The entitlement cap would force severe cutbacks in Medicare and Medicaid. To whack $15 billion out of Mr. Clinton's plan to raise tax credits for low-paid workers, as they propose, would gut the President's worthy pledge to make work pay -- and thus raise any family with a minimum-wage worker out of poverty.
And by permitting inflation to eat away the benefits of some Social Security retirees and charging the disabled elderly more for medical care, the plan would do many poor and middle-class families more harm than good.
In turning sane public policy upside down, the plan would lower the Federal share of welfare payments in high-income states, many in the North, like New York. Thus the states that are already forced to bear an undue burden for taking care of the nation's poor simply because the poor are concentrated in their cities would be forced to do even more. That's a sure way to persuade state legislatures to ratchet down benefits.
The plan's tax measures are equally unfair. It would index capital gains -- thereby eliminating future inflation from the calculation of profit on the sale of investments. But that would open up a gigantic loophole in the tax code since the Senators do not simultaneously propose eliminating inflation from the calculation of deductions these investors take on borrowing costs incurred to buy investments. The Senators also propose scrapping Mr. Clinton's plan to raise payroll taxes on high-paid workers.
To their credit, the Senators would raise Medicare premiums for high-income families. But Congress was beaten to a pulp by an angry public four years ago when it tried to raise these premiums -- and then it at least tied the idea to increased benefits.
The main purpose of these misguided proposals is to eliminate Mr. Clinton's B.T.U. tax. Mr. Boren's and Mr. Johnston's motives are clear, since they come from oil-producing states. And they have some good arguments on their side: The tax won't do much for the environment, having been compromised to suit various special interests. And it will punish exports of goods that use lots of energy to manufacture.
But the B.T.U. tax isn't very large and hardly terrifying. Its removal won't help many in the middle class as much as the spending cuts the Senators propose will hurt them. And the tax cut surely doesn't warrant victimizing the elderly poor and low-paid workers.
The Administration will muster its forces to try to beat down Senator Boren and his Republican friends. It must also consider coming up with its own spending cuts so that could be used to take the sting out of its tax hikes. There is, then, plenty of room for President Clinton to operate, but little room to accommodate the misguided Senators.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

INDUSTRY: NAICS 213112 OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (78%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: OKLAHOMA, USA (58%); LOUISIANA, USA (56%);

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Trickle-Down Mercy

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The best way for the U.S. to help the Chinese people win relief from daily oppression is to keep enriching the Chinese economy through trade.
Yes, that will also enrich the treasury of the Communist Government and its ability to enforce Communist order in the country. But a strengthened economy with a flavor of capitalism, however controlled, will lead to liberalization of the dictatorship, help moderates take over when the old men die and so in the long run benefit the Chinese people. 
 Those two paragraphs are the essential argument of the American China-trade lobby and its supporters against economic pressure on the Chinese Communist Government.
Now, then: Blessed though I am by a disposition aptly described as angelic, that argument for trickle-down mercy is being droned out so often, and so cynically, that I may be forced to bite the next lobbyist who parrots it.
The lobby goal is to edge President Clinton away from using trade penalties to persuade Communist China to give up certain of its customary instruments of governance.
Among these are slave labor built into the economy, political suppression, imprisonment and torture, forced abortion, confiscation, trade barriers and proliferation -- the sale of nuclear and missile weaponry or technology to other dictatorships. Instruments like that.
Lobbyists have a right to lobby. And I cherish the daydream that one of them, just one, will get up and say -- Look, in China we get labor at bottom dollar, without health care or Social Security fusses, no unions, no guff, and what goes on in political prisons is not our affair; we are a business, not some Human Rights Watch.
That would be more acceptable morally than the drivel that what is good for the Communists is good for the people who suffer under them.
I heard it when I was a correspondent in Communist Poland -- help the Communists industrialize because increasedindustrializationleadstoincreasedliberalization, said like that, fast, a one-word mantra.
That lasted until a specific day -- when all those liberalizing Communists who were supposed to give Poles freedom decided instead to give them martial law.
And Americans who believe that dictatorships soften in a powerful capitalist economy never got to the point in history class where somebody told them about Adolf Hitler.
But China lobbyists do not embarrass easily. Here they are asking us to worry about China's economy, and it turns out, according to the International Monetary Fund, that it is the third-largest in the world, right behind the U.S. and Japan. Are we supposed to surrender first place, in searing sympathy for Beijing? All right, but then do we sock it to Japan for not getting out of China's way?
We are told we must not "isolate" China, which nobody is asking for. We are told that foreign presence itself ameliorates life in China. That will be of interest to farmers whose crops are confiscated, teachers tied to torture boards in prison -- and women forced into abortion 20 years after U.N. population-control people were allowed into the country.
President Clinton will decide in the next two weeks whether to impose economic penalties on China for violating human rights and for proliferation -- or give them one more year to be good boys.
One more year is what he will probably decide. But Congressional friends of Chinese freedom expect him to issue an executive order that would make the next 12 months the last year of grace to Beijing unless it behaves with a touch of decency. If he does not do at least that, Congress will.
Under such an order, tariffs would be raised if human rights decencies were not improved in China and Tibet, or U.S. products fairly allowed into China.
That should mean real products made by real American labor, not just parts shipped there from somewhere even cheaper, put together with American investment money and sold to us. And if proliferation continues, trade could be just cut off.
All that may not work. Communist bureaucrats have a personal stake in tyranny -- their lives. But Americans will have done what they can for the Chinese, which is better than sitting around year after year, telling ourselves lies about how we are helping the people by helping their tormentors.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Haircut Grounded Clinton While the Price Took Off

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20

 BODY:
It may have been the most expensive haircut in history.
Two of Los Angeles International Airport's four runways were shut down for nearly an hour on Tuesday, some incoming flights were delayed and Air Force One sat on the tarmac with engines running -- all so that President Clinton's Beverly Hills hairstylist, Chistophe, could come aboard and give Mr. Clinton a high-price trim before he took off for Washington. 
 Questions about Mr. Clinton's runway razor cut dominated the White House news briefing today, with the communications director, George Stephanopoulos, scrambling to explain why the populist President tied up one of the country's busiest airports to have his hair trimmed.
 
Everybody Does It
 Federal Aviation Administration spokesmen were quoted by The Associated Press as saying that while Air Force One sat on the runway on an indefinite haircut hold, two of the airport's four runways were shut down and some commuter flights scheduled to land were forced to circle instead. The White House insisted, though, that the Secret Service had not sought any special hold on air traffic while the President was getting his locks shorn.
"Everybody has to get their hair cut," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "I think the President normally gets his hair cut sometime during the week. It happens at different places. As you know, he has a very busy schedule, and he just tries to work it in when he can. That was when we were able to work it in."
And who paid for this haircut?
"The President and his family have a personal services contract with Cristophe to cover things like this," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "They pay for it. It's for the whole family."
In light of Mr. Clinton's haircut by a stylist to Hollywood stars, Mr. Stephanopoulos was asked whether his boss was still the President of the common man.
"Absolutely," he answered. "And if you look at his economic package, it's a package that's designed to turn this around and to really get some real benefits to middle-class Americans. And that's what's important."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 22, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about President Clinton's haircut aboard Air Force One named his hairstylist incorrectly. The stylist is Cristophe of Beverly Hills, Calif.

HEADLINE: At What Point Is Pay Too High?

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
How much pay should the chairman and chief executive of a small public-utility company get?
At Citizens Utilities, which is based in Stamford, Conn., $21.6 million seems to be the right number. That's what Leonard Tow, a 64-year-old economist who runs the little-known company received last year, according to an independent valuation by a leading pay expert. 
The $21.6 million package, which was compiled in a study of the company's public records, comes atop the $10.5 million that Mr. Tow got from the Century Communications Corporation, another publicly traded company he runs. None of it includes other provisions in his employment contracts that will shower him with millions of dollars regardless of the companies' performance.
 
In Bill Payer's Terms
 One way to look at it is that more than 800,000 Citizens customers in 13 states who get their electricity, water, gas and telephone service from Citizens paid an average of $26 last year to provide for Mr. Tow's pay.
On Wednesday, he received national attention as he showed a canny flair for deal-making when Citizens announced the purchase of several small telephone properties from the GTE Corporation for $1.1 billion.
But unappreciated until now, at least by his shareholders and state regulators, has been Mr. Tow's skill in deal-making for himself.
Not only has he wrung millions of dollars in compensation out of two small companies for what seems essentially to be part-time work, but he has done it under the ordinarily watchful eyes of state utilities regulators and consumer groups.
The huge payments come at a time when many big companies and their boards have somewhat restrained executive pay, or at least demanded superior performance in return.
Mr. Tow professes to know little about his pay -- which includes stock options, restricted stock awards and retirement benefits, in addition to nearly $1.3 million in base salary and bonus at Citizens. He said he has left the details to his lawyer and the company to work out.
Mr. Tow says further that he has not read the pay analysis by Graef S. Crystal, a leading compensation expert, and he says he does not know why Mr. Crystal's estimate came in higher than the $15.2 million reported in proxy filings. Either way, he said, Mr. Crystal is "off his rocker."
"My compensation is basically of the order of $1 million," Mr. Tow said. "Beyond that, everything else is related to some kind of grant or bonus which is performance-related.
"I'm not getting paid any differently than Mike Eisner at Disney or Roberto Goizueta at Coca-Cola," he continued, referring to these industry leaders' pay packages of the last two years that amounted to tens of millions of dollars. "I'm performing better than those guys and getting a fraction of what those guys get. It's hard to find a guy who can do it in one company. I do it with two companies.
"If you were working at two jobs, wouldn't you expect to be paid at two jobs?" he said. "That's exactly what I do. Even when I sleep, I think about these companies. I wake up in the middle of the night with a note pad, and am busy writing this idea or that idea down."
 
New S.E.C. Rules
 The extent of Mr. Tow's compensation came to light because of new proxy rules adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission last fall that forced companies to be more candid about executive pay. Those rules allowed Mr. Crystal to compile the detailed estimates of Mr. Tow's pay package.
Among Citizens' traditional strengths have been its geographic diversification and varied businesses. Now it seems these were reasons helping it elude regulators' attention.
California, for instance, regulates about 14,000 utilities. With that workload, when the staff of the state Public Utilities Commission recommended last year that it audit Citizens' general expenses before acting on a request for higher water rates, the four state commissioners were reluctant to delay the process. Citizens ultimately won the right to raise water rates 9 percent to 26 percent.
"They have a small presence here," said Dr. Norman Shumway in explaining how his group might have overlooked Mr. Tow's pay. Dr. Shumway, the pioneering heart-transplant surgeon, now serves as one of four commissioners who regulate California utilities. "It's way out of line with what the heads of other utilities make," he added. "That's a huge amount of money. It would be very relevant" to rate considerations.
Arizona regulators have also pledged to scrutinize the company more closely on its pending rate-increase applications. Citizens is also seeking increases in Illinois, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
"It's all hidden," said Ron Mathis, director of Arizona's Residential Utility Consumer Office. His staff has challenged overhead items before, but not stumbled over the matter of corporate pay. "$23 million," he said, "is way out of line."
Shareholders also seem likely to start showing more interest in the company's pay practices.
"It is unconscionable," Merle Thorpe Jr., a Washington securities lawyer who owns $3.6 million worth of Citizens stock plus a small amount of Century, said of Mr. Tow's compensation. "It's not as if he's been around this company for a long time and built it up."
In his view, Mr. Tow's pay is beginning to put a drag on Citizens' earnings. On annual revenue last year of $589 million, the company earned $115 million, up $2.7 million from the year before and the smallest percentage gain in more than a decade.
That Mr. Tow is now seeking to add his wife, Claire, an executive at Century Communications, to the Citizens board does not seem to help matters. "It just confirms the feeling that this is a board that maybe has lost its independence," Mr. Thorpe said.
But at Century, the other company where he is founder and chairman, the fact that Mr. Tow is well paid is less troublesome to Mr. Thorpe. Mr. Tow still owns 37.3 million shares of Century stock, a $284 million stake that entitles him to cast more than 63 percent of the votes. And the board is occupied by longtime associates, including his wife and son Andrew.
 
The Job, and More
 Mr. Tow's involvement at Citizens began in 1989, when Century purchased a 2 percent stake from an investor group led by Richard L. Rosenthal, the longtime chairman, who had once turned down Mr. Tow for a job. Mr. Tow won a seat on the board, and 14 months later he became Citizens' chairman and chief executive without forfeiting his Century jobs.
All three of the independent directors who negotiated his Citizens employment contract have close ties to the company. Robert D. Siff made $520,200 in consulting fees. Aaron I. Fleischman benefits from Citizens legal work. And Norman I. Botwinik got 7,271 options in the cellular-phone subsidiary that sold stock, netting him a $123,000 paper profit.
Regulators and consumer groups were often not much more effective at putting the brakes on Mr. Tow.
Instead of focusing on his pay package, an Arizona consumer group that is contesting his efforts to raise electrical rates challenged expenses that it found unnecessary last year. These included artwork, $23,145 for an executive chef, trips to Martha's Vineyard, acupuncture, picnics, softball uniforms, jewelry, nine chairs at $3,000 each, and $987,000 spent on improving a Stamford office building that Citizens emptied and uses for mostly for storage.
It also questioned $53,717 in board fees that the company pays Mr. Tow to attend his own meetings.
A longtime director of Century acknowledged that Mr. Tow's insistence on being paid to attend his own board meetings might seem excessive, but he defended the package.
"He's worth it," said Peter Solomon, an investment banker, member of Century's board and "close personal friend" of Mr. Tow. "He is the driving force of this business. Leonard is a wonderful thinker in terms of the evolution of these industries, and to a great extent we're paying Leonard for that creative mind."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 22, 1993, Saturday

A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the compensation of Leonard Tow, chairman and chief executive of Citizens Utilities, misstated the value of his pension in some editions. The pension has a total value of $18 million, not $18 million a year.
The article also misidentified a member of California's Public Utilities Commission. He is Norman D. Shumway, a former Congressman from Stockton, Calif., not Dr. Norman D. Shumway, the noted heart surgeon.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Generation-Skipping Tax
 
Q. If a person of substantial means who inherits a large amount from his parent disclaims a part of it to let money go directly to his own children, what happens with the generation-skipping tax?
 JOYCE HERBERT MANN, Manhattan
 
A. Under a disclaimer, beneficiaries file a formal document with the court stating that they do not wish to accept some or all of a bequest from a will. A generation-skipping transfer tax, or G.S.T.T., whose purpose is to prevent the very wealthy from avoiding estate tax, is assessed when a bequest is made to a generation beneath the donor. But you can transfer up to $1 million to a lower-level generation without falling under this tax. 
 "If the amount disclaimed is not more than $1 million, and none of the $1 million exemption had been used, no G.S.T.T. would be due," said Martin M. Shenkman, a New York estate lawyer. There would be a levy, however, on any disclaimed amount exceeding the available exemption.
 
Car Leasing and Taxes
 
Q. We decided to lease a car instead of buying it. Since we are not the owners of the car, why did we have to pay the taxes on the entire price of the car?
 JEAN-PIERRE FOUCAULT, Evanston, Ill.
 
A. State and local sales taxes, which are always included when you purchase a car, are sometimes also required when you lease a vehicle, depending on the state. In some jurisdictions, the tax on leased automobiles is officially called a use tax, because you are being taxed for the privilege of using the property. Federal law requires the lessor to give you written disclosure of the tax to be paid.
Some states allow this tax to be included as part of your monthly payments and thus paid over two, three or more years. But in Illinois, autos leased for a year or more are subject to immediate taxation on the full purchase price.
"The tax," said Sam McGaw, acting director of the Illinois Department of Revenue, "must be paid before the vehicle can be registered. Leasing firms typically require the lessees to bear this tax obligation."
 
Reverse Mortgages
 
Q. What are reverse mortgages?
 JOCELYN SANTOS, Fairfield, Conn.
 
A. Reverse equity mortgages allow older homeowners who might not otherwise be able to afford to remain in their homes to do so. With such a mortgage, a homeowner pledges the equity in a house to a financial institution in return for a stream of fixed payments over a specific period, say, 10 or 20 years.
When the homeowner dies or sells the house, the bank is repaid the money it lent plus interest. "Reverse mortgages will normally carry an interest rate that reflects current fixed-mortgage rates for the same term," said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist of the National Association of Realtors.
A reverse mortgage, however, is not appropriate for individuals concerned about consuming their capital.
In addition, there will be origination, or closing, costs for reverse mortgages -- just as there are for most mortgages -- that could reach as high as $8,000.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Better Yields in Canada? Perhaps, but With Risk

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
CANADA these days offers more of interest to United States citizens than its much-studied health-care plan. In fact, it offers lots of just that -- interest.
In the search for yield to replace income lost when certificates of deposit or Treasury securities bought at higher interest rates come due, Jay Goldinger, chief investment strategist of Capital Insight Inc., a Beverly Hills, Calif., brokerage house, has found an answer that delights him: two-year Government of Canada notes. 
 The notes are yielding 6.70 percent, a positive return after allowing for inflation even though the notes are subject to income taxes in the United States at the Federal, state and local levels.
By contrast, two-year United States Treasury notes now pay 3.75 percent, a negative net return even though taxed only by Washington.
"I am in love with the Canadian debt market," Mr. Goldinger said. "I think it is the most conservative, risk-averse play right now. Horace Greeley said, 'Go West.' We say, 'Look North.' "
Still, Mr. Goldinger acknowledges, "It's a lonely vigil to be bullish on Canadian debt."
Why? Other financial professionals cite a number of reasons for caution: currency market fluctuations, which are a risk when buying any foreign security; political uncertainty in a nation that is expected to call a general election within months and the troubled Canadian economy.
Martin Jaffe, senior vice president and chief operating officer of Wood, Struthers & Winthrop, the investment management subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said he avoided foreign bonds unless a client lived in the country and needed local income or had a business reason to hedge. He cited an example of an American who owned a farm in Spain and needed enough cash flow in pesetas to operate it.
The reason he avoids foreign bonds is currency risk. "A couple of years ago Mexican bonds were earning 18 percent," he recalled. "A lot of people rushed in. Mexico devalued, and the value of their holdings plunged."
Mr. Jaffe's own strategy for conservative, income-oriented clients is serial maturities of two, three and four years in United States Treasuries and some corporates. "We can get more than 5 percent on average" in such portfolios, he said, adding that he was "staying short, not trying to squeeze every nickel currently," because he expects rates to rise in a year or two.
Tim Kochis, partner in Kochis & Fitz, San Francisco financial consultants, agrees about currency risks and also points to political uncertainties, although he added, "I have no expectation that Canada will default."
He pointed to the recent experience of many investors who bought high-yielding German securities figuring rates had to come down, and therefore, their principal value would rise. They were right -- in Deutsche marks -- but at the same time the mark fell against the dollar.
"Interest rates are capable of being politically manipulated," Mr. Kochis said. Governments may ease credit conditions to stimulate sluggish economies or tighten them to curb inflation or protect currencies. "Don't assume rates will move the same way domestic rates move," he added.
His point: Conservative investors should not buy the bonds of a country unless they have studied it, assessed the risk potential and still feel comfortable.
James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, has assessed the Canadian risk and is a decided bear. "Canada's debt statistics may shock even an American, with the ratio of public-sector debt to G.D.P., for instance, standing in excess of 100 percent," he wrote this month.
"Taking the Federal Government alone," he added, "Canada's receipts covered interest expense last year by a factor of 2.96:1, less than that of the United States (5.47:1) or Italy (4.35:1). At current trends of fiscal deterioration, interest coverage would slip to 2.5:1 by 2002."
Among the dire possibilities he cites for heavily indebted Canada are intervention by the International Monetary Fund to put its financial house in order.
Unemployment stands at 11.3 percent. A national election is expected to be called by fall, making it uncertain whether the weak Canadian dollar will be defended or allowed to slip further. Canadian bonds have been downgraded from AAA to AA+, and Canadians themselves use the phrase "debt crisis," Mr. Grant noted.
Mr. Goldinger, too, has assessed the risks, but he calls them "very slight." Canada is a stable democracy, and whoever is elected will honor the nation's debt obligations, he predicts.
The economy is heavily dependent on natural resources, and "gold and metals have been strong" of late, he said. "Canada is a little bit on the rebound."
Indeed, the Commodity Research Bureau Index, after moving in a narrow seven-point range around 200 for months, began climbing two months ago, and is now around 209.
In Canadian dollars there will be no loss of principal on two-year notes held to maturity, Mr. Goldinger said, and if the economy strengthens, leading the Canadian dollar to appreciate against the United States dollar, Americans will have a currency gain in addition to those rich interest payments.
In any event, the Canadian dollar, now at 78.83 cents to the United States dollar has been far less volatile than the mark or the franc, he noted.
Mr. Goldinger may make a persuasive case, but he seems to be nearly alone in making it for the conservative, risk-averse investor.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "A Neighbor's Rates" shows yeilds on two-year notes in Canada and the U.S. from 1991 to 1993. (Source: Bloomberg Financial Services)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC ADVISERS CAUTION PRESIDENT ON MEDICAL COSTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Some of the Clinton Administration's top economic officials told President Clinton on Thursday that they had serious questions about the cost and scope of the ambitious health-care plan being developed by Hillary Rodham Clinton, people who attended the meeting said today.
As Mr. Clinton nears crucial decisions on his health plan, his top advisers remain deeply divided on a question at the core of the proposal: how generous to make the standard package of medical benefits that would be guaranteed to all Americans. 
 These divisions emerged at a spirited three-hour meeting on Thursday night in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, where President Clinton's advisers on health policy and on the economy presented two starkly different alternatives.
 
Economic Team's Advice
 The economic advisers generally backed the more modest package of benefits, which would set higher deductibles and require larger out-of-pocket payments by consumers but less money from the Government and businesses, officials said.
By contrast, the health-policy advisers, apparently backed by Mrs. Clinton, tended to favor the more comprehensive package, which would be less costly to consumers but more expensive for the Government and businesses.
The tensions among Administration officials presage disagreements likely to erupt on Capitol Hill after Mr. Clinton sends his proposals to Congress. Both alternatives would probably require tax increases, but the size of the increases would vary with the generosity of the package. The President is buffeted by conflicting pressures to hold down costs and to make the benefits comprehensive.
 
Appeal of Richer Plan
 People who attended the meeting with the President and Mrs. Clinton on Thursday said no decisions were made then. But White House officials said today that Mr. Clinton tended to favor the more generous package of benefits and believed that all Americans should gain access to such coverage as swiftly as possible. Mr. Clinton originally intended to send his health-care plan to Congress by May 3, but the White House now says he will not unveil it before mid-June.
Health experts said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and Robert Rubin, coordinator of the National Economic Council, had espoused the modest plan for people who do not now have insurance.
Several economists in the Administration acknowledged that they favored the more modest package, but insisted, as one said, that "the economic team is not a coherent bloc."
The discussion focused on the generosity of benefits and the timetable for coverage to take effect.
The more modest proposal, described as Plan A, would set a deductible of about $2,000 a year for a family. The alternative, Plan B, would have a deductible of around $400. Patients pay their own health bills up to the deductible, and at that point insurance begins paying. Employers and employees would share costs under both plans, but the employees' share would be substantially bigger under Plan A.
By one estimate, Plan A is more generous than 20 percent of the private health insurance now in effect, while Plan B is more generous than 80 percent of the existing plans.
Benefits would be available under either plan by 1997 but they would be phased in more rapidly under the more generous plan.
The staff of the Task Force on National Health Care Reform, which numbered more than 500, is disbanding. Many people are going back to jobs in Government agencies and universities, leaving President Clinton to make tough decisions with his top advisers.
Robert O. Boorstin, a spokesman for the group, said about 30 people attended the meeting on Thursday. He would not give details of the discussion.
Besides Ms. Tyson and Mr. Rubin, the meeting was attended by Gene Sperling, the deputy assistant to the President for economic policy; Lloyd Bentsen, Secretary of the Treasury; Roger C. Altman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury; Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services; Atul Gawande, a senior health policy adviser to Dr. Shalala; Dr. Philip R. Lee, a nominee for Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Stanley B. Greenberg, the President's poll taker.
People who attended the meeting said Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Altman had often sided with Ms. Tyson and the Council of Economic Advisers.
 
Benefits of Generosity
 Mr. Greenberg and Mr. Sperling suggested that there were political benefits to be gained from having more generous coverage.
"I've argued all along that it's very important for every American to have a stake in health-care reform," Mr. Greenberg said today. "I've encouraged people to think bigger rather than smaller. There is an enormous opportunity here. People want this to happen. It's important that there be genuine benefits and genuine security. A bare-bones program won't excite the imagination of the public."
Mrs. Clinton and Ira C. Magaziner, the manager of her health-care group, have supervised development of the President's health plan. In their public remarks, they have held out the prospect of comprehensive insurance coverage providing peace of mind and economic security to all Americans. But they have offered comparatively few details about how to pay for the new program.
Walter A. Zelman, an architect of the Administration's health plan, said at a conference here on Thursday that there had been "a fairly significant separation between those of us developing policy and those of us developing the politics of it."
Middle-income families may have to pay higher premiums or taxes under the President's plan, and the Administration may risk losing their support unless they get better health benefits than they now have.
Members of the President's economic team were also apparently concerned about how the health plan would affect Mr. Clinton's broader economic agenda.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY OF RUSSIA MAKES SOME GAINS

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 21

 BODY:
The Russian economy has made some gains in recent weeks, with inflation down to about 17 percent a month and new pledges by the Government and the Central Bank to get better control over the budget deficit, the issuing of credits and the inflation rate.
Those pledges have secured a new agreement between the Government and the International Monetary Fund intended to provide $3 billion to finance the Russian budget deficit. The financing is aimed at reducing sharply the amount of domestic credits issued by the Central Bank and the inflation they cause, Russian officials and Western diplomats say. 
 But the Russian economy is by no means stabilized. Officials and diplomats worry about an emerging dangerous pattern of periodic free spending and issuing of credits followed by austerity -- bingeing and dieting -- that some liken to bulimia.
When the Central Bank grants credits, it is in effect printing rubles. The credits are loans to borrowers like Russian industrial enterprises, which repay at artificially low interest rates, if at all. Their accounts are credited with sums of money, which they spend, increasing the amount in circulation.
A period of bingeing this spring is expected to follow the recent gains and bring significantly higher inflation, though not hyperinflation, before the summer is out.
The agreement with the International Monetary Fund, which is expected to be announced soon, will provide Russia a quick $1.5 billion and another $1.5 billion a few months after that. It is a significant departure for the fund, which was pushed to be more flexible with Russia by the United States and other members of the Group of Seven major industrial countries.
But doubts remain, within and outside the fund, that the Russian Government will be able to make good on its promises, especially since it lacks real control over the Central Bank. The bank chairman, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, survived another effort to oust him after the victory of President Boris N. Yeltsin in the referendum on April 25.
Mr. Gerashchenko and the bank have been widely blamed for issuing trillions of rubles' worth of credits to try to keep faltering industrial enterprises alive and to enable commercial banks to make cheap loans, pushing Russia's inflation to dangerous levels that reached as high as 30 percent a month in January. Mr. Gerashchenko has challenged the relationship between credits and inflation, while blaming the Government for lack of discipline in running a large budget deficit, which the bank must cover.
 
Pressure From the West
 He did agree last month, under pressure from the West and the Deputy Prime Minister in charge of finance, Boris G. Fyodorov, to limit credits in this year's second quarter.
But Mr. Gerashchenko admitted that he had enormous reservations, convinced that the Government would not be able to live within "unrealistic" commitments to tight credit. On Wednesday, he said the budget deficit was already going out of control and could hit 10 trillion rubles (about $10 billion) by the end of the year.
That's where the new monetary fund money will be helpful. The $3 billion will be used to buy rubles, which are then to be used to finance a big part of the budget deficit in a non-inflationary way, since the bank would not need to issue new money to cover the deficit.
The Government is promising to cut its budget deficit further. Officials say Mr. Fyodorov is now checking off on all major expenditures and deliberately underfunding some of the expensive promises Mr. Yeltsin made during the referendum campaign.
Western diplomats say the current official inflation rate of 17 percent for April reflects a sharp reduction in the issuing of credits early this year, after a credit binge in December created fears of hyperinflation. But there was another credit and spending binge in April and May, including huge increases due to the indexation of pensions and wages, that will cause higher inflation in a few months' time.
Officials say the degree of Central Bank commitment to the agreement is unclear. The accord sets limits on the growth of credit and calls for an increase in interest rates and no further large spending commitments by the Government this year. But the bank retains its freedom of action, and new Government ministers are talking about restoring significant state controls over planning and supply.
This week, the ruble lost almost 20 percent of its value, ending the week at 940 rubles to the dollar. The exchange rate, one official said, reflects the prevailing psychology, which is negative. "The exchange rate is the market saying that more inflation is coming," the official said. "I don't expect the economy to hit hyperinflation, but it may not get a lot better than it is now."

HEADLINE: Ueberroth, Amid Criticism, Quits Post at 'Rebuild L.A.' Consortium

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 21

 BODY:
A year after being appointed to attract jobs and economic hope to this city's troubled neighborhoods after the riots last spring, Peter V. Ueberroth resigned today as head of Rebuild L.A. amid growing criticism that the group was faltering.
Mr. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner who was best known for organizing the highly successful 1984 Summer Olympics here, came under fire in recent months for what critics said had been Rebuild L.A.'s failure to attract enough corporate support to create meaningful jobs. 
 At a hastily arranged news conference at the headquarters of Rebuild L.A., Mr. Ueberroth said he was stepping down as one of five co-leaders of the public-private consortium because he had become the focus of criticism, which, he said, was limiting the group's ability to move ahead. Mr. Ueberroth will continue to be a volunteer on the consortium's board.
From his appointment by Mayor Tom Bradley last May, Mr. Ueberroth was greeted with skepticism and hostility from many community groups and politicians who viewed him as a most unlikely savior for the inner city, despite his reputation for tackling gargantuan tasks.
A white Republican from suburban Laguna Beach, Mr. Ueberroth did not reflect the ethnic makeups of the communities that he was responsible for revitalizing, and many critics accused Mr. Bradley of abdicating his responsibility to a business executive.
 
$500 Million in Commitments
 Asked in an interview why he had become the focus of criticism, Mr. Ueberroth replied: "I don't know why the focus was on me. Maybe it was because I was the only appointment of the Mayor. Maybe it had some racial overtones, because I'm white. I don't know."
Mr. Ueberroth's departure raises questions about the future of what has become the nation's largest effort to bring together businesses, government and the community to work on social problems. Major cities across the nation have been closely watching Rebuild L.A. in hopes of adopting its tactics to rejuvenate their own languishing communities.
Rebuild L.A. said it had received more than $500 million in commitments from corporations, but those pledges have done little to change bleak social conditions in the inner city. Indeed, most of the corporate donations will be in the form of contributed equipment, buildings and support for training programs.
Mr. Bradley initially picked Mr. Ueberroth to develop Rebuild L.A. Mr. Ueberroth later appointed four co-leaders. Rebuild L.A. officials said the four other leaders would share equally in running the organization. One of them, Bernard W. Kinsey, is quite likely to become the de facto leader. Mr. Kinsey, a 49-year-old former executive of the Xerox Corporation, is a black Democrat who has been very visible recently delivering speeches on development.
Much of Rebuild L.A.'s troubles have stemmed from the fact that the public did not understand its role and had unrealistic expectations for what it could accomplish. Officials of the group have said its mission is to spur the private sector to make meaningful and sustainable investments in the inner city.
But many politicians and community groups viewed Rebuild L.A. as a cure-all for the problems of the inner city, and the organization was repeatedly called on to deal with other issues.
Korean-Americans wanted it to provide immediate assistance for merchants whose shops were burned. The president of the school board urged Rebuild L.A. to take a stand against a possible teachers' strike. And by virtue of its name, Rebuild L.A. was asked to speed the rebuilding of burned-out stores and ease racial tensions.
"Politicians broadened our mission to include other issues that were never part of our endeavor," Mr. Ueberroth said. "And when we couldn't deliver they criticized us. That's one of the reasons for my moving aside is the criticism of politicians."
Mr. Bradley issued a statement today praising Mr. Ueberroth's work, saying: "Peter Ueberroth's decision to resign as a co-chair of R.L.A. in no way diminishes his commitment to the organization and to R.L.A.'s efforts to attract private investment into Los Angeles. My supreme faith in him to spearhead this revitalization organization has been confirmed time and time again."
But a mayoral candidate, Richard Riordan, took the occasion to criticize Mr. Bradley for not taking a more active role in rebuilding the city. "Peter Ueberroth reflected the best a public citizen can be as the leading co-chair of Rebuild L.A.," Mr. Riordan said. "But a festering problem must be corrected to remove community concerns, a personal involvement by our next mayor."
Another mayoral candidate, Councilman Mike Woo, said in a statement that Mr. Ueberroth's resignation was an opportunity "for new thinking and new commitment to solving the problems that plague our city."

HEADLINE: VENEZUELA SENATE AUTHORIZES TRIAL

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 21

 BODY:
The President of Venezuela's Senate, Octavio Lepage, became Acting President today after the Senate voted unanimously to authorize the Supreme Court to try President Carlos Andres Perez on corruption charges.
Mr. Perez, 70, is not expected to regain presidential powers because a Supreme Court trial would likely continue beyond Feb. 2, the date his five-year term expires. 
 Within 30 days, Venezuela's Congress is to elect an interim President to serve until February. As President of the Senate, Mr. Lepage automatically assumed presidential powers with today's vote.
 
Crowds Greet Fall
 While jubilant crowds greeted Mr. Perez's fall from power today, several politicians and diplomats predicted in interviews that Venezuela, a major source of United States imported oil, faces eight months with a weak executive at the helm.
"The likelihood of political upheaval is way down," a Western diplomat said. "But it will be very hard for a weak president to resist backward steps in economic policy."
Mr. Lepage, an opponent of free-market economic changes and a onetime presidential candidate, today did not conceal his ambitions to rule Venezuela until next February. A lifelong politician, the 69-year-old Acting President comes from a wing of the governing Democratic Action Party that has been hostile to Mr. Perez's effort to dismantle state economic controls.
"For all his political life, Lepage has supported the interventionist economic policies of his party," Political Impact, a weekly newsletter, said today. "Over the last four years, he has been a critic of Perez's free-market efforts."
 
Propose Moving Up Elections
 To shorten a period of political drift, several politicians today proposed moving up the date of Venezuela's presidential and congressional elections, currently scheduled for Dec. 5. Causa R, a left-wing political party, proposed holding elections in August.
"The election date could be advanced, but it would take a constitutional change to move the inauguration date," said Oswaldo Alvarez Paz, presidential candidate of Copei, the leading opposition party.
Despite calls by radicals outside Congress for a military-civilian junta, a diplomat predicted today that foreign investor interest in this country will remain high.
"Venezuela's economic growth this year will be comparable or higher than Latin America's average," said Michael Skol, the United States Ambassador, referring to economists' forecasts of 5 percent growth in 1993. "The pace of Venezuela's economic growth over the last two years has been such that even a downturn does not represent a big deal."
Venezuela has the largest proven oil reserves in the Americas. After taking office in February 1989, Mr. Perez started opening the nation's state-controlled oil industry to foreign investment.
"The interests of oil companies in Venezuela is immense," Mr. Skol said. "There is almost a frenzy going on."
