HEADLINE: Sanctions Have a $12 Billion Ripple Effect Along the Danube

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
The United Nations sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia have cost the other Danube basin nations more than $12 billion in the last 11 months, more than they have cost Yugoslavia, the governments of countries in the basin say.
With the tightening of the sanctions by the Security Council on April 26, the Danube basin countries' losses in transportation, trade and industry are expected to grow in the coming months. 
 The embargo begun last June against Yugoslavia, which consists of Serbia and Montenegro, has cost it $4 billion, Belgrade estimated last week.
 
The Calm 'Is a Disaster'
 Viewed during a tour of the lower Danube this month aboard a Romanian Air Force helicopter, the broad surface of Europe's mightiest waterway flowed unruffled by the wake of a single vessel. At the twin cities of Giurgiu, Romania, and Ruse, Bulgaria, normally bustling river ports, there was not a moving ship in sight. The same eerie calm prevailed for 40 miles upstream.
"It is a disaster for Romania," said Capt. Tudor Tataoana, the harbor master of Giurgiu. "We can't import and we can't export."
He pointed out his window, facing Ruse across the river, to scores of idled barges, tugs, and tourist ships. Among them were six Austrian barges and a Yugoslav oil tanker that had been here for months because they carry strategic cargoes and are therefore not permitted to travel into the Serbian section of the river, which begins about 250 miles upstream. Skeleton crews guarded them.
At Giurgiu, Ion Bigica, the Deputy Customs Director, said: "Normally this is like a major railway. Eight or 10 barge convoys from Russia and Ukraine, four or five from Bulgaria, plus the Czechs, Slovaks, Hungarians. And we Romanians have the biggest fleet on the Danube.
"Nothing is going now. Zero."
 
Ripples Through the Economy
 Captain Tataoana said the sanctions had virtually closed Giurgiu's port, which on an average day serviced eight Danube vessels needing fuel or other supplies or loading and unloading.
As a result, entire factories have shut down for lack of raw materials. "Sixty longshoremen are out of work, and there is no money to pay them," the harbor master said.
"The Romanian economy was not in good shape to begin with," Mr. Bigica said in his office at the foot of Friendship Bridge, which carries road traffic across the Danube. "But we have made this sacrifice in the hope that powerful countries will help us."
Outside, scores of double trailer trucks from Europe and the Middle East were lined up on the narrow highway for half a mile, waiting to be processed by customs officials. The heavy road traffic is also a consequence of the Balkan conflict, Mr. Bigica said, since nearly all vehicles traveling between central Europe and Greece, Turkey and beyond have to detour around the war zone through Bulgaria and Romania.
 
Seeking Compensation
 A number of Danube basin countries have filed for compensation under Article 50 of the United Nations Charter, which permits governments to "consult" the Security Council on damages incurred by observing its resolutions, like the Yugoslav embargo. But there is no compensation mechanism, and an official of the 15-member sanctions committee said, "There is no money for indemnification."
A United States official said, "We are trying to steer talk away from indemnification. It's political dynamite."
Romanian officials estimate that the sanctions have already cost their country $7 billion. Hungary claims losses of $500 million for the second half of 1992, and Ukraine has estimated losses of $2.3 billion so far. Volodymir Khandogy, a Ukrainian diplomat, said sanctions were "leading to the bankruptcy" of the Ukraine Danube Shipping Company and the idling of its 25,000 employees.
Bulgaria has notified the sanctions committee of $1.8 billion in losses so far and "a sharp rise in the direct losses" from the latest tightening of the embargo, which it estimates is costing Bulgaria $234 million a month.
 
$10 Billion From Germany
 Austria has registered about $130 million in lost trade so far, with prospects of losing an equal amount in the next six months, while the Czech Republic estimates losses at $256 million for 1992. Germany has estimated a trade loss of $10 billion but has not broken out the loss along the Danube.
Even some enforcers of the sanctions are idle. The United States gave Romania and Bulgaria six new Boston Whaler patrol boats, but with international river traffic halted, the boats have become useless.
The Bulgarians have been using one of their whalers for water skiing, while the Romanians trucked one of theirs 50 miles north to Lake Snagov to take tourists on scenic trips for hard currency. "It is the only way we'll get any use out of them," a Romanian official said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia are hurting other Danube basin countries. "It is a disaster for Romania," said Capt. Tudor Tataoana, harbor master of Giurgiu. "We can't import and we can't export." (David Binder/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Fall on Fed Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Short-term Treasury issues led a broad decline in the bond market yesterday as traders continued to react negatively to an unexpected spurt in the nation's money supply.
Traders were selling on expectations -- fueled by the money supply figures released late Thursday -- that the Federal Reserve would tighten interest rates. 
 Longer-term Treasury prices also declined as interest rates rose. The 30-year bond fell 18/32 point, pushing its yield up to 7.04 percent, its highest level in seven weeks, from 6.99 percent on Thursday.
The Fed's money supply data reignited fears that the economy is heating up and that inflation is heading higher. The Fed reported that the M-2 money supply measure, which tracks currency, checking and some time deposits, surged a larger-than-expected $20.1 billion in early May, on top of a large gain the previous week.
Those inflation fears were heightened by this week's $10-an-ounce rise in the price of gold, considered an investment hedge against inflation. Yesterday, gold for June delivery rose $3.20 an ounce, to $377.90, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
 Alan Levenson, a money-market economist at UBS Securities Inc., said many bond traders thought the Fed might be forced to push interest rates higher to arrest inflation by the end of the third quarter.
Higher interest rates on new securities would hurt the value of bonds already sold. But short-term maturities stand to suffer the most from a tightening because the central bank uses short-term rates to carry out its monetary policy.
"The interesting feature of today's selloff is how hard the bill portion of the curve has been hit," Mr. Levenson said, referring to Treasury bills. "The idea that the Fed's next move will be to tighten, and it will happen sometime before the end of the third quarter, is perfectly reasonable."
The Fed's policy-making committee met this week, but minutes of the meeting will not be made public for six weeks. But yesterday, the central bank released minutes of its March 23 meeting that showed the Fed maintained a policy that neither favored nor opposed a change in rates. At the same time, several members expressed their concern that increases in consumer and producer prices could aggravate inflation.
Also depressing the short end of the bond market are concerns that the Treasury's auctions next week of bills and notes will overwhelm a market with little appetite for new supply.
The auctions reflect the Treasury's decision, announced earlier this month, to cut its sales of 30-year bonds and shift borrowing to securities with shorter-term maturities.
"Next week will be very critical to see how the market holds up in face of supply," said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at First Chicago Capital Markets.
Short-term Treasury issues fell 3/32 to 7/32, and intermediate maturities dropped 11/32 to 15/32, the Telerate Inc. information service reported.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
New Fears of Inflation Spur Advance in Precious Metals

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Investors rushed to gold and silver again yesterday amid renewed fears of inflation.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for June delivery rose $3.20, to $377.90 an ounce, while May silver rose 15.5 cents, to $4.669 an ounce. 
 Since falling to $327 an ounce last March, gold shot up to a two-year high Tuesday, with June gold trading at $383.50 during the day.
Most analysts have pointed to fear of inflation for the surge in gold, a traditional inflation hedge, although there has been no solid evidence of rampant inflation. The annual rate stands at 4.3 percent so far this year, compared with 2.9 percent last year.
 
Jump in Money Supply
 Martin Reichenberg, manager of trading services for Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., attributed yesterday's rise in precious metals prices to a sharp drop in the Treasury bond market following a report Thursday that showed a jump in the money supply, which could lead to inflation.
"Once again, we saw people coming into the market when prices moved lower, trying to buy gold and silver," Mr. Reichenberg said. "Even after profit taking, new, fresh buying seems to be coming into the market."
Bernard Savaiko, a metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in Weehawken, N.J., said silver led the rally yesterday, which he believed was prompted by the money-supply situation and traders covering their positions before the weekend.
On other commodity markets, energy futures were mixed. Light crude oil for July delivery rose 34 cents, to $19.88 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. But June heating oil slipped 0.45 cent, to 54.44 cents a gallon; June unleaded gasoline retreated 0.13 cent, to 59.20 cents a gallon, and June natural gas fell 2.03 cents, to $2.119 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: 'Witching Hour' Turmoil Pushes Dow Down 30.45

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The stock market fell broadly yesterday in moderately heavy trading, as the "double witching hour" added a final bit of turmoil to a hectic week.
The Dow Jones industrial average gyrated wildly after setting records for two consecutive days. It fell sharply after the opening bell, recovered quickly by 10 A.M., and languished for much of the day. But around 3 P.M., the Dow plunged in earnest, losing some 46 points, following a rise in gold prices in the afternoon. 
 The Dow closed down 30.45 points, to 3,492.83, although it gained 49.82 points for the week.
 
2 Expiration Dates
 Much of the Dow's volatility in the afternoon appeared tied to the "witching hour," which occurs every month when some options expire. Yesterday, both stock options and index options expired.
Institutions and big traders find it less expensive to buy an option that represents a bet on the future price of, say, the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index than to buy shares in all the 500 stocks. But, like a lottery ticket that goes uncashed, successful bets become meaningless if such options go unused.
Thus, the options expirations can sometimes lead to a frenzied burst of buying or selling stocks, as they did yesterday.
But the market's direction was not all determined by the highly technical trading strategies of large investors.
Nervous traders were further rattled by an unexpected increase in the nation's money supply, which raised more fears of inflation. Gold prices rose sharply, while the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond climbed to 7.04 percent, its highest level in seven weeks.
Volume on the Big Board was somewhat heavy at 279.1 million shares, compared with Thursday's 289.2 million shares. The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index closed down 2.15 points, to 246.27. Losing stocks are outnumbering winners by 1,134 to 797.
Among other market indicators, the Nasdaq composite index was down 3.14 points, to 694.29. But the American Stock Exchange market value index, reflecting a large number of gold and oil stocks, was up 0.57 point, to 432.86, a record for the third day in a row.
Late Thursday, the Federal Reserve Board said that its main measure of money supply, known as M-2, rose an especially steep $20.1 billion in the week ended May 10, reviving traders' fears of inflation and a possible move by the Fed to raise interest rates.
But John R. Williams, a managing director of the Bankers Trust Company, played down the number's significance. He wrote in a commentary that the figures might simply mean that more people were keeping funds in cash and other liquid balances because of uncertainty in the stock and bond markets.
 
Gold Stocks Rise
 Gold stocks followed the rising price of gold. Echo Bay Mines, for example, was up 3/8, to 12 1/8. It was once again the most active stock on the American Stock Exchange, with 2.34 million shares changing hands. The exception to the modest rise for the gold group was Newmont Mining, up 2 1/2, to 52 1/8.
As in yesterday's trading, Spectrum Information Technologies was the most noteworthy stock, although volume was sharply down. Nonetheless, at 15.7 million shares, compared with 34.4 million shares Thursday, it was the most active stock on any exchange. Spectrum Information, whose prospects for growth have been severely questioned recently, closed down 1/8, to 5 7/8.

HEADLINE: Casino Bill Allowed to Die In Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 21

 BODY:
The Las Vegas gambling industry's high-stakes drive to legalize casino gambling in Connecticut ended today in retreat, when legislative leaders and representatives of Mirage Resorts jointly agreed to let the proposal die for the year without even taking a vote that they said would be sure to fail.
The announcement represented a major victory for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who led the forces against the casino plan through a five-month battle of wits and wills with Mirage Resorts' chairman, Stephen A. Wynn. 
 Mr. Wynn had pledged to invest $700 million in casino and entertainment complexes in Bridgeport and Hartford and to create 22,000 new jobs in a state battered by recession and cuts in military production. Mr. Weicker said casinos would increase crime and create only low-wage service jobs that would ultimately drag Connecticut's economy down.
"Thank you to the men and women of the Legislature who have put their state first," Mr. Weicker said in a statement. "I never lost faith."
 
'There Were Not Enough Votes'
 Debate had been scheduled for Monday in the House of Representatives, but House leaders, meeting with Mirage officials, concluded late in the day that the measure -- even if it did pass with a majority -- would come nowhere near the two-thirds margin that would be required to override Mr. Weicker's promised veto.
"We're realists," said Richard D. Bronson, a spokesman for Mirage. "There were not enough votes."
Mr. Bronson said, however, that the battle was far from over. He said that Mirage, which has already waged what state ethics officials say is the most costly advertising and lobbying campaign in state history -- more than $1 million in just the first few months of this year -- would continue to make its case with eye toward next year's legislative session.
"I'm not sure we ever expected in one fell swoop, in just one year, we'd be able to get something like this through," he said.
Mr. Weicker, a third-party independent Governor with no party loyalists in the General Assembly, announced last year after Mr. Wynn's first proposal to build a convention center and casino in Hartford, that he would oppose it with all his power. But the Governor was not content simply to promise a veto when and if the time came, and his political moves seemed to catch casino promoters off balance time and again.
In January, he signed an agreement with the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe under which the Indians could operate slot machines at their casino in Ledyard. The tribe agreed to pay the state a minimum of $100 million a year in slot-machine profits as long as it retained a monopoly on slot machines. If casinos and slot machines were legalized off the reservation, the Pequot Fund, as it was dubbed, would immediately end.
Mr. Wynn responded by pledging to match the Pequot money, and exceed it.
 
Reducing Taxes
 Earlier this week, as the countdown to the first floor debates on the issue began, the Weicker administration negotiated a deal to reduce the taxes paid by the state's existing gambling operations, the jai alai frontons and the dog track in Plainfield. Those companies had said that without the slot machines they would get as part of the casino bill, they could go out of business.
Mr. Wynn, who had already withdrawn his Hartford proposal in the face of local opposition from business leaders, then said he would have only table games like blackjack and roulette at his Bridgeport casino. That would preserve both the tax cut and the Pequot money, Mirage officials said.
But Mr. Wynn, in a news conference today before the announcement that the casino bill was dead, also said that in the last few weeks he had been in negotiations to buy almost all of the state's existing gambling enterprises, including the jai alai frontons in Milford and Hartford. The idea, he said, was to put those buildings "to other uses" once a casino was established and so avoid "too much gambling" that would dilute the impact of the casino.
Mr. Wynn said that Mr. Weicker's single-minded opposition controverted what opinions polls have indicated about support for casinos in the state.
"He needs a victory, and he has picked this as a Waterloo moment," Mr. Wynn said. "He's a cute fellow."
 
A Battered Economy
 The backdrop to both sides in the debate has been the question of where Connecticut's economy will go from here. The state, for years a compact dynamo of military manufacturers and financial services giants, has been battered on all fronts by the recession, which has eliminated almost 200,000 jobs in the last four years.
The campaign for the Mirage dealt with little else but that statistic, and asked residents and legislators the pointed question: if not casinos, then what?
Mr. Weicker argued that manufacturing should be the state's hope for the future and has pledged millions in grants and loans to retain companies and sell the state as a location for businesses. The Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce also became an ally after insurance industry leaders at companies like Aetna and the Travelers expressed opposition to a casino in their hometown.
Inside the Legislature the casino bill's chances were also hampered by the fact that the leaders in both parties were opposed to the idea and would twist no arms for votes. There were even indications through the day today that with the two-thirds margin unreachable, lawmakers who favored the idea were saying they might vote no to avoid going down with the ship.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Tumbles

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Confidence in the economy and in the Clinton Administration's handling of it took another tumble in May, suggesting that consumer and business spending is likely to remain so-so and that the President's political troubles are still growing.
The latest surveys of consumers and businesses show that the resurgence of hope that occurred between the election of President Clinton and his economic policy speech before Congress in mid-February has been totally erased by anxieties over higher taxes. Indeed, approval of the President's economic policies has plunged in the last month while disapproval has grown dramatically. 
 "This reflects worries about Washington," said David Kelly, an economist at the Boston Company Economic Advisers. "We've still got a half-paced recovery. That hasn't really changed."
 
Sharp Contrast With Reagan
 The abrupt loss of faith in the Clinton expansion contrasts starkly with rising confidence in Reaganomics during President Ronald Reagan's first spring in office, even after taking into account the surge in public sympathy after President Reagan was shot.
The University of Michigan index of consumer expectations -- which is based on a monthly survey of households around the country and figures in the Government's economic forecasting gauge -- dropped sharply in May, to 71.9 from 76.4 in April. The May reading is the lowest since last October.
The President's approval rating among consumers fell to 7 percent in May, from 15 percent in April, only a shade higher than President Bush's rock-bottom 5 percent rating last August.
Despite White House efforts to reach out to executives, the Cahners Business Confidence index, which measures business expectations about the economy, has dropped to its pre-election level after rising sharply during the fall and winter.
 
Only One Ingredient
 To be sure, the U-turn in confidence is the third since the recession ended in March 1991, and the mood of consumers and businesses is only one ingredient in buying decisions. Pay and profits, interest rates and inflation also count for a lot.
In this case, the snippets of economic data available for May suggest that retail sales continue to rise and car sales have weakened, but only after a very strong April. Conditions in the job market have stabilized.
The latest decline in confidence "won't abort the recovery, it's just a characteristic of this weak recovery," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw Hill.
 
Investors Ignore Survey
 The Michigan survey, which covers the first half of May, was released last week to clients -- some of whom passed some details to reporters -- but was ignored by investors who were more worried about inflation.
The overall Michigan consumer sentiment index -- a summary measure that reflects consumers' feelings about the present as well as the future -- fell to 81.9 in May from 85.6 in April, a significant drop in a measure that is not particularly volatile.
The main reason for the decline: Consumers' expectations about future business conditions took a dive.
Consumers' view of current economic conditions also turned a little gloomier, slipping from a reading of 99.9 to 97.4.
Confidence in the Clinton economic policy also took a turn for the worse: 52 percent rate the president's performance "fair" and 39 percent, up from 28 percent in March, as "poor."
As for executives, Cahners Economics, an economic research firm in Massachusetts, reported that their confidence fell sharply this month, another indication -- following on yesterday's report from the Philadelphia Federal Reserve -- that production could rise at a slower pace this month than last month.
One encouraging note in the Cahners survey is that businesses do not seem unduly concerned about the March pileup in inventories. Only 7 percent of the managers surveyed said they planned to scale back production.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Faith No More" shows results of a consumer confidence survey from April 1992 to May 1993. (Source: University of Michigan; Cahners Economics)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Continued Selloff of Marks Helps Dollar Rise in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against leading European currencies yesterday as traders continued to sell German marks.
The Japanese yen, meanwhile, strengthened against the dollar on continued speculation that the United States Government favored a stronger yen as a way to trim America's large trade deficit with Japan. 
 The rush to sell marks began on Tuesday, when Danish voters approved the European treaty on closer political and economic ties. That removed the immediate threat of turbulence in Europe's monetary system and led traders to sell marks and buy the Danish krone and other European currencies.
Traders are also increasingly uncertain about the interest rate policy of Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, which is under pressure to ease rates to help stimulate the country's troubled economy.
 
Dollar Mirroring the Mark
 "Generally speaking, the strength of the dollar against Continental currencies isn't necessarily due to a strong dollar but mirroring weakness of the mark," said Albert Soria, first vice president of Kansallis Osake Pankki, a Finnish bank.
The dollar rose more than a pfennig, to 1.6305 marks, before easing to 1.6256 marks in late New York trading, up from 1.6168 marks on Thursday.
Traders continued to buy the Japanese yen following the release of American trade figures earlier this week showing that the merchandise trade deficit ballooned in March.
That reignited speculation that the United States Government would aim to support the yen as a way to reduce the deficit. A stronger yen makes Japanese imports more expensive in the United States and American exports cheaper in Japan.
But the dollar failed to break below the important 110.00-yen level amid unconfirmed rumors that the Bank of Japan bought dollars during Tokyo trading to try to arrest the yen's appreciation.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 110.35 yen, down from 110.65 yen on Thursday.
The British pound, meanwhile, was quoted at $1.5430 in late New York trading, down from $1.5560 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Coast to Coast, Workers Say Fickle Economy Is a Riddle: The West;
From Boom to Bust And at Loose Ends

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RANCHO CUCAMONGA, Calif., May 19

 BODY:
In these hard times, more and more fathers have been appearing in the afternoons to pick up their children at the Coyote Canyon School, unemployed and at loose ends here in what was recently one of the fastest-growing regions in the country.
The fathers, who are former aerospace workers, construction men and real estate brokers, stand in the baking sun outside the new $8 million school that began to retrench as soon as it opened last year, cutting back staff positions and increasing class size as the money melted away. 
 "I have a lot more time to coach Little League now," said Frederick Fuhrmann, who lost his job as a trucking company sales manager eight months ago and was waiting today to pick up his son Jason, 9. "But by the same token, it's harder to pay the expenses of Little League."
Along with the rest of the Inland Empire, the parts of Riverside and San Bernardino counties that stretch eastward into the desert from Los Angeles, this young town of 115,000 people rode the crest of a boom in the aerospace and defense industries in the 1980's. More than a million people moved into the region in the last decade; now, with the sudden collapse of those industries, unemployment here has soared to nearly 11 percent.
 
Pessimism at Arm's Length
 "I think every family has someone who has been affected," said Eva Schneider, the school's librarian. But even though most economists say they see no short-term way out of the region's economic collapse, Mrs. Schneider, like most people here, still keeps her pessimism at arm's length.
"My husband works with McDonnell Douglas and he hasn't received his pink slip yet, at least as of last Friday," she said. "We try not to let the future get us down. There's always the hope that our President will get us out of this slump."
Economists see the Inland Empire as a microcosm of the California boom of the 1980's and of its current collapse. In his swing through California this week President Clinton asserted that the fate of the nation's economy is tied to that of its most populous state, and this region now presents a test of his ability to lead an economic revival.
"I voted for Clinton and I'll stand by him until he does something wrong," said Randy Robinson, an unemployed aerospace worker who had come to school to pick up his two daughters.
Inside the cool, high-ceiling school building, Sam Kachaenchai, a 47-year-old immigrant from Thailand, was completing his second day of work in four months, as a substitute janitor.
Five years ago he and his wife moved here from Chicago when a rapidly expanding local hospital recruited her to work as a nurse. Mr. Kachaenchai immediately found a job as an engineer.
"When we came here it was very, very exciting," he said. "We bought our house through the telephone. We chose the color, chose the carpeting, everything through the mail."
Within four days last January, both husband and wife lost their jobs because of retrenchments that included the layoffs of 152 people at the hospital. They now support themselves in part with the money their two teen-agers earn delivering newspapers.
But Mr. Kachaenchai refuses to be discouraged. "I came to America for the opportunity," he said. "It's still better than the third world, where I come from. I say that from the heart."
From around the country, hundreds of thousands of people joined Mr. Kachaenchai in seeking opportunity in Rancho Cucamonga and its neighboring communities.
"This was the American dream neighborhood; everything was booming along," said Patt Hatcher, the principal of Coyote Canyon School. "Now we're terrified. Everyone is in terrible shape. It's like the ax is going to fall."
Almost every day, she said, a teacher or a parent at the school reports that a husband has lost his job, and everyone rallies around to try to find him another job. Some fathers now work as classroom volunteers and playground proctors.
"We've got to do something different," Mrs. Hatcher said in frustration. "The President is saying, 'This is what we've got to do.' Well, let's do it. Let's at least do something. I just wish they'd quit fighting and get going."

"It seems like you've got to break your back just to stay even." He and his wife, Vivian Kizer, a preschool teacher, illustrate the nation's economic riddle: consumers await economic recovery, which awaits consumers. HEADLINE: Fed Panel Was Urged To Lift Rates

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21

 BODY:
Two Federal Reserve governors called for raising interest rates when the central bank's main policy-setting committee met in March, and some economists say the two might have won more support at last Tuesday's meeting because of the big jump in inflation in April.
According to the official summary of the March 23 meeting, two Fed governors, Lawrence B. Lindsey and Wayne D. Angell, called for an immediate increase in rates to fight inflationary pressures, saying such a move was needed to prevent a more drastic rate increase later on. 
 But a majority of the group, including Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, voted not to change their policy, which favors neither an increase nor a cut in rates. The group expressed confidence that inflation would remain low.
 
Prices Jumped in April
 That optimism was certainly reduced by April figures showing an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in producer prices, the largest in two and a half years, and a rise of fourth-tenths of 1 percent in consumer prices.
The Fed is not scheduled to release its summary of Tuesday's meeting until early July, although it could raise or cut rates at any time.
Many economists say that despite the recent news on inflation, the weak economic growth in the first quarter has led the committee to stay with its policy favoring no change in rates.
But there are some economists who say the Fed committee might have adopted a tilt toward higher rates because that would give the Fed more flexibility to raise rates in case inflation is high in May.
In interviews and speeches in recent weeks, Fed officials have said the inflation picture requires close scrutiny. The price increases in April brought the annualized increase in the core inflation rate, which excludes volatile energy and food prices, to 4.2 percent over the last seven months, from 2.7 percent over the previous six.
Some Fed officials say the economy is at a crossroads, with the Fed having to make sure that inflation continues heading toward 2 percent and not jumping back to a 4 to 5 percent rate. If inflation were to climb to that level, central bank officials fear, long-term bonds could jump back to 10 percent. That could further slow the already sluggish economy.
Mr. Angell and Mr. Lindsey said in the March meeting that monetary policy was not tight enough because the Fed's 3 percent interest rates were somewhat lower than the inflation rate. They worried that inflation would be fueled by a surge in commodity prices and the weakness of the dollar, which makes foreign goods more expensive.
In the summary of the March meeting, the majority of the committee expressed the view that the upturn in prices in January and February, compared with late last year, might be a temporary blip. The committee pointed to several factors that were inconsistent with higher inflation, including high unemployment, fierce competition in many markets, slow growth in the money supply and no growth in industrial orders.
 
Some See Disinflation

 
 The report said, "Most of the members concluded that the evidence at this point did not confirm a resurgence in inflationary pressures, and some commented that further modest disinflation remained a reasonable expectation for the next several quarters."
The summary added that the members acknowledged that recent price developments "had raised a degree of unease in their minds, and their concerns would rise if the recent pace of price advances was sustained in the months immediately ahead."
The Federal Open Market Committee meets eight times a year, and sets the Federal funds rate, the rate the central bank sets on overnight lending to banks. The committee comprises the 7 governors of the Federal Reserve Board and 5 of the presidents of the Fed's 12 district banks.

HEADLINE: Coast to Coast, Workers Say Fickle Economy Is a Riddle: The East;
Things Are 'Flat But Improving'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, May 20

 BODY:
Pest control may not be a leading economic indicator, but Chris Pickering, an exterminator here, says his business is highly sensitive to the economic well-being of his customers.
His business was flat last year, Mr. Pickering says, but it has been improving slightly this year. "That means people here don't think the economy is all that bad," said Mr. Pickering, 26, the manager of a Terminix International office in a middle-class corner of Philadelphia. 
 Economists say Mr. Pickering's "flat, but improving" assessment of the economy is a fair description of the situation in the Middle Atlantic States and New England.
"These regions were the first to enter the recession, and they will be the last to pull out of it," said Paul C. Bishop, director of state and metropolitan forecasting at the WEFA Group, a private consultant in suburban Bala-Cynwyd.
 
Four Structural Problems
 He said Philadelphia's economy shares the four structural problems that plague the economies of most Northeastern states: an oversupply of commercial office space, an overdependence on military contractors, declining populations and relatively high taxes and energy costs for businesses.
Thomas D. Kramer, a 27-year-old commercial real estate broker, is well aware of the vacant office space in Philadelphia, where 6 million of the city's 35 million square feet of office space are empty. Mr. Kramer, an assistant vice president of Albert M. Greenfield & Company, said that last year he made about 30 phone calls a day seeking new clients but now has to make 100 calls a day to remain competitive. "It's a war out there," he said.
Mr. Kramer said that many of his friends who have degrees from Ivy League graduate schools are out of work, and that he feels lucky to be doing as well as he is. Nonetheless, he is disappointed. He had expected that after three years' work he would have saved enough money to buy a house.
Now, he said, the economy is so uncertain that he would not buy a house until he had saved enough for two years' mortgage payments as well as a downpayment. "I work on straight, 100 percent commission, and face a huge uncertainty," he said. "Next year I may make nothing."
Fear of the future is particularly intense among defense workers. The planned closing of the Philadelphia Naval Base and other military installations by 1997 will eliminate about 17,500 jobs directly and 40,000 related jobs, or about 7.5 percent of the jobs in the Philadelphia area.
These defense-related jobs are at companies like VIZ Manufacturing, which makes meteorological instruments. In the last year, the company laid off 50 of its 175 employees.
"It's extremely difficult to lay off workers, and it creates a lot of uncertainty for the people who stay," said V. Scott Zelov, 35, who is president of the company that his grandfather started here in 1933. "It's more difficult and stressful to work in a company where we're cutting back, rather than growing."
Mr. Zelov said he often puts in 12-hour days now as he tries to develop new commercial products to replace lost Government contracts. "We're trying," he said, "but it's a very long process."

LENGTH: 370 words

HEADLINE: A Mighty Fall in Venezuela

 BODY:
As the United States' second-largest oil supplier and one of Latin America's longest-running democracies, Venezuela merits special attention. The downfall of its flamboyant President, Carlos Andres Perez, on charges of massive embezzlement of public funds poses no obvious threat to the oil flow. And it just might check the undermining of democratic morale that provoked two nearly successful coup attempts within 16 months.
Mr. Perez has been modern Venezuela's dominant political figure, serving as President for 9 of its 34 years of democratic rule. He has also thrust himself into the international spotlight, offering himself as a mediator of the violent conflicts that have convulsed Nicaragua, El Salvador and Haiti. 
 In his first term, during the 1970's, Mr. Perez nationalized Venezuela's oil industry and used the revenues to entrench a social democratic welfare state. In his second, he reversed course, pushing through free market reforms that have brought Venezuela some of the hemisphere's highest growth figures while devastating the living standards of its poor and middle-class citizens.
Mr. Perez's entourage has always emanated an aura of corruption. But what seemed tolerable to many Venezuelans during the good times of the 1970's became offensive when millions of ordinary citizens were struggling to get by. Devastating riots in 1989 and two military coup attempts in 1992 reflected popular discontent, amplified by the demagoguery of ambitious populist politicians like former President Rafael Caldera Rodriguez.
In the competitive international economy of the 1990's, continued economic reform remains Venezuela's only realistic option. With official corruption now under deserved judicial scrutiny, responsible politicians will have a chance to make the case for more equitably borne sacrifices for the sake of future prosperity.
Washington's most important obligation is to honor the democratic process now unfolding. Both the interim President, to be chosen by the Venezuelan Congress in the coming weeks, and his or her successor, to be popularly elected later this year, will need all the external support they can get to rebuild democratic faith after the Perez debacle.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Shuffle of Warehouse Clubs

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The long-anticipated shakeout in the warehouse club industry has begun.
The Kmart Corporation announced yesterday that it would close three of its Pace Membership Warehouse stores and sell 14 others to Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which operates a competing chain called Sam's Club. 
 "They are the first one to blink," said Monroe H. Greenstein, an equity analyst at Lazard Freres & Company.
He said the sale and store closings were likely to be the first of many. "There's been overexpansion in the industry over the last several years, and a lot of clubs are simply now competing with each other," he said.
The warehouse industry has been hurt by slowing sales and disappointing earnings of late, and none have fared worse than Pace, which had a 92 percent drop in operating earnings last year. Many major players, seeing fierce competition in the United States, have started expanding into Canada and Mexico.
 
A Rush to Major Markets
 The five key players in the industry have rushed over the last decade to establish themselves in major markets, where only two competitors can realistically survive, said Peter J. Siris, a retail analyst at UBS Securities.
"What happens then? They get more aggressive on price, which means no one is making any money," he said. "Category killers like Toys "R" Us and Office Depot and grocery stores are giving them increasing competition, too."
Of the Pace clubs being sold, four are in Dallas, three in Kansas City, Mo.; five in Chicago, and one each in St. Louis and in Toledo, Ohio. Of the clubs to be closed, one is in St. Louis and two are in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
Mr. Siris said Wal-Mart was essentially strengthening market dominance with the purchase of the 14 stores, while Pace was basically leaving areas where competition was intense.
 
A Sale, Not a Purchase
 Although analysts had been predicting consolidation in the industry, the sale of the Pace stores came as something of a surprise. They had been betting that Kmart would acquire the Price Company, which founded the warehouse club business in the mid-1970's and is the most productive of the major clubs.
Price and other chains have been battered by cannibalization -- which occurs when new stores take away the customer base of older ones in the same chain. Price also has a heavy concentration of stores in economically embattled Southern California.
Analysts had also expected Kmart, whose other specialty and discount stores generate strong cash flow, to wait out any consolidation that would rock the warehouse club industry.
 
Peace With Wal-Mart
 But Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., recently reported an 80 percent drop in first-quarter earnings and apparently decided it did not want to sustain underperforming stores through a potentially brutal battle. So it made peace with the company best poised to clean up in a consolidation, Wal-Mart, of Bentonville, Ark., which is the largest player in the $34 billion warehouse club industry with more than 250 clubs producing $12.3 billion in sales.
Shares of Kmart declined 37.5 cents yesterday, to $22.875, while Wal-Mart's stock was down $1.125, to $27.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Tom Grimm, chief executive of Pace, said the sale and closings were part of a realignment of Kmart's warehouse club business. Mr. Grimm, founder of the Price Savers Wholesale clubs that Kmart acquired in 1990 and turned into Pace stores, is himself part of that repositioning.
 
'Back to Basicscij'
 He took over the chain earlier this year, promising to bring the company "back to basics" by refocusing its attention on the small-business customers that make up the most lucrative segment of a warehouse club's business.
Analysts have criticized Pace for focusing too heavily on attracting individual customers instead of small businesses. Business customers buy in larger quantities per transaction than do individual shoppers, and the warehouse club business must turn over its inventory rapidly because profit margins are so slim.

HEADLINE: Coast to Coast, Workers Say Fickle Economy Is a Riddle

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 20

 BODY:
The sun poked through the clouds, vanished, then gave way to rain as Floyd Rucker and Vivian Kizer stepped inside a gleaming downtown shopping mall here, where they did more looking than buying. They have talked about buying a new house and having a baby. But the nation's economy, fickle as the spring sky in Missouri, has put their plans on hold.
"I think about the low interest rates, and figure maybe it's time to buy something," said Mr. Rucker, a 29-year-old veterinarian's assistant. "But then I think about a friend of mine. He's got a new baby, a big house payment, two car payments. And he just got laid off. He doesn't know what he's going to do." 
 "I don't plan on losing my job," he said, "but neither did he."
 
Many Remain Uncertain
 Although the nation's recession has long since been declared over, and some parts of the country have shown signs of a recovery, many Americans say they remain uncertain about the economy, fearful about their jobs and wary of making large purchases.
Like the principal of a school in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., where more and more unemployed fathers are showing up to volunteer their time, or a commercial real estate broker in Philadelphia who is facing a glut of empty office space, many workers across the country say they are not convinced that life will get easier any time soon.
The wariness of Mr. Rucker and Ms. Kizer, 28, a preschool teacher, who might otherwise now be buying house furnishings and baby clothes, illustrates the chicken-or-egg conundrum of the nation's sluggish economy: consumers wait for economic recovery, which waits for consumers.
 
Working Hard to Stay Even
 "A lot of things I always took for granted -- having a big family, owning a house -- it just doesn't seem realistic anymore," said Mr. Rucker, who recently saw his annual 5 percent raise cut to 3 percent because of a slack in business. "It seems like you've got to break your back just to stay even."
Here in the middle of America, which saw neither the extreme boom of the 1980's nor the sharp real estate slump of the early 1990's and where the recovery has been noticeable, people tend to take the long view of things, and most are not sanguine.
Anxious as they are for an economic recovery, Midwesterners say they believe the days of real job security have gone forever.
 
Everybody Is Wondering
 "All businesses are reorganizing, trying to get more efficient," said Mike Hutchinson, 36, the manager of a copy-machine store in Des Moines. "And everybody is kind of wondering, Where am I going to fit in?"
Like other regions in the United States, the Midwest has been hardest hit by layoffs in automobile and defense-related companies.
Diana Alvarez, 46, whose annual household income is nearly $80,000, said she cannot relax for more than two weeks at a time. Her husband, Dennis, works for Boeing in Wichita, Kan., and the company is laying off 6,000 people this year. The pink slips are delivered with the paychecks.
"Every two weeks on payday, my husband opens it up to see if there's anything pink inside," said Ms. Alvarez, a nurse. "So far he's come home every time to say, 'No pink slip today.' But we can't be sure about next payday. So you just live day to day."
With two children in college and elderly parents who need financial help, Ms. Alvarez said she shudders to think about the future if her husband loses his job. "I don't know how we'll survive," she said.
But retailers in the Crown City mall here in Kansas City say business has picked up in the last four or five months.
"When more people are buying flowers," said Del Draper, a florist who has been working overtime, "you know people are feeling better."
Unemployment is relatively low in Kansas City -- about 5.5 percent -- but the statistics do not say much about the kinds of jobs available.
David Gardine, a 40-year-old clerk in a housewares store here, said he could survive on his $7-an-hour wage as long as he stayed healthy. Like millions of working-class Americans, he has no health insurance. "You just lay low and try to take care of yourself," he said.

HEADLINE: DESIGN;
IN PRAISE OF PUBLIC PLACES

BYLINE: By Julie V. Iovine

 BODY:

FORT PECK DAM
Public works don't have to be as oppressively dull as they sound. Take dams. These monoliths that stud our rivers are strictly utilitarian, yet the best of them still manage to pack a visual wallop. Last year, 730,000 people trekked out to Nevada to see Hoover Dam. Margaret Bourke-White's 1936 photo of Fort Peck Dam in Montana (above) adorned the first cover of Life magazine, capturing in its ragged symmetry the pure drama of Art Deco design. F.D.R. was so impressed with the potential magnificence and employment opportunities of dams that he made building them the key to his recovery plan out west. By its completion in 1938, Fort Peck Dam had put more than 10,000 men to work and opened up navigable waterways all the way to Kansas City. Now that's infrastructure.
Infrastructure is not a word that comes trippingly off the tongue, and yet many invoke it as part of the solution to what ails us. In recent history, infrastructure has been associated with low-quality, low-cost design. Which is a shame, really. Because the courthouses, train stations, highways and bridges that we encounter each day have the potential to uplift us with their grandeur. 
 Architects have long been drawn to the design of utilitarian structures as a way to realize the ideal of pure line wedded to powerful function. At their best, public places can celebrate community by giving it a unique and recognizable shape. They can also elevate the individual through a kind of pride of ownership.
The projects shown here, smaller in scale than any dam, but with just as much impact, display the inspirational power unleashed when Government lends itself unstintingly to good design.
 
RED ROCKS AMPHITHEATER
Red Rocks Amphitheater, outside of Denver, typifies the best of the Works Project Administration. With an extremely simple design enhanced by the breathtaking majesty of the Rockies, the amphitheater has been in constant use since its opening in 1941.
It was constructed by 120 young men from the Civilian Conservation Corps, which Roosevelt envisioned as a kind of youth squad, rechanneling the energy of unemployed men, 18 to 25, into outdoor construction projects: planting trees, stocking fish and building wildlife shelters. By the time the Corps was disbanded on the eve of World War II, it had developed close to 3,000 parks.
Wedged between spurs of 300-million-year-old red sandstone, Red Rocks is a dramatic departure from most parkland design, which often tends to be rustic, even quaint. Here, instead of logs, a vast sculpture of rock -- sublime in its pure form -- arrests the eye at the point where the Rocky Mountains meet the plains.
Red Rocks was designed by the architect Burnham Hoyt, who also worked on Radio City Music Hall. Its inspiration came from the amphitheaters of ancient Greece, and it indeed belongs among the world's man-made wonders.
 
NATIONAL PORTRAIT GALLERY
Walt Whitman called it "that noblest of Washington buildings," and it's easy to see why. The National Portrait Gallery, originally the United States Patent Office, contains in its gaudy and grand architecture all the flamboyant aspirations of a young democracy intent on impressing the world. Begun in 1837, it was then the largest office building in Washington. The public grumbled at first, unaccustomed to Government spending on such a monumental scale. However, President Andrew Jackson, who commissioned it, remained stalwart in his determination to establish "a temple of the useful arts" to showcase not only patents (such was the importance of invention in its role of defining the newly centralized democracy), but the material wealth and resourcefulness of America, through displays of historical documents, artworks and geological specimens.
It was a good time to celebrate the promise of America. The mid-1830's was the first time since the Revolution that there was no national debt. By the time Whitman tended to the wounded sent there (for lack of space elsewhere) from the battles of Antietam and Fredericksburg, the Patent Office was a recognized landmark in the capital; in 1865, Abraham Lincoln chose its grand hall as the setting for his second inaugural ball.
The chief architect of record was Robert Mills, who also designed the Washington Monument. His high-style Greek Revival exterior is somewhat at odds with the Victorian Renaissance Great Hall, which dates to a restoration following an 1877 fire. The detailing throughout is extravagant even for those days, including a 20-foot stained-glass skylight, tessellated marble floors, reproduction Gothic tiles, brass railings and gilded fixtures. Today, after surviving the removal of a grand stair on its south portico to make way for a street widening, and its near razing in the 1950's for a parking garage, the United States Patent Office has been transformed into the National Portrait Gallery, with an exuberant permanent collection of some 14,000 American art objects.
 
LOOP 360
With L.B.J. in the White House, Lady Bird Johnson claimed conservation and the environment as her special sphere of influence. Despite its awkward-sounding name, her "beautification" project ("Plant a Tree, Plant a Shrub!") had a lasting impact, and today, our highways, like Loop 360 outside Austin, Texas, are in full flower.
It started with the volunteer Committee for a More Beautiful Capital and ultimately led to some 278 environmental measures, including the addition of one million acres of national parkland and the institution of the National Wild Rivers System and the National System of Trails. Lady Bird's particular fascination with wildflowers (in Texas, wildflower seeding programs for public roads have been in place since 1929) resulted in the 1987 Wildflower Act, which insures that 25 cents out of every $100 going to federally funded highways must be allocated to planting native wildflowers. Today, virtually every state has its own seeding program as well.
 
HAMILTONM FISH PARK
By 1900, civic pride mingled with social concern drove most public construction. The 1893 Columbian Exhibition in Chicago awed attendees with its Beaux-Arts architecture. At the same time, people were increasingly aware of immigrants living in urban degradation. The City Beautiful Movement sprung from these two forces. It placed its faith in the rejuvenative power of aesthetics. A new gym on the Lower East Side, for example, was supposed to reduce neighborhood crime by dint of its lavish design, based on the Petit Palais in Paris. And despite complaints that it was too ornate for the locals, they loved it. In 1936, pools were added, and last summer, after a 1992 restoration, Hamilton Fish Park attracted 65,000 kids.
 
JAMES LEE COURT
During the past 12 years, Federal money for public housing was cut by 75 percent. What did get built, according to Thomas Fisher, executive editor of Progressive Architecture, was neither particularly innovative nor inspired, but rather middle-class homes stripped of all amenities. James Lee Court, which opened last year in Oakland, Calif., is different. A result of a coalition of homeless people, architects, developers, social workers and church leaders who banded together to apply for $4 million in funds, it is both socially innovative and architecturally delightful.
It houses not only 104 people, many of them formerly homeless, but provides social services as well. The architect Michael Pyatok designed it to be small, with 26 units arranged in four stories around an open courtyard and a large public stoop. Families live on the ground or second floor with direct access to the courtyard in order to minimize children's use (and abuse) of elevators. Singles and older people are on upper floors with their own balconies or a roof deck. Appropriately, the leaping frogs on tiles over the entrance recall the African-American symbol for good fortune.
When the project was ready to open last fall, hundreds of Oakland's homeless population applied for the 20 available units. If emulation is the best measure of a role model, then James Lee Court is indeed successful; two more are already under way in Oakland.

GRAPHIC: Photos of designs (Photographs by David Maisel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
What's a Network TV Censor to Do?

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
"Exceptional care must be exercised when showing the 14-year-old being threatened."
"Discretion should be used governing the costuming of the woman in the bikini."
"Lose (expletive), (expletive), (expletive.)" 
 In an austere office high above midtown Manhattan, Rosalyn Weinman, the head of broadcast standards and practices at NBC, is reviewing reports from the field like those above. The reports, filed on blue paper and thus known as "blue sheets," are filled with exhortations, warnings and the occasional strongly worded command. They represent the best judgments of Ms. Weinman's staff about what NBC's audience should and should not be subjected to while watching the tube.
They also represent censorship's last stand against the prurient pleasures of American television.
It is nearly four decades since the heyday of broadcast standards, when a swollen Lucille Ball could not use the word "pregnant" on the air and the networks were ruled by such strict propriety that whole realms of human experience were simply considered off limits.
Much has changed, in society and on the air. The afternoon talk shows -- which are syndicated to local stations, bypassing the networks -- specialize in dissecting the most intimate sexual behavior. Local news programs, especially in larger cities, are in constant, headlong competition to find the most titillating "special reports." The upstart network Fox changed the definition of acceptable broadcast material with sex-saturated shows like "Married . . . With Children." And all the networks know they are continually losing viewers to cable channels, which offer a smorgasbord of nudity and profanity. (MTV, for example, has gone so far as to title one of its new series "Beavis and Butt-Head.")
All this puts the network standards and practices people in a lonely position: not only do the producers of entertainment shows want to push the envelope, as they always have, but the networks themselves -- the censors' own employers -- are tempted to present ever-greater amounts of naughty bits. The challenge is to slow the viewers' shift to cable without scaring off mainstream advertisers or tarnishing what's left of the networks' luster.
Just in the last few months, the networks have moved farther into once-forbidden territory. They have shown a sitcom episode celebrating masturbation (NBC's "Seinfeld"), a splash of female frontal nudity (on ABC's "Civil Wars") and a spoof of Madonna on a visit to her gynecologist (Fox's "Edge").
But perhaps the clearest sign of change at the networks came two weeks ago, when ABC took a deep breath and penciled onto its fall schedule Steven Bochco's new series, "N.Y.P.D. Blue," which chronicles the adventures -- professional and sexual -- of a New York City detective. The show, a kind of "Hill Street Blues" made more explicit for the 90's, is so raunchy that the network is considering whether to begin each episode with a parental advisory.
What's a censor to do? At standards and practices departments, which enforce the networks' fast-changing and sketchily defined rules, negotiating the shifting terrain between profitability and protocol is harder than ever. In recent interviews, the chief censors at ABC, CBS and NBC seemed to resent both the suggestion that they have relaxed their guard in response to economic pressure and the suggestion that they still sometimes act like prudes. And even as television taboos dwindle, there remain topics -- including oral sex, gay sex and abortion -- that put the censors on a collision course with producers.
" 'N.Y.P.D. Blue' has taken an extra year to get on the schedule precisely because of standards and practices difficulties," said David Milch, an executive producer of the show. "It is as inherently an adversarial process as there is."
 
The Mandate
Subjective Rules, Selectively Enforced
 Since the days when Mary Tyler Moore and Dick Van Dyke were forced to sleep in chaste twin beds, network censorship departments have been cut roughly in half, from about 60 employees to 30. One of the only reasons the departments still exist at all is that viewers, despite their taste for the lurid, continue to expect greater discretion from network television.
"Like it or not, we're held to a double standard," said Beth Bressan, head of broadcast standards and practices at CBS.
Just what this standard is, though, is an open question. For a process as inherently bureaucratic as censorship, there are surprisingly few written guidelines about what constitutes acceptable network fare. The networks' formal rules on topics like sex, profanity and nudity are worded only in the most general terms and take up just a few pages.
"It's like that Supreme Court decision on obscenity," said Christine Hikawa, head of standards and practices at ABC. "I can't describe it, but I know it when I see it."
Like graduates of a New Age sensitivity seminar, the censors of the 1990's speak about their role in soothing terms. They refer to themselves as "editors" or "facilitators" and describe their jobs mainly as running interference between producers on the one hand and affiliates and advertisers on the other.
"We look a lot to the views of our affiliates," said Ms. Bressan of CBS. "We look to our audience mail, our daily ratings, what the critics are saying, what the advertisers are saying."
Complaints from these groups get results. After advertisers groused about the incessant sexual innuendo of CBS's "Hearts Afire," for example, the producers were persuaded a few months ago to stage a wedding for the two main characters. Such a shotgun wedding probably would not have occurred if not for the show's early airtime -- 8:30 P.M. Later shows are allowed more leeway, because their audiences tend to be older. Established shows get away with more than new shows, and so do shows that attract more sophisticated, urban audiences.
As network data on audiences has grown increasingly precise, standards for shows have become increasingly customized. Probably there is no better example of this than "Seinfeld." In one recent episode, the star, Jerry Seinfeld, forgets the name of his date, who reminds him that it rhymes with a female body part.
"Mulva?" he guesses. "Dolores?"
In another episode, the main characters stage a contest over who can refrain the longest from masturbation, though the word itself is never used. ("Are you still master of your domain?" is the code phrase used.) Several advertisers dropped out of this episode, but because of the show's high ratings they were quickly replaced.
Ms. Weinman described the decision to air the episode as "a tough call." Ultimately, she assented because the "Seinfeld" audience has proved that it does not take offense easily. "Internally, there was discussion," she said. "It was a little bit questionable. There were people who said, 'You're taking a huge risk.' "
Even Larry David, the executive producer of "Seinfeld," admitted that he is surprised by the latitude the show has been allowed. "I have to say they have given us a lot of freedom," he said. "They see that we handle things tastefully," he went on, adding after a pause, "for the most part."
 
The Language
Bochco's Crusade For an R Rating
 "In the old days, you used to put in three 'bastards' to get one," recalled Dick Wolf, executive producer of NBC's "Law and Order." "You don't have to do that anymore. Unless you're really loading it on, they'll cut you some slack."
Language is one of the most obvious ways network standards have changed in recent years -- and are continuing to change. While four-letter words remain taboo, most others aren't. Roseanne, for example, tells her sitcom husband that his hockey playing "sucks." "Bastard" pops up much more frequently, as does "bitch."
Still, there are plenty of ways to alarm the networks with a few well-chosen words. Indeed, problems with potentially offensive language helped delay "N.Y.P.D. Blue" for almost a year.
When Mr. Bochco first outlined the police drama a year and a half ago, he said he wanted to do prime-time's first "R-rated" show, complete with nudity and lots of expletives. What ensued were protracted negotiations with ABC over virtually every aspect of the series. "There were endless trips to New York," said Mr. Milch, the show's executive producer. "This thing fell apart 10 different times."
Eventually, Mr. Milch said, Mr. Bochco and ABC agreed on a highly detailed -- and highly unusual -- treaty governing every foreseeable area of conflict. The agreement specifies what profanity can be used, Mr. Milch said, "and how many there would be in aggregate each episode." It outlines how much flesh can be shown and from what angle.
Although the agreement does not allow Mr. Bochco to say everything he wanted to, "we can say more than anybody thought we could," Mr. Milch said. As far as network television goes, he added, "This is a show that couldn't even have been done last year."
In announcing the new show, ABC offered a glimpse of just how far "N.Y.P.D. Blue" will go when it previewed scenes from the show for advertisers and reporters. Some of the scenes were so hot they provoked a surprised titter from the audience. In one, a man and a topless woman rolled around a bed, shifting position only at the precise moment the woman's breasts were about to come into clear view. In another, a woman stripped to her underwear and faced the camera. Words were used that cannot be printed in a family newspaper.
Introducing the scenes, Ted Harbert, the head of ABC's entertainment division, acknowledged the show's risque nature and pleaded with advertisers to "reserve any judgment." Although network officials would not talk about specifics of the show, Ms. Hikawa, head of the network's standards and practices department, allowed that there would be "a lot more street language" in it. "We're going to try to give him a lot of room," she said, referring to Mr. Bochco.
 
The Sex Scenes
When 2 Girls Kiss, The Alarm Goes Off
 Today, it is hard to find a form, style or configuration of sex that has not been explored on network television. But a few remain. Any actions that suggest oral sex, for example, are forbidden, and even verbal allusions are unlikely to make it on the air. "You cannot refer to oral sex in any way," said Marshall Herskovitz, a creator of "Thirtysomething," who learned this too late when such a mention was cut from an episode of the series.
In shows that contain explicit sex, network censors often scrutinize not just scripts but actual footage. The producers may be told to film the scene from different angles so the censors will have several shots from which to choose. Long shots might be all right, but not closeups.
The results of this sort of negotiation could be seen last month on an episode of CBS's "Picket Fences" touching on another topic guaranteed to provoke network anxiety: gay sex. In the episode, Kimberly, a teen-ager, and her best friend are discussing boys' kisses and decide to try one with each other. The scene was shot from several different angles; after long negotiations, the producers and CBS agreed to show the scene in semi-darkness. The show's creator, David E. Kelley, said he was satisfied with the episode but expressed frustration at the process, saying the network censors were acting as middlemen for affiliates and advertisers.
Mr. Wolf blames fear of advertiser reaction for some of the difficulty he had with an episode of "Law and Order" dealing with abortion. In the episode, an anti-abortion activist blows up an abortion clinic and then goes on trial.
"Virtually every word was looked at," Mr. Wolf said. For every anti-abortion remark the suspect made in the show, there had to be a pro-abortion rights statement so the show would appear completely neutral. The network was "terrified" that the show would provoke a controversy, he said, and the episode has never been re-aired.
Although network censors insist they would not prohibit a show from dealing with a particular topic simply because of advertisers' qualms, they acknowledge that keeping advertisers happy is a primary concern. This, they say, is in everyone's best interests, including the producers'. "We view our job as trying to help the producers," Ms. Weinman says. "That may sound disingenuous, but we're really trying to help them do what everyone wants to do: attract the most, offend the least."

HEADLINE: LETTER TO THE EDITOR;
Familiar Rhetoric Of Gun Control

 BODY:
I thank you for another anti-gun article ("The Battle Over Gun Control Moves to Hartford," April 11) replete with the raisin-brained rhetoric that we all know and love. I must admit, however, there has at least been some subtle changes made to the standard fare.
One of my all time "assault rifle" favorites, "no legitimate sporting purpose," has become "no legitimate civilian purpose." I suppose that means that target shooting has become a legitimate sporting purpose, but only if you are in the military. Mr. Jepsen fortunately has managed to retain the intent of the original and has even added to it. My only question is, if you are a "nobody" who shoots competitively or for recreaton, does that mean that you are not a citizen or that the gun is not an "assault weapon"? 
 The phrase "popular with gangs and drug dealers" hasn't changed much and neither have the crime statistics from the F.B.I. (less than 1 percent of all serious crime involves rifles both "assault" and "non-assault"). If New Jersey is any indication of the future in Connecticut, then gangs and drug dealers have nothing to fear. In fact, they might be able to pick up a few bargains.
I would also like to thank Ms. Leighton for pointing out that the framers of the Constitution intended an unarmed citizenry. After all, if it is illegal for a citizen to own a gun, then only the two biggest bullies, lawmakers and lawbreakers, will have them.
Though it might gratify those who detest guns to know that a gun ban may prevent people who obey the law from owning the proscribed firearms, few would suggest that such laws would return our cities to prosperity and safety.
While the Government's anti-drug laws have created a multibillion-dollar industry for itself ($13 billion Federal dollars at last count), for lawyers (both prosecution and defense), and for drug dealers (limit supply and increase the price), our cities have become war zones as battles rage over drug deals and turf.
Does anyone remember Al Capone and Prohibition? Is it any wonder the kind of role models this society creates?
While thousands remain unemployed or underemployed, our tax laws help to make it unprofitable to operate light industry in our cities and "Made in Connecticut" is replaced with "Made in China."
I suppose that if we can not ban the decline of our cities, we might just as well disarm the citizen.
 
GARY J. FOX
Salem
 
 The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Connecticut Weekly, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Building Amenities;
Testing New Routes to the Tenant's Heart

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
TO induce an outburst of lamentation from the executive bosom in Manhattan, ask where the great private dining clubs of the finer office buildings have gone.
The Pinnacle Club is no more in the Mobil Building. The Cloud Club has evaporated at the Chrysler Building. The Board Room, at 280 Park Avenue, closed last year. Downtown, the Wall Street Club at One Chase Manhattan Plaza has folded. 
 The Rockefeller Center tenant is in fair shape. For $850 a year the executive can join the Rockefeller Center Club and lunch in style on the 65th floor in space that becomes the Rainbow Room at night. At 101 Park Avenue, at East 41st Street, the executive can join Club 101 for $1,000 a year. And the collection of dining rooms on the 49th floor of Equitable Center at Seventh Avenue and 51st Street are available to tenants though the rooms are not operated as a club.
But now comes Continental Insurance, the property and casualty insurer, with a $6.5 million overhaul of large spaces within its 10-year-old headquarters building, Continental Center. The green-glass, octagonal tower is at 180 Maiden Lane, at the edge of the South Street Seaport. Continental has redone its lobby, added a fitness center, stuck in exhibition and performance spaces and opened a redesigned employee cafeteria to employees of other tenants.
It has also rebuilt its sanctum sanctorum on the 41st floor and opened it as a club for the lunching pleasure of the executives of the building. The Continental Club is expensively appointed in a quiet gray-green way, with a large dining room seating 85 plus 12 private dining rooms with East River views and tables for 4 to 20. It opened in February.
Membership in the club is limited to 400, or 12 per floor, and the annual fee for building tenants is a low $250 a person.
"This is a big step," said Bernard H. Mendik, chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York and a major office-building owner. He said he knew of no other case in which an owner was offering a private dining club for tenants as a building amenity. The usual fee at dining clubs in Manhattan is closer to $1,000 a person a year, and tenants are not likely to get discounts.
All this is part of a campaign to "reposition the asset," says Edgar A. Lampert, president of the Georgetown Company, a development company and asset manager that conceived and executed the plan for Continental. Talk of repositioning often quickens when an important tenant leaves. Last year Nomura Securities defected from Continental Center to the World Financial Center at Battery Park City. Nomura had five floors with 150,000 square feet in the million-square-foot building.
Other owners have also emphasized amenties packages as a way of attracting tenants in a soft market. A common theme seems to be to offer hotel-like services. There are new message centers. There are concierges in the lobby. There are new conference centers. There is a heightened emphasis on security services, if that can be called an amenity.
The institutional owner-occupants with grand private facilities that they can begin to share with other tenants in their building are in a particularly favorable position to supply dining services. Before Continental came along, for example, there was Chase Manhattan Bank, repositioning itself at the 1.3-million-square-foot One Chase Plaza.
The 60th floor of Chase Plaza used to be reserved for Chase executives exclusively. Now, with Chase's occupancy down to about half the building but stabilizing there, tenants can reserve tables on a per-meal basis. Chase itself operates the facility. "There wasn't much we had to do to it," said Gordon Lorig , a Chase vice president.
NOT so at Continental Center. The Georgetown Company as asset manager brought in the architectural firm of Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates and its interior-design affiliate, KPF Interior Architects. Kevin Kennon was the lead designer.
The task involved more than the club. As the lobby was originally built, a grand stairway between two escalators led to the main elevator bank at the mezzanine level. The stairway was removed, opening up the lobby to vista-like views, and new stairways were built inconspicuously to the side of the escalators. Also new to the lobby are more plantings and seating areas, a performance area with a stage and video screen and a photography exhibition area run by the International Center of Photography.
In the performance area, musicians from the Juilliard School give luncheon concerts twice a week and there are video programs from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Television and Radio and the American Museum of the Moving Image.
Storage space below the lobby level was converted into a 9,000-square-foot fitness center, open to all workers in the building.
As for the new 20,000-square-foot club on the 41st floor, it cost $1 million to build and $400,000 more to outfit and it already has its maximum of 400 members, though half of them are from Continental Insurance itself. If the club grows popular with new tenants, Continental will cut its membership, said Mr. Lampert of the Georgetown Group. Nontenants may some day be allowed club membership, he said, but not at the subsidized rate paid by tenants.
The operator of the club is Joseph Baum & Michael Whiteman Company, which also services the Rainbow Room. The firm will not only serve its little-cream, little-butter contemporary American food to patrons at the club, but will also deliver it on fine-china place settings with silver cutlery to executives at their desks. Main courses are priced at $12.50 to $18.50 and there is an $18.75 buffet.
AN economic analysis by the Georgetown Group indicates that the building's new amenities ought to provide a typical tenant with a benefit worth $3.83 a square foot a year.
The calculation is based on the needs of a typical full-floor tenant and is made up of a combination of factors: the saving on dining and fitness costs to the extent that they are subsidized by the owner; the lessened need for rented dining areas and the greater convenience of having these facilties within the building. Convenience leads to more efficient use of time and a productivity gain, Georgetown says.
And the hope is that it will help Georgetown lease out the 130,000 square feet remaining in the space Nomura gave up. Continental Center's tenants are primarily large space users. The law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Feron has five floors, and Asarco Inc. has four. Asarco renewed its lease on 110,000 square feet for 10 years two months ago.
The Georgetown Company, whose chairman is Marshall Rose, also handled the reconstruction of Madison Square Garden for Paramount Communications Inc. There the concept was to provide sky boxes and premium seats for added income from business people.
"It was a question of how the business class wants to be entertained," said Mr. Lampert.
